Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  MOBY DICK; OR THE WHALE 
Title:  
Title:  by Herman Melville
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 1
Title:  
Title:  Loomings.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Call me Ishmael.  Some years ago--never mind how long
Title:  precisely--having little or no money in my purse, and nothing
Title:  particular to interest me on shore, I thought I would sail about a
Title:  little and see the watery part of the world.  It is a way I have of
Title:  driving off the spleen and regulating the circulation.  Whenever I
Title:  find myself growing grim about the mouth; whenever it is a damp,
Title:  drizzly November in my soul; whenever I find myself involuntarily
Title:  pausing before coffin warehouses, and bringing up the rear of every
Title:  funeral I meet; and especially whenever my hypos get such an upper
Title:  hand of me, that it requires a strong moral principle to prevent me
Title:  from deliberately stepping into the street, and methodically knocking
Title:  people's hats off--then, I account it high time to get to sea as soon
Title:  as I can.  This is my substitute for pistol and ball.  With a
Title:  philosophical flourish Cato throws himself upon his sword; I quietly
Title:  take to the ship.  There is nothing surprising in this.  If they but
Title:  knew it, almost all men in their degree, some time or other, cherish
Title:  very nearly the same feelings towards the ocean with me.
Title:  
Title:  There now is your insular city of the Manhattoes, belted round by
Title:  wharves as Indian isles by coral reefs--commerce surrounds it with
Title:  her surf.  Right and left, the streets take you waterward.  Its
Title:  extreme downtown is the battery, where that noble mole is washed by
Title:  waves, and cooled by breezes, which a few hours previous were out of
Title:  sight of land.  Look at the crowds of water-gazers there.
Title:  
Title:  Circumambulate the city of a dreamy Sabbath afternoon.  Go from
Title:  Corlears Hook to Coenties Slip, and from thence, by Whitehall,
Title:  northward.  What do you see?--Posted like silent sentinels all around
Title:  the town, stand thousands upon thousands of mortal men fixed in ocean
Title:  reveries.  Some leaning against the spiles; some seated upon the
Title:  pier-heads; some looking over the bulwarks of ships from China; some
Title:  high aloft in the rigging, as if striving to get a still better
Title:  seaward peep.  But these are all landsmen; of week days pent up in
Title:  lath and plaster--tied to counters, nailed to benches, clinched to
Title:  desks.  How then is this?  Are the green fields gone?  What do they
Title:  here?
Title:  
Title:  But look! here come more crowds, pacing straight for the water, and
Title:  seemingly bound for a dive.  Strange!  Nothing will content them but
Title:  the extremest limit of the land; loitering under the shady lee of
Title:  yonder warehouses will not suffice.  No.  They must get just as nigh
Title:  the water as they possibly can without falling in.  And there they
Title:  stand--miles of them--leagues.  Inlanders all, they come from lanes
Title:  and alleys, streets and avenues--north, east, south, and west.  Yet
Title:  here they all unite.  Tell me, does the magnetic virtue of the
Title:  needles of the compasses of all those ships attract them thither?
Title:  
Title:  Once more.  Say you are in the country; in some high land of lakes.
Title:  Take almost any path you please, and ten to one it carries you down
Title:  in a dale, and leaves you there by a pool in the stream.  There is
Title:  magic in it.  Let the most absent-minded of men be plunged in his
Title:  deepest reveries--stand that man on his legs, set his feet a-going,
Title:  and he will infallibly lead you to water, if water there be in all
Title:  that region.  Should you ever be athirst in the great American
Title:  desert, try this experiment, if your caravan happen to be supplied
Title:  with a metaphysical professor.  Yes, as every one knows, meditation
Title:  and water are wedded for ever.
Title:  
Title:  But here is an artist.  He desires to paint you the dreamiest,
Title:  shadiest, quietest, most enchanting bit of romantic landscape in all
Title:  the valley of the Saco.  What is the chief element he employs?  There
Title:  stand his trees, each with a hollow trunk, as if a hermit and a
Title:  crucifix were within; and here sleeps his meadow, and there sleep his
Title:  cattle; and up from yonder cottage goes a sleepy smoke.  Deep into
Title:  distant woodlands winds a mazy way, reaching to overlapping spurs of
Title:  mountains bathed in their hill-side blue.  But though the picture
Title:  lies thus tranced, and though this pine-tree shakes down its sighs
Title:  like leaves upon this shepherd's head, yet all were vain, unless the
Title:  shepherd's eye were fixed upon the magic stream before him.  Go visit
Title:  the Prairies in June, when for scores on scores of miles you wade
Title:  knee-deep among Tiger-lilies--what is the one charm
Title:  wanting?--Water--there is not a drop of water there!  Were Niagara
Title:  but a cataract of sand, would you travel your thousand miles to see
Title:  it?  Why did the poor poet of Tennessee, upon suddenly receiving two
Title:  handfuls of silver, deliberate whether to buy him a coat, which he
Title:  sadly needed, or invest his money in a pedestrian trip to Rockaway
Title:  Beach?  Why is almost every robust healthy boy with a robust healthy
Title:  soul in him, at some time or other crazy to go to sea?  Why upon your
Title:  first voyage as a passenger, did you yourself feel such a mystical
Title:  vibration, when first told that you and your ship were now out of
Title:  sight of land?  Why did the old Persians hold the sea holy?  Why did
Title:  the Greeks give it a separate deity, and own brother of Jove?  Surely
Title:  all this is not without meaning.  And still deeper the meaning of
Title:  that story of Narcissus, who because he could not grasp the
Title:  tormenting, mild image he saw in the fountain, plunged into it and
Title:  was drowned.  But that same image, we ourselves see in all rivers and
Title:  oceans.  It is the image of the ungraspable phantom of life; and this
Title:  is the key to it all.
Title:  
Title:  Now, when I say that I am in the habit of going to sea whenever I
Title:  begin to grow hazy about the eyes, and begin to be over conscious of
Title:  my lungs, I do not mean to have it inferred that I ever go to sea as
Title:  a passenger.  For to go as a passenger you must needs have a purse,
Title:  and a purse is but a rag unless you have something in it.  Besides,
Title:  passengers get sea-sick--grow quarrelsome--don't sleep of nights--do
Title:  not enjoy themselves much, as a general thing;--no, I never go as a
Title:  passenger; nor, though I am something of a salt, do I ever go to sea
Title:  as a Commodore, or a Captain, or a Cook.  I abandon the glory and
Title:  distinction of such offices to those who like them.  For my part, I
Title:  abominate all honourable respectable toils, trials, and tribulations
Title:  of every kind whatsoever.  It is quite as much as I can do to take
Title:  care of myself, without taking care of ships, barques, brigs,
Title:  schooners, and what not.  And as for going as cook,--though I confess
Title:  there is considerable glory in that, a cook being a sort of officer
Title:  on ship-board--yet, somehow, I never fancied broiling fowls;--though
Title:  once broiled, judiciously buttered, and judgmatically salted and
Title:  peppered, there is no one who will speak more respectfully, not to
Title:  say reverentially, of a broiled fowl than I will.  It is out of the
Title:  idolatrous dotings of the old Egyptians upon broiled ibis and roasted
Title:  river horse, that you see the mummies of those creatures in their
Title:  huge bake-houses the pyramids.
Title:  
Title:  No, when I go to sea, I go as a simple sailor, right before the mast,
Title:  plumb down into the forecastle, aloft there to the royal mast-head.
Title:  True, they rather order me about some, and make me jump from spar to
Title:  spar, like a grasshopper in a May meadow.  And at first, this sort of
Title:  thing is unpleasant enough.  It touches one's sense of honour,
Title:  particularly if you come of an old established family in the land,
Title:  the Van Rensselaers, or Randolphs, or Hardicanutes.  And more than
Title:  all, if just previous to putting your hand into the tar-pot, you have
Title:  been lording it as a country schoolmaster, making the tallest boys
Title:  stand in awe of you.  The transition is a keen one, I assure you,
Title:  from a schoolmaster to a sailor, and requires a strong decoction of
Title:  Seneca and the Stoics to enable you to grin and bear it.  But even
Title:  this wears off in time.
Title:  
Title:  What of it, if some old hunks of a sea-captain orders me to get a
Title:  broom and sweep down the decks?  What does that indignity amount to,
Title:  weighed, I mean, in the scales of the New Testament?  Do you think
Title:  the archangel Gabriel thinks anything the less of me, because I
Title:  promptly and respectfully obey that old hunks in that particular
Title:  instance?  Who ain't a slave?  Tell me that.  Well, then, however the
Title:  old sea-captains may order me about--however they may thump and punch
Title:  me about, I have the satisfaction of knowing that it is all right;
Title:  that everybody else is one way or other served in much the same
Title:  way--either in a physical or metaphysical point of view, that is; and
Title:  so the universal thump is passed round, and all hands should rub each
Title:  other's shoulder-blades, and be content.
Title:  
Title:  Again, I always go to sea as a sailor, because they make a point of
Title:  paying me for my trouble, whereas they never pay passengers a single
Title:  penny that I ever heard of.  On the contrary, passengers themselves
Title:  must pay.  And there is all the difference in the world between
Title:  paying and being paid.  The act of paying is perhaps the most
Title:  uncomfortable infliction that the two orchard thieves entailed upon
Title:  us.  But BEING PAID,--what will compare with it?  The urbane activity
Title:  with which a man receives money is really marvellous, considering
Title:  that we so earnestly believe money to be the root of all earthly
Title:  ills, and that on no account can a monied man enter heaven.  Ah! how
Title:  cheerfully we consign ourselves to perdition!
Title:  
Title:  Finally, I always go to sea as a sailor, because of the wholesome
Title:  exercise and pure air of the fore-castle deck.  For as in this world,
Title:  head winds are far more prevalent than winds from astern (that is, if
Title:  you never violate the Pythagorean maxim), so for the most part the
Title:  Commodore on the quarter-deck gets his atmosphere at second hand from
Title:  the sailors on the forecastle.  He thinks he breathes it first; but
Title:  not so.  In much the same way do the commonalty lead their leaders in
Title:  many other things, at the same time that the leaders little suspect
Title:  it.  But wherefore it was that after having repeatedly smelt the sea
Title:  as a merchant sailor, I should now take it into my head to go on a
Title:  whaling voyage; this the invisible police officer of the Fates, who
Title:  has the constant surveillance of me, and secretly dogs me, and
Title:  influences me in some unaccountable way--he can better answer than
Title:  any one else.  And, doubtless, my going on this whaling voyage,
Title:  formed part of the grand programme of Providence that was drawn up a
Title:  long time ago.  It came in as a sort of brief interlude and solo
Title:  between more extensive performances.  I take it that this part of the
Title:  bill must have run something like this:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "GRAND CONTESTED ELECTION FOR THE PRESIDENCY OF THE UNITED STATES.
Title:  "WHALING VOYAGE BY ONE ISHMAEL.
Title:  "BLOODY BATTLE IN AFFGHANISTAN."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Though I cannot tell why it was exactly that those stage managers,
Title:  the Fates, put me down for this shabby part of a whaling voyage, when
Title:  others were set down for magnificent parts in high tragedies, and
Title:  short and easy parts in genteel comedies, and jolly parts in
Title:  farces--though I cannot tell why this was exactly; yet, now that I
Title:  recall all the circumstances, I think I can see a little into the
Title:  springs and motives which being cunningly presented to me under
Title:  various disguises, induced me to set about performing the part I did,
Title:  besides cajoling me into the delusion that it was a choice resulting
Title:  from my own unbiased freewill and discriminating judgment.
Title:  
Title:  Chief among these motives was the overwhelming idea of the great
Title:  whale himself.  Such a portentous and mysterious monster roused all
Title:  my curiosity.  Then the wild and distant seas where he rolled his
Title:  island bulk; the undeliverable, nameless perils of the whale; these,
Title:  with all the attending marvels of a thousand Patagonian sights and
Title:  sounds, helped to sway me to my wish.  With other men, perhaps, such
Title:  things would not have been inducements; but as for me, I am tormented
Title:  with an everlasting itch for things remote.  I love to sail forbidden
Title:  seas, and land on barbarous coasts.  Not ignoring what is good, I am
Title:  quick to perceive a horror, and could still be social with it--would
Title:  they let me--since it is but well to be on friendly terms with all
Title:  the inmates of the place one lodges in.
Title:  
Title:  By reason of these things, then, the whaling voyage was welcome; the
Title:  great flood-gates of the wonder-world swung open, and in the wild
Title:  conceits that swayed me to my purpose, two and two there floated into
Title:  my inmost soul, endless processions of the whale, and, mid most of
Title:  them all, one grand hooded phantom, like a snow hill in the air.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 2
Title:  
Title:  The Carpet-Bag.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  I stuffed a shirt or two into my old carpet-bag, tucked it under my
Title:  arm, and started for Cape Horn and the Pacific.  Quitting the good
Title:  city of old Manhatto, I duly arrived in New Bedford.  It was a
Title:  Saturday night in December.  Much was I disappointed upon learning
Title:  that the little packet for Nantucket had already sailed, and that no
Title:  way of reaching that place would offer, till the following Monday.
Title:  
Title:  As most young candidates for the pains and penalties of whaling stop
Title:  at this same New Bedford, thence to embark on their voyage, it may as
Title:  well be related that I, for one, had no idea of so doing.  For my
Title:  mind was made up to sail in no other than a Nantucket craft, because
Title:  there was a fine, boisterous something about everything connected
Title:  with that famous old island, which amazingly pleased me.  Besides
Title:  though New Bedford has of late been gradually monopolising the
Title:  business of whaling, and though in this matter poor old Nantucket is
Title:  now much behind her, yet Nantucket was her great original--the Tyre
Title:  of this Carthage;--the place where the first dead American whale was
Title:  stranded.  Where else but from Nantucket did those aboriginal
Title:  whalemen, the Red-Men, first sally out in canoes to give chase to the
Title:  Leviathan?  And where but from Nantucket, too, did that first
Title:  adventurous little sloop put forth, partly laden with imported
Title:  cobblestones--so goes the story--to throw at the whales, in order to
Title:  discover when they were nigh enough to risk a harpoon from the
Title:  bowsprit?
Title:  
Title:  Now having a night, a day, and still another night following before
Title:  me in New Bedford, ere I could embark for my destined port, it
Title:  became a matter of concernment where I was to eat and sleep
Title:  meanwhile.  It was a very dubious-looking, nay, a very dark and
Title:  dismal night, bitingly cold and cheerless.  I knew no one in the
Title:  place.  With anxious grapnels I had sounded my pocket, and only
Title:  brought up a few pieces of silver,--So, wherever you go, Ishmael,
Title:  said I to myself, as I stood in the middle of a dreary street
Title:  shouldering my bag, and comparing the gloom towards the north with
Title:  the darkness towards the south--wherever in your wisdom you may
Title:  conclude to lodge for the night, my dear Ishmael, be sure to inquire
Title:  the price, and don't be too particular.
Title:  
Title:  With halting steps I paced the streets, and passed the sign of "The
Title:  Crossed Harpoons"--but it looked too expensive and jolly there.
Title:  Further on, from the bright red windows of the "Sword-Fish Inn,"
Title:  there came such fervent rays, that it seemed to have melted the
Title:  packed snow and ice from before the house, for everywhere else the
Title:  congealed frost lay ten inches thick in a hard, asphaltic
Title:  pavement,--rather weary for me, when I struck my foot against the
Title:  flinty projections, because from hard, remorseless service the soles
Title:  of my boots were in a most miserable plight.  Too expensive and
Title:  jolly, again thought I, pausing one moment to watch the broad glare
Title:  in the street, and hear the sounds of the tinkling glasses within.
Title:  But go on, Ishmael, said I at last; don't you hear? get away from
Title:  before the door; your patched boots are stopping the way.  So on I
Title:  went.  I now by instinct followed the streets that took me waterward,
Title:  for there, doubtless, were the cheapest, if not the cheeriest inns.
Title:  
Title:  Such dreary streets! blocks of blackness, not houses, on either
Title:  hand, and here and there a candle, like a candle moving about in a
Title:  tomb.  At this hour of the night, of the last day of the week, that
Title:  quarter of the town proved all but deserted.  But presently I came to
Title:  a smoky light proceeding from a low, wide building, the door of which
Title:  stood invitingly open.  It had a careless look, as if it were meant
Title:  for the uses of the public; so, entering, the first thing I did was
Title:  to stumble over an ash-box in the porch.  Ha! thought I, ha, as the
Title:  flying particles almost choked me, are these ashes from that
Title:  destroyed city, Gomorrah?  But "The Crossed Harpoons," and "The
Title:  Sword-Fish?"--this, then must needs be the sign of "The Trap."
Title:  However, I picked myself up and hearing a loud voice within, pushed
Title:  on and opened a second, interior door.
Title:  
Title:  It seemed the great Black Parliament sitting in Tophet.  A hundred
Title:  black faces turned round in their rows to peer; and beyond, a black
Title:  Angel of Doom was beating a book in a pulpit.  It was a negro church;
Title:  and the preacher's text was about the blackness of darkness, and the
Title:  weeping and wailing and teeth-gnashing there.  Ha, Ishmael, muttered
Title:  I, backing out, Wretched entertainment at the sign of 'The Trap!'
Title:  
Title:  Moving on, I at last came to a dim sort of light not far from the
Title:  docks, and heard a forlorn creaking in the air; and looking up, saw a
Title:  swinging sign over the door with a white painting upon it, faintly
Title:  representing a tall straight jet of misty spray, and these words
Title:  underneath--"The Spouter Inn:--Peter Coffin."
Title:  
Title:  Coffin?--Spouter?--Rather ominous in that particular connexion,
Title:  thought I.  But it is a common name in Nantucket, they say, and I
Title:  suppose this Peter here is an emigrant from there.  As the light
Title:  looked so dim, and the place, for the time, looked quiet enough, and
Title:  the dilapidated little wooden house itself looked as if it might have
Title:  been carted here from the ruins of some burnt district, and as the
Title:  swinging sign had a poverty-stricken sort of creak to it, I thought
Title:  that here was the very spot for cheap lodgings, and the best of pea
Title:  coffee.
Title:  
Title:  It was a queer sort of place--a gable-ended old house, one side
Title:  palsied as it were, and leaning over sadly.  It stood on a sharp
Title:  bleak corner, where that tempestuous wind Euroclydon kept up a worse
Title:  howling than ever it did about poor Paul's tossed craft.  Euroclydon,
Title:  nevertheless, is a mighty pleasant zephyr to any one in-doors, with
Title:  his feet on the hob quietly toasting for bed.  "In judging of that
Title:  tempestuous wind called Euroclydon," says an old writer--of whose
Title:  works I possess the only copy extant--"it maketh a marvellous
Title:  difference, whether thou lookest out at it from a glass window where
Title:  the frost is all on the outside, or whether thou observest it from
Title:  that sashless window, where the frost is on both sides, and of which
Title:  the wight Death is the only glazier."  True enough, thought I, as
Title:  this passage occurred to my mind--old black-letter, thou reasonest
Title:  well.  Yes, these eyes are windows, and this body of mine is the
Title:  house.  What a pity they didn't stop up the chinks and the crannies
Title:  though, and thrust in a little lint here and there.  But it's too
Title:  late to make any improvements now.  The universe is finished; the
Title:  copestone is on, and the chips were carted off a million years ago.
Title:  Poor Lazarus there, chattering his teeth against the curbstone for
Title:  his pillow, and shaking off his tatters with his shiverings, he might
Title:  plug up both ears with rags, and put a corn-cob into his mouth, and
Title:  yet that would not keep out the tempestuous Euroclydon.  Euroclydon!
Title:  says old Dives, in his red silken wrapper--(he had a redder one
Title:  afterwards) pooh, pooh!  What a fine frosty night; how Orion
Title:  glitters; what northern lights!  Let them talk of their oriental
Title:  summer climes of everlasting conservatories; give me the privilege of
Title:  making my own summer with my own coals.
Title:  
Title:  But what thinks Lazarus?  Can he warm his blue hands by holding them
Title:  up to the grand northern lights?  Would not Lazarus rather be in
Title:  Sumatra than here?  Would he not far rather lay him down lengthwise
Title:  along the line of the equator; yea, ye gods! go down to the fiery pit
Title:  itself, in order to keep out this frost?
Title:  
Title:  Now, that Lazarus should lie stranded there on the curbstone before
Title:  the door of Dives, this is more wonderful than that an iceberg should
Title:  be moored to one of the Moluccas.  Yet Dives himself, he too lives
Title:  like a Czar in an ice palace made of frozen sighs, and being a
Title:  president of a temperance society, he only drinks the tepid tears of
Title:  orphans.
Title:  
Title:  But no more of this blubbering now, we are going a-whaling, and there
Title:  is plenty of that yet to come.  Let us scrape the ice from our
Title:  frosted feet, and see what sort of a place this "Spouter" may be.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 3
Title:  
Title:  The Spouter-Inn.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Entering that gable-ended Spouter-Inn, you found yourself in a wide,
Title:  low, straggling entry with old-fashioned wainscots, reminding one of
Title:  the bulwarks of some condemned old craft.  On one side hung a very
Title:  large oilpainting so thoroughly besmoked, and every way defaced,
Title:  that in the unequal crosslights by which you viewed it, it was only
Title:  by diligent study and a series of systematic visits to it, and
Title:  careful inquiry of the neighbors, that you could any way arrive at an
Title:  understanding of its purpose.  Such unaccountable masses of shades
Title:  and shadows, that at first you almost thought some ambitious young
Title:  artist, in the time of the New England hags, had endeavored to
Title:  delineate chaos bewitched.  But by dint of much and earnest
Title:  contemplation, and oft repeated ponderings, and especially by
Title:  throwing open the little window towards the back of the entry, you at
Title:  last come to the conclusion that such an idea, however wild, might
Title:  not be altogether unwarranted.
Title:  
Title:  But what most puzzled and confounded you was a long, limber,
Title:  portentous, black mass of something hovering in the centre of the
Title:  picture over three blue, dim, perpendicular lines floating in a
Title:  nameless yeast.  A boggy, soggy, squitchy picture truly, enough to
Title:  drive a nervous man distracted.  Yet was there a sort of indefinite,
Title:  half-attained, unimaginable sublimity about it that fairly froze you
Title:  to it, till you involuntarily took an oath with yourself to find out
Title:  what that marvellous painting meant.  Ever and anon a bright, but,
Title:  alas, deceptive idea would dart you through.--It's the Black Sea in a
Title:  midnight gale.--It's the unnatural combat of the four primal
Title:  elements.--It's a blasted heath.--It's a Hyperborean winter
Title:  scene.--It's the breaking-up of the icebound stream of Time.  But at
Title:  last all these fancies yielded to that one portentous something in
Title:  the picture's midst.  THAT once found out, and all the rest were
Title:  plain.  But stop; does it not bear a faint resemblance to a gigantic
Title:  fish? even the great leviathan himself?
Title:  
Title:  In fact, the artist's design seemed this: a final theory of my own,
Title:  partly based upon the aggregated opinions of many aged persons with
Title:  whom I conversed upon the subject.  The picture represents a
Title:  Cape-Horner in a great hurricane; the half-foundered ship weltering
Title:  there with its three dismantled masts alone visible; and an
Title:  exasperated whale, purposing to spring clean over the craft, is in
Title:  the enormous act of impaling himself upon the three mast-heads.
Title:  
Title:  The opposite wall of this entry was hung all over with a heathenish
Title:  array of monstrous clubs and spears.  Some were thickly set with
Title:  glittering teeth resembling ivory saws; others were tufted with knots
Title:  of human hair; and one was sickle-shaped, with a vast handle sweeping
Title:  round like the segment made in the new-mown grass by a long-armed
Title:  mower.  You shuddered as you gazed, and wondered what monstrous
Title:  cannibal and savage could ever have gone a death-harvesting with such
Title:  a hacking, horrifying implement.  Mixed with these were rusty old
Title:  whaling lances and harpoons all broken and deformed.  Some were
Title:  storied weapons.  With this once long lance, now wildly elbowed,
Title:  fifty years ago did Nathan Swain kill fifteen whales between a
Title:  sunrise and a sunset.  And that harpoon--so like a corkscrew now--was
Title:  flung in Javan seas, and run away with by a whale, years afterwards
Title:  slain off the Cape of Blanco.  The original iron entered nigh the
Title:  tail, and, like a restless needle sojourning in the body of a man,
Title:  travelled full forty feet, and at last was found imbedded in the
Title:  hump.
Title:  
Title:  Crossing this dusky entry, and on through yon low-arched way--cut
Title:  through what in old times must have been a great central chimney with
Title:  fireplaces all round--you enter the public room.  A still duskier
Title:  place is this, with such low ponderous beams above, and such old
Title:  wrinkled planks beneath, that you would almost fancy you trod some
Title:  old craft's cockpits, especially of such a howling night, when this
Title:  corner-anchored old ark rocked so furiously.  On one side stood a
Title:  long, low, shelf-like table covered with cracked glass cases, filled
Title:  with dusty rarities gathered from this wide world's remotest nooks.
Title:  Projecting from the further angle of the room stands a dark-looking
Title:  den--the bar--a rude attempt at a right whale's head.  Be that how it
Title:  may, there stands the vast arched bone of the whale's jaw, so wide, a
Title:  coach might almost drive beneath it.  Within are shabby shelves,
Title:  ranged round with old decanters, bottles, flasks; and in those jaws
Title:  of swift destruction, like another cursed Jonah (by which name indeed
Title:  they called him), bustles a little withered old man, who, for their
Title:  money, dearly sells the sailors deliriums and death.
Title:  
Title:  Abominable are the tumblers into which he pours his poison.  Though
Title:  true cylinders without--within, the villanous green goggling glasses
Title:  deceitfully tapered downwards to a cheating bottom.  Parallel
Title:  meridians rudely pecked into the glass, surround these footpads'
Title:  goblets.  Fill to THIS mark, and your charge is but a penny; to THIS
Title:  a penny more; and so on to the full glass--the Cape Horn measure,
Title:  which you may gulp down for a shilling.
Title:  
Title:  Upon entering the place I found a number of young seamen gathered
Title:  about a table, examining by a dim light divers specimens of
Title:  SKRIMSHANDER.  I sought the landlord, and telling him I desired to be
Title:  accommodated with a room, received for answer that his house was
Title:  full--not a bed unoccupied.  "But avast," he added, tapping his
Title:  forehead, "you haint no objections to sharing a harpooneer's blanket,
Title:  have ye?  I s'pose you are goin' a-whalin', so you'd better get used
Title:  to that sort of thing."
Title:  
Title:  I told him that I never liked to sleep two in a bed; that if I should
Title:  ever do so, it would depend upon who the harpooneer might be, and
Title:  that if he (the landlord) really had no other place for me, and the
Title:  harpooneer was not decidedly objectionable, why rather than wander
Title:  further about a strange town on so bitter a night, I would put up
Title:  with the half of any decent man's blanket.
Title:  
Title:  "I thought so.  All right; take a seat.  Supper?--you want supper?
Title:  Supper'll be ready directly."
Title:  
Title:  I sat down on an old wooden settle, carved all over like a bench on
Title:  the Battery.  At one end a ruminating tar was still further adorning
Title:  it with his jack-knife, stooping over and diligently working away at
Title:  the space between his legs.  He was trying his hand at a ship under
Title:  full sail, but he didn't make much headway, I thought.
Title:  
Title:  At last some four or five of us were summoned to our meal in an
Title:  adjoining room.  It was cold as Iceland--no fire at all--the landlord
Title:  said he couldn't afford it.  Nothing but two dismal tallow candles,
Title:  each in a winding sheet.  We were fain to button up our monkey
Title:  jackets, and hold to our lips cups of scalding tea with our half
Title:  frozen fingers.  But the fare was of the most substantial kind--not
Title:  only meat and potatoes, but dumplings; good heavens! dumplings for
Title:  supper!  One young fellow in a green box coat, addressed himself to
Title:  these dumplings in a most direful manner.
Title:  
Title:  "My boy," said the landlord, "you'll have the nightmare to a dead
Title:  sartainty."
Title:  
Title:  "Landlord," I whispered, "that aint the harpooneer is it?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, no," said he, looking a sort of diabolically funny, "the
Title:  harpooneer is a dark complexioned chap.  He never eats dumplings, he
Title:  don't--he eats nothing but steaks, and he likes 'em rare."
Title:  
Title:  "The devil he does," says I.  "Where is that harpooneer?  Is he
Title:  here?"
Title:  
Title:  "He'll be here afore long," was the answer.
Title:  
Title:  I could not help it, but I began to feel suspicious of this "dark
Title:  complexioned" harpooneer.  At any rate, I made up my mind that if it
Title:  so turned out that we should sleep together, he must undress and get
Title:  into bed before I did.
Title:  
Title:  Supper over, the company went back to the bar-room, when, knowing not
Title:  what else to do with myself, I resolved to spend the rest of the
Title:  evening as a looker on.
Title:  
Title:  Presently a rioting noise was heard without.  Starting up, the
Title:  landlord cried, "That's the Grampus's crew.  I seed her reported in
Title:  the offing this morning; a three years' voyage, and a full ship.
Title:  Hurrah, boys; now we'll have the latest news from the Feegees."
Title:  
Title:  A tramping of sea boots was heard in the entry; the door was flung
Title:  open, and in rolled a wild set of mariners enough.  Enveloped in
Title:  their shaggy watch coats, and with their heads muffled in woollen
Title:  comforters, all bedarned and ragged, and their beards stiff with
Title:  icicles, they seemed an eruption of bears from Labrador.  They had
Title:  just landed from their boat, and this was the first house they
Title:  entered.  No wonder, then, that they made a straight wake for the
Title:  whale's mouth--the bar--when the wrinkled little old Jonah, there
Title:  officiating, soon poured them out brimmers all round.  One complained
Title:  of a bad cold in his head, upon which Jonah mixed him a pitch-like
Title:  potion of gin and molasses, which he swore was a sovereign cure for
Title:  all colds and catarrhs whatsoever, never mind of how long standing,
Title:  or whether caught off the coast of Labrador, or on the weather side
Title:  of an ice-island.
Title:  
Title:  The liquor soon mounted into their heads, as it generally does even
Title:  with the arrantest topers newly landed from sea, and they began
Title:  capering about most obstreperously.
Title:  
Title:  I observed, however, that one of them held somewhat aloof, and though
Title:  he seemed desirous not to spoil the hilarity of his shipmates by his
Title:  own sober face, yet upon the whole he refrained from making as much
Title:  noise as the rest.  This man interested me at once; and since the
Title:  sea-gods had ordained that he should soon become my shipmate (though
Title:  but a sleeping-partner one, so far as this narrative is concerned),
Title:  I will here venture upon a little description of him.  He stood full
Title:  six feet in height, with noble shoulders, and a chest like a
Title:  coffer-dam.  I have seldom seen such brawn in a man.  His face was
Title:  deeply brown and burnt, making his white teeth dazzling by the
Title:  contrast; while in the deep shadows of his eyes floated some
Title:  reminiscences that did not seem to give him much joy.  His voice at
Title:  once announced that he was a Southerner, and from his fine stature, I
Title:  thought he must be one of those tall mountaineers from the
Title:  Alleghanian Ridge in Virginia.  When the revelry of his companions
Title:  had mounted to its height, this man slipped away unobserved, and I
Title:  saw no more of him till he became my comrade on the sea.  In a few
Title:  minutes, however, he was missed by his shipmates, and being, it
Title:  seems, for some reason a huge favourite with them, they raised a cry
Title:  of "Bulkington!  Bulkington! where's Bulkington?" and darted out of
Title:  the house in pursuit of him.
Title:  
Title:  It was now about nine o'clock, and the room seeming almost
Title:  supernaturally quiet after these orgies, I began to congratulate
Title:  myself upon a little plan that had occurred to me just previous to
Title:  the entrance of the seamen.
Title:  
Title:  No man prefers to sleep two in a bed.  In fact, you would a good deal
Title:  rather not sleep with your own brother.  I don't know how it is, but
Title:  people like to be private when they are sleeping.  And when it comes
Title:  to sleeping with an unknown stranger, in a strange inn, in a strange
Title:  town, and that stranger a harpooneer, then your objections
Title:  indefinitely multiply.  Nor was there any earthly reason why I as a
Title:  sailor should sleep two in a bed, more than anybody else; for sailors
Title:  no more sleep two in a bed at sea, than bachelor Kings do ashore.  To
Title:  be sure they all sleep together in one apartment, but you have your
Title:  own hammock, and cover yourself with your own blanket, and sleep in
Title:  your own skin.
Title:  
Title:  The more I pondered over this harpooneer, the more I abominated the
Title:  thought of sleeping with him.  It was fair to presume that being a
Title:  harpooneer, his linen or woollen, as the case might be, would not be
Title:  of the tidiest, certainly none of the finest.  I began to twitch all
Title:  over.  Besides, it was getting late, and my decent harpooneer ought
Title:  to be home and going bedwards.  Suppose now, he should tumble in upon
Title:  me at midnight--how could I tell from what vile hole he had been
Title:  coming?
Title:  
Title:  "Landlord!  I've changed my mind about that harpooneer.--I shan't
Title:  sleep with him.  I'll try the bench here."
Title:  
Title:  "Just as you please; I'm sorry I cant spare ye a tablecloth for a
Title:  mattress, and it's a plaguy rough board here"--feeling of the knots
Title:  and notches.  "But wait a bit, Skrimshander; I've got a carpenter's
Title:  plane there in the bar--wait, I say, and I'll make ye snug enough."
Title:  So saying he procured the plane; and with his old silk handkerchief
Title:  first dusting the bench, vigorously set to planing away at my bed,
Title:  the while grinning like an ape.  The shavings flew right and left;
Title:  till at last the plane-iron came bump against an indestructible knot.
Title:  The landlord was near spraining his wrist, and I told him for
Title:  heaven's sake to quit--the bed was soft enough to suit me, and I did
Title:  not know how all the planing in the world could make eider down of a
Title:  pine plank.  So gathering up the shavings with another grin, and
Title:  throwing them into the great stove in the middle of the room, he went
Title:  about his business, and left me in a brown study.
Title:  
Title:  I now took the measure of the bench, and found that it was a foot too
Title:  short; but that could be mended with a chair.  But it was a foot too
Title:  narrow, and the other bench in the room was about four inches higher
Title:  than the planed one--so there was no yoking them.  I then placed the
Title:  first bench lengthwise along the only clear space against the wall,
Title:  leaving a little interval between, for my back to settle down in.
Title:  But I soon found that there came such a draught of cold air over me
Title:  from under the sill of the window, that this plan would never do at
Title:  all, especially as another current from the rickety door met the one
Title:  from the window, and both together formed a series of small
Title:  whirlwinds in the immediate vicinity of the spot where I had thought
Title:  to spend the night.
Title:  
Title:  The devil fetch that harpooneer, thought I, but stop, couldn't I
Title:  steal a march on him--bolt his door inside, and jump into his bed,
Title:  not to be wakened by the most violent knockings?  It seemed no bad
Title:  idea; but upon second thoughts I dismissed it.  For who could tell
Title:  but what the next morning, so soon as I popped out of the room, the
Title:  harpooneer might be standing in the entry, all ready to knock me
Title:  down!
Title:  
Title:  Still, looking round me again, and seeing no possible chance of
Title:  spending a sufferable night unless in some other person's bed, I
Title:  began to think that after all I might be cherishing unwarrantable
Title:  prejudices against this unknown harpooneer.  Thinks I, I'll wait
Title:  awhile; he must be dropping in before long.  I'll have a good look at
Title:  him then, and perhaps we may become jolly good bedfellows after
Title:  all--there's no telling.
Title:  
Title:  But though the other boarders kept coming in by ones, twos, and
Title:  threes, and going to bed, yet no sign of my harpooneer.
Title:  
Title:  "Landlord! said I, "what sort of a chap is he--does he always keep
Title:  such late hours?"  It was now hard upon twelve o'clock.
Title:  
Title:  The landlord chuckled again with his lean chuckle, and seemed to be
Title:  mightily tickled at something beyond my comprehension.  "No," he
Title:  answered, "generally he's an early bird--airley to bed and airley to
Title:  rise--yes, he's the bird what catches the worm.  But to-night he
Title:  went out a peddling, you see, and I don't see what on airth keeps him
Title:  so late, unless, may be, he can't sell his head."
Title:  
Title:  "Can't sell his head?--What sort of a bamboozingly story is this you
Title:  are telling me?" getting into a towering rage.  "Do you pretend to
Title:  say, landlord, that this harpooneer is actually engaged this blessed
Title:  Saturday night, or rather Sunday morning, in peddling his head around
Title:  this town?"
Title:  
Title:  "That's precisely it," said the landlord, "and I told him he couldn't
Title:  sell it here, the market's overstocked."
Title:  
Title:  "With what?" shouted I.
Title:  
Title:  "With heads to be sure; ain't there too many heads in the world?"
Title:  
Title:  "I tell you what it is, landlord," said I quite calmly, "you'd better
Title:  stop spinning that yarn to me--I'm not green."
Title:  
Title:  "May be not," taking out a stick and whittling a toothpick, "but I
Title:  rayther guess you'll be done BROWN if that ere harpooneer hears you a
Title:  slanderin' his head."
Title:  
Title:  "I'll break it for him," said I, now flying into a passion again at
Title:  this unaccountable farrago of the landlord's.
Title:  
Title:  "It's broke a'ready," said he.
Title:  
Title:  "Broke," said I--"BROKE, do you mean?"
Title:  
Title:  "Sartain, and that's the very reason he can't sell it, I guess."
Title:  
Title:  "Landlord," said I, going up to him as cool as Mt. Hecla in a
Title:  snow-storm--"landlord, stop whittling.  You and I must understand one
Title:  another, and that too without delay.  I come to your house and want a
Title:  bed; you tell me you can only give me half a one; that the other half
Title:  belongs to a certain harpooneer.  And about this harpooneer, whom I
Title:  have not yet seen, you persist in telling me the most mystifying and
Title:  exasperating stories tending to beget in me an uncomfortable feeling
Title:  towards the man whom you design for my bedfellow--a sort of
Title:  connexion, landlord, which is an intimate and confidential one in the
Title:  highest degree.  I now demand of you to speak out and tell me who and
Title:  what this harpooneer is, and whether I shall be in all respects safe
Title:  to spend the night with him.  And in the first place, you will be so
Title:  good as to unsay that story about selling his head, which if true I
Title:  take to be good evidence that this harpooneer is stark mad, and I've
Title:  no idea of sleeping with a madman; and you, sir, YOU I mean,
Title:  landlord, YOU, sir, by trying to induce me to do so knowingly, would
Title:  thereby render yourself liable to a criminal prosecution."
Title:  
Title:  "Wall," said the landlord, fetching a long breath, "that's a purty
Title:  long sarmon for a chap that rips a little now and then.  But be easy,
Title:  be easy, this here harpooneer I have been tellin' you of has just
Title:  arrived from the south seas, where he bought up a lot of 'balmed New
Title:  Zealand heads (great curios, you know), and he's sold all on 'em but
Title:  one, and that one he's trying to sell to-night, cause to-morrow's
Title:  Sunday, and it would not do to be sellin' human heads about the
Title:  streets when folks is goin' to churches.  He wanted to, last Sunday,
Title:  but I stopped him just as he was goin' out of the door with four
Title:  heads strung on a string, for all the airth like a string of inions."
Title:  
Title:  This account cleared up the otherwise unaccountable mystery, and
Title:  showed that the landlord, after all, had had no idea of fooling
Title:  me--but at the same time what could I think of a harpooneer who
Title:  stayed out of a Saturday night clean into the holy Sabbath, engaged
Title:  in such a cannibal business as selling the heads of dead idolators?
Title:  
Title:  "Depend upon it, landlord, that harpooneer is a dangerous man."
Title:  
Title:  "He pays reg'lar," was the rejoinder.  "But come, it's getting
Title:  dreadful late, you had better be turning flukes--it's a nice bed;
Title:  Sal and me slept in that ere bed the night we were spliced.  There's
Title:  plenty of room for two to kick about in that bed; it's an almighty
Title:  big bed that.  Why, afore we give it up, Sal used to put our Sam and
Title:  little Johnny in the foot of it.  But I got a dreaming and sprawling
Title:  about one night, and somehow, Sam got pitched on the floor, and came
Title:  near breaking his arm.  Arter that, Sal said it wouldn't do.  Come
Title:  along here, I'll give ye a glim in a jiffy;" and so saying he lighted
Title:  a candle and held it towards me, offering to lead the way.  But I
Title:  stood irresolute; when looking at a clock in the corner, he exclaimed
Title:  "I vum it's Sunday--you won't see that harpooneer to-night; he's come
Title:  to anchor somewhere--come along then; DO come; WON'T ye come?"
Title:  
Title:  I considered the matter a moment, and then up stairs we went, and I
Title:  was ushered into a small room, cold as a clam, and furnished, sure
Title:  enough, with a prodigious bed, almost big enough indeed for any four
Title:  harpooneers to sleep abreast.
Title:  
Title:  "There," said the landlord, placing the candle on a crazy old sea
Title:  chest that did double duty as a wash-stand and centre table; "there,
Title:  make yourself comfortable now, and good night to ye."  I turned
Title:  round from eyeing the bed, but he had disappeared.
Title:  
Title:  Folding back the counterpane, I stooped over the bed.  Though none of
Title:  the most elegant, it yet stood the scrutiny tolerably well.  I then
Title:  glanced round the room; and besides the bedstead and centre table,
Title:  could see no other furniture belonging to the place, but a rude
Title:  shelf, the four walls, and a papered fireboard representing a man
Title:  striking a whale.  Of things not properly belonging to the room,
Title:  there was a hammock lashed up, and thrown upon the floor in one
Title:  corner; also a large seaman's bag, containing the harpooneer's
Title:  wardrobe, no doubt in lieu of a land trunk.  Likewise, there was a
Title:  parcel of outlandish bone fish hooks on the shelf over the
Title:  fire-place, and a tall harpoon standing at the head of the bed.
Title:  
Title:  But what is this on the chest?  I took it up, and held it close to
Title:  the light, and felt it, and smelt it, and tried every way possible to
Title:  arrive at some satisfactory conclusion concerning it.  I can compare
Title:  it to nothing but a large door mat, ornamented at the edges with
Title:  little tinkling tags something like the stained porcupine quills
Title:  round an Indian moccasin.  There was a hole or slit in the middle of
Title:  this mat, as you see the same in South American ponchos.  But could
Title:  it be possible that any sober harpooneer would get into a door mat,
Title:  and parade the streets of any Christian town in that sort of guise?
Title:  I put it on, to try it, and it weighed me down like a hamper, being
Title:  uncommonly shaggy and thick, and I thought a little damp, as though
Title:  this mysterious harpooneer had been wearing it of a rainy day.  I
Title:  went up in it to a bit of glass stuck against the wall, and I never
Title:  saw such a sight in my life.  I tore myself out of it in such a hurry
Title:  that I gave myself a kink in the neck.
Title:  
Title:  I sat down on the side of the bed, and commenced thinking about this
Title:  head-peddling harpooneer, and his door mat.  After thinking some time
Title:  on the bed-side, I got up and took off my monkey jacket, and then
Title:  stood in the middle of the room thinking.  I then took off my coat,
Title:  and thought a little more in my shirt sleeves.  But beginning to feel
Title:  very cold now, half undressed as I was, and remembering what the
Title:  landlord said about the harpooneer's not coming home at all that
Title:  night, it being so very late, I made no more ado, but jumped out of
Title:  my pantaloons and boots, and then blowing out the light tumbled into
Title:  bed, and commended myself to the care of heaven.
Title:  
Title:  Whether that mattress was stuffed with corn-cobs or broken crockery,
Title:  there is no telling, but I rolled about a good deal, and could not
Title:  sleep for a long time.  At last I slid off into a light doze, and had
Title:  pretty nearly made a good offing towards the land of Nod, when I
Title:  heard a heavy footfall in the passage, and saw a glimmer of light
Title:  come into the room from under the door.
Title:  
Title:  Lord save me, thinks I, that must be the harpooneer, the infernal
Title:  head-peddler.  But I lay perfectly still, and resolved not to say a
Title:  word till spoken to.  Holding a light in one hand, and that identical
Title:  New Zealand head in the other, the stranger entered the room, and
Title:  without looking towards the bed, placed his candle a good way off
Title:  from me on the floor in one corner, and then began working away at
Title:  the knotted cords of the large bag I before spoke of as being in the
Title:  room.  I was all eagerness to see his face, but he kept it averted
Title:  for some time while employed in unlacing the bag's mouth.  This
Title:  accomplished, however, he turned round--when, good heavens! what a
Title:  sight!  Such a face!  It was of a dark, purplish, yellow colour, here
Title:  and there stuck over with large blackish looking squares.  Yes, it's
Title:  just as I thought, he's a terrible bedfellow; he's been in a fight,
Title:  got dreadfully cut, and here he is, just from the surgeon.  But at
Title:  that moment he chanced to turn his face so towards the light, that I
Title:  plainly saw they could not be sticking-plasters at all, those black
Title:  squares on his cheeks.  They were stains of some sort or other.  At
Title:  first I knew not what to make of this; but soon an inkling of the
Title:  truth occurred to me.  I remembered a story of a white man--a
Title:  whaleman too--who, falling among the cannibals, had been tattooed by
Title:  them.  I concluded that this harpooneer, in the course of his distant
Title:  voyages, must have met with a similar adventure.  And what is it,
Title:  thought I, after all!  It's only his outside; a man can be honest in
Title:  any sort of skin.  But then, what to make of his unearthly
Title:  complexion, that part of it, I mean, lying round about, and
Title:  completely independent of the squares of tattooing.  To be sure, it
Title:  might be nothing but a good coat of tropical tanning; but I never
Title:  heard of a hot sun's tanning a white man into a purplish yellow one.
Title:  However, I had never been in the South Seas; and perhaps the sun
Title:  there produced these extraordinary effects upon the skin.  Now, while
Title:  all these ideas were passing through me like lightning, this
Title:  harpooneer never noticed me at all.  But, after some difficulty
Title:  having opened his bag, he commenced fumbling in it, and presently
Title:  pulled out a sort of tomahawk, and a seal-skin wallet with the hair
Title:  on.  Placing these on the old chest in the middle of the room, he
Title:  then took the New Zealand head--a ghastly thing enough--and crammed
Title:  it down into the bag.  He now took off his hat--a new beaver
Title:  hat--when I came nigh singing out with fresh surprise.  There was no
Title:  hair on his head--none to speak of at least--nothing but a small
Title:  scalp-knot twisted up on his forehead.  His bald purplish head now
Title:  looked for all the world like a mildewed skull.  Had not the stranger
Title:  stood between me and the door, I would have bolted out of it quicker
Title:  than ever I bolted a dinner.
Title:  
Title:  Even as it was, I thought something of slipping out of the window,
Title:  but it was the second floor back.  I am no coward, but what to make
Title:  of this head-peddling purple rascal altogether passed my
Title:  comprehension.  Ignorance is the parent of fear, and being completely
Title:  nonplussed and confounded about the stranger, I confess I was now as
Title:  much afraid of him as if it was the devil himself who had thus broken
Title:  into my room at the dead of night.  In fact, I was so afraid of him
Title:  that I was not game enough just then to address him, and demand a
Title:  satisfactory answer concerning what seemed inexplicable in him.
Title:  
Title:  Meanwhile, he continued the business of undressing, and at last
Title:  showed his chest and arms.  As I live, these covered parts of him
Title:  were checkered with the same squares as his face; his back, too, was
Title:  all over the same dark squares; he seemed to have been in a Thirty
Title:  Years' War, and just escaped from it with a sticking-plaster shirt.
Title:  Still more, his very legs were marked, as if a parcel of dark green
Title:  frogs were running up the trunks of young palms.  It was now quite
Title:  plain that he must be some abominable savage or other shipped aboard
Title:  of a whaleman in the South Seas, and so landed in this Christian
Title:  country.  I quaked to think of it.  A peddler of heads too--perhaps
Title:  the heads of his own brothers.  He might take a fancy to
Title:  mine--heavens! look at that tomahawk!
Title:  
Title:  But there was no time for shuddering, for now the savage went about
Title:  something that completely fascinated my attention, and convinced me
Title:  that he must indeed be a heathen.  Going to his heavy grego, or
Title:  wrapall, or dreadnaught, which he had previously hung on a chair, he
Title:  fumbled in the pockets, and produced at length a curious little
Title:  deformed image with a hunch on its back, and exactly the colour of a
Title:  three days' old Congo baby.  Remembering the embalmed head, at first
Title:  I almost thought that this black manikin was a real baby preserved
Title:  in some similar manner.  But seeing that it was not at all limber,
Title:  and that it glistened a good deal like polished ebony, I concluded
Title:  that it must be nothing but a wooden idol, which indeed it proved to
Title:  be.  For now the savage goes up to the empty fire-place, and removing
Title:  the papered fire-board, sets up this little hunch-backed image, like
Title:  a tenpin, between the andirons.  The chimney jambs and all the bricks
Title:  inside were very sooty, so that I thought this fire-place made a very
Title:  appropriate little shrine or chapel for his Congo idol.
Title:  
Title:  I now screwed my eyes hard towards the half hidden image, feeling but
Title:  ill at ease meantime--to see what was next to follow.  First he takes
Title:  about a double handful of shavings out of his grego pocket, and
Title:  places them carefully before the idol; then laying a bit of ship
Title:  biscuit on top and applying the flame from the lamp, he kindled the
Title:  shavings into a sacrificial blaze.  Presently, after many hasty
Title:  snatches into the fire, and still hastier withdrawals of his fingers
Title:  (whereby he seemed to be scorching them badly), he at last succeeded
Title:  in drawing out the biscuit; then blowing off the heat and ashes a
Title:  little, he made a polite offer of it to the little negro.  But the
Title:  little devil did not seem to fancy such dry sort of fare at all; he
Title:  never moved his lips.  All these strange antics were accompanied by
Title:  still stranger guttural noises from the devotee, who seemed to be
Title:  praying in a sing-song or else singing some pagan psalmody or other,
Title:  during which his face twitched about in the most unnatural manner.
Title:  At last extinguishing the fire, he took the idol up very
Title:  unceremoniously, and bagged it again in his grego pocket as
Title:  carelessly as if he were a sportsman bagging a dead woodcock.
Title:  
Title:  All these queer proceedings increased my uncomfortableness, and
Title:  seeing him now exhibiting strong symptoms of concluding his business
Title:  operations, and jumping into bed with me, I thought it was high time,
Title:  now or never, before the light was put out, to break the spell in
Title:  which I had so long been bound.
Title:  
Title:  But the interval I spent in deliberating what to say, was a fatal
Title:  one.  Taking up his tomahawk from the table, he examined the head of
Title:  it for an instant, and then holding it to the light, with his mouth
Title:  at the handle, he puffed out great clouds of tobacco smoke.  The next
Title:  moment the light was extinguished, and this wild cannibal, tomahawk
Title:  between his teeth, sprang into bed with me.  I sang out, I could not
Title:  help it now; and giving a sudden grunt of astonishment he began
Title:  feeling me.
Title:  
Title:  Stammering out something, I knew not what, I rolled away from him
Title:  against the wall, and then conjured him, whoever or whatever he might
Title:  be, to keep quiet, and let me get up and light the lamp again.  But
Title:  his guttural responses satisfied me at once that he but ill
Title:  comprehended my meaning.
Title:  
Title:  "Who-e debel you?"--he at last said--"you no speak-e, dam-me, I
Title:  kill-e."  And so saying the lighted tomahawk began flourishing about
Title:  me in the dark.
Title:  
Title:  "Landlord, for God's sake, Peter Coffin!" shouted I.  "Landlord!
Title:  Watch!  Coffin!  Angels! save me!"
Title:  
Title:  "Speak-e! tell-ee me who-ee be, or dam-me, I kill-e!" again growled
Title:  the cannibal, while his horrid flourishings of the tomahawk scattered
Title:  the hot tobacco ashes about me till I thought my linen would get on
Title:  fire.  But thank heaven, at that moment the landlord came into the
Title:  room light in hand, and leaping from the bed I ran up to him.
Title:  
Title:  "Don't be afraid now," said he, grinning again, "Queequeg here
Title:  wouldn't harm a hair of your head."
Title:  
Title:  "Stop your grinning," shouted I, "and why didn't you tell me that
Title:  that infernal harpooneer was a cannibal?"
Title:  
Title:  "I thought ye know'd it;--didn't I tell ye, he was a peddlin' heads
Title:  around town?--but turn flukes again and go to sleep.  Queequeg, look
Title:  here--you sabbee me, I sabbee--you this man sleepe you--you sabbee?"
Title:  
Title:  "Me sabbee plenty"--grunted Queequeg, puffing away at his pipe and
Title:  sitting up in bed.
Title:  
Title:  "You gettee in," he added, motioning to me with his tomahawk, and
Title:  throwing the clothes to one side.  He really did this in not only a
Title:  civil but a really kind and charitable way.  I stood looking at him a
Title:  moment.  For all his tattooings he was on the whole a clean, comely
Title:  looking cannibal.  What's all this fuss I have been making about,
Title:  thought I to myself--the man's a human being just as I am: he has
Title:  just as much reason to fear me, as I have to be afraid of him.
Title:  Better sleep with a sober cannibal than a drunken Christian.
Title:  
Title:  "Landlord," said I, "tell him to stash his tomahawk there, or pipe,
Title:  or whatever you call it; tell him to stop smoking, in short, and I
Title:  will turn in with him.  But I don't fancy having a man smoking in bed
Title:  with me.  It's dangerous.  Besides, I ain't insured."
Title:  
Title:  This being told to Queequeg, he at once complied, and again politely
Title:  motioned me to get into bed--rolling over to one side as much as to
Title:  say--I won't touch a leg of ye."
Title:  
Title:  "Good night, landlord," said I, "you may go."
Title:  
Title:  I turned in, and never slept better in my life.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 4
Title:  
Title:  The Counterpane.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Upon waking next morning about daylight, I found Queequeg's arm
Title:  thrown over me in the most loving and affectionate manner.  You had
Title:  almost thought I had been his wife.  The counterpane was of
Title:  patchwork, full of odd little parti-coloured squares and triangles;
Title:  and this arm of his tattooed all over with an interminable Cretan
Title:  labyrinth of a figure, no two parts of which were of one precise
Title:  shade--owing I suppose to his keeping his arm at sea unmethodically
Title:  in sun and shade, his shirt sleeves irregularly rolled up at various
Title:  times--this same arm of his, I say, looked for all the world like a
Title:  strip of that same patchwork quilt.  Indeed, partly lying on it as
Title:  the arm did when I first awoke, I could hardly tell it from the
Title:  quilt, they so blended their hues together; and it was only by the
Title:  sense of weight and pressure that I could tell that Queequeg was
Title:  hugging me.
Title:  
Title:  My sensations were strange.  Let me try to explain them.  When I was
Title:  a child, I well remember a somewhat similar circumstance that befell
Title:  me; whether it was a reality or a dream, I never could entirely
Title:  settle.  The circumstance was this.  I had been cutting up some caper
Title:  or other--I think it was trying to crawl up the chimney, as I had
Title:  seen a little sweep do a few days previous; and my stepmother who,
Title:  somehow or other, was all the time whipping me, or sending me to bed
Title:  supperless,--my mother dragged me by the legs out of the chimney and
Title:  packed me off to bed, though it was only two o'clock in the afternoon
Title:  of the 21st June, the longest day in the year in our hemisphere.  I
Title:  felt dreadfully.  But there was no help for it, so up stairs I went
Title:  to my little room in the third floor, undressed myself as slowly as
Title:  possible so as to kill time, and with a bitter sigh got between the
Title:  sheets.
Title:  
Title:  I lay there dismally calculating that sixteen entire hours must
Title:  elapse before I could hope for a resurrection.  Sixteen hours in bed!
Title:  the small of my back ached to think of it.  And it was so light too;
Title:  the sun shining in at the window, and a great rattling of coaches in
Title:  the streets, and the sound of gay voices all over the house.  I felt
Title:  worse and worse--at last I got up, dressed, and softly going down in
Title:  my stockinged feet, sought out my stepmother, and suddenly threw
Title:  myself at her feet, beseeching her as a particular favour to give me a
Title:  good slippering for my misbehaviour; anything indeed but condemning
Title:  me to lie abed such an unendurable length of time.  But she was the
Title:  best and most conscientious of stepmothers, and back I had to go to
Title:  my room.  For several hours I lay there broad awake, feeling a great
Title:  deal worse than I have ever done since, even from the greatest
Title:  subsequent misfortunes.  At last I must have fallen into a troubled
Title:  nightmare of a doze; and slowly waking from it--half steeped in
Title:  dreams--I opened my eyes, and the before sun-lit room was now wrapped
Title:  in outer darkness.  Instantly I felt a shock running through all my
Title:  frame; nothing was to be seen, and nothing was to be heard; but a
Title:  supernatural hand seemed placed in mine.  My arm hung over the
Title:  counterpane, and the nameless, unimaginable, silent form or phantom,
Title:  to which the hand belonged, seemed closely seated by my bed-side.
Title:  For what seemed ages piled on ages, I lay there, frozen with the most
Title:  awful fears, not daring to drag away my hand; yet ever thinking that
Title:  if I could but stir it one single inch, the horrid spell would be
Title:  broken.  I knew not how this consciousness at last glided away from
Title:  me; but waking in the morning, I shudderingly remembered it all, and
Title:  for days and weeks and months afterwards I lost myself in confounding
Title:  attempts to explain the mystery.  Nay, to this very hour, I often
Title:  puzzle myself with it.
Title:  
Title:  Now, take away the awful fear, and my sensations at feeling the
Title:  supernatural hand in mine were very similar, in their strangeness,
Title:  to those which I experienced on waking up and seeing Queequeg's pagan
Title:  arm thrown round me.  But at length all the past night's events
Title:  soberly recurred, one by one, in fixed reality, and then I lay only
Title:  alive to the comical predicament.  For though I tried to move his
Title:  arm--unlock his bridegroom clasp--yet, sleeping as he was, he still
Title:  hugged me tightly, as though naught but death should part us twain.
Title:  I now strove to rouse him--"Queequeg!"--but his only answer was a
Title:  snore.  I then rolled over, my neck feeling as if it were in a
Title:  horse-collar; and suddenly felt a slight scratch.  Throwing aside the
Title:  counterpane, there lay the tomahawk sleeping by the savage's side, as
Title:  if it were a hatchet-faced baby.  A pretty pickle, truly, thought I;
Title:  abed here in a strange house in the broad day, with a cannibal and a
Title:  tomahawk!  "Queequeg!--in the name of goodness, Queequeg, wake!"  At
Title:  length, by dint of much wriggling, and loud and incessant
Title:  expostulations upon the unbecomingness of his hugging a fellow male
Title:  in that matrimonial sort of style, I succeeded in extracting a grunt;
Title:  and presently, he drew back his arm, shook himself all over like a
Title:  Newfoundland dog just from the water, and sat up in bed, stiff as a
Title:  pike-staff, looking at me, and rubbing his eyes as if he did not
Title:  altogether remember how I came to be there, though a dim
Title:  consciousness of knowing something about me seemed slowly dawning
Title:  over him.  Meanwhile, I lay quietly eyeing him, having no serious
Title:  misgivings now, and bent upon narrowly observing so curious a
Title:  creature.  When, at last, his mind seemed made up touching the
Title:  character of his bedfellow, and he became, as it were, reconciled to
Title:  the fact; he jumped out upon the floor, and by certain signs and
Title:  sounds gave me to understand that, if it pleased me, he would dress
Title:  first and then leave me to dress afterwards, leaving the whole
Title:  apartment to myself.  Thinks I, Queequeg, under the circumstances,
Title:  this is a very civilized overture; but, the truth is, these savages
Title:  have an innate sense of delicacy, say what you will; it is marvellous
Title:  how essentially polite they are.  I pay this particular compliment to
Title:  Queequeg, because he treated me with so much civility and
Title:  consideration, while I was guilty of great rudeness; staring at him
Title:  from the bed, and watching all his toilette motions; for the time my
Title:  curiosity getting the better of my breeding.  Nevertheless, a man
Title:  like Queequeg you don't see every day, he and his ways were well
Title:  worth unusual regarding.
Title:  
Title:  He commenced dressing at top by donning his beaver hat, a very tall
Title:  one, by the by, and then--still minus his trowsers--he hunted up his
Title:  boots.  What under the heavens he did it for, I cannot tell, but his
Title:  next movement was to crush himself--boots in hand, and hat on--under
Title:  the bed; when, from sundry violent gaspings and strainings, I
Title:  inferred he was hard at work booting himself; though by no law of
Title:  propriety that I ever heard of, is any man required to be private
Title:  when putting on his boots.  But Queequeg, do you see, was a creature
Title:  in the transition stage--neither caterpillar nor butterfly.  He was
Title:  just enough civilized to show off his outlandishness in the strangest
Title:  possible manners.  His education was not yet completed.  He was an
Title:  undergraduate.  If he had not been a small degree civilized, he very
Title:  probably would not have troubled himself with boots at all; but then,
Title:  if he had not been still a savage, he never would have dreamt of
Title:  getting under the bed to put them on.  At last, he emerged with his
Title:  hat very much dented and crushed down over his eyes, and began
Title:  creaking and limping about the room, as if, not being much accustomed
Title:  to boots, his pair of damp, wrinkled cowhide ones--probably not made
Title:  to order either--rather pinched and tormented him at the first go off
Title:  of a bitter cold morning.
Title:  
Title:  Seeing, now, that there were no curtains to the window, and that the
Title:  street being very narrow, the house opposite commanded a plain view
Title:  into the room, and observing more and more the indecorous figure that
Title:  Queequeg made, staving about with little else but his hat and boots
Title:  on; I begged him as well as I could, to accelerate his toilet
Title:  somewhat, and particularly to get into his pantaloons as soon as
Title:  possible.  He complied, and then proceeded to wash himself.  At that
Title:  time in the morning any Christian would have washed his face; but
Title:  Queequeg, to my amazement, contented himself with restricting his
Title:  ablutions to his chest, arms, and hands.  He then donned his
Title:  waistcoat, and taking up a piece of hard soap on the wash-stand
Title:  centre table, dipped it into water and commenced lathering his face.
Title:  I was watching to see where he kept his razor, when lo and behold, he
Title:  takes the harpoon from the bed corner, slips out the long wooden
Title:  stock, unsheathes the head, whets it a little on his boot, and
Title:  striding up to the bit of mirror against the wall, begins a vigorous
Title:  scraping, or rather harpooning of his cheeks.  Thinks I, Queequeg,
Title:  this is using Rogers's best cutlery with a vengeance.  Afterwards I
Title:  wondered the less at this operation when I came to know of what fine
Title:  steel the head of a harpoon is made, and how exceedingly sharp the
Title:  long straight edges are always kept.
Title:  
Title:  The rest of his toilet was soon achieved, and he proudly marched out
Title:  of the room, wrapped up in his great pilot monkey jacket, and
Title:  sporting his harpoon like a marshal's baton.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 5
Title:  
Title:  Breakfast.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  I quickly followed suit, and descending into the bar-room accosted
Title:  the grinning landlord very pleasantly.  I cherished no malice towards
Title:  him, though he had been skylarking with me not a little in the matter
Title:  of my bedfellow.
Title:  
Title:  However, a good laugh is a mighty good thing, and rather too scarce a
Title:  good thing; the more's the pity.  So, if any one man, in his own
Title:  proper person, afford stuff for a good joke to anybody, let him not
Title:  be backward, but let him cheerfully allow himself to spend and be
Title:  spent in that way.  And the man that has anything bountifully
Title:  laughable about him, be sure there is more in that man than you
Title:  perhaps think for.
Title:  
Title:  The bar-room was now full of the boarders who had been dropping in
Title:  the night previous, and whom I had not as yet had a good look at.
Title:  They were nearly all whalemen; chief mates, and second mates, and
Title:  third mates, and sea carpenters, and sea coopers, and sea
Title:  blacksmiths, and harpooneers, and ship keepers; a brown and brawny
Title:  company, with bosky beards; an unshorn, shaggy set, all wearing
Title:  monkey jackets for morning gowns.
Title:  
Title:  You could pretty plainly tell how long each one had been ashore.
Title:  This young fellow's healthy cheek is like a sun-toasted pear in hue,
Title:  and would seem to smell almost as musky; he cannot have been three
Title:  days landed from his Indian voyage.  That man next him looks a few
Title:  shades lighter; you might say a touch of satin wood is in him.  In
Title:  the complexion of a third still lingers a tropic tawn, but slightly
Title:  bleached withal; HE doubtless has tarried whole weeks ashore.  But
Title:  who could show a cheek like Queequeg? which, barred with various
Title:  tints, seemed like the Andes' western slope, to show forth in one
Title:  array, contrasting climates, zone by zone.
Title:  
Title:  "Grub, ho!" now cried the landlord, flinging open a door, and in we
Title:  went to breakfast.
Title:  
Title:  They say that men who have seen the world, thereby become quite at
Title:  ease in manner, quite self-possessed in company.  Not always, though:
Title:  Ledyard, the great New England traveller, and Mungo Park, the Scotch
Title:  one; of all men, they possessed the least assurance in the parlor.
Title:  But perhaps the mere crossing of Siberia in a sledge drawn by dogs as
Title:  Ledyard did, or the taking a long solitary walk on an empty stomach,
Title:  in the negro heart of Africa, which was the sum of poor Mungo's
Title:  performances--this kind of travel, I say, may not be the very best
Title:  mode of attaining a high social polish.  Still, for the most part,
Title:  that sort of thing is to be had anywhere.
Title:  
Title:  These reflections just here are occasioned by the circumstance that
Title:  after we were all seated at the table, and I was preparing to hear
Title:  some good stories about whaling; to my no small surprise, nearly
Title:  every man maintained a profound silence.  And not only that, but they
Title:  looked embarrassed.  Yes, here were a set of sea-dogs, many of whom
Title:  without the slightest bashfulness had boarded great whales on the
Title:  high seas--entire strangers to them--and duelled them dead without
Title:  winking; and yet, here they sat at a social breakfast table--all of
Title:  the same calling, all of kindred tastes--looking round as sheepishly
Title:  at each other as though they had never been out of sight of some
Title:  sheepfold among the Green Mountains.  A curious sight; these bashful
Title:  bears, these timid warrior whalemen!
Title:  
Title:  But as for Queequeg--why, Queequeg sat there among them--at the head
Title:  of the table, too, it so chanced; as cool as an icicle.  To be sure I
Title:  cannot say much for his breeding.  His greatest admirer could not
Title:  have cordially justified his bringing his harpoon into breakfast with
Title:  him, and using it there without ceremony; reaching over the table
Title:  with it, to the imminent jeopardy of many heads, and grappling the
Title:  beefsteaks towards him.  But THAT was certainly very coolly done by
Title:  him, and every one knows that in most people's estimation, to do
Title:  anything coolly is to do it genteelly.
Title:  
Title:  We will not speak of all Queequeg's peculiarities here; how he
Title:  eschewed coffee and hot rolls, and applied his undivided attention to
Title:  beefsteaks, done rare.  Enough, that when breakfast was over he
Title:  withdrew like the rest into the public room, lighted his
Title:  tomahawk-pipe, and was sitting there quietly digesting and smoking
Title:  with his inseparable hat on, when I sallied out for a stroll.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 6
Title:  
Title:  The Street.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  If I had been astonished at first catching a glimpse of so outlandish
Title:  an individual as Queequeg circulating among the polite society of a
Title:  civilized town, that astonishment soon departed upon taking my first
Title:  daylight stroll through the streets of New Bedford.
Title:  
Title:  In thoroughfares nigh the docks, any considerable seaport will
Title:  frequently offer to view the queerest looking nondescripts from
Title:  foreign parts.  Even in Broadway and Chestnut streets, Mediterranean
Title:  mariners will sometimes jostle the affrighted ladies.  Regent Street
Title:  is not unknown to Lascars and Malays; and at Bombay, in the Apollo
Title:  Green, live Yankees have often scared the natives.  But New Bedford
Title:  beats all Water Street and Wapping.  In these last-mentioned haunts
Title:  you see only sailors; but in New Bedford, actual cannibals stand
Title:  chatting at street corners; savages outright; many of whom yet carry
Title:  on their bones unholy flesh.  It makes a stranger stare.
Title:  
Title:  But, besides the Feegeeans, Tongatobooarrs, Erromanggoans,
Title:  Pannangians, and Brighggians, and, besides the wild specimens of the
Title:  whaling-craft which unheeded reel about the streets, you will see
Title:  other sights still more curious, certainly more comical.  There
Title:  weekly arrive in this town scores of green Vermonters and New
Title:  Hampshire men, all athirst for gain and glory in the fishery.  They
Title:  are mostly young, of stalwart frames; fellows who have felled
Title:  forests, and now seek to drop the axe and snatch the whale-lance.
Title:  Many are as green as the Green Mountains whence they came.  In some
Title:  things you would think them but a few hours old.  Look there! that
Title:  chap strutting round the corner.  He wears a beaver hat and
Title:  swallow-tailed coat, girdled with a sailor-belt and sheath-knife.
Title:  Here comes another with a sou'-wester and a bombazine cloak.
Title:  
Title:  No town-bred dandy will compare with a country-bred one--I mean a
Title:  downright bumpkin dandy--a fellow that, in the dog-days, will mow his
Title:  two acres in buckskin gloves for fear of tanning his hands.  Now when
Title:  a country dandy like this takes it into his head to make a
Title:  distinguished reputation, and joins the great whale-fishery, you
Title:  should see the comical things he does upon reaching the seaport.  In
Title:  bespeaking his sea-outfit, he orders bell-buttons to his waistcoats;
Title:  straps to his canvas trowsers.  Ah, poor Hay-Seed! how bitterly will
Title:  burst those straps in the first howling gale, when thou art driven,
Title:  straps, buttons, and all, down the throat of the tempest.
Title:  
Title:  But think not that this famous town has only harpooneers, cannibals,
Title:  and bumpkins to show her visitors.  Not at all.  Still New Bedford is
Title:  a queer place.  Had it not been for us whalemen, that tract of land
Title:  would this day perhaps have been in as howling condition as the coast
Title:  of Labrador.  As it is, parts of her back country are enough to
Title:  frighten one, they look so bony.  The town itself is perhaps the
Title:  dearest place to live in, in all New England.  It is a land of oil,
Title:  true enough: but not like Canaan; a land, also, of corn and wine.
Title:  The streets do not run with milk; nor in the spring-time do they pave
Title:  them with fresh eggs.  Yet, in spite of this, nowhere in all America
Title:  will you find more patrician-like houses; parks and gardens more
Title:  opulent, than in New Bedford.  Whence came they? how planted upon
Title:  this once scraggy scoria of a country?
Title:  
Title:  Go and gaze upon the iron emblematical harpoons round yonder lofty
Title:  mansion, and your question will be answered.  Yes; all these brave
Title:  houses and flowery gardens came from the Atlantic, Pacific, and
Title:  Indian oceans.  One and all, they were harpooned and dragged up
Title:  hither from the bottom of the sea.  Can Herr Alexander perform a feat
Title:  like that?
Title:  
Title:  In New Bedford, fathers, they say, give whales for dowers to their
Title:  daughters, and portion off their nieces with a few porpoises a-piece.
Title:  You must go to New Bedford to see a brilliant wedding; for, they
