Title:  say, they have reservoirs of oil in every house, and every night
Title:  recklessly burn their lengths in spermaceti candles.
Title:  
Title:  In summer time, the town is sweet to see; full of fine maples--long
Title:  avenues of green and gold.  And in August, high in air, the beautiful
Title:  and bountiful horse-chestnuts, candelabra-wise, proffer the passer-by
Title:  their tapering upright cones of congregated blossoms.  So omnipotent
Title:  is art; which in many a district of New Bedford has superinduced
Title:  bright terraces of flowers upon the barren refuse rocks thrown aside
Title:  at creation's final day.
Title:  
Title:  And the women of New Bedford, they bloom like their own red roses.
Title:  But roses only bloom in summer; whereas the fine carnation of their
Title:  cheeks is perennial as sunlight in the seventh heavens.  Elsewhere
Title:  match that bloom of theirs, ye cannot, save in Salem, where they tell
Title:  me the young girls breathe such musk, their sailor sweethearts smell
Title:  them miles off shore, as though they were drawing nigh the odorous
Title:  Moluccas instead of the Puritanic sands.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 7
Title:  
Title:  The Chapel.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  In this same New Bedford there stands a Whaleman's Chapel, and few
Title:  are the moody fishermen, shortly bound for the Indian Ocean or
Title:  Pacific, who fail to make a Sunday visit to the spot.  I am sure that
Title:  I did not.
Title:  
Title:  Returning from my first morning stroll, I again sallied out upon this
Title:  special errand.  The sky had changed from clear, sunny cold, to
Title:  driving sleet and mist.  Wrapping myself in my shaggy jacket of the
Title:  cloth called bearskin, I fought my way against the stubborn storm.
Title:  Entering, I found a small scattered congregation of sailors, and
Title:  sailors' wives and widows.  A muffled silence reigned, only broken at
Title:  times by the shrieks of the storm.  Each silent worshipper seemed
Title:  purposely sitting apart from the other, as if each silent grief were
Title:  insular and incommunicable.  The chaplain had not yet arrived; and
Title:  there these silent islands of men and women sat steadfastly eyeing
Title:  several marble tablets, with black borders, masoned into the wall on
Title:  either side the pulpit.  Three of them ran something like the
Title:  following, but I do not pretend to quote:--
Title:  
Title:  SACRED
Title:  TO THE MEMORY
Title:  OF
Title:  JOHN TALBOT,
Title:  Who, at the age of eighteen, was lost overboard,
Title:  Near the Isle of Desolation, off Patagonia,
Title:  November 1st, 1836.
Title:  THIS TABLET
Title:  Is erected to his Memory
Title:  BY HIS
Title:  SISTER.
Title:  _____________
Title:  
Title:  SACRED
Title:  TO THE MEMORY
Title:  OF
Title:  ROBERT LONG, WILLIS ELLERY,
Title:  NATHAN COLEMAN, WALTER CANNY, SETH MACY,
Title:  AND SAMUEL GLEIG,
Title:  Forming one of the boats' crews
Title:  OF
Title:  THE SHIP ELIZA
Title:  Who were towed out of sight by a Whale,
Title:  On the Off-shore Ground in the
Title:  PACIFIC,
Title:  December 31st, 1839.
Title:  THIS MARBLE
Title:  Is here placed by their surviving
Title:  SHIPMATES.
Title:  _____________
Title:  
Title:  SACRED
Title:  TO THE MEMORY
Title:  OF
Title:  The late
Title:  CAPTAIN EZEKIEL HARDY,
Title:  Who in the bows of his boat was killed by a
Title:  Sperm Whale on the coast of Japan,
Title:  AUGUST 3d, 1833.
Title:  THIS TABLET
Title:  Is erected to his Memory
Title:  BY
Title:  HIS WIDOW.
Title:  
Title:  Shaking off the sleet from my ice-glazed hat and jacket, I seated
Title:  myself near the door, and turning sideways was surprised to see
Title:  Queequeg near me.  Affected by the solemnity of the scene, there was
Title:  a wondering gaze of incredulous curiosity in his countenance.  This
Title:  savage was the only person present who seemed to notice my entrance;
Title:  because he was the only one who could not read, and, therefore, was
Title:  not reading those frigid inscriptions on the wall.  Whether any of
Title:  the relatives of the seamen whose names appeared there were now among
Title:  the congregation, I knew not; but so many are the unrecorded
Title:  accidents in the fishery, and so plainly did several women present
Title:  wear the countenance if not the trappings of some unceasing grief,
Title:  that I feel sure that here before me were assembled those, in whose
Title:  unhealing hearts the sight of those bleak tablets sympathetically
Title:  caused the old wounds to bleed afresh.
Title:  
Title:  Oh! ye whose dead lie buried beneath the green grass; who standing
Title:  among flowers can say--here, HERE lies my beloved; ye know not the
Title:  desolation that broods in bosoms like these.  What bitter blanks in
Title:  those black-bordered marbles which cover no ashes!  What despair in
Title:  those immovable inscriptions!  What deadly voids and unbidden
Title:  infidelities in the lines that seem to gnaw upon all Faith, and
Title:  refuse resurrections to the beings who have placelessly perished
Title:  without a grave.  As well might those tablets stand in the cave of
Title:  Elephanta as here.
Title:  
Title:  In what census of living creatures, the dead of mankind are included;
Title:  why it is that a universal proverb says of them, that they tell no
Title:  tales, though containing more secrets than the Goodwin Sands; how it
Title:  is that to his name who yesterday departed for the other world, we
Title:  prefix so significant and infidel a word, and yet do not thus entitle
Title:  him, if he but embarks for the remotest Indies of this living earth;
Title:  why the Life Insurance Companies pay death-forfeitures upon
Title:  immortals; in what eternal, unstirring paralysis, and deadly,
Title:  hopeless trance, yet lies antique Adam who died sixty round centuries
Title:  ago; how it is that we still refuse to be comforted for those who we
Title:  nevertheless maintain are dwelling in unspeakable bliss; why all the
Title:  living so strive to hush all the dead; wherefore but the rumor of a
Title:  knocking in a tomb will terrify a whole city.  All these things are
Title:  not without their meanings.
Title:  
Title:  But Faith, like a jackal, feeds among the tombs, and even from these
Title:  dead doubts she gathers her most vital hope.
Title:  
Title:  It needs scarcely to be told, with what feelings, on the eve of a
Title:  Nantucket voyage, I regarded those marble tablets, and by the murky
Title:  light of that darkened, doleful day read the fate of the whalemen who
Title:  had gone before me.  Yes, Ishmael, the same fate may be thine.  But
Title:  somehow I grew merry again.  Delightful inducements to embark, fine
Title:  chance for promotion, it seems--aye, a stove boat will make me an
Title:  immortal by brevet.  Yes, there is death in this business of
Title:  whaling--a speechlessly quick chaotic bundling of a man into
Title:  Eternity.  But what then?  Methinks we have hugely mistaken this
Title:  matter of Life and Death.  Methinks that what they call my shadow
Title:  here on earth is my true substance.  Methinks that in looking at
Title:  things spiritual, we are too much like oysters observing the sun
Title:  through the water, and thinking that thick water the thinnest of air.
Title:  Methinks my body is but the lees of my better being.  In fact take
Title:  my body who will, take it I say, it is not me.  And therefore three
Title:  cheers for Nantucket; and come a stove boat and stove body when they
Title:  will, for stave my soul, Jove himself cannot.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 8
Title:  
Title:  The Pulpit.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  I had not been seated very long ere a man of a certain venerable
Title:  robustness entered; immediately as the storm-pelted door flew back
Title:  upon admitting him, a quick regardful eyeing of him by all the
Title:  congregation, sufficiently attested that this fine old man was the
Title:  chaplain.  Yes, it was the famous Father Mapple, so called by the
Title:  whalemen, among whom he was a very great favourite.  He had been a
Title:  sailor and a harpooneer in his youth, but for many years past had
Title:  dedicated his life to the ministry.  At the time I now write of,
Title:  Father Mapple was in the hardy winter of a healthy old age; that sort
Title:  of old age which seems merging into a second flowering youth, for
Title:  among all the fissures of his wrinkles, there shone certain mild
Title:  gleams of a newly developing bloom--the spring verdure peeping forth
Title:  even beneath February's snow.  No one having previously heard his
Title:  history, could for the first time behold Father Mapple without the
Title:  utmost interest, because there were certain engrafted clerical
Title:  peculiarities about him, imputable to that adventurous maritime life
Title:  he had led.  When he entered I observed that he carried no umbrella,
Title:  and certainly had not come in his carriage, for his tarpaulin hat ran
Title:  down with melting sleet, and his great pilot cloth jacket seemed
Title:  almost to drag him to the floor with the weight of the water it had
Title:  absorbed.  However, hat and coat and overshoes were one by one
Title:  removed, and hung up in a little space in an adjacent corner; when,
Title:  arrayed in a decent suit, he quietly approached the pulpit.
Title:  
Title:  Like most old fashioned pulpits, it was a very lofty one, and since a
Title:  regular stairs to such a height would, by its long angle with the
Title:  floor, seriously contract the already small area of the chapel, the
Title:  architect, it seemed, had acted upon the hint of Father Mapple, and
Title:  finished the pulpit without a stairs, substituting a perpendicular
Title:  side ladder, like those used in mounting a ship from a boat at sea.
Title:  The wife of a whaling captain had provided the chapel with a handsome
Title:  pair of red worsted man-ropes for this ladder, which, being itself
Title:  nicely headed, and stained with a mahogany colour, the whole
Title:  contrivance, considering what manner of chapel it was, seemed by no
Title:  means in bad taste.  Halting for an instant at the foot of the
Title:  ladder, and with both hands grasping the ornamental knobs of the
Title:  man-ropes, Father Mapple cast a look upwards, and then with a truly
Title:  sailor-like but still reverential dexterity, hand over hand, mounted
Title:  the steps as if ascending the main-top of his vessel.
Title:  
Title:  The perpendicular parts of this side ladder, as is usually the case
Title:  with swinging ones, were of cloth-covered rope, only the rounds were
Title:  of wood, so that at every step there was a joint.  At my first
Title:  glimpse of the pulpit, it had not escaped me that however convenient
Title:  for a ship, these joints in the present instance seemed unnecessary.
Title:  For I was not prepared to see Father Mapple after gaining the height,
Title:  slowly turn round, and stooping over the pulpit, deliberately drag up
Title:  the ladder step by step, till the whole was deposited within, leaving
Title:  him impregnable in his little Quebec.
Title:  
Title:  I pondered some time without fully comprehending the reason for this.
Title:  Father Mapple enjoyed such a wide reputation for sincerity and
Title:  sanctity, that I could not suspect him of courting notoriety by any
Title:  mere tricks of the stage.  No, thought I, there must be some sober
Title:  reason for this thing; furthermore, it must symbolize something
Title:  unseen.  Can it be, then, that by that act of physical isolation, he
Title:  signifies his spiritual withdrawal for the time, from all outward
Title:  worldly ties and connexions?  Yes, for replenished with the meat and
Title:  wine of the word, to the faithful man of God, this pulpit, I see, is
Title:  a self-containing stronghold--a lofty Ehrenbreitstein, with a
Title:  perennial well of water within the walls.
Title:  
Title:  But the side ladder was not the only strange feature of the place,
Title:  borrowed from the chaplain's former sea-farings.  Between the marble
Title:  cenotaphs on either hand of the pulpit, the wall which formed its
Title:  back was adorned with a large painting representing a gallant ship
Title:  beating against a terrible storm off a lee coast of black rocks and
Title:  snowy breakers.  But high above the flying scud and dark-rolling
Title:  clouds, there floated a little isle of sunlight, from which beamed
Title:  forth an angel's face; and this bright face shed a distinct spot of
Title:  radiance upon the ship's tossed deck, something like that silver
Title:  plate now inserted into the Victory's plank where Nelson fell.  "Ah,
Title:  noble ship," the angel seemed to say, "beat on, beat on, thou noble
Title:  ship, and bear a hardy helm; for lo! the sun is breaking through; the
Title:  clouds are rolling off--serenest azure is at hand."
Title:  
Title:  Nor was the pulpit itself without a trace of the same sea-taste that
Title:  had achieved the ladder and the picture.  Its panelled front was in
Title:  the likeness of a ship's bluff bows, and the Holy Bible rested on a
Title:  projecting piece of scroll work, fashioned after a ship's
Title:  fiddle-headed beak.
Title:  
Title:  What could be more full of meaning?--for the pulpit is ever this
Title:  earth's foremost part; all the rest comes in its rear; the pulpit
Title:  leads the world.  From thence it is the storm of God's quick wrath is
Title:  first descried, and the bow must bear the earliest brunt.  From
Title:  thence it is the God of breezes fair or foul is first invoked for
Title:  favourable winds.  Yes, the world's a ship on its passage out, and not
Title:  a voyage complete; and the pulpit is its prow.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 9
Title:  
Title:  The Sermon.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Father Mapple rose, and in a mild voice of unassuming authority
Title:  ordered the scattered people to condense.  "Starboard gangway,
Title:  there! side away to larboard--larboard gangway to starboard!
Title:  Midships! midships!"
Title:  
Title:  There was a low rumbling of heavy sea-boots among the benches, and a
Title:  still slighter shuffling of women's shoes, and all was quiet again,
Title:  and every eye on the preacher.
Title:  
Title:  He paused a little; then kneeling in the pulpit's bows, folded his
Title:  large brown hands across his chest, uplifted his closed eyes, and
Title:  offered a prayer so deeply devout that he seemed kneeling and praying
Title:  at the bottom of the sea.
Title:  
Title:  This ended, in prolonged solemn tones, like the continual tolling of
Title:  a bell in a ship that is foundering at sea in a fog--in such tones he
Title:  commenced reading the following hymn; but changing his manner towards
Title:  the concluding stanzas, burst forth with a pealing exultation and
Title:  joy--
Title:  
Title:  "The ribs and terrors in the whale,
Title:  Arched over me a dismal gloom,
Title:  While all God's sun-lit waves rolled by,
Title:  And lift me deepening down to doom.
Title:  
Title:  "I saw the opening maw of hell,
Title:  With endless pains and sorrows there;
Title:  Which none but they that feel can tell--
Title:  Oh, I was plunging to despair.
Title:  
Title:  "In black distress, I called my God,
Title:  When I could scarce believe him mine,
Title:  He bowed his ear to my complaints--
Title:  No more the whale did me confine.
Title:  
Title:  "With speed he flew to my relief,
Title:  As on a radiant dolphin borne;
Title:  Awful, yet bright, as lightning shone
Title:  The face of my Deliverer God.
Title:  
Title:  "My song for ever shall record
Title:  That terrible, that joyful hour;
Title:  I give the glory to my God,
Title:  His all the mercy and the power.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Nearly all joined in singing this hymn, which swelled high above the
Title:  howling of the storm.  A brief pause ensued; the preacher slowly
Title:  turned over the leaves of the Bible, and at last, folding his hand
Title:  down upon the proper page, said: "Beloved shipmates, clinch the last
Title:  verse of the first chapter of Jonah--'And God had prepared a great
Title:  fish to swallow up Jonah.'"
Title:  
Title:  "Shipmates, this book, containing only four chapters--four yarns--is
Title:  one of the smallest strands in the mighty cable of the Scriptures.
Title:  Yet what depths of the soul does Jonah's deep sealine sound! what a
Title:  pregnant lesson to us is this prophet!  What a noble thing is that
Title:  canticle in the fish's belly!  How billow-like and boisterously
Title:  grand!  We feel the floods surging over us; we sound with him to the
Title:  kelpy bottom of the waters; sea-weed and all the slime of the sea is
Title:  about us!  But WHAT is this lesson that the book of Jonah teaches?
Title:  Shipmates, it is a two-stranded lesson; a lesson to us all as sinful
Title:  men, and a lesson to me as a pilot of the living God.  As sinful men,
Title:  it is a lesson to us all, because it is a story of the sin,
Title:  hard-heartedness, suddenly awakened fears, the swift punishment,
Title:  repentance, prayers, and finally the deliverance and joy of Jonah.
Title:  As with all sinners among men, the sin of this son of Amittai was in
Title:  his wilful disobedience of the command of God--never mind now what
Title:  that command was, or how conveyed--which he found a hard command.
Title:  But all the things that God would have us do are hard for us to
Title:  do--remember that--and hence, he oftener commands us than endeavors
Title:  to persuade.  And if we obey God, we must disobey ourselves; and it
Title:  is in this disobeying ourselves, wherein the hardness of obeying God
Title:  consists.
Title:  
Title:  "With this sin of disobedience in him, Jonah still further flouts at
Title:  God, by seeking to flee from Him.  He thinks that a ship made by men
Title:  will carry him into countries where God does not reign, but only the
Title:  Captains of this earth.  He skulks about the wharves of Joppa, and
Title:  seeks a ship that's bound for Tarshish.  There lurks, perhaps, a
Title:  hitherto unheeded meaning here.  By all accounts Tarshish could have
Title:  been no other city than the modern Cadiz.  That's the opinion of
Title:  learned men.  And where is Cadiz, shipmates?  Cadiz is in Spain; as
Title:  far by water, from Joppa, as Jonah could possibly have sailed in
Title:  those ancient days, when the Atlantic was an almost unknown sea.
Title:  Because Joppa, the modern Jaffa, shipmates, is on the most easterly
Title:  coast of the Mediterranean, the Syrian; and Tarshish or Cadiz more
Title:  than two thousand miles to the westward from that, just outside the
Title:  Straits of Gibraltar.  See ye not then, shipmates, that Jonah sought
Title:  to flee world-wide from God?  Miserable man!  Oh! most contemptible
Title:  and worthy of all scorn; with slouched hat and guilty eye, skulking
Title:  from his God; prowling among the shipping like a vile burglar
Title:  hastening to cross the seas.  So disordered, self-condemning is his
Title:  look, that had there been policemen in those days, Jonah, on the mere
Title:  suspicion of something wrong, had been arrested ere he touched a
Title:  deck.  How plainly he's a fugitive! no baggage, not a hat-box,
Title:  valise, or carpet-bag,--no friends accompany him to the wharf with
Title:  their adieux.  At last, after much dodging search, he finds the
Title:  Tarshish ship receiving the last items of her cargo; and as he steps
Title:  on board to see its Captain in the cabin, all the sailors for the
Title:  moment desist from hoisting in the goods, to mark the stranger's evil
Title:  eye.  Jonah sees this; but in vain he tries to look all ease and
Title:  confidence; in vain essays his wretched smile.  Strong intuitions of
Title:  the man assure the mariners he can be no innocent.  In their gamesome
Title:  but still serious way, one whispers to the other--"Jack, he's robbed
Title:  a widow;" or, "Joe, do you mark him; he's a bigamist;" or, "Harry
Title:  lad, I guess he's the adulterer that broke jail in old Gomorrah, or
Title:  belike, one of the missing murderers from Sodom."  Another runs to
Title:  read the bill that's stuck against the spile upon the wharf to which
Title:  the ship is moored, offering five hundred gold coins for the
Title:  apprehension of a parricide, and containing a description of his
Title:  person.  He reads, and looks from Jonah to the bill; while all his
Title:  sympathetic shipmates now crowd round Jonah, prepared to lay their
Title:  hands upon him.  Frighted Jonah trembles, and summoning all his
Title:  boldness to his face, only looks so much the more a coward.  He will
Title:  not confess himself suspected; but that itself is strong suspicion.
Title:  So he makes the best of it; and when the sailors find him not to be
Title:  the man that is advertised, they let him pass, and he descends into
Title:  the cabin.
Title:  
Title:  "'Who's there?' cries the Captain at his busy desk, hurriedly making
Title:  out his papers for the Customs--'Who's there?'  Oh! how that harmless
Title:  question mangles Jonah!  For the instant he almost turns to flee
Title:  again.  But he rallies.  'I seek a passage in this ship to Tarshish;
Title:  how soon sail ye, sir?'  Thus far the busy Captain had not looked up
Title:  to Jonah, though the man now stands before him; but no sooner does he
Title:  hear that hollow voice, than he darts a scrutinizing glance.  'We
Title:  sail with the next coming tide,' at last he slowly answered, still
Title:  intently eyeing him.  'No sooner, sir?'--'Soon enough for any honest
Title:  man that goes a passenger.'  Ha!  Jonah, that's another stab.  But he
Title:  swiftly calls away the Captain from that scent.  'I'll sail with
Title:  ye,'--he says,--'the passage money how much is that?--I'll pay now.'
Title:  For it is particularly written, shipmates, as if it were a thing not
Title:  to be overlooked in this history, 'that he paid the fare thereof' ere
Title:  the craft did sail.  And taken with the context, this is full of
Title:  meaning.
Title:  
Title:  "Now Jonah's Captain, shipmates, was one whose discernment detects
Title:  crime in any, but whose cupidity exposes it only in the penniless.
Title:  In this world, shipmates, sin that pays its way can travel freely,
Title:  and without a passport; whereas Virtue, if a pauper, is stopped at
Title:  all frontiers.  So Jonah's Captain prepares to test the length of
Title:  Jonah's purse, ere he judge him openly.  He charges him thrice the
Title:  usual sum; and it's assented to.  Then the Captain knows that Jonah
Title:  is a fugitive; but at the same time resolves to help a flight that
Title:  paves its rear with gold.  Yet when Jonah fairly takes out his purse,
Title:  prudent suspicions still molest the Captain.  He rings every coin to
Title:  find a counterfeit.  Not a forger, any way, he mutters; and Jonah is
Title:  put down for his passage.  'Point out my state-room, Sir,' says Jonah
Title:  now, 'I'm travel-weary; I need sleep.'  'Thou lookest like it,' says
Title:  the Captain, 'there's thy room.'  Jonah enters, and would lock the
Title:  door, but the lock contains no key.  Hearing him foolishly fumbling
Title:  there, the Captain laughs lowly to himself, and mutters something
Title:  about the doors of convicts' cells being never allowed to be locked
Title:  within.  All dressed and dusty as he is, Jonah throws himself into
Title:  his berth, and finds the little state-room ceiling almost resting on
Title:  his forehead.  The air is close, and Jonah gasps.  Then, in that
Title:  contracted hole, sunk, too, beneath the ship's water-line, Jonah
Title:  feels the heralding presentiment of that stifling hour, when the
Title:  whale shall hold him in the smallest of his bowels' wards.
Title:  
Title:  "Screwed at its axis against the side, a swinging lamp slightly
Title:  oscillates in Jonah's room; and the ship, heeling over towards the
Title:  wharf with the weight of the last bales received, the lamp, flame and
Title:  all, though in slight motion, still maintains a permanent obliquity
Title:  with reference to the room; though, in truth, infallibly straight
Title:  itself, it but made obvious the false, lying levels among which it
Title:  hung.  The lamp alarms and frightens Jonah; as lying in his berth his
Title:  tormented eyes roll round the place, and this thus far successful
Title:  fugitive finds no refuge for his restless glance.  But that
Title:  contradiction in the lamp more and more appals him.  The floor, the
Title:  ceiling, and the side, are all awry.  'Oh! so my conscience hangs in
Title:  me!' he groans, 'straight upwards, so it burns; but the chambers of
Title:  my soul are all in crookedness!'
Title:  
Title:  "Like one who after a night of drunken revelry hies to his bed, still
Title:  reeling, but with conscience yet pricking him, as the plungings of
Title:  the Roman race-horse but so much the more strike his steel tags into
Title:  him; as one who in that miserable plight still turns and turns in
Title:  giddy anguish, praying God for annihilation until the fit be passed;
Title:  and at last amid the whirl of woe he feels, a deep stupor steals over
Title:  him, as over the man who bleeds to death, for conscience is the
Title:  wound, and there's naught to staunch it; so, after sore wrestlings in
Title:  his berth, Jonah's prodigy of ponderous misery drags him drowning
Title:  down to sleep.
Title:  
Title:  "And now the time of tide has come; the ship casts off her cables;
Title:  and from the deserted wharf the uncheered ship for Tarshish, all
Title:  careening, glides to sea.  That ship, my friends, was the first of
Title:  recorded smugglers! the contraband was Jonah.  But the sea rebels; he
Title:  will not bear the wicked burden.  A dreadful storm comes on, the
Title:  ship is like to break.  But now when the boatswain calls all hands to
Title:  lighten her; when boxes, bales, and jars are clattering overboard;
Title:  when the wind is shrieking, and the men are yelling, and every plank
Title:  thunders with trampling feet right over Jonah's head; in all this
Title:  raging tumult, Jonah sleeps his hideous sleep.  He sees no black sky
Title:  and raging sea, feels not the reeling timbers, and little hears he or
Title:  heeds he the far rush of the mighty whale, which even now with open
Title:  mouth is cleaving the seas after him.  Aye, shipmates, Jonah was gone
Title:  down into the sides of the ship--a berth in the cabin as I have taken
Title:  it, and was fast asleep.  But the frightened master comes to him, and
Title:  shrieks in his dead ear, 'What meanest thou, O, sleeper! arise!'
Title:  Startled from his lethargy by that direful cry, Jonah staggers to his
Title:  feet, and stumbling to the deck, grasps a shroud, to look out upon
Title:  the sea.  But at that moment he is sprung upon by a panther billow
Title:  leaping over the bulwarks.  Wave after wave thus leaps into the ship,
Title:  and finding no speedy vent runs roaring fore and aft, till the
Title:  mariners come nigh to drowning while yet afloat.  And ever, as the
Title:  white moon shows her affrighted face from the steep gullies in the
Title:  blackness overhead, aghast Jonah sees the rearing bowsprit pointing
Title:  high upward, but soon beat downward again towards the tormented deep.
Title:  
Title:  "Terrors upon terrors run shouting through his soul.  In all his
Title:  cringing attitudes, the God-fugitive is now too plainly known.  The
Title:  sailors mark him; more and more certain grow their suspicions of him,
Title:  and at last, fully to test the truth, by referring the whole matter
Title:  to high Heaven, they fall to casting lots, to see for whose
Title:  cause this great tempest was upon them.  The lot is Jonah's; that
Title:  discovered, then how furiously they mob him with their questions.
Title:  'What is thine occupation?  Whence comest thou?  Thy country?  What
Title:  people?  But mark now, my shipmates, the behavior of poor Jonah.  The
Title:  eager mariners but ask him who he is, and where from; whereas, they
Title:  not only receive an answer to those questions, but likewise another
Title:  answer to a question not put by them, but the unsolicited answer is
Title:  forced from Jonah by the hard hand of God that is upon him.
Title:  
Title:  "'I am a Hebrew,' he cries--and then--'I fear the Lord the God of
Title:  Heaven who hath made the sea and the dry land!'  Fear him, O Jonah?
Title:  Aye, well mightest thou fear the Lord God THEN!  Straightway, he now
Title:  goes on to make a full confession; whereupon the mariners became more
Title:  and more appalled, but still are pitiful.  For when Jonah, not yet
Title:  supplicating God for mercy, since he but too well knew the darkness
Title:  of his deserts,--when wretched Jonah cries out to them to take him
Title:  and cast him forth into the sea, for he knew that for HIS sake this
Title:  great tempest was upon them; they mercifully turn from him, and seek
Title:  by other means to save the ship.  But all in vain; the indignant gale
Title:  howls louder; then, with one hand raised invokingly to God, with the
Title:  other they not unreluctantly lay hold of Jonah.
Title:  
Title:  "And now behold Jonah taken up as an anchor and dropped into the sea;
Title:  when instantly an oily calmness floats out from the east, and the sea
Title:  is still, as Jonah carries down the gale with him, leaving smooth
Title:  water behind.  He goes down in the whirling heart of such a
Title:  masterless commotion that he scarce heeds the moment when he drops
Title:  seething into the yawning jaws awaiting him; and the whale shoots-to
Title:  all his ivory teeth, like so many white bolts, upon his prison.  Then
Title:  Jonah prayed unto the Lord out of the fish's belly.  But observe his
Title:  prayer, and learn a weighty lesson.  For sinful as he is, Jonah does
Title:  not weep and wail for direct deliverance.  He feels that his dreadful
Title:  punishment is just.  He leaves all his deliverance to God, contenting
Title:  himself with this, that spite of all his pains and pangs, he will
Title:  still look towards His holy temple.  And here, shipmates, is true and
Title:  faithful repentance; not clamorous for pardon, but grateful for
Title:  punishment.  And how pleasing to God was this conduct in Jonah, is
Title:  shown in the eventual deliverance of him from the sea and the whale.
Title:  Shipmates, I do not place Jonah before you to be copied for his sin
Title:  but I do place him before you as a model for repentance.  Sin not;
Title:  but if you do, take heed to repent of it like Jonah."
Title:  
Title:  While he was speaking these words, the howling of the shrieking,
Title:  slanting storm without seemed to add new power to the preacher, who,
Title:  when describing Jonah's sea-storm, seemed tossed by a storm himself.
Title:  His deep chest heaved as with a ground-swell; his tossed arms seemed
Title:  the warring elements at work; and the thunders that rolled away from
Title:  off his swarthy brow, and the light leaping from his eye, made all
Title:  his simple hearers look on him with a quick fear that was strange to
Title:  them.
Title:  
Title:  There now came a lull in his look, as he silently turned over the
Title:  leaves of the Book once more; and, at last, standing motionless, with
Title:  closed eyes, for the moment, seemed communing with God and himself.
Title:  
Title:  But again he leaned over towards the people, and bowing his head
Title:  lowly, with an aspect of the deepest yet manliest humility, he spake
Title:  these words:
Title:  
Title:  "Shipmates, God has laid but one hand upon you; both his hands press
Title:  upon me.  I have read ye by what murky light may be mine the lesson
Title:  that Jonah teaches to all sinners; and therefore to ye, and still
Title:  more to me, for I am a greater sinner than ye.  And now how gladly
Title:  would I come down from this mast-head and sit on the hatches there
Title:  where you sit, and listen as you listen, while some one of you reads
Title:  ME that other and more awful lesson which Jonah teaches to ME, as a
Title:  pilot of the living God.  How being an anointed pilot-prophet, or
Title:  speaker of true things, and bidden by the Lord to sound those
Title:  unwelcome truths in the ears of a wicked Nineveh, Jonah, appalled at
Title:  the hostility he should raise, fled from his mission, and sought to
Title:  escape his duty and his God by taking ship at Joppa.  But God is
Title:  everywhere; Tarshish he never reached.  As we have seen, God came
Title:  upon him in the whale, and swallowed him down to living gulfs of
Title:  doom, and with swift slantings tore him along 'into the midst of the
Title:  seas,' where the eddying depths sucked him ten thousand fathoms down,
Title:  and 'the weeds were wrapped about his head,' and all the watery world
Title:  of woe bowled over him.  Yet even then beyond the reach of any
Title:  plummet--'out of the belly of hell'--when the whale grounded upon the
Title:  ocean's utmost bones, even then, God heard the engulphed, repenting
Title:  prophet when he cried.  Then God spake unto the fish; and from the
Title:  shuddering cold and blackness of the sea, the whale came breeching up
Title:  towards the warm and pleasant sun, and all the delights of air and
Title:  earth; and 'vomited out Jonah upon the dry land;' when the word of
Title:  the Lord came a second time; and Jonah, bruised and beaten--his ears,
Title:  like two sea-shells, still multitudinously murmuring of the
Title:  ocean--Jonah did the Almighty's bidding.  And what was that,
Title:  shipmates?  To preach the Truth to the face of Falsehood!  That was
Title:  it!
Title:  
Title:  "This, shipmates, this is that other lesson; and woe to that pilot of
Title:  the living God who slights it.  Woe to him whom this world charms
Title:  from Gospel duty!  Woe to him who seeks to pour oil upon the waters
Title:  when God has brewed them into a gale!  Woe to him who seeks to please
Title:  rather than to appal!  Woe to him whose good name is more to him than
Title:  goodness!  Woe to him who, in this world, courts not dishonour!  Woe
Title:  to him who would not be true, even though to be false were salvation!
Title:  Yea, woe to him who, as the great Pilot Paul has it, while preaching
Title:  to others is himself a castaway!"
Title:  
Title:  He dropped and fell away from himself for a moment; then lifting his
Title:  face to them again, showed a deep joy in his eyes, as he cried out
Title:  with a heavenly enthusiasm,--"But oh! shipmates! on the starboard
Title:  hand of every woe, there is a sure delight; and higher the top of
Title:  that delight, than the bottom of the woe is deep.  Is not the
Title:  main-truck higher than the kelson is low?  Delight is to him--a far,
Title:  far upward, and inward delight--who against the proud gods and
Title:  commodores of this earth, ever stands forth his own inexorable self.
Title:  Delight is to him whose strong arms yet support him, when the ship of
Title:  this base treacherous world has gone down beneath him.  Delight is to
Title:  him, who gives no quarter in the truth, and kills, burns, and
Title:  destroys all sin though he pluck it out from under the robes of
Title:  Senators and Judges.  Delight,--top-gallant delight is to him, who
Title:  acknowledges no law or lord, but the Lord his God, and is only a
Title:  patriot to heaven.  Delight is to him, whom all the waves of the
Title:  billows of the seas of the boisterous mob can never shake from this
Title:  sure Keel of the Ages.  And eternal delight and deliciousness will be
Title:  his, who coming to lay him down, can say with his final breath--O
Title:  Father!--chiefly known to me by Thy rod--mortal or immortal, here I
Title:  die.  I have striven to be Thine, more than to be this world's, or
Title:  mine own.  Yet this is nothing: I leave eternity to Thee; for what
Title:  is man that he should live out the lifetime of his God?"
Title:  
Title:  He said no more, but slowly waving a benediction, covered his face
Title:  with his hands, and so remained kneeling, till all the people had
Title:  departed, and he was left alone in the place.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 10
Title:  
Title:  A Bosom Friend.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Returning to the Spouter-Inn from the Chapel, I found Queequeg there
Title:  quite alone; he having left the Chapel before the benediction some
Title:  time.  He was sitting on a bench before the fire, with his feet on
Title:  the stove hearth, and in one hand was holding close up to his face
Title:  that little negro idol of his; peering hard into its face, and with a
Title:  jack-knife gently whittling away at its nose, meanwhile humming to
Title:  himself in his heathenish way.
Title:  
Title:  But being now interrupted, he put up the image; and pretty soon,
Title:  going to the table, took up a large book there, and placing it on his
Title:  lap began counting the pages with deliberate regularity; at every
Title:  fiftieth page--as I fancied--stopping a moment, looking vacantly
Title:  around him, and giving utterance to a long-drawn gurgling whistle of
Title:  astonishment.  He would then begin again at the next fifty; seeming
Title:  to commence at number one each time, as though he could not count
Title:  more than fifty, and it was only by such a large number of fifties
Title:  being found together, that his astonishment at the multitude of pages
Title:  was excited.
Title:  
Title:  With much interest I sat watching him.  Savage though he was, and
Title:  hideously marred about the face--at least to my taste--his
Title:  countenance yet had a something in it which was by no means
Title:  disagreeable.  You cannot hide the soul.  Through all his unearthly
Title:  tattooings, I thought I saw the traces of a simple honest heart; and
Title:  in his large, deep eyes, fiery black and bold, there seemed tokens of
Title:  a spirit that would dare a thousand devils.  And besides all this,
Title:  there was a certain lofty bearing about the Pagan, which even his
Title:  uncouthness could not altogether maim.  He looked like a man who had
Title:  never cringed and never had had a creditor.  Whether it was, too,
Title:  that his head being shaved, his forehead was drawn out in freer and
Title:  brighter relief, and looked more expansive than it otherwise would,
Title:  this I will not venture to decide; but certain it was his head was
Title:  phrenologically an excellent one.  It may seem ridiculous, but it
Title:  reminded me of General Washington's head, as seen in the popular
Title:  busts of him.  It had the same long regularly graded retreating slope
Title:  from above the brows, which were likewise very projecting, like two
Title:  long promontories thickly wooded on top.  Queequeg was George
Title:  Washington cannibalistically developed.
Title:  
Title:  Whilst I was thus closely scanning him, half-pretending meanwhile to
Title:  be looking out at the storm from the casement, he never heeded my
Title:  presence, never troubled himself with so much as a single glance; but
Title:  appeared wholly occupied with counting the pages of the marvellous
Title:  book.  Considering how sociably we had been sleeping together the
Title:  night previous, and especially considering the affectionate arm I had
Title:  found thrown over me upon waking in the morning, I thought this
Title:  indifference of his very strange.  But savages are strange beings; at
Title:  times you do not know exactly how to take them.  At first they are
Title:  overawing; their calm self-collectedness of simplicity seems a
Title:  Socratic wisdom.  I had noticed also that Queequeg never consorted at
Title:  all, or but very little, with the other seamen in the inn.  He made
Title:  no advances whatever; appeared to have no desire to enlarge the
Title:  circle of his acquaintances.  All this struck me as mighty singular;
Title:  yet, upon second thoughts, there was something almost sublime in it.
Title:  Here was a man some twenty thousand miles from home, by the way of
Title:  Cape Horn, that is--which was the only way he could get there--thrown
Title:  among people as strange to him as though he were in the planet
Title:  Jupiter; and yet he seemed entirely at his ease; preserving the
Title:  utmost serenity; content with his own companionship; always equal to
Title:  himself.  Surely this was a touch of fine philosophy; though no doubt
Title:  he had never heard there was such a thing as that.  But, perhaps, to
Title:  be true philosophers, we mortals should not be conscious of so living
Title:  or so striving.  So soon as I hear that such or such a man gives
Title:  himself out for a philosopher, I conclude that, like the dyspeptic
Title:  old woman, he must have "broken his digester."
Title:  
Title:  As I sat there in that now lonely room; the fire burning low, in that
Title:  mild stage when, after its first intensity has warmed the air, it
Title:  then only glows to be looked at; the evening shades and phantoms
Title:  gathering round the casements, and peering in upon us silent,
Title:  solitary twain; the storm booming without in solemn swells; I began
Title:  to be sensible of strange feelings.  I felt a melting in me.  No more
Title:  my splintered heart and maddened hand were turned against the wolfish
Title:  world.  This soothing savage had redeemed it.  There he sat, his very
Title:  indifference speaking a nature in which there lurked no civilized
Title:  hypocrisies and bland deceits.  Wild he was; a very sight of sights
Title:  to see; yet I began to feel myself mysteriously drawn towards him.
Title:  And those same things that would have repelled most others, they were
Title:  the very magnets that thus drew me.  I'll try a pagan friend, thought
Title:  I, since Christian kindness has proved but hollow courtesy.  I drew
Title:  my bench near him, and made some friendly signs and hints, doing my
Title:  best to talk with him meanwhile.  At first he little noticed these
Title:  advances; but presently, upon my referring to his last night's
Title:  hospitalities, he made out to ask me whether we were again to be
Title:  bedfellows.  I told him yes; whereat I thought he looked pleased,
Title:  perhaps a little complimented.
Title:  
Title:  We then turned over the book together, and I endeavored to explain to
Title:  him the purpose of the printing, and the meaning of the few pictures
Title:  that were in it.  Thus I soon engaged his interest; and from that we
Title:  went to jabbering the best we could about the various outer sights to
Title:  be seen in this famous town.  Soon I proposed a social smoke; and,
Title:  producing his pouch and tomahawk, he quietly offered me a puff.  And
Title:  then we sat exchanging puffs from that wild pipe of his, and keeping
Title:  it regularly passing between us.
Title:  
Title:  If there yet lurked any ice of indifference towards me in the Pagan's
Title:  breast, this pleasant, genial smoke we had, soon thawed it out, and
Title:  left us cronies.  He seemed to take to me quite as naturally and
Title:  unbiddenly as I to him; and when our smoke was over, he pressed his
Title:  forehead against mine, clasped me round the waist, and said that
Title:  henceforth we were married; meaning, in his country's phrase, that we
Title:  were bosom friends; he would gladly die for me, if need should be.
Title:  In a countryman, this sudden flame of friendship would have seemed
Title:  far too premature, a thing to be much distrusted; but in this simple
Title:  savage those old rules would not apply.
Title:  
Title:  After supper, and another social chat and smoke, we went to our room
Title:  together.  He made me a present of his embalmed head; took out his
Title:  enormous tobacco wallet, and groping under the tobacco, drew out some
Title:  thirty dollars in silver; then spreading them on the table, and
Title:  mechanically dividing them into two equal portions, pushed one of
Title:  them towards me, and said it was mine.  I was going to remonstrate;
Title:  but he silenced me by pouring them into my trowsers' pockets.  I let
Title:  them stay.  He then went about his evening prayers, took out his
Title:  idol, and removed the paper fireboard.  By certain signs and
Title:  symptoms, I thought he seemed anxious for me to join him; but well
Title:  knowing what was to follow, I deliberated a moment whether, in case
Title:  he invited me, I would comply or otherwise.
Title:  
Title:  I was a good Christian; born and bred in the bosom of the infallible
Title:  Presbyterian Church.  How then could I unite with this wild idolator
Title:  in worshipping his piece of wood?  But what is worship? thought I.
Title:  Do you suppose now, Ishmael, that the magnanimous God of heaven and
Title:  earth--pagans and all included--can possibly be jealous of an
Title:  insignificant bit of black wood?  Impossible!  But what is
Title:  worship?--to do the will of God--THAT is worship.  And what is the
Title:  will of God?--to do to my fellow man what I would have my fellow man
Title:  to do to me--THAT is the will of God.  Now, Queequeg is my fellow
Title:  man.  And what do I wish that this Queequeg would do to me?  Why,
Title:  unite with me in my particular Presbyterian form of worship.
Title:  Consequently, I must then unite with him in his; ergo, I must turn
Title:  idolator.  So I kindled the shavings; helped prop up the innocent
Title:  little idol; offered him burnt biscuit with Queequeg; salamed before
Title:  him twice or thrice; kissed his nose; and that done, we undressed and
Title:  went to bed, at peace with our own consciences and all the world.
Title:  But we did not go to sleep without some little chat.
Title:  
Title:  How it is I know not; but there is no place like a bed for
Title:  confidential disclosures between friends.  Man and wife, they say,
Title:  there open the very bottom of their souls to each other; and some old
Title:  couples often lie and chat over old times till nearly morning.  Thus,
Title:  then, in our hearts' honeymoon, lay I and Queequeg--a cosy, loving
Title:  pair.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 11
Title:  
Title:  Nightgown.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  We had lain thus in bed, chatting and napping at short intervals, and
Title:  Queequeg now and then affectionately throwing his brown tattooed legs
Title:  over mine, and then drawing them back; so entirely sociable and free
Title:  and easy were we; when, at last, by reason of our confabulations,
Title:  what little nappishness remained in us altogether departed, and we
Title:  felt like getting up again, though day-break was yet some way down
Title:  the future.
Title:  
Title:  Yes, we became very wakeful; so much so that our recumbent position
Title:  began to grow wearisome, and by little and little we found ourselves
Title:  sitting up; the clothes well tucked around us, leaning against the
Title:  head-board with our four knees drawn up close together, and our two
Title:  noses bending over them, as if our kneepans were warming-pans.  We
Title:  felt very nice and snug, the more so since it was so chilly out of
Title:  doors; indeed out of bed-clothes too, seeing that there was no fire
Title:  in the room.  The more so, I say, because truly to enjoy bodily
Title:  warmth, some small part of you must be cold, for there is no quality
Title:  in this world that is not what it is merely by contrast.  Nothing
Title:  exists in itself.  If you flatter yourself that you are all over
Title:  comfortable, and have been so a long time, then you cannot be said to
Title:  be comfortable any more.  But if, like Queequeg and me in the bed,
Title:  the tip of your nose or the crown of your head be slightly chilled,
Title:  why then, indeed, in the general consciousness you feel most
Title:  delightfully and unmistakably warm.  For this reason a sleeping
Title:  apartment should never be furnished with a fire, which is one of the
Title:  luxurious discomforts of the rich.  For the height of this sort of
Title:  deliciousness is to have nothing but the blanket between you and
Title:  your snugness and the cold of the outer air.  Then there you lie like
Title:  the one warm spark in the heart of an arctic crystal.
Title:  
Title:  We had been sitting in this crouching manner for some time, when all
Title:  at once I thought I would open my eyes; for when between sheets,
Title:  whether by day or by night, and whether asleep or awake, I have a way
Title:  of always keeping my eyes shut, in order the more to concentrate the
Title:  snugness of being in bed.  Because no man can ever feel his own
Title:  identity aright except his eyes be closed; as if darkness were
Title:  indeed the proper element of our essences, though light be more
Title:  congenial to our clayey part.  Upon opening my eyes then, and coming
Title:  out of my own pleasant and self-created darkness into the imposed and
Title:  coarse outer gloom of the unilluminated twelve-o'clock-at-night, I
Title:  experienced a disagreeable revulsion.  Nor did I at all object to the
Title:  hint from Queequeg that perhaps it were best to strike a light,
Title:  seeing that we were so wide awake; and besides he felt a strong
Title:  desire to have a few quiet puffs from his Tomahawk.  Be it said, that
Title:  though I had felt such a strong repugnance to his smoking in the bed
Title:  the night before, yet see how elastic our stiff prejudices grow when
Title:  love once comes to bend them.  For now I liked nothing better than
Title:  to have Queequeg smoking by me, even in bed, because he seemed to be
Title:  full of such serene household joy then.  I no more felt unduly
Title:  concerned for the landlord's policy of insurance.  I was only alive
Title:  to the condensed confidential comfortableness of sharing a pipe and a
Title:  blanket with a real friend.  With our shaggy jackets drawn about our
Title:  shoulders, we now passed the Tomahawk from one to the other, till
Title:  slowly there grew over us a blue hanging tester of smoke, illuminated
Title:  by the flame of the new-lit lamp.
Title:  
Title:  Whether it was that this undulating tester rolled the savage away to
Title:  far distant scenes, I know not, but he now spoke of his native
Title:  island; and, eager to hear his history, I begged him to go on and
Title:  tell it.  He gladly complied.  Though at the time I but ill
Title:  comprehended not a few of his words, yet subsequent disclosures, when
Title:  I had become more familiar with his broken phraseology, now enable me
Title:  to present the whole story such as it may prove in the mere skeleton
Title:  I give.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 12
Title:  
Title:  Biographical.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Queequeg was a native of Rokovoko, an island far away to the West
Title:  and South.  It is not down in any map; true places never are.
Title:  
Title:  When a new-hatched savage running wild about his native woodlands in
Title:  a grass clout, followed by the nibbling goats, as if he were a green
Title:  sapling; even then, in Queequeg's ambitious soul, lurked a strong
Title:  desire to see something more of Christendom than a specimen whaler or
Title:  two.  His father was a High Chief, a King; his uncle a High Priest;
Title:  and on the maternal side he boasted aunts who were the wives of
Title:  unconquerable warriors.  There was excellent blood in his
Title:  veins--royal stuff; though sadly vitiated, I fear, by the cannibal
Title:  propensity he nourished in his untutored youth.
Title:  
Title:  A Sag Harbor ship visited his father's bay, and Queequeg sought a
Title:  passage to Christian lands.  But the ship, having her full complement
Title:  of seamen, spurned his suit; and not all the King his father's
Title:  influence could prevail.  But Queequeg vowed a vow.  Alone in his
Title:  canoe, he paddled off to a distant strait, which he knew the ship
Title:  must pass through when she quitted the island.  On one side was a
Title:  coral reef; on the other a low tongue of land, covered with mangrove
Title:  thickets that grew out into the water.  Hiding his canoe, still
Title:  afloat, among these thickets, with its prow seaward, he sat down in
Title:  the stern, paddle low in hand; and when the ship was gliding by, like
Title:  a flash he darted out; gained her side; with one backward dash of his
Title:  foot capsized and sank his canoe; climbed up the chains; and throwing
Title:  himself at full length upon the deck, grappled a ring-bolt there, and
Title:  swore not to let it go, though hacked in pieces.
Title:  
Title:  In vain the captain threatened to throw him overboard; suspended a
Title:  cutlass over his naked wrists; Queequeg was the son of a King, and
Title:  Queequeg budged not.  Struck by his desperate dauntlessness, and his
Title:  wild desire to visit Christendom, the captain at last relented, and
Title:  told him he might make himself at home.  But this fine young
Title:  savage--this sea Prince of Wales, never saw the Captain's cabin.
Title:  They put him down among the sailors, and made a whaleman of him.  But
Title:  like Czar Peter content to toil in the shipyards of foreign cities,
Title:  Queequeg disdained no seeming ignominy, if thereby he might happily
Title:  gain the power of enlightening his untutored countrymen.  For at
Title:  bottom--so he told me--he was actuated by a profound desire to learn
Title:  among the Christians, the arts whereby to make his people still
Title:  happier than they were; and more than that, still better than they
Title:  were.  But, alas! the practices of whalemen soon convinced him that
Title:  even Christians could be both miserable and wicked; infinitely more
Title:  so, than all his father's heathens.  Arrived at last in old Sag
Title:  Harbor; and seeing what the sailors did there; and then going on to
Title:  Nantucket, and seeing how they spent their wages in that place also,
Title:  poor Queequeg gave it up for lost.  Thought he, it's a wicked world
Title:  in all meridians; I'll die a pagan.
Title:  
Title:  And thus an old idolator at heart, he yet lived among these
Title:  Christians, wore their clothes, and tried to talk their gibberish.
Title:  Hence the queer ways about him, though now some time from home.
Title:  
Title:  By hints, I asked him whether he did not propose going back, and
Title:  having a coronation; since he might now consider his father dead and
Title:  gone, he being very old and feeble at the last accounts.  He answered
Title:  no, not yet; and added that he was fearful Christianity, or rather
Title:  Christians, had unfitted him for ascending the pure and undefiled
Title:  throne of thirty pagan Kings before him.  But by and by, he said, he
Title:  would return,--as soon as he felt himself baptized again.  For the
Title:  nonce, however, he proposed to sail about, and sow his wild oats in
Title:  all four oceans.  They had made a harpooneer of him, and that barbed
Title:  iron was in lieu of a sceptre now.
Title:  
Title:  I asked him what might be his immediate purpose, touching his future
Title:  movements.  He answered, to go to sea again, in his old vocation.
Title:  Upon this, I told him that whaling was my own design, and informed
Title:  him of my intention to sail out of Nantucket, as being the most
Title:  promising port for an adventurous whaleman to embark from.  He at
Title:  once resolved to accompany me to that island, ship aboard the same
Title:  vessel, get into the same watch, the same boat, the same mess with
Title:  me, in short to share my every hap; with both my hands in his, boldly
Title:  dip into the Potluck of both worlds.  To all this I joyously
Title:  assented; for besides the affection I now felt for Queequeg, he was
Title:  an experienced harpooneer, and as such, could not fail to be of great
Title:  usefulness to one, who, like me, was wholly ignorant of the mysteries
Title:  of whaling, though well acquainted with the sea, as known to merchant
Title:  seamen.
Title:  
Title:  His story being ended with his pipe's last dying puff, Queequeg
Title:  embraced me, pressed his forehead against mine, and blowing out the
Title:  light, we rolled over from each other, this way and that, and very
Title:  soon were sleeping.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 13
Title:  
Title:  Wheelbarrow.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Next morning, Monday, after disposing of the embalmed head to a
Title:  barber, for a block, I settled my own and comrade's bill; using,
Title:  however, my comrade's money.  The grinning landlord, as well as the
Title:  boarders, seemed amazingly tickled at the sudden friendship which had
Title:  sprung up between me and Queequeg--especially as Peter Coffin's cock
Title:  and bull stories about him had previously so much alarmed me
Title:  concerning the very person whom I now companied with.
Title:  
Title:  We borrowed a wheelbarrow, and embarking our things, including my own
Title:  poor carpet-bag, and Queequeg's canvas sack and hammock, away we went
Title:  down to "the Moss," the little Nantucket packet schooner moored at
Title:  the wharf.  As we were going along the people stared; not at Queequeg
Title:  so much--for they were used to seeing cannibals like him in their
Title:  streets,--but at seeing him and me upon such confidential terms.  But
Title:  we heeded them not, going along wheeling the barrow by turns, and
Title:  Queequeg now and then stopping to adjust the sheath on his harpoon
Title:  barbs.  I asked him why he carried such a troublesome thing with him
Title:  ashore, and whether all whaling ships did not find their own
Title:  harpoons.  To this, in substance, he replied, that though what I
Title:  hinted was true enough, yet he had a particular affection for his own
Title:  harpoon, because it was of assured stuff, well tried in many a mortal
Title:  combat, and deeply intimate with the hearts of whales.  In short,
Title:  like many inland reapers and mowers, who go into the farmers' meadows
Title:  armed with their own scythes--though in no wise obliged to furnish
Title:  them--even so, Queequeg, for his own private reasons, preferred his
Title:  own harpoon.
Title:  
Title:  Shifting the barrow from my hand to his, he told me a funny story
Title:  about the first wheelbarrow he had ever seen.  It was in Sag Harbor.
Title:  The owners of his ship, it seems, had lent him one, in which to carry
Title:  his heavy chest to his boarding house.  Not to seem ignorant about
Title:  the thing--though in truth he was entirely so, concerning the precise
Title:  way in which to manage the barrow--Queequeg puts his chest upon it;
Title:  lashes it fast; and then shoulders the barrow and marches up the
Title:  wharf.  "Why," said I, "Queequeg, you might have known better than
Title:  that, one would think.  Didn't the people laugh?"
Title:  
Title:  Upon this, he told me another story.  The people of his island of
Title:  Rokovoko, it seems, at their wedding feasts express the fragrant
Title:  water of young cocoanuts into a large stained calabash like a
Title:  punchbowl; and this punchbowl always forms the great central ornament
Title:  on the braided mat where the feast is held.  Now a certain grand
Title:  merchant ship once touched at Rokovoko, and its commander--from all
Title:  accounts, a very stately punctilious gentleman, at least for a sea
Title:  captain--this commander was invited to the wedding feast of
Title:  Queequeg's sister, a pretty young princess just turned of ten.  Well;
Title:  when all the wedding guests were assembled at the bride's bamboo
Title:  cottage, this Captain marches in, and being assigned the post of
Title:  honour, placed himself over against the punchbowl, and between the
Title:  High Priest and his majesty the King, Queequeg's father.  Grace being
Title:  said,--for those people have their grace as well as we--though
Title:  Queequeg told me that unlike us, who at such times look downwards to
Title:  our platters, they, on the contrary, copying the ducks, glance
Title:  upwards to the great Giver of all feasts--Grace, I say, being said,
Title:  the High Priest opens the banquet by the immemorial ceremony of the
Title:  island; that is, dipping his consecrated and consecrating fingers
Title:  into the bowl before the blessed beverage circulates.  Seeing himself
Title:  placed next the Priest, and noting the ceremony, and thinking
Title:  himself--being Captain of a ship--as having plain precedence over a
Title:  mere island King, especially in the King's own house--the Captain
Title:  coolly proceeds to wash his hands in the punchbowl;--taking it I
Title:  suppose for a huge finger-glass.  "Now," said Queequeg, "what you
Title:  tink now?--Didn't our people laugh?"
Title:  
Title:  At last, passage paid, and luggage safe, we stood on board the
Title:  schooner.  Hoisting sail, it glided down the Acushnet river.  On one
Title:  side, New Bedford rose in terraces of streets, their ice-covered
Title:  trees all glittering in the clear, cold air.  Huge hills and
Title:  mountains of casks on casks were piled upon her wharves, and side by
Title:  side the world-wandering whale ships lay silent and safely moored at
Title:  last; while from others came a sound of carpenters and coopers, with
Title:  blended noises of fires and forges to melt the pitch, all betokening
Title:  that new cruises were on the start; that one most perilous and long
Title:  voyage ended, only begins a second; and a second ended, only begins a
Title:  third, and so on, for ever and for aye.  Such is the endlessness,
Title:  yea, the intolerableness of all earthly effort.
Title:  
Title:  Gaining the more open water, the bracing breeze waxed fresh; the
Title:  little Moss tossed the quick foam from her bows, as a young colt his
Title:  snortings.  How I snuffed that Tartar air!--how I spurned that
Title:  turnpike earth!--that common highway all over dented with the marks
Title:  of slavish heels and hoofs; and turned me to admire the magnanimity
Title:  of the sea which will permit no records.
Title:  
Title:  At the same foam-fountain, Queequeg seemed to drink and reel with me.
Title:  His dusky nostrils swelled apart; he showed his filed and pointed
Title:  teeth.  On, on we flew; and our offing gained, the Moss did homage to
Title:  the blast; ducked and dived her bows as a slave before the Sultan.
Title:  Sideways leaning, we sideways darted; every ropeyarn tingling like a
Title:  wire; the two tall masts buckling like Indian canes in land
Title:  tornadoes.  So full of this reeling scene were we, as we stood by the
Title:  plunging bowsprit, that for some time we did not notice the jeering
Title:  glances of the passengers, a lubber-like assembly, who marvelled that
Title:  two fellow beings should be so companionable; as though a white man
Title:  were anything more dignified than a whitewashed negro.  But there
Title:  were some boobies and bumpkins there, who, by their intense
Title:  greenness, must have come from the heart and centre of all verdure.
Title:  Queequeg caught one of these young saplings mimicking him behind his
Title:  back.  I thought the bumpkin's hour of doom was come.  Dropping his
Title:  harpoon, the brawny savage caught him in his arms, and by an almost
Title:  miraculous dexterity and strength, sent him high up bodily into the
Title:  air; then slightly tapping his stern in mid-somerset, the fellow
Title:  landed with bursting lungs upon his feet, while Queequeg, turning his
Title:  back upon him, lighted his tomahawk pipe and passed it to me for a
Title:  puff.
Title:  
Title:  "Capting!  Capting! yelled the bumpkin, running towards that officer;
Title:  "Capting, Capting, here's the devil."
Title:  
Title:  "Hallo, YOU sir," cried the Captain, a gaunt rib of the sea, stalking
Title:  up to Queequeg, "what in thunder do you mean by that?  Don't you know
Title:  you might have killed that chap?"
Title:  
Title:  "What him say?" said Queequeg, as he mildly turned to me.
Title:  
Title:  "He say," said I, "that you came near kill-e that man there,"
Title:  pointing to the still shivering greenhorn.
Title:  
Title:  "Kill-e," cried Queequeg, twisting his tattooed face into an
Title:  unearthly expression of disdain, "ah! him bevy small-e fish-e;
Title:  Queequeg no kill-e so small-e fish-e; Queequeg kill-e big whale!"
Title:  
Title:  "Look you," roared the Captain, "I'll kill-e YOU, you cannibal, if
Title:  you try any more of your tricks aboard here; so mind your eye."
Title:  
Title:  But it so happened just then, that it was high time for the Captain
Title:  to mind his own eye.  The prodigious strain upon the main-sail had
Title:  parted the weather-sheet, and the tremendous boom was now flying from
Title:  side to side, completely sweeping the entire after part of the deck.
Title:  The poor fellow whom Queequeg had handled so roughly, was swept
Title:  overboard; all hands were in a panic; and to attempt snatching at the
Title:  boom to stay it, seemed madness.  It flew from right to left, and
Title:  back again, almost in one ticking of a watch, and every instant
Title:  seemed on the point of snapping into splinters.  Nothing was done,
Title:  and nothing seemed capable of being done; those on deck rushed
Title:  towards the bows, and stood eyeing the boom as if it were the lower
Title:  jaw of an exasperated whale.  In the midst of this consternation,
Title:  Queequeg dropped deftly to his knees, and crawling under the path of
Title:  the boom, whipped hold of a rope, secured one end to the bulwarks,
Title:  and then flinging the other like a lasso, caught it round the boom as
Title:  it swept over his head, and at the next jerk, the spar was that way
Title:  trapped, and all was safe.  The schooner was run into the wind, and
Title:  while the hands were clearing away the stern boat, Queequeg, stripped
Title:  to the waist, darted from the side with a long living arc of a leap.
Title:  For three minutes or more he was seen swimming like a dog, throwing
Title:  his long arms straight out before him, and by turns revealing his
Title:  brawny shoulders through the freezing foam.  I looked at the grand
Title:  and glorious fellow, but saw no one to be saved.  The greenhorn had
Title:  gone down.  Shooting himself perpendicularly from the water,
Title:  Queequeg, now took an instant's glance around him, and seeming to see
Title:  just how matters were, dived down and disappeared.  A few minutes
Title:  more, and he rose again, one arm still striking out, and with the
Title:  other dragging a lifeless form.  The boat soon picked them up.  The
Title:  poor bumpkin was restored.  All hands voted Queequeg a noble trump;
Title:  the captain begged his pardon.  From that hour I clove to Queequeg
Title:  like a barnacle; yea, till poor Queequeg took his last long dive.
Title:  
Title:  Was there ever such unconsciousness?  He did not seem to think that
Title:  he at all deserved a medal from the Humane and Magnanimous Societies.
Title:  He only asked for water--fresh water--something to wipe the brine
Title:  off; that done, he put on dry clothes, lighted his pipe, and leaning
Title:  against the bulwarks, and mildly eyeing those around him, seemed to
Title:  be saying to himself--"It's a mutual, joint-stock world, in all
Title:  meridians.  We cannibals must help these Christians."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 14
Title:  
Title:  Nantucket.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Nothing more happened on the passage worthy the mentioning; so, after
Title:  a fine run, we safely arrived in Nantucket.
Title:  
Title:  Nantucket!  Take out your map and look at it.  See what a real corner
Title:  of the world it occupies; how it stands there, away off shore, more
Title:  lonely than the Eddystone lighthouse.  Look at it--a mere hillock,
Title:  and elbow of sand; all beach, without a background.  There is more
Title:  sand there than you would use in twenty years as a substitute for
Title:  blotting paper.  Some gamesome wights will tell you that they have to
Title:  plant weeds there, they don't grow naturally; that they import Canada
Title:  thistles; that they have to send beyond seas for a spile to stop a
Title:  leak in an oil cask; that pieces of wood in Nantucket are carried
Title:  about like bits of the true cross in Rome; that people there plant
Title:  toadstools before their houses, to get under the shade in summer
Title:  time; that one blade of grass makes an oasis, three blades in a day's
Title:  walk a prairie; that they wear quicksand shoes, something like
Title:  Laplander snow-shoes; that they are so shut up, belted about, every
Title:  way inclosed, surrounded, and made an utter island of by the ocean,
Title:  that to their very chairs and tables small clams will sometimes be
Title:  found adhering, as to the backs of sea turtles.  But these
Title:  extravaganzas only show that Nantucket is no Illinois.
Title:  
Title:  Look now at the wondrous traditional story of how this island was
Title:  settled by the red-men.  Thus goes the legend.  In olden times an
Title:  eagle swooped down upon the New England coast, and carried off an
Title:  infant Indian in his talons.  With loud lament the parents saw their
Title:  child borne out of sight over the wide waters.  They resolved to
Title:  follow in the same direction.  Setting out in their canoes, after a
Title:  perilous passage they discovered the island, and there they found an
Title:  empty ivory casket,--the poor little Indian's skeleton.
Title:  
Title:  What wonder, then, that these Nantucketers, born on a beach, should
Title:  take to the sea for a livelihood!  They first caught crabs and
Title:  quohogs in the sand; grown bolder, they waded out with nets for
Title:  mackerel; more experienced, they pushed off in boats and captured
Title:  cod; and at last, launching a navy of great ships on the sea,
Title:  explored this watery world; put an incessant belt of
Title:  circumnavigations round it; peeped in at Behring's Straits; and in
Title:  all seasons and all oceans declared everlasting war with the
Title:  mightiest animated mass that has survived the flood; most monstrous
Title:  and most mountainous!  That Himmalehan, salt-sea Mastodon, clothed
Title:  with such portentousness of unconscious power, that his very panics
Title:  are more to be dreaded than his most fearless and malicious assaults!
Title:  
Title:  And thus have these naked Nantucketers, these sea hermits, issuing
Title:  from their ant-hill in the sea, overrun and conquered the watery
Title:  world like so many Alexanders; parcelling out among them the
Title:  Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian oceans, as the three pirate powers did
Title:  Poland.  Let America add Mexico to Texas, and pile Cuba upon Canada;
Title:  let the English overswarm all India, and hang out their blazing
Title:  banner from the sun; two thirds of this terraqueous globe are the
Title:  Nantucketer's.  For the sea is his; he owns it, as Emperors own
Title:  empires; other seamen having but a right of way through it.  Merchant
Title:  ships are but extension bridges; armed ones but floating forts; even
Title:  pirates and privateers, though following the sea as highwaymen the
Title:  road, they but plunder other ships, other fragments of the land like
Title:  themselves, without seeking to draw their living from the bottomless
Title:  deep itself.  The Nantucketer, he alone resides and riots on the sea;
Title:  he alone, in Bible language, goes down to it in ships; to and fro
Title:  ploughing it as his own special plantation.  THERE is his home; THERE
Title:  lies his business, which a Noah's flood would not interrupt, though
Title:  it overwhelmed all the millions in China.  He lives on the sea, as
Title:  prairie cocks in the prairie; he hides among the waves, he climbs
Title:  them as chamois hunters climb the Alps.  For years he knows not the
Title:  land; so that when he comes to it at last, it smells like another
Title:  world, more strangely than the moon would to an Earthsman.  With the
Title:  landless gull, that at sunset folds her wings and is rocked to sleep
Title:  between billows; so at nightfall, the Nantucketer, out of sight of
Title:  land, furls his sails, and lays him to his rest, while under his very
Title:  pillow rush herds of walruses and whales.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 15
Title:  
Title:  Chowder.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  It was quite late in the evening when the little Moss came snugly to
Title:  anchor, and Queequeg and I went ashore; so we could attend to no
Title:  business that day, at least none but a supper and a bed.  The
Title:  landlord of the Spouter-Inn had recommended us to his cousin Hosea
Title:  Hussey of the Try Pots, whom he asserted to be the proprietor of one
Title:  of the best kept hotels in all Nantucket, and moreover he had assured
Title:  us that Cousin Hosea, as he called him, was famous for his chowders.
Title:  In short, he plainly hinted that we could not possibly do better than
Title:  try pot-luck at the Try Pots.  But the directions he had given us
Title:  about keeping a yellow warehouse on our starboard hand till we opened
Title:  a white church to the larboard, and then keeping that on the larboard
Title:  hand till we made a corner three points to the starboard, and that
Title:  done, then ask the first man we met where the place was: these
Title:  crooked directions of his very much puzzled us at first, especially
Title:  as, at the outset, Queequeg insisted that the yellow warehouse--our
Title:  first point of departure--must be left on the larboard hand, whereas
Title:  I had understood Peter Coffin to say it was on the starboard.
Title:  However, by dint of beating about a little in the dark, and now and
Title:  then knocking up a peaceable inhabitant to inquire the way, we at
Title:  last came to something which there was no mistaking.
Title:  
Title:  Two enormous wooden pots painted black, and suspended by asses' ears,
Title:  swung from the cross-trees of an old top-mast, planted in front of an
Title:  old doorway.  The horns of the cross-trees were sawed off on the
Title:  other side, so that this old top-mast looked not a little like a
Title:  gallows.  Perhaps I was over sensitive to such impressions at the
Title:  time, but I could not help staring at this gallows with a vague
Title:  misgiving.  A sort of crick was in my neck as I gazed up to the two
Title:  remaining horns; yes, TWO of them, one for Queequeg, and one for me.
Title:  It's ominous, thinks I.  A Coffin my Innkeeper upon landing in my
Title:  first whaling port; tombstones staring at me in the whalemen's
Title:  chapel; and here a gallows! and a pair of prodigious black pots too!
Title:  Are these last throwing out oblique hints touching Tophet?
Title:  
Title:  I was called from these reflections by the sight of a freckled woman
Title:  with yellow hair and a yellow gown, standing in the porch of the inn,
Title:  under a dull red lamp swinging there, that looked much like an
Title:  injured eye, and carrying on a brisk scolding with a man in a purple
Title:  woollen shirt.
Title:  
Title:  "Get along with ye," said she to the man, "or I'll be combing ye!"
Title:  
Title:  "Come on, Queequeg," said I, "all right.  There's Mrs. Hussey."
Title:  
Title:  And so it turned out; Mr. Hosea Hussey being from home, but leaving
Title:  Mrs. Hussey entirely competent to attend to all his affairs.  Upon
Title:  making known our desires for a supper and a bed, Mrs. Hussey,
Title:  postponing further scolding for the present, ushered us into a little
Title:  room, and seating us at a table spread with the relics of a recently
Title:  concluded repast, turned round to us and said--"Clam or Cod?"
Title:  
Title:  "What's that about Cods, ma'am?" said I, with much politeness.
Title:  
Title:  "Clam or Cod?" she repeated.
Title:  
Title:  "A clam for supper? a cold clam; is THAT what you mean, Mrs. Hussey?"
Title:  says I, "but that's a rather cold and clammy reception in the winter
Title:  time, ain't it, Mrs. Hussey?"
Title:  
Title:  But being in a great hurry to resume scolding the man in the purple
Title:  Shirt, who was waiting for it in the entry, and seeming to hear
Title:  nothing but the word "clam," Mrs. Hussey hurried towards an open door
Title:  leading to the kitchen, and bawling out "clam for two," disappeared.
Title:  
Title:  "Queequeg," said I, "do you think that we can make out a supper for
Title:  us both on one clam?"
Title:  
Title:  However, a warm savory steam from the kitchen served to belie the
Title:  apparently cheerless prospect before us.  But when that smoking
Title:  chowder came in, the mystery was delightfully explained.  Oh, sweet
Title:  friends! hearken to me.  It was made of small juicy clams, scarcely
Title:  bigger than hazel nuts, mixed with pounded ship biscuit, and salted
Title:  pork cut up into little flakes; the whole enriched with butter, and
Title:  plentifully seasoned with pepper and salt.  Our appetites being
Title:  sharpened by the frosty voyage, and in particular, Queequeg seeing
Title:  his favourite fishing food before him, and the chowder being
Title:  surpassingly excellent, we despatched it with great expedition: when
Title:  leaning back a moment and bethinking me of Mrs. Hussey's clam and cod
Title:  announcement, I thought I would try a little experiment.  Stepping to
Title:  the kitchen door, I uttered the word "cod" with great emphasis, and
Title:  resumed my seat.  In a few moments the savoury steam came forth
Title:  again, but with a different flavor, and in good time a fine
Title:  cod-chowder was placed before us.
Title:  
Title:  We resumed business; and while plying our spoons in the bowl, thinks
Title:  I to myself, I wonder now if this here has any effect on the head?
Title:  What's that stultifying saying about chowder-headed people?  "But
Title:  look, Queequeg, ain't that a live eel in your bowl?  Where's your
Title:  harpoon?"
Title:  
Title:  Fishiest of all fishy places was the Try Pots, which well deserved
Title:  its name; for the pots there were always boiling chowders.  Chowder
Title:  for breakfast, and chowder for dinner, and chowder for supper, till
Title:  you began to look for fish-bones coming through your clothes.  The
Title:  area before the house was paved with clam-shells.  Mrs. Hussey wore a
Title:  polished necklace of codfish vertebra; and Hosea Hussey had his
Title:  account books bound in superior old shark-skin.  There was a fishy
Title:  flavor to the milk, too, which I could not at all account for, till
Title:  one morning happening to take a stroll along the beach among some
Title:  fishermen's boats, I saw Hosea's brindled cow feeding on fish
Title:  remnants, and marching along the sand with each foot in a cod's
Title:  decapitated head, looking very slip-shod, I assure ye.
Title:  
Title:  Supper concluded, we received a lamp, and directions from Mrs. Hussey
Title:  concerning the nearest way to bed; but, as Queequeg was about to
Title:  precede me up the stairs, the lady reached forth her arm, and
Title:  demanded his harpoon; she allowed no harpoon in her chambers.  "Why
Title:  not? said I; "every true whaleman sleeps with his harpoon--but why
Title:  not?"  "Because it's dangerous," says she.  "Ever since young Stiggs
Title:  coming from that unfort'nt v'y'ge of his, when he was gone four years
Title:  and a half, with only three barrels of ILE, was found dead in my
