Title:  first floor back, with his harpoon in his side; ever since then I
Title:  allow no boarders to take sich dangerous weepons in their rooms at
Title:  night.  So, Mr. Queequeg" (for she had learned his name), "I will
Title:  just take this here iron, and keep it for you till morning.  But the
Title:  chowder; clam or cod to-morrow for breakfast, men?"
Title:  
Title:  "Both," says I; "and let's have a couple of smoked herring by way of
Title:  variety."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 16
Title:  
Title:  The Ship.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  In bed we concocted our plans for the morrow.  But to my surprise and
Title:  no small concern, Queequeg now gave me to understand, that he had
Title:  been diligently consulting Yojo--the name of his black little
Title:  god--and Yojo had told him two or three times over, and strongly
Title:  insisted upon it everyway, that instead of our going together among
Title:  the whaling-fleet in harbor, and in concert selecting our craft;
Title:  instead of this, I say, Yojo earnestly enjoined that the selection of
Title:  the ship should rest wholly with me, inasmuch as Yojo purposed
Title:  befriending us; and, in order to do so, had already pitched upon a
Title:  vessel, which, if left to myself, I, Ishmael, should infallibly light
Title:  upon, for all the world as though it had turned out by chance; and in
Title:  that vessel I must immediately ship myself, for the present
Title:  irrespective of Queequeg.
Title:  
Title:  I have forgotten to mention that, in many things, Queequeg placed
Title:  great confidence in the excellence of Yojo's judgment and surprising
Title:  forecast of things; and cherished Yojo with considerable esteem, as a
Title:  rather good sort of god, who perhaps meant well enough upon the
Title:  whole, but in all cases did not succeed in his benevolent designs.
Title:  
Title:  Now, this plan of Queequeg's, or rather Yojo's, touching the
Title:  selection of our craft; I did not like that plan at all.  I had not a
Title:  little relied upon Queequeg's sagacity to point out the whaler best
Title:  fitted to carry us and our fortunes securely.  But as all my
Title:  remonstrances produced no effect upon Queequeg, I was obliged to
Title:  acquiesce; and accordingly prepared to set about this business with a
Title:  determined rushing sort of energy and vigor, that should quickly
Title:  settle that trifling little affair.  Next morning early, leaving
Title:  Queequeg shut up with Yojo in our little bedroom--for it seemed that
Title:  it was some sort of Lent or Ramadan, or day of fasting, humiliation,
Title:  and prayer with Queequeg and Yojo that day; HOW it was I never could
Title:  find out, for, though I applied myself to it several times, I never
Title:  could master his liturgies and XXXIX Articles--leaving Queequeg,
Title:  then, fasting on his tomahawk pipe, and Yojo warming himself at his
Title:  sacrificial fire of shavings, I sallied out among the shipping.
Title:  After much prolonged sauntering and many random inquiries, I learnt
Title:  that there were three ships up for three-years' voyages--The
Title:  Devil-dam, the Tit-bit, and the Pequod.  DEVIL-DAM, I do not know
Title:  the origin of; TIT-BIT is obvious; PEQUOD, you will no doubt
Title:  remember, was the name of a celebrated tribe of Massachusetts
Title:  Indians; now extinct as the ancient Medes.  I peered and pryed about
Title:  the Devil-dam; from her, hopped over to the Tit-bit; and finally,
Title:  going on board the Pequod, looked around her for a moment, and then
Title:  decided that this was the very ship for us.
Title:  
Title:  You may have seen many a quaint craft in your day, for aught I
Title:  know;--square-toed luggers; mountainous Japanese junks; butter-box
Title:  galliots, and what not; but take my word for it, you never saw such a
Title:  rare old craft as this same rare old Pequod.  She was a ship of the
Title:  old school, rather small if anything; with an old-fashioned
Title:  claw-footed look about her.  Long seasoned and weather-stained in the
Title:  typhoons and calms of all four oceans, her old hull's complexion was
Title:  darkened like a French grenadier's, who has alike fought in Egypt and
Title:  Siberia.  Her venerable bows looked bearded.  Her masts--cut
Title:  somewhere on the coast of Japan, where her original ones were lost
Title:  overboard in a gale--her masts stood stiffly up like the spines of
Title:  the three old kings of Cologne.  Her ancient decks were worn and
Title:  wrinkled, like the pilgrim-worshipped flag-stone in Canterbury
Title:  Cathedral where Becket bled.  But to all these her old antiquities,
Title:  were added new and marvellous features, pertaining to the wild
Title:  business that for more than half a century she had followed.  Old
Title:  Captain Peleg, many years her chief-mate, before he commanded another
Title:  vessel of his own, and now a retired seaman, and one of the principal
Title:  owners of the Pequod,--this old Peleg, during the term of his
Title:  chief-mateship, had built upon her original grotesqueness, and inlaid
Title:  it, all over, with a quaintness both of material and device,
Title:  unmatched by anything except it be Thorkill-Hake's carved buckler or
Title:  bedstead.  She was apparelled like any barbaric Ethiopian emperor,
Title:  his neck heavy with pendants of polished ivory.  She was a thing of
Title:  trophies.  A cannibal of a craft, tricking herself forth in the
Title:  chased bones of her enemies.  All round, her unpanelled, open
Title:  bulwarks were garnished like one continuous jaw, with the long sharp
Title:  teeth of the sperm whale, inserted there for pins, to fasten her old
Title:  hempen thews and tendons to.  Those thews ran not through base blocks
Title:  of land wood, but deftly travelled over sheaves of sea-ivory.
Title:  Scorning a turnstile wheel at her reverend helm, she sported there a
Title:  tiller; and that tiller was in one mass, curiously carved from the
Title:  long narrow lower jaw of her hereditary foe.  The helmsman who
Title:  steered by that tiller in a tempest, felt like the Tartar, when he
Title:  holds back his fiery steed by clutching its jaw.  A noble craft, but
Title:  somehow a most melancholy!  All noble things are touched with that.
Title:  
Title:  Now when I looked about the quarter-deck, for some one having
Title:  authority, in order to propose myself as a candidate for the voyage,
Title:  at first I saw nobody; but I could not well overlook a strange sort
Title:  of tent, or rather wigwam, pitched a little behind the main-mast.  It
Title:  seemed only a temporary erection used in port.  It was of a conical
Title:  shape, some ten feet high; consisting of the long, huge slabs of
Title:  limber black bone taken from the middle and highest part of the jaws
Title:  of the right-whale.  Planted with their broad ends on the deck, a
Title:  circle of these slabs laced together, mutually sloped towards each
Title:  other, and at the apex united in a tufted point, where the loose
Title:  hairy fibres waved to and fro like the top-knot on some old
Title:  Pottowottamie Sachem's head.  A triangular opening faced towards the
Title:  bows of the ship, so that the insider commanded a complete view
Title:  forward.
Title:  
Title:  And half concealed in this queer tenement, I at length found one who
Title:  by his aspect seemed to have authority; and who, it being noon, and
Title:  the ship's work suspended, was now enjoying respite from the burden
Title:  of command.  He was seated on an old-fashioned oaken chair, wriggling
Title:  all over with curious carving; and the bottom of which was formed of
Title:  a stout interlacing of the same elastic stuff of which the wigwam was
Title:  constructed.
Title:  
Title:  There was nothing so very particular, perhaps, about the appearance
Title:  of the elderly man I saw; he was brown and brawny, like most old
Title:  seamen, and heavily rolled up in blue pilot-cloth, cut in the Quaker
Title:  style; only there was a fine and almost microscopic net-work of the
Title:  minutest wrinkles interlacing round his eyes, which must have arisen
Title:  from his continual sailings in many hard gales, and always looking to
Title:  windward;--for this causes the muscles about the eyes to become
Title:  pursed together.  Such eye-wrinkles are very effectual in a scowl.
Title:  
Title:  "Is this the Captain of the Pequod?" said I, advancing to the door of
Title:  the tent.
Title:  
Title:  "Supposing it be the captain of the Pequod, what dost thou want of
Title:  him?" he demanded.
Title:  
Title:  "I was thinking of shipping."
Title:  
Title:  "Thou wast, wast thou?  I see thou art no Nantucketer--ever been in
Title:  a stove boat?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, Sir, I never have."
Title:  
Title:  "Dost know nothing at all about whaling, I dare say--eh?
Title:  
Title:  "Nothing, Sir; but I have no doubt I shall soon learn.  I've been
Title:  several voyages in the merchant service, and I think that--"
Title:  
Title:  "Merchant service be damned.  Talk not that lingo to me.  Dost see
Title:  that leg?--I'll take that leg away from thy stern, if ever thou
Title:  talkest of the marchant service to me again.  Marchant service
Title:  indeed!  I suppose now ye feel considerable proud of having served in
Title:  those marchant ships.  But flukes! man, what makes thee want to go a
Title:  whaling, eh?--it looks a little suspicious, don't it, eh?--Hast not
Title:  been a pirate, hast thou?--Didst not rob thy last Captain, didst
Title:  thou?--Dost not think of murdering the officers when thou gettest to
Title:  sea?"
Title:  
Title:  I protested my innocence of these things.  I saw that under the mask
Title:  of these half humorous innuendoes, this old seaman, as an insulated
Title:  Quakerish Nantucketer, was full of his insular prejudices, and rather
Title:  distrustful of all aliens, unless they hailed from Cape Cod or the
Title:  Vineyard.
Title:  
Title:  "But what takes thee a-whaling?  I want to know that before I think
Title:  of shipping ye."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, sir, I want to see what whaling is.  I want to see the world."
Title:  
Title:  "Want to see what whaling is, eh?  Have ye clapped eye on Captain
Title:  Ahab?"
Title:  
Title:  "Who is Captain Ahab, sir?"
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, aye, I thought so.  Captain Ahab is the Captain of this ship."
Title:  
Title:  "I am mistaken then.  I thought I was speaking to the Captain
Title:  himself."
Title:  
Title:  "Thou art speaking to Captain Peleg--that's who ye are speaking to,
Title:  young man.  It belongs to me and Captain Bildad to see the Pequod
Title:  fitted out for the voyage, and supplied with all her needs, including
Title:  crew.  We are part owners and agents.  But as I was going to say, if
Title:  thou wantest to know what whaling is, as thou tellest ye do, I can
Title:  put ye in a way of finding it out before ye bind yourself to it, past
Title:  backing out.  Clap eye on Captain Ahab, young man, and thou wilt find
Title:  that he has only one leg."
Title:  
Title:  "What do you mean, sir?  Was the other one lost by a whale?"
Title:  
Title:  "Lost by a whale!  Young man, come nearer to me: it was devoured,
Title:  chewed up, crunched by the monstrousest parmacetty that ever chipped
Title:  a boat!--ah, ah!"
Title:  
Title:  I was a little alarmed by his energy, perhaps also a little touched
Title:  at the hearty grief in his concluding exclamation, but said as calmly
Title:  as I could, "What you say is no doubt true enough, sir; but how could
Title:  I know there was any peculiar ferocity in that particular whale,
Title:  though indeed I might have inferred as much from the simple fact of
Title:  the accident."
Title:  
Title:  "Look ye now, young man, thy lungs are a sort of soft, d'ye see; thou
Title:  dost not talk shark a bit.  SURE, ye've been to sea before now; sure
Title:  of that?"
Title:  
Title:  "Sir," said I, "I thought I told you that I had been four voyages in
Title:  the merchant--"
Title:  
Title:  "Hard down out of that!  Mind what I said about the marchant
Title:  service--don't aggravate me--I won't have it.  But let us understand
Title:  each other.  I have given thee a hint about what whaling is; do ye
Title:  yet feel inclined for it?"
Title:  
Title:  "I do, sir."
Title:  
Title:  "Very good.  Now, art thou the man to pitch a harpoon down a live
Title:  whale's throat, and then jump after it?  Answer, quick!"
Title:  
Title:  "I am, sir, if it should be positively indispensable to do so; not to
Title:  be got rid of, that is; which I don't take to be the fact."
Title:  
Title:  "Good again.  Now then, thou not only wantest to go a-whaling, to
Title:  find out by experience what whaling is, but ye also want to go in
Title:  order to see the world?  Was not that what ye said?  I thought so.
Title:  Well then, just step forward there, and take a peep over the
Title:  weather-bow, and then back to me and tell me what ye see there."
Title:  
Title:  For a moment I stood a little puzzled by this curious request, not
Title:  knowing exactly how to take it, whether humorously or in earnest.
Title:  But concentrating all his crow's feet into one scowl, Captain Peleg
Title:  started me on the errand.
Title:  
Title:  Going forward and glancing over the weather bow, I perceived that the
Title:  ship swinging to her anchor with the flood-tide, was now obliquely
Title:  pointing towards the open ocean.  The prospect was unlimited, but
Title:  exceedingly monotonous and forbidding; not the slightest variety that
Title:  I could see.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, what's the report?" said Peleg when I came back; "what did ye
Title:  see?"
Title:  
Title:  "Not much," I replied--"nothing but water; considerable horizon
Title:  though, and there's a squall coming up, I think."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, what does thou think then of seeing the world?  Do ye wish to
Title:  go round Cape Horn to see any more of it, eh?  Can't ye see the world
Title:  where you stand?"
Title:  
Title:  I was a little staggered, but go a-whaling I must, and I would; and
Title:  the Pequod was as good a ship as any--I thought the best--and all
Title:  this I now repeated to Peleg.  Seeing me so determined, he expressed
Title:  his willingness to ship me.
Title:  
Title:  "And thou mayest as well sign the papers right off," he added--"come
Title:  along with ye."  And so saying, he led the way below deck into the
Title:  cabin.
Title:  
Title:  Seated on the transom was what seemed to me a most uncommon and
Title:  surprising figure.  It turned out to be Captain Bildad, who along
Title:  with Captain Peleg was one of the largest owners of the vessel; the
Title:  other shares, as is sometimes the case in these ports, being held by
Title:  a crowd of old annuitants; widows, fatherless children, and chancery
Title:  wards; each owning about the value of a timber head, or a foot of
Title:  plank, or a nail or two in the ship.  People in Nantucket invest
Title:  their money in whaling vessels, the same way that you do yours in
Title:  approved state stocks bringing in good interest.
Title:  
Title:  Now, Bildad, like Peleg, and indeed many other Nantucketers, was a
Title:  Quaker, the island having been originally settled by that sect; and
Title:  to this day its inhabitants in general retain in an uncommon measure
Title:  the peculiarities of the Quaker, only variously and anomalously
Title:  modified by things altogether alien and heterogeneous.  For some of
Title:  these same Quakers are the most sanguinary of all sailors and
Title:  whale-hunters.  They are fighting Quakers; they are Quakers with a
Title:  vengeance.
Title:  
Title:  So that there are instances among them of men, who, named with
Title:  Scripture names--a singularly common fashion on the island--and in
Title:  childhood naturally imbibing the stately dramatic thee and thou of
Title:  the Quaker idiom; still, from the audacious, daring, and boundless
Title:  adventure of their subsequent lives, strangely blend with these
Title:  unoutgrown peculiarities, a thousand bold dashes of character, not
Title:  unworthy a Scandinavian sea-king, or a poetical Pagan Roman.  And
Title:  when these things unite in a man of greatly superior natural force,
Title:  with a globular brain and a ponderous heart; who has also by the
Title:  stillness and seclusion of many long night-watches in the remotest
Title:  waters, and beneath constellations never seen here at the north, been
Title:  led to think untraditionally and independently; receiving all
Title:  nature's sweet or savage impressions fresh from her own virgin
Title:  voluntary and confiding breast, and thereby chiefly, but with some
Title:  help from accidental advantages, to learn a bold and nervous lofty
Title:  language--that man makes one in a whole nation's census--a mighty
Title:  pageant creature, formed for noble tragedies.  Nor will it at all
Title:  detract from him, dramatically regarded, if either by birth or other
Title:  circumstances, he have what seems a half wilful overruling morbidness
Title:  at the bottom of his nature.  For all men tragically great are made
Title:  so through a certain morbidness.  Be sure of this, O young ambition,
Title:  all mortal greatness is but disease.  But, as yet we have not to do
Title:  with such an one, but with quite another; and still a man, who, if
Title:  indeed peculiar, it only results again from another phase of the
Title:  Quaker, modified by individual circumstances.
Title:  
Title:  Like Captain Peleg, Captain Bildad was a well-to-do, retired
Title:  whaleman.  But unlike Captain Peleg--who cared not a rush for what
Title:  are called serious things, and indeed deemed those self-same serious
Title:  things the veriest of all trifles--Captain Bildad had not only been
Title:  originally educated according to the strictest sect of Nantucket
Title:  Quakerism, but all his subsequent ocean life, and the sight of many
Title:  unclad, lovely island creatures, round the Horn--all that had not
Title:  moved this native born Quaker one single jot, had not so much as
Title:  altered one angle of his vest.  Still, for all this immutableness,
Title:  was there some lack of common consistency about worthy Captain
Title:  Peleg.  Though refusing, from conscientious scruples, to bear arms
Title:  against land invaders, yet himself had illimitably invaded the
Title:  Atlantic and Pacific; and though a sworn foe to human bloodshed, yet
Title:  had he in his straight-bodied coat, spilled tuns upon tuns of
Title:  leviathan gore.  How now in the contemplative evening of his days,
Title:  the pious Bildad reconciled these things in the reminiscence, I do
Title:  not know; but it did not seem to concern him much, and very probably
Title:  he had long since come to the sage and sensible conclusion that a
Title:  man's religion is one thing, and this practical world quite another.
Title:  This world pays dividends.  Rising from a little cabin-boy in short
Title:  clothes of the drabbest drab, to a harpooneer in a broad shad-bellied
Title:  waistcoat; from that becoming boat-header, chief-mate, and captain,
Title:  and finally a ship owner; Bildad, as I hinted before, had concluded
Title:  his adventurous career by wholly retiring from active life at the
Title:  goodly age of sixty, and dedicating his remaining days to the quiet
Title:  receiving of his well-earned income.
Title:  
Title:  Now, Bildad, I am sorry to say, had the reputation of being an
Title:  incorrigible old hunks, and in his sea-going days, a bitter, hard
Title:  task-master.  They told me in Nantucket, though it certainly seems a
Title:  curious story, that when he sailed the old Categut whaleman, his
Title:  crew, upon arriving home, were mostly all carried ashore to the
Title:  hospital, sore exhausted and worn out.  For a pious man, especially
Title:  for a Quaker, he was certainly rather hard-hearted, to say the
Title:  least.  He never used to swear, though, at his men, they said; but
Title:  somehow he got an inordinate quantity of cruel, unmitigated hard work
Title:  out of them.  When Bildad was a chief-mate, to have his drab-coloured
Title:  eye intently looking at you, made you feel completely nervous, till
Title:  you could clutch something--a hammer or a marling-spike, and go to
Title:  work like mad, at something or other, never mind what.  Indolence and
Title:  idleness perished before him.  His own person was the exact
Title:  embodiment of his utilitarian character.  On his long, gaunt body, he
Title:  carried no spare flesh, no superfluous beard, his chin having a soft,
Title:  economical nap to it, like the worn nap of his broad-brimmed hat.
Title:  
Title:  Such, then, was the person that I saw seated on the transom when I
Title:  followed Captain Peleg down into the cabin.  The space between the
Title:  decks was small; and there, bolt-upright, sat old Bildad, who always
Title:  sat so, and never leaned, and this to save his coat tails.  His
Title:  broad-brim was placed beside him; his legs were stiffly crossed; his
Title:  drab vesture was buttoned up to his chin; and spectacles on nose, he
Title:  seemed absorbed in reading from a ponderous volume.
Title:  
Title:  "Bildad," cried Captain Peleg, "at it again, Bildad, eh?  Ye have
Title:  been studying those Scriptures, now, for the last thirty years, to my
Title:  certain knowledge.  How far ye got, Bildad?"
Title:  
Title:  As if long habituated to such profane talk from his old shipmate,
Title:  Bildad, without noticing his present irreverence, quietly looked up,
Title:  and seeing me, glanced again inquiringly towards Peleg.
Title:  
Title:  "He says he's our man, Bildad," said Peleg, "he wants to ship."
Title:  
Title:  "Dost thee?" said Bildad, in a hollow tone, and turning round to me.
Title:  
Title:  "I dost," said I unconsciously, he was so intense a Quaker.
Title:  
Title:  "What do ye think of him, Bildad?" said Peleg.
Title:  
Title:  "He'll do," said Bildad, eyeing me, and then went on spelling away at
Title:  his book in a mumbling tone quite audible.
Title:  
Title:  I thought him the queerest old Quaker I ever saw, especially as
Title:  Peleg, his friend and old shipmate, seemed such a blusterer.  But I
Title:  said nothing, only looking round me sharply.  Peleg now threw open a
Title:  chest, and drawing forth the ship's articles, placed pen and ink
Title:  before him, and seated himself at a little table.  I began to think
Title:  it was high time to settle with myself at what terms I would be
Title:  willing to engage for the voyage.  I was already aware that in the
Title:  whaling business they paid no wages; but all hands, including the
Title:  captain, received certain shares of the profits called lays, and that
Title:  these lays were proportioned to the degree of importance pertaining
Title:  to the respective duties of the ship's company.  I was also aware
Title:  that being a green hand at whaling, my own lay would not be very
Title:  large; but considering that I was used to the sea, could steer a
Title:  ship, splice a rope, and all that, I made no doubt that from all I
Title:  had heard I should be offered at least the 275th lay--that is, the
Title:  275th part of the clear net proceeds of the voyage, whatever that
Title:  might eventually amount to.  And though the 275th lay was what they
Title:  call a rather LONG LAY, yet it was better than nothing; and if we had
Title:  a lucky voyage, might pretty nearly pay for the clothing I would wear
Title:  out on it, not to speak of my three years' beef and board, for which
Title:  I would not have to pay one stiver.
Title:  
Title:  It might be thought that this was a poor way to accumulate a princely
Title:  fortune--and so it was, a very poor way indeed.  But I am one of
Title:  those that never take on about princely fortunes, and am quite
Title:  content if the world is ready to board and lodge me, while I am
Title:  putting up at this grim sign of the Thunder Cloud.  Upon the whole, I
Title:  thought that the 275th lay would be about the fair thing, but would not
Title:  have been surprised had I been offered the 200th, considering I was
Title:  of a broad-shouldered make.
Title:  
Title:  But one thing, nevertheless, that made me a little distrustful about
Title:  receiving a generous share of the profits was this: Ashore, I had
Title:  heard something of both Captain Peleg and his unaccountable old crony
Title:  Bildad; how that they being the principal proprietors of the Pequod,
Title:  therefore the other and more inconsiderable and scattered owners,
Title:  left nearly the whole management of the ship's affairs to these two.
Title:  And I did not know but what the stingy old Bildad might have a mighty
Title:  deal to say about shipping hands, especially as I now found him on
Title:  board the Pequod, quite at home there in the cabin, and reading his
Title:  Bible as if at his own fireside.  Now while Peleg was vainly trying
Title:  to mend a pen with his jack-knife, old Bildad, to my no small
Title:  surprise, considering that he was such an interested party in these
Title:  proceedings; Bildad never heeded us, but went on mumbling to himself
Title:  out of his book, "LAY not up for yourselves treasures upon earth,
Title:  where moth--"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, Captain Bildad," interrupted Peleg, "what d'ye say, what lay
Title:  shall we give this young man?"
Title:  
Title:  "Thou knowest best," was the sepulchral reply, "the seven hundred and
Title:  seventy-seventh wouldn't be too much, would it?--'where moth and rust
Title:  do corrupt, but LAY--'"
Title:  
Title:  LAY, indeed, thought I, and such a lay! the seven hundred and
Title:  seventy-seventh!  Well, old Bildad, you are determined that I, for
Title:  one, shall not LAY up many LAYS here below, where moth and rust do
Title:  corrupt.  It was an exceedingly LONG LAY that, indeed; and though
Title:  from the magnitude of the figure it might at first deceive a
Title:  landsman, yet the slightest consideration will show that though seven
Title:  hundred and seventy-seven is a pretty large number, yet, when you
Title:  come to make a TEENTH of it, you will then see, I say, that the seven
Title:  hundred and seventy-seventh part of a farthing is a good deal less
Title:  than seven hundred and seventy-seven gold doubloons; and so I thought
Title:  at the time.
Title:  
Title:  "Why, blast your eyes, Bildad," cried Peleg, "thou dost not want to
Title:  swindle this young man! he must have more than that."
Title:  
Title:  "Seven hundred and seventy-seventh," again said Bildad, without
Title:  lifting his eyes; and then went on mumbling--"for where your treasure
Title:  is, there will your heart be also."
Title:  
Title:  "I am going to put him down for the three hundredth," said Peleg, "do
Title:  ye hear that, Bildad!  The three hundredth lay, I say."
Title:  
Title:  Bildad laid down his book, and turning solemnly towards him said,
Title:  "Captain Peleg, thou hast a generous heart; but thou must consider
Title:  the duty thou owest to the other owners of this ship--widows and
Title:  orphans, many of them--and that if we too abundantly reward the
Title:  labors of this young man, we may be taking the bread from those
Title:  widows and those orphans.  The seven hundred and seventy-seventh lay,
Title:  Captain Peleg."
Title:  
Title:  "Thou Bildad!" roared Peleg, starting up and clattering about the
Title:  cabin.  "Blast ye, Captain Bildad, if I had followed thy advice in
Title:  these matters, I would afore now had a conscience to lug about that
Title:  would be heavy enough to founder the largest ship that ever sailed
Title:  round Cape Horn."
Title:  
Title:  "Captain Peleg," said Bildad steadily, "thy conscience may be drawing
Title:  ten inches of water, or ten fathoms, I can't tell; but as thou art
Title:  still an impenitent man, Captain Peleg, I greatly fear lest thy
Title:  conscience be but a leaky one; and will in the end sink thee
Title:  foundering down to the fiery pit, Captain Peleg."
Title:  
Title:  "Fiery pit! fiery pit! ye insult me, man; past all natural bearing,
Title:  ye insult me.  It's an all-fired outrage to tell any human creature
Title:  that he's bound to hell.  Flukes and flames!  Bildad, say that again
Title:  to me, and start my soul-bolts, but I'll--I'll--yes, I'll swallow a
Title:  live goat with all his hair and horns on.  Out of the cabin, ye
Title:  canting, drab-coloured son of a wooden gun--a straight wake with ye!"
Title:  
Title:  As he thundered out this he made a rush at Bildad, but with a
Title:  marvellous oblique, sliding celerity, Bildad for that time eluded
Title:  him.
Title:  
Title:  Alarmed at this terrible outburst between the two principal and
Title:  responsible owners of the ship, and feeling half a mind to give up
Title:  all idea of sailing in a vessel so questionably owned and temporarily
Title:  commanded, I stepped aside from the door to give egress to Bildad,
Title:  who, I made no doubt, was all eagerness to vanish from before the
Title:  awakened wrath of Peleg.  But to my astonishment, he sat down again
Title:  on the transom very quietly, and seemed to have not the slightest
Title:  intention of withdrawing.  He seemed quite used to impenitent Peleg
Title:  and his ways.  As for Peleg, after letting off his rage as he had,
Title:  there seemed no more left in him, and he, too, sat down like a lamb,
Title:  though he twitched a little as if still nervously agitated.  "Whew!"
Title:  he whistled at last--"the squall's gone off to leeward, I think.
Title:  Bildad, thou used to be good at sharpening a lance, mend that pen,
Title:  will ye.  My jack-knife here needs the grindstone.  That's he; thank
Title:  ye, Bildad.  Now then, my young man, Ishmael's thy name, didn't ye
Title:  say?  Well then, down ye go here, Ishmael, for the three hundredth
Title:  lay."
Title:  
Title:  "Captain Peleg," said I, "I have a friend with me who wants to ship
Title:  too--shall I bring him down to-morrow?"
Title:  
Title:  "To be sure," said Peleg.  "Fetch him along, and we'll look at him."
Title:  
Title:  "What lay does he want?" groaned Bildad, glancing up from the book
Title:  in which he had again been burying himself.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh! never thee mind about that, Bildad," said Peleg.  "Has he ever
Title:  whaled it any?" turning to me.
Title:  
Title:  "Killed more whales than I can count, Captain Peleg."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, bring him along then."
Title:  
Title:  And, after signing the papers, off I went; nothing doubting but that
Title:  I had done a good morning's work, and that the Pequod was the
Title:  identical ship that Yojo had provided to carry Queequeg and me round
Title:  the Cape.
Title:  
Title:  But I had not proceeded far, when I began to bethink me that the
Title:  Captain with whom I was to sail yet remained unseen by me; though,
Title:  indeed, in many cases, a whale-ship will be completely fitted out,
Title:  and receive all her crew on board, ere the captain makes himself
Title:  visible by arriving to take command; for sometimes these voyages are
Title:  so prolonged, and the shore intervals at home so exceedingly brief,
Title:  that if the captain have a family, or any absorbing concernment of
Title:  that sort, he does not trouble himself much about his ship in port,
Title:  but leaves her to the owners till all is ready for sea.  However, it
Title:  is always as well to have a look at him before irrevocably committing
Title:  yourself into his hands.  Turning back I accosted Captain Peleg,
Title:  inquiring where Captain Ahab was to be found.
Title:  
Title:  "And what dost thou want of Captain Ahab?  It's all right enough;
Title:  thou art shipped."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, but I should like to see him."
Title:  
Title:  "But I don't think thou wilt be able to at present.  I don't know
Title:  exactly what's the matter with him; but he keeps close inside the
Title:  house; a sort of sick, and yet he don't look so.  In fact, he ain't
Title:  sick; but no, he isn't well either.  Any how, young man, he won't
Title:  always see me, so I don't suppose he will thee.  He's a queer man,
Title:  Captain Ahab--so some think--but a good one.  Oh, thou'lt like him
Title:  well enough; no fear, no fear.  He's a grand, ungodly, god-like man,
Title:  Captain Ahab; doesn't speak much; but, when he does speak, then you
Title:  may well listen.  Mark ye, be forewarned; Ahab's above the common;
Title:  Ahab's been in colleges, as well as 'mong the cannibals; been used to
Title:  deeper wonders than the waves; fixed his fiery lance in mightier,
Title:  stranger foes than whales.  His lance! aye, the keenest and the surest
Title:  that out of all our isle!  Oh! he ain't Captain Bildad; no, and he
Title:  ain't Captain Peleg; HE'S AHAB, boy; and Ahab of old, thou knowest,
Title:  was a crowned king!"
Title:  
Title:  "And a very vile one.  When that wicked king was slain, the dogs, did
Title:  they not lick his blood?"
Title:  
Title:  "Come hither to me--hither, hither," said Peleg, with a significance
Title:  in his eye that almost startled me.  "Look ye, lad; never say that on
Title:  board the Pequod.  Never say it anywhere.  Captain Ahab did not name
Title:  himself.  'Twas a foolish, ignorant whim of his crazy, widowed
Title:  mother, who died when he was only a twelvemonth old.  And yet the old
Title:  squaw Tistig, at Gayhead, said that the name would somehow prove
Title:  prophetic.  And, perhaps, other fools like her may tell thee the
Title:  same.  I wish to warn thee.  It's a lie.  I know Captain Ahab well;
Title:  I've sailed with him as mate years ago; I know what he is--a good
Title:  man--not a pious, good man, like Bildad, but a swearing good
Title:  man--something like me--only there's a good deal more of him.  Aye,
Title:  aye, I know that he was never very jolly; and I know that on the
Title:  passage home, he was a little out of his mind for a spell; but it was
Title:  the sharp shooting pains in his bleeding stump that brought that
Title:  about, as any one might see.  I know, too, that ever since he lost
Title:  his leg last voyage by that accursed whale, he's been a kind of
Title:  moody--desperate moody, and savage sometimes; but that will all pass
Title:  off.  And once for all, let me tell thee and assure thee, young man,
Title:  it's better to sail with a moody good captain than a laughing bad
Title:  one.  So good-bye to thee--and wrong not Captain Ahab, because he
Title:  happens to have a wicked name.  Besides, my boy, he has a wife--not
Title:  three voyages wedded--a sweet, resigned girl.  Think of that; by that
Title:  sweet girl that old man has a child: hold ye then there can be any
Title:  utter, hopeless harm in Ahab?  No, no, my lad; stricken, blasted, if
Title:  he be, Ahab has his humanities!"
Title:  
Title:  As I walked away, I was full of thoughtfulness; what had been
Title:  incidentally revealed to me of Captain Ahab, filled me with a certain
Title:  wild vagueness of painfulness concerning him.  And somehow, at the
Title:  time, I felt a sympathy and a sorrow for him, but for I don't know
Title:  what, unless it was the cruel loss of his leg.  And yet I also felt a
Title:  strange awe of him; but that sort of awe, which I cannot at all
Title:  describe, was not exactly awe; I do not know what it was.  But I felt
Title:  it; and it did not disincline me towards him; though I felt
Title:  impatience at what seemed like mystery in him, so imperfectly as he
Title:  was known to me then.  However, my thoughts were at length carried in
Title:  other directions, so that for the present dark Ahab slipped my mind.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 17
Title:  
Title:  The Ramadan.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  As Queequeg's Ramadan, or Fasting and Humiliation, was to continue
Title:  all day, I did not choose to disturb him till towards night-fall; for
Title:  I cherish the greatest respect towards everybody's religious
Title:  obligations, never mind how comical, and could not find it in my
Title:  heart to undervalue even a congregation of ants worshipping a
Title:  toad-stool; or those other creatures in certain parts of our earth,
Title:  who with a degree of footmanism quite unprecedented in other planets,
Title:  bow down before the torso of a deceased landed proprietor merely on
Title:  account of the inordinate possessions yet owned and rented in his
Title:  name.
Title:  
Title:  I say, we good Presbyterian Christians should be charitable in these
Title:  things, and not fancy ourselves so vastly superior to other mortals,
Title:  pagans and what not, because of their half-crazy conceits on these
Title:  subjects.  There was Queequeg, now, certainly entertaining the most
Title:  absurd notions about Yojo and his Ramadan;--but what of that?
Title:  Queequeg thought he knew what he was about, I suppose; he seemed to
Title:  be content; and there let him rest.  All our arguing with him would
Title:  not avail; let him be, I say: and Heaven have mercy on us
Title:  all--Presbyterians and Pagans alike--for we are all somehow
Title:  dreadfully cracked about the head, and sadly need mending.
Title:  
Title:  Towards evening, when I felt assured that all his performances and
Title:  rituals must be over, I went up to his room and knocked at the door;
Title:  but no answer.  I tried to open it, but it was fastened inside.
Title:  "Queequeg," said I softly through the key-hole:--all silent.  "I say,
Title:  Queequeg! why don't you speak?  It's I--Ishmael."  But all remained
Title:  still as before.  I began to grow alarmed.  I had allowed him such
Title:  abundant time; I thought he might have had an apoplectic fit.  I
Title:  looked through the key-hole; but the door opening into an odd corner
Title:  of the room, the key-hole prospect was but a crooked and sinister
Title:  one.  I could only see part of the foot-board of the bed and a line
Title:  of the wall, but nothing more.  I was surprised to behold resting
Title:  against the wall the wooden shaft of Queequeg's harpoon, which the
Title:  landlady the evening previous had taken from him, before our mounting
Title:  to the chamber.  That's strange, thought I; but at any rate, since
Title:  the harpoon stands yonder, and he seldom or never goes abroad without
Title:  it, therefore he must be inside here, and no possible mistake.
Title:  
Title:  "Queequeg!--Queequeg!"--all still.  Something must have happened.
Title:  Apoplexy!  I tried to burst open the door; but it stubbornly
Title:  resisted.  Running down stairs, I quickly stated my suspicions to the
Title:  first person I met--the chamber-maid.  "La! la!" she cried, "I
Title:  thought something must be the matter.  I went to make the bed after
Title:  breakfast, and the door was locked; and not a mouse to be heard; and
Title:  it's been just so silent ever since.  But I thought, may be, you had
Title:  both gone off and locked your baggage in for safe keeping.  La! la,
Title:  ma'am!--Mistress! murder!  Mrs. Hussey! apoplexy!"--and with these
Title:  cries, she ran towards the kitchen, I following.
Title:  
Title:  Mrs. Hussey soon appeared, with a mustard-pot in one hand and a
Title:  vinegar-cruet in the other, having just broken away from the
Title:  occupation of attending to the castors, and scolding her little black
Title:  boy meantime.
Title:  
Title:  "Wood-house!" cried I, "which way to it?  Run for God's sake, and
Title:  fetch something to pry open the door--the axe!--the axe! he's had a
Title:  stroke; depend upon it!"--and so saying I was unmethodically rushing
Title:  up stairs again empty-handed, when Mrs. Hussey interposed the
Title:  mustard-pot and vinegar-cruet, and the entire castor of her
Title:  countenance.
Title:  
Title:  "What's the matter with you, young man?"
Title:  
Title:  "Get the axe!  For God's sake, run for the doctor, some one, while I
Title:  pry it open!"
Title:  
Title:  "Look here," said the landlady, quickly putting down the
Title:  vinegar-cruet, so as to have one hand free; "look here; are you
Title:  talking about prying open any of my doors?"--and with that she seized
Title:  my arm.  "What's the matter with you?  What's the matter with you,
Title:  shipmate?"
Title:  
Title:  In as calm, but rapid a manner as possible, I gave her to understand
Title:  the whole case.  Unconsciously clapping the vinegar-cruet to one side
Title:  of her nose, she ruminated for an instant; then exclaimed--"No!  I
Title:  haven't seen it since I put it there."  Running to a little closet
Title:  under the landing of the stairs, she glanced in, and returning, told
Title:  me that Queequeg's harpoon was missing.  "He's killed himself," she
Title:  cried.  "It's unfort'nate Stiggs done over again there goes another
Title:  counterpane--God pity his poor mother!--it will be the ruin of my
Title:  house.  Has the poor lad a sister?  Where's that girl?--there, Betty,
Title:  go to Snarles the Painter, and tell him to paint me a sign, with--"no
Title:  suicides permitted here, and no smoking in the parlor;"--might as
Title:  well kill both birds at once.  Kill?  The Lord be merciful to his
Title:  ghost!  What's that noise there?  You, young man, avast there!"
Title:  
Title:  And running up after me, she caught me as I was again trying to force
Title:  open the door.
Title:  
Title:  "I don't allow it; I won't have my premises spoiled.  Go for the
Title:  locksmith, there's one about a mile from here.  But avast!" putting
Title:  her hand in her side-pocket, "here's a key that'll fit, I guess;
Title:  let's see."  And with that, she turned it in the lock; but, alas!
Title:  Queequeg's supplemental bolt remained unwithdrawn within.
Title:  
Title:  "Have to burst it open," said I, and was running down the entry a
Title:  little, for a good start, when the landlady caught at me, again
Title:  vowing I should not break down her premises; but I tore from her, and
Title:  with a sudden bodily rush dashed myself full against the mark.
Title:  
Title:  With a prodigious noise the door flew open, and the knob slamming
Title:  against the wall, sent the plaster to the ceiling; and there, good
Title:  heavens! there sat Queequeg, altogether cool and self-collected;
Title:  right in the middle of the room; squatting on his hams, and holding
Title:  Yojo on top of his head.  He looked neither one way nor the other
Title:  way, but sat like a carved image with scarce a sign of active life.
Title:  
Title:  "Queequeg," said I, going up to him, "Queequeg, what's the matter
Title:  with you?"
Title:  
Title:  "He hain't been a sittin' so all day, has he?" said the landlady.
Title:  
Title:  But all we said, not a word could we drag out of him; I almost felt
Title:  like pushing him over, so as to change his position, for it was
Title:  almost intolerable, it seemed so painfully and unnaturally
Title:  constrained; especially, as in all probability he had been sitting so
Title:  for upwards of eight or ten hours, going too without his regular
Title:  meals.
Title:  
Title:  "Mrs. Hussey," said I, "he's ALIVE at all events; so leave us, if you
Title:  please, and I will see to this strange affair myself."
Title:  
Title:  Closing the door upon the landlady, I endeavored to prevail upon
Title:  Queequeg to take a chair; but in vain.  There he sat; and all he
Title:  could do--for all my polite arts and blandishments--he would not move
Title:  a peg, nor say a single word, nor even look at me, nor notice my
Title:  presence in the slightest way.
Title:  
Title:  I wonder, thought I, if this can possibly be a part of his Ramadan;
Title:  do they fast on their hams that way in his native island.  It must be
Title:  so; yes, it's part of his creed, I suppose; well, then, let him
Title:  rest; he'll get up sooner or later, no doubt.  It can't last for
Title:  ever, thank God, and his Ramadan only comes once a year; and I don't
Title:  believe it's very punctual then.
Title:  
Title:  I went down to supper.  After sitting a long time listening to the
Title:  long stories of some sailors who had just come from a plum-pudding
Title:  voyage, as they called it (that is, a short whaling-voyage in a
Title:  schooner or brig, confined to the north of the line, in the Atlantic
Title:  Ocean only); after listening to these plum-puddingers till nearly
Title:  eleven o'clock, I went up stairs to go to bed, feeling quite sure by
Title:  this time Queequeg must certainly have brought his Ramadan to a
Title:  termination.  But no; there he was just where I had left him; he had
Title:  not stirred an inch.  I began to grow vexed with him; it seemed so
Title:  downright senseless and insane to be sitting there all day and half
Title:  the night on his hams in a cold room, holding a piece of wood on his
Title:  head.
Title:  
Title:  "For heaven's sake, Queequeg, get up and shake yourself; get up and
Title:  have some supper.  You'll starve; you'll kill yourself, Queequeg."
Title:  But not a word did he reply.
Title:  
Title:  Despairing of him, therefore, I determined to go to bed and to sleep;
Title:  and no doubt, before a great while, he would follow me.  But previous
Title:  to turning in, I took my heavy bearskin jacket, and threw it over
Title:  him, as it promised to be a very cold night; and he had nothing but
Title:  his ordinary round jacket on.  For some time, do all I would, I could
Title:  not get into the faintest doze.  I had blown out the candle; and the
Title:  mere thought of Queequeg--not four feet off--sitting there in that
Title:  uneasy position, stark alone in the cold and dark; this made me
Title:  really wretched.  Think of it; sleeping all night in the same room
Title:  with a wide awake pagan on his hams in this dreary, unaccountable
Title:  Ramadan!
Title:  
Title:  But somehow I dropped off at last, and knew nothing more till break
Title:  of day; when, looking over the bedside, there squatted Queequeg, as
Title:  if he had been screwed down to the floor.  But as soon as the first
Title:  glimpse of sun entered the window, up he got, with stiff and grating
Title:  joints, but with a cheerful look; limped towards me where I lay;
Title:  pressed his forehead again against mine; and said his Ramadan was
Title:  over.
Title:  
Title:  Now, as I before hinted, I have no objection to any person's
Title:  religion, be it what it may, so long as that person does not kill or
Title:  insult any other person, because that other person don't believe it
Title:  also.  But when a man's religion becomes really frantic; when it is a
Title:  positive torment to him; and, in fine, makes this earth of ours an
Title:  uncomfortable inn to lodge in; then I think it high time to take that
Title:  individual aside and argue the point with him.
Title:  
Title:  And just so I now did with Queequeg.  "Queequeg," said I, "get into
Title:  bed now, and lie and listen to me."  I then went on, beginning with
Title:  the rise and progress of the primitive religions, and coming down to
Title:  the various religions of the present time, during which time I
Title:  labored to show Queequeg that all these Lents, Ramadans, and
Title:  prolonged ham-squattings in cold, cheerless rooms were stark
Title:  nonsense; bad for the health; useless for the soul; opposed, in
Title:  short, to the obvious laws of Hygiene and common sense.  I told him,
Title:  too, that he being in other things such an extremely sensible and
Title:  sagacious savage, it pained me, very badly pained me, to see him now
Title:  so deplorably foolish about this ridiculous Ramadan of his.  Besides,
Title:  argued I, fasting makes the body cave in; hence the spirit caves in;
Title:  and all thoughts born of a fast must necessarily be half-starved.
Title:  This is the reason why most dyspeptic religionists cherish such
Title:  melancholy notions about their hereafters.  In one word, Queequeg,
Title:  said I, rather digressively; hell is an idea first born on an
Title:  undigested apple-dumpling; and since then perpetuated through the
Title:  hereditary dyspepsias nurtured by Ramadans.
Title:  
Title:  I then asked Queequeg whether he himself was ever troubled with
Title:  dyspepsia; expressing the idea very plainly, so that he could take it
Title:  in.  He said no; only upon one memorable occasion.  It was after a
Title:  great feast given by his father the king, on the gaining of a great
Title:  battle wherein fifty of the enemy had been killed by about two
Title:  o'clock in the afternoon, and all cooked and eaten that very evening.
Title:  
Title:  "No more, Queequeg," said I, shuddering; "that will do;" for I knew
Title:  the inferences without his further hinting them.  I had seen a sailor
Title:  who had visited that very island, and he told me that it was the
Title:  custom, when a great battle had been gained there, to barbecue all
Title:  the slain in the yard or garden of the victor; and then, one by one,
Title:  they were placed in great wooden trenchers, and garnished round like
Title:  a pilau, with breadfruit and cocoanuts; and with some parsley in
Title:  their mouths, were sent round with the victor's compliments to all
Title:  his friends, just as though these presents were so many Christmas
Title:  turkeys.
Title:  
Title:  After all, I do not think that my remarks about religion made much
Title:  impression upon Queequeg.  Because, in the first place, he somehow
Title:  seemed dull of hearing on that important subject, unless considered
Title:  from his own point of view; and, in the second place, he did not more
Title:  than one third understand me, couch my ideas simply as I would; and,
Title:  finally, he no doubt thought he knew a good deal more about the true
Title:  religion than I did.  He looked at me with a sort of condescending
Title:  concern and compassion, as though he thought it a great pity that
Title:  such a sensible young man should be so hopelessly lost to evangelical
Title:  pagan piety.
Title:  
Title:  At last we rose and dressed; and Queequeg, taking a prodigiously
Title:  hearty breakfast of chowders of all sorts, so that the landlady
Title:  should not make much profit by reason of his Ramadan, we sallied out
Title:  to board the Pequod, sauntering along, and picking our teeth with
Title:  halibut bones.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 18
Title:  
Title:  His Mark.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  As we were walking down the end of the wharf towards the ship,
Title:  Queequeg carrying his harpoon, Captain Peleg in his gruff voice
Title:  loudly hailed us from his wigwam, saying he had not suspected my
Title:  friend was a cannibal, and furthermore announcing that he let no
Title:  cannibals on board that craft, unless they previously produced their
Title:  papers.
Title:  
Title:  "What do you mean by that, Captain Peleg?" said I, now jumping on the
Title:  bulwarks, and leaving my comrade standing on the wharf.
Title:  
Title:  "I mean," he replied, "he must show his papers."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said Captain Bildad in his hollow voice, sticking his head
Title:  from behind Peleg's, out of the wigwam.  "He must show that he's
Title:  converted.  Son of darkness," he added, turning to Queequeg, "art
Title:  thou at present in communion with any Christian church?"
Title:  
Title:  "Why," said I, "he's a member of the first Congregational Church."
Title:  Here be it said, that many tattooed savages sailing in Nantucket
Title:  ships at last come to be converted into the churches.
Title:  
Title:  "First Congregational Church," cried Bildad, "what! that worships in
Title:  Deacon Deuteronomy Coleman's meeting-house?" and so saying, taking
Title:  out his spectacles, he rubbed them with his great yellow bandana
Title:  handkerchief, and putting them on very carefully, came out of the
Title:  wigwam, and leaning stiffly over the bulwarks, took a good long look
Title:  at Queequeg.
Title:  
Title:  "How long hath he been a member?" he then said, turning to me; "not
Title:  very long, I rather guess, young man."
Title:  
Title:  "No," said Peleg, "and he hasn't been baptized right either, or it
Title:  would have washed some of that devil's blue off his face."
Title:  
Title:  "Do tell, now," cried Bildad, "is this Philistine a regular member of
Title:  Deacon Deuteronomy's meeting?  I never saw him going there, and I
Title:  pass it every Lord's day."
Title:  
Title:  "I don't know anything about Deacon Deuteronomy or his meeting," said
Title:  I; "all I know is, that Queequeg here is a born member of the First
Title:  Congregational Church.  He is a deacon himself, Queequeg is."
Title:  
Title:  "Young man," said Bildad sternly, "thou art skylarking with
Title:  me--explain thyself, thou young Hittite.  What church dost thee mean?
Title:  answer me."
Title:  
Title:  Finding myself thus hard pushed, I replied.  "I mean, sir, the same
Title:  ancient Catholic Church to which you and I, and Captain Peleg there,
Title:  and Queequeg here, and all of us, and every mother's son and soul of
Title:  us belong; the great and everlasting First Congregation of this whole
Title:  worshipping world; we all belong to that; only some of us cherish
Title:  some queer crotchets no ways touching the grand belief; in THAT we
Title:  all join hands."
Title:  
Title:  "Splice, thou mean'st SPLICE hands," cried Peleg, drawing nearer.
Title:  "Young man, you'd better ship for a missionary, instead of a
Title:  fore-mast hand; I never heard a better sermon.  Deacon
Title:  Deuteronomy--why Father Mapple himself couldn't beat it, and he's
Title:  reckoned something.  Come aboard, come aboard; never mind about the
Title:  papers.  I say, tell Quohog there--what's that you call him? tell
Title:  Quohog to step along.  By the great anchor, what a harpoon he's got
Title:  there! looks like good stuff that; and he handles it about right.  I
Title:  say, Quohog, or whatever your name is, did you ever stand in the head
Title:  of a whale-boat? did you ever strike a fish?"
Title:  
Title:  Without saying a word, Queequeg, in his wild sort of way, jumped upon
Title:  the bulwarks, from thence into the bows of one of the whale-boats
Title:  hanging to the side; and then bracing his left knee, and poising his
Title:  harpoon, cried out in some such way as this:--
Title:  
Title:  "Cap'ain, you see him small drop tar on water dere?  You see him?
Title:  well, spose him one whale eye, well, den!" and taking sharp aim at
Title:  it, he darted the iron right over old Bildad's broad brim, clean
Title:  across the ship's decks, and struck the glistening tar spot out of
Title:  sight.
Title:  
Title:  "Now," said Queequeg, quietly hauling in the line, "spos-ee him
Title:  whale-e eye; why, dad whale dead."
Title:  
Title:  "Quick, Bildad," said Peleg, his partner, who, aghast at the close
Title:  vicinity of the flying harpoon, had retreated towards the cabin
Title:  gangway.  "Quick, I say, you Bildad, and get the ship's papers.  We
Title:  must have Hedgehog there, I mean Quohog, in one of our boats.  Look
Title:  ye, Quohog, we'll give ye the ninetieth lay, and that's more than
Title:  ever was given a harpooneer yet out of Nantucket."
Title:  
Title:  So down we went into the cabin, and to my great joy Queequeg was soon
Title:  enrolled among the same ship's company to which I myself belonged.
Title:  
Title:  When all preliminaries were over and Peleg had got everything ready
Title:  for signing, he turned to me and said, "I guess, Quohog there don't
Title:  know how to write, does he?  I say, Quohog, blast ye! dost thou sign
Title:  thy name or make thy mark?
Title:  
Title:  But at this question, Queequeg, who had twice or thrice before taken
Title:  part in similar ceremonies, looked no ways abashed; but taking the
Title:  offered pen, copied upon the paper, in the proper place, an exact
Title:  counterpart of a queer round figure which was tattooed upon his arm;
Title:  so that through Captain Peleg's obstinate mistake touching his
Title:  appellative, it stood something like this:--
Title:  
Title:  Quohog.
Title:  his X mark.
Title:  
Title:  Meanwhile Captain Bildad sat earnestly and steadfastly eyeing
Title:  Queequeg, and at last rising solemnly and fumbling in the huge
Title:  pockets of his broad-skirted drab coat, took out a bundle of tracts,
Title:  and selecting one entitled "The Latter Day Coming; or No Time to
Title:  Lose," placed it in Queequeg's hands, and then grasping them and the
Title:  book with both his, looked earnestly into his eyes, and said, "Son of
Title:  darkness, I must do my duty by thee; I am part owner of this ship,
Title:  and feel concerned for the souls of all its crew; if thou still
Title:  clingest to thy Pagan ways, which I sadly fear, I beseech thee,
Title:  remain not for aye a Belial bondsman.  Spurn the idol Bell, and the
Title:  hideous dragon; turn from the wrath to come; mind thine eye, I say;
Title:  oh! goodness gracious! steer clear of the fiery pit!"
Title:  
Title:  Something of the salt sea yet lingered in old Bildad's language,
Title:  heterogeneously mixed with Scriptural and domestic phrases.
Title:  
Title:  "Avast there, avast there, Bildad, avast now spoiling our
Title:  harpooneer," Peleg.  "Pious harpooneers never make good voyagers--it
Title:  takes the shark out of 'em; no harpooneer is worth a straw who aint
Title:  pretty sharkish.  There was young Nat Swaine, once the bravest
Title:  boat-header out of all Nantucket and the Vineyard; he joined the
Title:  meeting, and never came to good.  He got so frightened about his
Title:  plaguy soul, that he shrinked and sheered away from whales, for fear
Title:  of after-claps, in case he got stove and went to Davy Jones."
Title:  
Title:  "Peleg!  Peleg!" said Bildad, lifting his eyes and hands, "thou
Title:  thyself, as I myself, hast seen many a perilous time; thou knowest,
Title:  Peleg, what it is to have the fear of death; how, then, can'st thou
Title:  prate in this ungodly guise.  Thou beliest thine own heart, Peleg.
Title:  Tell me, when this same Pequod here had her three masts overboard in
Title:  that typhoon on Japan, that same voyage when thou went mate with
Title:  Captain Ahab, did'st thou not think of Death and the Judgment then?"
Title:  
Title:  "Hear him, hear him now," cried Peleg, marching across the cabin, and
Title:  thrusting his hands far down into his pockets,--"hear him, all of ye.
Title:  Think of that!  When every moment we thought the ship would sink!
Title:  Death and the Judgment then?  What?  With all three masts making such
Title:  an everlasting thundering against the side; and every sea breaking
Title:  over us, fore and aft.  Think of Death and the Judgment then?  No!
Title:  no time to think about Death then.  Life was what Captain Ahab and I
Title:  was thinking of; and how to save all hands--how to rig
Title:  jury-masts--how to get into the nearest port; that was what I was
Title:  thinking of."
Title:  
Title:  Bildad said no more, but buttoning up his coat, stalked on deck,
Title:  where we followed him.  There he stood, very quietly overlooking some
Title:  sailmakers who were mending a top-sail in the waist.  Now and then he
Title:  stooped to pick up a patch, or save an end of tarred twine, which
Title:  otherwise might have been wasted.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 19
Title:  
Title:  The Prophet.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "Shipmates, have ye shipped in that ship?"
Title:  
Title:  Queequeg and I had just left the Pequod, and were sauntering away from
Title:  the water, for the moment each occupied with his own thoughts, when
Title:  the above words were put to us by a stranger, who, pausing before us,
Title:  levelled his massive forefinger at the vessel in question.  He was
Title:  but shabbily apparelled in faded jacket and patched trowsers; a rag
Title:  of a black handkerchief investing his neck.  A confluent small-pox
Title:  had in all directions flowed over his face, and left it like the
Title:  complicated ribbed bed of a torrent, when the rushing waters have
Title:  been dried up.
Title:  
Title:  "Have ye shipped in her?" he repeated.
Title:  
Title:  "You mean the ship Pequod, I suppose," said I, trying to gain a
Title:  little more time for an uninterrupted look at him.
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, the Pequod--that ship there," he said, drawing back his whole
Title:  arm, and then rapidly shoving it straight out from him, with the
Title:  fixed bayonet of his pointed finger darted full at the object.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said I, "we have just signed the articles."
Title:  
Title:  "Anything down there about your souls?"
Title:  
Title:  "About what?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, perhaps you hav'n't got any," he said quickly.  "No matter
Title:  though, I know many chaps that hav'n't got any,--good luck to 'em;
Title:  and they are all the better off for it.  A soul's a sort of a fifth
Title:  wheel to a wagon."
Title:  
Title:  "What are you jabbering about, shipmate?" said I.
Title:  
Title:  "HE'S got enough, though, to make up for all deficiencies of that
Title:  sort in other chaps," abruptly said the stranger, placing a nervous
Title:  emphasis upon the word HE.
Title:  
Title:  "Queequeg," said I, "let's go; this fellow has broken loose from
Title:  somewhere; he's talking about something and somebody we don't know."
Title:  
Title:  "Stop!" cried the stranger.  "Ye said true--ye hav'n't seen Old
Title:  Thunder yet, have ye?"
Title:  
Title:  "Who's Old Thunder?" said I, again riveted with the insane
Title:  earnestness of his manner.
Title:  
Title:  "Captain Ahab."
Title:  
Title:  "What! the captain of our ship, the Pequod?"
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, among some of us old sailor chaps, he goes by that name.  Ye
Title:  hav'n't seen him yet, have ye?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, we hav'n't.  He's sick they say, but is getting better, and will
Title:  be all right again before long."
Title:  
Title:  "All right again before long!" laughed the stranger, with a solemnly
Title:  derisive sort of laugh.  "Look ye; when Captain Ahab is all right,
Title:  then this left arm of mine will be all right; not before."
Title:  
Title:  "What do you know about him?"
Title:  
Title:  "What did they TELL you about him?  Say that!"
Title:  
Title:  "They didn't tell much of anything about him; only I've heard that
Title:  he's a good whale-hunter, and a good captain to his crew."
Title:  
Title:  "That's true, that's true--yes, both true enough.  But you must jump
Title:  when he gives an order.  Step and growl; growl and go--that's the
Title:  word with Captain Ahab.  But nothing about that thing that happened
Title:  to him off Cape Horn, long ago, when he lay like dead for three days
Title:  and nights; nothing about that deadly skrimmage with the Spaniard
Title:  afore the altar in Santa?--heard nothing about that, eh?  Nothing
Title:  about the silver calabash he spat into?  And nothing about his losing
Title:  his leg last voyage, according to the prophecy.  Didn't ye hear a
Title:  word about them matters and something more, eh?  No, I don't think ye
Title:  did; how could ye?  Who knows it?  Not all Nantucket, I guess.  But
Title:  hows'ever, mayhap, ye've heard tell about the leg, and how he lost
Title:  it; aye, ye have heard of that, I dare say.  Oh yes, THAT every one
Title:  knows a'most--I mean they know he's only one leg; and that a
Title:  parmacetti took the other off."
Title:  
Title:  "My friend," said I, "what all this gibberish of yours is about, I
Title:  don't know, and I don't much care; for it seems to me that you must
Title:  be a little damaged in the head.  But if you are speaking of Captain
Title:  Ahab, of that ship there, the Pequod, then let me tell you, that I
Title:  know all about the loss of his leg."
Title:  
Title:  "ALL about it, eh--sure you do?--all?"
Title:  
Title:  "Pretty sure."
Title:  
Title:  With finger pointed and eye levelled at the Pequod, the beggar-like
Title:  stranger stood a moment, as if in a troubled reverie; then starting a
Title:  little, turned and said:--"Ye've shipped, have ye?  Names down on the
Title:  papers?  Well, well, what's signed, is signed; and what's to be, will
Title:  be; and then again, perhaps it won't be, after all.  Anyhow, it's
Title:  all fixed and arranged a'ready; and some sailors or other must go
Title:  with him, I suppose; as well these as any other men, God pity 'em!
Title:  Morning to ye, shipmates, morning; the ineffable heavens bless ye;
Title:  I'm sorry I stopped ye."
Title:  
Title:  "Look here, friend," said I, "if you have anything important to tell
Title:  us, out with it; but if you are only trying to bamboozle us, you are
Title:  mistaken in your game; that's all I have to say."
Title:  
Title:  "And it's said very well, and I like to hear a chap talk up that way;
Title:  you are just the man for him--the likes of ye.  Morning to ye,
Title:  shipmates, morning!  Oh! when ye get there, tell 'em I've concluded
Title:  not to make one of 'em."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, my dear fellow, you can't fool us that way--you can't fool us.
Title:  It is the easiest thing in the world for a man to look as if he had a
Title:  great secret in him."
Title:  
Title:  "Morning to ye, shipmates, morning."
Title:  
Title:  "Morning it is," said I.  "Come along, Queequeg, let's leave this
Title:  crazy man.  But stop, tell me your name, will you?"
Title:  
Title:  "Elijah."
Title:  
Title:  Elijah! thought I, and we walked away, both commenting, after each
Title:  other's fashion, upon this ragged old sailor; and agreed that he was
Title:  nothing but a humbug, trying to be a bugbear.  But we had not gone
Title:  perhaps above a hundred yards, when chancing to turn a corner, and
Title:  looking back as I did so, who should be seen but Elijah following us,
Title:  though at a distance.  Somehow, the sight of him struck me so, that I
Title:  said nothing to Queequeg of his being behind, but passed on with my
Title:  comrade, anxious to see whether the stranger would turn the same
Title:  corner that we did.  He did; and then it seemed to me that he was
Title:  dogging us, but with what intent I could not for the life of me
Title:  imagine.  This circumstance, coupled with his ambiguous,
Title:  half-hinting, half-revealing, shrouded sort of talk, now begat in me
Title:  all kinds of vague wonderments and half-apprehensions, and all
Title:  connected with the Pequod; and Captain Ahab; and the leg he had lost;
Title:  and the Cape Horn fit; and the silver calabash; and what Captain
Title:  Peleg had said of him, when I left the ship the day previous; and the
Title:  prediction of the squaw Tistig; and the voyage we had bound ourselves
Title:  to sail; and a hundred other shadowy things.
Title:  
Title:  I was resolved to satisfy myself whether this ragged Elijah was
Title:  really dogging us or not, and with that intent crossed the way with
Title:  Queequeg, and on that side of it retraced our steps.  But Elijah
Title:  passed on, without seeming to notice us.  This relieved me; and once
Title:  more, and finally as it seemed to me, I pronounced him in my heart, a
Title:  humbug.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 20
Title:  
Title:  All Astir.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  A day or two passed, and there was great activity aboard the Pequod.
Title:  Not only were the old sails being mended, but new sails were coming
Title:  on board, and bolts of canvas, and coils of rigging; in short,
Title:  everything betokened that the ship's preparations were hurrying to a
Title:  close.  Captain Peleg seldom or never went ashore, but sat in his
Title:  wigwam keeping a sharp look-out upon the hands: Bildad did all the
Title:  purchasing and providing at the stores; and the men employed in the
Title:  hold and on the rigging were working till long after night-fall.
Title:  
Title:  On the day following Queequeg's signing the articles, word was given
Title:  at all the inns where the ship's company were stopping, that their
Title:  chests must be on board before night, for there was no telling how
Title:  soon the vessel might be sailing.  So Queequeg and I got down our
Title:  traps, resolving, however, to sleep ashore till the last.  But it
Title:  seems they always give very long notice in these cases, and the ship
Title:  did not sail for several days.  But no wonder; there was a good deal
Title:  to be done, and there is no telling how many things to be thought of,
Title:  before the Pequod was fully equipped.
Title:  
Title:  Every one knows what a multitude of things--beds, sauce-pans, knives
Title:  and forks, shovels and tongs, napkins, nut-crackers, and what not,
Title:  are indispensable to the business of housekeeping.  Just so with
Title:  whaling, which necessitates a three-years' housekeeping upon the wide
Title:  ocean, far from all grocers, costermongers, doctors, bakers, and
Title:  bankers.  And though this also holds true of merchant vessels, yet
Title:  not by any means to the same extent as with whalemen.  For besides
Title:  the great length of the whaling voyage, the numerous articles
Title:  peculiar to the prosecution of the fishery, and the impossibility of
Title:  replacing them at the remote harbors usually frequented, it must be
Title:  remembered, that of all ships, whaling vessels are the most exposed
Title:  to accidents of all kinds, and especially to the destruction and loss
Title:  of the very things upon which the success of the voyage most depends.
Title:  Hence, the spare boats, spare spars, and spare lines and harpoons,
Title:  and spare everythings, almost, but a spare Captain and duplicate
Title:  ship.
Title:  
Title:  At the period of our arrival at the Island, the heaviest storage of
Title:  the Pequod had been almost completed; comprising her beef, bread,
Title:  water, fuel, and iron hoops and staves.  But, as before hinted, for
Title:  some time there was a continual fetching and carrying on board of
Title:  divers odds and ends of things, both large and small.
Title:  
Title:  Chief among those who did this fetching and carrying was Captain
Title:  Bildad's sister, a lean old lady of a most determined and
Title:  indefatigable spirit, but withal very kindhearted, who seemed
Title:  resolved that, if SHE could help it, nothing should be found wanting
Title:  in the Pequod, after once fairly getting to sea.  At one time she
Title:  would come on board with a jar of pickles for the steward's pantry;
Title:  another time with a bunch of quills for the chief mate's desk, where
Title:  he kept his log; a third time with a roll of flannel for the small of
Title:  some one's rheumatic back.  Never did any woman better deserve her
Title:  name, which was Charity--Aunt Charity, as everybody called her.  And
Title:  like a sister of charity did this charitable Aunt Charity bustle
Title:  about hither and thither, ready to turn her hand and heart to
Title:  anything that promised to yield safety, comfort, and consolation to
Title:  all on board a ship in which her beloved brother Bildad was
Title:  concerned, and in which she herself owned a score or two of
Title:  well-saved dollars.
Title:  
Title:  But it was startling to see this excellent hearted Quakeress coming
Title:  on board, as she did the last day, with a long oil-ladle in one hand,
Title:  and a still longer whaling lance in the other.  Nor was Bildad himself
Title:  nor Captain Peleg at all backward.  As for Bildad, he carried about
Title:  with him a long list of the articles needed, and at every fresh
Title:  arrival, down went his mark opposite that article upon the paper.
Title:  Every once in a while Peleg came hobbling out of his whalebone den,
Title:  roaring at the men down the hatchways, roaring up to the riggers at
Title:  the mast-head, and then concluded by roaring back into his wigwam.
Title:  
Title:  During these days of preparation, Queequeg and I often visited the
Title:  craft, and as often I asked about Captain Ahab, and how he was, and
Title:  when he was going to come on board his ship.  To these questions they
Title:  would answer, that he was getting better and better, and was expected
Title:  aboard every day; meantime, the two captains, Peleg and Bildad, could
Title:  attend to everything necessary to fit the vessel for the voyage.  If
Title:  I had been downright honest with myself, I would have seen very
Title:  plainly in my heart that I did but half fancy being committed this
Title:  way to so long a voyage, without once laying my eyes on the man who
Title:  was to be the absolute dictator of it, so soon as the ship sailed out
Title:  upon the open sea.  But when a man suspects any wrong, it sometimes
Title:  happens that if he be already involved in the matter, he insensibly
Title:  strives to cover up his suspicions even from himself.  And much this
Title:  way it was with me.  I said nothing, and tried to think nothing.
Title:  
Title:  At last it was given out that some time next day the ship would
Title:  certainly sail.  So next morning, Queequeg and I took a very early
Title:  start.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 21
Title:  
Title:  Going Aboard.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  It was nearly six o'clock, but only grey imperfect misty dawn, when
Title:  we drew nigh the wharf.
Title:  
Title:  "There are some sailors running ahead there, if I see right," said I
Title:  to Queequeg, "it can't be shadows; she's off by sunrise, I guess;
Title:  come on!"
Title:  
Title:  "Avast!" cried a voice, whose owner at the same time coming close
Title:  behind us, laid a hand upon both our shoulders, and then insinuating
Title:  himself between us, stood stooping forward a little, in the uncertain
Title:  twilight, strangely peering from Queequeg to me.  It was Elijah.
Title:  
Title:  "Going aboard?"
Title:  
Title:  "Hands off, will you," said I.
Title:  
Title:  "Lookee here," said Queequeg, shaking himself, "go 'way!"
Title:  
Title:  "Ain't going aboard, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, we are," said I, "but what business is that of yours?  Do you
Title:  know, Mr. Elijah, that I consider you a little impertinent?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, no, no; I wasn't aware of that," said Elijah, slowly and
Title:  wonderingly looking from me to Queequeg, with the most unaccountable
Title:  glances.
Title:  
Title:  "Elijah," said I, "you will oblige my friend and me by withdrawing.
Title:  We are going to the Indian and Pacific Oceans, and would prefer not
Title:  to be detained."
Title:  
Title:  "Ye be, be ye?  Coming back afore breakfast?"
Title:  
Title:  "He's cracked, Queequeg," said I, "come on."
Title:  
Title:  "Holloa!" cried stationary Elijah, hailing us when we had removed a
Title:  few paces.
Title:  
Title:  "Never mind him," said I, "Queequeg, come on."
Title:  
Title:  But he stole up to us again, and suddenly clapping his hand on my
Title:  shoulder, said--"Did ye see anything looking like men going towards
Title:  that ship a while ago?"
Title:  
Title:  Struck by this plain matter-of-fact question, I answered, saying,
Title:  "Yes, I thought I did see four or five men; but it was too dim to be
Title:  sure."
Title:  
Title:  "Very dim, very dim," said Elijah.  "Morning to ye."
Title:  
Title:  Once more we quitted him; but once more he came softly after us; and
Title:  touching my shoulder again, said, "See if you can find 'em now, will
Title:  ye?
Title:  
Title:  "Find who?"
Title:  
Title:  "Morning to ye! morning to ye!" he rejoined, again moving off.  "Oh!
Title:  I was going to warn ye against--but never mind, never mind--it's all
Title:  one, all in the family too;--sharp frost this morning, ain't it?
Title:  Good-bye to ye.  Shan't see ye again very soon, I guess; unless it's
Title:  before the Grand Jury."  And with these cracked words he finally
Title:  departed, leaving me, for the moment, in no small wonderment at his
Title:  frantic impudence.
Title:  
Title:  At last, stepping on board the Pequod, we found everything in
Title:  profound quiet, not a soul moving.  The cabin entrance was locked
Title:  within; the hatches were all on, and lumbered with coils of rigging.
Title:  Going forward to the forecastle, we found the slide of the scuttle
Title:  open.  Seeing a light, we went down, and found only an old rigger
Title:  there, wrapped in a tattered pea-jacket.  He was thrown at whole
Title:  length upon two chests, his face downwards and inclosed in his folded
Title:  arms.  The profoundest slumber slept upon him.
Title:  
Title:  "Those sailors we saw, Queequeg, where can they have gone to?" said
Title:  I, looking dubiously at the sleeper.  But it seemed that, when on the
Title:  wharf, Queequeg had not at all noticed what I now alluded to; hence I
Title:  would have thought myself to have been optically deceived in that
Title:  matter, were it not for Elijah's otherwise inexplicable question.
Title:  But I beat the thing down; and again marking the sleeper, jocularly
Title:  hinted to Queequeg that perhaps we had best sit up with the body;
Title:  telling him to establish himself accordingly.  He put his hand upon
Title:  the sleeper's rear, as though feeling if it was soft enough; and
Title:  then, without more ado, sat quietly down there.
Title:  
Title:  "Gracious!  Queequeg, don't sit there," said I.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh! perry dood seat," said Queequeg, "my country way; won't hurt
Title:  him face."
Title:  
Title:  "Face!" said I, "call that his face? very benevolent countenance
Title:  then; but how hard he breathes, he's heaving himself; get off,
Title:  Queequeg, you are heavy, it's grinding the face of the poor.  Get
Title:  off, Queequeg!  Look, he'll twitch you off soon.  I wonder he don't
Title:  wake."
Title:  
Title:  Queequeg removed himself to just beyond the head of the sleeper, and
Title:  lighted his tomahawk pipe.  I sat at the feet.  We kept the pipe
Title:  passing over the sleeper, from one to the other.  Meanwhile, upon
Title:  questioning him in his broken fashion, Queequeg gave me to understand
Title:  that, in his land, owing to the absence of settees and sofas of all
Title:  sorts, the king, chiefs, and great people generally, were in the
Title:  custom of fattening some of the lower orders for ottomans; and to
Title:  furnish a house comfortably in that respect, you had only to buy up
Title:  eight or ten lazy fellows, and lay them round in the piers and
Title:  alcoves.  Besides, it was very convenient on an excursion; much
Title:  better than those garden-chairs which are convertible into
Title:  walking-sticks; upon occasion, a chief calling his attendant, and
Title:  desiring him to make a settee of himself under a spreading tree,
Title:  perhaps in some damp marshy place.
Title:  
Title:  While narrating these things, every time Queequeg received the
Title:  tomahawk from me, he flourished the hatchet-side of it over the
Title:  sleeper's head.
Title:  
Title:  "What's that for, Queequeg?"
Title:  
Title:  "Perry easy, kill-e; oh! perry easy!
Title:  
Title:  He was going on with some wild reminiscences about his tomahawk-pipe,
Title:  which, it seemed, had in its two uses both brained his foes and
Title:  soothed his soul, when we were directly attracted to the sleeping
Title:  rigger.  The strong vapour now completely filling the contracted hole,
Title:  it began to tell upon him.  He breathed with a sort of muffledness;
Title:  then seemed troubled in the nose; then revolved over once or twice;
Title:  then sat up and rubbed his eyes.
Title:  
Title:  "Holloa!" he breathed at last, "who be ye smokers?"
Title:  
Title:  "Shipped men," answered I, "when does she sail?"
Title:
