Title:  "Aye, aye, ye are going in her, be ye?  She sails to-day.  The
Title:  Captain came aboard last night."
Title:  
Title:  "What Captain?--Ahab?"
Title:  
Title:  "Who but him indeed?"
Title:  
Title:  I was going to ask him some further questions concerning Ahab, when
Title:  we heard a noise on deck.
Title:  
Title:  "Holloa!  Starbuck's astir," said the rigger.  "He's a lively chief
Title:  mate, that; good man, and a pious; but all alive now, I must turn
Title:  to."  And so saying he went on deck, and we followed.
Title:  
Title:  It was now clear sunrise.  Soon the crew came on board in twos and
Title:  threes; the riggers bestirred themselves; the mates were actively
Title:  engaged; and several of the shore people were busy in bringing
Title:  various last things on board.  Meanwhile Captain Ahab remained
Title:  invisibly enshrined within his cabin.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 22
Title:  
Title:  Merry Christmas.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  At length, towards noon, upon the final dismissal of the ship's
Title:  riggers, and after the Pequod had been hauled out from the wharf, and
Title:  after the ever-thoughtful Charity had come off in a whale-boat, with
Title:  her last gift--a night-cap for Stubb, the second mate, her
Title:  brother-in-law, and a spare Bible for the steward--after all this,
Title:  the two Captains, Peleg and Bildad, issued from the cabin, and
Title:  turning to the chief mate, Peleg said:
Title:  
Title:  "Now, Mr. Starbuck, are you sure everything is right?  Captain Ahab
Title:  is all ready--just spoke to him--nothing more to be got from shore,
Title:  eh?  Well, call all hands, then.  Muster 'em aft here--blast 'em!"
Title:  
Title:  "No need of profane words, however great the hurry, Peleg," said
Title:  Bildad, "but away with thee, friend Starbuck, and do our bidding."
Title:  
Title:  How now!  Here upon the very point of starting for the voyage,
Title:  Captain Peleg and Captain Bildad were going it with a high hand on
Title:  the quarter-deck, just as if they were to be joint-commanders at sea,
Title:  as well as to all appearances in port.  And, as for Captain Ahab, no
Title:  sign of him was yet to be seen; only, they said he was in the cabin.
Title:  But then, the idea was, that his presence was by no means necessary
Title:  in getting the ship under weigh, and steering her well out to sea.
Title:  Indeed, as that was not at all his proper business, but the pilot's;
Title:  and as he was not yet completely recovered--so they said--therefore,
Title:  Captain Ahab stayed below.  And all this seemed natural enough;
Title:  especially as in the merchant service many captains never show
Title:  themselves on deck for a considerable time after heaving up the
Title:  anchor, but remain over the cabin table, having a farewell
Title:  merry-making with their shore friends, before they quit the ship for
Title:  good with the pilot.
Title:  
Title:  But there was not much chance to think over the matter, for Captain
Title:  Peleg was now all alive.  He seemed to do most of the talking and
Title:  commanding, and not Bildad.
Title:  
Title:  "Aft here, ye sons of bachelors," he cried, as the sailors lingered
Title:  at the main-mast.  "Mr. Starbuck, drive'em aft."
Title:  
Title:  "Strike the tent there!"--was the next order.  As I hinted before,
Title:  this whalebone marquee was never pitched except in port; and on board
Title:  the Pequod, for thirty years, the order to strike the tent was well
Title:  known to be the next thing to heaving up the anchor.
Title:  
Title:  "Man the capstan!  Blood and thunder!--jump!"--was the next command,
Title:  and the crew sprang for the handspikes.
Title:  
Title:  Now in getting under weigh, the station generally occupied by the
Title:  pilot is the forward part of the ship.  And here Bildad, who, with
Title:  Peleg, be it known, in addition to his other officers, was one of the
Title:  licensed pilots of the port--he being suspected to have got himself
Title:  made a pilot in order to save the Nantucket pilot-fee to all the
Title:  ships he was concerned in, for he never piloted any other
Title:  craft--Bildad, I say, might now be seen actively engaged in looking
Title:  over the bows for the approaching anchor, and at intervals singing
Title:  what seemed a dismal stave of psalmody, to cheer the hands at the
Title:  windlass, who roared forth some sort of a chorus about the girls in
Title:  Booble Alley, with hearty good will.  Nevertheless, not three days
Title:  previous, Bildad had told them that no profane songs would be allowed
Title:  on board the Pequod, particularly in getting under weigh; and
Title:  Charity, his sister, had placed a small choice copy of Watts in each
Title:  seaman's berth.
Title:  
Title:  Meantime, overseeing the other part of the ship, Captain Peleg ripped
Title:  and swore astern in the most frightful manner.  I almost thought he
Title:  would sink the ship before the anchor could be got up; involuntarily
Title:  I paused on my handspike, and told Queequeg to do the same, thinking
Title:  of the perils we both ran, in starting on the voyage with such a
Title:  devil for a pilot.  I was comforting myself, however, with the
Title:  thought that in pious Bildad might be found some salvation, spite of
Title:  his seven hundred and seventy-seventh lay; when I felt a sudden sharp
Title:  poke in my rear, and turning round, was horrified at the apparition
Title:  of Captain Peleg in the act of withdrawing his leg from my immediate
Title:  vicinity.  That was my first kick.
Title:  
Title:  "Is that the way they heave in the marchant service?" he roared.
Title:  "Spring, thou sheep-head; spring, and break thy backbone!  Why don't
Title:  ye spring, I say, all of ye--spring!  Quohog! spring, thou chap with
Title:  the red whiskers; spring there, Scotch-cap; spring, thou green
Title:  pants.  Spring, I say, all of ye, and spring your eyes out!"  And so
Title:  saying, he moved along the windlass, here and there using his leg
Title:  very freely, while imperturbable Bildad kept leading off with his
Title:  psalmody.  Thinks I, Captain Peleg must have been drinking something
Title:  to-day.
Title:  
Title:  At last the anchor was up, the sails were set, and off we glided.  It
Title:  was a short, cold Christmas; and as the short northern day merged
Title:  into night, we found ourselves almost broad upon the wintry ocean,
Title:  whose freezing spray cased us in ice, as in polished armor.  The long
Title:  rows of teeth on the bulwarks glistened in the moonlight; and like
Title:  the white ivory tusks of some huge elephant, vast curving icicles
Title:  depended from the bows.
Title:  
Title:  Lank Bildad, as pilot, headed the first watch, and ever and anon, as
Title:  the old craft deep dived into the green seas, and sent the shivering
Title:  frost all over her, and the winds howled, and the cordage rang, his
Title:  steady notes were heard,--
Title:  
Title:  "Sweet fields beyond the swelling flood,
Title:  Stand dressed in living green.
Title:  So to the Jews old Canaan stood,
Title:  While Jordan rolled between."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Never did those sweet words sound more sweetly to me than then.  They
Title:  were full of hope and fruition.  Spite of this frigid winter night in
Title:  the boisterous Atlantic, spite of my wet feet and wetter jacket,
Title:  there was yet, it then seemed to me, many a pleasant haven in store;
Title:  and meads and glades so eternally vernal, that the grass shot up by
Title:  the spring, untrodden, unwilted, remains at midsummer.
Title:  
Title:  At last we gained such an offing, that the two pilots were needed no
Title:  longer.  The stout sail-boat that had accompanied us began ranging
Title:  alongside.
Title:  
Title:  It was curious and not unpleasing, how Peleg and Bildad were affected
Title:  at this juncture, especially Captain Bildad.  For loath to depart,
Title:  yet; very loath to leave, for good, a ship bound on so long and
Title:  perilous a voyage--beyond both stormy Capes; a ship in which some
Title:  thousands of his hard earned dollars were invested; a ship, in which
Title:  an old shipmate sailed as captain; a man almost as old as he, once
Title:  more starting to encounter all the terrors of the pitiless jaw; loath
Title:  to say good-bye to a thing so every way brimful of every interest to
Title:  him,--poor old Bildad lingered long; paced the deck with anxious
Title:  strides; ran down into the cabin to speak another farewell word
Title:  there; again came on deck, and looked to windward; looked towards the
Title:  wide and endless waters, only bounded by the far-off unseen Eastern
Title:  Continents; looked towards the land; looked aloft; looked right and
Title:  left; looked everywhere and nowhere; and at last, mechanically
Title:  coiling a rope upon its pin, convulsively grasped stout Peleg by the
Title:  hand, and holding up a lantern, for a moment stood gazing heroically
Title:  in his face, as much as to say, "Nevertheless, friend Peleg, I can
Title:  stand it; yes, I can."
Title:  
Title:  As for Peleg himself, he took it more like a philosopher; but for all
Title:  his philosophy, there was a tear twinkling in his eye, when the
Title:  lantern came too near.  And he, too, did not a little run from cabin
Title:  to deck--now a word below, and now a word with Starbuck, the chief
Title:  mate.
Title:  
Title:  But, at last, he turned to his comrade, with a final sort of look
Title:  about him,--"Captain Bildad--come, old shipmate, we must go.  Back
Title:  the main-yard there!  Boat ahoy!  Stand by to come close alongside,
Title:  now!  Careful, careful!--come, Bildad, boy--say your last.  Luck to
Title:  ye, Starbuck--luck to ye, Mr. Stubb--luck to ye, Mr. Flask--good-bye
Title:  and good luck to ye all--and this day three years I'll have a hot
Title:  supper smoking for ye in old Nantucket.  Hurrah and away!"
Title:  
Title:  "God bless ye, and have ye in His holy keeping, men," murmured old
Title:  Bildad, almost incoherently.  "I hope ye'll have fine weather now, so
Title:  that Captain Ahab may soon be moving among ye--a pleasant sun is all
Title:  he needs, and ye'll have plenty of them in the tropic voyage ye go.
Title:  Be careful in the hunt, ye mates.  Don't stave the boats needlessly,
Title:  ye harpooneers; good white cedar plank is raised full three per cent.
Title:  within the year.  Don't forget your prayers, either.  Mr. Starbuck,
Title:  mind that cooper don't waste the spare staves.  Oh! the sail-needles
Title:  are in the green locker!  Don't whale it too much a' Lord's days,
Title:  men; but don't miss a fair chance either, that's rejecting Heaven's
Title:  good gifts.  Have an eye to the molasses tierce, Mr. Stubb; it was a
Title:  little leaky, I thought.  If ye touch at the islands, Mr. Flask,
Title:  beware of fornication.  Good-bye, good-bye!  Don't keep that cheese
Title:  too long down in the hold, Mr. Starbuck; it'll spoil.  Be careful
Title:  with the butter--twenty cents the pound it was, and mind ye, if--"
Title:  
Title:  "Come, come, Captain Bildad; stop palavering,--away!" and with that,
Title:  Peleg hurried him over the side, and both dropt into the boat.
Title:  
Title:  Ship and boat diverged; the cold, damp night breeze blew between; a
Title:  screaming gull flew overhead; the two hulls wildly rolled; we gave
Title:  three heavy-hearted cheers, and blindly plunged like fate into the
Title:  lone Atlantic.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 23
Title:  
Title:  The Lee Shore.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Some chapters back, one Bulkington was spoken of, a tall, newlanded
Title:  mariner, encountered in New Bedford at the inn.
Title:  
Title:  When on that shivering winter's night, the Pequod thrust her
Title:  vindictive bows into the cold malicious waves, who should I see
Title:  standing at her helm but Bulkington!  I looked with sympathetic awe
Title:  and fearfulness upon the man, who in mid-winter just landed from a
Title:  four years' dangerous voyage, could so unrestingly push off again for
Title:  still another tempestuous term.  The land seemed scorching to his
Title:  feet.  Wonderfullest things are ever the unmentionable; deep memories
Title:  yield no epitaphs; this six-inch chapter is the stoneless grave of
Title:  Bulkington.  Let me only say that it fared with him as with the
Title:  storm-tossed ship, that miserably drives along the leeward land.  The
Title:  port would fain give succor; the port is pitiful; in the port is
Title:  safety, comfort, hearthstone, supper, warm blankets, friends, all
Title:  that's kind to our mortalities.  But in that gale, the port, the
Title:  land, is that ship's direst jeopardy; she must fly all hospitality;
Title:  one touch of land, though it but graze the keel, would make her
Title:  shudder through and through.  With all her might she crowds all sail
Title:  off shore; in so doing, fights 'gainst the very winds that fain would
Title:  blow her homeward; seeks all the lashed sea's landlessness again; for
Title:  refuge's sake forlornly rushing into peril; her only friend her
Title:  bitterest foe!
Title:  
Title:  Know ye now, Bulkington?  Glimpses do ye seem to see of that mortally
Title:  intolerable truth; that all deep, earnest thinking is but the
Title:  intrepid effort of the soul to keep the open independence of her sea;
Title:  while the wildest winds of heaven and earth conspire to cast her on
Title:  the treacherous, slavish shore?
Title:  
Title:  But as in landlessness alone resides highest truth, shoreless,
Title:  indefinite as God--so, better is it to perish in that howling
Title:  infinite, than be ingloriously dashed upon the lee, even if that were
Title:  safety!  For worm-like, then, oh! who would craven crawl to land!
Title:  Terrors of the terrible! is all this agony so vain?  Take heart, take
Title:  heart, O Bulkington!  Bear thee grimly, demigod!  Up from the spray
Title:  of thy ocean-perishing--straight up, leaps thy apotheosis!
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 24
Title:  
Title:  The Advocate.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  As Queequeg and I are now fairly embarked in this business of
Title:  whaling; and as this business of whaling has somehow come to be
Title:  regarded among landsmen as a rather unpoetical and disreputable
Title:  pursuit; therefore, I am all anxiety to convince ye, ye landsmen, of
Title:  the injustice hereby done to us hunters of whales.
Title:  
Title:  In the first place, it may be deemed almost superfluous to establish
Title:  the fact, that among people at large, the business of whaling is not
Title:  accounted on a level with what are called the liberal professions.
Title:  If a stranger were introduced into any miscellaneous metropolitan
Title:  society, it would but slightly advance the general opinion of his
Title:  merits, were he presented to the company as a harpooneer, say; and if
Title:  in emulation of the naval officers he should append the initials
Title:  S.W.F. (Sperm Whale Fishery) to his visiting card, such a procedure
Title:  would be deemed pre-eminently presuming and ridiculous.
Title:  
Title:  Doubtless one leading reason why the world declines honouring us
Title:  whalemen, is this: they think that, at best, our vocation amounts to
Title:  a butchering sort of business; and that when actively engaged
Title:  therein, we are surrounded by all manner of defilements.  Butchers we
Title:  are, that is true.  But butchers, also, and butchers of the bloodiest
Title:  badge have been all Martial Commanders whom the world invariably
Title:  delights to honour.  And as for the matter of the alleged
Title:  uncleanliness of our business, ye shall soon be initiated into
Title:  certain facts hitherto pretty generally unknown, and which, upon the
Title:  whole, will triumphantly plant the sperm whale-ship at least among
Title:  the cleanliest things of this tidy earth.  But even granting the
Title:  charge in question to be true; what disordered slippery decks of a
Title:  whale-ship are comparable to the unspeakable carrion of those
Title:  battle-fields from which so many soldiers return to drink in all
Title:  ladies' plaudits?  And if the idea of peril so much enhances the
Title:  popular conceit of the soldier's profession; let me assure ye that
Title:  many a veteran who has freely marched up to a battery, would quickly
Title:  recoil at the apparition of the sperm whale's vast tail, fanning into
Title:  eddies the air over his head.  For what are the comprehensible
Title:  terrors of man compared with the interlinked terrors and wonders of
Title:  God!
Title:  
Title:  But, though the world scouts at us whale hunters, yet does it
Title:  unwittingly pay us the profoundest homage; yea, an all-abounding
Title:  adoration! for almost all the tapers, lamps, and candles that burn
Title:  round the globe, burn, as before so many shrines, to our glory!
Title:  
Title:  But look at this matter in other lights; weigh it in all sorts of
Title:  scales; see what we whalemen are, and have been.
Title:  
Title:  Why did the Dutch in De Witt's time have admirals of their whaling
Title:  fleets?  Why did Louis XVI. of France, at his own personal expense,
Title:  fit out whaling ships from Dunkirk, and politely invite to that town
Title:  some score or two of families from our own island of Nantucket?  Why
Title:  did Britain between the years 1750 and 1788 pay to her whalemen in
Title:  bounties upwards of L1,000,000?  And lastly, how comes it that we
Title:  whalemen of America now outnumber all the rest of the banded whalemen
Title:  in the world; sail a navy of upwards of seven hundred vessels; manned
Title:  by eighteen thousand men; yearly consuming 4,000,000 of dollars; the
Title:  ships worth, at the time of sailing, $20,000,000! and every year
Title:  importing into our harbors a well reaped harvest of $7,000,000.  How
Title:  comes all this, if there be not something puissant in whaling?
Title:  
Title:  But this is not the half; look again.
Title:  
Title:  I freely assert, that the cosmopolite philosopher cannot, for his
Title:  life, point out one single peaceful influence, which within the last
Title:  sixty years has operated more potentially upon the whole broad world,
Title:  taken in one aggregate, than the high and mighty business of whaling.
Title:  One way and another, it has begotten events so remarkable in
Title:  themselves, and so continuously momentous in their sequential issues,
Title:  that whaling may well be regarded as that Egyptian mother, who bore
Title:  offspring themselves pregnant from her womb.  It would be a hopeless,
Title:  endless task to catalogue all these things.  Let a handful suffice.
Title:  For many years past the whale-ship has been the pioneer in ferreting
Title:  out the remotest and least known parts of the earth.  She has
Title:  explored seas and archipelagoes which had no chart, where no Cook or
Title:  Vancouver had ever sailed.  If American and European men-of-war
Title:  now peacefully ride in once savage harbors, let them fire salutes to
Title:  the honour and glory of the whale-ship, which originally showed them
Title:  the way, and first interpreted between them and the savages.  They
Title:  may celebrate as they will the heroes of Exploring Expeditions, your
Title:  Cooks, your Krusensterns; but I say that scores of anonymous
Title:  Captains have sailed out of Nantucket, that were as great, and
Title:  greater than your Cook and your Krusenstern.  For in their
Title:  succourless empty-handedness, they, in the heathenish sharked waters,
Title:  and by the beaches of unrecorded, javelin islands, battled with
Title:  virgin wonders and terrors that Cook with all his marines and
Title:  muskets would not willingly have dared.  All that is made such a
Title:  flourish of in the old South Sea Voyages, those things were but the
Title:  life-time commonplaces of our heroic Nantucketers.  Often,
Title:  adventures which Vancouver dedicates three chapters to, these men
Title:  accounted unworthy of being set down in the ship's common log.  Ah,
Title:  the world!  Oh, the world!
Title:  
Title:  Until the whale fishery rounded Cape Horn, no commerce but colonial,
Title:  scarcely any intercourse but colonial, was carried on between Europe
Title:  and the long line of the opulent Spanish provinces on the Pacific
Title:  coast.  It was the whaleman who first broke through the jealous
Title:  policy of the Spanish crown, touching those colonies; and, if space
Title:  permitted, it might be distinctly shown how from those whalemen at
Title:  last eventuated the liberation of Peru, Chili, and Bolivia from the
Title:  yoke of Old Spain, and the establishment of the eternal democracy in
Title:  those parts.
Title:  
Title:  That great America on the other side of the sphere, Australia, was
Title:  given to the enlightened world by the whaleman.  After its first
Title:  blunder-born discovery by a Dutchman, all other ships long shunned
Title:  those shores as pestiferously barbarous; but the whale-ship touched
Title:  there.  The whale-ship is the true mother of that now mighty colony.
Title:  Moreover, in the infancy of the first Australian settlement, the
Title:  emigrants were several times saved from starvation by the benevolent
Title:  biscuit of the whale-ship luckily dropping an anchor in their waters.
Title:  The uncounted isles of all Polynesia confess the same truth, and do
Title:  commercial homage to the whale-ship, that cleared the way for the
Title:  missionary and the merchant, and in many cases carried the primitive
Title:  missionaries to their first destinations.  If that double-bolted
Title:  land, Japan, is ever to become hospitable, it is the whale-ship alone
Title:  to whom the credit will be due; for already she is on the threshold.
Title:  
Title:  But if, in the face of all this, you still declare that whaling has
Title:  no aesthetically noble associations connected with it, then am I
Title:  ready to shiver fifty lances with you there, and unhorse you with a
Title:  split helmet every time.
Title:  
Title:  The whale has no famous author, and whaling no famous chronicler, you
Title:  will say.
Title:  
Title:  THE WHALE NO FAMOUS AUTHOR, AND WHALING NO FAMOUS CHRONICLER?  Who
Title:  wrote the first account of our Leviathan?  Who but mighty Job!  And
Title:  who composed the first narrative of a whaling-voyage?  Who, but no
Title:  less a prince than Alfred the Great, who, with his own royal pen,
Title:  took down the words from Other, the Norwegian whale-hunter of those
Title:  times!  And who pronounced our glowing eulogy in Parliament?  Who,
Title:  but Edmund Burke!
Title:  
Title:  True enough, but then whalemen themselves are poor devils; they have
Title:  no good blood in their veins.
Title:  
Title:  NO GOOD BLOOD IN THEIR VEINS?  They have something better than royal
Title:  blood there.  The grandmother of Benjamin Franklin was Mary Morrel;
Title:  afterwards, by marriage, Mary Folger, one of the old settlers of
Title:  Nantucket, and the ancestress to a long line of Folgers and
Title:  harpooneers--all kith and kin to noble Benjamin--this day darting the
Title:  barbed iron from one side of the world to the other.
Title:  
Title:  Good again; but then all confess that somehow whaling is not
Title:  respectable.
Title:  
Title:  WHALING NOT RESPECTABLE?  Whaling is imperial!  By old English
Title:  statutory law, the whale is declared "a royal fish."*
Title:  
Title:  Oh, that's only nominal!  The whale himself has never figured in any
Title:  grand imposing way.
Title:  
Title:  THE WHALE NEVER FIGURED IN ANY GRAND IMPOSING WAY?  In one of the
Title:  mighty triumphs given to a Roman general upon his entering the
Title:  world's capital, the bones of a whale, brought all the way from the
Title:  Syrian coast, were the most conspicuous object in the cymballed
Title:  procession.*
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *See subsequent chapters for something more on this head.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Grant it, since you cite it; but, say what you will, there is no real
Title:  dignity in whaling.
Title:  
Title:  NO DIGNITY IN WHALING?  The dignity of our calling the very heavens
Title:  attest.  Cetus is a constellation in the South!  No more!  Drive
Title:  down your hat in presence of the Czar, and take it off to Queequeg!
Title:  No more!  I know a man that, in his lifetime, has taken three hundred
Title:  and fifty whales.  I account that man more honourable than that great
Title:  captain of antiquity who boasted of taking as many walled towns.
Title:  
Title:  And, as for me, if, by any possibility, there be any as yet
Title:  undiscovered prime thing in me; if I shall ever deserve any real
Title:  repute in that small but high hushed world which I might not be
Title:  unreasonably ambitious of; if hereafter I shall do anything that, upon
Title:  the whole, a man might rather have done than to have left undone; if,
Title:  at my death, my executors, or more properly my creditors, find any
Title:  precious MSS. in my desk, then here I prospectively ascribe all the
Title:  honour and the glory to whaling; for a whale-ship was my Yale College
Title:  and my Harvard.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 25
Title:  
Title:  Postscript.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  In behalf of the dignity of whaling, I would fain advance naught but
Title:  substantiated facts.  But after embattling his facts, an advocate who
Title:  should wholly suppress a not unreasonable surmise, which might tell
Title:  eloquently upon his cause--such an advocate, would he not be
Title:  blameworthy?
Title:  
Title:  It is well known that at the coronation of kings and queens, even
Title:  modern ones, a certain curious process of seasoning them for their
Title:  functions is gone through.  There is a saltcellar of state, so
Title:  called, and there may be a castor of state.  How they use the salt,
Title:  precisely--who knows?  Certain I am, however, that a king's head is
Title:  solemnly oiled at his coronation, even as a head of salad.  Can it
Title:  be, though, that they anoint it with a view of making its interior
Title:  run well, as they anoint machinery?  Much might be ruminated here,
Title:  concerning the essential dignity of this regal process, because in
Title:  common life we esteem but meanly and contemptibly a fellow who
Title:  anoints his hair, and palpably smells of that anointing.  In truth, a
Title:  mature man who uses hair-oil, unless medicinally, that man has
Title:  probably got a quoggy spot in him somewhere.  As a general rule, he
Title:  can't amount to much in his totality.
Title:  
Title:  But the only thing to be considered here, is this--what kind of oil
Title:  is used at coronations?  Certainly it cannot be olive oil, nor
Title:  macassar oil, nor castor oil, nor bear's oil, nor train oil, nor
Title:  cod-liver oil.  What then can it possibly be, but sperm oil in
Title:  its unmanufactured, unpolluted state, the sweetest of all oils?
Title:  
Title:  Think of that, ye loyal Britons! we whalemen supply your kings and
Title:  queens with coronation stuff!
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 26
Title:  
Title:  Knights and Squires.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  The chief mate of the Pequod was Starbuck, a native of Nantucket, and
Title:  a Quaker by descent.  He was a long, earnest man, and though born on
Title:  an icy coast, seemed well adapted to endure hot latitudes, his flesh
Title:  being hard as twice-baked biscuit.  Transported to the Indies, his
Title:  live blood would not spoil like bottled ale.  He must have been born
Title:  in some time of general drought and famine, or upon one of those fast
Title:  days for which his state is famous.  Only some thirty arid summers
Title:  had he seen; those summers had dried up all his physical
Title:  superfluousness.  But this, his thinness, so to speak, seemed no more
Title:  the token of wasting anxieties and cares, than it seemed the
Title:  indication of any bodily blight.  It was merely the condensation of
Title:  the man.  He was by no means ill-looking; quite the contrary.  His
Title:  pure tight skin was an excellent fit; and closely wrapped up in it,
Title:  and embalmed with inner health and strength, like a revivified
Title:  Egyptian, this Starbuck seemed prepared to endure for long ages to
Title:  come, and to endure always, as now; for be it Polar snow or torrid
Title:  sun, like a patent chronometer, his interior vitality was warranted
Title:  to do well in all climates.  Looking into his eyes, you seemed to
Title:  see there the yet lingering images of those thousand-fold perils he
Title:  had calmly confronted through life.  A staid, steadfast man, whose
Title:  life for the most part was a telling pantomime of action, and not a
Title:  tame chapter of sounds.  Yet, for all his hardy sobriety and
Title:  fortitude, there were certain qualities in him which at times
Title:  affected, and in some cases seemed well nigh to overbalance all the
Title:  rest.  Uncommonly conscientious for a seaman, and endued with a deep
Title:  natural reverence, the wild watery loneliness of his life did
Title:  therefore strongly incline him to superstition; but to that sort of
Title:  superstition, which in some organizations seems rather to spring,
Title:  somehow, from intelligence than from ignorance.  Outward portents and
Title:  inward presentiments were his.  And if at times these things bent the
Title:  welded iron of his soul, much more did his far-away domestic memories
Title:  of his young Cape wife and child, tend to bend him still more from
Title:  the original ruggedness of his nature, and open him still further to
Title:  those latent influences which, in some honest-hearted men, restrain
Title:  the gush of dare-devil daring, so often evinced by others in the more
Title:  perilous vicissitudes of the fishery.  "I will have no man in my
Title:  boat," said Starbuck, "who is not afraid of a whale."  By this, he
Title:  seemed to mean, not only that the most reliable and useful courage
Title:  was that which arises from the fair estimation of the encountered
Title:  peril, but that an utterly fearless man is a far more dangerous
Title:  comrade than a coward.
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, aye," said Stubb, the second mate, "Starbuck, there, is as
Title:  careful a man as you'll find anywhere in this fishery."  But we shall
Title:  ere long see what that word "careful" precisely means when used by a
Title:  man like Stubb, or almost any other whale hunter.
Title:  
Title:  Starbuck was no crusader after perils; in him courage was not a
Title:  sentiment; but a thing simply useful to him, and always at hand upon
Title:  all mortally practical occasions.  Besides, he thought, perhaps, that
Title:  in this business of whaling, courage was one of the great staple
Title:  outfits of the ship, like her beef and her bread, and not to be
Title:  foolishly wasted.  Wherefore he had no fancy for lowering for whales
Title:  after sun-down; nor for persisting in fighting a fish that too much
Title:  persisted in fighting him.  For, thought Starbuck, I am here in this
Title:  critical ocean to kill whales for my living, and not to be killed by
Title:  them for theirs; and that hundreds of men had been so killed Starbuck
Title:  well knew.  What doom was his own father's?  Where, in the bottomless
Title:  deeps, could he find the torn limbs of his brother?
Title:  
Title:  With memories like these in him, and, moreover, given to a certain
Title:  superstitiousness, as has been said; the courage of this Starbuck
Title:  which could, nevertheless, still flourish, must indeed have been
Title:  extreme.  But it was not in reasonable nature that a man so
Title:  organized, and with such terrible experiences and remembrances as he
Title:  had; it was not in nature that these things should fail in latently
Title:  engendering an element in him, which, under suitable circumstances,
Title:  would break out from its confinement, and burn all his courage up.
Title:  And brave as he might be, it was that sort of bravery chiefly,
Title:  visible in some intrepid men, which, while generally abiding firm in
Title:  the conflict with seas, or winds, or whales, or any of the ordinary
Title:  irrational horrors of the world, yet cannot withstand those more
Title:  terrific, because more spiritual terrors, which sometimes menace you
Title:  from the concentrating brow of an enraged and mighty man.
Title:  
Title:  But were the coming narrative to reveal in any instance, the complete
Title:  abasement of poor Starbuck's fortitude, scarce might I have the heart
Title:  to write it; for it is a thing most sorrowful, nay shocking, to
Title:  expose the fall of valour in the soul.  Men may seem detestable as
Title:  joint stock-companies and nations; knaves, fools, and murderers there
Title:  may be; men may have mean and meagre faces; but man, in the ideal,
Title:  is so noble and so sparkling, such a grand and glowing creature, that
Title:  over any ignominious blemish in him all his fellows should run to
Title:  throw their costliest robes.  That immaculate manliness we feel
Title:  within ourselves, so far within us, that it remains intact though all
Title:  the outer character seem gone; bleeds with keenest anguish at the
Title:  undraped spectacle of a valor-ruined man.  Nor can piety itself, at
Title:  such a shameful sight, completely stifle her upbraidings against the
Title:  permitting stars.  But this august dignity I treat of, is not the
Title:  dignity of kings and robes, but that abounding dignity which has no
Title:  robed investiture.  Thou shalt see it shining in the arm that wields
Title:  a pick or drives a spike; that democratic dignity which, on all
Title:  hands, radiates without end from God; Himself!  The great God
Title:  absolute!  The centre and circumference of all democracy!  His
Title:  omnipresence, our divine equality!
Title:  
Title:  If, then, to meanest mariners, and renegades and castaways, I shall
Title:  hereafter ascribe high qualities, though dark; weave round them
Title:  tragic graces; if even the most mournful, perchance the most abased,
Title:  among them all, shall at times lift himself to the exalted mounts; if
Title:  I shall touch that workman's arm with some ethereal light; if I shall
Title:  spread a rainbow over his disastrous set of sun; then against all
Title:  mortal critics bear me out in it, thou Just Spirit of Equality,
Title:  which hast spread one royal mantle of humanity over all my kind!
Title:  Bear me out in it, thou great democratic God! who didst not refuse to
Title:  the swart convict, Bunyan, the pale, poetic pearl; Thou who didst
Title:  clothe with doubly hammered leaves of finest gold, the stumped and
Title:  paupered arm of old Cervantes; Thou who didst pick up Andrew Jackson
Title:  from the pebbles; who didst hurl him upon a war-horse; who didst
Title:  thunder him higher than a throne!  Thou who, in all Thy mighty,
Title:  earthly marchings, ever cullest Thy selectest champions from the
Title:  kingly commons; bear me out in it, O God!
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 27
Title:  
Title:  Knights and Squires.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Stubb was the second mate.  He was a native of Cape Cod; and hence,
Title:  according to local usage, was called a Cape-Cod-man.  A
Title:  happy-go-lucky; neither craven nor valiant; taking perils as they
Title:  came with an indifferent air; and while engaged in the most imminent
Title:  crisis of the chase, toiling away, calm and collected as a journeyman
Title:  joiner engaged for the year.  Good-humored, easy, and careless, he
Title:  presided over his whale-boat as if the most deadly encounter were but
Title:  a dinner, and his crew all invited guests.  He was as particular
Title:  about the comfortable arrangement of his part of the boat, as an
Title:  old stage-driver is about the snugness of his box.  When close to the
Title:  whale, in the very death-lock of the fight, he handled his unpitying
Title:  lance coolly and off-handedly, as a whistling tinker his hammer.  He
Title:  would hum over his old rigadig tunes while flank and flank with the
Title:  most exasperated monster.  Long usage had, for this Stubb, converted
Title:  the jaws of death into an easy chair.  What he thought of death
Title:  itself, there is no telling.  Whether he ever thought of it at all,
Title:  might be a question; but, if he ever did chance to cast his mind that
Title:  way after a comfortable dinner, no doubt, like a good sailor, he took
Title:  it to be a sort of call of the watch to tumble aloft, and bestir
Title:  themselves there, about something which he would find out when he
Title:  obeyed the order, and not sooner.
Title:  
Title:  What, perhaps, with other things, made Stubb such an easy-going,
Title:  unfearing man, so cheerily trudging off with the burden of life in a
Title:  world full of grave pedlars, all bowed to the ground with their
Title:  packs; what helped to bring about that almost impious good-humor of
Title:  his; that thing must have been his pipe.  For, like his nose, his
Title:  short, black little pipe was one of the regular features of his face.
Title:  You would almost as soon have expected him to turn out of his bunk
Title:  without his nose as without his pipe.  He kept a whole row of pipes
Title:  there ready loaded, stuck in a rack, within easy reach of his hand;
Title:  and, whenever he turned in, he smoked them all out in succession,
Title:  lighting one from the other to the end of the chapter; then loading
Title:  them again to be in readiness anew.  For, when Stubb dressed, instead
Title:  of first putting his legs into his trowsers, he put his pipe into his
Title:  mouth.
Title:  
Title:  I say this continual smoking must have been one cause, at least, of
Title:  his peculiar disposition; for every one knows that this earthly air,
Title:  whether ashore or afloat, is terribly infected with the nameless
Title:  miseries of the numberless mortals who have died exhaling it; and as
Title:  in time of the cholera, some people go about with a camphorated
Title:  handkerchief to their mouths; so, likewise, against all mortal
Title:  tribulations, Stubb's tobacco smoke might have operated as a sort of
Title:  disinfecting agent.
Title:  
Title:  The third mate was Flask, a native of Tisbury, in Martha's Vineyard.
Title:  A short, stout, ruddy young fellow, very pugnacious concerning
Title:  whales, who somehow seemed to think that the great leviathans had
Title:  personally and hereditarily affronted him; and therefore it was a
Title:  sort of point of honour with him, to destroy them whenever
Title:  encountered.  So utterly lost was he to all sense of reverence for
Title:  the many marvels of their majestic bulk and mystic ways; and so dead
Title:  to anything like an apprehension of any possible danger from
Title:  encountering them; that in his poor opinion, the wondrous whale was
Title:  but a species of magnified mouse, or at least water-rat, requiring
Title:  only a little circumvention and some small application of time and
Title:  trouble in order to kill and boil.  This ignorant, unconscious
Title:  fearlessness of his made him a little waggish in the matter of
Title:  whales; he followed these fish for the fun of it; and a three years'
Title:  voyage round Cape Horn was only a jolly joke that lasted that length
Title:  of time.  As a carpenter's nails are divided into wrought nails and
Title:  cut nails; so mankind may be similarly divided.  Little Flask was one
Title:  of the wrought ones; made to clinch tight and last long.  They called
Title:  him King-Post on board of the Pequod; because, in form, he could be
Title:  well likened to the short, square timber known by that name in Arctic
Title:  whalers; and which by the means of many radiating side timbers
Title:  inserted into it, serves to brace the ship against the icy
Title:  concussions of those battering seas.
Title:  
Title:  Now these three mates--Starbuck, Stubb, and Flask, were momentous
Title:  men.  They it was who by universal prescription commanded three of the
Title:  Pequod's boats as headsmen.  In that grand order of battle in which
Title:  Captain Ahab would probably marshal his forces to descend on the
Title:  whales, these three headsmen were as captains of companies.  Or,
Title:  being armed with their long keen whaling spears, they were as a
Title:  picked trio of lancers; even as the harpooneers were flingers of
Title:  javelins.
Title:  
Title:  And since in this famous fishery, each mate or headsman, like a
Title:  Gothic Knight of old, is always accompanied by his boat-steerer or
Title:  harpooneer, who in certain conjunctures provides him with a fresh
Title:  lance, when the former one has been badly twisted, or elbowed in the
Title:  assault; and moreover, as there generally subsists between the two, a
Title:  close intimacy and friendliness; it is therefore but meet, that in
Title:  this place we set down who the Pequod's harpooneers were, and to what
Title:  headsman each of them belonged.
Title:  
Title:  First of all was Queequeg, whom Starbuck, the chief mate, had
Title:  selected for his squire.  But Queequeg is already known.
Title:  
Title:  Next was Tashtego, an unmixed Indian from Gay Head, the most westerly
Title:  promontory of Martha's Vineyard, where there still exists the last
Title:  remnant of a village of red men, which has long supplied the
Title:  neighboring island of Nantucket with many of her most daring
Title:  harpooneers.  In the fishery, they usually go by the generic name of
Title:  Gay-Headers.  Tashtego's long, lean, sable hair, his high cheek
Title:  bones, and black rounding eyes--for an Indian, Oriental in their
Title:  largeness, but Antarctic in their glittering expression--all this
Title:  sufficiently proclaimed him an inheritor of the unvitiated blood of
Title:  those proud warrior hunters, who, in quest of the great New England
Title:  moose, had scoured, bow in hand, the aboriginal forests of the main.
Title:  But no longer snuffing in the trail of the wild beasts of the
Title:  woodland, Tashtego now hunted in the wake of the great whales of the
Title:  sea; the unerring harpoon of the son fitly replacing the infallible
Title:  arrow of the sires.  To look at the tawny brawn of his lithe snaky
Title:  limbs, you would almost have credited the superstitions of some of
Title:  the earlier Puritans, and half-believed this wild Indian to be a son
Title:  of the Prince of the Powers of the Air.  Tashtego was Stubb the
Title:  second mate's squire.
Title:  
Title:  Third among the harpooneers was Daggoo, a gigantic, coal-black
Title:  negro-savage, with a lion-like tread--an Ahasuerus to behold.
Title:  Suspended from his ears were two golden hoops, so large that the
Title:  sailors called them ring-bolts, and would talk of securing the
Title:  top-sail halyards to them.  In his youth Daggoo had voluntarily
Title:  shipped on board of a whaler, lying in a lonely bay on his native
Title:  coast.  And never having been anywhere in the world but in Africa,
Title:  Nantucket, and the pagan harbors most frequented by whalemen; and
Title:  having now led for many years the bold life of the fishery in the
Title:  ships of owners uncommonly heedful of what manner of men they
Title:  shipped; Daggoo retained all his barbaric virtues, and erect as a
Title:  giraffe, moved about the decks in all the pomp of six feet five in
Title:  his socks.  There was a corporeal humility in looking up at him; and
Title:  a white man standing before him seemed a white flag come to beg truce
Title:  of a fortress.  Curious to tell, this imperial negro, Ahasuerus
Title:  Daggoo, was the Squire of little Flask, who looked like a chess-man
Title:  beside him.  As for the residue of the Pequod's company, be it said,
Title:  that at the present day not one in two of the many thousand men
Title:  before the mast employed in the American whale fishery, are Americans
Title:  born, though pretty nearly all the officers are.  Herein it is the
Title:  same with the American whale fishery as with the American army and
Title:  military and merchant navies, and the engineering forces employed in
Title:  the construction of the American Canals and Railroads.  The same, I
Title:  say, because in all these cases the native American liberally
Title:  provides the brains, the rest of the world as generously supplying
Title:  the muscles.  No small number of these whaling seamen belong to the
Title:  Azores, where the outward bound Nantucket whalers frequently touch to
Title:  augment their crews from the hardy peasants of those rocky shores.
Title:  In like manner, the Greenland whalers sailing out of Hull or London,
Title:  put in at the Shetland Islands, to receive the full complement of
Title:  their crew.  Upon the passage homewards, they drop them there again.
Title:  How it is, there is no telling, but Islanders seem to make the best
Title:  whalemen.  They were nearly all Islanders in the Pequod, ISOLATOES
Title:  too, I call such, not acknowledging the common continent of men, but
Title:  each ISOLATO living on a separate continent of his own.  Yet now,
Title:  federated along one keel, what a set these Isolatoes were!  An
Title:  Anacharsis Clootz deputation from all the isles of the sea, and all
Title:  the ends of the earth, accompanying Old Ahab in the Pequod to lay the
Title:  world's grievances before that bar from which not very many of them
Title:  ever come back.  Black Little Pip--he never did--oh, no! he went
Title:  before.  Poor Alabama boy!  On the grim Pequod's forecastle, ye shall
Title:  ere long see him, beating his tambourine; prelusive of the eternal
Title:  time, when sent for, to the great quarter-deck on high, he was bid
Title:  strike in with angels, and beat his tambourine in glory; called a
Title:  coward here, hailed a hero there!
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 28
Title:  
Title:  Ahab.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  For several days after leaving Nantucket, nothing above hatches was
Title:  seen of Captain Ahab.  The mates regularly relieved each other at the
Title:  watches, and for aught that could be seen to the contrary, they
Title:  seemed to be the only commanders of the ship; only they sometimes
Title:  issued from the cabin with orders so sudden and peremptory, that
Title:  after all it was plain they but commanded vicariously.  Yes, their
Title:  supreme lord and dictator was there, though hitherto unseen by any
Title:  eyes not permitted to penetrate into the now sacred retreat of the
Title:  cabin.
Title:  
Title:  Every time I ascended to the deck from my watches below, I instantly
Title:  gazed aft to mark if any strange face were visible; for my first
Title:  vague disquietude touching the unknown captain, now in the seclusion
Title:  of the sea, became almost a perturbation.  This was strangely
Title:  heightened at times by the ragged Elijah's diabolical incoherences
Title:  uninvitedly recurring to me, with a subtle energy I could not have
Title:  before conceived of.  But poorly could I withstand them, much as in
Title:  other moods I was almost ready to smile at the solemn whimsicalities
Title:  of that outlandish prophet of the wharves.  But whatever it was of
Title:  apprehensiveness or uneasiness--to call it so--which I felt, yet
Title:  whenever I came to look about me in the ship, it seemed against all
Title:  warrantry to cherish such emotions.  For though the harpooneers, with
Title:  the great body of the crew, were a far more barbaric, heathenish, and
Title:  motley set than any of the tame merchant-ship companies which my
Title:  previous experiences had made me acquainted with, still I ascribed
Title:  this--and rightly ascribed it--to the fierce uniqueness of the very
Title:  nature of that wild Scandinavian vocation in which I had so
Title:  abandonedly embarked.  But it was especially the aspect of the three
Title:  chief officers of the ship, the mates, which was most forcibly
Title:  calculated to allay these colourless misgivings, and induce confidence
Title:  and cheerfulness in every presentment of the voyage.  Three better,
Title:  more likely sea-officers and men, each in his own different way,
Title:  could not readily be found, and they were every one of them
Title:  Americans; a Nantucketer, a Vineyarder, a Cape man.  Now, it being
Title:  Christmas when the ship shot from out her harbor, for a space we had
Title:  biting Polar weather, though all the time running away from it to the
Title:  southward; and by every degree and minute of latitude which we
Title:  sailed, gradually leaving that merciless winter, and all its
Title:  intolerable weather behind us.  It was one of those less lowering,
Title:  but still grey and gloomy enough mornings of the transition, when
Title:  with a fair wind the ship was rushing through the water with a
Title:  vindictive sort of leaping and melancholy rapidity, that as I mounted
Title:  to the deck at the call of the forenoon watch, so soon as I levelled
Title:  my glance towards the taffrail, foreboding shivers ran over me.
Title:  Reality outran apprehension; Captain Ahab stood upon his
Title:  quarter-deck.
Title:  
Title:  There seemed no sign of common bodily illness about him, nor of the
Title:  recovery from any.  He looked like a man cut away from the stake,
Title:  when the fire has overrunningly wasted all the limbs without
Title:  consuming them, or taking away one particle from their compacted aged
Title:  robustness.  His whole high, broad form, seemed made of solid bronze,
Title:  and shaped in an unalterable mould, like Cellini's cast Perseus.
Title:  Threading its way out from among his grey hairs, and continuing right
Title:  down one side of his tawny scorched face and neck, till it
Title:  disappeared in his clothing, you saw a slender rod-like mark, lividly
Title:  whitish.  It resembled that perpendicular seam sometimes made in the
Title:  straight, lofty trunk of a great tree, when the upper lightning
Title:  tearingly darts down it, and without wrenching a single twig, peels
Title:  and grooves out the bark from top to bottom, ere running off into the
Title:  soil, leaving the tree still greenly alive, but branded.  Whether
Title:  that mark was born with him, or whether it was the scar left by some
Title:  desperate wound, no one could certainly say.  By some tacit consent,
Title:  throughout the voyage little or no allusion was made to it,
Title:  especially by the mates.  But once Tashtego's senior, an old Gay-Head
Title:  Indian among the crew, superstitiously asserted that not till he was
Title:  full forty years old did Ahab become that way branded, and then it
Title:  came upon him, not in the fury of any mortal fray, but in an
Title:  elemental strife at sea.  Yet, this wild hint seemed inferentially
Title:  negatived, by what a grey Manxman insinuated, an old sepulchral man,
Title:  who, having never before sailed out of Nantucket, had never ere this
Title:  laid eye upon wild Ahab.  Nevertheless, the old sea-traditions, the
Title:  immemorial credulities, popularly invested this old Manxman with
Title:  preternatural powers of discernment.  So that no white sailor
Title:  seriously contradicted him when he said that if ever Captain Ahab
Title:  should be tranquilly laid out--which might hardly come to pass, so he
Title:  muttered--then, whoever should do that last office for the dead,
Title:  would find a birth-mark on him from crown to sole.
Title:  
Title:  So powerfully did the whole grim aspect of Ahab affect me, and the
Title:  livid brand which streaked it, that for the first few moments I
Title:  hardly noted that not a little of this overbearing grimness was owing
Title:  to the barbaric white leg upon which he partly stood.  It had
Title:  previously come to me that this ivory leg had at sea been fashioned
Title:  from the polished bone of the sperm whale's jaw.  "Aye, he was
Title:  dismasted off Japan," said the old Gay-Head Indian once; "but like
Title:  his dismasted craft, he shipped another mast without coming home for
Title:  it.  He has a quiver of 'em."
Title:  
Title:  I was struck with the singular posture he maintained.  Upon each side
Title:  of the Pequod's quarter deck, and pretty close to the mizzen shrouds,
Title:  there was an auger hole, bored about half an inch or so, into the
Title:  plank.  His bone leg steadied in that hole; one arm elevated, and
Title:  holding by a shroud; Captain Ahab stood erect, looking straight out
Title:  beyond the ship's ever-pitching prow.  There was an infinity of
Title:  firmest fortitude, a determinate, unsurrenderable wilfulness, in the
Title:  fixed and fearless, forward dedication of that glance.  Not a word he
Title:  spoke; nor did his officers say aught to him; though by all their
Title:  minutest gestures and expressions, they plainly showed the uneasy, if
Title:  not painful, consciousness of being under a troubled master-eye.  And
Title:  not only that, but moody stricken Ahab stood before them with a
Title:  crucifixion in his face; in all the nameless regal overbearing
Title:  dignity of some mighty woe.
Title:  
Title:  Ere long, from his first visit in the air, he withdrew into his
Title:  cabin.  But after that morning, he was every day visible to the crew;
Title:  either standing in his pivot-hole, or seated upon an ivory stool he
Title:  had; or heavily walking the deck.  As the sky grew less gloomy;
Title:  indeed, began to grow a little genial, he became still less and less
Title:  a recluse; as if, when the ship had sailed from home, nothing but the
Title:  dead wintry bleakness of the sea had then kept him so secluded.  And,
Title:  by and by, it came to pass, that he was almost continually in the
Title:  air; but, as yet, for all that he said, or perceptibly did, on the at
Title:  last sunny deck, he seemed as unnecessary there as another mast.  But
Title:  the Pequod was only making a passage now; not regularly cruising;
Title:  nearly all whaling preparatives needing supervision the mates were
Title:  fully competent to, so that there was little or nothing, out of
Title:  himself, to employ or excite Ahab, now; and thus chase away, for that
Title:  one interval, the clouds that layer upon layer were piled upon his
Title:  brow, as ever all clouds choose the loftiest peaks to pile themselves
Title:  upon.
Title:  
Title:  Nevertheless, ere long, the warm, warbling persuasiveness of the
Title:  pleasant, holiday weather we came to, seemed gradually to charm him
Title:  from his mood.  For, as when the red-cheeked, dancing girls, April
Title:  and May, trip home to the wintry, misanthropic woods; even the
Title:  barest, ruggedest, most thunder-cloven old oak will at least send
Title:  forth some few green sprouts, to welcome such glad-hearted visitants;
Title:  so Ahab did, in the end, a little respond to the playful allurings of
Title:  that girlish air.  More than once did he put forth the faint blossom
Title:  of a look, which, in any other man, would have soon flowered out in a
Title:  smile.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 29
Title:  
Title:  Enter Ahab; to Him, Stubb.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Some days elapsed, and ice and icebergs all astern, the Pequod now
Title:  went rolling through the bright Quito spring, which, at sea, almost
Title:  perpetually reigns on the threshold of the eternal August of the
Title:  Tropic.  The warmly cool, clear, ringing, perfumed, overflowing,
Title:  redundant days, were as crystal goblets of Persian sherbet, heaped
Title:  up--flaked up, with rose-water snow.  The starred and stately nights
Title:  seemed haughty dames in jewelled velvets, nursing at home in lonely
Title:  pride, the memory of their absent conquering Earls, the golden
Title:  helmeted suns!  For sleeping man, 'twas hard to choose between such
Title:  winsome days and such seducing nights.  But all the witcheries of
Title:  that unwaning weather did not merely lend new spells and potencies to
Title:  the outward world.  Inward they turned upon the soul, especially when
Title:  the still mild hours of eve came on; then, memory shot her crystals
Title:  as the clear ice most forms of noiseless twilights.  And all these
Title:  subtle agencies, more and more they wrought on Ahab's texture.
Title:  
Title:  Old age is always wakeful; as if, the longer linked with life, the
Title:  less man has to do with aught that looks like death.  Among
Title:  sea-commanders, the old greybeards will oftenest leave their berths
Title:  to visit the night-cloaked deck.  It was so with Ahab; only that now,
Title:  of late, he seemed so much to live in the open air, that truly
Title:  speaking, his visits were more to the cabin, than from the cabin to
Title:  the planks.  "It feels like going down into one's tomb,"--he would
Title:  mutter to himself--"for an old captain like me to be descending this
Title:  narrow scuttle, to go to my grave-dug berth."
Title:  
Title:  So, almost every twenty-four hours, when the watches of the night
Title:  were set, and the band on deck sentinelled the slumbers of the band
Title:  below; and when if a rope was to be hauled upon the forecastle, the
Title:  sailors flung it not rudely down, as by day, but with some
Title:  cautiousness dropt it to its place for fear of disturbing their
Title:  slumbering shipmates; when this sort of steady quietude would begin
Title:  to prevail, habitually, the silent steersman would watch the
Title:  cabin-scuttle; and ere long the old man would emerge, gripping at the
Title:  iron banister, to help his crippled way.  Some considering touch of
Title:  humanity was in him; for at times like these, he usually abstained
Title:  from patrolling the quarter-deck; because to his wearied mates,
Title:  seeking repose within six inches of his ivory heel, such would have
Title:  been the reverberating crack and din of that bony step, that their
Title:  dreams would have been on the crunching teeth of sharks.  But once,
Title:  the mood was on him too deep for common regardings; and as with
Title:  heavy, lumber-like pace he was measuring the ship from taffrail to
Title:  mainmast, Stubb, the old second mate, came up from below, with a
Title:  certain unassured, deprecating humorousness, hinted that if Captain
Title:  Ahab was pleased to walk the planks, then, no one could say nay; but
Title:  there might be some way of muffling the noise; hinting something
Title:  indistinctly and hesitatingly about a globe of tow, and the insertion
Title:  into it, of the ivory heel.  Ah!  Stubb, thou didst not know Ahab
Title:  then.
Title:  
Title:  "Am I a cannon-ball, Stubb," said Ahab, "that thou wouldst wad me
Title:  that fashion?  But go thy ways; I had forgot.  Below to thy nightly
Title:  grave; where such as ye sleep between shrouds, to use ye to the
Title:  filling one at last.--Down, dog, and kennel!"
Title:  
Title:  Starting at the unforseen concluding exclamation of the so suddenly
Title:  scornful old man, Stubb was speechless a moment; then said excitedly,
Title:  "I am not used to be spoken to that way, sir; I do but less than half
Title:  like it, sir."
Title:  
Title:  "Avast! gritted Ahab between his set teeth, and violently moving
Title:  away, as if to avoid some passionate temptation.
Title:  
Title:  "No, sir; not yet," said Stubb, emboldened, "I will not tamely be
Title:  called a dog, sir."
Title:  
Title:  "Then be called ten times a donkey, and a mule, and an ass, and
Title:  begone, or I'll clear the world of thee!"
Title:  
Title:  As he said this, Ahab advanced upon him with such overbearing terrors
Title:  in his aspect, that Stubb involuntarily retreated.
Title:  
Title:  "I was never served so before without giving a hard blow for it,"
Title:  muttered Stubb, as he found himself descending the cabin-scuttle.
Title:  "It's very queer.  Stop, Stubb; somehow, now, I don't well know
Title:  whether to go back and strike him, or--what's that?--down here on my
Title:  knees and pray for him?  Yes, that was the thought coming up in me;
Title:  but it would be the first time I ever DID pray.  It's queer; very
Title:  queer; and he's queer too; aye, take him fore and aft, he's about the
Title:  queerest old man Stubb ever sailed with.  How he flashed at me!--his
Title:  eyes like powder-pans! is he mad?  Anyway there's something on his
Title:  mind, as sure as there must be something on a deck when it cracks.
Title:  He aint in his bed now, either, more than three hours out of the
Title:  twenty-four; and he don't sleep then.  Didn't that Dough-Boy, the
Title:  steward, tell me that of a morning he always finds the old man's
Title:  hammock clothes all rumpled and tumbled, and the sheets down at the
Title:  foot, and the coverlid almost tied into knots, and the pillow a sort
Title:  of frightful hot, as though a baked brick had been on it?  A hot old
Title:  man!  I guess he's got what some folks ashore call a conscience; it's
Title:  a kind of Tic-Dolly-row they say--worse nor a toothache.  Well, well;
Title:  I don't know what it is, but the Lord keep me from catching it.  He's
Title:  full of riddles; I wonder what he goes into the after hold for, every
Title:  night, as Dough-Boy tells me he suspects; what's that for, I should
Title:  like to know?  Who's made appointments with him in the hold?  Ain't
Title:  that queer, now?  But there's no telling, it's the old game--Here
Title:  goes for a snooze.  Damn me, it's worth a fellow's while to be born
Title:  into the world, if only to fall right asleep.  And now that I think
Title:  of it, that's about the first thing babies do, and that's a sort of
Title:  queer, too.  Damn me, but all things are queer, come to think of 'em.
Title:  But that's against my principles.  Think not, is my eleventh
Title:  commandment; and sleep when you can, is my twelfth--So here goes
Title:  again.  But how's that? didn't he call me a dog? blazes! he called me
Title:  ten times a donkey, and piled a lot of jackasses on top of THAT!  He
Title:  might as well have kicked me, and done with it.  Maybe he DID kick
Title:  me, and I didn't observe it, I was so taken all aback with his brow,
Title:  somehow.  It flashed like a bleached bone.  What the devil's the
Title:  matter with me?  I don't stand right on my legs.  Coming afoul of
Title:  that old man has a sort of turned me wrong side out.  By the Lord, I
Title:  must have been dreaming, though--How? how? how?--but the only way's
Title:  to stash it; so here goes to hammock again; and in the morning, I'll
Title:  see how this plaguey juggling thinks over by daylight."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 30
Title:  
Title:  The Pipe.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  When Stubb had departed, Ahab stood for a while leaning over the
Title:  bulwarks; and then, as had been usual with him of late, calling a
Title:  sailor of the watch, he sent him below for his ivory stool, and also
Title:  his pipe.  Lighting the pipe at the binnacle lamp and planting the
Title:  stool on the weather side of the deck, he sat and smoked.
Title:  
Title:  In old Norse times, the thrones of the sea-loving Danish kings were
Title:  fabricated, saith tradition, of the tusks of the narwhale.  How could
Title:  one look at Ahab then, seated on that tripod of bones, without
Title:  bethinking him of the royalty it symbolized?  For a Khan of the
Title:  plank, and a king of the sea, and a great lord of Leviathans was
Title:  Ahab.
Title:  
Title:  Some moments passed, during which the thick vapour came from his mouth
Title:  in quick and constant puffs, which blew back again into his face.
Title:  "How now," he soliloquized at last, withdrawing the tube, "this
Title:  smoking no longer soothes.  Oh, my pipe! hard must it go with me if
Title:  thy charm be gone!  Here have I been unconsciously toiling, not
Title:  pleasuring--aye, and ignorantly smoking to windward all the while; to
Title:  windward, and with such nervous whiffs, as if, like the dying whale,
Title:  my final jets were the strongest and fullest of trouble.  What
Title:  business have I with this pipe?  This thing that is meant for
Title:  sereneness, to send up mild white vapours among mild white hairs, not
Title:  among torn iron-grey locks like mine.  I'll smoke no more--"
Title:  
Title:  He tossed the still lighted pipe into the sea.  The fire hissed in
Title:  the waves; the same instant the ship shot by the bubble the sinking
Title:  pipe made.  With slouched hat, Ahab lurchingly paced the planks.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 31
Title:  
Title:  Queen Mab.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Next morning Stubb accosted Flask.
Title:  
Title:  "Such a queer dream, King-Post, I never had.  You know the old man's
Title:  ivory leg, well I dreamed he kicked me with it; and when I tried to
Title:  kick back, upon my soul, my little man, I kicked my leg right off!
Title:  And then, presto!  Ahab seemed a pyramid, and I, like a blazing fool,
Title:  kept kicking at it.  But what was still more curious, Flask--you know
Title:  how curious all dreams are--through all this rage that I was in, I
Title:  somehow seemed to be thinking to myself, that after all, it was not
Title:  much of an insult, that kick from Ahab.  'Why,' thinks I, 'what's the
Title:  row?  It's not a real leg, only a false leg.'  And there's a mighty
Title:  difference between a living thump and a dead thump.  That's what
Title:  makes a blow from the hand, Flask, fifty times more savage to bear
Title:  than a blow from a cane.  The living member--that makes the living
Title:  insult, my little man.  And thinks I to myself all the while, mind,
Title:  while I was stubbing my silly toes against that cursed pyramid--so
Title:  confoundedly contradictory was it all, all the while, I say, I was
Title:  thinking to myself, 'what's his leg now, but a cane--a whalebone
Title:  cane.  Yes,' thinks I, 'it was only a playful cudgelling--in fact,
Title:  only a whaleboning that he gave me--not a base kick.  Besides,'
Title:  thinks I, 'look at it once; why, the end of it--the foot part--what a
Title:  small sort of end it is; whereas, if a broad footed farmer kicked me,
Title:  THERE'S a devilish broad insult.  But this insult is whittled down to
Title:  a point only.'  But now comes the greatest joke of the dream, Flask.
Title:  While I was battering away at the pyramid, a sort of badger-haired
Title:  old merman, with a hump on his back, takes me by the shoulders, and
Title:  slews me round.  'What are you 'bout?' says he.  Slid! man, but I was
Title:  frightened.  Such a phiz!  But, somehow, next moment I was over the
Title:  fright.  'What am I about?' says I at last.  'And what business is
Title:  that of yours, I should like to know, Mr. Humpback?  Do YOU want a
Title:  kick?'  By the lord, Flask, I had no sooner said that, than he turned
Title:  round his stern to me, bent over, and dragging up a lot of seaweed he
Title:  had for a clout--what do you think, I saw?--why thunder alive, man,
Title:  his stern was stuck full of marlinspikes, with the points out.  Says
Title:  I, on second thoughts, 'I guess I won't kick you, old fellow.'  'Wise
Title:  Stubb,' said he, 'wise Stubb;' and kept muttering it all the time, a
Title:  sort of eating of his own gums like a chimney hag.  Seeing he wasn't
Title:  going to stop saying over his 'wise Stubb, wise Stubb,' I thought I
Title:  might as well fall to kicking the pyramid again.  But I had only just
Title:  lifted my foot for it, when he roared out, 'Stop that kicking!'
Title:  'Halloa,' says I, 'what's the matter now, old fellow?'  'Look ye
Title:  here,' says he; 'let's argue the insult.  Captain Ahab kicked ye,
Title:  didn't he?'  'Yes, he did,' says I--'right HERE it was.'  'Very
Title:  good,' says he--'he used his ivory leg, didn't he?'  'Yes, he did,'
Title:  says I.  'Well then,' says he, 'wise Stubb, what have you to complain
Title:  of?  Didn't he kick with right good will? it wasn't a common pitch
Title:  pine leg he kicked with, was it?  No, you were kicked by a great man,
Title:  and with a beautiful ivory leg, Stubb.  It's an honour; I consider it
Title:  an honour.  Listen, wise Stubb.  In old England the greatest lords
Title:  think it great glory to be slapped by a queen, and made
Title:  garter-knights of; but, be YOUR boast, Stubb, that ye were kicked by
Title:  old Ahab, and made a wise man of.  Remember what I say; BE kicked by
Title:  him; account his kicks honours; and on no account kick back; for you
Title:  can't help yourself, wise Stubb.  Don't you see that pyramid?'  With
Title:  that, he all of a sudden seemed somehow, in some queer fashion, to
Title:  swim off into the air.  I snored; rolled over; and there I was in my
Title:  hammock!  Now, what do you think of that dream, Flask?"
Title:  
Title:  "I don't know; it seems a sort of foolish to me, tho.'"
Title:  
Title:  "May be; may be.  But it's made a wise man of me, Flask.  D'ye see
Title:  Ahab standing there, sideways looking over the stern?  Well, the best
Title:  thing you can do, Flask, is to let the old man alone; never speak to
Title:  him, whatever he says.  Halloa!  What's that he shouts?  Hark!"
Title:  
Title:  "Mast-head, there!  Look sharp, all of ye!  There are whales
Title:  hereabouts!
Title:  
Title:  If ye see a white one, split your lungs for him!
Title:  
Title:  "What do you think of that now, Flask? ain't there a small drop of
Title:  something queer about that, eh?  A white whale--did ye mark that,
Title:  man?  Look ye--there's something special in the wind.  Stand by for
Title:  it, Flask.  Ahab has that that's bloody on his mind.  But, mum; he
Title:  comes this way."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 32
Title:  
Title:  Cetology.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Already we are boldly launched upon the deep; but soon we shall be
Title:  lost in its unshored, harbourless immensities.  Ere that come to pass;
Title:  ere the Pequod's weedy hull rolls side by side with the barnacled
Title:  hulls of the leviathan; at the outset it is but well to attend to a
Title:  matter almost indispensable to a thorough appreciative understanding
Title:  of the more special leviathanic revelations and allusions of all
Title:  sorts which are to follow.
Title:  
Title:  It is some systematized exhibition of the whale in his broad genera,
Title:  that I would now fain put before you.  Yet is it no easy task.  The
Title:  classification of the constituents of a chaos, nothing less is here
Title:  essayed.  Listen to what the best and latest authorities have laid
Title:  down.
Title:  
Title:  "No branch of Zoology is so much involved as that which is entitled
Title:  Cetology," says Captain Scoresby, A.D. 1820.
Title:  
Title:  "It is not my intention, were it in my power, to enter into the
Title:  inquiry as to the true method of dividing the cetacea into groups and
Title:  families....  Utter confusion exists among the historians of this
Title:  animal" (sperm whale), says Surgeon Beale, A.D. 1839.
Title:  
Title:  "Unfitness to pursue our research in the unfathomable waters."
Title:  "Impenetrable veil covering our knowledge of the cetacea."  "A field
Title:  strewn with thorns."  "All these incomplete indications but serve to
Title:  torture us naturalists."
Title:  
Title:  Thus speak of the whale, the great Cuvier, and John Hunter, and
Title:  Lesson, those lights of zoology and anatomy.  Nevertheless, though of
Title:  real knowledge there be little, yet of books there are a plenty; and
Title:  so in some small degree, with cetology, or the science of whales.
Title:  Many are the men, small and great, old and new, landsmen and seamen,
Title:  who have at large or in little, written of the whale.  Run over a
Title:  few:--The Authors of the Bible; Aristotle; Pliny; Aldrovandi; Sir
Title:  Thomas Browne; Gesner; Ray; Linnaeus; Rondeletius; Willoughby; Green;
Title:  Artedi; Sibbald; Brisson; Marten; Lacepede; Bonneterre; Desmarest;
Title:  Baron Cuvier; Frederick Cuvier; John Hunter; Owen; Scoresby; Beale;
Title:  Bennett; J.  Ross Browne; the Author of Miriam Coffin; Olmstead; and
Title:  the Rev.  T.  Cheever.  But to what ultimate generalizing purpose all
Title:  these have written, the above cited extracts will show.
Title:  
Title:  Of the names in this list of whale authors, only those following Owen
Title:  ever saw living whales; and but one of them was a real professional
Title:  harpooneer and whaleman.  I mean Captain Scoresby.  On the separate
Title:  subject of the Greenland or right-whale, he is the best existing
Title:  authority.  But Scoresby knew nothing and says nothing of the great
Title:  sperm whale, compared with which the Greenland whale is almost
Title:  unworthy mentioning.  And here be it said, that the Greenland whale
Title:  is an usurper upon the throne of the seas.  He is not even by any
Title:  means the largest of the whales.  Yet, owing to the long priority of
Title:  his claims, and the profound ignorance which, till some seventy years
Title:  back, invested the then fabulous or utterly unknown sperm-whale, and
Title:  which ignorance to this present day still reigns in all but some few
Title:  scientific retreats and whale-ports; this usurpation has been every
Title:  way complete.  Reference to nearly all the leviathanic allusions in
Title:  the great poets of past days, will satisfy you that the Greenland
Title:  whale, without one rival, was to them the monarch of the seas.  But
Title:  the time has at last come for a new proclamation.  This is Charing
Title:  Cross; hear ye! good people all,--the Greenland whale is
Title:  deposed,--the great sperm whale now reigneth!
Title:  
Title:  There are only two books in being which at all pretend to put the
Title:  living sperm whale before you, and at the same time, in the remotest
Title:  degree succeed in the attempt.  Those books are Beale's and
Title:  Bennett's; both in their time surgeons to English South-Sea
Title:  whale-ships, and both exact and reliable men.  The original matter
Title:  touching the sperm whale to be found in their volumes is necessarily
Title:  small; but so far as it goes, it is of excellent quality, though
Title:  mostly confined to scientific description.  As yet, however, the
Title:  sperm whale, scientific or poetic, lives not complete in any
Title:  literature.  Far above all other hunted whales, his is an unwritten
Title:  life.
Title:  
Title:  Now the various species of whales need some sort of popular
Title:  comprehensive classification, if only an easy outline one for the
Title:  present, hereafter to be filled in all its departments by subsequent
Title:  laborers.  As no better man advances to take this matter in hand, I
Title:  hereupon offer my own poor endeavors.  I promise nothing complete;
Title:  because any human thing supposed to be complete, must for that very
Title:  reason infallibly be faulty.  I shall not pretend to a minute
Title:  anatomical description of the various species, or--in this place at
Title:  least--to much of any description.  My object here is simply to
Title:  project the draught of a systematization of cetology.  I am the
Title:  architect, not the builder.
Title:  
Title:  But it is a ponderous task; no ordinary letter-sorter in the
Title:  Post-Office is equal to it.  To grope down into the bottom of the sea
Title:  after them; to have one's hands among the unspeakable foundations,
Title:  ribs, and very pelvis of the world; this is a fearful thing.  What am
Title:  I that I should essay to hook the nose of this leviathan!  The awful
Title:  tauntings in Job might well appal me.  "Will he the (leviathan) make
Title:  a covenant with thee?  Behold the hope of him is vain!  But I have
Title:  swam through libraries and sailed through oceans; I have had to do
Title:  with whales with these visible hands; I am in earnest; and I will
Title:  try.  There are some preliminaries to settle.
Title:  
Title:  First: The uncertain, unsettled condition of this science of Cetology
Title:  is in the very vestibule attested by the fact, that in some quarters
Title:  it still remains a moot point whether a whale be a fish.  In his
Title:  System of Nature, A.D. 1776, Linnaeus declares, "I hereby separate
Title:  the whales from the fish."  But of my own knowledge, I know that down
Title:  to the year 1850, sharks and shad, alewives and herring, against
Title:  Linnaeus's express edict, were still found dividing the possession of
Title:  the same seas with the Leviathan.
Title:  
Title:  The grounds upon which Linnaeus would fain have banished the whales
Title:  from the waters, he states as follows: "On account of their warm
Title:  bilocular heart, their lungs, their movable eyelids, their hollow
Title:  ears, penem intrantem feminam mammis lactantem," and finally, "ex
Title:  lege naturae jure meritoque."  I submitted all this to my friends
Title:  Simeon Macey and Charley Coffin, of Nantucket, both messmates of mine
Title:  in a certain voyage, and they united in the opinion that the reasons
Title:  set forth were altogether insufficient.  Charley profanely hinted
Title:  they were humbug.
Title:  
Title:  Be it known that, waiving all argument, I take the good old fashioned
Title:  ground that the whale is a fish, and call upon holy Jonah to back me.
Title:  This fundamental thing settled, the next point is, in what internal
Title:  respect does the whale differ from other fish.  Above, Linnaeus has
Title:  given you those items.  But in brief, they are these: lungs and warm
Title:  blood; whereas, all other fish are lungless and cold blooded.
Title:  
Title:  Next: how shall we define the whale, by his obvious externals, so as
Title:  conspicuously to label him for all time to come?  To be short, then,
Title:  a whale is A SPOUTING FISH WITH A HORIZONTAL TAIL.  There you have
Title:  him.  However contracted, that definition is the result of expanded
Title:  meditation.  A walrus spouts much like a whale, but the walrus is not
Title:  a fish, because he is amphibious.  But the last term of the
Title:  definition is still more cogent, as coupled with the first.  Almost
Title:  any one must have noticed that all the fish familiar to landsmen have
Title:  not a flat, but a vertical, or up-and-down tail.  Whereas, among
Title:  spouting fish the tail, though it may be similarly shaped, invariably
Title:  assumes a horizontal position.
Title:  
Title:  By the above definition of what a whale is, I do by no means exclude
Title:  from the leviathanic brotherhood any sea creature hitherto identified
Title:  with the whale by the best informed Nantucketers; nor, on the other
Title:  hand, link with it any fish hitherto authoritatively regarded as
Title:  alien.*  Hence, all the smaller, spouting, and horizontal tailed fish
Title:  must be included in this ground-plan of Cetology.  Now, then, come
Title:  the grand divisions of the entire whale host.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *I am aware that down to the present time, the fish styled Lamatins
Title:  and Dugongs (Pig-fish and Sow-fish of the Coffins of Nantucket) are
Title:  included by many naturalists among the whales.  But as these pig-fish
Title:  are a noisy, contemptible set, mostly lurking in the mouths of
Title:  rivers, and feeding on wet hay, and especially as they do not spout,
Title:  I deny their credentials as whales; and have presented them with
Title:  their passports to quit the Kingdom of Cetology.
Title:  
Title:
