Title:  First: According to magnitude I divide the whales into three primary
Title:  BOOKS (subdivisible into CHAPTERS), and these shall comprehend them
Title:  all, both small and large.
Title:  
Title:  I. THE FOLIO WHALE; II. the OCTAVO WHALE; III. the DUODECIMO WHALE.
Title:  
Title:  As the type of the FOLIO I present the SPERM WHALE; of the OCTAVO,
Title:  the GRAMPUS; of the DUODECIMO, the PORPOISE.
Title:  
Title:  FOLIOS.  Among these I here include the following chapters:--I. The
Title:  SPERM WHALE; II. the RIGHT WHALE; III. the FIN-BACK WHALE; IV. the
Title:  HUMP-BACKED WHALE; V. the RAZOR-BACK WHALE; VI. the SULPHUR-BOTTOM
Title:  WHALE.
Title:  
Title:  BOOK I. (FOLIO), CHAPTER I. (SPERM WHALE).--This whale, among the
Title:  English of old vaguely known as the Trumpa whale, and the Physeter
Title:  whale, and the Anvil Headed whale, is the present Cachalot of the
Title:  French, and the Pottsfich of the Germans, and the Macrocephalus of
Title:  the Long Words.  He is, without doubt, the largest inhabitant of the
Title:  globe; the most formidable of all whales to encounter; the most
Title:  majestic in aspect; and lastly, by far the most valuable in commerce;
Title:  he being the only creature from which that valuable substance,
Title:  spermaceti, is obtained.  All his peculiarities will, in many other
Title:  places, be enlarged upon.  It is chiefly with his name that I now
Title:  have to do.  Philologically considered, it is absurd.  Some centuries
Title:  ago, when the Sperm whale was almost wholly unknown in his own
Title:  proper individuality, and when his oil was only accidentally obtained
Title:  from the stranded fish; in those days spermaceti, it would seem, was
Title:  popularly supposed to be derived from a creature identical with the
Title:  one then known in England as the Greenland or Right Whale.  It was
Title:  the idea also, that this same spermaceti was that quickening humor of
Title:  the Greenland Whale which the first syllable of the word literally
Title:  expresses.  In those times, also, spermaceti was exceedingly scarce,
Title:  not being used for light, but only as an ointment and medicament.  It
Title:  was only to be had from the druggists as you nowadays buy an ounce of
Title:  rhubarb.  When, as I opine, in the course of time, the true nature of
Title:  spermaceti became known, its original name was still retained by the
Title:  dealers; no doubt to enhance its value by a notion so strangely
Title:  significant of its scarcity.  And so the appellation must at last
Title:  have come to be bestowed upon the whale from which this spermaceti
Title:  was really derived.
Title:  
Title:  BOOK I. (FOLIO), CHAPTER II. (RIGHT WHALE).--In one respect this is
Title:  the most venerable of the leviathans, being the one first regularly
Title:  hunted by man.  It yields the article commonly known as whalebone or
Title:  baleen; and the oil specially known as "whale oil," an inferior
Title:  article in commerce.  Among the fishermen, he is indiscriminately
Title:  designated by all the following titles: The Whale; the Greenland
Title:  Whale; the Black Whale; the Great Whale; the True Whale; the Right
Title:  Whale.  There is a deal of obscurity concerning the identity of the
Title:  species thus multitudinously baptised.  What then is the whale, which
Title:  I include in the second species of my Folios?  It is the Great
Title:  Mysticetus of the English naturalists; the Greenland Whale of the
Title:  English whalemen; the Baliene Ordinaire of the French whalemen; the
Title:  Growlands Walfish of the Swedes.  It is the whale which for more than
Title:  two centuries past has been hunted by the Dutch and English in the
Title:  Arctic seas; it is the whale which the American fishermen have long
Title:  pursued in the Indian ocean, on the Brazil Banks, on the Nor' West
Title:  Coast, and various other parts of the world, designated by them Right
Title:  Whale Cruising Grounds.
Title:  
Title:  Some pretend to see a difference between the Greenland whale of the
Title:  English and the right whale of the Americans.  But they precisely
Title:  agree in all their grand features; nor has there yet been presented a
Title:  single determinate fact upon which to ground a radical distinction.
Title:  It is by endless subdivisions based upon the most inconclusive
Title:  differences, that some departments of natural history become so
Title:  repellingly intricate.  The right whale will be elsewhere treated of
Title:  at some length, with reference to elucidating the sperm whale.
Title:  
Title:  BOOK I. (FOLIO), CHAPTER III. (FIN-BACK).--Under this head I reckon a
Title:  monster which, by the various names of Fin-Back, Tall-Spout, and
Title:  Long-John, has been seen almost in every sea and is commonly the
Title:  whale whose distant jet is so often descried by passengers crossing
Title:  the Atlantic, in the New York packet-tracks.  In the length he
Title:  attains, and in his baleen, the Fin-back resembles the right whale,
Title:  but is of a less portly girth, and a lighter colour, approaching to
Title:  olive.  His great lips present a cable-like aspect, formed by the
Title:  intertwisting, slanting folds of large wrinkles.  His grand
Title:  distinguishing feature, the fin, from which he derives his name, is
Title:  often a conspicuous object.  This fin is some three or four feet
Title:  long, growing vertically from the hinder part of the back, of an
Title:  angular shape, and with a very sharp pointed end.  Even if not the
Title:  slightest other part of the creature be visible, this isolated fin
Title:  will, at times, be seen plainly projecting from the surface.  When
Title:  the sea is moderately calm, and slightly marked with spherical
Title:  ripples, and this gnomon-like fin stands up and casts shadows upon
Title:  the wrinkled surface, it may well be supposed that the watery circle
Title:  surrounding it somewhat resembles a dial, with its style and wavy
Title:  hour-lines graved on it.  On that Ahaz-dial the shadow often goes
Title:  back.  The Fin-Back is not gregarious.  He seems a whale-hater, as
Title:  some men are man-haters.  Very shy; always going solitary;
Title:  unexpectedly rising to the surface in the remotest and most sullen
Title:  waters; his straight and single lofty jet rising like a tall
Title:  misanthropic spear upon a barren plain; gifted with such wondrous
Title:  power and velocity in swimming, as to defy all present pursuit from
Title:  man; this leviathan seems the banished and unconquerable Cain of his
Title:  race, bearing for his mark that style upon his back.  From having the
Title:  baleen in his mouth, the Fin-Back is sometimes included with the
Title:  right whale, among a theoretic species denominated WHALEBONE WHALES,
Title:  that is, whales with baleen.  Of these so called Whalebone whales,
Title:  there would seem to be several varieties, most of which, however, are
Title:  little known.  Broad-nosed whales and beaked whales; pike-headed
Title:  whales; bunched whales; under-jawed whales and rostrated whales, are
Title:  the fishermen's names for a few sorts.
Title:  
Title:  In connection with this appellative of "Whalebone whales," it is of
Title:  great importance to mention, that however such a nomenclature may be
Title:  convenient in facilitating allusions to some kind of whales, yet it
Title:  is in vain to attempt a clear classification of the Leviathan,
Title:  founded upon either his baleen, or hump, or fin, or teeth;
Title:  notwithstanding that those marked parts or features very obviously
Title:  seem better adapted to afford the basis for a regular system of
Title:  Cetology than any other detached bodily distinctions, which the
Title:  whale, in his kinds, presents.  How then?  The baleen, hump,
Title:  back-fin, and teeth; these are things whose peculiarities are
Title:  indiscriminately dispersed among all sorts of whales, without any
Title:  regard to what may be the nature of their structure in other and
Title:  more essential particulars.  Thus, the sperm whale and the humpbacked
Title:  whale, each has a hump; but there the similitude ceases.  Then, this
Title:  same humpbacked whale and the Greenland whale, each of these has
Title:  baleen; but there again the similitude ceases.  And it is just the
Title:  same with the other parts above mentioned.  In various sorts of
Title:  whales, they form such irregular combinations; or, in the case of any
Title:  one of them detached, such an irregular isolation; as utterly to defy
Title:  all general methodization formed upon such a basis.  On this rock
Title:  every one of the whale-naturalists has split.
Title:  
Title:  But it may possibly be conceived that, in the internal parts of the
Title:  whale, in his anatomy--there, at least, we shall be able to hit the
Title:  right classification.  Nay; what thing, for example, is there in the
Title:  Greenland whale's anatomy more striking than his baleen?  Yet we have
Title:  seen that by his baleen it is impossible correctly to classify the
Title:  Greenland whale.  And if you descend into the bowels of the various
Title:  leviathans, why there you will not find distinctions a fiftieth part
Title:  as available to the systematizer as those external ones already
Title:  enumerated.  What then remains? nothing but to take hold of the
Title:  whales bodily, in their entire liberal volume, and boldly sort them
Title:  that way.  And this is the Bibliographical system here adopted; and
Title:  it is the only one that can possibly succeed, for it alone is
Title:  practicable.  To proceed.
Title:  
Title:  BOOK I. (FOLIO) CHAPTER IV. (HUMP-BACK).--This whale is often seen on
Title:  the northern American coast.  He has been frequently captured there,
Title:  and towed into harbor.  He has a great pack on him like a peddler; or
Title:  you might call him the Elephant and Castle whale.  At any rate, the
Title:  popular name for him does not sufficiently distinguish him, since the
Title:  sperm whale also has a hump though a smaller one.  His oil is not
Title:  very valuable.  He has baleen.  He is the most gamesome and
Title:  light-hearted of all the whales, making more gay foam and white water
Title:  generally than any other of them.
Title:  
Title:  BOOK I. (FOLIO), CHAPTER V. (RAZOR-BACK).--Of this whale little is
Title:  known but his name.  I have seen him at a distance off Cape Horn.  Of
Title:  a retiring nature, he eludes both hunters and philosophers.  Though
Title:  no coward, he has never yet shown any part of him but his back, which
Title:  rises in a long sharp ridge.  Let him go.  I know little more of him,
Title:  nor does anybody else.
Title:  
Title:  BOOK I. (FOLIO), CHAPTER VI. (SULPHUR-BOTTOM).--Another retiring
Title:  gentleman, with a brimstone belly, doubtless got by scraping along
Title:  the Tartarian tiles in some of his profounder divings.  He is seldom
Title:  seen; at least I have never seen him except in the remoter southern
Title:  seas, and then always at too great a distance to study his
Title:  countenance.  He is never chased; he would run away with rope-walks
Title:  of line.  Prodigies are told of him.  Adieu, Sulphur Bottom!  I can
Title:  say nothing more that is true of ye, nor can the oldest Nantucketer.
Title:  
Title:  Thus ends BOOK I. (FOLIO), and now begins BOOK II. (OCTAVO).
Title:  
Title:  OCTAVOES.*--These embrace the whales of middling magnitude, among
Title:  which present may be numbered:--I., the GRAMPUS; II., the BLACK FISH;
Title:  III., the NARWHALE; IV., the THRASHER; V., the KILLER.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *Why this book of whales is not denominated the Quarto is very plain.
Title:  Because, while the whales of this order, though smaller than those
Title:  of the former order, nevertheless retain a proportionate likeness to
Title:  them in figure, yet the bookbinder's Quarto volume in its dimensioned
Title:  form does not preserve the shape of the Folio volume, but the Octavo
Title:  volume does.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  BOOK II. (OCTAVO), CHAPTER I. (GRAMPUS).--Though this fish, whose
Title:  loud sonorous breathing, or rather blowing, has furnished a proverb
Title:  to landsmen, is so well known a denizen of the deep, yet is he not
Title:  popularly classed among whales.  But possessing all the grand
Title:  distinctive features of the leviathan, most naturalists have
Title:  recognised him for one.  He is of moderate octavo size, varying from
Title:  fifteen to twenty-five feet in length, and of corresponding
Title:  dimensions round the waist.  He swims in herds; he is never regularly
Title:  hunted, though his oil is considerable in quantity, and pretty good
Title:  for light.  By some fishermen his approach is regarded as premonitory
Title:  of the advance of the great sperm whale.
Title:  
Title:  BOOK II. (OCTAVO), CHAPTER II. (BLACK FISH).--I give the popular
Title:  fishermen's names for all these fish, for generally they are the
Title:  best.  Where any name happens to be vague or inexpressive, I shall
Title:  say so, and suggest another.  I do so now, touching the Black Fish,
Title:  so-called, because blackness is the rule among almost all whales.
Title:  So, call him the Hyena Whale, if you please.  His voracity is well
Title:  known, and from the circumstance that the inner angles of his lips
Title:  are curved upwards, he carries an everlasting Mephistophelean grin on
Title:  his face.  This whale averages some sixteen or eighteen feet in
Title:  length.  He is found in almost all latitudes.  He has a peculiar way
Title:  of showing his dorsal hooked fin in swimming, which looks something
Title:  like a Roman nose.  When not more profitably employed, the sperm
Title:  whale hunters sometimes capture the Hyena whale, to keep up the
Title:  supply of cheap oil for domestic employment--as some frugal
Title:  housekeepers, in the absence of company, and quite alone by
Title:  themselves, burn unsavory tallow instead of odorous wax.  Though
Title:  their blubber is very thin, some of these whales will yield you
Title:  upwards of thirty gallons of oil.
Title:  
Title:  BOOK II. (OCTAVO), CHAPTER III. (NARWHALE), that is, NOSTRIL
Title:  WHALE.--Another instance of a curiously named whale, so named I
Title:  suppose from his peculiar horn being originally mistaken for a peaked
Title:  nose.  The creature is some sixteen feet in length, while its horn
Title:  averages five feet, though some exceed ten, and even attain to
Title:  fifteen feet.  Strictly speaking, this horn is but a lengthened tusk,
Title:  growing out from the jaw in a line a little depressed from the
Title:  horizontal.  But it is only found on the sinister side, which has an
Title:  ill effect, giving its owner something analogous to the aspect of a
Title:  clumsy left-handed man.  What precise purpose this ivory horn or
Title:  lance answers, it would be hard to say.  It does not seem to be used
Title:  like the blade of the sword-fish and bill-fish; though some sailors
Title:  tell me that the Narwhale employs it for a rake in turning over the
Title:  bottom of the sea for food.  Charley Coffin said it was used for an
Title:  ice-piercer; for the Narwhale, rising to the surface of the Polar
Title:  Sea, and finding it sheeted with ice, thrusts his horn up, and so
Title:  breaks through.  But you cannot prove either of these surmises to be
Title:  correct.  My own opinion is, that however this one-sided horn may
Title:  really be used by the Narwhale--however that may be--it would
Title:  certainly be very convenient to him for a folder in reading
Title:  pamphlets.  The Narwhale I have heard called the Tusked whale, the
Title:  Horned whale, and the Unicorn whale.  He is certainly a curious
Title:  example of the Unicornism to be found in almost every kingdom of
Title:  animated nature.  From certain cloistered old authors I have gathered
Title:  that this same sea-unicorn's horn was in ancient days regarded as the
Title:  great antidote against poison, and as such, preparations of it
Title:  brought immense prices.  It was also distilled to a volatile salts
Title:  for fainting ladies, the same way that the horns of the male deer are
Title:  manufactured into hartshorn.  Originally it was in itself accounted
Title:  an object of great curiosity.  Black Letter tells me that Sir Martin
Title:  Frobisher on his return from that voyage, when Queen Bess did
Title:  gallantly wave her jewelled hand to him from a window of Greenwich
Title:  Palace, as his bold ship sailed down the Thames; "when Sir Martin
Title:  returned from that voyage," saith Black Letter, "on bended knees he
Title:  presented to her highness a prodigious long horn of the Narwhale,
Title:  which for a long period after hung in the castle at Windsor."  An
Title:  Irish author avers that the Earl of Leicester, on bended knees, did
Title:  likewise present to her highness another horn, pertaining to a land
Title:  beast of the unicorn nature.
Title:  
Title:  The Narwhale has a very picturesque, leopard-like look, being of a
Title:  milk-white ground colour, dotted with round and oblong spots of black.
Title:  His oil is very superior, clear and fine; but there is little of it,
Title:  and he is seldom hunted.  He is mostly found in the circumpolar seas.
Title:  
Title:  BOOK II. (OCTAVO), CHAPTER IV. (KILLER).--Of this whale little is
Title:  precisely known to the Nantucketer, and nothing at all to the
Title:  professed naturalist.  From what I have seen of him at a distance,
Title:  I should say that he was about the bigness of a grampus.  He is very
Title:  savage--a sort of Feegee fish.  He sometimes takes the great Folio
Title:  whales by the lip, and hangs there like a leech, till the mighty
Title:  brute is worried to death.  The Killer is never hunted.  I never
Title:  heard what sort of oil he has.  Exception might be taken to the name
Title:  bestowed upon this whale, on the ground of its indistinctness.  For
Title:  we are all killers, on land and on sea; Bonapartes and Sharks
Title:  included.
Title:  
Title:  BOOK II. (OCTAVO), CHAPTER V. (THRASHER).--This gentleman is famous
Title:  for his tail, which he uses for a ferule in thrashing his foes.  He
Title:  mounts the Folio whale's back, and as he swims, he works his passage
Title:  by flogging him; as some schoolmasters get along in the world by a
Title:  similar process.  Still less is known of the Thrasher than of the
Title:  Killer.  Both are outlaws, even in the lawless seas.
Title:  
Title:  Thus ends BOOK II. (OCTAVO), and begins BOOK III. (DUODECIMO).
Title:  
Title:  DUODECIMOES.--These include the smaller whales.  I. The Huzza
Title:  Porpoise.  II. The Algerine Porpoise.  III. The Mealy-mouthed
Title:  Porpoise.
Title:  
Title:  To those who have not chanced specially to study the subject, it may
Title:  possibly seem strange, that fishes not commonly exceeding four or
Title:  five feet should be marshalled among WHALES--a word, which, in the
Title:  popular sense, always conveys an idea of hugeness.  But the creatures
Title:  set down above as Duodecimoes are infallibly whales, by the terms of
Title:  my definition of what a whale is--i.e. a spouting fish, with a
Title:  horizontal tail.
Title:  
Title:  BOOK III. (DUODECIMO), CHAPTER 1. (HUZZA PORPOISE).--This is the
Title:  common porpoise found almost all over the globe.  The name is of my
Title:  own bestowal; for there are more than one sort of porpoises, and
Title:  something must be done to distinguish them.  I call him thus, because
Title:  he always swims in hilarious shoals, which upon the broad sea keep
Title:  tossing themselves to heaven like caps in a Fourth-of-July crowd.
Title:  Their appearance is generally hailed with delight by the mariner.
Title:  Full of fine spirits, they invariably come from the breezy billows to
Title:  windward.  They are the lads that always live before the wind.  They
Title:  are accounted a lucky omen.  If you yourself can withstand three
Title:  cheers at beholding these vivacious fish, then heaven help ye; the
Title:  spirit of godly gamesomeness is not in ye.  A well-fed, plump Huzza
Title:  Porpoise will yield you one good gallon of good oil.  But the fine
Title:  and delicate fluid extracted from his jaws is exceedingly valuable.
Title:  It is in request among jewellers and watchmakers.  Sailors put it on
Title:  their hones.  Porpoise meat is good eating, you know.  It may never
Title:  have occurred to you that a porpoise spouts.  Indeed, his spout is so
Title:  small that it is not very readily discernible.  But the next time you
Title:  have a chance, watch him; and you will then see the great Sperm whale
Title:  himself in miniature.
Title:  
Title:  BOOK III. (DUODECIMO), CHAPTER II. (ALGERINE PORPOISE).--A pirate.
Title:  Very savage.  He is only found, I think, in the Pacific.  He is
Title:  somewhat larger than the Huzza Porpoise, but much of the same general
Title:  make.  Provoke him, and he will buckle to a shark.  I have lowered
Title:  for him many times, but never yet saw him captured.
Title:  
Title:  BOOK III. (DUODECIMO), CHAPTER III. (MEALY-MOUTHED PORPOISE).--The
Title:  largest kind of Porpoise; and only found in the Pacific, so far as it
Title:  is known.  The only English name, by which he has hitherto been
Title:  designated, is that of the fishers--Right-Whale Porpoise, from the
Title:  circumstance that he is chiefly found in the vicinity of that Folio.
Title:  In shape, he differs in some degree from the Huzza Porpoise, being of
Title:  a less rotund and jolly girth; indeed, he is of quite a neat and
Title:  gentleman-like figure.  He has no fins on his back (most other
Title:  porpoises have), he has a lovely tail, and sentimental Indian eyes of
Title:  a hazel hue.  But his mealy-mouth spoils all.  Though his entire
Title:  back down to his side fins is of a deep sable, yet a boundary line,
Title:  distinct as the mark in a ship's hull, called the "bright waist,"
Title:  that line streaks him from stem to stern, with two separate colours,
Title:  black above and white below.  The white comprises part of his head,
Title:  and the whole of his mouth, which makes him look as if he had just
Title:  escaped from a felonious visit to a meal-bag.  A most mean and mealy
Title:  aspect!  His oil is much like that of the common porpoise.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Beyond the DUODECIMO, this system does not proceed, inasmuch as the
Title:  Porpoise is the smallest of the whales.  Above, you have all the
Title:  Leviathans of note.  But there are a rabble of uncertain, fugitive,
Title:  half-fabulous whales, which, as an American whaleman, I know by
Title:  reputation, but not personally.  I shall enumerate them by their
Title:  fore-castle appellations; for possibly such a list may be valuable to
Title:  future investigators, who may complete what I have here but begun.
Title:  If any of the following whales, shall hereafter be caught and marked,
Title:  then he can readily be incorporated into this System, according to
Title:  his Folio, Octavo, or Duodecimo magnitude:--The Bottle-Nose Whale;
Title:  the Junk Whale; the Pudding-Headed Whale; the Cape Whale; the Leading
Title:  Whale; the Cannon Whale; the Scragg Whale; the Coppered Whale; the
Title:  Elephant Whale; the Iceberg Whale; the Quog Whale; the Blue Whale; etc.
Title:  From Icelandic, Dutch, and old English authorities, there might
Title:  be quoted other lists of uncertain whales, blessed with all manner of
Title:  uncouth names.  But I omit them as altogether obsolete; and can
Title:  hardly help suspecting them for mere sounds, full of Leviathanism,
Title:  but signifying nothing.
Title:  
Title:  Finally: It was stated at the outset, that this system would not be
Title:  here, and at once, perfected.  You cannot but plainly see that I have
Title:  kept my word.  But I now leave my cetological System standing thus
Title:  unfinished, even as the great Cathedral of Cologne was left, with the
Title:  crane still standing upon the top of the uncompleted tower.  For
Title:  small erections may be finished by their first architects; grand
Title:  ones, true ones, ever leave the copestone to posterity.  God keep me
Title:  from ever completing anything.  This whole book is but a
Title:  draught--nay, but the draught of a draught.  Oh, Time, Strength,
Title:  Cash, and Patience!
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 33
Title:  
Title:  The Specksynder.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Concerning the officers of the whale-craft, this seems as good a
Title:  place as any to set down a little domestic peculiarity on ship-board,
Title:  arising from the existence of the harpooneer class of officers, a
Title:  class unknown of course in any other marine than the whale-fleet.
Title:  
Title:  The large importance attached to the harpooneer's vocation is evinced
Title:  by the fact, that originally in the old Dutch Fishery, two centuries
Title:  and more ago, the command of a whale ship was not wholly lodged in
Title:  the person now called the captain, but was divided between him and an
Title:  officer called the Specksynder.  Literally this word means
Title:  Fat-Cutter; usage, however, in time made it equivalent to Chief
Title:  Harpooneer.  In those days, the captain's authority was restricted to
Title:  the navigation and general management of the vessel; while over the
Title:  whale-hunting department and all its concerns, the Specksynder or
Title:  Chief Harpooneer reigned supreme.  In the British Greenland Fishery,
Title:  under the corrupted title of Specksioneer, this old Dutch official is
Title:  still retained, but his former dignity is sadly abridged.  At present
Title:  he ranks simply as senior Harpooneer; and as such, is but one of the
Title:  captain's more inferior subalterns.  Nevertheless, as upon the good
Title:  conduct of the harpooneers the success of a whaling voyage largely
Title:  depends, and since in the American Fishery he is not only an
Title:  important officer in the boat, but under certain circumstances (night
Title:  watches on a whaling ground) the command of the ship's deck is also
Title:  his; therefore the grand political maxim of the sea demands, that he
Title:  should nominally live apart from the men before the mast, and be in
Title:  some way distinguished as their professional superior; though always,
Title:  by them, familiarly regarded as their social equal.
Title:  
Title:  Now, the grand distinction drawn between officer and man at sea, is
Title:  this--the first lives aft, the last forward.  Hence, in whale-ships
Title:  and merchantmen alike, the mates have their quarters with the
Title:  captain; and so, too, in most of the American whalers the harpooneers
Title:  are lodged in the after part of the ship.  That is to say, they take
Title:  their meals in the captain's cabin, and sleep in a place indirectly
Title:  communicating with it.
Title:  
Title:  Though the long period of a Southern whaling voyage (by far the
Title:  longest of all voyages now or ever made by man), the peculiar perils
Title:  of it, and the community of interest prevailing among a company, all
Title:  of whom, high or low, depend for their profits, not upon fixed wages,
Title:  but upon their common luck, together with their common vigilance,
Title:  intrepidity, and hard work; though all these things do in some cases
Title:  tend to beget a less rigorous discipline than in merchantmen
Title:  generally; yet, never mind how much like an old Mesopotamian family
Title:  these whalemen may, in some primitive instances, live together; for
Title:  all that, the punctilious externals, at least, of the quarter-deck
Title:  are seldom materially relaxed, and in no instance done away.  Indeed,
Title:  many are the Nantucket ships in which you will see the skipper
Title:  parading his quarter-deck with an elated grandeur not surpassed in
Title:  any military navy; nay, extorting almost as much outward homage as if
Title:  he wore the imperial purple, and not the shabbiest of pilot-cloth.
Title:  
Title:  And though of all men the moody captain of the Pequod was the least
Title:  given to that sort of shallowest assumption; and though the only
Title:  homage he ever exacted, was implicit, instantaneous obedience; though
Title:  he required no man to remove the shoes from his feet ere stepping
Title:  upon the quarter-deck; and though there were times when, owing to
Title:  peculiar circumstances connected with events hereafter to be
Title:  detailed, he addressed them in unusual terms, whether of
Title:  condescension or IN TERROREM, or otherwise; yet even Captain Ahab was
Title:  by no means unobservant of the paramount forms and usages of the sea.
Title:  
Title:  Nor, perhaps, will it fail to be eventually perceived, that behind
Title:  those forms and usages, as it were, he sometimes masked himself;
Title:  incidentally making use of them for other and more private ends than
Title:  they were legitimately intended to subserve.  That certain sultanism
Title:  of his brain, which had otherwise in a good degree remained
Title:  unmanifested; through those forms that same sultanism became
Title:  incarnate in an irresistible dictatorship.  For be a man's
Title:  intellectual superiority what it will, it can never assume the
Title:  practical, available supremacy over other men, without the aid of
Title:  some sort of external arts and entrenchments, always, in themselves,
Title:  more or less paltry and base.  This it is, that for ever keeps God's
Title:  true princes of the Empire from the world's hustings; and leaves the
Title:  highest honours that this air can give, to those men who become famous
Title:  more through their infinite inferiority to the choice hidden handful
Title:  of the Divine Inert, than through their undoubted superiority over
Title:  the dead level of the mass.  Such large virtue lurks in these small
Title:  things when extreme political superstitions invest them, that in some
Title:  royal instances even to idiot imbecility they have imparted potency.
Title:  But when, as in the case of Nicholas the Czar, the ringed crown of
Title:  geographical empire encircles an imperial brain; then, the plebeian
Title:  herds crouch abased before the tremendous centralization.  Nor, will
Title:  the tragic dramatist who would depict mortal indomitableness in its
Title:  fullest sweep and direct swing, ever forget a hint, incidentally so
Title:  important in his art, as the one now alluded to.
Title:  
Title:  But Ahab, my Captain, still moves before me in all his Nantucket
Title:  grimness and shagginess; and in this episode touching Emperors and
Title:  Kings, I must not conceal that I have only to do with a poor old
Title:  whale-hunter like him; and, therefore, all outward majestical
Title:  trappings and housings are denied me.  Oh, Ahab! what shall be grand
Title:  in thee, it must needs be plucked at from the skies, and dived for in
Title:  the deep, and featured in the unbodied air!
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 34
Title:  
Title:  The Cabin-Table.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  It is noon; and Dough-Boy, the steward, thrusting his pale
Title:  loaf-of-bread face from the cabin-scuttle, announces dinner to his
Title:  lord and master; who, sitting in the lee quarter-boat, has just been
Title:  taking an observation of the sun; and is now mutely reckoning the
Title:  latitude on the smooth, medallion-shaped tablet, reserved for that
Title:  daily purpose on the upper part of his ivory leg.  From his complete
Title:  inattention to the tidings, you would think that moody Ahab had not
Title:  heard his menial.  But presently, catching hold of the mizen shrouds,
Title:  he swings himself to the deck, and in an even, unexhilarated voice,
Title:  saying, "Dinner, Mr. Starbuck," disappears into the cabin.
Title:  
Title:  When the last echo of his sultan's step has died away, and Starbuck,
Title:  the first Emir, has every reason to suppose that he is seated, then
Title:  Starbuck rouses from his quietude, takes a few turns along the
Title:  planks, and, after a grave peep into the binnacle, says, with some
Title:  touch of pleasantness, "Dinner, Mr. Stubb," and descends the scuttle.
Title:  The second Emir lounges about the rigging awhile, and then slightly
Title:  shaking the main brace, to see whether it will be all right with
Title:  that important rope, he likewise takes up the old burden, and with a
Title:  rapid "Dinner, Mr. Flask," follows after his predecessors.
Title:  
Title:  But the third Emir, now seeing himself all alone on the quarter-deck,
Title:  seems to feel relieved from some curious restraint; for, tipping all
Title:  sorts of knowing winks in all sorts of directions, and kicking off
Title:  his shoes, he strikes into a sharp but noiseless squall of a hornpipe
Title:  right over the Grand Turk's head; and then, by a dexterous sleight,
Title:  pitching his cap up into the mizentop for a shelf, he goes down
Title:  rollicking so far at least as he remains visible from the deck,
Title:  reversing all other processions, by bringing up the rear with music.
Title:  But ere stepping into the cabin doorway below, he pauses, ships a new
Title:  face altogether, and, then, independent, hilarious little Flask
Title:  enters King Ahab's presence, in the character of Abjectus, or the
Title:  Slave.
Title:  
Title:  It is not the least among the strange things bred by the intense
Title:  artificialness of sea-usages, that while in the open air of the deck
Title:  some officers will, upon provocation, bear themselves boldly and
Title:  defyingly enough towards their commander; yet, ten to one, let those
Title:  very officers the next moment go down to their customary dinner in
Title:  that same commander's cabin, and straightway their inoffensive, not
Title:  to say deprecatory and humble air towards him, as he sits at the head
Title:  of the table; this is marvellous, sometimes most comical.  Wherefore
Title:  this difference?  A problem?  Perhaps not.  To have been Belshazzar,
Title:  King of Babylon; and to have been Belshazzar, not haughtily but
Title:  courteously, therein certainly must have been some touch of mundane
Title:  grandeur.  But he who in the rightly regal and intelligent spirit
Title:  presides over his own private dinner-table of invited guests, that
Title:  man's unchallenged power and dominion of individual influence for the
Title:  time; that man's royalty of state transcends Belshazzar's, for
Title:  Belshazzar was not the greatest.  Who has but once dined his friends,
Title:  has tasted what it is to be Caesar.  It is a witchery of social
Title:  czarship which there is no withstanding.  Now, if to this
Title:  consideration you superadd the official supremacy of a ship-master,
Title:  then, by inference, you will derive the cause of that peculiarity of
Title:  sea-life just mentioned.
Title:  
Title:  Over his ivory-inlaid table, Ahab presided like a mute, maned
Title:  sea-lion on the white coral beach, surrounded by his warlike but
Title:  still deferential cubs.  In his own proper turn, each officer waited
Title:  to be served.  They were as little children before Ahab; and yet, in
Title:  Ahab, there seemed not to lurk the smallest social arrogance.  With
Title:  one mind, their intent eyes all fastened upon the old man's knife, as
Title:  he carved the chief dish before him.  I do not suppose that for the
Title:  world they would have profaned that moment with the slightest
Title:  observation, even upon so neutral a topic as the weather.  No!  And
Title:  when reaching out his knife and fork, between which the slice of beef
Title:  was locked, Ahab thereby motioned Starbuck's plate towards him, the
Title:  mate received his meat as though receiving alms; and cut it tenderly;
Title:  and a little started if, perchance, the knife grazed against the
Title:  plate; and chewed it noiselessly; and swallowed it, not without
Title:  circumspection.  For, like the Coronation banquet at Frankfort, where
Title:  the German Emperor profoundly dines with the seven Imperial
Title:  Electors, so these cabin meals were somehow solemn meals, eaten in
Title:  awful silence; and yet at table old Ahab forbade not conversation;
Title:  only he himself was dumb.  What a relief it was to choking Stubb,
Title:  when a rat made a sudden racket in the hold below.  And poor little
Title:  Flask, he was the youngest son, and little boy of this weary family
Title:  party.  His were the shinbones of the saline beef; his would have
Title:  been the drumsticks.  For Flask to have presumed to help himself,
Title:  this must have seemed to him tantamount to larceny in the first
Title:  degree.  Had he helped himself at that table, doubtless, never more
Title:  would he have been able to hold his head up in this honest world;
Title:  nevertheless, strange to say, Ahab never forbade him.  And had Flask
Title:  helped himself, the chances were Ahab had never so much as noticed
Title:  it.  Least of all, did Flask presume to help himself to butter.
Title:  Whether he thought the owners of the ship denied it to him, on
Title:  account of its clotting his clear, sunny complexion; or whether he
Title:  deemed that, on so long a voyage in such marketless waters, butter
Title:  was at a premium, and therefore was not for him, a subaltern; however
Title:  it was, Flask, alas! was a butterless man!
Title:  
Title:  Another thing.  Flask was the last person down at the dinner, and
Title:  Flask is the first man up.  Consider!  For hereby Flask's dinner was
Title:  badly jammed in point of time.  Starbuck and Stubb both had the start
Title:  of him; and yet they also have the privilege of lounging in the rear.
Title:  If Stubb even, who is but a peg higher than Flask, happens to have
Title:  but a small appetite, and soon shows symptoms of concluding his
Title:  repast, then Flask must bestir himself, he will not get more than
Title:  three mouthfuls that day; for it is against holy usage for Stubb to
Title:  precede Flask to the deck.  Therefore it was that Flask once admitted
Title:  in private, that ever since he had arisen to the dignity of an
Title:  officer, from that moment he had never known what it was to be
Title:  otherwise than hungry, more or less.  For what he ate did not so much
Title:  relieve his hunger, as keep it immortal in him.  Peace and
Title:  satisfaction, thought Flask, have for ever departed from my stomach.
Title:  I am an officer; but, how I wish I could fish a bit of old-fashioned
Title:  beef in the forecastle, as I used to when I was before the mast.
Title:  There's the fruits of promotion now; there's the vanity of glory:
Title:  there's the insanity of life!  Besides, if it were so that any mere
Title:  sailor of the Pequod had a grudge against Flask in Flask's official
Title:  capacity, all that sailor had to do, in order to obtain ample
Title:  vengeance, was to go aft at dinner-time, and get a peep at Flask
Title:  through the cabin sky-light, sitting silly and dumfoundered before
Title:  awful Ahab.
Title:  
Title:  Now, Ahab and his three mates formed what may be called the first
Title:  table in the Pequod's cabin.  After their departure, taking place in
Title:  inverted order to their arrival, the canvas cloth was cleared, or
Title:  rather was restored to some hurried order by the pallid steward.  And
Title:  then the three harpooneers were bidden to the feast, they being its
Title:  residuary legatees.  They made a sort of temporary servants' hall of
Title:  the high and mighty cabin.
Title:  
Title:  In strange contrast to the hardly tolerable constraint and nameless
Title:  invisible domineerings of the captain's table, was the entire
Title:  care-free license and ease, the almost frantic democracy of those
Title:  inferior fellows the harpooneers.  While their masters, the mates,
Title:  seemed afraid of the sound of the hinges of their own jaws, the
Title:  harpooneers chewed their food with such a relish that there was a
Title:  report to it.  They dined like lords; they filled their bellies like
Title:  Indian ships all day loading with spices.  Such portentous appetites
Title:  had Queequeg and Tashtego, that to fill out the vacancies made by the
Title:  previous repast, often the pale Dough-Boy was fain to bring on a
Title:  great baron of salt-junk, seemingly quarried out of the solid ox.
Title:  And if he were not lively about it, if he did not go with a nimble
Title:  hop-skip-and-jump, then Tashtego had an ungentlemanly way of
Title:  accelerating him by darting a fork at his back, harpoon-wise.  And
Title:  once Daggoo, seized with a sudden humor, assisted Dough-Boy's memory
Title:  by snatching him up bodily, and thrusting his head into a great empty
Title:  wooden trencher, while Tashtego, knife in hand, began laying out the
Title:  circle preliminary to scalping him.  He was naturally a very nervous,
Title:  shuddering sort of little fellow, this bread-faced steward; the
Title:  progeny of a bankrupt baker and a hospital nurse.  And what with the
Title:  standing spectacle of the black terrific Ahab, and the periodical
Title:  tumultuous visitations of these three savages, Dough-Boy's whole life
Title:  was one continual lip-quiver.  Commonly, after seeing the harpooneers
Title:  furnished with all things they demanded, he would escape from their
Title:  clutches into his little pantry adjoining, and fearfully peep out at
Title:  them through the blinds of its door, till all was over.
Title:  
Title:  It was a sight to see Queequeg seated over against Tashtego, opposing
Title:  his filed teeth to the Indian's: crosswise to them, Daggoo seated on
Title:  the floor, for a bench would have brought his hearse-plumed head to
Title:  the low carlines; at every motion of his colossal limbs, making the
Title:  low cabin framework to shake, as when an African elephant goes
Title:  passenger in a ship.  But for all this, the great negro was
Title:  wonderfully abstemious, not to say dainty.  It seemed hardly possible
Title:  that by such comparatively small mouthfuls he could keep up the
Title:  vitality diffused through so broad, baronial, and superb a person.
Title:  But, doubtless, this noble savage fed strong and drank deep of the
Title:  abounding element of air; and through his dilated nostrils snuffed in
Title:  the sublime life of the worlds.  Not by beef or by bread, are giants
Title:  made or nourished.  But Queequeg, he had a mortal, barbaric smack of
Title:  the lip in eating--an ugly sound enough--so much so, that the
Title:  trembling Dough-Boy almost looked to see whether any marks of teeth
Title:  lurked in his own lean arms.  And when he would hear Tashtego singing
Title:  out for him to produce himself, that his bones might be picked, the
Title:  simple-witted steward all but shattered the crockery hanging round
Title:  him in the pantry, by his sudden fits of the palsy.  Nor did the
Title:  whetstone which the harpooneers carried in their pockets, for their
Title:  lances and other weapons; and with which whetstones, at dinner, they
Title:  would ostentatiously sharpen their knives; that grating sound did not
Title:  at all tend to tranquillize poor Dough-Boy.  How could he forget that
Title:  in his Island days, Queequeg, for one, must certainly have been
Title:  guilty of some murderous, convivial indiscretions.  Alas!  Dough-Boy!
Title:  hard fares the white waiter who waits upon cannibals.  Not a napkin
Title:  should he carry on his arm, but a buckler.  In good time, though, to
Title:  his great delight, the three salt-sea warriors would rise and depart;
Title:  to his credulous, fable-mongering ears, all their martial bones
Title:  jingling in them at every step, like Moorish scimetars in scabbards.
Title:  
Title:  But, though these barbarians dined in the cabin, and nominally lived
Title:  there; still, being anything but sedentary in their habits, they were
Title:  scarcely ever in it except at mealtimes, and just before
Title:  sleeping-time, when they passed through it to their own peculiar
Title:  quarters.
Title:  
Title:  In this one matter, Ahab seemed no exception to most American whale
Title:  captains, who, as a set, rather incline to the opinion that by rights
Title:  the ship's cabin belongs to them; and that it is by courtesy alone
Title:  that anybody else is, at any time, permitted there.  So that, in real
Title:  truth, the mates and harpooneers of the Pequod might more properly be
Title:  said to have lived out of the cabin than in it.  For when they did
Title:  enter it, it was something as a street-door enters a house; turning
Title:  inwards for a moment, only to be turned out the next; and, as a
Title:  permanent thing, residing in the open air.  Nor did they lose much
Title:  hereby; in the cabin was no companionship; socially, Ahab was
Title:  inaccessible.  Though nominally included in the census of
Title:  Christendom, he was still an alien to it.  He lived in the world, as
Title:  the last of the Grisly Bears lived in settled Missouri.  And as when
Title:  Spring and Summer had departed, that wild Logan of the woods, burying
Title:  himself in the hollow of a tree, lived out the winter there, sucking
Title:  his own paws; so, in his inclement, howling old age, Ahab's soul,
Title:  shut up in the caved trunk of his body, there fed upon the sullen
Title:  paws of its gloom!
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 35
Title:  
Title:  The Mast-Head.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  It was during the more pleasant weather, that in due rotation with
Title:  the other seamen my first mast-head came round.
Title:  
Title:  In most American whalemen the mast-heads are manned almost
Title:  simultaneously with the vessel's leaving her port; even though she
Title:  may have fifteen thousand miles, and more, to sail ere reaching her
Title:  proper cruising ground.  And if, after a three, four, or five years'
Title:  voyage she is drawing nigh home with anything empty in her--say, an
Title:  empty vial even--then, her mast-heads are kept manned to the last;
Title:  and not till her skysail-poles sail in among the spires of the port,
Title:  does she altogether relinquish the hope of capturing one whale more.
Title:  
Title:  Now, as the business of standing mast-heads, ashore or afloat, is a
Title:  very ancient and interesting one, let us in some measure expatiate
Title:  here.  I take it, that the earliest standers of mast-heads were the
Title:  old Egyptians; because, in all my researches, I find none prior to
Title:  them.  For though their progenitors, the builders of Babel, must
Title:  doubtless, by their tower, have intended to rear the loftiest
Title:  mast-head in all Asia, or Africa either; yet (ere the final truck was
Title:  put to it) as that great stone mast of theirs may be said to have
Title:  gone by the board, in the dread gale of God's wrath; therefore, we
Title:  cannot give these Babel builders priority over the Egyptians.  And
Title:  that the Egyptians were a nation of mast-head standers, is an
Title:  assertion based upon the general belief among archaeologists, that
Title:  the first pyramids were founded for astronomical purposes: a theory
Title:  singularly supported by the peculiar stair-like formation of all four
Title:  sides of those edifices; whereby, with prodigious long upliftings of
Title:  their legs, those old astronomers were wont to mount to the apex, and
Title:  sing out for new stars; even as the look-outs of a modern ship sing
Title:  out for a sail, or a whale just bearing in sight.  In Saint Stylites,
Title:  the famous Christian hermit of old times, who built him a lofty stone
Title:  pillar in the desert and spent the whole latter portion of his life
Title:  on its summit, hoisting his food from the ground with a tackle; in
Title:  him we have a remarkable instance of a dauntless
Title:  stander-of-mast-heads; who was not to be driven from his place by
Title:  fogs or frosts, rain, hail, or sleet; but valiantly facing everything
Title:  out to the last, literally died at his post.  Of modern
Title:  standers-of-mast-heads we have but a lifeless set; mere stone, iron,
Title:  and bronze men; who, though well capable of facing out a stiff gale,
Title:  are still entirely incompetent to the business of singing out upon
Title:  discovering any strange sight.  There is Napoleon; who, upon the top
Title:  of the column of Vendome, stands with arms folded, some one hundred
Title:  and fifty feet in the air; careless, now, who rules the decks below;
Title:  whether Louis Philippe, Louis Blanc, or Louis the Devil.  Great
Title:  Washington, too, stands high aloft on his towering main-mast in
Title:  Baltimore, and like one of Hercules' pillars, his column marks that
Title:  point of human grandeur beyond which few mortals will go.  Admiral
Title:  Nelson, also, on a capstan of gun-metal, stands his mast-head in
Title:  Trafalgar Square; and ever when most obscured by that London smoke,
Title:  token is yet given that a hidden hero is there; for where there is
Title:  smoke, must be fire.  But neither great Washington, nor Napoleon, nor
Title:  Nelson, will answer a single hail from below, however madly invoked
Title:  to befriend by their counsels the distracted decks upon which they
Title:  gaze; however it may be surmised, that their spirits penetrate
Title:  through the thick haze of the future, and descry what shoals and what
Title:  rocks must be shunned.
Title:  
Title:  It may seem unwarrantable to couple in any respect the mast-head
Title:  standers of the land with those of the sea; but that in truth it is
Title:  not so, is plainly evinced by an item for which Obed Macy, the sole
Title:  historian of Nantucket, stands accountable.  The worthy Obed tells
Title:  us, that in the early times of the whale fishery, ere ships were
Title:  regularly launched in pursuit of the game, the people of that island
Title:  erected lofty spars along the sea-coast, to which the look-outs
Title:  ascended by means of nailed cleats, something as fowls go upstairs in
Title:  a hen-house.  A few years ago this same plan was adopted by the Bay
Title:  whalemen of New Zealand, who, upon descrying the game, gave notice to
Title:  the ready-manned boats nigh the beach.  But this custom has now
Title:  become obsolete; turn we then to the one proper mast-head, that of a
Title:  whale-ship at sea.  The three mast-heads are kept manned from
Title:  sun-rise to sun-set; the seamen taking their regular turns (as at the
Title:  helm), and relieving each other every two hours.  In the serene
Title:  weather of the tropics it is exceedingly pleasant the mast-head; nay,
Title:  to a dreamy meditative man it is delightful.  There you stand, a
Title:  hundred feet above the silent decks, striding along the deep, as if
Title:  the masts were gigantic stilts, while beneath you and between your
Title:  legs, as it were, swim the hugest monsters of the sea, even as ships
Title:  once sailed between the boots of the famous Colossus at old Rhodes.
Title:  There you stand, lost in the infinite series of the sea, with nothing
Title:  ruffled but the waves.  The tranced ship indolently rolls; the drowsy
Title:  trade winds blow; everything resolves you into languor.  For the most
Title:  part, in this tropic whaling life, a sublime uneventfulness invests
Title:  you; you hear no news; read no gazettes; extras with startling
Title:  accounts of commonplaces never delude you into unnecessary
Title:  excitements; you hear of no domestic afflictions; bankrupt
Title:  securities; fall of stocks; are never troubled with the thought of
Title:  what you shall have for dinner--for all your meals for three years
Title:  and more are snugly stowed in casks, and your bill of fare is
Title:  immutable.
Title:  
Title:  In one of those southern whalesmen, on a long three or four years'
Title:  voyage, as often happens, the sum of the various hours you spend at
Title:  the mast-head would amount to several entire months.  And it is much
Title:  to be deplored that the place to which you devote so considerable a
Title:  portion of the whole term of your natural life, should be so sadly
Title:  destitute of anything approaching to a cosy inhabitiveness, or
Title:  adapted to breed a comfortable localness of feeling, such as pertains
Title:  to a bed, a hammock, a hearse, a sentry box, a pulpit, a coach, or
Title:  any other of those small and snug contrivances in which men
Title:  temporarily isolate themselves.  Your most usual point of perch is
Title:  the head of the t' gallant-mast, where you stand upon two thin
Title:  parallel sticks (almost peculiar to whalemen) called the t' gallant
Title:  cross-trees.  Here, tossed about by the sea, the beginner feels about
Title:  as cosy as he would standing on a bull's horns.  To be sure, in cold
Title:  weather you may carry your house aloft with you, in the shape of a
Title:  watch-coat; but properly speaking the thickest watch-coat is no more
Title:  of a house than the unclad body; for as the soul is glued inside of
Title:  its fleshy tabernacle, and cannot freely move about in it, nor even
Title:  move out of it, without running great risk of perishing (like an
Title:  ignorant pilgrim crossing the snowy Alps in winter); so a watch-coat
Title:  is not so much of a house as it is a mere envelope, or additional
Title:  skin encasing you.  You cannot put a shelf or chest of drawers in
Title:  your body, and no more can you make a convenient closet of your
Title:  watch-coat.
Title:  
Title:  Concerning all this, it is much to be deplored that the mast-heads of
Title:  a southern whale ship are unprovided with those enviable little tents
Title:  or pulpits, called CROW'S-NESTS, in which the look-outs of a
Title:  Greenland whaler are protected from the inclement weather of the
Title:  frozen seas.  In the fireside narrative of Captain Sleet, entitled
Title:  "A Voyage among the Icebergs, in quest of the Greenland Whale, and
Title:  incidentally for the re-discovery of the Lost Icelandic Colonies of
Title:  Old Greenland;" in this admirable volume, all standers of mast-heads
Title:  are furnished with a charmingly circumstantial account of the then
Title:  recently invented CROW'S-NEST of the Glacier, which was the name of
Title:  Captain Sleet's good craft.  He called it the SLEET'S CROW'S-NEST, in
Title:  honour of himself; he being the original inventor and patentee, and
Title:  free from all ridiculous false delicacy, and holding that if we call
Title:  our own children after our own names (we fathers being the original
Title:  inventors and patentees), so likewise should we denominate after
Title:  ourselves any other apparatus we may beget.  In shape, the Sleet's
Title:  crow's-nest is something like a large tierce or pipe; it is open
Title:  above, however, where it is furnished with a movable side-screen to
Title:  keep to windward of your head in a hard gale.  Being fixed on the
Title:  summit of the mast, you ascend into it through a little trap-hatch in
Title:  the bottom.  On the after side, or side next the stern of the ship,
Title:  is a comfortable seat, with a locker underneath for umbrellas,
Title:  comforters, and coats.  In front is a leather rack, in which to keep
Title:  your speaking trumpet, pipe, telescope, and other nautical
Title:  conveniences.  When Captain Sleet in person stood his mast-head in
Title:  this crow's-nest of his, he tells us that he always had a rifle with
Title:  him (also fixed in the rack), together with a powder flask and shot,
Title:  for the purpose of popping off the stray narwhales, or vagrant sea
Title:  unicorns infesting those waters; for you cannot successfully shoot at
Title:  them from the deck owing to the resistance of the water, but to shoot
Title:  down upon them is a very different thing.  Now, it was plainly a
Title:  labor of love for Captain Sleet to describe, as he does, all the
Title:  little detailed conveniences of his crow's-nest; but though he so
Title:  enlarges upon many of these, and though he treats us to a very
Title:  scientific account of his experiments in this crow's-nest, with a
Title:  small compass he kept there for the purpose of counteracting the
Title:  errors resulting from what is called the "local attraction" of all
Title:  binnacle magnets; an error ascribable to the horizontal vicinity of
Title:  the iron in the ship's planks, and in the Glacier's case, perhaps, to
Title:  there having been so many broken-down blacksmiths among her crew; I
Title:  say, that though the Captain is very discreet and scientific here,
Title:  yet, for all his learned "binnacle deviations," "azimuth compass
Title:  observations," and "approximate errors," he knows very well, Captain
Title:  Sleet, that he was not so much immersed in those profound magnetic
Title:  meditations, as to fail being attracted occasionally towards that
Title:  well replenished little case-bottle, so nicely tucked in on one side
Title:  of his crow's nest, within easy reach of his hand.  Though, upon the
Title:  whole, I greatly admire and even love the brave, the honest, and
Title:  learned Captain; yet I take it very ill of him that he should so
Title:  utterly ignore that case-bottle, seeing what a faithful friend and
Title:  comforter it must have been, while with mittened fingers and hooded
Title:  head he was studying the mathematics aloft there in that bird's nest
Title:  within three or four perches of the pole.
Title:  
Title:  But if we Southern whale-fishers are not so snugly housed aloft as
Title:  Captain Sleet and his Greenlandmen were; yet that disadvantage is
Title:  greatly counter-balanced by the widely contrasting serenity of those
Title:  seductive seas in which we South fishers mostly float.  For one, I
Title:  used to lounge up the rigging very leisurely, resting in the top to
Title:  have a chat with Queequeg, or any one else off duty whom I might find
Title:  there; then ascending a little way further, and throwing a lazy leg
Title:  over the top-sail yard, take a preliminary view of the watery
Title:  pastures, and so at last mount to my ultimate destination.
Title:  
Title:  Let me make a clean breast of it here, and frankly admit that I kept
Title:  but sorry guard.  With the problem of the universe revolving in me,
Title:  how could I--being left completely to myself at such a
Title:  thought-engendering altitude--how could I but lightly hold my
Title:  obligations to observe all whale-ships' standing orders, "Keep your
Title:  weather eye open, and sing out every time."
Title:  
Title:  And let me in this place movingly admonish you, ye ship-owners of
Title:  Nantucket!  Beware of enlisting in your vigilant fisheries any lad
Title:  with lean brow and hollow eye; given to unseasonable meditativeness;
Title:  and who offers to ship with the Phaedon instead of Bowditch in his
Title:  head.  Beware of such an one, I say; your whales must be seen before
Title:  they can be killed; and this sunken-eyed young Platonist will tow you
Title:  ten wakes round the world, and never make you one pint of sperm the
Title:  richer.  Nor are these monitions at all unneeded.  For nowadays, the
Title:  whale-fishery furnishes an asylum for many romantic, melancholy, and
Title:  absent-minded young men, disgusted with the carking cares of earth,
Title:  and seeking sentiment in tar and blubber.  Childe Harold not
Title:  unfrequently perches himself upon the mast-head of some luckless
Title:  disappointed whale-ship, and in moody phrase ejaculates:--
Title:  
Title:  "Roll on, thou deep and dark blue ocean, roll!  Ten thousand
Title:  blubber-hunters sweep over thee in vain."
Title:  
Title:  Very often do the captains of such ships take those absent-minded
Title:  young philosophers to task, upbraiding them with not feeling
Title:  sufficient "interest" in the voyage; half-hinting that they are so
Title:  hopelessly lost to all honourable ambition, as that in their secret
Title:  souls they would rather not see whales than otherwise.  But all in
Title:  vain; those young Platonists have a notion that their vision is
Title:  imperfect; they are short-sighted; what use, then, to strain the
Title:  visual nerve?  They have left their opera-glasses at home.
Title:  
Title:  "Why, thou monkey," said a harpooneer to one of these lads, "we've
Title:  been cruising now hard upon three years, and thou hast not raised a
Title:  whale yet.  Whales are scarce as hen's teeth whenever thou art up
Title:  here."  Perhaps they were; or perhaps there might have been shoals of
Title:  them in the far horizon; but lulled into such an opium-like
Title:  listlessness of vacant, unconscious reverie is this absent-minded
Title:  youth by the blending cadence of waves with thoughts, that at last he
Title:  loses his identity; takes the mystic ocean at his feet for the
Title:  visible image of that deep, blue, bottomless soul, pervading mankind
Title:  and nature; and every strange, half-seen, gliding, beautiful thing
Title:  that eludes him; every dimly-discovered, uprising fin of some
Title:  undiscernible form, seems to him the embodiment of those elusive
Title:  thoughts that only people the soul by continually flitting through
Title:  it.  In this enchanted mood, thy spirit ebbs away to whence it came;
Title:  becomes diffused through time and space; like Crammer's sprinkled
Title:  Pantheistic ashes, forming at last a part of every shore the round
Title:  globe over.
Title:  
Title:  There is no life in thee, now, except that rocking life imparted by a
Title:  gently rolling ship; by her, borrowed from the sea; by the sea, from
Title:  the inscrutable tides of God.  But while this sleep, this dream is on
Title:  ye, move your foot or hand an inch; slip your hold at all; and your
Title:  identity comes back in horror.  Over Descartian vortices you hover.
Title:  And perhaps, at mid-day, in the fairest weather, with one
Title:  half-throttled shriek you drop through that transparent air into the
Title:  summer sea, no more to rise for ever.  Heed it well, ye Pantheists!
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 36
Title:  
Title:  The Quarter-Deck.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  (ENTER AHAB: THEN, ALL)
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  It was not a great while after the affair of the pipe, that one
Title:  morning shortly after breakfast, Ahab, as was his wont, ascended the
Title:  cabin-gangway to the deck.  There most sea-captains usually walk at
Title:  that hour, as country gentlemen, after the same meal, take a few
Title:  turns in the garden.
Title:  
Title:  Soon his steady, ivory stride was heard, as to and fro he paced his
Title:  old rounds, upon planks so familiar to his tread, that they were all
Title:  over dented, like geological stones, with the peculiar mark of his
Title:  walk.  Did you fixedly gaze, too, upon that ribbed and dented brow;
Title:  there also, you would see still stranger foot-prints--the foot-prints
Title:  of his one unsleeping, ever-pacing thought.
Title:  
Title:  But on the occasion in question, those dents looked deeper, even as
Title:  his nervous step that morning left a deeper mark.  And, so full of
Title:  his thought was Ahab, that at every uniform turn that he made, now at
Title:  the main-mast and now at the binnacle, you could almost see that
Title:  thought turn in him as he turned, and pace in him as he paced; so
Title:  completely possessing him, indeed, that it all but seemed the inward
Title:  mould of every outer movement.
Title:  
Title:  "D'ye mark him, Flask?" whispered Stubb; "the chick that's in him
Title:  pecks the shell.  'Twill soon be out."
Title:  
Title:  The hours wore on;--Ahab now shut up within his cabin; anon, pacing
Title:  the deck, with the same intense bigotry of purpose in his aspect.
Title:  
Title:  It drew near the close of day.  Suddenly he came to a halt by the
Title:  bulwarks, and inserting his bone leg into the auger-hole there, and
Title:  with one hand grasping a shroud, he ordered Starbuck to send
Title:  everybody aft.
Title:  
Title:  "Sir!" said the mate, astonished at an order seldom or never given on
Title:  ship-board except in some extraordinary case.
Title:  
Title:  "Send everybody aft," repeated Ahab.  "Mast-heads, there! come down!"
Title:  
Title:  When the entire ship's company were assembled, and with curious and
Title:  not wholly unapprehensive faces, were eyeing him, for he looked not
Title:  unlike the weather horizon when a storm is coming up, Ahab, after
Title:  rapidly glancing over the bulwarks, and then darting his eyes among
Title:  the crew, started from his standpoint; and as though not a soul were
Title:  nigh him resumed his heavy turns upon the deck.  With bent head and
Title:  half-slouched hat he continued to pace, unmindful of the wondering
Title:  whispering among the men; till Stubb cautiously whispered to Flask,
Title:  that Ahab must have summoned them there for the purpose of witnessing
Title:  a pedestrian feat.  But this did not last long.  Vehemently pausing,
Title:  he cried:--
Title:  
Title:  "What do ye do when ye see a whale, men?"
Title:  
Title:  "Sing out for him!" was the impulsive rejoinder from a score of
Title:  clubbed voices.
Title:  
Title:  "Good!" cried Ahab, with a wild approval in his tones; observing the
Title:  hearty animation into which his unexpected question had so
Title:  magnetically thrown them.
Title:  
Title:  "And what do ye next, men?"
Title:  
Title:  "Lower away, and after him!"
Title:  
Title:  "And what tune is it ye pull to, men?"
Title:  
Title:  "A dead whale or a stove boat!"
Title:  
Title:  More and more strangely and fiercely glad and approving, grew the
Title:  countenance of the old man at every shout; while the mariners began
Title:  to gaze curiously at each other, as if marvelling how it was that
Title:  they themselves became so excited at such seemingly purposeless
Title:  questions.
Title:  
Title:  But, they were all eagerness again, as Ahab, now half-revolving in
Title:  his pivot-hole, with one hand reaching high up a shroud, and tightly,
Title:  almost convulsively grasping it, addressed them thus:--
Title:  
Title:  "All ye mast-headers have before now heard me give orders about a
Title:  white whale.  Look ye! d'ye see this Spanish ounce of gold?"--holding
Title:  up a broad bright coin to the sun--"it is a sixteen dollar piece,
Title:  men.  D'ye see it?  Mr. Starbuck, hand me yon top-maul."
Title:  
Title:  While the mate was getting the hammer, Ahab, without speaking, was
Title:  slowly rubbing the gold piece against the skirts of his jacket, as if
Title:  to heighten its lustre, and without using any words was meanwhile
Title:  lowly humming to himself, producing a sound so strangely muffled and
Title:  inarticulate that it seemed the mechanical humming of the wheels of
Title:  his vitality in him.
Title:  
Title:  Receiving the top-maul from Starbuck, he advanced towards the
Title:  main-mast with the hammer uplifted in one hand, exhibiting the gold
Title:  with the other, and with a high raised voice exclaiming: "Whosoever
Title:  of ye raises me a white-headed whale with a wrinkled brow and a
Title:  crooked jaw; whosoever of ye raises me that white-headed whale, with
Title:  three holes punctured in his starboard fluke--look ye, whosoever of
Title:  ye raises me that same white whale, he shall have this gold ounce, my
Title:  boys!"
Title:  
Title:  "Huzza! huzza!" cried the seamen, as with swinging tarpaulins they
Title:  hailed the act of nailing the gold to the mast.
Title:  
Title:  "It's a white whale, I say," resumed Ahab, as he threw down the
Title:  topmaul: "a white whale.  Skin your eyes for him, men; look sharp for
Title:  white water; if ye see but a bubble, sing out."
Title:  
Title:  All this while Tashtego, Daggoo, and Queequeg had looked on with even
Title:  more intense interest and surprise than the rest, and at the mention
Title:  of the wrinkled brow and crooked jaw they had started as if each was
Title:  separately touched by some specific recollection.
Title:  
Title:  "Captain Ahab," said Tashtego, "that white whale must be the same
Title:  that some call Moby Dick."
Title:  
Title:  "Moby Dick?" shouted Ahab.  "Do ye know the white whale then, Tash?"
Title:  
Title:  "Does he fan-tail a little curious, sir, before he goes down?" said
Title:  the Gay-Header deliberately.
Title:  
Title:  "And has he a curious spout, too," said Daggoo, "very bushy, even for
Title:  a parmacetty, and mighty quick, Captain Ahab?"
Title:  
Title:  "And he have one, two, three--oh! good many iron in him hide, too,
Title:  Captain," cried Queequeg disjointedly, "all twiske-tee be-twisk, like
Title:  him--him--" faltering hard for a word, and screwing his hand round
Title:  and round as though uncorking a bottle--"like him--him--"
Title:  
Title:  "Corkscrew!" cried Ahab, "aye, Queequeg, the harpoons lie all twisted
Title:  and wrenched in him; aye, Daggoo, his spout is a big one, like a
Title:  whole shock of wheat, and white as a pile of our Nantucket wool after
Title:  the great annual sheep-shearing; aye, Tashtego, and he fan-tails like
Title:  a split jib in a squall.  Death and devils! men, it is Moby Dick ye
Title:  have seen--Moby Dick--Moby Dick!"
Title:  
Title:  "Captain Ahab," said Starbuck, who, with Stubb and Flask, had thus
Title:  far been eyeing his superior with increasing surprise, but at last
Title:  seemed struck with a thought which somewhat explained all the wonder.
Title:  "Captain Ahab, I have heard of Moby Dick--but it was not Moby Dick
Title:  that took off thy leg?"
Title:  
Title:  "Who told thee that?" cried Ahab; then pausing, "Aye, Starbuck; aye,
Title:  my hearties all round; it was Moby Dick that dismasted me; Moby Dick
Title:  that brought me to this dead stump I stand on now.  Aye, aye," he
Title:  shouted with a terrific, loud, animal sob, like that of a
Title:  heart-stricken moose; "Aye, aye! it was that accursed white whale
Title:  that razeed me; made a poor pegging lubber of me for ever and a day!"
Title:  Then tossing both arms, with measureless imprecations he shouted
Title:  out: "Aye, aye! and I'll chase him round Good Hope, and round the
Title:  Horn, and round the Norway Maelstrom, and round perdition's flames
Title:  before I give him up.  And this is what ye have shipped for, men! to
Title:  chase that white whale on both sides of land, and over all sides of
Title:  earth, till he spouts black blood and rolls fin out.  What say ye,
Title:  men, will ye splice hands on it, now?  I think ye do look brave."
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, aye!" shouted the harpooneers and seamen, running closer to the
Title:  excited old man: "A sharp eye for the white whale; a sharp lance for
Title:  Moby Dick!"
Title:  
Title:  "God bless ye," he seemed to half sob and half shout.  "God bless ye,
Title:  men.  Steward! go draw the great measure of grog.  But what's this
Title:  long face about, Mr. Starbuck; wilt thou not chase the white whale?
Title:  art not game for Moby Dick?"
Title:  
Title:  "I am game for his crooked jaw, and for the jaws of Death too,
Title:  Captain Ahab, if it fairly comes in the way of the business we
Title:  follow; but I came here to hunt whales, not my commander's vengeance.
Title:  How many barrels will thy vengeance yield thee even if thou gettest
Title:  it, Captain Ahab? it will not fetch thee much in our Nantucket
Title:  market."
Title:  
Title:  "Nantucket market!  Hoot!  But come closer, Starbuck; thou requirest
Title:  a little lower layer.  If money's to be the measurer, man, and the
Title:  accountants have computed their great counting-house the globe, by
Title:  girdling it with guineas, one to every three parts of an inch; then,
Title:  let me tell thee, that my vengeance will fetch a great premium HERE!"
Title:  
Title:  "He smites his chest," whispered Stubb, "what's that for? methinks it
Title:  rings most vast, but hollow."
Title:  
Title:  "Vengeance on a dumb brute!" cried Starbuck, "that simply smote thee
Title:  from blindest instinct!  Madness!  To be enraged with a dumb thing,
Title:  Captain Ahab, seems blasphemous."
Title:  
Title:  "Hark ye yet again--the little lower layer.  All visible objects,
Title:  man, are but as pasteboard masks.  But in each event--in the living
Title:  act, the undoubted deed--there, some unknown but still reasoning
Title:  thing puts forth the mouldings of its features from behind the
Title:  unreasoning mask.  If man will strike, strike through the mask!  How
Title:  can the prisoner reach outside except by thrusting through the wall?
Title:  To me, the white whale is that wall, shoved near to me.  Sometimes I
Title:  think there's naught beyond.  But 'tis enough.  He tasks me; he heaps
Title:  me; I see in him outrageous strength, with an inscrutable malice
Title:  sinewing it.  That inscrutable thing is chiefly what I hate; and be
Title:  the white whale agent, or be the white whale principal, I will wreak
Title:  that hate upon him.  Talk not to me of blasphemy, man; I'd strike the
Title:  sun if it insulted me.  For could the sun do that, then could I do
Title:  the other; since there is ever a sort of fair play herein, jealousy
Title:  presiding over all creations.  But not my master, man, is even that
Title:  fair play.  Who's over me?  Truth hath no confines.  Take off thine
Title:  eye! more intolerable than fiends' glarings is a doltish stare!  So,
Title:  so; thou reddenest and palest; my heat has melted thee to anger-glow.
Title:  But look ye, Starbuck, what is said in heat, that thing unsays
Title:  itself.  There are men from whom warm words are small indignity.  I
Title:  meant not to incense thee.  Let it go.  Look! see yonder Turkish
Title:  cheeks of spotted tawn--living, breathing pictures painted by the
Title:  sun.  The Pagan leopards--the unrecking and unworshipping things,
Title:  that live; and seek, and give no reasons for the torrid life they
Title:  feel!  The crew, man, the crew!  Are they not one and all with Ahab,
Title:  in this matter of the whale?  See Stubb! he laughs!  See yonder
Title:  Chilian! he snorts to think of it.  Stand up amid the general
Title:  hurricane, thy one tost sapling cannot, Starbuck!  And what is it?
Title:  Reckon it.  'Tis but to help strike a fin; no wondrous feat for
Title:  Starbuck.  What is it more?  From this one poor hunt, then, the best
Title:  lance out of all Nantucket, surely he will not hang back, when every
Title:  foremast-hand has clutched a whetstone?  Ah! constrainings seize
Title:  thee; I see! the billow lifts thee!  Speak, but speak!--Aye, aye! thy
Title:  silence, then, THAT voices thee.  (ASIDE) Something shot from my
Title:  dilated nostrils, he has inhaled it in his lungs.  Starbuck now is
Title:  mine; cannot oppose me now, without rebellion."
Title:  
Title:  "God keep me!--keep us all!" murmured Starbuck, lowly.
Title:  
Title:  But in his joy at the enchanted, tacit acquiescence of the mate, Ahab
Title:  did not hear his foreboding invocation; nor yet the low laugh from
Title:  the hold; nor yet the presaging vibrations of the winds in the
Title:  cordage; nor yet the hollow flap of the sails against the masts, as
Title:  for a moment their hearts sank in.  For again Starbuck's downcast
Title:  eyes lighted up with the stubbornness of life; the subterranean laugh
Title:  died away; the winds blew on; the sails filled out; the ship heaved
Title:  and rolled as before.  Ah, ye admonitions and warnings! why stay ye
Title:  not when ye come?  But rather are ye predictions than warnings, ye
Title:  shadows!  Yet not so much predictions from without, as verifications
Title:  of the foregoing things within.  For with little external to
Title:  constrain us, the innermost necessities in our being, these still
Title:  drive us on.
Title:  
Title:  "The measure! the measure!" cried Ahab.
Title:  
Title:  Receiving the brimming pewter, and turning to the harpooneers, he
Title:  ordered them to produce their weapons.  Then ranging them before him
Title:  near the capstan, with their harpoons in their hands, while his three
Title:  mates stood at his side with their lances, and the rest of the ship's
Title:  company formed a circle round the group; he stood for an instant
Title:  searchingly eyeing every man of his crew.  But those wild eyes met
Title:  his, as the bloodshot eyes of the prairie wolves meet the eye of
Title:  their leader, ere he rushes on at their head in the trail of the
Title:  bison; but, alas! only to fall into the hidden snare of the Indian.
Title:  
Title:  "Drink and pass!" he cried, handing the heavy charged flagon to the
Title:  nearest seaman.  "The crew alone now drink.  Round with it, round!
Title:  Short draughts--long swallows, men; 'tis hot as Satan's hoof.  So,
Title:  so; it goes round excellently.  It spiralizes in ye; forks out at the
Title:  serpent-snapping eye.  Well done; almost drained.  That way it went,
Title:  this way it comes.  Hand it me--here's a hollow!  Men, ye seem the
Title:  years; so brimming life is gulped and gone.  Steward, refill!
Title:  
Title:  "Attend now, my braves.  I have mustered ye all round this capstan;
Title:  and ye mates, flank me with your lances; and ye harpooneers, stand
Title:  there with your irons; and ye, stout mariners, ring me in, that I may
Title:  in some sort revive a noble custom of my fisherman fathers before
Title:  me.  O men, you will yet see that--Ha! boy, come back? bad pennies
Title:  come not sooner.  Hand it me.  Why, now, this pewter had run brimming
Title:  again, were't not thou St. Vitus' imp--away, thou ague!
Title:  
Title:  "Advance, ye mates!  Cross your lances full before me.  Well done!
Title:  Let me touch the axis."  So saying, with extended arm, he grasped the
Title:  three level, radiating lances at their crossed centre; while so
Title:  doing, suddenly and nervously twitched them; meanwhile, glancing
Title:  intently from Starbuck to Stubb; from Stubb to Flask.  It seemed as
Title:  though, by some nameless, interior volition, he would fain have
Title:  shocked into them the same fiery emotion accumulated within the
Title:  Leyden jar of his own magnetic life.  The three mates quailed before
Title:  his strong, sustained, and mystic aspect.  Stubb and Flask looked
Title:  sideways from him; the honest eye of Starbuck fell downright.
Title:  
Title:  "In vain!" cried Ahab; "but, maybe, 'tis well.  For did ye three but
Title:  once take the full-forced shock, then mine own electric thing, THAT
Title:  had perhaps expired from out me.  Perchance, too, it would have
Title:  dropped ye dead.  Perchance ye need it not.  Down lances!  And now,
Title:  ye mates, I do appoint ye three cupbearers to my three pagan kinsmen
Title:  there--yon three most honourable gentlemen and noblemen, my valiant
Title:  harpooneers.  Disdain the task?  What, when the great Pope washes the
Title:  feet of beggars, using his tiara for ewer?  Oh, my sweet cardinals!
Title:  your own condescension, THAT shall bend ye to it.  I do not order ye;
Title:  ye will it.  Cut your seizings and draw the poles, ye harpooneers!"
Title:  
Title:  Silently obeying the order, the three harpooneers now stood with the
Title:  detached iron part of their harpoons, some three feet long, held,
Title:  barbs up, before him.
Title:  
Title:  "Stab me not with that keen steel!  Cant them; cant them over! know
Title:  ye not the goblet end?  Turn up the socket!  So, so; now, ye
Title:  cup-bearers, advance.  The irons! take them; hold them while I fill!"
Title:  Forthwith, slowly going from one officer to the other, he brimmed
