Title:  the harpoon sockets with the fiery waters from the pewter.
Title:  
Title:  "Now, three to three, ye stand.  Commend the murderous chalices!
Title:  Bestow them, ye who are now made parties to this indissoluble league.
Title:  Ha!  Starbuck! but the deed is done!  Yon ratifying sun now waits to
Title:  sit upon it.  Drink, ye harpooneers! drink and swear, ye men that man
Title:  the deathful whaleboat's bow--Death to Moby Dick!  God hunt us all,
Title:  if we do not hunt Moby Dick to his death!"  The long, barbed steel
Title:  goblets were lifted; and to cries and maledictions against the white
Title:  whale, the spirits were simultaneously quaffed down with a hiss.
Title:  Starbuck paled, and turned, and shivered.  Once more, and finally,
Title:  the replenished pewter went the rounds among the frantic crew; when,
Title:  waving his free hand to them, they all dispersed; and Ahab retired
Title:  within his cabin.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 37
Title:  
Title:  Sunset.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  THE CABIN; BY THE STERN WINDOWS; AHAB SITTING ALONE, AND GAZING OUT.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  I leave a white and turbid wake; pale waters, paler cheeks, where'er
Title:  I sail.  The envious billows sidelong swell to whelm my track; let
Title:  them; but first I pass.
Title:  
Title:  Yonder, by ever-brimming goblet's rim, the warm waves blush like
Title:  wine.  The gold brow plumbs the blue.  The diver sun--slow dived from
Title:  noon--goes down; my soul mounts up! she wearies with her endless
Title:  hill.  Is, then, the crown too heavy that I wear? this Iron Crown of
Title:  Lombardy.  Yet is it bright with many a gem; I the wearer, see not
Title:  its far flashings; but darkly feel that I wear that, that dazzlingly
Title:  confounds.  'Tis iron--that I know--not gold.  'Tis split, too--that
Title:  I feel; the jagged edge galls me so, my brain seems to beat against
Title:  the solid metal; aye, steel skull, mine; the sort that needs no
Title:  helmet in the most brain-battering fight!
Title:  
Title:  Dry heat upon my brow?  Oh! time was, when as the sunrise nobly
Title:  spurred me, so the sunset soothed.  No more.  This lovely light, it
Title:  lights not me; all loveliness is anguish to me, since I can ne'er
Title:  enjoy.  Gifted with the high perception, I lack the low, enjoying
Title:  power; damned, most subtly and most malignantly! damned in the midst
Title:  of Paradise!  Good night--good night! (WAVING HIS HAND, HE MOVES FROM
Title:  THE WINDOW.)
Title:  
Title:  'Twas not so hard a task.  I thought to find one stubborn, at the
Title:  least; but my one cogged circle fits into all their various wheels,
Title:  and they revolve.  Or, if you will, like so many ant-hills of powder,
Title:  they all stand before me; and I their match.  Oh, hard! that to fire
Title:  others, the match itself must needs be wasting!  What I've dared,
Title:  I've willed; and what I've willed, I'll do!  They think me
Title:  mad--Starbuck does; but I'm demoniac, I am madness maddened!  That
Title:  wild madness that's only calm to comprehend itself!  The prophecy was
Title:  that I should be dismembered; and--Aye!  I lost this leg.  I now
Title:  prophesy that I will dismember my dismemberer.  Now, then, be the
Title:  prophet and the fulfiller one.  That's more than ye, ye great gods,
Title:  ever were.  I laugh and hoot at ye, ye cricket-players, ye pugilists,
Title:  ye deaf Burkes and blinded Bendigoes!  I will not say as schoolboys
Title:  do to bullies--Take some one of your own size; don't pommel ME!  No,
Title:  ye've knocked me down, and I am up again; but YE have run and hidden.
Title:  Come forth from behind your cotton bags!  I have no long gun to
Title:  reach ye.  Come, Ahab's compliments to ye; come and see if ye can
Title:  swerve me.  Swerve me? ye cannot swerve me, else ye swerve
Title:  yourselves! man has ye there.  Swerve me?  The path to my fixed
Title:  purpose is laid with iron rails, whereon my soul is grooved to run.
Title:  Over unsounded gorges, through the rifled hearts of mountains, under
Title:  torrents' beds, unerringly I rush!  Naught's an obstacle, naught's an
Title:  angle to the iron way!
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 38
Title:  
Title:  Dusk.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  BY THE MAINMAST; STARBUCK LEANING AGAINST IT.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  My soul is more than matched; she's overmanned; and by a madman!
Title:  Insufferable sting, that sanity should ground arms on such a field!
Title:  But he drilled deep down, and blasted all my reason out of me!  I
Title:  think I see his impious end; but feel that I must help him to it.
Title:  Will I, nill I, the ineffable thing has tied me to him; tows me with
Title:  a cable I have no knife to cut.  Horrible old man!  Who's over him,
Title:  he cries;--aye, he would be a democrat to all above; look, how he
Title:  lords it over all below!  Oh!  I plainly see my miserable office,--to
Title:  obey, rebelling; and worse yet, to hate with touch of pity!  For in
Title:  his eyes I read some lurid woe would shrivel me up, had I it.  Yet is
Title:  there hope.  Time and tide flow wide.  The hated whale has the round
Title:  watery world to swim in, as the small gold-fish has its glassy globe.
Title:  His heaven-insulting purpose, God may wedge aside.  I would up
Title:  heart, were it not like lead.  But my whole clock's run down; my
Title:  heart the all-controlling weight, I have no key to lift again.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  [A BURST OF REVELRY FROM THE FORECASTLE.]
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Oh, God! to sail with such a heathen crew that have small touch of
Title:  human mothers in them!  Whelped somewhere by the sharkish sea.  The
Title:  white whale is their demigorgon.  Hark! the infernal orgies! that
Title:  revelry is forward! mark the unfaltering silence aft!  Methinks it
Title:  pictures life.  Foremost through the sparkling sea shoots on the gay,
Title:  embattled, bantering bow, but only to drag dark Ahab after it, where
Title:  he broods within his sternward cabin, builded over the dead water of
Title:  the wake, and further on, hunted by its wolfish gurglings.  The long
Title:  howl thrills me through!  Peace! ye revellers, and set the watch!
Title:  Oh, life!  'tis in an hour like this, with soul beat down and held to
Title:  knowledge,--as wild, untutored things are forced to feed--Oh, life!
Title:  'tis now that I do feel the latent horror in thee! but 'tis not me!
Title:  that horror's out of me! and with the soft feeling of the human in
Title:  me, yet will I try to fight ye, ye grim, phantom futures!  Stand by
Title:  me, hold me, bind me, O ye blessed influences!
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 39
Title:  
Title:  First Night Watch.
Title:  
Title:  Fore-Top.
Title:  
Title:  (STUBB SOLUS, AND MENDING A BRACE.)
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Ha! ha! ha! ha! hem! clear my throat!--I've been thinking over it
Title:  ever since, and that ha, ha's the final consequence.  Why so?
Title:  Because a laugh's the wisest, easiest answer to all that's queer; and
Title:  come what will, one comfort's always left--that unfailing comfort is,
Title:  it's all predestinated.  I heard not all his talk with Starbuck; but
Title:  to my poor eye Starbuck then looked something as I the other evening
Title:  felt.  Be sure the old Mogul has fixed him, too.  I twigged it, knew
Title:  it; had had the gift, might readily have prophesied it--for when I
Title:  clapped my eye upon his skull I saw it.  Well, Stubb, WISE
Title:  Stubb--that's my title--well, Stubb, what of it, Stubb?  Here's a
Title:  carcase.  I know not all that may be coming, but be it what it will,
Title:  I'll go to it laughing.  Such a waggish leering as lurks in all your
Title:  horribles!  I feel funny.  Fa, la! lirra, skirra!  What's my juicy
Title:  little pear at home doing now?  Crying its eyes out?--Giving a party
Title:  to the last arrived harpooneers, I dare say, gay as a frigate's
Title:  pennant, and so am I--fa, la! lirra, skirra!  Oh--
Title:  
Title:  We'll drink to-night with hearts as light,
Title:  To love, as gay and fleeting
Title:  As bubbles that swim, on the beaker's brim,
Title:  And break on the lips while meeting.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  A brave stave that--who calls?  Mr. Starbuck?  Aye, aye, sir--(ASIDE)
Title:  he's my superior, he has his too, if I'm not mistaken.--Aye, aye,
Title:  sir, just through with this job--coming.
Title:  
Title:

Title:  CHAPTER 40
Title:  
Title:  Midnight, Forecastle.
Title:  
Title:  HARPOONEERS AND SAILORS.
Title:  
Title:  (FORESAIL RISES AND DISCOVERS THE WATCH STANDING, LOUNGING, LEANING,
Title:  AND LYING IN VARIOUS ATTITUDES, ALL SINGING IN CHORUS.)

Title:  Farewell and adieu to you, Spanish ladies!
Title:  Farewell and adieu to you, ladies of Spain!
Title:  Our captain's commanded.--

Title:  1ST NANTUCKET SAILOR.
Title:  Oh, boys, don't be sentimental; it's bad for the digestion!  Take a
Title:  tonic, follow me!
Title:  (SINGS, AND ALL FOLLOW)
Title:  
Title:  Our captain stood upon the deck,
Title:  A spy-glass in his hand,
Title:  A viewing of those gallant whales
Title:  That blew at every strand.
Title:  Oh, your tubs in your boats, my boys,
Title:  And by your braces stand,
Title:  And we'll have one of those fine whales,
Title:  Hand, boys, over hand!
Title:  So, be cheery, my lads! may your hearts never fail!
Title:  While the bold harpooner is striking the whale!

Title:  2ND NANTUCKET SAILOR.

Title:  I've the sort of mouth for that--the hogshead mouth.  So, so,
Title:  (THRUSTS HIS HEAD DOWN THE SCUTTLE,) Star-bo-l-e-e-n-s, a-h-o-y!
Title:  Eight bells there below!  Tumble up!
Title:  
Title:  DUTCH SAILOR.
Title:  Grand snoozing to-night, maty; fat night for that.  I mark this in
Title:  our old Mogul's wine; it's quite as deadening to some as filliping to
Title:  others.  We sing; they sleep--aye, lie down there, like ground-tier
Title:  butts.  At 'em again!  There, take this copper-pump, and hail 'em
Title:  through it.  Tell 'em to avast dreaming of their lasses.  Tell 'em
Title:  it's the resurrection; they must kiss their last, and come to
Title:  judgment.  That's the way--THAT'S it; thy throat ain't spoiled with
Title:  eating Amsterdam butter.
Title:  
Title:  FRENCH SAILOR.
Title:  Hist, boys! let's have a jig or two before we ride to anchor in
Title:  Blanket Bay.  What say ye?  There comes the other watch.  Stand by
Title:  all legs!  Pip! little Pip! hurrah with your tambourine!
Title:  
Title:  PIP.
Title:  (SULKY AND SLEEPY)
Title:  Don't know where it is.
Title:  
Title:  FRENCH SAILOR.
Title:  Beat thy belly, then, and wag thy ears.  Jig it, men, I say; merry's
Title:  the word; hurrah!  Damn me, won't you dance?  Form, now, Indian-file,
Title:  and gallop into the double-shuffle?  Throw yourselves!  Legs! legs!
Title:  
Title:  ICELAND SAILOR.
Title:  I don't like your floor, maty; it's too springy to my taste.  I'm
Title:  used to ice-floors.  I'm sorry to throw cold water on the subject;
Title:  but excuse me.
Title:  
Title:  MALTESE SAILOR.
Title:  Me too; where's your girls?  Who but a fool would take his left hand
Title:  by his right, and say to himself, how d'ye do?  Partners!  I must
Title:  have partners!
Title:  
Title:  SICILIAN SAILOR.
Title:  Aye; girls and a green!--then I'll hop with ye; yea, turn
Title:  grasshopper!
Title:  
Title:  LONG-ISLAND SAILOR.
Title:  Well, well, ye sulkies, there's plenty more of us.  Hoe corn when you
Title:  may, say I.  All legs go to harvest soon.  Ah! here comes the music;
Title:  now for it!
Title:  
Title:  AZORE SAILOR.
Title:  (ASCENDING, AND PITCHING THE TAMBOURINE UP THE SCUTTLE.)
Title:  Here you are, Pip; and there's the windlass-bitts; up you mount!
Title:  Now, boys!
Title:  (THE HALF OF THEM DANCE TO THE TAMBOURINE; SOME GO BELOW; SOME SLEEP
Title:  OR LIE AMONG THE COILS OF RIGGING.  OATHS A-PLENTY.)

Title:  bell-boy!  Make fire-flies; break the jinglers!
Title:  
Title:  PIP.
Title:  Jinglers, you say?--there goes another, dropped off; I pound it so.
Title:

Title:  
Title:  TASHTEGO.
Title:  (QUIETLY SMOKING)
Title:  That's a white man; he calls that fun: humph!  I save my sweat.
Title:  
Title:  OLD MANX SAILOR.
Title:  I wonder whether those jolly lads bethink them of what they are
Title:  dancing over.  I'll dance over your grave, I will--that's the
Title:  bitterest threat of your night-women, that beat head-winds round
Title:  corners.  O Christ! to think of the green navies and the
Title:  green-skulled crews!  Well, well; belike the whole world's a ball, as
Title:  you scholars have it; and so 'tis right to make one ballroom of it.
Title:  Dance on, lads, you're young; I was once.
Title:  
Title:  3D NANTUCKET SAILOR.
Title:  Spell oh!--whew! this is worse than pulling after whales in a
Title:  calm--give us a whiff, Tash.
Title:  
Title:  (THEY CEASE DANCING, AND GATHER IN CLUSTERS.  MEANTIME THE SKY
Title:  DARKENS--THE WIND RISES.)
Title:  
Title:  LASCAR SAILOR.
Title:  By Brahma! boys, it'll be douse sail soon.  The sky-born, high-tide
Title:  Ganges turned to wind!  Thou showest thy black brow, Seeva!
Title:  
Title:  MALTESE SAILOR.
Title:  (RECLINING AND SHAKING HIS CAP.)
Title:  It's the waves--the snow's caps turn to jig it now.  They'll shake
Title:  their tassels soon.  Now would all the waves were women, then I'd go
Title:  drown, and chassee with them evermore!  There's naught so sweet on
Title:  earth--heaven may not match it!--as those swift glances of warm, wild
Title:  bosoms in the dance, when the over-arboring arms hide such ripe,
Title:  bursting grapes.
Title:  
Title:  SICILIAN SAILOR.
Title:  (RECLINING.)
Title:  Tell me not of it!  Hark ye, lad--fleet interlacings of the
Title:  limbs--lithe swayings--coyings--flutterings! lip! heart! hip! all
Title:  graze: unceasing touch and go! not taste, observe ye, else come
Title:  satiety.  Eh, Pagan? (NUDGING.)
Title:  
Title:  TAHITAN SAILOR.
Title:  (RECLINING ON A MAT.)
Title:  Hail, holy nakedness of our dancing girls!--the Heeva-Heeva!  Ah! low
Title:  veiled, high palmed Tahiti!  I still rest me on thy mat, but the soft
Title:  soil has slid!  I saw thee woven in the wood, my mat! green the first
Title:  day I brought ye thence; now worn and wilted quite.  Ah me!--not thou
Title:  nor I can bear the change!  How then, if so be transplanted to yon
Title:  sky?  Hear I the roaring streams from Pirohitee's peak of spears,
Title:  when they leap down the crags and drown the villages?--The blast! the
Title:  blast!  Up, spine, and meet it! (LEAPS TO HIS FEET.)
Title:  
Title:  PORTUGUESE SAILOR.
Title:  How the sea rolls swashing 'gainst the side!  Stand by for reefing,
Title:  hearties! the winds are just crossing swords, pell-mell they'll go
Title:  lunging presently.
Title:  
Title:  DANISH SAILOR.
Title:  Crack, crack, old ship! so long as thou crackest, thou holdest!  Well
Title:  done!  The mate there holds ye to it stiffly.  He's no more afraid
Title:  than the isle fort at Cattegat, put there to fight the Baltic with
Title:  storm-lashed guns, on which the sea-salt cakes!
Title:  
Title:  4TH NANTUCKET SAILOR.
Title:  He has his orders, mind ye that.  I heard old Ahab tell him he must
Title:  always kill a squall, something as they burst a waterspout with a
Title:  pistol--fire your ship right into it!
Title:  
Title:  ENGLISH SAILOR.
Title:  Blood! but that old man's a grand old cove!  We are the lads to hunt
Title:  him up his whale!
Title:  
Title:  ALL.
Title:  Aye! aye!
Title:  
Title:  OLD MANX SAILOR.

Title:  live when shifted to any other soil, and here there's none but the
Title:  crew's cursed clay.  Steady, helmsman! steady.  This is the sort of
Title:  weather when brave hearts snap ashore, and keeled hulls split at sea.
Title:  Our captain has his birthmark; look yonder, boys, there's another in
Title:  the sky--lurid-like, ye see, all else pitch black.
Title:  
Title:  DAGGOO.
Title:  What of that?  Who's afraid of black's afraid of me!  I'm quarried
Title:  out of it!
Title:

Title:  mankind--devilish dark at that.  No offence.
Title:

Title:

Title:  
Title:  SPANISH SAILOR (MEETING HIM).

Title:

Title:  A row! a row! a row!
Title:

Title:

Title:  A row! arrah a row!  The Virgin be blessed, a row!  Plunge in with
Title:  ye!
Title:  
Title:  ENGLISH SAILOR.
Title:  Fair play!  Snatch the Spaniard's knife!  A ring, a ring!
Title:  
Title:  OLD MANX SAILOR.
Title:  Ready formed.  There! the ringed horizon.  In that ring Cain struck
Title:  Abel.  Sweet work, right work!  No?  Why then, God, mad'st thou the
Title:  ring?
Title:  
Title:  MATE'S VOICE FROM THE QUARTER-DECK.
Title:  Hands by the halyards! in top-gallant sails!  Stand by to reef
Title:  topsails!
Title:  
Title:  ALL.
Title:  The squall! the squall! jump, my jollies! (THEY SCATTER.)
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  PIP (SHRINKING UNDER THE WINDLASS).
Title:  Jollies?  Lord help such jollies!  Crish, crash! there goes the
Title:  jib-stay!  Blang-whang!  God!  Duck lower, Pip, here comes the royal
Title:  yard!  It's worse than being in the whirled woods, the last day of
Title:  the year!  Who'd go climbing after chestnuts now?  But there they
Title:  go, all cursing, and here I don't.  Fine prospects to 'em; they're on
Title:  the road to heaven.  Hold on hard!  Jimmini, what a squall!  But
Title:  those chaps there are worse yet--they are your white squalls, they.
Title:  White squalls? white whale, shirr! shirr!  Here have I heard all
Title:  their chat just now, and the white whale--shirr! shirr!--but spoken
Title:  of once! and only this evening--it makes me jingle all over like my
Title:  tambourine--that anaconda of an old man swore 'em in to hunt him!
Title:  Oh, thou big white God aloft there somewhere in yon darkness, have
Title:  mercy on this small black boy down here; preserve him from all men
Title:  that have no bowels to feel fear!
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 41
Title:  
Title:  Moby Dick.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  I, Ishmael, was one of that crew; my shouts had gone up with the
Title:  rest; my oath had been welded with theirs; and stronger I shouted,
Title:  and more did I hammer and clinch my oath, because of the dread in my
Title:  soul.  A wild, mystical, sympathetical feeling was in me; Ahab's
Title:  quenchless feud seemed mine.  With greedy ears I learned the history
Title:  of that murderous monster against whom I and all the others had taken
Title:  our oaths of violence and revenge.
Title:  
Title:  For some time past, though at intervals only, the unaccompanied,
Title:  secluded White Whale had haunted those uncivilized seas mostly
Title:  frequented by the Sperm Whale fishermen.  But not all of them knew of
Title:  his existence; only a few of them, comparatively, had knowingly seen
Title:  him; while the number who as yet had actually and knowingly given
Title:  battle to him, was small indeed.  For, owing to the large number of
Title:  whale-cruisers; the disorderly way they were sprinkled over the
Title:  entire watery circumference, many of them adventurously pushing their
Title:  quest along solitary latitudes, so as seldom or never for a whole
Title:  twelvemonth or more on a stretch, to encounter a single news-telling
Title:  sail of any sort; the inordinate length of each separate voyage; the
Title:  irregularity of the times of sailing from home; all these, with other
Title:  circumstances, direct and indirect, long obstructed the spread
Title:  through the whole world-wide whaling-fleet of the special
Title:  individualizing tidings concerning Moby Dick.  It was hardly to be
Title:  doubted, that several vessels reported to have encountered, at such
Title:  or such a time, or on such or such a meridian, a Sperm Whale of
Title:  uncommon magnitude and malignity, which whale, after doing great
Title:  mischief to his assailants, had completely escaped them; to some
Title:  minds it was not an unfair presumption, I say, that the whale in
Title:  question must have been no other than Moby Dick.  Yet as of late the
Title:  Sperm Whale fishery had been marked by various and not unfrequent
Title:  instances of great ferocity, cunning, and malice in the monster
Title:  attacked; therefore it was, that those who by accident ignorantly
Title:  gave battle to Moby Dick; such hunters, perhaps, for the most part,
Title:  were content to ascribe the peculiar terror he bred, more, as it
Title:  were, to the perils of the Sperm Whale fishery at large, than to the
Title:  individual cause.  In that way, mostly, the disastrous encounter
Title:  between Ahab and the whale had hitherto been popularly regarded.
Title:  
Title:  And as for those who, previously hearing of the White Whale, by
Title:  chance caught sight of him; in the beginning of the thing they had
Title:  every one of them, almost, as boldly and fearlessly lowered for him,
Title:  as for any other whale of that species.  But at length, such
Title:  calamities did ensue in these assaults--not restricted to sprained
Title:  wrists and ankles, broken limbs, or devouring amputations--but fatal
Title:  to the last degree of fatality; those repeated disastrous repulses,
Title:  all accumulating and piling their terrors upon Moby Dick; those
Title:  things had gone far to shake the fortitude of many brave hunters, to
Title:  whom the story of the White Whale had eventually come.
Title:  
Title:  Nor did wild rumors of all sorts fail to exaggerate, and still the
Title:  more horrify the true histories of these deadly encounters.  For not
Title:  only do fabulous rumors naturally grow out of the very body of all
Title:  surprising terrible events,--as the smitten tree gives birth to its
Title:  fungi; but, in maritime life, far more than in that of terra firma,
Title:  wild rumors abound, wherever there is any adequate reality for them
Title:  to cling to.  And as the sea surpasses the land in this matter, so
Title:  the whale fishery surpasses every other sort of maritime life, in the
Title:  wonderfulness and fearfulness of the rumors which sometimes circulate
Title:  there.  For not only are whalemen as a body unexempt from that
Title:  ignorance and superstitiousness hereditary to all sailors; but of all
Title:  sailors, they are by all odds the most directly brought into contact
Title:  with whatever is appallingly astonishing in the sea; face to face
Title:  they not only eye its greatest marvels, but, hand to jaw, give battle
Title:  to them.  Alone, in such remotest waters, that though you sailed a
Title:  thousand miles, and passed a thousand shores, you would not come to
Title:  any chiseled hearth-stone, or aught hospitable beneath that part of
Title:  the sun; in such latitudes and longitudes, pursuing too such a
Title:  calling as he does, the whaleman is wrapped by influences all tending
Title:  to make his fancy pregnant with many a mighty birth.
Title:  
Title:  No wonder, then, that ever gathering volume from the mere transit
Title:  over the widest watery spaces, the outblown rumors of the White Whale
Title:  did in the end incorporate with themselves all manner of morbid
Title:  hints, and half-formed foetal suggestions of supernatural agencies,
Title:  which eventually invested Moby Dick with new terrors unborrowed from
Title:  anything that visibly appears.  So that in many cases such a panic
Title:  did he finally strike, that few who by those rumors, at least, had
Title:  heard of the White Whale, few of those hunters were willing to
Title:  encounter the perils of his jaw.
Title:  
Title:  But there were still other and more vital practical influences at
Title:  work.  Not even at the present day has the original prestige of the
Title:  Sperm Whale, as fearfully distinguished from all other species of the
Title:  leviathan, died out of the minds of the whalemen as a body.  There
Title:  are those this day among them, who, though intelligent and courageous
Title:  enough in offering battle to the Greenland or Right whale, would
Title:  perhaps--either from professional inexperience, or incompetency, or
Title:  timidity, decline a contest with the Sperm Whale; at any rate, there
Title:  are plenty of whalemen, especially among those whaling nations not
Title:  sailing under the American flag, who have never hostilely encountered
Title:  the Sperm Whale, but whose sole knowledge of the leviathan is
Title:  restricted to the ignoble monster primitively pursued in the North;
Title:  seated on their hatches, these men will hearken with a childish
Title:  fireside interest and awe, to the wild, strange tales of Southern
Title:  whaling.  Nor is the pre-eminent tremendousness of the great Sperm
Title:  Whale anywhere more feelingly comprehended, than on board of those
Title:  prows which stem him.
Title:  
Title:  And as if the now tested reality of his might had in former legendary
Title:  times thrown its shadow before it; we find some book
Title:  naturalists--Olassen and Povelson--declaring the Sperm Whale not only
Title:  to be a consternation to every other creature in the sea, but also to
Title:  be so incredibly ferocious as continually to be athirst for human
Title:  blood.  Nor even down to so late a time as Cuvier's, were these or
Title:  almost similar impressions effaced.  For in his Natural History, the
Title:  Baron himself affirms that at sight of the Sperm Whale, all fish
Title:  (sharks included) are "struck with the most lively terrors," and
Title:  "often in the precipitancy of their flight dash themselves against
Title:  the rocks with such violence as to cause instantaneous death."  And
Title:  however the general experiences in the fishery may amend such reports
Title:  as these; yet in their full terribleness, even to the bloodthirsty
Title:  item of Povelson, the superstitious belief in them is, in some
Title:  vicissitudes of their vocation, revived in the minds of the hunters.
Title:  
Title:  So that overawed by the rumors and portents concerning him, not a few
Title:  of the fishermen recalled, in reference to Moby Dick, the earlier
Title:  days of the Sperm Whale fishery, when it was oftentimes hard to
Title:  induce long practised Right whalemen to embark in the perils of this
Title:  new and daring warfare; such men protesting that although other
Title:  leviathans might be hopefully pursued, yet to chase and point lance
Title:  at such an apparition as the Sperm Whale was not for mortal man.
Title:  That to attempt it, would be inevitably to be torn into a quick
Title:  eternity.  On this head, there are some remarkable documents that may
Title:  be consulted.
Title:  
Title:  Nevertheless, some there were, who even in the face of these things
Title:  were ready to give chase to Moby Dick; and a still greater number
Title:  who, chancing only to hear of him distantly and vaguely, without the
Title:  specific details of any certain calamity, and without superstitious
Title:  accompaniments, were sufficiently hardy not to flee from the battle
Title:  if offered.
Title:  
Title:  One of the wild suggestions referred to, as at last coming to be
Title:  linked with the White Whale in the minds of the superstitiously
Title:  inclined, was the unearthly conceit that Moby Dick was ubiquitous;
Title:  that he had actually been encountered in opposite latitudes at one
Title:  and the same instant of time.
Title:  
Title:  Nor, credulous as such minds must have been, was this conceit
Title:  altogether without some faint show of superstitious probability.  For
Title:  as the secrets of the currents in the seas have never yet been
Title:  divulged, even to the most erudite research; so the hidden ways of
Title:  the Sperm Whale when beneath the surface remain, in great part,
Title:  unaccountable to his pursuers; and from time to time have originated
Title:  the most curious and contradictory speculations regarding them,
Title:  especially concerning the mystic modes whereby, after sounding to a
Title:  great depth, he transports himself with such vast swiftness to the
Title:  most widely distant points.
Title:  
Title:  It is a thing well known to both American and English whale-ships,
Title:  and as well a thing placed upon authoritative record years ago by
Title:  Scoresby, that some whales have been captured far north in the
Title:  Pacific, in whose bodies have been found the barbs of harpoons darted
Title:  in the Greenland seas.  Nor is it to be gainsaid, that in some of
Title:  these instances it has been declared that the interval of time
Title:  between the two assaults could not have exceeded very many days.
Title:  Hence, by inference, it has been believed by some whalemen, that the
Title:  Nor' West Passage, so long a problem to man, was never a problem to
Title:  the whale.  So that here, in the real living experience of living
Title:  men, the prodigies related in old times of the inland Strello
Title:  mountain in Portugal (near whose top there was said to be a lake in
Title:  which the wrecks of ships floated up to the surface); and that still
Title:  more wonderful story of the Arethusa fountain near Syracuse (whose
Title:  waters were believed to have come from the Holy Land by an
Title:  underground passage); these fabulous narrations are almost fully
Title:  equalled by the realities of the whalemen.
Title:  
Title:  Forced into familiarity, then, with such prodigies as these; and
Title:  knowing that after repeated, intrepid assaults, the White Whale had
Title:  escaped alive; it cannot be much matter of surprise that some
Title:  whalemen should go still further in their superstitions; declaring
Title:  Moby Dick not only ubiquitous, but immortal (for immortality is but
Title:  ubiquity in time); that though groves of spears should be planted in
Title:  his flanks, he would still swim away unharmed; or if indeed he should
Title:  ever be made to spout thick blood, such a sight would be but a
Title:  ghastly deception; for again in unensanguined billows hundreds of
Title:  leagues away, his unsullied jet would once more be seen.
Title:  
Title:  But even stripped of these supernatural surmisings, there was enough
Title:  in the earthly make and incontestable character of the monster to
Title:  strike the imagination with unwonted power.  For, it was not so much
Title:  his uncommon bulk that so much distinguished him from other sperm
Title:  whales, but, as was elsewhere thrown out--a peculiar snow-white
Title:  wrinkled forehead, and a high, pyramidical white hump.  These were
Title:  his prominent features; the tokens whereby, even in the limitless,
Title:  uncharted seas, he revealed his identity, at a long distance, to
Title:  those who knew him.
Title:  
Title:  The rest of his body was so streaked, and spotted, and marbled with
Title:  the same shrouded hue, that, in the end, he had gained his
Title:  distinctive appellation of the White Whale; a name, indeed, literally
Title:  justified by his vivid aspect, when seen gliding at high noon through
Title:  a dark blue sea, leaving a milky-way wake of creamy foam, all
Title:  spangled with golden gleamings.
Title:  
Title:  Nor was it his unwonted magnitude, nor his remarkable hue, nor yet
Title:  his deformed lower jaw, that so much invested the whale with natural
Title:  terror, as that unexampled, intelligent malignity which, according to
Title:  specific accounts, he had over and over again evinced in his
Title:  assaults.  More than all, his treacherous retreats struck more of
Title:  dismay than perhaps aught else.  For, when swimming before his
Title:  exulting pursuers, with every apparent symptom of alarm, he had
Title:  several times been known to turn round suddenly, and, bearing down
Title:  upon them, either stave their boats to splinters, or drive them back
Title:  in consternation to their ship.
Title:  
Title:  Already several fatalities had attended his chase.  But though
Title:  similar disasters, however little bruited ashore, were by no means
Title:  unusual in the fishery; yet, in most instances, such seemed the White
Title:  Whale's infernal aforethought of ferocity, that every dismembering or
Title:  death that he caused, was not wholly regarded as having been
Title:  inflicted by an unintelligent agent.
Title:  
Title:  Judge, then, to what pitches of inflamed, distracted fury the minds
Title:  of his more desperate hunters were impelled, when amid the chips of
Title:  chewed boats, and the sinking limbs of torn comrades, they swam out
Title:  of the white curds of the whale's direful wrath into the serene,
Title:  exasperating sunlight, that smiled on, as if at a birth or a bridal.
Title:  
Title:  His three boats stove around him, and oars and men both whirling in
Title:  the eddies; one captain, seizing the line-knife from his broken prow,
Title:  had dashed at the whale, as an Arkansas duellist at his foe, blindly
Title:  seeking with a six inch blade to reach the fathom-deep life of the
Title:  whale.  That captain was Ahab.  And then it was, that suddenly
Title:  sweeping his sickle-shaped lower jaw beneath him, Moby Dick had
Title:  reaped away Ahab's leg, as a mower a blade of grass in the field.  No
Title:  turbaned Turk, no hired Venetian or Malay, could have smote him with
Title:  more seeming malice.  Small reason was there to doubt, then, that
Title:  ever since that almost fatal encounter, Ahab had cherished a wild
Title:  vindictiveness against the whale, all the more fell for that in his
Title:  frantic morbidness he at last came to identify with him, not only all
Title:  his bodily woes, but all his intellectual and spiritual
Title:  exasperations.  The White Whale swam before him as the monomaniac
Title:  incarnation of all those malicious agencies which some deep men feel
Title:  eating in them, till they are left living on with half a heart and
Title:  half a lung.  That intangible malignity which has been from the
Title:  beginning; to whose dominion even the modern Christians ascribe
Title:  one-half of the worlds; which the ancient Ophites of the east
Title:  reverenced in their statue devil;--Ahab did not fall down and worship
Title:  it like them; but deliriously transferring its idea to the abhorred
Title:  white whale, he pitted himself, all mutilated, against it.  All that
Title:  most maddens and torments; all that stirs up the lees of things; all
Title:  truth with malice in it; all that cracks the sinews and cakes the
Title:  brain; all the subtle demonisms of life and thought; all evil, to
Title:  crazy Ahab, were visibly personified, and made practically assailable
Title:  in Moby Dick.  He piled upon the whale's white hump the sum of all
Title:  the general rage and hate felt by his whole race from Adam down; and
Title:  then, as if his chest had been a mortar, he burst his hot heart's
Title:  shell upon it.
Title:  
Title:  It is not probable that this monomania in him took its instant rise
Title:  at the precise time of his bodily dismemberment.  Then, in darting at
Title:  the monster, knife in hand, he had but given loose to a sudden,
Title:  passionate, corporal animosity; and when he received the stroke that
Title:  tore him, he probably but felt the agonizing bodily laceration, but
Title:  nothing more.  Yet, when by this collision forced to turn towards
Title:  home, and for long months of days and weeks, Ahab and anguish lay
Title:  stretched together in one hammock, rounding in mid winter that
Title:  dreary, howling Patagonian Cape; then it was, that his torn body and
Title:  gashed soul bled into one another; and so interfusing, made him mad.
Title:  That it was only then, on the homeward voyage, after the encounter,
Title:  that the final monomania seized him, seems all but certain from the
Title:  fact that, at intervals during the passage, he was a raving lunatic;
Title:  and, though unlimbed of a leg, yet such vital strength yet lurked in
Title:  his Egyptian chest, and was moreover intensified by his delirium,
Title:  that his mates were forced to lace him fast, even there, as he
Title:  sailed, raving in his hammock.  In a strait-jacket, he swung to the
Title:  mad rockings of the gales.  And, when running into more sufferable
Title:  latitudes, the ship, with mild stun'sails spread, floated across the
Title:  tranquil tropics, and, to all appearances, the old man's delirium
Title:  seemed left behind him with the Cape Horn swells, and he came forth
Title:  from his dark den into the blessed light and air; even then, when he
Title:  bore that firm, collected front, however pale, and issued his calm
Title:  orders once again; and his mates thanked God the direful madness was
Title:  now gone; even then, Ahab, in his hidden self, raved on.  Human
Title:  madness is oftentimes a cunning and most feline thing.  When you
Title:  think it fled, it may have but become transfigured into some still
Title:  subtler form.  Ahab's full lunacy subsided not, but deepeningly
Title:  contracted; like the unabated Hudson, when that noble Northman flows
Title:  narrowly, but unfathomably through the Highland gorge.  But, as in
Title:  his narrow-flowing monomania, not one jot of Ahab's broad madness had
Title:  been left behind; so in that broad madness, not one jot of his great
Title:  natural intellect had perished.  That before living agent, now became
Title:  the living instrument.  If such a furious trope may stand, his
Title:  special lunacy stormed his general sanity, and carried it, and turned
Title:  all its concentred cannon upon its own mad mark; so that far from
Title:  having lost his strength, Ahab, to that one end, did now possess a
Title:  thousand fold more potency than ever he had sanely brought to bear
Title:  upon any one reasonable object.
Title:  
Title:  This is much; yet Ahab's larger, darker, deeper part remains
Title:  unhinted.  But vain to popularize profundities, and all truth is
Title:  profound.  Winding far down from within the very heart of this spiked
Title:  Hotel de Cluny where we here stand--however grand and wonderful, now
Title:  quit it;--and take your way, ye nobler, sadder souls, to those vast
Title:  Roman halls of Thermes; where far beneath the fantastic towers of
Title:  man's upper earth, his root of grandeur, his whole awful essence sits
Title:  in bearded state; an antique buried beneath antiquities, and throned
Title:  on torsoes!  So with a broken throne, the great gods mock that
Title:  captive king; so like a Caryatid, he patient sits, upholding on his
Title:  frozen brow the piled entablatures of ages.  Wind ye down there, ye
Title:  prouder, sadder souls! question that proud, sad king!  A family
Title:  likeness! aye, he did beget ye, ye young exiled royalties; and from
Title:  your grim sire only will the old State-secret come.
Title:  
Title:  Now, in his heart, Ahab had some glimpse of this, namely: all my
Title:  means are sane, my motive and my object mad.  Yet without power to
Title:  kill, or change, or shun the fact; he likewise knew that to mankind
Title:  he did long dissemble; in some sort, did still.  But that thing of
Title:  his dissembling was only subject to his perceptibility, not to his
Title:  will determinate.  Nevertheless, so well did he succeed in that
Title:  dissembling, that when with ivory leg he stepped ashore at last, no
Title:  Nantucketer thought him otherwise than but naturally grieved, and
Title:  that to the quick, with the terrible casualty which had overtaken
Title:  him.
Title:  
Title:  The report of his undeniable delirium at sea was likewise popularly
Title:  ascribed to a kindred cause.  And so too, all the added moodiness
Title:  which always afterwards, to the very day of sailing in the Pequod on
Title:  the present voyage, sat brooding on his brow.  Nor is it so very
Title:  unlikely, that far from distrusting his fitness for another whaling
Title:  voyage, on account of such dark symptoms, the calculating people of
Title:  that prudent isle were inclined to harbor the conceit, that for those
Title:  very reasons he was all the better qualified and set on edge, for a
Title:  pursuit so full of rage and wildness as the bloody hunt of whales.
Title:  Gnawed within and scorched without, with the infixed, unrelenting
Title:  fangs of some incurable idea; such an one, could he be found, would
Title:  seem the very man to dart his iron and lift his lance against the
Title:  most appalling of all brutes.  Or, if for any reason thought to be
Title:  corporeally incapacitated for that, yet such an one would seem
Title:  superlatively competent to cheer and howl on his underlings to the
Title:  attack.  But be all this as it may, certain it is, that with the mad
Title:  secret of his unabated rage bolted up and keyed in him, Ahab had
Title:  purposely sailed upon the present voyage with the one only and
Title:  all-engrossing object of hunting the White Whale.  Had any one of his
Title:  old acquaintances on shore but half dreamed of what was lurking in
Title:  him then, how soon would their aghast and righteous souls have
Title:  wrenched the ship from such a fiendish man!  They were bent on
Title:  profitable cruises, the profit to be counted down in dollars from the
Title:  mint.  He was intent on an audacious, immitigable, and supernatural
Title:  revenge.
Title:  
Title:  Here, then, was this grey-headed, ungodly old man, chasing with
Title:  curses a Job's whale round the world, at the head of a crew, too,
Title:  chiefly made up of mongrel renegades, and castaways, and
Title:  cannibals--morally enfeebled also, by the incompetence of mere
Title:  unaided virtue or right-mindedness in Starbuck, the invunerable
Title:  jollity of indifference and recklessness in Stubb, and the pervading
Title:  mediocrity in Flask.  Such a crew, so officered, seemed specially
Title:  picked and packed by some infernal fatality to help him to his
Title:  monomaniac revenge.  How it was that they so aboundingly responded to
Title:  the old man's ire--by what evil magic their souls were possessed,
Title:  that at times his hate seemed almost theirs; the White Whale as much
Title:  their insufferable foe as his; how all this came to be--what the
Title:  White Whale was to them, or how to their unconscious understandings,
Title:  also, in some dim, unsuspected way, he might have seemed the gliding
Title:  great demon of the seas of life,--all this to explain, would be to
Title:  dive deeper than Ishmael can go.  The subterranean miner that works
Title:  in us all, how can one tell whither leads his shaft by the ever
Title:  shifting, muffled sound of his pick?  Who does not feel the
Title:  irresistible arm drag?  What skiff in tow of a seventy-four can stand
Title:  still?  For one, I gave myself up to the abandonment of the time and
Title:  the place; but while yet all a-rush to encounter the whale, could see
Title:  naught in that brute but the deadliest ill.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 42
Title:  
Title:  The Whiteness of The Whale.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  What the white whale was to Ahab, has been hinted; what, at times, he
Title:  was to me, as yet remains unsaid.
Title:  
Title:  Aside from those more obvious considerations touching Moby Dick,
Title:  which could not but occasionally awaken in any man's soul some alarm,
Title:  there was another thought, or rather vague, nameless horror
Title:  concerning him, which at times by its intensity completely
Title:  overpowered all the rest; and yet so mystical and well nigh ineffable
Title:  was it, that I almost despair of putting it in a comprehensible form.
Title:  It was the whiteness of the whale that above all things appalled me.
Title:  But how can I hope to explain myself here; and yet, in some dim,
Title:  random way, explain myself I must, else all these chapters might be
Title:  naught.
Title:  
Title:  Though in many natural objects, whiteness refiningly enhances beauty,
Title:  as if imparting some special virtue of its own, as in marbles,
Title:  japonicas, and pearls; and though various nations have in some way
Title:  recognised a certain royal preeminence in this hue; even the
Title:  barbaric, grand old kings of Pegu placing the title "Lord of the
Title:  White Elephants" above all their other magniloquent ascriptions of
Title:  dominion; and the modern kings of Siam unfurling the same snow-white
Title:  quadruped in the royal standard; and the Hanoverian flag bearing the
Title:  one figure of a snow-white charger; and the great Austrian Empire,
Title:  Caesarian, heir to overlording Rome, having for the imperial colour
Title:  the same imperial hue; and though this pre-eminence in it applies to
Title:  the human race itself, giving the white man ideal mastership over
Title:  every dusky tribe; and though, besides, all this, whiteness has been
Title:  even made significant of gladness, for among the Romans a white stone
Title:  marked a joyful day; and though in other mortal sympathies and
Title:  symbolizings, this same hue is made the emblem of many touching,
Title:  noble things--the innocence of brides, the benignity of age; though
Title:  among the Red Men of America the giving of the white belt of wampum
Title:  was the deepest pledge of honour; though in many climes, whiteness
Title:  typifies the majesty of Justice in the ermine of the Judge, and
Title:  contributes to the daily state of kings and queens drawn by
Title:  milk-white steeds; though even in the higher mysteries of the most
Title:  august religions it has been made the symbol of the divine
Title:  spotlessness and power; by the Persian fire worshippers, the white
Title:  forked flame being held the holiest on the altar; and in the Greek
Title:  mythologies, Great Jove himself being made incarnate in a snow-white
Title:  bull; and though to the noble Iroquois, the midwinter sacrifice of
Title:  the sacred White Dog was by far the holiest festival of their
Title:  theology, that spotless, faithful creature being held the purest
Title:  envoy they could send to the Great Spirit with the annual tidings of
Title:  their own fidelity; and though directly from the Latin word for
Title:  white, all Christian priests derive the name of one part of their
Title:  sacred vesture, the alb or tunic, worn beneath the cassock; and
Title:  though among the holy pomps of the Romish faith, white is specially
Title:  employed in the celebration of the Passion of our Lord; though in the
Title:  Vision of St. John, white robes are given to the redeemed, and the
Title:  four-and-twenty elders stand clothed in white before the great-white
Title:  throne, and the Holy One that sitteth there white like wool; yet for
Title:  all these accumulated associations, with whatever is sweet, and
Title:  honourable, and sublime, there yet lurks an elusive something in the
Title:  innermost idea of this hue, which strikes more of panic to the soul
Title:  than that redness which affrights in blood.
Title:  
Title:  This elusive quality it is, which causes the thought of whiteness,
Title:  when divorced from more kindly associations, and coupled with any
Title:  object terrible in itself, to heighten that terror to the furthest
Title:  bounds.  Witness the white bear of the poles, and the white shark of
Title:  the tropics; what but their smooth, flaky whiteness makes them the
Title:  transcendent horrors they are?  That ghastly whiteness it is which
Title:  imparts such an abhorrent mildness, even more loathsome than
Title:  terrific, to the dumb gloating of their aspect.  So that not the
Title:  fierce-fanged tiger in his heraldic coat can so stagger courage as
Title:  the white-shrouded bear or shark.*
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *With reference to the Polar bear, it may possibly be urged by him
Title:  who would fain go still deeper into this matter, that it is not the
Title:  whiteness, separately regarded, which heightens the intolerable
Title:  hideousness of that brute; for, analysed, that heightened
Title:  hideousness, it might be said, only rises from the circumstance, that
Title:  the irresponsible ferociousness of the creature stands invested in
Title:  the fleece of celestial innocence and love; and hence, by bringing
Title:  together two such opposite emotions in our minds, the Polar bear
Title:  frightens us with so unnatural a contrast.  But even assuming all
Title:  this to be true; yet, were it not for the whiteness, you would not
Title:  have that intensified terror.
Title:  
Title:  As for the white shark, the white gliding ghostliness of repose in
Title:  that creature, when beheld in his ordinary moods, strangely tallies
Title:  with the same quality in the Polar quadruped.  This peculiarity is
Title:  most vividly hit by the French in the name they bestow upon that
Title:  fish.  The Romish mass for the dead begins with "Requiem eternam"
Title:  (eternal rest), whence REQUIEM denominating the mass itself, and any
Title:  other funeral music.  Now, in allusion to the white, silent stillness
Title:  of death in this shark, and the mild deadliness of his habits, the
Title:  French call him REQUIN.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Bethink thee of the albatross, whence come those clouds of spiritual
Title:  wonderment and pale dread, in which that white phantom sails in all
Title:  imaginations?  Not Coleridge first threw that spell; but God's great,
Title:  unflattering laureate, Nature.*
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *I remember the first albatross I ever saw.  It was during a
Title:  prolonged gale, in waters hard upon the Antarctic seas.  From my
Title:  forenoon watch below, I ascended to the overclouded deck; and there,
Title:  dashed upon the main hatches, I saw a regal, feathery thing of
Title:  unspotted whiteness, and with a hooked, Roman bill sublime.  At
Title:  intervals, it arched forth its vast archangel wings, as if to embrace
Title:  some holy ark.  Wondrous flutterings and throbbings shook it.  Though
Title:  bodily unharmed, it uttered cries, as some king's ghost in
Title:  supernatural distress.  Through its inexpressible, strange eyes,
Title:  methought I peeped to secrets which took hold of God.  As Abraham
Title:  before the angels, I bowed myself; the white thing was so white, its
Title:  wings so wide, and in those for ever exiled waters, I had lost the
Title:  miserable warping memories of traditions and of towns.  Long I gazed
Title:  at that prodigy of plumage.  I cannot tell, can only hint, the things
Title:  that darted through me then.  But at last I awoke; and turning, asked
Title:  a sailor what bird was this.  A goney, he replied.  Goney! never had
Title:  heard that name before; is it conceivable that this glorious thing is
Title:  utterly unknown to men ashore! never!  But some time after, I learned
Title:  that goney was some seaman's name for albatross.  So that by no
Title:  possibility could Coleridge's wild Rhyme have had aught to do with
Title:  those mystical impressions which were mine, when I saw that bird upon
Title:  our deck.  For neither had I then read the Rhyme, nor knew the bird
Title:  to be an albatross.  Yet, in saying this, I do but indirectly burnish
Title:  a little brighter the noble merit of the poem and the poet.
Title:  
Title:  I assert, then, that in the wondrous bodily whiteness of the bird
Title:  chiefly lurks the secret of the spell; a truth the more evinced in
Title:  this, that by a solecism of terms there are birds called grey
Title:  albatrosses; and these I have frequently seen, but never with such
Title:  emotions as when I beheld the Antarctic fowl.
Title:  
Title:  But how had the mystic thing been caught?  Whisper it not, and I will
Title:  tell; with a treacherous hook and line, as the fowl floated on the
Title:  sea.  At last the Captain made a postman of it; tying a lettered,
Title:  leathern tally round its neck, with the ship's time and place; and
Title:  then letting it escape.  But I doubt not, that leathern tally, meant
Title:  for man, was taken off in Heaven, when the white fowl flew to join
Title:  the wing-folding, the invoking, and adoring cherubim!
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Most famous in our Western annals and Indian traditions is that of
Title:  the White Steed of the Prairies; a magnificent milk-white charger,
Title:  large-eyed, small-headed, bluff-chested, and with the dignity of a
Title:  thousand monarchs in his lofty, overscorning carriage.  He was the
Title:  elected Xerxes of vast herds of wild horses, whose pastures in those
Title:  days were only fenced by the Rocky Mountains and the Alleghanies.  At
Title:  their flaming head he westward trooped it like that chosen star which
Title:  every evening leads on the hosts of light.  The flashing cascade of
Title:  his mane, the curving comet of his tail, invested him with housings
Title:  more resplendent than gold and silver-beaters could have furnished
Title:  him.  A most imperial and archangelical apparition of that unfallen,
Title:  western world, which to the eyes of the old trappers and hunters
Title:  revived the glories of those primeval times when Adam walked majestic
Title:  as a god, bluff-browed and fearless as this mighty steed.  Whether
Title:  marching amid his aides and marshals in the van of countless cohorts
Title:  that endlessly streamed it over the plains, like an Ohio; or whether
Title:  with his circumambient subjects browsing all around at the horizon,
Title:  the White Steed gallopingly reviewed them with warm nostrils
Title:  reddening through his cool milkiness; in whatever aspect he presented
Title:  himself, always to the bravest Indians he was the object of trembling
Title:  reverence and awe.  Nor can it be questioned from what stands on
Title:  legendary record of this noble horse, that it was his spiritual
Title:  whiteness chiefly, which so clothed him with divineness; and that
Title:  this divineness had that in it which, though commanding worship, at
Title:  the same time enforced a certain nameless terror.
Title:  
Title:  But there are other instances where this whiteness loses all that
Title:  accessory and strange glory which invests it in the White Steed and
Title:  Albatross.
Title:  
Title:  What is it that in the Albino man so peculiarly repels and often
Title:  shocks the eye, as that sometimes he is loathed by his own kith and
Title:  kin!  It is that whiteness which invests him, a thing expressed by
Title:  the name he bears.  The Albino is as well made as other men--has no
Title:  substantive deformity--and yet this mere aspect of all-pervading
Title:  whiteness makes him more strangely hideous than the ugliest abortion.
Title:  Why should this be so?
Title:  
Title:  Nor, in quite other aspects, does Nature in her least palpable but
Title:  not the less malicious agencies, fail to enlist among her forces this
Title:  crowning attribute of the terrible.  From its snowy aspect, the
Title:  gauntleted ghost of the Southern Seas has been denominated the White
Title:  Squall.  Nor, in some historic instances, has the art of human malice
Title:  omitted so potent an auxiliary.  How wildly it heightens the effect
Title:  of that passage in Froissart, when, masked in the snowy symbol of
Title:  their faction, the desperate White Hoods of Ghent murder their
Title:  bailiff in the market-place!
Title:  
Title:  Nor, in some things, does the common, hereditary experience of all
Title:  mankind fail to bear witness to the supernaturalism of this hue.  It
Title:  cannot well be doubted, that the one visible quality in the aspect of
Title:  the dead which most appals the gazer, is the marble pallor lingering
Title:  there; as if indeed that pallor were as much like the badge of
Title:  consternation in the other world, as of mortal trepidation here.  And
Title:  from that pallor of the dead, we borrow the expressive hue of the
Title:  shroud in which we wrap them.  Nor even in our superstitions do we
Title:  fail to throw the same snowy mantle round our phantoms; all ghosts
Title:  rising in a milk-white fog--Yea, while these terrors seize us, let us
Title:  add, that even the king of terrors, when personified by the
Title:  evangelist, rides on his pallid horse.
Title:  
Title:  Therefore, in his other moods, symbolize whatever grand or gracious
Title:  thing he will by whiteness, no man can deny that in its profoundest
Title:  idealized significance it calls up a peculiar apparition to the soul.
Title:  
Title:  But though without dissent this point be fixed, how is mortal man to
Title:  account for it?  To analyse it, would seem impossible.  Can we,
Title:  then, by the citation of some of those instances wherein this thing
Title:  of whiteness--though for the time either wholly or in great part
Title:  stripped of all direct associations calculated to impart to it aught
Title:  fearful, but nevertheless, is found to exert over us the same
Title:  sorcery, however modified;--can we thus hope to light upon some
Title:  chance clue to conduct us to the hidden cause we seek?
Title:  
Title:  Let us try.  But in a matter like this, subtlety appeals to subtlety,
Title:  and without imagination no man can follow another into these halls.
Title:  And though, doubtless, some at least of the imaginative impressions
Title:  about to be presented may have been shared by most men, yet few
Title:  perhaps were entirely conscious of them at the time, and therefore
Title:  may not be able to recall them now.
Title:  
Title:  Why to the man of untutored ideality, who happens to be but loosely
Title:  acquainted with the peculiar character of the day, does the bare
Title:  mention of Whitsuntide marshal in the fancy such long, dreary,
Title:  speechless processions of slow-pacing pilgrims, down-cast and hooded
Title:  with new-fallen snow?  Or, to the unread, unsophisticated Protestant
Title:  of the Middle American States, why does the passing mention of a
Title:  White Friar or a White Nun, evoke such an eyeless statue in the soul?
Title:  
Title:  Or what is there apart from the traditions of dungeoned warriors and
Title:  kings (which will not wholly account for it) that makes the White
Title:  Tower of London tell so much more strongly on the imagination of an
Title:  untravelled American, than those other storied structures, its
Title:  neighbors--the Byward Tower, or even the Bloody?  And those sublimer
Title:  towers, the White Mountains of New Hampshire, whence, in peculiar
Title:  moods, comes that gigantic ghostliness over the soul at the bare
Title:  mention of that name, while the thought of Virginia's Blue Ridge is
Title:  full of a soft, dewy, distant dreaminess?  Or why, irrespective of
Title:  all latitudes and longitudes, does the name of the White Sea exert
Title:  such a spectralness over the fancy, while that of the Yellow Sea
Title:  lulls us with mortal thoughts of long lacquered mild afternoons on
Title:  the waves, followed by the gaudiest and yet sleepiest of sunsets?
Title:  Or, to choose a wholly unsubstantial instance, purely addressed to
Title:  the fancy, why, in reading the old fairy tales of Central Europe,
Title:  does "the tall pale man" of the Hartz forests, whose changeless
Title:  pallor unrustlingly glides through the green of the groves--why is
Title:  this phantom more terrible than all the whooping imps of the
Title:  Blocksburg?
Title:  
Title:  Nor is it, altogether, the remembrance of her cathedral-toppling
Title:  earthquakes; nor the stampedoes of her frantic seas; nor the
Title:  tearlessness of arid skies that never rain; nor the sight of her
Title:  wide field of leaning spires, wrenched cope-stones, and crosses all
Title:  adroop (like canted yards of anchored fleets); and her suburban
Title:  avenues of house-walls lying over upon each other, as a tossed pack
Title:  of cards;--it is not these things alone which make tearless Lima, the
Title:  strangest, saddest city thou can'st see.  For Lima has taken the
Title:  white veil; and there is a higher horror in this whiteness of her
Title:  woe.  Old as Pizarro, this whiteness keeps her ruins for ever new;
Title:  admits not the cheerful greenness of complete decay; spreads over her
Title:  broken ramparts the rigid pallor of an apoplexy that fixes its own
Title:  distortions.
Title:  
Title:  I know that, to the common apprehension, this phenomenon of whiteness
Title:  is not confessed to be the prime agent in exaggerating the terror of
Title:  objects otherwise terrible; nor to the unimaginative mind is there
Title:  aught of terror in those appearances whose awfulness to another mind
Title:  almost solely consists in this one phenomenon, especially when
Title:  exhibited under any form at all approaching to muteness or
Title:  universality.  What I mean by these two statements may perhaps be
Title:  respectively elucidated by the following examples.
Title:  
Title:  First: The mariner, when drawing nigh the coasts of foreign lands, if
Title:  by night he hear the roar of breakers, starts to vigilance, and feels
Title:  just enough of trepidation to sharpen all his faculties; but under
Title:  precisely similar circumstances, let him be called from his hammock
Title:  to view his ship sailing through a midnight sea of milky
Title:  whiteness--as if from encircling headlands shoals of combed white
Title:  bears were swimming round him, then he feels a silent, superstitious
Title:  dread; the shrouded phantom of the whitened waters is horrible to him
Title:  as a real ghost; in vain the lead assures him he is still off
Title:  soundings; heart and helm they both go down; he never rests till blue
Title:  water is under him again.  Yet where is the mariner who will tell
Title:  thee, "Sir, it was not so much the fear of striking hidden rocks, as
Title:  the fear of that hideous whiteness that so stirred me?"
Title:  
Title:  Second: To the native Indian of Peru, the continual sight of the
Title:  snowhowdahed Andes conveys naught of dread, except, perhaps, in the
Title:  mere fancying of the eternal frosted desolateness reigning at such
Title:  vast altitudes, and the natural conceit of what a fearfulness it
Title:  would be to lose oneself in such inhuman solitudes.  Much the same is
Title:  it with the backwoodsman of the West, who with comparative
Title:  indifference views an unbounded prairie sheeted with driven snow, no
Title:  shadow of tree or twig to break the fixed trance of whiteness.  Not
Title:  so the sailor, beholding the scenery of the Antarctic seas; where at
Title:  times, by some infernal trick of legerdemain in the powers of frost
Title:  and air, he, shivering and half shipwrecked, instead of rainbows
Title:  speaking hope and solace to his misery, views what seems a boundless
Title:  churchyard grinning upon him with its lean ice monuments and
Title:  splintered crosses.
Title:  
Title:  But thou sayest, methinks that white-lead chapter about whiteness is
Title:  but a white flag hung out from a craven soul; thou surrenderest to a
Title:  hypo, Ishmael.
Title:  
Title:  Tell me, why this strong young colt, foaled in some peaceful valley
Title:  of Vermont, far removed from all beasts of prey--why is it that upon
Title:  the sunniest day, if you but shake a fresh buffalo robe behind him,
Title:  so that he cannot even see it, but only smells its wild animal
Title:  muskiness--why will he start, snort, and with bursting eyes paw the
Title:  ground in phrensies of affright?  There is no remembrance in him of
Title:  any gorings of wild creatures in his green northern home, so that the
Title:  strange muskiness he smells cannot recall to him anything associated
Title:  with the experience of former perils; for what knows he, this New
Title:  England colt, of the black bisons of distant Oregon?
Title:  
Title:  No; but here thou beholdest even in a dumb brute, the instinct of the
Title:  knowledge of the demonism in the world.  Though thousands of miles
Title:  from Oregon, still when he smells that savage musk, the rending,
Title:  goring bison herds are as present as to the deserted wild foal of the
Title:  prairies, which this instant they may be trampling into dust.
Title:  
Title:  Thus, then, the muffled rollings of a milky sea; the bleak rustlings
Title:  of the festooned frosts of mountains; the desolate shiftings of the
Title:  windrowed snows of prairies; all these, to Ishmael, are as the
Title:  shaking of that buffalo robe to the frightened colt!
Title:  
Title:  Though neither knows where lie the nameless things of which the
Title:  mystic sign gives forth such hints; yet with me, as with the colt,
Title:  somewhere those things must exist.  Though in many of its aspects
Title:  this visible world seems formed in love, the invisible spheres were
Title:  formed in fright.
Title:  
Title:  But not yet have we solved the incantation of this whiteness, and
Title:  learned why it appeals with such power to the soul; and more strange
Title:  and far more portentous--why, as we have seen, it is at once the most
Title:  meaning symbol of spiritual things, nay, the very veil of the
Title:  Christian's Deity; and yet should be as it is, the intensifying agent
Title:  in things the most appalling to mankind.
Title:  
Title:  Is it that by its indefiniteness it shadows forth the heartless voids
Title:  and immensities of the universe, and thus stabs us from behind with
Title:  the thought of annihilation, when beholding the white depths of the
Title:  milky way?  Or is it, that as in essence whiteness is not so much a
Title:  colour as the visible absence of colour; and at the same time the
Title:  concrete of all colours; is it for these reasons that there is such a
Title:  dumb blankness, full of meaning, in a wide landscape of snows--a
Title:  colourless, all-colour of atheism from which we shrink?  And when we
Title:  consider that other theory of the natural philosophers, that all
Title:  other earthly hues--every stately or lovely emblazoning--the sweet
Title:  tinges of sunset skies and woods; yea, and the gilded velvets of
Title:  butterflies, and the butterfly cheeks of young girls; all these are
Title:  but subtile deceits, not actually inherent in substances, but only
Title:  laid on from without; so that all deified Nature absolutely paints
Title:  like the harlot, whose allurements cover nothing but the
Title:  charnel-house within; and when we proceed further, and consider that
Title:  the mystical cosmetic which produces every one of her hues, the great
Title:  principle of light, for ever remains white or colourless in itself,
Title:  and if operating without medium upon matter, would touch all objects,
Title:  even tulips and roses, with its own blank tinge--pondering all this,
Title:  the palsied universe lies before us a leper; and like wilful
Title:  travellers in Lapland, who refuse to wear coloured and colouring
Title:  glasses upon their eyes, so the wretched infidel gazes himself blind
Title:  at the monumental white shroud that wraps all the prospect around
Title:  him.  And of all these things the Albino whale was the symbol.
Title:  Wonder ye then at the fiery hunt?
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 43
Title:  
Title:  Hark!
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "HIST!  Did you hear that noise, Cabaco?
Title:  
Title:  It was the middle-watch; a fair moonlight; the seamen were standing
Title:  in a cordon, extending from one of the fresh-water butts in the
Title:  waist, to the scuttle-butt near the taffrail.  In this manner, they
Title:  passed the buckets to fill the scuttle-butt.  Standing, for the most
Title:  part, on the hallowed precincts of the quarter-deck, they were
Title:  careful not to speak or rustle their feet.  From hand to hand, the
Title:  buckets went in the deepest silence, only broken by the occasional
Title:  flap of a sail, and the steady hum of the unceasingly advancing keel.
Title:  
Title:  It was in the midst of this repose, that Archy, one of the cordon,
Title:  whose post was near the after-hatches, whispered to his neighbor, a
Title:  Cholo, the words above.
Title:  
Title:  "Hist! did you hear that noise, Cabaco?"
Title:  
Title:  "Take the bucket, will ye, Archy? what noise d'ye mean?"
Title:  
Title:  "There it is again--under the hatches--don't you hear it--a cough--it
Title:  sounded like a cough."
Title:  
Title:  "Cough be damned!  Pass along that return bucket."
Title:  
Title:  "There again--there it is!--it sounds like two or three sleepers
Title:  turning over, now!"
Title:  
Title:  "Caramba! have done, shipmate, will ye?  It's the three soaked
Title:  biscuits ye eat for supper turning over inside of ye--nothing else.
Title:  Look to the bucket!"
Title:  
Title:  "Say what ye will, shipmate; I've sharp ears."
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, you are the chap, ain't ye, that heard the hum of the old
Title:  Quakeress's knitting-needles fifty miles at sea from Nantucket;
Title:  you're the chap."
Title:  
Title:  "Grin away; we'll see what turns up.  Hark ye, Cabaco, there is
Title:  somebody down in the after-hold that has not yet been seen on deck;
Title:  and I suspect our old Mogul knows something of it too.  I heard Stubb
Title:  tell Flask, one morning watch, that there was something of that sort
Title:  in the wind."
Title:  
Title:  "Tish! the bucket!"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 44
Title:  
Title:  The Chart.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Had you followed Captain Ahab down into his cabin after the squall
Title:  that took place on the night succeeding that wild ratification of his
Title:  purpose with his crew, you would have seen him go to a locker in the
Title:  transom, and bringing out a large wrinkled roll of yellowish sea
Title:  charts, spread them before him on his screwed-down table.  Then
Title:  seating himself before it, you would have seen him intently study the
Title:  various lines and shadings which there met his eye; and with slow but
Title:  steady pencil trace additional courses over spaces that before were
Title:  blank.  At intervals, he would refer to piles of old log-books beside
Title:  him, wherein were set down the seasons and places in which, on
Title:  various former voyages of various ships, sperm whales had been
Title:  captured or seen.
Title:  
Title:  While thus employed, the heavy pewter lamp suspended in chains over
Title:  his head, continually rocked with the motion of the ship, and for
Title:  ever threw shifting gleams and shadows of lines upon his wrinkled
Title:  brow, till it almost seemed that while he himself was marking out
Title:  lines and courses on the wrinkled charts, some invisible pencil was
Title:  also tracing lines and courses upon the deeply marked chart of his
Title:  forehead.
Title:  
Title:  But it was not this night in particular that, in the solitude of his
Title:  cabin, Ahab thus pondered over his charts.  Almost every night they
Title:  were brought out; almost every night some pencil marks were effaced,
Title:  and others were substituted.  For with the charts of all four oceans
Title:  before him, Ahab was threading a maze of currents and eddies, with a
Title:  view to the more certain accomplishment of that monomaniac thought of
Title:  his soul.
Title:  
Title:  Now, to any one not fully acquainted with the ways of the leviathans,
Title:  it might seem an absurdly hopeless task thus to seek out one solitary
Title:  creature in the unhooped oceans of this planet.  But not so did it
Title:  seem to Ahab, who knew the sets of all tides and currents; and
Title:  thereby calculating the driftings of the sperm whale's food; and,
Title:  also, calling to mind the regular, ascertained seasons for hunting
Title:  him in particular latitudes; could arrive at reasonable surmises,
Title:  almost approaching to certainties, concerning the timeliest day to be
Title:  upon this or that ground in search of his prey.
Title:  
Title:  So assured, indeed, is the fact concerning the periodicalness of the
Title:  sperm whale's resorting to given waters, that many hunters believe
Title:  that, could he be closely observed and studied throughout the world;
Title:  were the logs for one voyage of the entire whale fleet carefully
Title:  collated, then the migrations of the sperm whale would be found to
Title:  correspond in invariability to those of the herring-shoals or the
Title:  flights of swallows.  On this hint, attempts have been made to
Title:  construct elaborate migratory charts of the sperm whale.*
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *Since the above was written, the statement is happily borne out by
Title:  an official circular, issued by Lieutenant Maury, of the National
Title:  Observatory, Washington, April 16th, 1851.  By that circular, it
Title:  appears that precisely such a chart is in course of completion; and
Title:  portions of it are presented in the circular.  "This chart divides
Title:  the ocean into districts of five degrees of latitude by five degrees
Title:  of longitude; perpendicularly through each of which districts are
Title:  twelve columns for the twelve months; and horizontally through each
Title:  of which districts are three lines; one to show the number of days
Title:  that have been spent in each month in every district, and the two
Title:  others to show the number of days in which whales, sperm or right,
Title:  have been seen."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Besides, when making a passage from one feeding-ground to another,
Title:  the sperm whales, guided by some infallible instinct--say, rather,
Title:  secret intelligence from the Deity--mostly swim in VEINS, as they are
Title:  called; continuing their way along a given ocean-line with such
Title:  undeviating exactitude, that no ship ever sailed her course, by any
Title:  chart, with one tithe of such marvellous precision.  Though, in these
Title:  cases, the direction taken by any one whale be straight as a
Title:  surveyor's parallel, and though the line of advance be strictly
Title:  confined to its own unavoidable, straight wake, yet the arbitrary
Title:  VEIN in which at these times he is said to swim, generally embraces
Title:  some few miles in width (more or less, as the vein is presumed to
Title:  expand or contract); but never exceeds the visual sweep from the
Title:  whale-ship's mast-heads, when circumspectly gliding along this magic
Title:  zone.  The sum is, that at particular seasons within that breadth and
Title:  along that path, migrating whales may with great confidence be looked
Title:  for.
Title:  
Title:  And hence not only at substantiated times, upon well known separate
Title:  feeding-grounds, could Ahab hope to encounter his prey; but in
Title:  crossing the widest expanses of water between those grounds he could,
Title:  by his art, so place and time himself on his way, as even then not to
Title:  be wholly without prospect of a meeting.
Title:  
Title:  There was a circumstance which at first sight seemed to entangle his
Title:  delirious but still methodical scheme.  But not so in the reality,
Title:  perhaps.  Though the gregarious sperm whales have their regular
Title:  seasons for particular grounds, yet in general you cannot conclude
Title:  that the herds which haunted such and such a latitude or longitude
Title:  this year, say, will turn out to be identically the same with those
Title:  that were found there the preceding season; though there are peculiar
Title:  and unquestionable instances where the contrary of this has proved
Title:  true.  In general, the same remark, only within a less wide limit,
Title:  applies to the solitaries and hermits among the matured, aged sperm
Title:  whales.  So that though Moby Dick had in a former year been seen, for
Title:  example, on what is called the Seychelle ground in the Indian ocean,
Title:  or Volcano Bay on the Japanese Coast; yet it did not follow, that
Title:  were the Pequod to visit either of those spots at any subsequent
Title:  corresponding season, she would infallibly encounter him there.  So,
Title:  too, with some other feeding grounds, where he had at times revealed
Title:  himself.  But all these seemed only his casual stopping-places and
Title:  ocean-inns, so to speak, not his places of prolonged abode.  And
Title:  where Ahab's chances of accomplishing his object have hitherto been
Title:  spoken of, allusion has only been made to whatever way-side,
Title:  antecedent, extra prospects were his, ere a particular set time or
Title:  place were attained, when all possibilities would become
Title:  probabilities, and, as Ahab fondly thought, every possibility the
Title:  next thing to a certainty.  That particular set time and place were
Title:  conjoined in the one technical phrase--the Season-on-the-Line.  For
Title:  there and then, for several consecutive years, Moby Dick had been
Title:  periodically descried, lingering in those waters for awhile, as the
Title:  sun, in its annual round, loiters for a predicted interval in any one
Title:  sign of the Zodiac.  There it was, too, that most of the deadly
Title:  encounters with the white whale had taken place; there the waves were
Title:  storied with his deeds; there also was that tragic spot where the
Title:  monomaniac old man had found the awful motive to his vengeance.  But
Title:  in the cautious comprehensiveness and unloitering vigilance with
Title:  which Ahab threw his brooding soul into this unfaltering hunt, he
Title:  would not permit himself to rest all his hopes upon the one crowning
Title:  fact above mentioned, however flattering it might be to those hopes;
Title:  nor in the sleeplessness of his vow could he so tranquillize his
Title:  unquiet heart as to postpone all intervening quest.
Title:  
Title:  Now, the Pequod had sailed from Nantucket at the very beginning of
Title:  the Season-on-the-Line.  No possible endeavor then could enable her
Title:  commander to make the great passage southwards, double Cape Horn, and
Title:  then running down sixty degrees of latitude arrive in the equatorial
Title:  Pacific in time to cruise there.  Therefore, he must wait for the
Title:  next ensuing season.  Yet the premature hour of the Pequod's sailing
Title:  had, perhaps, been correctly selected by Ahab, with a view to this
Title:  very complexion of things.  Because, an interval of three hundred and
Title:  sixty-five days and nights was before him; an interval which, instead
Title:  of impatiently enduring ashore, he would spend in a miscellaneous
Title:  hunt; if by chance the White Whale, spending his vacation in seas far
Title:  remote from his periodical feeding-grounds, should turn up his
Title:  wrinkled brow off the Persian Gulf, or in the Bengal Bay, or China
Title:  Seas, or in any other waters haunted by his race.  So that Monsoons,
Title:  Pampas, Nor'-Westers, Harmattans, Trades; any wind but the Levanter
Title:  and Simoon, might blow Moby Dick into the devious zig-zag
Title:  world-circle of the Pequod's circumnavigating wake.
Title:  
Title:  But granting all this; yet, regarded discreetly and coolly, seems it
Title:  not but a mad idea, this; that in the broad boundless ocean, one
Title:  solitary whale, even if encountered, should be thought capable of
Title:  individual recognition from his hunter, even as a white-bearded Mufti
Title:  in the thronged thoroughfares of Constantinople?  Yes.  For the
Title:  peculiar snow-white brow of Moby Dick, and his snow-white hump, could
Title:  not but be unmistakable.  And have I not tallied the whale, Ahab
Title:  would mutter to himself, as after poring over his charts till long
Title:  after midnight he would throw himself back in reveries--tallied him,
Title:  and shall he escape?  His broad fins are bored, and scalloped out
Title:  like a lost sheep's ear!  And here, his mad mind would run on in a
Title:  breathless race; till a weariness and faintness of pondering came
