Title:  over him; and in the open air of the deck he would seek to recover
Title:  his strength.  Ah, God! what trances of torments does that man endure
Title:  who is consumed with one unachieved revengeful desire.  He sleeps
Title:  with clenched hands; and wakes with his own bloody nails in his
Title:  palms.
Title:  
Title:  Often, when forced from his hammock by exhausting and intolerably
Title:  vivid dreams of the night, which, resuming his own intense thoughts
Title:  through the day, carried them on amid a clashing of phrensies, and
Title:  whirled them round and round and round in his blazing brain, till
Title:  the very throbbing of his life-spot became insufferable anguish; and
Title:  when, as was sometimes the case, these spiritual throes in him heaved
Title:  his being up from its base, and a chasm seemed opening in him, from
Title:  which forked flames and lightnings shot up, and accursed fiends
Title:  beckoned him to leap down among them; when this hell in himself
Title:  yawned beneath him, a wild cry would be heard through the ship; and
Title:  with glaring eyes Ahab would burst from his state room, as though
Title:  escaping from a bed that was on fire.  Yet these, perhaps, instead of
Title:  being the unsuppressable symptoms of some latent weakness, or fright
Title:  at his own resolve, were but the plainest tokens of its intensity.
Title:  For, at such times, crazy Ahab, the scheming, unappeasedly steadfast
Title:  hunter of the white whale; this Ahab that had gone to his hammock,
Title:  was not the agent that so caused him to burst from it in horror
Title:  again.  The latter was the eternal, living principle or soul in him;
Title:  and in sleep, being for the time dissociated from the characterizing
Title:  mind, which at other times employed it for its outer vehicle or
Title:  agent, it spontaneously sought escape from the scorching contiguity
Title:  of the frantic thing, of which, for the time, it was no longer an
Title:  integral.  But as the mind does not exist unless leagued with the
Title:  soul, therefore it must have been that, in Ahab's case, yielding up
Title:  all his thoughts and fancies to his one supreme purpose; that
Title:  purpose, by its own sheer inveteracy of will, forced itself against
Title:  gods and devils into a kind of self-assumed, independent being of its
Title:  own.  Nay, could grimly live and burn, while the common vitality to
Title:  which it was conjoined, fled horror-stricken from the unbidden and
Title:  unfathered birth.  Therefore, the tormented spirit that glared out of
Title:  bodily eyes, when what seemed Ahab rushed from his room, was for the
Title:  time but a vacated thing, a formless somnambulistic being, a ray of
Title:  living light, to be sure, but without an object to colour, and
Title:  therefore a blankness in itself.  God help thee, old man, thy
Title:  thoughts have created a creature in thee; and he whose intense
Title:  thinking thus makes him a Prometheus; a vulture feeds upon that heart
Title:  for ever; that vulture the very creature he creates.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 45
Title:  
Title:  The Affidavit.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  So far as what there may be of a narrative in this book; and, indeed,
Title:  as indirectly touching one or two very interesting and curious
Title:  particulars in the habits of sperm whales, the foregoing chapter, in
Title:  its earlier part, is as important a one as will be found in this
Title:  volume; but the leading matter of it requires to be still further and
Title:  more familiarly enlarged upon, in order to be adequately understood,
Title:  and moreover to take away any incredulity which a profound ignorance
Title:  of the entire subject may induce in some minds, as to the natural
Title:  verity of the main points of this affair.
Title:  
Title:  I care not to perform this part of my task methodically; but shall be
Title:  content to produce the desired impression by separate citations of
Title:  items, practically or reliably known to me as a whaleman; and from
Title:  these citations, I take it--the conclusion aimed at will naturally
Title:  follow of itself.
Title:  
Title:  First: I have personally known three instances where a whale, after
Title:  receiving a harpoon, has effected a complete escape; and, after an
Title:  interval (in one instance of three years), has been again struck by
Title:  the same hand, and slain; when the two irons, both marked by the same
Title:  private cypher, have been taken from the body.  In the instance where
Title:  three years intervened between the flinging of the two harpoons; and
Title:  I think it may have been something more than that; the man who darted
Title:  them happening, in the interval, to go in a trading ship on a voyage
Title:  to Africa, went ashore there, joined a discovery party, and
Title:  penetrated far into the interior, where he travelled for a period of
Title:  nearly two years, often endangered by serpents, savages, tigers,
Title:  poisonous miasmas, with all the other common perils incident to
Title:  wandering in the heart of unknown regions.  Meanwhile, the whale he
Title:  had struck must also have been on its travels; no doubt it had thrice
Title:  circumnavigated the globe, brushing with its flanks all the coasts of
Title:  Africa; but to no purpose.  This man and this whale again came
Title:  together, and the one vanquished the other.  I say I, myself, have
Title:  known three instances similar to this; that is in two of them I saw
Title:  the whales struck; and, upon the second attack, saw the two irons
Title:  with the respective marks cut in them, afterwards taken from the dead
Title:  fish.  In the three-year instance, it so fell out that I was in the
Title:  boat both times, first and last, and the last time distinctly
Title:  recognised a peculiar sort of huge mole under the whale's eye, which
Title:  I had observed there three years previous.  I say three years, but I
Title:  am pretty sure it was more than that.  Here are three instances,
Title:  then, which I personally know the truth of; but I have heard of many
Title:  other instances from persons whose veracity in the matter there is no
Title:  good ground to impeach.
Title:  
Title:  Secondly: It is well known in the Sperm Whale Fishery, however
Title:  ignorant the world ashore may be of it, that there have been several
Title:  memorable historical instances where a particular whale in the ocean
Title:  has been at distant times and places popularly cognisable.  Why such
Title:  a whale became thus marked was not altogether and originally owing to
Title:  his bodily peculiarities as distinguished from other whales; for
Title:  however peculiar in that respect any chance whale may be, they soon
Title:  put an end to his peculiarities by killing him, and boiling him down
Title:  into a peculiarly valuable oil.  No: the reason was this: that from
Title:  the fatal experiences of the fishery there hung a terrible prestige
Title:  of perilousness about such a whale as there did about Rinaldo
Title:  Rinaldini, insomuch that most fishermen were content to recognise him
Title:  by merely touching their tarpaulins when he would be discovered
Title:  lounging by them on the sea, without seeking to cultivate a more
Title:  intimate acquaintance.  Like some poor devils ashore that happen to
Title:  know an irascible great man, they make distant unobtrusive
Title:  salutations to him in the street, lest if they pursued the
Title:  acquaintance further, they might receive a summary thump for their
Title:  presumption.
Title:  
Title:  But not only did each of these famous whales enjoy great individual
Title:  celebrity--Nay, you may call it an ocean-wide renown; not only was he
Title:  famous in life and now is immortal in forecastle stories after death,
Title:  but he was admitted into all the rights, privileges, and distinctions
Title:  of a name; had as much a name indeed as Cambyses or Caesar.  Was it
Title:  not so, O Timor Tom! thou famed leviathan, scarred like an iceberg,
Title:  who so long did'st lurk in the Oriental straits of that name, whose
Title:  spout was oft seen from the palmy beach of Ombay?  Was it not so, O
Title:  New Zealand Jack! thou terror of all cruisers that crossed their
Title:  wakes in the vicinity of the Tattoo Land?  Was it not so, O Morquan!
Title:  King of Japan, whose lofty jet they say at times assumed the
Title:  semblance of a snow-white cross against the sky?  Was it not so, O
Title:  Don Miguel! thou Chilian whale, marked like an old tortoise with
Title:  mystic hieroglyphics upon the back!  In plain prose, here are four
Title:  whales as well known to the students of Cetacean History as Marius or
Title:  Sylla to the classic scholar.
Title:  
Title:  But this is not all.  New Zealand Tom and Don Miguel, after at
Title:  various times creating great havoc among the boats of different
Title:  vessels, were finally gone in quest of, systematically hunted out,
Title:  chased and killed by valiant whaling captains, who heaved up their
Title:  anchors with that express object as much in view, as in setting out
Title:  through the Narragansett Woods, Captain Butler of old had it in his
Title:  mind to capture that notorious murderous savage Annawon, the headmost
Title:  warrior of the Indian King Philip.
Title:  
Title:  I do not know where I can find a better place than just here, to make
Title:  mention of one or two other things, which to me seem important, as in
Title:  printed form establishing in all respects the reasonableness of the
Title:  whole story of the White Whale, more especially the catastrophe.  For
Title:  this is one of those disheartening instances where truth requires
Title:  full as much bolstering as error.  So ignorant are most landsmen of
Title:  some of the plainest and most palpable wonders of the world, that
Title:  without some hints touching the plain facts, historical and
Title:  otherwise, of the fishery, they might scout at Moby Dick as a
Title:  monstrous fable, or still worse and more detestable, a hideous and
Title:  intolerable allegory.
Title:  
Title:  First: Though most men have some vague flitting ideas of the general
Title:  perils of the grand fishery, yet they have nothing like a fixed,
Title:  vivid conception of those perils, and the frequency with which they
Title:  recur.  One reason perhaps is, that not one in fifty of the actual
Title:  disasters and deaths by casualties in the fishery, ever finds a
Title:  public record at home, however transient and immediately forgotten
Title:  that record.  Do you suppose that that poor fellow there, who this
Title:  moment perhaps caught by the whale-line off the coast of New Guinea,
Title:  is being carried down to the bottom of the sea by the sounding
Title:  leviathan--do you suppose that that poor fellow's name will appear in
Title:  the newspaper obituary you will read to-morrow at your breakfast?
Title:  No: because the mails are very irregular between here and New Guinea.
Title:  In fact, did you ever hear what might be called regular news direct
Title:  or indirect from New Guinea?  Yet I tell you that upon one particular
Title:  voyage which I made to the Pacific, among many others we spoke thirty
Title:  different ships, every one of which had had a death by a whale, some
Title:  of them more than one, and three that had each lost a boat's crew.
Title:  For God's sake, be economical with your lamps and candles! not a
Title:  gallon you burn, but at least one drop of man's blood was spilled for
Title:  it.
Title:  
Title:  Secondly: People ashore have indeed some indefinite idea that a whale
Title:  is an enormous creature of enormous power; but I have ever found that
Title:  when narrating to them some specific example of this two-fold
Title:  enormousness, they have significantly complimented me upon my
Title:  facetiousness; when, I declare upon my soul, I had no more idea of
Title:  being facetious than Moses, when he wrote the history of the plagues
Title:  of Egypt.
Title:  
Title:  But fortunately the special point I here seek can be established upon
Title:  testimony entirely independent of my own.  That point is this: The
Title:  Sperm Whale is in some cases sufficiently powerful, knowing, and
Title:  judiciously malicious, as with direct aforethought to stave in,
Title:  utterly destroy, and sink a large ship; and what is more, the Sperm
Title:  Whale HAS done it.
Title:  
Title:  First: In the year 1820 the ship Essex, Captain Pollard, of
Title:  Nantucket, was cruising in the Pacific Ocean.  One day she saw
Title:  spouts, lowered her boats, and gave chase to a shoal of sperm whales.
Title:  Ere long, several of the whales were wounded; when, suddenly, a very
Title:  large whale escaping from the boats, issued from the shoal, and bore
Title:  directly down upon the ship.  Dashing his forehead against her hull,
Title:  he so stove her in, that in less than "ten minutes" she settled down
Title:  and fell over.  Not a surviving plank of her has been seen since.
Title:  After the severest exposure, part of the crew reached the land in
Title:  their boats.  Being returned home at last, Captain Pollard once more
Title:  sailed for the Pacific in command of another ship, but the gods
Title:  shipwrecked him again upon unknown rocks and breakers; for the second
Title:  time his ship was utterly lost, and forthwith forswearing the sea, he
Title:  has never tempted it since.  At this day Captain Pollard is a
Title:  resident of Nantucket.  I have seen Owen Chace, who was chief mate of
Title:  the Essex at the time of the tragedy; I have read his plain and
Title:  faithful narrative; I have conversed with his son; and all this
Title:  within a few miles of the scene of the catastrophe.*
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *The following are extracts from Chace's narrative: "Every fact
Title:  seemed to warrant me in concluding that it was anything but chance
Title:  which directed his operations; he made two several attacks upon the
Title:  ship, at a short interval between them, both of which, according to
Title:  their direction, were calculated to do us the most injury, by being
Title:  made ahead, and thereby combining the speed of the two objects for
Title:  the shock; to effect which, the exact manoeuvres which he made were
Title:  necessary.  His aspect was most horrible, and such as indicated
Title:  resentment and fury.  He came directly from the shoal which we had
Title:  just before entered, and in which we had struck three of his
Title:  companions, as if fired with revenge for their sufferings."  Again:
Title:  "At all events, the whole circumstances taken together, all happening
Title:  before my own eyes, and producing, at the time, impressions in my
Title:  mind of decided, calculating mischief, on the part of the whale (many
Title:  of which impressions I cannot now recall), induce me to be satisfied
Title:  that I am correct in my opinion."
Title:  
Title:  Here are his reflections some time after quitting the ship, during a
Title:  black night an open boat, when almost despairing of reaching any
Title:  hospitable shore.  "The dark ocean and swelling waters were nothing;
Title:  the fears of being swallowed up by some dreadful tempest, or dashed
Title:  upon hidden rocks, with all the other ordinary subjects of fearful
Title:  contemplation, seemed scarcely entitled to a moment's thought; the
Title:  dismal looking wreck, and THE HORRID ASPECT AND REVENGE OF THE WHALE,
Title:  wholly engrossed my reflections, until day again made its
Title:  appearance."
Title:  
Title:  In another place--p. 45,--he speaks of "THE MYSTERIOUS AND MORTAL
Title:  ATTACK OF THE ANIMAL."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Secondly: The ship Union, also of Nantucket, was in the year 1807
Title:  totally lost off the Azores by a similar onset, but the authentic
Title:  particulars of this catastrophe I have never chanced to encounter,
Title:  though from the whale hunters I have now and then heard casual
Title:  allusions to it.
Title:  
Title:  Thirdly: Some eighteen or twenty years ago Commodore J---, then
Title:  commanding an American sloop-of-war of the first class, happened to
Title:  be dining with a party of whaling captains, on board a Nantucket ship
Title:  in the harbor of Oahu, Sandwich Islands.  Conversation turning upon
Title:  whales, the Commodore was pleased to be sceptical touching the
Title:  amazing strength ascribed to them by the professional gentlemen
Title:  present.  He peremptorily denied for example, that any whale could so
Title:  smite his stout sloop-of-war as to cause her to leak so much as a
Title:  thimbleful.  Very good; but there is more coming.  Some weeks after,
Title:  the Commodore set sail in this impregnable craft for Valparaiso.  But
Title:  he was stopped on the way by a portly sperm whale, that begged a few
Title:  moments' confidential business with him.  That business consisted in
Title:  fetching the Commodore's craft such a thwack, that with all his pumps
Title:  going he made straight for the nearest port to heave down and repair.
Title:  I am not superstitious, but I consider the Commodore's interview
Title:  with that whale as providential.  Was not Saul of Tarsus converted
Title:  from unbelief by a similar fright?  I tell you, the sperm whale will
Title:  stand no nonsense.
Title:  
Title:  I will now refer you to Langsdorff's Voyages for a little
Title:  circumstance in point, peculiarly interesting to the writer hereof.
Title:  Langsdorff, you must know by the way, was attached to the Russian
Title:  Admiral Krusenstern's famous Discovery Expedition in the beginning of
Title:  the present century.  Captain Langsdorff thus begins his seventeenth
Title:  chapter:
Title:  
Title:  "By the thirteenth of May our ship was ready to sail, and the next
Title:  day we were out in the open sea, on our way to Ochotsh.  The weather
Title:  was very clear and fine, but so intolerably cold that we were obliged
Title:  to keep on our fur clothing.  For some days we had very little wind;
Title:  it was not till the nineteenth that a brisk gale from the northwest
Title:  sprang up.  An uncommon large whale, the body of which was larger
Title:  than the ship itself, lay almost at the surface of the water, but was
Title:  not perceived by any one on board till the moment when the ship,
Title:  which was in full sail, was almost upon him, so that it was
Title:  impossible to prevent its striking against him.  We were thus placed
Title:  in the most imminent danger, as this gigantic creature, setting up
Title:  its back, raised the ship three feet at least out of the water.  The
Title:  masts reeled, and the sails fell altogether, while we who were below
Title:  all sprang instantly upon the deck, concluding that we had struck
Title:  upon some rock; instead of this we saw the monster sailing off with
Title:  the utmost gravity and solemnity.  Captain D'Wolf applied immediately
Title:  to the pumps to examine whether or not the vessel had received any
Title:  damage from the shock, but we found that very happily it had escaped
Title:  entirely uninjured."
Title:  
Title:  Now, the Captain D'Wolf here alluded to as commanding the ship in
Title:  question, is a New Englander, who, after a long life of unusual
Title:  adventures as a sea-captain, this day resides in the village of
Title:  Dorchester near Boston.  I have the honour of being a nephew of his.
Title:  I have particularly questioned him concerning this passage in
Title:  Langsdorff.  He substantiates every word.  The ship, however, was by
Title:  no means a large one: a Russian craft built on the Siberian coast,
Title:  and purchased by my uncle after bartering away the vessel in which he
Title:  sailed from home.
Title:  
Title:  In that up and down manly book of old-fashioned adventure, so full,
Title:  too, of honest wonders--the voyage of Lionel Wafer, one of ancient
Title:  Dampier's old chums--I found a little matter set down so like that
Title:  just quoted from Langsdorff, that I cannot forbear inserting it here
Title:  for a corroborative example, if such be needed.
Title:  
Title:  Lionel, it seems, was on his way to "John Ferdinando," as he calls
Title:  the modern Juan Fernandes.  "In our way thither," he says, "about
Title:  four o'clock in the morning, when we were about one hundred and fifty
Title:  leagues from the Main of America, our ship felt a terrible shock,
Title:  which put our men in such consternation that they could hardly tell
Title:  where they were or what to think; but every one began to prepare for
Title:  death.  And, indeed, the shock was so sudden and violent, that we
Title:  took it for granted the ship had struck against a rock; but when the
Title:  amazement was a little over, we cast the lead, and sounded, but found
Title:  no ground.  ....  The suddenness of the shock made the guns leap in
Title:  their carriages, and several of the men were shaken out of their
Title:  hammocks.  Captain Davis, who lay with his head on a gun, was thrown
Title:  out of his cabin!"  Lionel then goes on to impute the shock to an
Title:  earthquake, and seems to substantiate the imputation by stating that
Title:  a great earthquake, somewhere about that time, did actually do great
Title:  mischief along the Spanish land.  But I should not much wonder if, in
Title:  the darkness of that early hour of the morning, the shock was after
Title:  all caused by an unseen whale vertically bumping the hull from
Title:  beneath.
Title:  
Title:  I might proceed with several more examples, one way or another known
Title:  to me, of the great power and malice at times of the sperm whale.  In
Title:  more than one instance, he has been known, not only to chase the
Title:  assailing boats back to their ships, but to pursue the ship itself,
Title:  and long withstand all the lances hurled at him from its decks.  The
Title:  English ship Pusie Hall can tell a story on that head; and, as for
Title:  his strength, let me say, that there have been examples where the
Title:  lines attached to a running sperm whale have, in a calm, been
Title:  transferred to the ship, and secured there; the whale towing her
Title:  great hull through the water, as a horse walks off with a cart.
Title:  Again, it is very often observed that, if the sperm whale, once
Title:  struck, is allowed time to rally, he then acts, not so often with
Title:  blind rage, as with wilful, deliberate designs of destruction to his
Title:  pursuers; nor is it without conveying some eloquent indication of his
Title:  character, that upon being attacked he will frequently open his
Title:  mouth, and retain it in that dread expansion for several consecutive
Title:  minutes.  But I must be content with only one more and a concluding
Title:  illustration; a remarkable and most significant one, by which you
Title:  will not fail to see, that not only is the most marvellous event in
Title:  this book corroborated by plain facts of the present day, but that
Title:  these marvels (like all marvels) are mere repetitions of the ages; so
Title:  that for the millionth time we say amen with Solomon--Verily there is
Title:  nothing new under the sun.
Title:  
Title:  In the sixth Christian century lived Procopius, a Christian
Title:  magistrate of Constantinople, in the days when Justinian was Emperor
Title:  and Belisarius general.  As many know, he wrote the history of his
Title:  own times, a work every way of uncommon value.  By the best
Title:  authorities, he has always been considered a most trustworthy and
Title:  unexaggerating historian, except in some one or two particulars, not
Title:  at all affecting the matter presently to be mentioned.
Title:  
Title:  Now, in this history of his, Procopius mentions that, during the term
Title:  of his prefecture at Constantinople, a great sea-monster was captured
Title:  in the neighboring Propontis, or Sea of Marmora, after having
Title:  destroyed vessels at intervals in those waters for a period of more
Title:  than fifty years.  A fact thus set down in substantial history cannot
Title:  easily be gainsaid.  Nor is there any reason it should be.  Of what
Title:  precise species this sea-monster was, is not mentioned.  But as he
Title:  destroyed ships, as well as for other reasons, he must have been a
Title:  whale; and I am strongly inclined to think a sperm whale.  And I will
Title:  tell you why.  For a long time I fancied that the sperm whale had
Title:  been always unknown in the Mediterranean and the deep waters
Title:  connecting with it.  Even now I am certain that those seas are not,
Title:  and perhaps never can be, in the present constitution of things, a
Title:  place for his habitual gregarious resort.  But further investigations
Title:  have recently proved to me, that in modern times there have been
Title:  isolated instances of the presence of the sperm whale in the
Title:  Mediterranean.  I am told, on good authority, that on the Barbary
Title:  coast, a Commodore Davis of the British navy found the skeleton of a
Title:  sperm whale.  Now, as a vessel of war readily passes through the
Title:  Dardanelles, hence a sperm whale could, by the same route, pass out
Title:  of the Mediterranean into the Propontis.
Title:  
Title:  In the Propontis, as far as I can learn, none of that peculiar
Title:  substance called BRIT is to be found, the aliment of the right whale.
Title:  But I have every reason to believe that the food of the sperm
Title:  whale--squid or cuttle-fish--lurks at the bottom of that sea, because
Title:  large creatures, but by no means the largest of that sort, have been
Title:  found at its surface.  If, then, you properly put these statements
Title:  together, and reason upon them a bit, you will clearly perceive that,
Title:  according to all human reasoning, Procopius's sea-monster, that for
Title:  half a century stove the ships of a Roman Emperor, must in all
Title:  probability have been a sperm whale.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 46
Title:  
Title:  Surmises.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Though, consumed with the hot fire of his purpose, Ahab in all his
Title:  thoughts and actions ever had in view the ultimate capture of Moby
Title:  Dick; though he seemed ready to sacrifice all mortal interests to
Title:  that one passion; nevertheless it may have been that he was by nature
Title:  and long habituation far too wedded to a fiery whaleman's ways,
Title:  altogether to abandon the collateral prosecution of the voyage.  Or
Title:  at least if this were otherwise, there were not wanting other motives
Title:  much more influential with him.  It would be refining too much,
Title:  perhaps, even considering his monomania, to hint that his
Title:  vindictiveness towards the White Whale might have possibly extended
Title:  itself in some degree to all sperm whales, and that the more monsters
Title:  he slew by so much the more he multiplied the chances that each
Title:  subsequently encountered whale would prove to be the hated one he
Title:  hunted.  But if such an hypothesis be indeed exceptionable, there
Title:  were still additional considerations which, though not so strictly
Title:  according with the wildness of his ruling passion, yet were by no
Title:  means incapable of swaying him.
Title:  
Title:  To accomplish his object Ahab must use tools; and of all tools used
Title:  in the shadow of the moon, men are most apt to get out of order.  He
Title:  knew, for example, that however magnetic his ascendency in some
Title:  respects was over Starbuck, yet that ascendency did not cover the
Title:  complete spiritual man any more than mere corporeal superiority
Title:  involves intellectual mastership; for to the purely spiritual, the
Title:  intellectual but stand in a sort of corporeal relation.  Starbuck's
Title:  body and Starbuck's coerced will were Ahab's, so long as Ahab kept
Title:  his magnet at Starbuck's brain; still he knew that for all this the
Title:  chief mate, in his soul, abhorred his captain's quest, and could he,
Title:  would joyfully disintegrate himself from it, or even frustrate it.
Title:  It might be that a long interval would elapse ere the White Whale was
Title:  seen.  During that long interval Starbuck would ever be apt to fall
Title:  into open relapses of rebellion against his captain's leadership,
Title:  unless some ordinary, prudential, circumstantial influences were
Title:  brought to bear upon him.  Not only that, but the subtle insanity of
Title:  Ahab respecting Moby Dick was noways more significantly manifested
Title:  than in his superlative sense and shrewdness in foreseeing that, for
Title:  the present, the hunt should in some way be stripped of that strange
Title:  imaginative impiousness which naturally invested it; that the full
Title:  terror of the voyage must be kept withdrawn into the obscure
Title:  background (for few men's courage is proof against protracted
Title:  meditation unrelieved by action); that when they stood their long
Title:  night watches, his officers and men must have some nearer things to
Title:  think of than Moby Dick.  For however eagerly and impetuously the
Title:  savage crew had hailed the announcement of his quest; yet all sailors
Title:  of all sorts are more or less capricious and unreliable--they live in
Title:  the varying outer weather, and they inhale its fickleness--and when
Title:  retained for any object remote and blank in the pursuit, however
Title:  promissory of life and passion in the end, it is above all things
Title:  requisite that temporary interests and employments should intervene
Title:  and hold them healthily suspended for the final dash.
Title:  
Title:  Nor was Ahab unmindful of another thing.  In times of strong emotion
Title:  mankind disdain all base considerations; but such times are
Title:  evanescent.  The permanent constitutional condition of the
Title:  manufactured man, thought Ahab, is sordidness.  Granting that the
Title:  White Whale fully incites the hearts of this my savage crew, and
Title:  playing round their savageness even breeds a certain generous
Title:  knight-errantism in them, still, while for the love of it they give
Title:  chase to Moby Dick, they must also have food for their more common,
Title:  daily appetites.  For even the high lifted and chivalric Crusaders of
Title:  old times were not content to traverse two thousand miles of land to
Title:  fight for their holy sepulchre, without committing burglaries,
Title:  picking pockets, and gaining other pious perquisites by the way.  Had
Title:  they been strictly held to their one final and romantic object--that
Title:  final and romantic object, too many would have turned from in
Title:  disgust.  I will not strip these men, thought Ahab, of all hopes of
Title:  cash--aye, cash.  They may scorn cash now; but let some months go by,
Title:  and no perspective promise of it to them, and then this same
Title:  quiescent cash all at once mutinying in them, this same cash would
Title:  soon cashier Ahab.
Title:  
Title:  Nor was there wanting still another precautionary motive more related
Title:  to Ahab personally.  Having impulsively, it is probable, and perhaps
Title:  somewhat prematurely revealed the prime but private purpose of the
Title:  Pequod's voyage, Ahab was now entirely conscious that, in so doing,
Title:  he had indirectly laid himself open to the unanswerable charge of
Title:  usurpation; and with perfect impunity, both moral and legal, his crew
Title:  if so disposed, and to that end competent, could refuse all further
Title:  obedience to him, and even violently wrest from him the command.
Title:  From even the barely hinted imputation of usurpation, and the
Title:  possible consequences of such a suppressed impression gaining ground,
Title:  Ahab must of course have been most anxious to protect himself.  That
Title:  protection could only consist in his own predominating brain and
Title:  heart and hand, backed by a heedful, closely calculating attention to
Title:  every minute atmospheric influence which it was possible for his crew
Title:  to be subjected to.
Title:  
Title:  For all these reasons then, and others perhaps too analytic to be
Title:  verbally developed here, Ahab plainly saw that he must still in a
Title:  good degree continue true to the natural, nominal purpose of the
Title:  Pequod's voyage; observe all customary usages; and not only that, but
Title:  force himself to evince all his well known passionate interest in the
Title:  general pursuit of his profession.
Title:  
Title:  Be all this as it may, his voice was now often heard hailing the
Title:  three mast-heads and admonishing them to keep a bright look-out, and
Title:  not omit reporting even a porpoise.  This vigilance was not long
Title:  without reward.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 47
Title:  
Title:  The Mat-Maker.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  It was a cloudy, sultry afternoon; the seamen were lazily lounging
Title:  about the decks, or vacantly gazing over into the lead-coloured
Title:  waters.  Queequeg and I were mildly employed weaving what is called a
Title:  sword-mat, for an additional lashing to our boat.  So still and
Title:  subdued and yet somehow preluding was all the scene, and such an
Title:  incantation of reverie lurked in the air, that each silent sailor
Title:  seemed resolved into his own invisible self.
Title:  
Title:  I was the attendant or page of Queequeg, while busy at the mat.  As I
Title:  kept passing and repassing the filling or woof of marline between the
Title:  long yarns of the warp, using my own hand for the shuttle, and as
Title:  Queequeg, standing sideways, ever and anon slid his heavy oaken sword
Title:  between the threads, and idly looking off upon the water, carelessly
Title:  and unthinkingly drove home every yarn: I say so strange a
Title:  dreaminess did there then reign all over the ship and all over the
Title:  sea, only broken by the intermitting dull sound of the sword, that it
Title:  seemed as if this were the Loom of Time, and I myself were a shuttle
Title:  mechanically weaving and weaving away at the Fates.  There lay the
Title:  fixed threads of the warp subject to but one single, ever returning,
Title:  unchanging vibration, and that vibration merely enough to admit of
Title:  the crosswise interblending of other threads with its own.  This warp
Title:  seemed necessity; and here, thought I, with my own hand I ply my own
Title:  shuttle and weave my own destiny into these unalterable threads.
Title:  Meantime, Queequeg's impulsive, indifferent sword, sometimes hitting
Title:  the woof slantingly, or crookedly, or strongly, or weakly, as the
Title:  case might be; and by this difference in the concluding blow
Title:  producing a corresponding contrast in the final aspect of the
Title:  completed fabric; this savage's sword, thought I, which thus finally
Title:  shapes and fashions both warp and woof; this easy, indifferent sword
Title:  must be chance--aye, chance, free will, and necessity--nowise
Title:  incompatible--all interweavingly working together.  The straight warp
Title:  of necessity, not to be swerved from its ultimate course--its every
Title:  alternating vibration, indeed, only tending to that; free will still
Title:  free to ply her shuttle between given threads; and chance, though
Title:  restrained in its play within the right lines of necessity, and
Title:  sideways in its motions directed by free will, though thus prescribed
Title:  to by both, chance by turns rules either, and has the last featuring
Title:  blow at events.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Thus we were weaving and weaving away when I started at a sound so
Title:  strange, long drawn, and musically wild and unearthly, that the ball
Title:  of free will dropped from my hand, and I stood gazing up at the
Title:  clouds whence that voice dropped like a wing.  High aloft in the
Title:  cross-trees was that mad Gay-Header, Tashtego.  His body was reaching
Title:  eagerly forward, his hand stretched out like a wand, and at brief
Title:  sudden intervals he continued his cries.  To be sure the same sound
Title:  was that very moment perhaps being heard all over the seas, from
Title:  hundreds of whalemen's look-outs perched as high in the air; but from
Title:  few of those lungs could that accustomed old cry have derived such a
Title:  marvellous cadence as from Tashtego the Indian's.
Title:  
Title:  As he stood hovering over you half suspended in air, so wildly and
Title:  eagerly peering towards the horizon, you would have thought him some
Title:  prophet or seer beholding the shadows of Fate, and by those wild
Title:  cries announcing their coming.
Title:  
Title:  "There she blows! there! there! there! she blows! she blows!"
Title:  
Title:  "Where-away?"
Title:  
Title:  "On the lee-beam, about two miles off! a school of them!"
Title:  
Title:  Instantly all was commotion.
Title:  
Title:  The Sperm Whale blows as a clock ticks, with the same undeviating and
Title:  reliable uniformity.  And thereby whalemen distinguish this fish from
Title:  other tribes of his genus.
Title:  
Title:  "There go flukes!" was now the cry from Tashtego; and the whales
Title:  disappeared.
Title:  
Title:  "Quick, steward!" cried Ahab.  "Time! time!"
Title:  
Title:  Dough-Boy hurried below, glanced at the watch, and reported the exact
Title:  minute to Ahab.
Title:  
Title:  The ship was now kept away from the wind, and she went gently rolling
Title:  before it.  Tashtego reporting that the whales had gone down heading
Title:  to leeward, we confidently looked to see them again directly in
Title:  advance of our bows.  For that singular craft at times evinced by the
Title:  Sperm Whale when, sounding with his head in one direction, he
Title:  nevertheless, while concealed beneath the surface, mills round, and
Title:  swiftly swims off in the opposite quarter--this deceitfulness of his
Title:  could not now be in action; for there was no reason to suppose that
Title:  the fish seen by Tashtego had been in any way alarmed, or indeed knew
Title:  at all of our vicinity.  One of the men selected for
Title:  shipkeepers--that is, those not appointed to the boats, by this time
Title:  relieved the Indian at the main-mast head.  The sailors at the fore
Title:  and mizzen had come down; the line tubs were fixed in their places;
Title:  the cranes were thrust out; the mainyard was backed, and the three
Title:  boats swung over the sea like three samphire baskets over high
Title:  cliffs.  Outside of the bulwarks their eager crews with one hand
Title:  clung to the rail, while one foot was expectantly poised on the
Title:  gunwale.  So look the long line of man-of-war's men about to throw
Title:  themselves on board an enemy's ship.
Title:  
Title:  But at this critical instant a sudden exclamation was heard that took
Title:  every eye from the whale.  With a start all glared at dark Ahab, who
Title:  was surrounded by five dusky phantoms that seemed fresh formed out of
Title:  air.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 48
Title:  
Title:  The First Lowering.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  The phantoms, for so they then seemed, were flitting on the other
Title:  side of the deck, and, with a noiseless celerity, were casting loose
Title:  the tackles and bands of the boat which swung there.  This boat had
Title:  always been deemed one of the spare boats, though technically called
Title:  the captain's, on account of its hanging from the starboard quarter.
Title:  The figure that now stood by its bows was tall and swart, with one
Title:  white tooth evilly protruding from its steel-like lips.  A rumpled
Title:  Chinese jacket of black cotton funereally invested him, with wide
Title:  black trowsers of the same dark stuff.  But strangely crowning this
Title:  ebonness was a glistening white plaited turban, the living hair
Title:  braided and coiled round and round upon his head.  Less swart in
Title:  aspect, the companions of this figure were of that vivid,
Title:  tiger-yellow complexion peculiar to some of the aboriginal natives of
Title:  the Manillas;--a race notorious for a certain diabolism of subtilty,
Title:  and by some honest white mariners supposed to be the paid spies and
Title:  secret confidential agents on the water of the devil, their lord,
Title:  whose counting-room they suppose to be elsewhere.
Title:  
Title:  While yet the wondering ship's company were gazing upon these
Title:  strangers, Ahab cried out to the white-turbaned old man at their
Title:  head, "All ready there, Fedallah?"
Title:  
Title:  "Ready," was the half-hissed reply.
Title:  
Title:  "Lower away then; d'ye hear?" shouting across the deck.  "Lower away
Title:  there, I say."
Title:  
Title:  Such was the thunder of his voice, that spite of their amazement the
Title:  men sprang over the rail; the sheaves whirled round in the blocks;
Title:  with a wallow, the three boats dropped into the sea; while, with a
Title:  dexterous, off-handed daring, unknown in any other vocation, the
Title:  sailors, goat-like, leaped down the rolling ship's side into the
Title:  tossed boats below.
Title:  
Title:  Hardly had they pulled out from under the ship's lee, when a fourth
Title:  keel, coming from the windward side, pulled round under the stern,
Title:  and showed the five strangers rowing Ahab, who, standing erect in the
Title:  stern, loudly hailed Starbuck, Stubb, and Flask, to spread themselves
Title:  widely, so as to cover a large expanse of water.  But with all their
Title:  eyes again riveted upon the swart Fedallah and his crew, the inmates
Title:  of the other boats obeyed not the command.
Title:  
Title:  "Captain Ahab?--" said Starbuck.
Title:  
Title:  "Spread yourselves," cried Ahab; "give way, all four boats.  Thou,
Title:  Flask, pull out more to leeward!"
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, aye, sir," cheerily cried little King-Post, sweeping round his
Title:  great steering oar.  "Lay back!" addressing his crew.
Title:  "There!--there!--there again!  There she blows right ahead,
Title:  boys!--lay back!"
Title:  
Title:  "Never heed yonder yellow boys, Archy."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, I don't mind'em, sir," said Archy; "I knew it all before now.
Title:  Didn't I hear 'em in the hold?  And didn't I tell Cabaco here of it?
Title:  What say ye, Cabaco?  They are stowaways, Mr. Flask."
Title:  
Title:  "Pull, pull, my fine hearts-alive; pull, my children; pull, my little
Title:  ones," drawlingly and soothingly sighed Stubb to his crew, some of
Title:  whom still showed signs of uneasiness.  "Why don't you break your
Title:  backbones, my boys?  What is it you stare at?  Those chaps in yonder
Title:  boat?  Tut!  They are only five more hands come to help us--never
Title:  mind from where--the more the merrier.  Pull, then, do pull; never
Title:  mind the brimstone--devils are good fellows enough.  So, so; there
Title:  you are now; that's the stroke for a thousand pounds; that's the
Title:  stroke to sweep the stakes!  Hurrah for the gold cup of sperm oil, my
Title:  heroes!  Three cheers, men--all hearts alive!  Easy, easy; don't be
Title:  in a hurry--don't be in a hurry.  Why don't you snap your oars, you
Title:  rascals?  Bite something, you dogs!  So, so, so, then:--softly,
Title:  softly!  That's it--that's it! long and strong.  Give way there, give
Title:  way!  The devil fetch ye, ye ragamuffin rapscallions; ye are all
Title:  asleep.  Stop snoring, ye sleepers, and pull.  Pull, will ye? pull,
Title:  can't ye? pull, won't ye?  Why in the name of gudgeons and
Title:  ginger-cakes don't ye pull?--pull and break something! pull, and
Title:  start your eyes out!  Here!" whipping out the sharp knife from his
Title:  girdle; "every mother's son of ye draw his knife, and pull with the
Title:  blade between his teeth.  That's it--that's it.  Now ye do something;
Title:  that looks like it, my steel-bits.  Start her--start her, my
Title:  silver-spoons!  Start her, marling-spikes!"
Title:  
Title:  Stubb's exordium to his crew is given here at large, because he had
Title:  rather a peculiar way of talking to them in general, and especially
Title:  in inculcating the religion of rowing.  But you must not suppose from
Title:  this specimen of his sermonizings that he ever flew into downright
Title:  passions with his congregation.  Not at all; and therein consisted
Title:  his chief peculiarity.  He would say the most terrific things to his
Title:  crew, in a tone so strangely compounded of fun and fury, and the fury
Title:  seemed so calculated merely as a spice to the fun, that no oarsman
Title:  could hear such queer invocations without pulling for dear life, and
Title:  yet pulling for the mere joke of the thing.  Besides he all the time
Title:  looked so easy and indolent himself, so loungingly managed his
Title:  steering-oar, and so broadly gaped--open-mouthed at times--that the
Title:  mere sight of such a yawning commander, by sheer force of contrast,
Title:  acted like a charm upon the crew.  Then again, Stubb was one of those
Title:  odd sort of humorists, whose jollity is sometimes so curiously
Title:  ambiguous, as to put all inferiors on their guard in the matter of
Title:  obeying them.
Title:  
Title:  In obedience to a sign from Ahab, Starbuck was now pulling obliquely
Title:  across Stubb's bow; and when for a minute or so the two boats were
Title:  pretty near to each other, Stubb hailed the mate.
Title:  
Title:  "Mr. Starbuck! larboard boat there, ahoy! a word with ye, sir, if ye
Title:  please!"
Title:  
Title:  "Halloa!" returned Starbuck, turning round not a single inch as he
Title:  spoke; still earnestly but whisperingly urging his crew; his face set
Title:  like a flint from Stubb's.
Title:  
Title:  "What think ye of those yellow boys, sir!
Title:  
Title:  "Smuggled on board, somehow, before the ship sailed. (Strong, strong,
Title:  boys!)" in a whisper to his crew, then speaking out loud again: "A
Title:  sad business, Mr. Stubb! (seethe her, seethe her, my lads!) but never
Title:  mind, Mr. Stubb, all for the best.  Let all your crew pull strong,
Title:  come what will. (Spring, my men, spring!) There's hogsheads of sperm
Title:  ahead, Mr. Stubb, and that's what ye came for. (Pull, my boys!)
Title:  Sperm, sperm's the play!  This at least is duty; duty and profit hand
Title:  in hand."
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, aye, I thought as much," soliloquized Stubb, when the boats
Title:  diverged, "as soon as I clapt eye on 'em, I thought so.  Aye, and
Title:  that's what he went into the after hold for, so often, as Dough-Boy
Title:  long suspected.  They were hidden down there.  The White Whale's at
Title:  the bottom of it.  Well, well, so be it!  Can't be helped!  All
Title:  right!  Give way, men!  It ain't the White Whale to-day!  Give way!"
Title:  
Title:  Now the advent of these outlandish strangers at such a critical
Title:  instant as the lowering of the boats from the deck, this had not
Title:  unreasonably awakened a sort of superstitious amazement in some of
Title:  the ship's company; but Archy's fancied discovery having some time
Title:  previous got abroad among them, though indeed not credited then, this
Title:  had in some small measure prepared them for the event.  It took off
Title:  the extreme edge of their wonder; and so what with all this and
Title:  Stubb's confident way of accounting for their appearance, they were
Title:  for the time freed from superstitious surmisings; though the affair
Title:  still left abundant room for all manner of wild conjectures as to
Title:  dark Ahab's precise agency in the matter from the beginning.  For me,
Title:  I silently recalled the mysterious shadows I had seen creeping on
Title:  board the Pequod during the dim Nantucket dawn, as well as the
Title:  enigmatical hintings of the unaccountable Elijah.
Title:  
Title:  Meantime, Ahab, out of hearing of his officers, having sided the
Title:  furthest to windward, was still ranging ahead of the other boats; a
Title:  circumstance bespeaking how potent a crew was pulling him.  Those
Title:  tiger yellow creatures of his seemed all steel and whalebone; like
Title:  five trip-hammers they rose and fell with regular strokes of
Title:  strength, which periodically started the boat along the water like a
Title:  horizontal burst boiler out of a Mississippi steamer.  As for
Title:  Fedallah, who was seen pulling the harpooneer oar, he had thrown
Title:  aside his black jacket, and displayed his naked chest with the whole
Title:  part of his body above the gunwale, clearly cut against the
Title:  alternating depressions of the watery horizon; while at the other end
Title:  of the boat Ahab, with one arm, like a fencer's, thrown half backward
Title:  into the air, as if to counterbalance any tendency to trip; Ahab was
Title:  seen steadily managing his steering oar as in a thousand boat
Title:  lowerings ere the White Whale had torn him.  All at once the
Title:  outstretched arm gave a peculiar motion and then remained fixed,
Title:  while the boat's five oars were seen simultaneously peaked.  Boat and
Title:  crew sat motionless on the sea.  Instantly the three spread boats in
Title:  the rear paused on their way.  The whales had irregularly settled
Title:  bodily down into the blue, thus giving no distantly discernible token
Title:  of the movement, though from his closer vicinity Ahab had observed
Title:  it.
Title:  
Title:  "Every man look out along his oars!" cried Starbuck.  "Thou,
Title:  Queequeg, stand up!"
Title:  
Title:  Nimbly springing up on the triangular raised box in the bow, the
Title:  savage stood erect there, and with intensely eager eyes gazed off
Title:  towards the spot where the chase had last been descried.  Likewise
Title:  upon the extreme stern of the boat where it was also triangularly
Title:  platformed level with the gunwale, Starbuck himself was seen coolly
Title:  and adroitly balancing himself to the jerking tossings of his chip of
Title:  a craft, and silently eyeing the vast blue eye of the sea.
Title:  
Title:  Not very far distant Flask's boat was also lying breathlessly still;
Title:  its commander recklessly standing upon the top of the loggerhead, a
Title:  stout sort of post rooted in the keel, and rising some two feet above
Title:  the level of the stern platform.  It is used for catching turns with
Title:  the whale line.  Its top is not more spacious than the palm of a
Title:  man's hand, and standing upon such a base as that, Flask seemed
Title:  perched at the mast-head of some ship which had sunk to all but her
Title:  trucks.  But little King-Post was small and short, and at the same
Title:  time little King-Post was full of a large and tall ambition, so that
Title:  this loggerhead stand-point of his did by no means satisfy King-Post.
Title:  
Title:  "I can't see three seas off; tip us up an oar there, and let me on to
Title:  that."
Title:  
Title:  Upon this, Daggoo, with either hand upon the gunwale to steady his
Title:  way, swiftly slid aft, and then erecting himself volunteered his
Title:  lofty shoulders for a pedestal.
Title:  
Title:  "Good a mast-head as any, sir.  Will you mount?"
Title:  
Title:  "That I will, and thank ye very much, my fine fellow; only I wish you
Title:  fifty feet taller."
Title:  
Title:  Whereupon planting his feet firmly against two opposite planks of the
Title:  boat, the gigantic negro, stooping a little, presented his flat palm
Title:  to Flask's foot, and then putting Flask's hand on his hearse-plumed
Title:  head and bidding him spring as he himself should toss, with one
Title:  dexterous fling landed the little man high and dry on his shoulders.
Title:  And here was Flask now standing, Daggoo with one lifted arm
Title:  furnishing him with a breastband to lean against and steady himself
Title:  by.
Title:  
Title:  At any time it is a strange sight to the tyro to see with what
Title:  wondrous habitude of unconscious skill the whaleman will maintain an
Title:  erect posture in his boat, even when pitched about by the most
Title:  riotously perverse and cross-running seas.  Still more strange to see
Title:  him giddily perched upon the loggerhead itself, under such
Title:  circumstances.  But the sight of little Flask mounted upon gigantic
Title:  Daggoo was yet more curious; for sustaining himself with a cool,
Title:  indifferent, easy, unthought of, barbaric majesty, the noble negro to
Title:  every roll of the sea harmoniously rolled his fine form.  On his
Title:  broad back, flaxen-haired Flask seemed a snow-flake.  The bearer
Title:  looked nobler than the rider.  Though truly vivacious, tumultuous,
Title:  ostentatious little Flask would now and then stamp with impatience;
Title:  but not one added heave did he thereby give to the negro's lordly
Title:  chest.  So have I seen Passion and Vanity stamping the living
Title:  magnanimous earth, but the earth did not alter her tides and her
Title:  seasons for that.
Title:  
Title:  Meanwhile Stubb, the third mate, betrayed no such far-gazing
Title:  solicitudes.  The whales might have made one of their regular
Title:  soundings, not a temporary dive from mere fright; and if that were
Title:  the case, Stubb, as his wont in such cases, it seems, was resolved to
Title:  solace the languishing interval with his pipe.  He withdrew it from
Title:  his hatband, where he always wore it aslant like a feather.  He
Title:  loaded it, and rammed home the loading with his thumb-end; but hardly
Title:  had he ignited his match across the rough sandpaper of his hand,
Title:  when Tashtego, his harpooneer, whose eyes had been setting to
Title:  windward like two fixed stars, suddenly dropped like light from his
Title:  erect attitude to his seat, crying out in a quick phrensy of hurry,
Title:  "Down, down all, and give way!--there they are!"
Title:  
Title:  To a landsman, no whale, nor any sign of a herring, would have been
Title:  visible at that moment; nothing but a troubled bit of greenish white
Title:  water, and thin scattered puffs of vapour hovering over it, and
Title:  suffusingly blowing off to leeward, like the confused scud from white
Title:  rolling billows.  The air around suddenly vibrated and tingled, as it
Title:  were, like the air over intensely heated plates of iron.  Beneath
Title:  this atmospheric waving and curling, and partially beneath a thin
Title:  layer of water, also, the whales were swimming.  Seen in advance of
Title:  all the other indications, the puffs of vapour they spouted, seemed
Title:  their forerunning couriers and detached flying outriders.
Title:  
Title:  All four boats were now in keen pursuit of that one spot of troubled
Title:  water and air.  But it bade fair to outstrip them; it flew on and on,
Title:  as a mass of interblending bubbles borne down a rapid stream from the
Title:  hills.
Title:  
Title:  "Pull, pull, my good boys," said Starbuck, in the lowest possible but
Title:  intensest concentrated whisper to his men; while the sharp fixed
Title:  glance from his eyes darted straight ahead of the bow, almost seemed
Title:  as two visible needles in two unerring binnacle compasses.  He did
Title:  not say much to his crew, though, nor did his crew say anything to
Title:  him.  Only the silence of the boat was at intervals startlingly
Title:  pierced by one of his peculiar whispers, now harsh with command, now
Title:  soft with entreaty.
Title:  
Title:  How different the loud little King-Post.  "Sing out and say
Title:  something, my hearties.  Roar and pull, my thunderbolts!  Beach me,
Title:  beach me on their black backs, boys; only do that for me, and I'll
Title:  sign over to you my Martha's Vineyard plantation, boys; including
Title:  wife and children, boys.  Lay me on--lay me on!  O Lord, Lord! but I
Title:  shall go stark, staring mad!  See! see that white water!"  And so
Title:  shouting, he pulled his hat from his head, and stamped up and down on
Title:  it; then picking it up, flirted it far off upon the sea; and finally
Title:  fell to rearing and plunging in the boat's stern like a crazed colt
Title:  from the prairie.
Title:  
Title:  "Look at that chap now," philosophically drawled Stubb, who, with his
Title:  unlighted short pipe, mechanically retained between his teeth, at a
Title:  short distance, followed after--"He's got fits, that Flask has.
Title:  Fits? yes, give him fits--that's the very word--pitch fits into 'em.
Title:  Merrily, merrily, hearts-alive.  Pudding for supper, you
Title:  know;--merry's the word.  Pull, babes--pull, sucklings--pull, all.
Title:  But what the devil are you hurrying about?  Softly, softly, and
Title:  steadily, my men.  Only pull, and keep pulling; nothing more.  Crack
Title:  all your backbones, and bite your knives in two--that's all.  Take it
Title:  easy--why don't ye take it easy, I say, and burst all your livers and
Title:  lungs!"
Title:  
Title:  But what it was that inscrutable Ahab said to that tiger-yellow crew
Title:  of his--these were words best omitted here; for you live under the
Title:  blessed light of the evangelical land.  Only the infidel sharks in
Title:  the audacious seas may give ear to such words, when, with tornado
Title:  brow, and eyes of red murder, and foam-glued lips, Ahab leaped after
Title:  his prey.
Title:  
Title:  Meanwhile, all the boats tore on.  The repeated specific allusions of
Title:  Flask to "that whale," as he called the fictitious monster which he
Title:  declared to be incessantly tantalizing his boat's bow with its
Title:  tail--these allusions of his were at times so vivid and life-like,
Title:  that they would cause some one or two of his men to snatch a fearful
Title:  look over the shoulder.  But this was against all rule; for the
Title:  oarsmen must put out their eyes, and ram a skewer through their
Title:  necks; usage pronouncing that they must have no organs but ears, and
Title:  no limbs but arms, in these critical moments.
Title:  
Title:  It was a sight full of quick wonder and awe!  The vast swells of the
Title:  omnipotent sea; the surging, hollow roar they made, as they rolled
Title:  along the eight gunwales, like gigantic bowls in a boundless
Title:  bowling-green; the brief suspended agony of the boat, as it would tip
Title:  for an instant on the knife-like edge of the sharper waves, that
Title:  almost seemed threatening to cut it in two; the sudden profound dip
Title:  into the watery glens and hollows; the keen spurrings and goadings to
Title:  gain the top of the opposite hill; the headlong, sled-like slide down
Title:  its other side;--all these, with the cries of the headsmen and
Title:  harpooneers, and the shuddering gasps of the oarsmen, with the
Title:  wondrous sight of the ivory Pequod bearing down upon her boats with
Title:  outstretched sails, like a wild hen after her screaming brood;--all
Title:  this was thrilling.
Title:  
Title:  Not the raw recruit, marching from the bosom of his wife into the
Title:  fever heat of his first battle; not the dead man's ghost encountering
Title:  the first unknown phantom in the other world;--neither of these can
Title:  feel stranger and stronger emotions than that man does, who for the
Title:  first time finds himself pulling into the charmed, churned circle of
Title:  the hunted sperm whale.
Title:  
Title:  The dancing white water made by the chase was now becoming more and
Title:  more visible, owing to the increasing darkness of the dun
Title:  cloud-shadows flung upon the sea.  The jets of vapour no longer
Title:  blended, but tilted everywhere to right and left; the whales seemed
Title:  separating their wakes.  The boats were pulled more apart; Starbuck
Title:  giving chase to three whales running dead to leeward.  Our sail was
Title:  now set, and, with the still rising wind, we rushed along; the boat
Title:  going with such madness through the water, that the lee oars could
Title:  scarcely be worked rapidly enough to escape being torn from the
Title:  row-locks.
Title:  
Title:  Soon we were running through a suffusing wide veil of mist; neither
Title:  ship nor boat to be seen.
Title:  
Title:  "Give way, men," whispered Starbuck, drawing still further aft the
Title:  sheet of his sail; "there is time to kill a fish yet before the
Title:  squall comes.  There's white water again!--close to!  Spring!"
Title:  
Title:  Soon after, two cries in quick succession on each side of us denoted
Title:  that the other boats had got fast; but hardly were they overheard,
Title:  when with a lightning-like hurtling whisper Starbuck said: "Stand
Title:  up!" and Queequeg, harpoon in hand, sprang to his feet.
Title:  
Title:  Though not one of the oarsmen was then facing the life and death
Title:  peril so close to them ahead, yet with their eyes on the intense
Title:  countenance of the mate in the stern of the boat, they knew that the
Title:  imminent instant had come; they heard, too, an enormous wallowing
Title:  sound as of fifty elephants stirring in their litter.  Meanwhile the
Title:  boat was still booming through the mist, the waves curling and
Title:  hissing around us like the erected crests of enraged serpents.
Title:  
Title:  "That's his hump.  THERE, THERE, give it to him!" whispered Starbuck.
Title:  
Title:  A short rushing sound leaped out of the boat; it was the darted iron
Title:  of Queequeg.  Then all in one welded commotion came an invisible push
Title:  from astern, while forward the boat seemed striking on a ledge; the
Title:  sail collapsed and exploded; a gush of scalding vapour shot up near
Title:  by; something rolled and tumbled like an earthquake beneath us.  The
Title:  whole crew were half suffocated as they were tossed helter-skelter
Title:  into the white curdling cream of the squall.  Squall, whale, and
Title:  harpoon had all blended together; and the whale, merely grazed by the
Title:  iron, escaped.
Title:  
Title:  Though completely swamped, the boat was nearly unharmed.  Swimming
Title:  round it we picked up the floating oars, and lashing them across the
Title:  gunwale, tumbled back to our places.  There we sat up to our knees in
Title:  the sea, the water covering every rib and plank, so that to our
Title:  downward gazing eyes the suspended craft seemed a coral boat grown up
Title:  to us from the bottom of the ocean.
Title:  
Title:  The wind increased to a howl; the waves dashed their bucklers
Title:  together; the whole squall roared, forked, and crackled around us
Title:  like a white fire upon the prairie, in which, unconsumed, we were
Title:  burning; immortal in these jaws of death!  In vain we hailed the
Title:  other boats; as well roar to the live coals down the chimney of a
Title:  flaming furnace as hail those boats in that storm.  Meanwhile the
Title:  driving scud, rack, and mist, grew darker with the shadows of night;
Title:  no sign of the ship could be seen.  The rising sea forbade all
Title:  attempts to bale out the boat.  The oars were useless as propellers,
Title:  performing now the office of life-preservers.  So, cutting the
Title:  lashing of the waterproof match keg, after many failures Starbuck
Title:  contrived to ignite the lamp in the lantern; then stretching it on a
Title:  waif pole, handed it to Queequeg as the standard-bearer of this
Title:  forlorn hope.  There, then, he sat, holding up that imbecile candle
Title:  in the heart of that almighty forlornness.  There, then, he sat, the
Title:  sign and symbol of a man without faith, hopelessly holding up hope in
Title:  the midst of despair.
Title:  
Title:  Wet, drenched through, and shivering cold, despairing of ship or
Title:  boat, we lifted up our eyes as the dawn came on.  The mist still
Title:  spread over the sea, the empty lantern lay crushed in the bottom of
Title:  the boat.  Suddenly Queequeg started to his feet, hollowing his hand
Title:  to his ear.  We all heard a faint creaking, as of ropes and yards
Title:  hitherto muffled by the storm.  The sound came nearer and nearer; the
Title:  thick mists were dimly parted by a huge, vague form.  Affrighted, we
Title:  all sprang into the sea as the ship at last loomed into view, bearing
Title:  right down upon us within a distance of not much more than its
Title:  length.
Title:  
Title:  Floating on the waves we saw the abandoned boat, as for one instant
Title:  it tossed and gaped beneath the ship's bows like a chip at the base
Title:  of a cataract; and then the vast hull rolled over it, and it was seen
Title:  no more till it came up weltering astern.  Again we swam for it, were
Title:  dashed against it by the seas, and were at last taken up and safely
Title:  landed on board.  Ere the squall came close to, the other boats had
Title:  cut loose from their fish and returned to the ship in good time.  The
Title:  ship had given us up, but was still cruising, if haply it might light
Title:  upon some token of our perishing,--an oar or a lance pole.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 49
Title:  
Title:  The Hyena.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  There are certain queer times and occasions in this strange mixed
Title:  affair we call life when a man takes this whole universe for a vast
Title:  practical joke, though the wit thereof he but dimly discerns, and
Title:  more than suspects that the joke is at nobody's expense but his own.
Title:  However, nothing dispirits, and nothing seems worth while disputing.
Title:  He bolts down all events, all creeds, and beliefs, and persuasions,
Title:  all hard things visible and invisible, never mind how knobby; as an
Title:  ostrich of potent digestion gobbles down bullets and gun flints.  And
Title:  as for small difficulties and worryings, prospects of sudden
Title:  disaster, peril of life and limb; all these, and death itself, seem
Title:  to him only sly, good-natured hits, and jolly punches in the side
Title:  bestowed by the unseen and unaccountable old joker.  That odd sort of
Title:  wayward mood I am speaking of, comes over a man only in some time of
Title:  extreme tribulation; it comes in the very midst of his earnestness,
Title:  so that what just before might have seemed to him a thing most
Title:  momentous, now seems but a part of the general joke.  There is
Title:  nothing like the perils of whaling to breed this free and easy sort
Title:  of genial, desperado philosophy; and with it I now regarded this
Title:  whole voyage of the Pequod, and the great White Whale its object.
Title:  
Title:  "Queequeg," said I, when they had dragged me, the last man, to the
Title:  deck, and I was still shaking myself in my jacket to fling off the
Title:  water; "Queequeg, my fine friend, does this sort of thing often
Title:  happen?"  Without much emotion, though soaked through just like me,
Title:  he gave me to understand that such things did often happen.
Title:  
Title:  "Mr. Stubb," said I, turning to that worthy, who, buttoned up in his
Title:  oil-jacket, was now calmly smoking his pipe in the rain; "Mr. Stubb,
Title:  I think I have heard you say that of all whalemen you ever met, our
Title:  chief mate, Mr. Starbuck, is by far the most careful and prudent.  I
Title:  suppose then, that going plump on a flying whale with your sail set
Title:  in a foggy squall is the height of a whaleman's discretion?"
Title:  
Title:  "Certain.  I've lowered for whales from a leaking ship in a gale off
Title:  Cape Horn."
Title:  
Title:  "Mr. Flask," said I, turning to little King-Post, who was standing
Title:  close by; "you are experienced in these things, and I am not.  Will
Title:  you tell me whether it is an unalterable law in this fishery, Mr.
Title:  Flask, for an oarsman to break his own back pulling himself
Title:  back-foremost into death's jaws?"
Title:  
Title:  "Can't you twist that smaller?" said Flask.  "Yes, that's the law.  I
Title:  should like to see a boat's crew backing water up to a whale face
Title:  foremost.  Ha, ha! the whale would give them squint for squint, mind
Title:  that!"
Title:  
Title:  Here then, from three impartial witnesses, I had a deliberate
Title:  statement of the entire case.  Considering, therefore, that squalls
Title:  and capsizings in the water and consequent bivouacks on the deep,
Title:  were matters of common occurrence in this kind of life; considering
Title:  that at the superlatively critical instant of going on to the whale I
Title:  must resign my life into the hands of him who steered the
Title:  boat--oftentimes a fellow who at that very moment is in his
Title:  impetuousness upon the point of scuttling the craft with his own
Title:  frantic stampings; considering that the particular disaster to our
Title:  own particular boat was chiefly to be imputed to Starbuck's driving
Title:  on to his whale almost in the teeth of a squall, and considering that
Title:  Starbuck, notwithstanding, was famous for his great heedfulness in
Title:  the fishery; considering that I belonged to this uncommonly prudent
Title:  Starbuck's boat; and finally considering in what a devil's chase I
Title:  was implicated, touching the White Whale: taking all things together,
Title:  I say, I thought I might as well go below and make a rough draft of
Title:  my will.  "Queequeg," said I, "come along, you shall be my lawyer,
Title:  executor, and legatee."
Title:  
Title:  It may seem strange that of all men sailors should be tinkering at
Title:  their last wills and testaments, but there are no people in the world
Title:  more fond of that diversion.  This was the fourth time in my nautical
Title:  life that I had done the same thing.  After the ceremony was
Title:  concluded upon the present occasion, I felt all the easier; a stone
Title:  was rolled away from my heart.  Besides, all the days I should now
Title:  live would be as good as the days that Lazarus lived after his
Title:  resurrection; a supplementary clean gain of so many months or weeks
Title:  as the case might be.  I survived myself; my death and burial were
Title:  locked up in my chest.  I looked round me tranquilly and contentedly,
Title:  like a quiet ghost with a clean conscience sitting inside the bars of
Title:  a snug family vault.
Title:  
Title:  Now then, thought I, unconsciously rolling up the sleeves of my
Title:  frock, here goes for a cool, collected dive at death and destruction,
Title:  and the devil fetch the hindmost.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 50
Title:  
Title:  Ahab's Boat and Crew.  Fedallah.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "Who would have thought it, Flask!" cried Stubb; "if I had but one
Title:  leg you would not catch me in a boat, unless maybe to stop the
Title:  plug-hole with my timber toe.  Oh! he's a wonderful old man!"
Title:  
Title:  "I don't think it so strange, after all, on that account," said
Title:  Flask.  "If his leg were off at the hip, now, it would be a different
Title:  thing.  That would disable him; but he has one knee, and good part of
Title:  the other left, you know."
Title:  
Title:  "I don't know that, my little man; I never yet saw him kneel."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Among whale-wise people it has often been argued whether, considering
Title:  the paramount importance of his life to the success of the voyage, it
Title:  is right for a whaling captain to jeopardize that life in the active
Title:  perils of the chase.  So Tamerlane's soldiers often argued with tears
Title:  in their eyes, whether that invaluable life of his ought to be
Title:  carried into the thickest of the fight.
Title:  
Title:  But with Ahab the question assumed a modified aspect.  Considering
Title:  that with two legs man is but a hobbling wight in all times of
Title:  danger; considering that the pursuit of whales is always under great
Title:  and extraordinary difficulties; that every individual moment, indeed,
Title:  then comprises a peril; under these circumstances is it wise for any
Title:  maimed man to enter a whale-boat in the hunt?  As a general thing,
Title:  the joint-owners of the Pequod must have plainly thought not.
Title:  
Title:  Ahab well knew that although his friends at home would think little
Title:  of his entering a boat in certain comparatively harmless vicissitudes
Title:  of the chase, for the sake of being near the scene of action and
Title:  giving his orders in person, yet for Captain Ahab to have a boat
Title:  actually apportioned to him as a regular headsman in the hunt--above
Title:  all for Captain Ahab to be supplied with five extra men, as that same
Title:  boat's crew, he well knew that such generous conceits never entered the
Title:  heads of the owners of the Pequod.  Therefore he had not solicited a
Title:  boat's crew from them, nor had he in any way hinted his desires on
Title:  that head.  Nevertheless he had taken private measures of his own
Title:  touching all that matter.  Until Cabaco's published discovery, the
Title:  sailors had little foreseen it, though to be sure when, after being a
Title:  little while out of port, all hands had concluded the customary
Title:  business of fitting the whaleboats for service; when some time after
Title:  this Ahab was now and then found bestirring himself in the matter of
Title:  making thole-pins with his own hands for what was thought to be one
Title:  of the spare boats, and even solicitously cutting the small wooden
Title:  skewers, which when the line is running out are pinned over the
Title:  groove in the bow: when all this was observed in him, and
Title:  particularly his solicitude in having an extra coat of sheathing in
Title:  the bottom of the boat, as if to make it better withstand the pointed
Title:  pressure of his ivory limb; and also the anxiety he evinced in
Title:  exactly shaping the thigh board, or clumsy cleat, as it is sometimes
Title:  called, the horizontal piece in the boat's bow for bracing the knee
Title:  against in darting or stabbing at the whale; when it was observed how
Title:  often he stood up in that boat with his solitary knee fixed in the
Title:  semi-circular depression in the cleat, and with the carpenter's
Title:  chisel gouged out a little here and straightened it a little there;
Title:  all these things, I say, had awakened much interest and curiosity at
Title:  the time.  But almost everybody supposed that this particular
Title:  preparative heedfulness in Ahab must only be with a view to the
Title:  ultimate chase of Moby Dick; for he had already revealed his
Title:  intention to hunt that mortal monster in person.  But such a
Title:  supposition did by no means involve the remotest suspicion as to any
Title:  boat's crew being assigned to that boat.
Title:  
Title:  Now, with the subordinate phantoms, what wonder remained soon waned
Title:  away; for in a whaler wonders soon wane.  Besides, now and then such
Title:  unaccountable odds and ends of strange nations come up from the
Title:  unknown nooks and ash-holes of the earth to man these floating
Title:  outlaws of whalers; and the ships themselves often pick up such queer
Title:  castaway creatures found tossing about the open sea on planks, bits
Title:  of wreck, oars, whaleboats, canoes, blown-off Japanese junks, and
Title:  what not; that Beelzebub himself might climb up the side and step
Title:  down into the cabin to chat with the captain, and it would not create
Title:  any unsubduable excitement in the forecastle.
Title:  
Title:  But be all this as it may, certain it is that while the subordinate
Title:  phantoms soon found their place among the crew, though still as it
Title:  were somehow distinct from them, yet that hair-turbaned Fedallah
Title:  remained a muffled mystery to the last.  Whence he came in a mannerly
Title:  world like this, by what sort of unaccountable tie he soon evinced
Title:  himself to be linked with Ahab's peculiar fortunes; nay, so far as to
Title:  have some sort of a half-hinted influence; Heaven knows, but it might
Title:  have been even authority over him; all this none knew.  But one
Title:  cannot sustain an indifferent air concerning Fedallah.  He was such a
Title:  creature as civilized, domestic people in the temperate zone only see
Title:  in their dreams, and that but dimly; but the like of whom now and
Title:  then glide among the unchanging Asiatic communities, especially the
Title:  Oriental isles to the east of the continent--those insulated,
Title:  immemorial, unalterable countries, which even in these modern days
Title:  still preserve much of the ghostly aboriginalness of earth's primal
Title:  generations, when the memory of the first man was a distinct
Title:  recollection, and all men his descendants, unknowing whence he came,
Title:  eyed each other as real phantoms, and asked of the sun and the moon
Title:  why they were created and to what end; when though, according to
Title:  Genesis, the angels indeed consorted with the daughters of men, the
Title:  devils also, add the uncanonical Rabbins, indulged in mundane amours.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 51
Title:  
Title:  The Spirit-Spout.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Days, weeks passed, and under easy sail, the ivory Pequod had slowly
Title:  swept across four several cruising-grounds; that off the Azores; off
Title:  the Cape de Verdes; on the Plate (so called), being off the mouth of
Title:  the Rio de la Plata; and the Carrol Ground, an unstaked, watery
Title:  locality, southerly from St. Helena.
Title:  
Title:  It was while gliding through these latter waters that one serene and
Title:  moonlight night, when all the waves rolled by like scrolls of silver;
Title:  and, by their soft, suffusing seethings, made what seemed a silvery
Title:  silence, not a solitude; on such a silent night a silvery jet was
Title:  seen far in advance of the white bubbles at the bow.  Lit up by the
Title:  moon, it looked celestial; seemed some plumed and glittering god
Title:  uprising from the sea.  Fedallah first descried this jet.  For of
Title:  these moonlight nights, it was his wont to mount to the main-mast
Title:  head, and stand a look-out there, with the same precision as if it
Title:  had been day.  And yet, though herds of whales were seen by night,
Title:  not one whaleman in a hundred would venture a lowering for them.  You
Title:  may think with what emotions, then, the seamen beheld this old
Title:  Oriental perched aloft at such unusual hours; his turban and the
Title:  moon, companions in one sky.  But when, after spending his uniform
Title:  interval there for several successive nights without uttering a
Title:  single sound; when, after all this silence, his unearthly voice was
Title:  heard announcing that silvery, moon-lit jet, every reclining mariner
Title:  started to his feet as if some winged spirit had lighted in the
Title:  rigging, and hailed the mortal crew.  "There she blows!"  Had the
Title:  trump of judgment blown, they could not have quivered more; yet still
Title:  they felt no terror; rather pleasure.  For though it was a most
Title:  unwonted hour, yet so impressive was the cry, and so deliriously
Title:  exciting, that almost every soul on board instinctively desired a
Title:  lowering.
Title:  
Title:  Walking the deck with quick, side-lunging strides, Ahab commanded the
Title:  t'gallant sails and royals to be set, and every stunsail spread.  The
Title:  best man in the ship must take the helm.  Then, with every mast-head
Title:  manned, the piled-up craft rolled down before the wind.  The strange,
Title:  upheaving, lifting tendency of the taffrail breeze filling the
Title:  hollows of so many sails, made the buoyant, hovering deck to feel
Title:  like air beneath the feet; while still she rushed along, as if two
