Title:  antagonistic influences were struggling in her--one to mount direct
Title:  to heaven, the other to drive yawingly to some horizontal goal.  And
Title:  had you watched Ahab's face that night, you would have thought that
Title:  in him also two different things were warring.  While his one live
Title:  leg made lively echoes along the deck, every stroke of his dead limb
Title:  sounded like a coffin-tap.  On life and death this old man walked.
Title:  But though the ship so swiftly sped, and though from every eye, like
Title:  arrows, the eager glances shot, yet the silvery jet was no more seen
Title:  that night.  Every sailor swore he saw it once, but not a second
Title:  time.
Title:  
Title:  This midnight-spout had almost grown a forgotten thing, when, some
Title:  days after, lo! at the same silent hour, it was again announced:
Title:  again it was descried by all; but upon making sail to overtake it,
Title:  once more it disappeared as if it had never been.  And so it served
Title:  us night after night, till no one heeded it but to wonder at it.
Title:  Mysteriously jetted into the clear moonlight, or starlight, as the
Title:  case might be; disappearing again for one whole day, or two days, or
Title:  three; and somehow seeming at every distinct repetition to be
Title:  advancing still further and further in our van, this solitary jet
Title:  seemed for ever alluring us on.
Title:  
Title:  Nor with the immemorial superstition of their race, and in accordance
Title:  with the preternaturalness, as it seemed, which in many things
Title:  invested the Pequod, were there wanting some of the seamen who swore
Title:  that whenever and wherever descried; at however remote times, or in
Title:  however far apart latitudes and longitudes, that unnearable spout was
Title:  cast by one self-same whale; and that whale, Moby Dick.  For a time,
Title:  there reigned, too, a sense of peculiar dread at this flitting
Title:  apparition, as if it were treacherously beckoning us on and on, in
Title:  order that the monster might turn round upon us, and rend us at last
Title:  in the remotest and most savage seas.
Title:  
Title:  These temporary apprehensions, so vague but so awful, derived a
Title:  wondrous potency from the contrasting serenity of the weather, in
Title:  which, beneath all its blue blandness, some thought there lurked a
Title:  devilish charm, as for days and days we voyaged along, through seas
Title:  so wearily, lonesomely mild, that all space, in repugnance to our
Title:  vengeful errand, seemed vacating itself of life before our urn-like
Title:  prow.
Title:  
Title:  But, at last, when turning to the eastward, the Cape winds began
Title:  howling around us, and we rose and fell upon the long, troubled seas
Title:  that are there; when the ivory-tusked Pequod sharply bowed to the
Title:  blast, and gored the dark waves in her madness, till, like showers of
Title:  silver chips, the foam-flakes flew over her bulwarks; then all this
Title:  desolate vacuity of life went away, but gave place to sights more
Title:  dismal than before.
Title:  
Title:  Close to our bows, strange forms in the water darted hither and
Title:  thither before us; while thick in our rear flew the inscrutable
Title:  sea-ravens.  And every morning, perched on our stays, rows of these
Title:  birds were seen; and spite of our hootings, for a long time
Title:  obstinately clung to the hemp, as though they deemed our ship some
Title:  drifting, uninhabited craft; a thing appointed to desolation, and
Title:  therefore fit roosting-place for their homeless selves.  And heaved
Title:  and heaved, still unrestingly heaved the black sea, as if its vast
Title:  tides were a conscience; and the great mundane soul were in anguish
Title:  and remorse for the long sin and suffering it had bred.
Title:  
Title:  Cape of Good Hope, do they call ye?  Rather Cape Tormentoto, as
Title:  called of yore; for long allured by the perfidious silences that
Title:  before had attended us, we found ourselves launched into this
Title:  tormented sea, where guilty beings transformed into those fowls and
Title:  these fish, seemed condemned to swim on everlastingly without any
Title:  haven in store, or beat that black air without any horizon.  But
Title:  calm, snow-white, and unvarying; still directing its fountain of
Title:  feathers to the sky; still beckoning us on from before, the solitary
Title:  jet would at times be descried.
Title:  
Title:  During all this blackness of the elements, Ahab, though assuming for
Title:  the time the almost continual command of the drenched and dangerous
Title:  deck, manifested the gloomiest reserve; and more seldom than ever
Title:  addressed his mates.  In tempestuous times like these, after
Title:  everything above and aloft has been secured, nothing more can be done
Title:  but passively to await the issue of the gale.  Then Captain and crew
Title:  become practical fatalists.  So, with his ivory leg inserted into its
Title:  accustomed hole, and with one hand firmly grasping a shroud, Ahab for
Title:  hours and hours would stand gazing dead to windward, while an
Title:  occasional squall of sleet or snow would all but congeal his very
Title:  eyelashes together.  Meantime, the crew driven from the forward part
Title:  of the ship by the perilous seas that burstingly broke over its bows,
Title:  stood in a line along the bulwarks in the waist; and the better to
Title:  guard against the leaping waves, each man had slipped himself into a
Title:  sort of bowline secured to the rail, in which he swung as in a
Title:  loosened belt.  Few or no words were spoken; and the silent ship, as
Title:  if manned by painted sailors in wax, day after day tore on through
Title:  all the swift madness and gladness of the demoniac waves.  By night
Title:  the same muteness of humanity before the shrieks of the ocean
Title:  prevailed; still in silence the men swung in the bowlines; still
Title:  wordless Ahab stood up to the blast.  Even when wearied nature seemed
Title:  demanding repose he would not seek that repose in his hammock.
Title:  Never could Starbuck forget the old man's aspect, when one night
Title:  going down into the cabin to mark how the barometer stood, he saw him
Title:  with closed eyes sitting straight in his floor-screwed chair; the
Title:  rain and half-melted sleet of the storm from which he had some time
Title:  before emerged, still slowly dripping from the unremoved hat and
Title:  coat.  On the table beside him lay unrolled one of those charts of
Title:  tides and currents which have previously been spoken of.  His lantern
Title:  swung from his tightly clenched hand.  Though the body was erect, the
Title:  head was thrown back so that the closed eyes were pointed towards the
Title:  needle of the tell-tale that swung from a beam in the ceiling.*
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *The cabin-compass is called the tell-tale, because without going to
Title:  the compass at the helm, the Captain, while below, can inform himself
Title:  of the course of the ship.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Terrible old man! thought Starbuck with a shudder, sleeping in this
Title:  gale, still thou steadfastly eyest thy purpose.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 52
Title:  
Title:  The Albatross.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  South-eastward from the Cape, off the distant Crozetts, a good
Title:  cruising ground for Right Whalemen, a sail loomed ahead, the Goney
Title:  (Albatross) by name.  As she slowly drew nigh, from my lofty perch at
Title:  the fore-mast-head, I had a good view of that sight so remarkable to
Title:  a tyro in the far ocean fisheries--a whaler at sea, and long absent
Title:  from home.
Title:  
Title:  As if the waves had been fullers, this craft was bleached like the
Title:  skeleton of a stranded walrus.  All down her sides, this spectral
Title:  appearance was traced with long channels of reddened rust, while all
Title:  her spars and her rigging were like the thick branches of trees
Title:  furred over with hoar-frost.  Only her lower sails were set.  A wild
Title:  sight it was to see her long-bearded look-outs at those three
Title:  mast-heads.  They seemed clad in the skins of beasts, so torn and
Title:  bepatched the raiment that had survived nearly four years of
Title:  cruising.  Standing in iron hoops nailed to the mast, they swayed and
Title:  swung over a fathomless sea; and though, when the ship slowly glided
Title:  close under our stern, we six men in the air came so nigh to each
Title:  other that we might almost have leaped from the mast-heads of one
Title:  ship to those of the other; yet, those forlorn-looking fishermen,
Title:  mildly eyeing us as they passed, said not one word to our own
Title:  look-outs, while the quarter-deck hail was being heard from below.
Title:  
Title:  "Ship ahoy!  Have ye seen the White Whale?"
Title:  
Title:  But as the strange captain, leaning over the pallid bulwarks, was in
Title:  the act of putting his trumpet to his mouth, it somehow fell from his
Title:  hand into the sea; and the wind now rising amain, he in vain strove
Title:  to make himself heard without it.  Meantime his ship was still
Title:  increasing the distance between.  While in various silent ways
Title:  the seamen of the Pequod were evincing their observance of this
Title:  ominous incident at the first mere mention of the White Whale's name
Title:  to another ship, Ahab for a moment paused; it almost seemed as though
Title:  he would have lowered a boat to board the stranger, had not the
Title:  threatening wind forbade.  But taking advantage of his windward
Title:  position, he again seized his trumpet, and knowing by her aspect that
Title:  the stranger vessel was a Nantucketer and shortly bound home, he
Title:  loudly hailed--"Ahoy there!  This is the Pequod, bound round the
Title:  world!  Tell them to address all future letters to the Pacific ocean!
Title:  and this time three years, if I am not at home, tell them to address
Title:  them to--"
Title:  
Title:  At that moment the two wakes were fairly crossed, and instantly,
Title:  then, in accordance with their singular ways, shoals of small
Title:  harmless fish, that for some days before had been placidly swimming
Title:  by our side, darted away with what seemed shuddering fins, and ranged
Title:  themselves fore and aft with the stranger's flanks.  Though in the
Title:  course of his continual voyagings Ahab must often before have noticed
Title:  a similar sight, yet, to any monomaniac man, the veriest trifles
Title:  capriciously carry meanings.
Title:  
Title:  "Swim away from me, do ye?" murmured Ahab, gazing over into the
Title:  water.  There seemed but little in the words, but the tone conveyed
Title:  more of deep helpless sadness than the insane old man had ever before
Title:  evinced.  But turning to the steersman, who thus far had been holding
Title:  the ship in the wind to diminish her headway, he cried out in his old
Title:  lion voice,--"Up helm!  Keep her off round the world!"
Title:  
Title:  Round the world!  There is much in that sound to inspire proud
Title:  feelings; but whereto does all that circumnavigation conduct?  Only
Title:  through numberless perils to the very point whence we started, where
Title:  those that we left behind secure, were all the time before us.
Title:  
Title:  Were this world an endless plain, and by sailing eastward we could
Title:  for ever reach new distances, and discover sights more sweet and
Title:  strange than any Cyclades or Islands of King Solomon, then there were
Title:  promise in the voyage.  But in pursuit of those far mysteries we
Title:  dream of, or in tormented chase of that demon phantom that, some time
Title:  or other, swims before all human hearts; while chasing such over this
Title:  round globe, they either lead us on in barren mazes or midway leave
Title:  us whelmed.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 53
Title:  
Title:  The Gam.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  The ostensible reason why Ahab did not go on board of the whaler we
Title:  had spoken was this: the wind and sea betokened storms.  But even had
Title:  this not been the case, he would not after all, perhaps, have boarded
Title:  her--judging by his subsequent conduct on similar occasions--if so it
Title:  had been that, by the process of hailing, he had obtained a negative
Title:  answer to the question he put.  For, as it eventually turned out, he
Title:  cared not to consort, even for five minutes, with any stranger
Title:  captain, except he could contribute some of that information he so
Title:  absorbingly sought.  But all this might remain inadequately
Title:  estimated, were not something said here of the peculiar usages of
Title:  whaling-vessels when meeting each other in foreign seas, and
Title:  especially on a common cruising-ground.
Title:  
Title:  If two strangers crossing the Pine Barrens in New York State, or the
Title:  equally desolate Salisbury Plain in England; if casually encountering
Title:  each other in such inhospitable wilds, these twain, for the life of
Title:  them, cannot well avoid a mutual salutation; and stopping for a
Title:  moment to interchange the news; and, perhaps, sitting down for a
Title:  while and resting in concert: then, how much more natural that upon
Title:  the illimitable Pine Barrens and Salisbury Plains of the sea, two
Title:  whaling vessels descrying each other at the ends of the earth--off
Title:  lone Fanning's Island, or the far away King's Mills; how much more
Title:  natural, I say, that under such circumstances these ships should not
Title:  only interchange hails, but come into still closer, more friendly and
Title:  sociable contact.  And especially would this seem to be a matter of
Title:  course, in the case of vessels owned in one seaport, and whose
Title:  captains, officers, and not a few of the men are personally known to
Title:  each other; and consequently, have all sorts of dear domestic things
Title:  to talk about.
Title:  
Title:  For the long absent ship, the outward-bounder, perhaps, has letters
Title:  on board; at any rate, she will be sure to let her have some papers
Title:  of a date a year or two later than the last one on her blurred and
Title:  thumb-worn files.  And in return for that courtesy, the outward-bound
Title:  ship would receive the latest whaling intelligence from the
Title:  cruising-ground to which she may be destined, a thing of the utmost
Title:  importance to her.  And in degree, all this will hold true concerning
Title:  whaling vessels crossing each other's track on the cruising-ground
Title:  itself, even though they are equally long absent from home.  For one
Title:  of them may have received a transfer of letters from some third, and
Title:  now far remote vessel; and some of those letters may be for the
Title:  people of the ship she now meets.  Besides, they would exchange the
Title:  whaling news, and have an agreeable chat.  For not only would they
Title:  meet with all the sympathies of sailors, but likewise with all the
Title:  peculiar congenialities arising from a common pursuit and mutually
Title:  shared privations and perils.
Title:  
Title:  Nor would difference of country make any very essential difference;
Title:  that is, so long as both parties speak one language, as is the case
Title:  with Americans and English.  Though, to be sure, from the small
Title:  number of English whalers, such meetings do not very often occur, and
Title:  when they do occur there is too apt to be a sort of shyness between
Title:  them; for your Englishman is rather reserved, and your Yankee, he
Title:  does not fancy that sort of thing in anybody but himself.  Besides,
Title:  the English whalers sometimes affect a kind of metropolitan
Title:  superiority over the American whalers; regarding the long, lean
Title:  Nantucketer, with his nondescript provincialisms, as a sort of
Title:  sea-peasant.  But where this superiority in the English whalemen
Title:  does really consist, it would be hard to say, seeing that the Yankees
Title:  in one day, collectively, kill more whales than all the English,
Title:  collectively, in ten years.  But this is a harmless little foible in
Title:  the English whale-hunters, which the Nantucketer does not take much
Title:  to heart; probably, because he knows that he has a few foibles
Title:  himself.
Title:  
Title:  So, then, we see that of all ships separately sailing the sea, the
Title:  whalers have most reason to be sociable--and they are so.  Whereas,
Title:  some merchant ships crossing each other's wake in the mid-Atlantic,
Title:  will oftentimes pass on without so much as a single word of
Title:  recognition, mutually cutting each other on the high seas, like a
Title:  brace of dandies in Broadway; and all the time indulging, perhaps, in
Title:  finical criticism upon each other's rig.  As for Men-of-War, when
Title:  they chance to meet at sea, they first go through such a string of
Title:  silly bowings and scrapings, such a ducking of ensigns, that there
Title:  does not seem to be much right-down hearty good-will and brotherly
Title:  love about it at all.  As touching Slave-ships meeting, why, they are
Title:  in such a prodigious hurry, they run away from each other as soon as
Title:  possible.  And as for Pirates, when they chance to cross each other's
Title:  cross-bones, the first hail is--"How many skulls?"--the same way that
Title:  whalers hail--"How many barrels?"  And that question once answered,
Title:  pirates straightway steer apart, for they are infernal villains on
Title:  both sides, and don't like to see overmuch of each other's villanous
Title:  likenesses.
Title:  
Title:  But look at the godly, honest, unostentatious, hospitable, sociable,
Title:  free-and-easy whaler!  What does the whaler do when she meets another
Title:  whaler in any sort of decent weather?  She has a "GAM," a thing so
Title:  utterly unknown to all other ships that they never heard of the name
Title:  even; and if by chance they should hear of it, they only grin at it,
Title:  and repeat gamesome stuff about "spouters" and "blubber-boilers," and
Title:  such like pretty exclamations.  Why it is that all Merchant-seamen,
Title:  and also all Pirates and Man-of-War's men, and Slave-ship sailors,
Title:  cherish such a scornful feeling towards Whale-ships; this is a
Title:  question it would be hard to answer.  Because, in the case of
Title:  pirates, say, I should like to know whether that profession of theirs
Title:  has any peculiar glory about it.  It sometimes ends in uncommon
Title:  elevation, indeed; but only at the gallows.  And besides, when a man
Title:  is elevated in that odd fashion, he has no proper foundation for his
Title:  superior altitude.  Hence, I conclude, that in boasting himself to be
Title:  high lifted above a whaleman, in that assertion the pirate has no
Title:  solid basis to stand on.
Title:  
Title:  But what is a GAM?  You might wear out your index-finger running up
Title:  and down the columns of dictionaries, and never find the word.  Dr.
Title:  Johnson never attained to that erudition; Noah Webster's ark does not
Title:  hold it.  Nevertheless, this same expressive word has now for many
Title:  years been in constant use among some fifteen thousand true born
Title:  Yankees.  Certainly, it needs a definition, and should be
Title:  incorporated into the Lexicon.  With that view, let me learnedly
Title:  define it.
Title:  
Title:  GAM.  NOUN--A SOCIAL MEETING OF TWO (OR MORE) WHALESHIPS, GENERALLY
Title:  ON A CRUISING-GROUND; WHEN, AFTER EXCHANGING HAILS, THEY EXCHANGE
Title:  VISITS BY BOATS' CREWS; THE TWO CAPTAINS REMAINING, FOR THE TIME, ON
Title:  BOARD OF ONE SHIP, AND THE TWO CHIEF MATES ON THE OTHER.
Title:  
Title:  There is another little item about Gamming which must not be
Title:  forgotten here.  All professions have their own little peculiarities
Title:  of detail; so has the whale fishery.  In a pirate, man-of-war, or
Title:  slave ship, when the captain is rowed anywhere in his boat, he always
Title:  sits in the stern sheets on a comfortable, sometimes cushioned seat
Title:  there, and often steers himself with a pretty little milliner's
Title:  tiller decorated with gay cords and ribbons.  But the whale-boat has
Title:  no seat astern, no sofa of that sort whatever, and no tiller at all.
Title:  High times indeed, if whaling captains were wheeled about the water
Title:  on castors like gouty old aldermen in patent chairs.  And as for a
Title:  tiller, the whale-boat never admits of any such effeminacy; and
Title:  therefore as in gamming a complete boat's crew must leave the ship,
Title:  and hence as the boat steerer or harpooneer is of the number, that
Title:  subordinate is the steersman upon the occasion, and the captain,
Title:  having no place to sit in, is pulled off to his visit all standing
Title:  like a pine tree.  And often you will notice that being conscious of
Title:  the eyes of the whole visible world resting on him from the sides of
Title:  the two ships, this standing captain is all alive to the importance
Title:  of sustaining his dignity by maintaining his legs.  Nor is this any
Title:  very easy matter; for in his rear is the immense projecting steering
Title:  oar hitting him now and then in the small of his back, the after-oar
Title:  reciprocating by rapping his knees in front.  He is thus completely
Title:  wedged before and behind, and can only expand himself sideways by
Title:  settling down on his stretched legs; but a sudden, violent pitch of
Title:  the boat will often go far to topple him, because length of
Title:  foundation is nothing without corresponding breadth.  Merely make a
Title:  spread angle of two poles, and you cannot stand them up.  Then,
Title:  again, it would never do in plain sight of the world's riveted eyes,
Title:  it would never do, I say, for this straddling captain to be seen
Title:  steadying himself the slightest particle by catching hold of anything
Title:  with his hands; indeed, as token of his entire, buoyant self-command,
Title:  he generally carries his hands in his trowsers' pockets; but perhaps
Title:  being generally very large, heavy hands, he carries them there for
Title:  ballast.  Nevertheless there have occurred instances, well
Title:  authenticated ones too, where the captain has been known for an
Title:  uncommonly critical moment or two, in a sudden squall say--to seize
Title:  hold of the nearest oarsman's hair, and hold on there like grim
Title:  death.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 54
Title:  
Title:  The Town-Ho's Story.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  (AS TOLD AT THE GOLDEN INN)
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  The Cape of Good Hope, and all the watery region round about there,
Title:  is much like some noted four corners of a great highway, where you
Title:  meet more travellers than in any other part.
Title:  
Title:  It was not very long after speaking the Goney that another
Title:  homeward-bound whaleman, the Town-Ho,* was encountered.  She was
Title:  manned almost wholly by Polynesians.  In the short gam that ensued
Title:  she gave us strong news of Moby Dick.  To some the general interest
Title:  in the White Whale was now wildly heightened by a circumstance of the
Title:  Town-Ho's story, which seemed obscurely to involve with the whale a
Title:  certain wondrous, inverted visitation of one of those so called
Title:  judgments of God which at times are said to overtake some men.  This
Title:  latter circumstance, with its own particular accompaniments, forming
Title:  what may be called the secret part of the tragedy about to be
Title:  narrated, never reached the ears of Captain Ahab or his mates.  For
Title:  that secret part of the story was unknown to the captain of the
Title:  Town-Ho himself.  It was the private property of three confederate
Title:  white seamen of that ship, one of whom, it seems, communicated it to
Title:  Tashtego with Romish injunctions of secrecy, but the following night
Title:  Tashtego rambled in his sleep, and revealed so much of it in that
Title:  way, that when he was wakened he could not well withhold the rest.
Title:  Nevertheless, so potent an influence did this thing have on those
Title:  seamen in the Pequod who came to the full knowledge of it, and by
Title:  such a strange delicacy, to call it so, were they governed in this
Title:  matter, that they kept the secret among themselves so that it never
Title:  transpired abaft the Pequod's main-mast.  Interweaving in its proper
Title:  place this darker thread with the story as publicly narrated on the
Title:  ship, the whole of this strange affair I now proceed to put on
Title:  lasting record.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *The ancient whale-cry upon first sighting a whale from the
Title:  mast-head, still used by whalemen in hunting the famous Gallipagos
Title:  terrapin.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  For my humor's sake, I shall preserve the style in which I once
Title:  narrated it at Lima, to a lounging circle of my Spanish friends, one
Title:  saint's eve, smoking upon the thick-gilt tiled piazza of the Golden
Title:  Inn.  Of those fine cavaliers, the young Dons, Pedro and Sebastian,
Title:  were on the closer terms with me; and hence the interluding questions
Title:  they occasionally put, and which are duly answered at the time.
Title:  
Title:  "Some two years prior to my first learning the events which I am
Title:  about rehearsing to you, gentlemen, the Town-Ho, Sperm Whaler of
Title:  Nantucket, was cruising in your Pacific here, not very many days'
Title:  sail eastward from the eaves of this good Golden Inn.  She was
Title:  somewhere to the northward of the Line.  One morning upon handling
Title:  the pumps, according to daily usage, it was observed that she made
Title:  more water in her hold than common.  They supposed a sword-fish had
Title:  stabbed her, gentlemen.  But the captain, having some unusual reason
Title:  for believing that rare good luck awaited him in those latitudes; and
Title:  therefore being very averse to quit them, and the leak not being then
Title:  considered at all dangerous, though, indeed, they could not find it
Title:  after searching the hold as low down as was possible in rather heavy
Title:  weather, the ship still continued her cruisings, the mariners working
Title:  at the pumps at wide and easy intervals; but no good luck came; more
Title:  days went by, and not only was the leak yet undiscovered, but it
Title:  sensibly increased.  So much so, that now taking some alarm, the
Title:  captain, making all sail, stood away for the nearest harbor among the
Title:  islands, there to have his hull hove out and repaired.
Title:  
Title:  "Though no small passage was before her, yet, if the commonest chance
Title:  favoured, he did not at all fear that his ship would founder by the
Title:  way, because his pumps were of the best, and being periodically
Title:  relieved at them, those six-and-thirty men of his could easily keep
Title:  the ship free; never mind if the leak should double on her.  In
Title:  truth, well nigh the whole of this passage being attended by very
Title:  prosperous breezes, the Town-Ho had all but certainly arrived in
Title:  perfect safety at her port without the occurrence of the least
Title:  fatality, had it not been for the brutal overbearing of Radney, the
Title:  mate, a Vineyarder, and the bitterly provoked vengeance of Steelkilt,
Title:  a Lakeman and desperado from Buffalo.
Title:  
Title:  "'Lakeman!--Buffalo!  Pray, what is a Lakeman, and where is Buffalo?'
Title:  said Don Sebastian, rising in his swinging mat of grass.
Title:  
Title:  "On the eastern shore of our Lake Erie, Don; but--I crave your
Title:  courtesy--may be, you shall soon hear further of all that.  Now,
Title:  gentlemen, in square-sail brigs and three-masted ships, well-nigh as
Title:  large and stout as any that ever sailed out of your old Callao to far
Title:  Manilla; this Lakeman, in the land-locked heart of our America, had
Title:  yet been nurtured by all those agrarian freebooting impressions
Title:  popularly connected with the open ocean.  For in their interflowing
Title:  aggregate, those grand fresh-water seas of ours,--Erie, and Ontario,
Title:  and Huron, and Superior, and Michigan,--possess an ocean-like
Title:  expansiveness, with many of the ocean's noblest traits; with many of
Title:  its rimmed varieties of races and of climes.  They contain round
Title:  archipelagoes of romantic isles, even as the Polynesian waters do; in
Title:  large part, are shored by two great contrasting nations, as the
Title:  Atlantic is; they furnish long maritime approaches to our numerous
Title:  territorial colonies from the East, dotted all round their banks;
Title:  here and there are frowned upon by batteries, and by the goat-like
Title:  craggy guns of lofty Mackinaw; they have heard the fleet thunderings
Title:  of naval victories; at intervals, they yield their beaches to wild
Title:  barbarians, whose red painted faces flash from out their peltry
Title:  wigwams; for leagues and leagues are flanked by ancient and unentered
Title:  forests, where the gaunt pines stand like serried lines of kings in
Title:  Gothic genealogies; those same woods harboring wild Afric beasts of
Title:  prey, and silken creatures whose exported furs give robes to Tartar
Title:  Emperors; they mirror the paved capitals of Buffalo and Cleveland, as
Title:  well as Winnebago villages; they float alike the full-rigged merchant
Title:  ship, the armed cruiser of the State, the steamer, and the beech
Title:  canoe; they are swept by Borean and dismasting blasts as direful as
Title:  any that lash the salted wave; they know what shipwrecks are, for out
Title:  of sight of land, however inland, they have drowned full many a
Title:  midnight ship with all its shrieking crew.  Thus, gentlemen, though
Title:  an inlander, Steelkilt was wild-ocean born, and wild-ocean nurtured;
Title:  as much of an audacious mariner as any.  And for Radney, though in
Title:  his infancy he may have laid him down on the lone Nantucket beach, to
Title:  nurse at his maternal sea; though in after life he had long followed
Title:  our austere Atlantic and your contemplative Pacific; yet was he quite
Title:  as vengeful and full of social quarrel as the backwoods seaman, fresh
Title:  from the latitudes of buck-horn handled bowie-knives.  Yet was this
Title:  Nantucketer a man with some good-hearted traits; and this Lakeman, a
Title:  mariner, who though a sort of devil indeed, might yet by inflexible
Title:  firmness, only tempered by that common decency of human recognition
Title:  which is the meanest slave's right; thus treated, this Steelkilt had
Title:  long been retained harmless and docile.  At all events, he had proved
Title:  so thus far; but Radney was doomed and made mad, and Steelkilt--but,
Title:  gentlemen, you shall hear.
Title:  
Title:  "It was not more than a day or two at the furthest after pointing her
Title:  prow for her island haven, that the Town-Ho's leak seemed again
Title:  increasing, but only so as to require an hour or more at the pumps
Title:  every day.  You must know that in a settled and civilized ocean like
Title:  our Atlantic, for example, some skippers think little of pumping
Title:  their whole way across it; though of a still, sleepy night, should
Title:  the officer of the deck happen to forget his duty in that respect,
Title:  the probability would be that he and his shipmates would never again
Title:  remember it, on account of all hands gently subsiding to the bottom.
Title:  Nor in the solitary and savage seas far from you to the westward,
Title:  gentlemen, is it altogether unusual for ships to keep clanging at
Title:  their pump-handles in full chorus even for a voyage of considerable
Title:  length; that is, if it lie along a tolerably accessible coast, or if
Title:  any other reasonable retreat is afforded them.  It is only when a
Title:  leaky vessel is in some very out of the way part of those waters,
Title:  some really landless latitude, that her captain begins to feel a
Title:  little anxious.
Title:  
Title:  "Much this way had it been with the Town-Ho; so when her leak was
Title:  found gaining once more, there was in truth some small concern
Title:  manifested by several of her company; especially by Radney the mate.
Title:  He commanded the upper sails to be well hoisted, sheeted home anew,
Title:  and every way expanded to the breeze.  Now this Radney, I suppose,
Title:  was as little of a coward, and as little inclined to any sort of
Title:  nervous apprehensiveness touching his own person as any fearless,
Title:  unthinking creature on land or on sea that you can conveniently
Title:  imagine, gentlemen.  Therefore when he betrayed this solicitude about
Title:  the safety of the ship, some of the seamen declared that it was only
Title:  on account of his being a part owner in her.  So when they were
Title:  working that evening at the pumps, there was on this head no small
Title:  gamesomeness slily going on among them, as they stood with their feet
Title:  continually overflowed by the rippling clear water; clear as any
Title:  mountain spring, gentlemen--that bubbling from the pumps ran across
Title:  the deck, and poured itself out in steady spouts at the lee
Title:  scupper-holes.
Title:  
Title:  "Now, as you well know, it is not seldom the case in this
Title:  conventional world of ours--watery or otherwise; that when a person
Title:  placed in command over his fellow-men finds one of them to be very
Title:  significantly his superior in general pride of manhood, straightway
Title:  against that man he conceives an unconquerable dislike and
Title:  bitterness; and if he have a chance he will pull down and pulverize
Title:  that subaltern's tower, and make a little heap of dust of it.  Be
Title:  this conceit of mine as it may, gentlemen, at all events Steelkilt
Title:  was a tall and noble animal with a head like a Roman, and a flowing
Title:  golden beard like the tasseled housings of your last viceroy's
Title:  snorting charger; and a brain, and a heart, and a soul in him,
Title:  gentlemen, which had made Steelkilt Charlemagne, had he been born son
Title:  to Charlemagne's father.  But Radney, the mate, was ugly as a mule;
Title:  yet as hardy, as stubborn, as malicious.  He did not love Steelkilt,
Title:  and Steelkilt knew it.
Title:  
Title:  "Espying the mate drawing near as he was toiling at the pump with the
Title:  rest, the Lakeman affected not to notice him, but unawed, went on
Title:  with his gay banterings.
Title:  
Title:  "'Aye, aye, my merry lads, it's a lively leak this; hold a cannikin,
Title:  one of ye, and let's have a taste.  By the Lord, it's worth bottling!
Title:  I tell ye what, men, old Rad's investment must go for it! he had
Title:  best cut away his part of the hull and tow it home.  The fact is,
Title:  boys, that sword-fish only began the job; he's come back again with a
Title:  gang of ship-carpenters, saw-fish, and file-fish, and what not; and
Title:  the whole posse of 'em are now hard at work cutting and slashing at
Title:  the bottom; making improvements, I suppose.  If old Rad were here
Title:  now, I'd tell him to jump overboard and scatter 'em.  They're playing
Title:  the devil with his estate, I can tell him.  But he's a simple old
Title:  soul,--Rad, and a beauty too.  Boys, they say the rest of his
Title:  property is invested in looking-glasses.  I wonder if he'd give a
Title:  poor devil like me the model of his nose.'
Title:  
Title:  "'Damn your eyes! what's that pump stopping for?' roared Radney,
Title:  pretending not to have heard the sailors' talk.  'Thunder away at
Title:  it!'
Title:  
Title:  'Aye, aye, sir,' said Steelkilt, merry as a cricket.  'Lively, boys,
Title:  lively, now!'  And with that the pump clanged like fifty
Title:  fire-engines; the men tossed their hats off to it, and ere long that
Title:  peculiar gasping of the lungs was heard which denotes the fullest
Title:  tension of life's utmost energies.
Title:  
Title:  "Quitting the pump at last, with the rest of his band, the Lakeman
Title:  went forward all panting, and sat himself down on the windlass; his
Title:  face fiery red, his eyes bloodshot, and wiping the profuse sweat from
Title:  his brow.  Now what cozening fiend it was, gentlemen, that possessed
Title:  Radney to meddle with such a man in that corporeally exasperated
Title:  state, I know not; but so it happened.  Intolerably striding along
Title:  the deck, the mate commanded him to get a broom and sweep down the
Title:  planks, and also a shovel, and remove some offensive matters
Title:  consequent upon allowing a pig to run at large.
Title:  
Title:  "Now, gentlemen, sweeping a ship's deck at sea is a piece of
Title:  household work which in all times but raging gales is regularly
Title:  attended to every evening; it has been known to be done in the case
Title:  of ships actually foundering at the time.  Such, gentlemen, is the
Title:  inflexibility of sea-usages and the instinctive love of neatness in
Title:  seamen; some of whom would not willingly drown without first washing
Title:  their faces.  But in all vessels this broom business is the
Title:  prescriptive province of the boys, if boys there be aboard.  Besides,
Title:  it was the stronger men in the Town-Ho that had been divided into
Title:  gangs, taking turns at the pumps; and being the most athletic seaman
Title:  of them all, Steelkilt had been regularly assigned captain of one of
Title:  the gangs; consequently he should have been freed from any trivial
Title:  business not connected with truly nautical duties, such being the
Title:  case with his comrades.  I mention all these particulars so that you
Title:  may understand exactly how this affair stood between the two men.
Title:  
Title:  "But there was more than this: the order about the shovel was almost
Title:  as plainly meant to sting and insult Steelkilt, as though Radney had
Title:  spat in his face.  Any man who has gone sailor in a whale-ship will
Title:  understand this; and all this and doubtless much more, the Lakeman
Title:  fully comprehended when the mate uttered his command.  But as he sat
Title:  still for a moment, and as he steadfastly looked into the mate's
Title:  malignant eye and perceived the stacks of powder-casks heaped up in
Title:  him and the slow-match silently burning along towards them; as he
Title:  instinctively saw all this, that strange forbearance and
Title:  unwillingness to stir up the deeper passionateness in any already
Title:  ireful being--a repugnance most felt, when felt at all, by really
Title:  valiant men even when aggrieved--this nameless phantom feeling,
Title:  gentlemen, stole over Steelkilt.
Title:  
Title:  "Therefore, in his ordinary tone, only a little broken by the bodily
Title:  exhaustion he was temporarily in, he answered him saying that
Title:  sweeping the deck was not his business, and he would not do it.  And
Title:  then, without at all alluding to the shovel, he pointed to three
Title:  lads as the customary sweepers; who, not being billeted at the
Title:  pumps, had done little or nothing all day.  To this, Radney replied
Title:  with an oath, in a most domineering and outrageous manner
Title:  unconditionally reiterating his command; meanwhile advancing upon the
Title:  still seated Lakeman, with an uplifted cooper's club hammer which he
Title:  had snatched from a cask near by.
Title:  
Title:  "Heated and irritated as he was by his spasmodic toil at the pumps,
Title:  for all his first nameless feeling of forbearance the sweating
Title:  Steelkilt could but ill brook this bearing in the mate; but somehow
Title:  still smothering the conflagration within him, without speaking he
Title:  remained doggedly rooted to his seat, till at last the incensed
Title:  Radney shook the hammer within a few inches of his face, furiously
Title:  commanding him to do his bidding.
Title:  
Title:  "Steelkilt rose, and slowly retreating round the windlass, steadily
Title:  followed by the mate with his menacing hammer, deliberately repeated
Title:  his intention not to obey.  Seeing, however, that his forbearance had
Title:  not the slightest effect, by an awful and unspeakable intimation with
Title:  his twisted hand he warned off the foolish and infatuated man; but it
Title:  was to no purpose.  And in this way the two went once slowly round
Title:  the windlass; when, resolved at last no longer to retreat, bethinking
Title:  him that he had now forborne as much as comported with his humor, the
Title:  Lakeman paused on the hatches and thus spoke to the officer:
Title:  
Title:  "'Mr. Radney, I will not obey you.  Take that hammer away, or look to
Title:  yourself.'  But the predestinated mate coming still closer to him,
Title:  where the Lakeman stood fixed, now shook the heavy hammer within an
Title:  inch of his teeth; meanwhile repeating a string of insufferable
Title:  maledictions.  Retreating not the thousandth part of an inch;
Title:  stabbing him in the eye with the unflinching poniard of his glance,
Title:  Steelkilt, clenching his right hand behind him and creepingly drawing
Title:  it back, told his persecutor that if the hammer but grazed his cheek
Title:  he (Steelkilt) would murder him.  But, gentlemen, the fool had been
Title:  branded for the slaughter by the gods.  Immediately the hammer
Title:  touched the cheek; the next instant the lower jaw of the mate was
Title:  stove in his head; he fell on the hatch spouting blood like a whale.
Title:  
Title:  "Ere the cry could go aft Steelkilt was shaking one of the backstays
Title:  leading far aloft to where two of his comrades were standing their
Title:  mastheads.  They were both Canallers.
Title:  
Title:  "'Canallers!' cried Don Pedro.  'We have seen many whale-ships in our
Title:  harbours, but never heard of your Canallers.  Pardon: who and what are
Title:  they?'
Title:  
Title:  "'Canallers, Don, are the boatmen belonging to our grand Erie Canal.
Title:  You must have heard of it.'
Title:  
Title:  "'Nay, Senor; hereabouts in this dull, warm, most lazy, and
Title:  hereditary land, we know but little of your vigorous North.'
Title:  
Title:  "'Aye?  Well then, Don, refill my cup.  Your chicha's very fine; and
Title:  ere proceeding further I will tell ye what our Canallers are; for
Title:  such information may throw side-light upon my story.'
Title:  
Title:  "For three hundred and sixty miles, gentlemen, through the entire
Title:  breadth of the state of New York; through numerous populous cities
Title:  and most thriving villages; through long, dismal, uninhabited swamps,
Title:  and affluent, cultivated fields, unrivalled for fertility; by
Title:  billiard-room and bar-room; through the holy-of-holies of great
Title:  forests; on Roman arches over Indian rivers; through sun and shade;
Title:  by happy hearts or broken; through all the wide contrasting scenery
Title:  of those noble Mohawk counties; and especially, by rows of snow-white
Title:  chapels, whose spires stand almost like milestones, flows one
Title:  continual stream of Venetianly corrupt and often lawless life.
Title:  There's your true Ashantee, gentlemen; there howl your pagans; where
Title:  you ever find them, next door to you; under the long-flung shadow,
Title:  and the snug patronising lee of churches.  For by some curious
Title:  fatality, as it is often noted of your metropolitan freebooters that
Title:  they ever encamp around the halls of justice, so sinners, gentlemen,
Title:  most abound in holiest vicinities.
Title:  
Title:  "'Is that a friar passing?' said Don Pedro, looking downwards into
Title:  the crowded plazza, with humorous concern.
Title:  
Title:  "'Well for our northern friend, Dame Isabella's Inquisition wanes in
Title:  Lima,' laughed Don Sebastian.  'Proceed, Senor.'
Title:  
Title:  "'A moment!  Pardon!' cried another of the company.  'In the name of
Title:  all us Limeese, I but desire to express to you, sir sailor, that we
Title:  have by no means overlooked your delicacy in not substituting present
Title:  Lima for distant Venice in your corrupt comparison.  Oh! do not bow
Title:  and look surprised; you know the proverb all along this
Title:  coast--"Corrupt as Lima."  It but bears out your saying, too;
Title:  churches more plentiful than billiard-tables, and for ever open--and
Title:  "Corrupt as Lima."  So, too, Venice; I have been there; the holy city
Title:  of the blessed evangelist, St. Mark!--St. Dominic, purge it!  Your
Title:  cup!  Thanks: here I refill; now, you pour out again.'
Title:  
Title:  "Freely depicted in his own vocation, gentlemen, the Canaller would
Title:  make a fine dramatic hero, so abundantly and picturesquely wicked is
Title:  he.  Like Mark Antony, for days and days along his green-turfed,
Title:  flowery Nile, he indolently floats, openly toying with his
Title:  red-cheeked Cleopatra, ripening his apricot thigh upon the sunny
Title:  deck.  But ashore, all this effeminacy is dashed.  The brigandish
Title:  guise which the Canaller so proudly sports; his slouched and
Title:  gaily-ribboned hat betoken his grand features.  A terror to the
Title:  smiling innocence of the villages through which he floats; his swart
Title:  visage and bold swagger are not unshunned in cities.  Once a vagabond
Title:  on his own canal, I have received good turns from one of these
Title:  Canallers; I thank him heartily; would fain be not ungrateful; but it
Title:  is often one of the prime redeeming qualities of your man of
Title:  violence, that at times he has as stiff an arm to back a poor
Title:  stranger in a strait, as to plunder a wealthy one.  In sum,
Title:  gentlemen, what the wildness of this canal life is, is emphatically
Title:  evinced by this; that our wild whale-fishery contains so many of its
Title:  most finished graduates, and that scarce any race of mankind, except
Title:  Sydney men, are so much distrusted by our whaling captains.  Nor does
Title:  it at all diminish the curiousness of this matter, that to many
Title:  thousands of our rural boys and young men born along its line, the
Title:  probationary life of the Grand Canal furnishes the sole transition
Title:  between quietly reaping in a Christian corn-field, and recklessly
Title:  ploughing the waters of the most barbaric seas.
Title:  
Title:  "'I see!  I see!' impetuously exclaimed Don Pedro, spilling his
Title:  chicha upon his silvery ruffles.  'No need to travel!  The world's
Title:  one Lima.  I had thought, now, that at your temperate North the
Title:  generations were cold and holy as the hills.--But the story.'
Title:  
Title:  "I left off, gentlemen, where the Lakeman shook the backstay.
Title:  Hardly had he done so, when he was surrounded by the three junior
Title:  mates and the four harpooneers, who all crowded him to the deck.  But
Title:  sliding down the ropes like baleful comets, the two Canallers rushed
Title:  into the uproar, and sought to drag their man out of it towards the
Title:  forecastle.  Others of the sailors joined with them in this attempt,
Title:  and a twisted turmoil ensued; while standing out of harm's way, the
Title:  valiant captain danced up and down with a whale-pike, calling upon
Title:  his officers to manhandle that atrocious scoundrel, and smoke him
Title:  along to the quarter-deck.  At intervals, he ran close up to the
Title:  revolving border of the confusion, and prying into the heart of it
Title:  with his pike, sought to prick out the object of his resentment.  But
Title:  Steelkilt and his desperadoes were too much for them all; they
Title:  succeeded in gaining the forecastle deck, where, hastily slewing
Title:  about three or four large casks in a line with the windlass, these
Title:  sea-Parisians entrenched themselves behind the barricade.
Title:  
Title:  "'Come out of that, ye pirates!' roared the captain, now menacing
Title:  them with a pistol in each hand, just brought to him by the steward.
Title:  'Come out of that, ye cut-throats!'
Title:  
Title:  "Steelkilt leaped on the barricade, and striding up and down there,
Title:  defied the worst the pistols could do; but gave the captain to
Title:  understand distinctly, that his (Steelkilt's) death would be the
Title:  signal for a murderous mutiny on the part of all hands.  Fearing in
Title:  his heart lest this might prove but too true, the captain a little
Title:  desisted, but still commanded the insurgents instantly to return to
Title:  their duty.
Title:  
Title:  "'Will you promise not to touch us, if we do?' demanded their
Title:  ringleader.
Title:  
Title:  "'Turn to! turn to!--I make no promise;--to your duty!  Do you want
Title:  to sink the ship, by knocking off at a time like this?  Turn to!' and
Title:  he once more raised a pistol.
Title:  
Title:  "'Sink the ship?' cried Steelkilt.  'Aye, let her sink.  Not a man of
Title:  us turns to, unless you swear not to raise a rope-yarn against us.
Title:  What say ye, men?' turning to his comrades.  A fierce cheer was their
Title:  response.
Title:  
Title:  "The Lakeman now patrolled the barricade, all the while keeping his
Title:  eye on the Captain, and jerking out such sentences as these:--'It's
Title:  not our fault; we didn't want it; I told him to take his hammer away;
Title:  it was boy's business; he might have known me before this; I told him
Title:  not to prick the buffalo; I believe I have broken a finger here
Title:  against his cursed jaw; ain't those mincing knives down in the
Title:  forecastle there, men? look to those handspikes, my hearties.
Title:  Captain, by God, look to yourself; say the word; don't be a fool;
Title:  forget it all; we are ready to turn to; treat us decently, and we're
Title:  your men; but we won't be flogged.'
Title:  
Title:  "'Turn to!  I make no promises, turn to, I say!'
Title:  
Title:  "'Look ye, now,' cried the Lakeman, flinging out his arm towards him,
Title:  'there are a few of us here (and I am one of them) who have shipped
Title:  for the cruise, d'ye see; now as you well know, sir, we can claim our
Title:  discharge as soon as the anchor is down; so we don't want a row; it's
Title:  not our interest; we want to be peaceable; we are ready to work, but
Title:  we won't be flogged.'
Title:  
Title:  "'Turn to!' roared the Captain.
Title:  
Title:  "Steelkilt glanced round him a moment, and then said:--'I tell you
Title:  what it is now, Captain, rather than kill ye, and be hung for such a
Title:  shabby rascal, we won't lift a hand against ye unless ye attack us;
Title:  but till you say the word about not flogging us, we don't do a hand's
Title:  turn.'
Title:  
Title:  "'Down into the forecastle then, down with ye, I'll keep ye there
Title:  till ye're sick of it.  Down ye go.'
Title:  
Title:  "'Shall we?' cried the ringleader to his men.  Most of them were
Title:  against it; but at length, in obedience to Steelkilt, they preceded
Title:  him down into their dark den, growlingly disappearing, like bears
Title:  into a cave.
Title:  
Title:  "As the Lakeman's bare head was just level with the planks, the
Title:  Captain and his posse leaped the barricade, and rapidly drawing over
Title:  the slide of the scuttle, planted their group of hands upon it, and
Title:  loudly called for the steward to bring the heavy brass padlock
Title:  belonging to the companionway.
Title:  
Title:  Then opening the slide a little, the Captain whispered something down
Title:  the crack, closed it, and turned the key upon them--ten in
Title:  number--leaving on deck some twenty or more, who thus far had
Title:  remained neutral.
Title:  
Title:  "All night a wide-awake watch was kept by all the officers, forward
Title:  and aft, especially about the forecastle scuttle and fore hatchway;
Title:  at which last place it was feared the insurgents might emerge, after
Title:  breaking through the bulkhead below.  But the hours of darkness
Title:  passed in peace; the men who still remained at their duty toiling
Title:  hard at the pumps, whose clinking and clanking at intervals through
Title:  the dreary night dismally resounded through the ship.
Title:  
Title:  "At sunrise the Captain went forward, and knocking on the deck,
Title:  summoned the prisoners to work; but with a yell they refused.  Water
Title:  was then lowered down to them, and a couple of handfuls of biscuit
Title:  were tossed after it; when again turning the key upon them and
Title:  pocketing it, the Captain returned to the quarter-deck.  Twice every
Title:  day for three days this was repeated; but on the fourth morning a
Title:  confused wrangling, and then a scuffling was heard, as the customary
Title:  summons was delivered; and suddenly four men burst up from the
Title:  forecastle, saying they were ready to turn to.  The fetid closeness
Title:  of the air, and a famishing diet, united perhaps to some fears of
Title:  ultimate retribution, had constrained them to surrender at
Title:  discretion.  Emboldened by this, the Captain reiterated his demand to
Title:  the rest, but Steelkilt shouted up to him a terrific hint to stop his
Title:  babbling and betake himself where he belonged.  On the fifth morning
Title:  three others of the mutineers bolted up into the air from the
Title:  desperate arms below that sought to restrain them.  Only three were
Title:  left.
Title:  
Title:  "'Better turn to, now?' said the Captain with a heartless jeer.
Title:  
Title:  "'Shut us up again, will ye!' cried Steelkilt.
Title:  
Title:  "'Oh certainly,' the Captain, and the key clicked.
Title:  
Title:  "It was at this point, gentlemen, that enraged by the defection of
Title:  seven of his former associates, and stung by the mocking voice that
Title:  had last hailed him, and maddened by his long entombment in a place
Title:  as black as the bowels of despair; it was then that Steelkilt
Title:  proposed to the two Canallers, thus far apparently of one mind with
Title:  him, to burst out of their hole at the next summoning of the
Title:  garrison; and armed with their keen mincing knives (long, crescentic,
Title:  heavy implements with a handle at each end) run amuck from the
Title:  bowsprit to the taffrail; and if by any devilishness of desperation
Title:  possible, seize the ship.  For himself, he would do this, he said,
Title:  whether they joined him or not.  That was the last night he should
Title:  spend in that den.  But the scheme met with no opposition on the part
Title:  of the other two; they swore they were ready for that, or for any
Title:  other mad thing, for anything in short but a surrender.  And what was
Title:  more, they each insisted upon being the first man on deck, when the
Title:  time to make the rush should come.  But to this their leader as
Title:  fiercely objected, reserving that priority for himself; particularly
Title:  as his two comrades would not yield, the one to the other, in the
Title:  matter; and both of them could not be first, for the ladder would but
Title:  admit one man at a time.  And here, gentlemen, the foul play of these
Title:  miscreants must come out.
Title:  
Title:  "Upon hearing the frantic project of their leader, each in his own
Title:  separate soul had suddenly lighted, it would seem, upon the same
Title:  piece of treachery, namely: to be foremost in breaking out, in
Title:  order to be the first of the three, though the last of the ten, to
Title:  surrender; and thereby secure whatever small chance of pardon such
Title:  conduct might merit.  But when Steelkilt made known his determination
Title:  still to lead them to the last, they in some way, by some subtle
Title:  chemistry of villany, mixed their before secret treacheries together;
Title:  and when their leader fell into a doze, verbally opened their souls
Title:  to each other in three sentences; and bound the sleeper with cords,
Title:  and gagged him with cords; and shrieked out for the Captain at
Title:  midnight.
Title:  
Title:  "Thinking murder at hand, and smelling in the dark for the blood, he
Title:  and all his armed mates and harpooneers rushed for the forecastle.
Title:  In a few minutes the scuttle was opened, and, bound hand and foot,
Title:  the still struggling ringleader was shoved up into the air by his
Title:  perfidious allies, who at once claimed the honour of securing a man
Title:  who had been fully ripe for murder.  But all these were collared, and
Title:  dragged along the deck like dead cattle; and, side by side, were
Title:  seized up into the mizzen rigging, like three quarters of meat, and
Title:  there they hung till morning.  'Damn ye,' cried the Captain, pacing
Title:  to and fro before them, 'the vultures would not touch ye, ye
Title:  villains!'
Title:  
Title:  "At sunrise he summoned all hands; and separating those who had
Title:  rebelled from those who had taken no part in the mutiny, he told the
Title:  former that he had a good mind to flog them all round--thought, upon
Title:  the whole, he would do so--he ought to--justice demanded it; but for
Title:  the present, considering their timely surrender, he would let them go
Title:  with a reprimand, which he accordingly administered in the vernacular.
Title:  
Title:  "'But as for you, ye carrion rogues,' turning to the three men in the
Title:  rigging--'for you, I mean to mince ye up for the try-pots;' and,
Title:  seizing a rope, he applied it with all his might to the backs of the
Title:  two traitors, till they yelled no more, but lifelessly hung their
Title:  heads sideways, as the two crucified thieves are drawn.
Title:  
Title:  "'My wrist is sprained with ye!' he cried, at last; 'but there is
Title:  still rope enough left for you, my fine bantam, that wouldn't give
Title:  up.  Take that gag from his mouth, and let us hear what he can say
Title:  for himself.'
Title:  
Title:  "For a moment the exhausted mutineer made a tremulous motion of his
Title:  cramped jaws, and then painfully twisting round his head, said in a
Title:  sort of hiss, 'What I say is this--and mind it well--if you flog me,
Title:  I murder you!'
Title:  
Title:  "'Say ye so? then see how ye frighten me'--and the Captain drew off
Title:  with the rope to strike.
Title:  
Title:  "'Best not,' hissed the Lakeman.
Title:  
Title:  "'But I must,'--and the rope was once more drawn back for the stroke.
Title:  
Title:  "Steelkilt here hissed out something, inaudible to all but the
Title:  Captain; who, to the amazement of all hands, started back, paced the
Title:  deck rapidly two or three times, and then suddenly throwing down his
Title:  rope, said, 'I won't do it--let him go--cut him down: d'ye hear?'
Title:  
Title:  But as the junior mates were hurrying to execute the order, a pale
Title:  man, with a bandaged head, arrested them--Radney the chief mate.
Title:  Ever since the blow, he had lain in his berth; but that morning,
Title:  hearing the tumult on the deck, he had crept out, and thus far had
Title:  watched the whole scene.  Such was the state of his mouth, that he
Title:  could hardly speak; but mumbling something about his being willing
Title:  and able to do what the captain dared not attempt, he snatched the
Title:  rope and advanced to his pinioned foe.
Title:  
Title:  "'You are a coward!' hissed the Lakeman.
Title:  
Title:  "'So I am, but take that.'  The mate was in the very act of striking,
Title:  when another hiss stayed his uplifted arm.  He paused: and then
Title:  pausing no more, made good his word, spite of Steelkilt's threat,
Title:  whatever that might have been.  The three men were then cut down, all
Title:  hands were turned to, and, sullenly worked by the moody seamen, the
Title:  iron pumps clanged as before.
Title:  
Title:  "Just after dark that day, when one watch had retired below, a clamor
Title:  was heard in the forecastle; and the two trembling traitors running
Title:  up, besieged the cabin door, saying they durst not consort with the
Title:  crew.  Entreaties, cuffs, and kicks could not drive them back, so at
Title:  their own instance they were put down in the ship's run for
Title:  salvation.  Still, no sign of mutiny reappeared among the rest.  On
Title:  the contrary, it seemed, that mainly at Steelkilt's instigation, they
Title:  had resolved to maintain the strictest peacefulness, obey all orders
Title:  to the last, and, when the ship reached port, desert her in a body.
Title:  But in order to insure the speediest end to the voyage, they all
Title:  agreed to another thing--namely, not to sing out for whales, in case
Title:  any should be discovered.  For, spite of her leak, and spite of all her
Title:  other perils, the Town-Ho still maintained her mast-heads, and her
Title:  captain was just as willing to lower for a fish that moment, as on
Title:  the day his craft first struck the cruising ground; and Radney the mate
Title:  was quite as ready to change his berth for a boat, and with his
Title:  bandaged mouth seek to gag in death the vital jaw of the whale.
Title:  
Title:  "But though the Lakeman had induced the seamen to adopt this sort of
Title:  passiveness in their conduct, he kept his own counsel (at least till
Title:  all was over) concerning his own proper and private revenge upon the
Title:  man who had stung him in the ventricles of his heart.  He was in
Title:  Radney the chief mate's watch; and as if the infatuated man sought to
Title:  run more than half way to meet his doom, after the scene at the
Title:  rigging, he insisted, against the express counsel of the captain,
Title:  upon resuming the head of his watch at night.  Upon this, and one or
Title:  two other circumstances, Steelkilt systematically built the plan of
Title:  his revenge.
Title:  
Title:  "During the night, Radney had an unseamanlike way of sitting on the
Title:  bulwarks of the quarter-deck, and leaning his arm upon the gunwale of
Title:  the boat which was hoisted up there, a little above the ship's side.
Title:  In this attitude, it was well known, he sometimes dozed.  There was a
Title:  considerable vacancy between the boat and the ship, and down between
Title:  this was the sea.  Steelkilt calculated his time, and found that his
Title:  next trick at the helm would come round at two o'clock, in the
Title:  morning of the third day from that in which he had been betrayed.  At
Title:  his leisure, he employed the interval in braiding something very
Title:  carefully in his watches below.
Title:  
Title:  "'What are you making there?' said a shipmate.
Title:  
Title:  "'What do you think? what does it look like?'
Title:  
Title:  "'Like a lanyard for your bag; but it's an odd one, seems to me.'
Title:  
Title:  'Yes, rather oddish,' said the Lakeman, holding it at arm's length
Title:  before him; 'but I think it will answer.  Shipmate, I haven't enough
Title:  twine,--have you any?'
Title:  
Title:  "But there was none in the forecastle.
Title:  
Title:  "'Then I must get some from old Rad;' and he rose to go aft.
Title:  
Title:  "'You don't mean to go a begging to HIM!' said a sailor.
Title:  
Title:  "'Why not?  Do you think he won't do me a turn, when it's to help
Title:  himself in the end, shipmate?' and going to the mate, he looked at
Title:  him quietly, and asked him for some twine to mend his hammock.  It
Title:  was given him--neither twine nor lanyard were seen again; but the
Title:  next night an iron ball, closely netted, partly rolled from the
Title:  pocket of the Lakeman's monkey jacket, as he was tucking the coat
Title:  into his hammock for a pillow.  Twenty-four hours after, his trick at
Title:  the silent helm--nigh to the man who was apt to doze over the grave
Title:  always ready dug to the seaman's hand--that fatal hour was then to
Title:  come; and in the fore-ordaining soul of Steelkilt, the mate was
Title:  already stark and stretched as a corpse, with his forehead crushed
Title:  in.
Title:  
Title:  "But, gentlemen, a fool saved the would-be murderer from the bloody
Title:  deed he had planned.  Yet complete revenge he had, and without being
Title:  the avenger.  For by a mysterious fatality, Heaven itself seemed to
Title:  step in to take out of his hands into its own the damning thing he
Title:  would have done.
Title:  
Title:  "It was just between daybreak and sunrise of the morning of the
Title:  second day, when they were washing down the decks, that a stupid
Title:  Teneriffe man, drawing water in the main-chains, all at once shouted
Title:  out, 'There she rolls! there she rolls!'  Jesu, what a whale!  It was
Title:  Moby Dick.
Title:  
Title:  "'Moby Dick!' cried Don Sebastian; 'St. Dominic!  Sir sailor, but do
Title:  whales have christenings?  Whom call you Moby Dick?'
Title:  
Title:  "'A very white, and famous, and most deadly immortal monster,
Title:  Don;--but that would be too long a story.'
Title:  
Title:  "'How? how?' cried all the young Spaniards, crowding.
Title:  
Title:  "'Nay, Dons, Dons--nay, nay!  I cannot rehearse that now.  Let me get
Title:  more into the air, Sirs.'
Title:  
Title:  "'The chicha! the chicha!' cried Don Pedro; 'our vigorous friend looks
Title:  faint;--fill up his empty glass!'
Title:  
Title:  "No need, gentlemen; one moment, and I proceed.--Now, gentlemen, so
Title:  suddenly perceiving the snowy whale within fifty yards of the
Title:  ship--forgetful of the compact among the crew--in the excitement of
Title:  the moment, the Teneriffe man had instinctively and involuntarily
Title:  lifted his voice for the monster, though for some little time past it
Title:  had been plainly beheld from the three sullen mast-heads.  All was
Title:  now a phrensy.  'The White Whale--the White Whale!' was the cry from
Title:  captain, mates, and harpooneers, who, undeterred by fearful rumours,
Title:  were all anxious to capture so famous and precious a fish; while the
Title:  dogged crew eyed askance, and with curses, the appalling beauty of
Title:  the vast milky mass, that lit up by a horizontal spangling sun,
Title:  shifted and glistened like a living opal in the blue morning sea.
Title:  Gentlemen, a strange fatality pervades the whole career of these
Title:  events, as if verily mapped out before the world itself was charted.
Title:  The mutineer was the bowsman of the mate, and when fast to a fish, it
Title:  was his duty to sit next him, while Radney stood up with his lance in
Title:  the prow, and haul in or slacken the line, at the word of command.
Title:  Moreover, when the four boats were lowered, the mate's got the start;
Title:  and none howled more fiercely with delight than did Steelkilt, as he
Title:  strained at his oar.  After a stiff pull, their harpooneer got fast,
Title:  and, spear in hand, Radney sprang to the bow.  He was always a
Title:  furious man, it seems, in a boat.  And now his bandaged cry was, to
Title:  beach him on the whale's topmost back.  Nothing loath, his bowsman
Title:  hauled him up and up, through a blinding foam that blent two
Title:  whitenesses together; till of a sudden the boat struck as against a
Title:  sunken ledge, and keeling over, spilled out the standing mate.  That
Title:  instant, as he fell on the whale's slippery back, the boat righted,
Title:  and was dashed aside by the swell, while Radney was tossed over into
Title:  the sea, on the other flank of the whale.  He struck out through the
Title:  spray, and, for an instant, was dimly seen through that veil, wildly
Title:  seeking to remove himself from the eye of Moby Dick.  But the whale
Title:  rushed round in a sudden maelstrom; seized the swimmer between his
Title:  jaws; and rearing high up with him, plunged headlong again, and went
Title:  down.
Title:  
Title:  "Meantime, at the first tap of the boat's bottom, the Lakeman had
Title:  slackened the line, so as to drop astern from the whirlpool; calmly
Title:  looking on, he thought his own thoughts.  But a sudden, terrific,
Title:  downward jerking of the boat, quickly brought his knife to the line.
Title:  He cut it; and the whale was free.  But, at some distance, Moby Dick
Title:  rose again, with some tatters of Radney's red woollen shirt, caught
Title:  in the teeth that had destroyed him.  All four boats gave chase
Title:  again; but the whale eluded them, and finally wholly disappeared.
Title:  
Title:  "In good time, the Town-Ho reached her port--a savage, solitary
Title:  place--where no civilized creature resided.  There, headed by the
Title:  Lakeman, all but five or six of the foremastmen deliberately
Title:  deserted among the palms; eventually, as it turned out, seizing a
Title:  large double war-canoe of the savages, and setting sail for some
Title:  other harbor.
Title:  
Title:  "The ship's company being reduced to but a handful, the captain
Title:  called upon the Islanders to assist him in the laborious business of
Title:  heaving down the ship to stop the leak.  But to such unresting
Title:  vigilance over their dangerous allies was this small band of whites
Title:  necessitated, both by night and by day, and so extreme was the hard
Title:  work they underwent, that upon the vessel being ready again for sea,
Title:  they were in such a weakened condition that the captain durst not put
Title:  off with them in so heavy a vessel.  After taking counsel with his
Title:  officers, he anchored the ship as far off shore as possible; loaded
Title:  and ran out his two cannon from the bows; stacked his muskets on the
Title:  poop; and warning the Islanders not to approach the ship at their
Title:  peril, took one man with him, and setting the sail of his best
Title:  whale-boat, steered straight before the wind for Tahiti, five hundred
Title:  miles distant, to procure a reinforcement to his crew.
Title:  
Title:  "On the fourth day of the sail, a large canoe was descried, which
Title:  seemed to have touched at a low isle of corals.  He steered away from
Title:  it; but the savage craft bore down on him; and soon the voice of
Title:  Steelkilt hailed him to heave to, or he would run him under water.
Title:  The captain presented a pistol.  With one foot on each prow of the
Title:  yoked war-canoes, the Lakeman laughed him to scorn; assuring him that
Title:  if the pistol so much as clicked in the lock, he would bury him in
Title:  bubbles and foam.
Title:  
Title:  "'What do you want of me?' cried the captain.
Title:  
Title:  "'Where are you bound? and for what are you bound?' demanded
Title:  Steelkilt; 'no lies.'
Title:  
Title:  "'I am bound to Tahiti for more men.'
Title:  
Title:  "'Very good.  Let me board you a moment--I come in peace.'  With that
Title:  he leaped from the canoe, swam to the boat; and climbing the gunwale,
Title:  stood face to face with the captain.
Title:  
Title:  "'Cross your arms, sir; throw back your head.  Now, repeat after me.
Title:  As soon as Steelkilt leaves me, I swear to beach this boat on yonder
Title:  island, and remain there six days.  If I do not, may lightning strike
Title:  me!'
Title:  
Title:  "'A pretty scholar,' laughed the Lakeman.  'Adios, Senor!' and
Title:  leaping into the sea, he swam back to his comrades.
Title:  
Title:  "Watching the boat till it was fairly beached, and drawn up to the
Title:  roots of the cocoa-nut trees, Steelkilt made sail again, and in due
Title:  time arrived at Tahiti, his own place of destination.  There, luck
Title:  befriended him; two ships were about to sail for France, and were
Title:  providentially in want of precisely that number of men which the
Title:  sailor headed.  They embarked; and so for ever got the start of
Title:  their former captain, had he been at all minded to work them legal
Title:  retribution.
Title:  
Title:  "Some ten days after the French ships sailed, the whale-boat arrived,
Title:  and the captain was forced to enlist some of the more civilized
Title:  Tahitians, who had been somewhat used to the sea.  Chartering a small
Title:  native schooner, he returned with them to his vessel; and finding all
Title:  right there, again resumed his cruisings.
Title:  
Title:  "Where Steelkilt now is, gentlemen, none know; but upon the island of
Title:  Nantucket, the widow of Radney still turns to the sea which refuses
Title:  to give up its dead; still in dreams sees the awful white whale that
Title:  destroyed him.
Title:  
Title:  "'Are you through?' said Don Sebastian, quietly.
Title:  
Title:  "'I am, Don.'
Title:  
Title:  "'Then I entreat you, tell me if to the best of your own convictions,
Title:  this your story is in substance really true?  It is so passing
Title:  wonderful!  Did you get it from an unquestionable source?  Bear with
Title:  me if I seem to press.'
Title:  
Title:  "'Also bear with all of us, sir sailor; for we all join in Don
Title:  Sebastian's suit,' cried the company, with exceeding interest.
Title:  
Title:  "'Is there a copy of the Holy Evangelists in the Golden Inn,
Title:  gentlemen?'
Title:  
Title:  "'Nay,' said Don Sebastian; 'but I know a worthy priest near by, who
Title:  will quickly procure one for me.  I go for it; but are you well
Title:  advised? this may grow too serious.'
Title:  
Title:  "'Will you be so good as to bring the priest also, Don?'
Title:  
Title:  "'Though there are no Auto-da-Fe's in Lima now,' said one of the
Title:  company to another; 'I fear our sailor friend runs risk of the
Title:  archiepiscopacy.  Let us withdraw more out of the moonlight.  I see
Title:  no need of this.'
Title:  
Title:  "'Excuse me for running after you, Don Sebastian; but may I also beg
Title:  that you will be particular in procuring the largest sized
Title:  Evangelists you can.'
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  'This is the priest, he brings you the Evangelists,' said Don
Title:  Sebastian, gravely, returning with a tall and solemn figure.
Title:  
Title:  "'Let me remove my hat.  Now, venerable priest, further into the
Title:  light, and hold the Holy Book before me that I may touch it.
Title:  
Title:  "'So help me Heaven, and on my honour the story I have told ye,
Title:  gentlemen, is in substance and its great items, true.  I know it to
Title:  be true; it happened on this ball; I trod the ship; I knew the crew;
Title:  I have seen and talked with Steelkilt since the death of Radney.'"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 55
Title:  
Title:  Of the Monstrous Pictures of Whales.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  I shall ere long paint to you as well as one can without canvas,
Title:  something like the true form of the whale as he actually appears to
Title:  the eye of the whaleman when in his own absolute body the whale is
Title:  moored alongside the whale-ship so that he can be fairly stepped upon
Title:  there.  It may be worth while, therefore, previously to advert to
Title:  those curious imaginary portraits of him which even down to the
Title:  present day confidently challenge the faith of the landsman.  It is
Title:  time to set the world right in this matter, by proving such pictures
Title:  of the whale all wrong.
Title:  
Title:  It may be that the primal source of all those pictorial delusions
Title:  will be found among the oldest Hindoo, Egyptian, and Grecian
Title:  sculptures.  For ever since those inventive but unscrupulous times
Title:  when on the marble panellings of temples, the pedestals of statues,
Title:  and on shields, medallions, cups, and coins, the dolphin was drawn in
Title:  scales of chain-armor like Saladin's, and a helmeted head like St.
Title:  George's; ever since then has something of the same sort of license
Title:  prevailed, not only in most popular pictures of the whale, but in
Title:  many scientific presentations of him.
Title:  
Title:  Now, by all odds, the most ancient extant portrait anyways purporting
Title:  to be the whale's, is to be found in the famous cavern-pagoda of
Title:  Elephanta, in India.  The Brahmins maintain that in the almost
Title:  endless sculptures of that immemorial pagoda, all the trades and
Title:  pursuits, every conceivable avocation of man, were prefigured ages
Title:  before any of them actually came into being.  No wonder then, that in
Title:  some sort our noble profession of whaling should have been there
Title:  shadowed forth.  The Hindoo whale referred to, occurs in a separate
Title:  department of the wall, depicting the incarnation of Vishnu in the
Title:  form of leviathan, learnedly known as the Matse Avatar.  But though
Title:  this sculpture is half man and half whale, so as only to give the
Title:  tail of the latter, yet that small section of him is all wrong.  It
Title:  looks more like the tapering tail of an anaconda, than the broad palms
Title:  of the true whale's majestic flukes.
Title:  
Title:  But go to the old Galleries, and look now at a great Christian
Title:  painter's portrait of this fish; for he succeeds no better than the
Title:  antediluvian Hindoo.  It is Guido's picture of Perseus rescuing
Title:  Andromeda from the sea-monster or whale.  Where did Guido get the
Title:  model of such a strange creature as that?  Nor does Hogarth, in
Title:  painting the same scene in his own "Perseus Descending," make out one
Title:  whit better.  The huge corpulence of that Hogarthian monster
Title:  undulates on the surface, scarcely drawing one inch of water.  It has
Title:  a sort of howdah on its back, and its distended tusked mouth into
Title:  which the billows are rolling, might be taken for the Traitors' Gate
Title:  leading from the Thames by water into the Tower.  Then, there are the
Title:  Prodromus whales of old Scotch Sibbald, and Jonah's whale, as
Title:  depicted in the prints of old Bibles and the cuts of old primers.
Title:  What shall be said of these?  As for the book-binder's whale winding
Title:  like a vine-stalk round the stock of a descending anchor--as stamped
Title:  and gilded on the backs and title-pages of many books both old and
Title:  new--that is a very picturesque but purely fabulous creature,
Title:  imitated, I take it, from the like figures on antique vases.  Though
Title:  universally denominated a dolphin, I nevertheless call this
Title:  book-binder's fish an attempt at a whale; because it was so intended
Title:  when the device was first introduced.  It was introduced by an old
Title:  Italian publisher somewhere about the 15th century, during the
Title:  Revival of Learning; and in those days, and even down to a
Title:  comparatively late period, dolphins were popularly supposed to be a
Title:  species of the Leviathan.
Title:  
Title:  In the vignettes and other embellishments of some ancient books you
Title:  will at times meet with very curious touches at the whale, where all
Title:  manner of spouts, jets d'eau, hot springs and cold, Saratoga and
Title:  Baden-Baden, come bubbling up from his unexhausted brain.  In the
Title:  title-page of the original edition of the "Advancement of Learning"
Title:  you will find some curious whales.
Title:  
Title:  But quitting all these unprofessional attempts, let us glance at
Title:  those pictures of leviathan purporting to be sober, scientific
Title:  delineations, by those who know.  In old Harris's collection of
Title:  voyages there are some plates of whales extracted from a Dutch book
Title:  of voyages, A.D. 1671, entitled "A Whaling Voyage to Spitzbergen in
Title:  the ship Jonas in the Whale, Peter Peterson of Friesland, master."
Title:  In one of those plates the whales, like great rafts of logs, are
Title:  represented lying among ice-isles, with white bears running over
Title:  their living backs.  In another plate, the prodigious blunder is made
