Title:  of representing the whale with perpendicular flukes.
Title:  
Title:  Then again, there is an imposing quarto, written by one Captain
Title:  Colnett, a Post Captain in the English navy, entitled "A Voyage round
Title:  Cape Horn into the South Seas, for the purpose of extending the
Title:  Spermaceti Whale Fisheries."  In this book is an outline purporting
Title:  to be a "Picture of a Physeter or Spermaceti whale, drawn by scale
Title:  from one killed on the coast of Mexico, August, 1793, and hoisted on
Title:  deck."  I doubt not the captain had this veracious picture taken for
Title:  the benefit of his marines.  To mention but one thing about it, let
Title:  me say that it has an eye which applied, according to the
Title:  accompanying scale, to a full grown sperm whale, would make the eye
Title:  of that whale a bow-window some five feet long.  Ah, my gallant
Title:  captain, why did ye not give us Jonah looking out of that eye!
Title:  
Title:  Nor are the most conscientious compilations of Natural History for
Title:  the benefit of the young and tender, free from the same heinousness
Title:  of mistake.  Look at that popular work "Goldsmith's Animated Nature."
Title:  In the abridged London edition of 1807, there are plates of an
Title:  alleged "whale" and a "narwhale."  I do not wish to seem inelegant,
Title:  but this unsightly whale looks much like an amputated sow; and, as
Title:  for the narwhale, one glimpse at it is enough to amaze one, that in
Title:  this nineteenth century such a hippogriff could be palmed for genuine
Title:  upon any intelligent public of schoolboys.
Title:  
Title:  Then, again, in 1825, Bernard Germain, Count de Lacepede, a great
Title:  naturalist, published a scientific systemized whale book, wherein are
Title:  several pictures of the different species of the Leviathan.  All
Title:  these are not only incorrect, but the picture of the Mysticetus or
Title:  Greenland whale (that is to say, the Right whale), even Scoresby, a
Title:  long experienced man as touching that species, declares not to have
Title:  its counterpart in nature.
Title:  
Title:  But the placing of the cap-sheaf to all this blundering business was
Title:  reserved for the scientific Frederick Cuvier, brother to the famous
Title:  Baron.  In 1836, he published a Natural History of Whales, in which
Title:  he gives what he calls a picture of the Sperm Whale.  Before showing
Title:  that picture to any Nantucketer, you had best provide for your
Title:  summary retreat from Nantucket.  In a word, Frederick Cuvier's Sperm
Title:  Whale is not a Sperm Whale, but a squash.  Of course, he never had
Title:  the benefit of a whaling voyage (such men seldom have), but whence he
Title:  derived that picture, who can tell?  Perhaps he got it as his
Title:  scientific predecessor in the same field, Desmarest, got one of his
Title:  authentic abortions; that is, from a Chinese drawing.  And what sort
Title:  of lively lads with the pencil those Chinese are, many queer cups and
Title:  saucers inform us.
Title:  
Title:  As for the sign-painters' whales seen in the streets hanging over the
Title:  shops of oil-dealers, what shall be said of them?  They are generally
Title:  Richard III. whales, with dromedary humps, and very savage;
Title:  breakfasting on three or four sailor tarts, that is whaleboats full
Title:  of mariners: their deformities floundering in seas of blood and blue
Title:  paint.
Title:  
Title:  But these manifold mistakes in depicting the whale are not so very
Title:  surprising after all.  Consider!  Most of the scientific drawings
Title:  have been taken from the stranded fish; and these are about as
Title:  correct as a drawing of a wrecked ship, with broken back, would
Title:  correctly represent the noble animal itself in all its undashed pride
Title:  of hull and spars.  Though elephants have stood for their
Title:  full-lengths, the living Leviathan has never yet fairly floated
Title:  himself for his portrait.  The living whale, in his full majesty and
Title:  significance, is only to be seen at sea in unfathomable waters; and
Title:  afloat the vast bulk of him is out of sight, like a launched
Title:  line-of-battle ship; and out of that element it is a thing eternally
Title:  impossible for mortal man to hoist him bodily into the air, so as to
Title:  preserve all his mighty swells and undulations.  And, not to speak of
Title:  the highly presumable difference of contour between a young sucking
Title:  whale and a full-grown Platonian Leviathan; yet, even in the case of
Title:  one of those young sucking whales hoisted to a ship's deck, such is
Title:  then the outlandish, eel-like, limbered, varying shape of him, that
Title:  his precise expression the devil himself could not catch.
Title:  
Title:  But it may be fancied, that from the naked skeleton of the stranded
Title:  whale, accurate hints may be derived touching his true form.  Not at
Title:  all.  For it is one of the more curious things about this Leviathan,
Title:  that his skeleton gives very little idea of his general shape.
Title:  Though Jeremy Bentham's skeleton, which hangs for candelabra in the
Title:  library of one of his executors, correctly conveys the idea of a
Title:  burly-browed utilitarian old gentleman, with all Jeremy's other
Title:  leading personal characteristics; yet nothing of this kind could be
Title:  inferred from any leviathan's articulated bones.  In fact, as the
Title:  great Hunter says, the mere skeleton of the whale bears the same
Title:  relation to the fully invested and padded animal as the insect does
Title:  to the chrysalis that so roundingly envelopes it.  This peculiarity
Title:  is strikingly evinced in the head, as in some part of this book will
Title:  be incidentally shown.  It is also very curiously displayed in the
Title:  side fin, the bones of which almost exactly answer to the bones of the
Title:  human hand, minus only the thumb.  This fin has four regular
Title:  bone-fingers, the index, middle, ring, and little finger.  But all
Title:  these are permanently lodged in their fleshy covering, as the human
Title:  fingers in an artificial covering.  "However recklessly the whale may
Title:  sometimes serve us," said humorous Stubb one day, "he can never be
Title:  truly said to handle us without mittens."
Title:  
Title:  For all these reasons, then, any way you may look at it, you must
Title:  needs conclude that the great Leviathan is that one creature in the
Title:  world which must remain unpainted to the last.  True, one portrait
Title:  may hit the mark much nearer than another, but none can hit it with
Title:  any very considerable degree of exactness.  So there is no earthly
Title:  way of finding out precisely what the whale really looks like.  And
Title:  the only mode in which you can derive even a tolerable idea of his
Title:  living contour, is by going a whaling yourself; but by so doing, you
Title:  run no small risk of being eternally stove and sunk by him.
Title:  Wherefore, it seems to me you had best not be too fastidious in your
Title:  curiosity touching this Leviathan.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 56
Title:  
Title:  Of the Less Erroneous Pictures of Whales, and the True Pictures of
Title:  Whaling Scenes.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  In connexion with the monstrous pictures of whales, I am strongly
Title:  tempted here to enter upon those still more monstrous stories of them
Title:  which are to be found in certain books, both ancient and modern,
Title:  especially in Pliny, Purchas, Hackluyt, Harris, Cuvier, etc.  But I
Title:  pass that matter by.
Title:  
Title:  I know of only four published outlines of the great Sperm Whale;
Title:  Colnett's, Huggins's, Frederick Cuvier's, and Beale's.  In the
Title:  previous chapter Colnett and Cuvier have been referred to.  Huggins's
Title:  is far better than theirs; but, by great odds, Beale's is the best.
Title:  All Beale's drawings of this whale are good, excepting the middle
Title:  figure in the picture of three whales in various attitudes, capping
Title:  his second chapter.  His frontispiece, boats attacking Sperm Whales,
Title:  though no doubt calculated to excite the civil scepticism of some
Title:  parlor men, is admirably correct and life-like in its general effect.
Title:  Some of the Sperm Whale drawings in J.  Ross Browne are pretty
Title:  correct in contour; but they are wretchedly engraved.  That is not
Title:  his fault though.
Title:  
Title:  Of the Right Whale, the best outline pictures are in Scoresby; but
Title:  they are drawn on too small a scale to convey a desirable impression.
Title:  He has but one picture of whaling scenes, and this is a sad
Title:  deficiency, because it is by such pictures only, when at all well
Title:  done, that you can derive anything like a truthful idea of the living
Title:  whale as seen by his living hunters.
Title:  
Title:  But, taken for all in all, by far the finest, though in some details
Title:  not the most correct, presentations of whales and whaling scenes to
Title:  be anywhere found, are two large French engravings, well executed,
Title:  and taken from paintings by one Garnery.  Respectively, they
Title:  represent attacks on the Sperm and Right Whale.  In the first
Title:  engraving a noble Sperm Whale is depicted in full majesty of might,
Title:  just risen beneath the boat from the profundities of the ocean, and
Title:  bearing high in the air upon his back the terrific wreck of the
Title:  stoven planks.  The prow of the boat is partially unbroken, and is
Title:  drawn just balancing upon the monster's spine; and standing in that
Title:  prow, for that one single incomputable flash of time, you behold an
Title:  oarsman, half shrouded by the incensed boiling spout of the whale,
Title:  and in the act of leaping, as if from a precipice.  The action of the
Title:  whole thing is wonderfully good and true.  The half-emptied line-tub
Title:  floats on the whitened sea; the wooden poles of the spilled harpoons
Title:  obliquely bob in it; the heads of the swimming crew are scattered
Title:  about the whale in contrasting expressions of affright; while in the
Title:  black stormy distance the ship is bearing down upon the scene.
Title:  Serious fault might be found with the anatomical details of this
Title:  whale, but let that pass; since, for the life of me, I could not draw
Title:  so good a one.
Title:  
Title:  In the second engraving, the boat is in the act of drawing alongside
Title:  the barnacled flank of a large running Right Whale, that rolls his
Title:  black weedy bulk in the sea like some mossy rock-slide from the
Title:  Patagonian cliffs.  His jets are erect, full, and black like soot; so
Title:  that from so abounding a smoke in the chimney, you would think there
Title:  must be a brave supper cooking in the great bowels below.  Sea fowls
Title:  are pecking at the small crabs, shell-fish, and other sea candies and
Title:  maccaroni, which the Right Whale sometimes carries on his pestilent
Title:  back.  And all the while the thick-lipped leviathan is rushing
Title:  through the deep, leaving tons of tumultuous white curds in his wake,
Title:  and causing the slight boat to rock in the swells like a skiff caught
Title:  nigh the paddle-wheels of an ocean steamer.  Thus, the foreground is
Title:  all raging commotion; but behind, in admirable artistic contrast, is
Title:  the glassy level of a sea becalmed, the drooping unstarched sails of
Title:  the powerless ship, and the inert mass of a dead whale, a conquered
Title:  fortress, with the flag of capture lazily hanging from the whale-pole
Title:  inserted into his spout-hole.
Title:  
Title:  Who Garnery the painter is, or was, I know not.  But my life for it
Title:  he was either practically conversant with his subject, or else
Title:  marvellously tutored by some experienced whaleman.  The French are
Title:  the lads for painting action.  Go and gaze upon all the paintings of
Title:  Europe, and where will you find such a gallery of living and
Title:  breathing commotion on canvas, as in that triumphal hall at
Title:  Versailles; where the beholder fights his way, pell-mell, through the
Title:  consecutive great battles of France; where every sword seems a flash
Title:  of the Northern Lights, and the successive armed kings and Emperors
Title:  dash by, like a charge of crowned centaurs?  Not wholly unworthy of a
Title:  place in that gallery, are these sea battle-pieces of Garnery.
Title:  
Title:  The natural aptitude of the French for seizing the picturesqueness of
Title:  things seems to be peculiarly evinced in what paintings and
Title:  engravings they have of their whaling scenes.  With not one tenth of
Title:  England's experience in the fishery, and not the thousandth part of
Title:  that of the Americans, they have nevertheless furnished both nations
Title:  with the only finished sketches at all capable of conveying the real
Title:  spirit of the whale hunt.  For the most part, the English and
Title:  American whale draughtsmen seem entirely content with presenting the
Title:  mechanical outline of things, such as the vacant profile of the
Title:  whale; which, so far as picturesqueness of effect is concerned, is
Title:  about tantamount to sketching the profile of a pyramid.  Even
Title:  Scoresby, the justly renowned Right whaleman, after giving us a stiff
Title:  full length of the Greenland whale, and three or four delicate
Title:  miniatures of narwhales and porpoises, treats us to a series of
Title:  classical engravings of boat hooks, chopping knives, and grapnels;
Title:  and with the microscopic diligence of a Leuwenhoeck submits to the
Title:  inspection of a shivering world ninety-six fac-similes of magnified
Title:  Arctic snow crystals.  I mean no disparagement to the excellent
Title:  voyager (I honour him for a veteran), but in so important a matter it
Title:  was certainly an oversight not to have procured for every crystal a
Title:  sworn affidavit taken before a Greenland Justice of the Peace.
Title:  
Title:  In addition to those fine engravings from Garnery, there are two
Title:  other French engravings worthy of note, by some one who subscribes
Title:  himself "H.  Durand."  One of them, though not precisely adapted to
Title:  our present purpose, nevertheless deserves mention on other accounts.
Title:  It is a quiet noon-scene among the isles of the Pacific; a French
Title:  whaler anchored, inshore, in a calm, and lazily taking water on
Title:  board; the loosened sails of the ship, and the long leaves of the
Title:  palms in the background, both drooping together in the breezeless
Title:  air.  The effect is very fine, when considered with reference to its
Title:  presenting the hardy fishermen under one of their few aspects of
Title:  oriental repose.  The other engraving is quite a different affair:
Title:  the ship hove-to upon the open sea, and in the very heart of the
Title:  Leviathanic life, with a Right Whale alongside; the vessel (in the
Title:  act of cutting-in) hove over to the monster as if to a quay; and a
Title:  boat, hurriedly pushing off from this scene of activity, is about
Title:  giving chase to whales in the distance.  The harpoons and lances lie
Title:  levelled for use; three oarsmen are just setting the mast in its
Title:  hole; while from a sudden roll of the sea, the little craft stands
Title:  half-erect out of the water, like a rearing horse.  From the ship,
Title:  the smoke of the torments of the boiling whale is going up like the
Title:  smoke over a village of smithies; and to windward, a black cloud,
Title:  rising up with earnest of squalls and rains, seems to quicken the
Title:  activity of the excited seamen.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 57
Title:  
Title:  Of Whales in Paint; in Teeth; in Wood; in Sheet-Iron; in Stone; in
Title:  Mountains; in Stars.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  On Tower-hill, as you go down to the London docks, you may have seen
Title:  a crippled beggar (or KEDGER, as the sailors say) holding a painted
Title:  board before him, representing the tragic scene in which he lost his
Title:  leg.  There are three whales and three boats; and one of the boats
Title:  (presumed to contain the missing leg in all its original integrity)
Title:  is being crunched by the jaws of the foremost whale.  Any time these
Title:  ten years, they tell me, has that man held up that picture, and
Title:  exhibited that stump to an incredulous world.  But the time of his
Title:  justification has now come.  His three whales are as good whales as
Title:  were ever published in Wapping, at any rate; and his stump as
Title:  unquestionable a stump as any you will find in the western clearings.
Title:  But, though for ever mounted on that stump, never a stump-speech
Title:  does the poor whaleman make; but, with downcast eyes, stands ruefully
Title:  contemplating his own amputation.
Title:  
Title:  Throughout the Pacific, and also in Nantucket, and New Bedford, and
Title:  Sag Harbor, you will come across lively sketches of whales and
Title:  whaling-scenes, graven by the fishermen themselves on Sperm
Title:  Whale-teeth, or ladies' busks wrought out of the Right Whale-bone,
Title:  and other like skrimshander articles, as the whalemen call the
Title:  numerous little ingenious contrivances they elaborately carve out of
Title:  the rough material, in their hours of ocean leisure.  Some of them
Title:  have little boxes of dentistical-looking implements, specially
Title:  intended for the skrimshandering business.  But, in general, they
Title:  toil with their jack-knives alone; and, with that almost omnipotent
Title:  tool of the sailor, they will turn you out anything you please, in
Title:  the way of a mariner's fancy.
Title:  
Title:  Long exile from Christendom and civilization inevitably restores a
Title:  man to that condition in which God placed him, i.e. what is called
Title:  savagery.  Your true whale-hunter is as much a savage as an Iroquois.
Title:  I myself am a savage, owning no allegiance but to the King of the
Title:  Cannibals; and ready at any moment to rebel against him.
Title:  
Title:  Now, one of the peculiar characteristics of the savage in his
Title:  domestic hours, is his wonderful patience of industry.  An ancient
Title:  Hawaiian war-club or spear-paddle, in its full multiplicity and
Title:  elaboration of carving, is as great a trophy of human perseverance as
Title:  a Latin lexicon.  For, with but a bit of broken sea-shell or a
Title:  shark's tooth, that miraculous intricacy of wooden net-work has been
Title:  achieved; and it has cost steady years of steady application.
Title:  
Title:  As with the Hawaiian savage, so with the white sailor-savage.  With
Title:  the same marvellous patience, and with the same single shark's tooth,
Title:  of his one poor jack-knife, he will carve you a bit of bone
Title:  sculpture, not quite as workmanlike, but as close packed in its
Title:  maziness of design, as the Greek savage, Achilles's shield; and full
Title:  of barbaric spirit and suggestiveness, as the prints of that fine old
Title:  Dutch savage, Albert Durer.
Title:  
Title:  Wooden whales, or whales cut in profile out of the small dark slabs
Title:  of the noble South Sea war-wood, are frequently met with in the
Title:  forecastles of American whalers.  Some of them are done with much
Title:  accuracy.
Title:  
Title:  At some old gable-roofed country houses you will see brass whales
Title:  hung by the tail for knockers to the road-side door.  When the porter
Title:  is sleepy, the anvil-headed whale would be best.  But these knocking
Title:  whales are seldom remarkable as faithful essays.  On the spires of
Title:  some old-fashioned churches you will see sheet-iron whales placed
Title:  there for weather-cocks; but they are so elevated, and besides that
Title:  are to all intents and purposes so labelled with "HANDS OFF!" you
Title:  cannot examine them closely enough to decide upon their merit.
Title:  
Title:  In bony, ribby regions of the earth, where at the base of high broken
Title:  cliffs masses of rock lie strewn in fantastic groupings upon the
Title:  plain, you will often discover images as of the petrified forms of
Title:  the Leviathan partly merged in grass, which of a windy day breaks
Title:  against them in a surf of green surges.
Title:  
Title:  Then, again, in mountainous countries where the traveller is
Title:  continually girdled by amphitheatrical heights; here and there from
Title:  some lucky point of view you will catch passing glimpses of the
Title:  profiles of whales defined along the undulating ridges.  But you must
Title:  be a thorough whaleman, to see these sights; and not only that, but
Title:  if you wish to return to such a sight again, you must be sure and
Title:  take the exact intersecting latitude and longitude of your first
Title:  stand-point, else so chance-like are such observations of the hills,
Title:  that your precise, previous stand-point would require a laborious
Title:  re-discovery; like the Soloma Islands, which still remain incognita,
Title:  though once high-ruffed Mendanna trod them and old Figuera
Title:  chronicled them.
Title:  
Title:  Nor when expandingly lifted by your subject, can you fail to trace
Title:  out great whales in the starry heavens, and boats in pursuit of them;
Title:  as when long filled with thoughts of war the Eastern nations saw
Title:  armies locked in battle among the clouds.  Thus at the North have I
Title:  chased Leviathan round and round the Pole with the revolutions of the
Title:  bright points that first defined him to me.  And beneath the
Title:  effulgent Antarctic skies I have boarded the Argo-Navis, and joined
Title:  the chase against the starry Cetus far beyond the utmost stretch of
Title:  Hydrus and the Flying Fish.
Title:  
Title:  With a frigate's anchors for my bridle-bitts and fasces of harpoons
Title:  for spurs, would I could mount that whale and leap the topmost skies,
Title:  to see whether the fabled heavens with all their countless tents
Title:  really lie encamped beyond my mortal sight!
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 58
Title:  
Title:  Brit.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Steering north-eastward from the Crozetts, we fell in with vast
Title:  meadows of brit, the minute, yellow substance, upon which the Right
Title:  Whale largely feeds.  For leagues and leagues it undulated round us,
Title:  so that we seemed to be sailing through boundless fields of ripe and
Title:  golden wheat.
Title:  
Title:  On the second day, numbers of Right Whales were seen, who, secure
Title:  from the attack of a Sperm Whaler like the Pequod, with open jaws
Title:  sluggishly swam through the brit, which, adhering to the fringing
Title:  fibres of that wondrous Venetian blind in their mouths, was in that
Title:  manner separated from the water that escaped at the lip.
Title:  
Title:  As morning mowers, who side by side slowly and seethingly advance
Title:  their scythes through the long wet grass of marshy meads; even so
Title:  these monsters swam, making a strange, grassy, cutting sound; and
Title:  leaving behind them endless swaths of blue upon the yellow sea.*
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *That part of the sea known among whalemen as the "Brazil Banks" does
Title:  not bear that name as the Banks of Newfoundland do, because of there
Title:  being shallows and soundings there, but because of this remarkable
Title:  meadow-like appearance, caused by the vast drifts of brit continually
Title:  floating in those latitudes, where the Right Whale is often chased.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  But it was only the sound they made as they parted the brit which at
Title:  all reminded one of mowers.  Seen from the mast-heads, especially
Title:  when they paused and were stationary for a while, their vast black
Title:  forms looked more like lifeless masses of rock than anything else.
Title:  And as in the great hunting countries of India, the stranger at a
Title:  distance will sometimes pass on the plains recumbent elephants
Title:  without knowing them to be such, taking them for bare, blackened
Title:  elevations of the soil; even so, often, with him, who for the first
Title:  time beholds this species of the leviathans of the sea.  And even
Title:  when recognised at last, their immense magnitude renders it very
Title:  hard really to believe that such bulky masses of overgrowth can
Title:  possibly be instinct, in all parts, with the same sort of life that
Title:  lives in a dog or a horse.
Title:  
Title:  Indeed, in other respects, you can hardly regard any creatures of the
Title:  deep with the same feelings that you do those of the shore.  For
Title:  though some old naturalists have maintained that all creatures of the
Title:  land are of their kind in the sea; and though taking a broad general
Title:  view of the thing, this may very well be; yet coming to specialties,
Title:  where, for example, does the ocean furnish any fish that in
Title:  disposition answers to the sagacious kindness of the dog?  The
Title:  accursed shark alone can in any generic respect be said to bear
Title:  comparative analogy to him.
Title:  
Title:  But though, to landsmen in general, the native inhabitants of the
Title:  seas have ever been regarded with emotions unspeakably unsocial and
Title:  repelling; though we know the sea to be an everlasting terra
Title:  incognita, so that Columbus sailed over numberless unknown worlds to
Title:  discover his one superficial western one; though, by vast odds, the
Title:  most terrific of all mortal disasters have immemorially and
Title:  indiscriminately befallen tens and hundreds of thousands of those who
Title:  have gone upon the waters; though but a moment's consideration will
Title:  teach, that however baby man may brag of his science and skill, and
Title:  however much, in a flattering future, that science and skill may
Title:  augment; yet for ever and for ever, to the crack of doom, the sea
Title:  will insult and murder him, and pulverize the stateliest, stiffest
Title:  frigate he can make; nevertheless, by the continual repetition of
Title:  these very impressions, man has lost that sense of the full awfulness
Title:  of the sea which aboriginally belongs to it.
Title:  
Title:  The first boat we read of, floated on an ocean, that with Portuguese
Title:  vengeance had whelmed a whole world without leaving so much as a
Title:  widow.  That same ocean rolls now; that same ocean destroyed the
Title:  wrecked ships of last year.  Yea, foolish mortals, Noah's flood is
Title:  not yet subsided; two thirds of the fair world it yet covers.
Title:  
Title:  Wherein differ the sea and the land, that a miracle upon one is not a
Title:  miracle upon the other?  Preternatural terrors rested upon the
Title:  Hebrews, when under the feet of Korah and his company the live ground
Title:  opened and swallowed them up for ever; yet not a modern sun ever
Title:  sets, but in precisely the same manner the live sea swallows up ships
Title:  and crews.
Title:  
Title:  But not only is the sea such a foe to man who is an alien to it, but
Title:  it is also a fiend to its own off-spring; worse than the Persian host
Title:  who murdered his own guests; sparing not the creatures which itself
Title:  hath spawned.  Like a savage tigress that tossing in the jungle
Title:  overlays her own cubs, so the sea dashes even the mightiest whales
Title:  against the rocks, and leaves them there side by side with the split
Title:  wrecks of ships.  No mercy, no power but its own controls it.
Title:  Panting and snorting like a mad battle steed that has lost its rider,
Title:  the masterless ocean overruns the globe.
Title:  
Title:  Consider the subtleness of the sea; how its most dreaded creatures
Title:  glide under water, unapparent for the most part, and treacherously
Title:  hidden beneath the loveliest tints of azure.  Consider also the
Title:  devilish brilliance and beauty of many of its most remorseless
Title:  tribes, as the dainty embellished shape of many species of sharks.
Title:  Consider, once more, the universal cannibalism of the sea; all whose
Title:  creatures prey upon each other, carrying on eternal war since the
Title:  world began.
Title:  
Title:  Consider all this; and then turn to this green, gentle, and most
Title:  docile earth; consider them both, the sea and the land; and do you
Title:  not find a strange analogy to something in yourself?  For as this
Title:  appalling ocean surrounds the verdant land, so in the soul of man
Title:  there lies one insular Tahiti, full of peace and joy, but encompassed
Title:  by all the horrors of the half known life.  God keep thee!  Push not
Title:  off from that isle, thou canst never return!
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 59
Title:  
Title:  Squid.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Slowly wading through the meadows of brit, the Pequod still held on
Title:  her way north-eastward towards the island of Java; a gentle air
Title:  impelling her keel, so that in the surrounding serenity her three
Title:  tall tapering masts mildly waved to that languid breeze, as three
Title:  mild palms on a plain.  And still, at wide intervals in the silvery
Title:  night, the lonely, alluring jet would be seen.
Title:  
Title:  But one transparent blue morning, when a stillness almost
Title:  preternatural spread over the sea, however unattended with any
Title:  stagnant calm; when the long burnished sun-glade on the waters seemed
Title:  a golden finger laid across them, enjoining some secrecy; when the
Title:  slippered waves whispered together as they softly ran on; in this
Title:  profound hush of the visible sphere a strange spectre was seen by
Title:  Daggoo from the main-mast-head.
Title:  
Title:  In the distance, a great white mass lazily rose, and rising higher
Title:  and higher, and disentangling itself from the azure, at last gleamed
Title:  before our prow like a snow-slide, new slid from the hills.  Thus
Title:  glistening for a moment, as slowly it subsided, and sank.  Then once
Title:  more arose, and silently gleamed.  It seemed not a whale; and yet is
Title:  this Moby Dick? thought Daggoo.  Again the phantom went down, but on
Title:  re-appearing once more, with a stiletto-like cry that startled every
Title:  man from his nod, the negro yelled out--"There! there again! there
Title:  she breaches! right ahead!  The White Whale, the White Whale!"
Title:  
Title:  Upon this, the seamen rushed to the yard-arms, as in swarming-time
Title:  the bees rush to the boughs.  Bare-headed in the sultry sun, Ahab
Title:  stood on the bowsprit, and with one hand pushed far behind in
Title:  readiness to wave his orders to the helmsman, cast his eager glance
Title:  in the direction indicated aloft by the outstretched motionless arm
Title:  of Daggoo.
Title:  
Title:  Whether the flitting attendance of the one still and solitary jet had
Title:  gradually worked upon Ahab, so that he was now prepared to connect
Title:  the ideas of mildness and repose with the first sight of the
Title:  particular whale he pursued; however this was, or whether his
Title:  eagerness betrayed him; whichever way it might have been, no sooner
Title:  did he distinctly perceive the white mass, than with a quick
Title:  intensity he instantly gave orders for lowering.
Title:  
Title:  The four boats were soon on the water; Ahab's in advance, and all
Title:  swiftly pulling towards their prey.  Soon it went down, and while,
Title:  with oars suspended, we were awaiting its reappearance, lo! in the
Title:  same spot where it sank, once more it slowly rose.  Almost forgetting
Title:  for the moment all thoughts of Moby Dick, we now gazed at the most
Title:  wondrous phenomenon which the secret seas have hitherto revealed to
Title:  mankind.  A vast pulpy mass, furlongs in length and breadth, of a
Title:  glancing cream-colour, lay floating on the water, innumerable long
Title:  arms radiating from its centre, and curling and twisting like a nest
Title:  of anacondas, as if blindly to clutch at any hapless object within
Title:  reach.  No perceptible face or front did it have; no conceivable
Title:  token of either sensation or instinct; but undulated there on the
Title:  billows, an unearthly, formless, chance-like apparition of life.
Title:  
Title:  As with a low sucking sound it slowly disappeared again, Starbuck
Title:  still gazing at the agitated waters where it had sunk, with a wild
Title:  voice exclaimed--"Almost rather had I seen Moby Dick and fought him,
Title:  than to have seen thee, thou white ghost!"
Title:  
Title:  "What was it, Sir?" said Flask.
Title:  
Title:  "The great live squid, which, they say, few whale-ships ever beheld,
Title:  and returned to their ports to tell of it."
Title:  
Title:  But Ahab said nothing; turning his boat, he sailed back to the
Title:  vessel; the rest as silently following.
Title:  
Title:  Whatever superstitions the sperm whalemen in general have connected
Title:  with the sight of this object, certain it is, that a glimpse of it
Title:  being so very unusual, that circumstance has gone far to invest it
Title:  with portentousness.  So rarely is it beheld, that though one and all
Title:  of them declare it to be the largest animated thing in the ocean, yet
Title:  very few of them have any but the most vague ideas concerning its
Title:  true nature and form; notwithstanding, they believe it to furnish to
Title:  the sperm whale his only food.  For though other species of whales
Title:  find their food above water, and may be seen by man in the act of
Title:  feeding, the spermaceti whale obtains his whole food in unknown zones
Title:  below the surface; and only by inference is it that any one can tell
Title:  of what, precisely, that food consists.  At times, when closely
Title:  pursued, he will disgorge what are supposed to be the detached arms
Title:  of the squid; some of them thus exhibited exceeding twenty and thirty
Title:  feet in length.  They fancy that the monster to which these arms
Title:  belonged ordinarily clings by them to the bed of the ocean; and that
Title:  the sperm whale, unlike other species, is supplied with teeth in
Title:  order to attack and tear it.
Title:  
Title:  There seems some ground to imagine that the great Kraken of Bishop
Title:  Pontoppodan may ultimately resolve itself into Squid.  The manner in
Title:  which the Bishop describes it, as alternately rising and sinking,
Title:  with some other particulars he narrates, in all this the two
Title:  correspond.  But much abatement is necessary with respect to the
Title:  incredible bulk he assigns it.
Title:  
Title:  By some naturalists who have vaguely heard rumors of the mysterious
Title:  creature, here spoken of, it is included among the class of
Title:  cuttle-fish, to which, indeed, in certain external respects it would
Title:  seem to belong, but only as the Anak of the tribe.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 60
Title:  
Title:  The Line.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  With reference to the whaling scene shortly to be described, as well
Title:  as for the better understanding of all similar scenes elsewhere
Title:  presented, I have here to speak of the magical, sometimes horrible
Title:  whale-line.
Title:  
Title:  The line originally used in the fishery was of the best hemp,
Title:  slightly vapoured with tar, not impregnated with it, as in the case of
Title:  ordinary ropes; for while tar, as ordinarily used, makes the hemp
Title:  more pliable to the rope-maker, and also renders the rope itself more
Title:  convenient to the sailor for common ship use; yet, not only would the
Title:  ordinary quantity too much stiffen the whale-line for the close
Title:  coiling to which it must be subjected; but as most seamen are
Title:  beginning to learn, tar in general by no means adds to the rope's
Title:  durability or strength, however much it may give it compactness and
Title:  gloss.
Title:  
Title:  Of late years the Manilla rope has in the American fishery almost
Title:  entirely superseded hemp as a material for whale-lines; for, though
Title:  not so durable as hemp, it is stronger, and far more soft and
Title:  elastic; and I will add (since there is an aesthetics in all things),
Title:  is much more handsome and becoming to the boat, than hemp.  Hemp is a
Title:  dusky, dark fellow, a sort of Indian; but Manilla is as a
Title:  golden-haired Circassian to behold.
Title:  
Title:  The whale-line is only two-thirds of an inch in thickness.  At first
Title:  sight, you would not think it so strong as it really is.  By
Title:  experiment its one and fifty yarns will each suspend a weight of one
Title:  hundred and twenty pounds; so that the whole rope will bear a strain
Title:  nearly equal to three tons.  In length, the common sperm whale-line
Title:  measures something over two hundred fathoms.  Towards the stern of
Title:  the boat it is spirally coiled away in the tub, not like the
Title:  worm-pipe of a still though, but so as to form one round,
Title:  cheese-shaped mass of densely bedded "sheaves," or layers of
Title:  concentric spiralizations, without any hollow but the "heart," or
Title:  minute vertical tube formed at the axis of the cheese.  As the least
Title:  tangle or kink in the coiling would, in running out, infallibly take
Title:  somebody's arm, leg, or entire body off, the utmost precaution is
Title:  used in stowing the line in its tub.  Some harpooneers will consume
Title:  almost an entire morning in this business, carrying the line high
Title:  aloft and then reeving it downwards through a block towards the tub,
Title:  so as in the act of coiling to free it from all possible wrinkles and
Title:  twists.
Title:  
Title:  In the English boats two tubs are used instead of one; the same line
Title:  being continuously coiled in both tubs.  There is some advantage in
Title:  this; because these twin-tubs being so small they fit more readily
Title:  into the boat, and do not strain it so much; whereas, the American
Title:  tub, nearly three feet in diameter and of proportionate depth, makes
Title:  a rather bulky freight for a craft whose planks are but one half-inch
Title:  in thickness; for the bottom of the whale-boat is like critical ice,
Title:  which will bear up a considerable distributed weight, but not very
Title:  much of a concentrated one.  When the painted canvas cover is clapped
Title:  on the American line-tub, the boat looks as if it were pulling off
Title:  with a prodigious great wedding-cake to present to the whales.
Title:  
Title:  Both ends of the line are exposed; the lower end terminating in an
Title:  eye-splice or loop coming up from the bottom against the side of the
Title:  tub, and hanging over its edge completely disengaged from everything.
Title:  This arrangement of the lower end is necessary on two accounts.
Title:  First: In order to facilitate the fastening to it of an additional
Title:  line from a neighboring boat, in case the stricken whale should sound
Title:  so deep as to threaten to carry off the entire line originally
Title:  attached to the harpoon.  In these instances, the whale of course is
Title:  shifted like a mug of ale, as it were, from the one boat to the
Title:  other; though the first boat always hovers at hand to assist its
Title:  consort.  Second: This arrangement is indispensable for common
Title:  safety's sake; for were the lower end of the line in any way attached
Title:  to the boat, and were the whale then to run the line out to the end
Title:  almost in a single, smoking minute as he sometimes does, he would not
Title:  stop there, for the doomed boat would infallibly be dragged down
Title:  after him into the profundity of the sea; and in that case no
Title:  town-crier would ever find her again.
Title:  
Title:  Before lowering the boat for the chase, the upper end of the line is
Title:  taken aft from the tub, and passing round the loggerhead there, is
Title:  again carried forward the entire length of the boat, resting
Title:  crosswise upon the loom or handle of every man's oar, so that it jogs
Title:  against his wrist in rowing; and also passing between the men, as
Title:  they alternately sit at the opposite gunwales, to the leaded chocks
Title:  or grooves in the extreme pointed prow of the boat, where a wooden
Title:  pin or skewer the size of a common quill, prevents it from slipping
Title:  out.  From the chocks it hangs in a slight festoon over the bows, and
Title:  is then passed inside the boat again; and some ten or twenty fathoms
Title:  (called box-line) being coiled upon the box in the bows, it continues
Title:  its way to the gunwale still a little further aft, and is then
Title:  attached to the short-warp--the rope which is immediately connected
Title:  with the harpoon; but previous to that connexion, the short-warp goes
Title:  through sundry mystifications too tedious to detail.
Title:  
Title:  Thus the whale-line folds the whole boat in its complicated coils,
Title:  twisting and writhing around it in almost every direction.  All the
Title:  oarsmen are involved in its perilous contortions; so that to the
Title:  timid eye of the landsman, they seem as Indian jugglers, with the
Title:  deadliest snakes sportively festooning their limbs.  Nor can any son
Title:  of mortal woman, for the first time, seat himself amid those hempen
Title:  intricacies, and while straining his utmost at the oar, bethink him
Title:  that at any unknown instant the harpoon may be darted, and all these
Title:  horrible contortions be put in play like ringed lightnings; he cannot
Title:  be thus circumstanced without a shudder that makes the very marrow in
Title:  his bones to quiver in him like a shaken jelly.  Yet habit--strange
Title:  thing! what cannot habit accomplish?--Gayer sallies, more merry
Title:  mirth, better jokes, and brighter repartees, you never heard over
Title:  your mahogany, than you will hear over the half-inch white cedar of
Title:  the whale-boat, when thus hung in hangman's nooses; and, like the six
Title:  burghers of Calais before King Edward, the six men composing the crew
Title:  pull into the jaws of death, with a halter around every neck, as you
Title:  may say.
Title:  
Title:  Perhaps a very little thought will now enable you to account for
Title:  those repeated whaling disasters--some few of which are casually
Title:  chronicled--of this man or that man being taken out of the boat by
Title:  the line, and lost.  For, when the line is darting out, to be seated
Title:  then in the boat, is like being seated in the midst of the manifold
Title:  whizzings of a steam-engine in full play, when every flying beam, and
Title:  shaft, and wheel, is grazing you.  It is worse; for you cannot sit
Title:  motionless in the heart of these perils, because the boat is rocking
Title:  like a cradle, and you are pitched one way and the other, without the
Title:  slightest warning; and only by a certain self-adjusting buoyancy and
Title:  simultaneousness of volition and action, can you escape being made a
Title:  Mazeppa of, and run away with where the all-seeing sun himself could
Title:  never pierce you out.
Title:  
Title:  Again: as the profound calm which only apparently precedes and
Title:  prophesies of the storm, is perhaps more awful than the storm itself;
Title:  for, indeed, the calm is but the wrapper and envelope of the storm;
Title:  and contains it in itself, as the seemingly harmless rifle holds the
Title:  fatal powder, and the ball, and the explosion; so the graceful repose
Title:  of the line, as it silently serpentines about the oarsmen before
Title:  being brought into actual play--this is a thing which carries more of
Title:  true terror than any other aspect of this dangerous affair.  But why
Title:  say more?  All men live enveloped in whale-lines.  All are born with
Title:  halters round their necks; but it is only when caught in the swift,
Title:  sudden turn of death, that mortals realize the silent, subtle,
Title:  ever-present perils of life.  And if you be a philosopher, though
Title:  seated in the whale-boat, you would not at heart feel one whit more
Title:  of terror, than though seated before your evening fire with a poker,
Title:  and not a harpoon, by your side.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 61
Title:  
Title:  Stubb Kills a Whale.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  If to Starbuck the apparition of the Squid was a thing of portents,
Title:  to Queequeg it was quite a different object.
Title:  
Title:  "When you see him 'quid," said the savage, honing his harpoon in the
Title:  bow of his hoisted boat, "then you quick see him 'parm whale."
Title:  
Title:  The next day was exceedingly still and sultry, and with nothing
Title:  special to engage them, the Pequod's crew could hardly resist the
Title:  spell of sleep induced by such a vacant sea.  For this part of the
Title:  Indian Ocean through which we then were voyaging is not what whalemen
Title:  call a lively ground; that is, it affords fewer glimpses of
Title:  porpoises, dolphins, flying-fish, and other vivacious denizens of
Title:  more stirring waters, than those off the Rio de la Plata, or the
Title:  in-shore ground off Peru.
Title:  
Title:  It was my turn to stand at the foremast-head; and with my shoulders
Title:  leaning against the slackened royal shrouds, to and fro I idly swayed
Title:  in what seemed an enchanted air.  No resolution could withstand it;
Title:  in that dreamy mood losing all consciousness, at last my soul went
Title:  out of my body; though my body still continued to sway as a pendulum
Title:  will, long after the power which first moved it is withdrawn.
Title:  
Title:  Ere forgetfulness altogether came over me, I had noticed that the
Title:  seamen at the main and mizzen-mast-heads were already drowsy.  So
Title:  that at last all three of us lifelessly swung from the spars, and for
Title:  every swing that we made there was a nod from below from the
Title:  slumbering helmsman.  The waves, too, nodded their indolent crests;
Title:  and across the wide trance of the sea, east nodded to west, and the
Title:  sun over all.
Title:  
Title:  Suddenly bubbles seemed bursting beneath my closed eyes; like vices
Title:  my hands grasped the shrouds; some invisible, gracious agency
Title:  preserved me; with a shock I came back to life.  And lo! close under
Title:  our lee, not forty fathoms off, a gigantic Sperm Whale lay rolling in
Title:  the water like the capsized hull of a frigate, his broad, glossy
Title:  back, of an Ethiopian hue, glistening in the sun's rays like a
Title:  mirror.  But lazily undulating in the trough of the sea, and ever and
Title:  anon tranquilly spouting his vapoury jet, the whale looked like a
Title:  portly burgher smoking his pipe of a warm afternoon.  But that pipe,
Title:  poor whale, was thy last.  As if struck by some enchanter's wand, the
Title:  sleepy ship and every sleeper in it all at once started into
Title:  wakefulness; and more than a score of voices from all parts of the
Title:  vessel, simultaneously with the three notes from aloft, shouted forth
Title:  the accustomed cry, as the great fish slowly and regularly spouted
Title:  the sparkling brine into the air.
Title:  
Title:  "Clear away the boats!  Luff!" cried Ahab.  And obeying his own
Title:  order, he dashed the helm down before the helmsman could handle the
Title:  spokes.
Title:  
Title:  The sudden exclamations of the crew must have alarmed the whale; and
Title:  ere the boats were down, majestically turning, he swam away to the
Title:  leeward, but with such a steady tranquillity, and making so few
Title:  ripples as he swam, that thinking after all he might not as yet be
Title:  alarmed, Ahab gave orders that not an oar should be used, and no man
Title:  must speak but in whispers.  So seated like Ontario Indians on the
Title:  gunwales of the boats, we swiftly but silently paddled along; the
Title:  calm not admitting of the noiseless sails being set.  Presently, as
Title:  we thus glided in chase, the monster perpendicularly flitted his tail
Title:  forty feet into the air, and then sank out of sight like a tower
Title:  swallowed up.
Title:  
Title:  "There go flukes!" was the cry, an announcement immediately followed
Title:  by Stubb's producing his match and igniting his pipe, for now a
Title:  respite was granted.  After the full interval of his sounding had
Title:  elapsed, the whale rose again, and being now in advance of the
Title:  smoker's boat, and much nearer to it than to any of the others, Stubb
Title:  counted upon the honour of the capture.  It was obvious, now, that the
Title:  whale had at length become aware of his pursuers.  All silence of
Title:  cautiousness was therefore no longer of use.  Paddles were dropped,
Title:  and oars came loudly into play.  And still puffing at his pipe, Stubb
Title:  cheered on his crew to the assault.
Title:  
Title:  Yes, a mighty change had come over the fish.  All alive to his
Title:  jeopardy, he was going "head out"; that part obliquely projecting
Title:  from the mad yeast which he brewed.*
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *It will be seen in some other place of what a very light substance
Title:  the entire interior of the sperm whale's enormous head consists.
Title:  Though apparently the most massive, it is by far the most buoyant
Title:  part about him.  So that with ease he elevates it in the air, and
Title:  invariably does so when going at his utmost speed.  Besides, such is
Title:  the breadth of the upper part of the front of his head, and such the
Title:  tapering cut-water formation of the lower part, that by obliquely
Title:  elevating his head, he thereby may be said to transform himself from
Title:  a bluff-bowed sluggish galliot into a sharppointed New York
Title:  pilot-boat.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "Start her, start her, my men!  Don't hurry yourselves; take plenty
Title:  of time--but start her; start her like thunder-claps, that's all,"
Title:  cried Stubb, spluttering out the smoke as he spoke.  "Start her, now;
Title:  give 'em the long and strong stroke, Tashtego.  Start her, Tash, my
Title:  boy--start her, all; but keep cool, keep cool--cucumbers is the
Title:  word--easy, easy--only start her like grim death and grinning devils,
Title:  and raise the buried dead perpendicular out of their graves,
Title:  boys--that's all.  Start her!"
Title:  
Title:  "Woo-hoo!  Wa-hee!" screamed the Gay-Header in reply, raising some
Title:  old war-whoop to the skies; as every oarsman in the strained boat
Title:  involuntarily bounced forward with the one tremendous leading stroke
Title:  which the eager Indian gave.
Title:  
Title:  But his wild screams were answered by others quite as wild.
Title:  "Kee-hee!  Kee-hee!" yelled Daggoo, straining forwards and backwards
Title:  on his seat, like a pacing tiger in his cage.
Title:  
Title:  "Ka-la!  Koo-loo!" howled Queequeg, as if smacking his lips over a
Title:  mouthful of Grenadier's steak.  And thus with oars and yells the
Title:  keels cut the sea.  Meanwhile, Stubb retaining his place in the
Title:  van, still encouraged his men to the onset, all the while puffing the
Title:  smoke from his mouth.  Like desperadoes they tugged and they
Title:  strained, till the welcome cry was heard--"Stand up, Tashtego!--give
Title:  it to him!"  The harpoon was hurled.  "Stern all!"  The oarsmen
Title:  backed water; the same moment something went hot and hissing along
Title:  every one of their wrists.  It was the magical line.  An instant
Title:  before, Stubb had swiftly caught two additional turns with it round
Title:  the loggerhead, whence, by reason of its increased rapid circlings, a
Title:  hempen blue smoke now jetted up and mingled with the steady fumes
Title:  from his pipe.  As the line passed round and round the loggerhead; so
Title:  also, just before reaching that point, it blisteringly passed through
Title:  and through both of Stubb's hands, from which the hand-cloths, or
Title:  squares of quilted canvas sometimes worn at these times, had
Title:  accidentally dropped.  It was like holding an enemy's sharp two-edged
Title:  sword by the blade, and that enemy all the time striving to wrest it
Title:  out of your clutch.
Title:  
Title:  "Wet the line! wet the line!" cried Stubb to the tub oarsman (him
Title:  seated by the tub) who, snatching off his hat, dashed sea-water into
Title:  it.*  More turns were taken, so that the line began holding its place.
Title:  The boat now flew through the boiling water like a shark all fins.
Title:  Stubb and Tashtego here changed places--stem for stern--a staggering
Title:  business truly in that rocking commotion.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *Partly to show the indispensableness of this act, it may here be
Title:  stated, that, in the old Dutch fishery, a mop was used to dash the
Title:  running line with water; in many other ships, a wooden piggin, or
Title:  bailer, is set apart for that purpose.  Your hat, however, is the
Title:  most convenient.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  From the vibrating line extending the entire length of the upper part
Title:  of the boat, and from its now being more tight than a harpstring, you
Title:  would have thought the craft had two keels--one cleaving the water,
Title:  the other the air--as the boat churned on through both opposing
Title:  elements at once.  A continual cascade played at the bows; a
Title:  ceaseless whirling eddy in her wake; and, at the slightest motion
Title:  from within, even but of a little finger, the vibrating, cracking
Title:  craft canted over her spasmodic gunwale into the sea.  Thus they
Title:  rushed; each man with might and main clinging to his seat, to prevent
Title:  being tossed to the foam; and the tall form of Tashtego at the
Title:  steering oar crouching almost double, in order to bring down his
Title:  centre of gravity.  Whole Atlantics and Pacifics seemed passed as
Title:  they shot on their way, till at length the whale somewhat slackened
Title:  his flight.
Title:  
Title:  "Haul in--haul in!" cried Stubb to the bowsman! and, facing round
Title:  towards the whale, all hands began pulling the boat up to him, while
Title:  yet the boat was being towed on.  Soon ranging up by his flank,
Title:  Stubb, firmly planting his knee in the clumsy cleat, darted dart
Title:  after dart into the flying fish; at the word of command, the boat
Title:  alternately sterning out of the way of the whale's horrible wallow,
Title:  and then ranging up for another fling.
Title:  
Title:  The red tide now poured from all sides of the monster like brooks
Title:  down a hill.  His tormented body rolled not in brine but in blood,
Title:  which bubbled and seethed for furlongs behind in their wake.  The
Title:  slanting sun playing upon this crimson pond in the sea, sent back
Title:  its reflection into every face, so that they all glowed to each other
Title:  like red men.  And all the while, jet after jet of white smoke was
Title:  agonizingly shot from the spiracle of the whale, and vehement puff
Title:  after puff from the mouth of the excited headsman; as at every dart,
Title:  hauling in upon his crooked lance (by the line attached to it), Stubb
Title:  straightened it again and again, by a few rapid blows against the
Title:  gunwale, then again and again sent it into the whale.
Title:  
Title:  "Pull up--pull up!" he now cried to the bowsman, as the waning whale
Title:  relaxed in his wrath.  "Pull up!--close to!" and the boat ranged
Title:  along the fish's flank.  When reaching far over the bow, Stubb slowly
Title:  churned his long sharp lance into the fish, and kept it there,
Title:  carefully churning and churning, as if cautiously seeking to feel
Title:  after some gold watch that the whale might have swallowed, and which
Title:  he was fearful of breaking ere he could hook it out.  But that gold
Title:  watch he sought was the innermost life of the fish.  And now it is
Title:  struck; for, starting from his trance into that unspeakable thing
Title:  called his "flurry," the monster horribly wallowed in his blood,
Title:  overwrapped himself in impenetrable, mad, boiling spray, so that the
Title:  imperilled craft, instantly dropping astern, had much ado blindly to
Title:  struggle out from that phrensied twilight into the clear air of the
Title:  day.
Title:  
Title:  And now abating in his flurry, the whale once more rolled out into
Title:  view; surging from side to side; spasmodically dilating and
Title:  contracting his spout-hole, with sharp, cracking, agonized
Title:  respirations.  At last, gush after gush of clotted red gore, as if it
Title:  had been the purple lees of red wine, shot into the frighted air; and
Title:  falling back again, ran dripping down his motionless flanks into
Title:  the sea.  His heart had burst!
Title:  
Title:  "He's dead, Mr. Stubb," said Daggoo.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; both pipes smoked out!" and withdrawing his own from his mouth,
Title:  Stubb scattered the dead ashes over the water; and, for a moment,
Title:  stood thoughtfully eyeing the vast corpse he had made.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 62
Title:  
Title:  The Dart.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  A word concerning an incident in the last chapter.
Title:  
Title:  According to the invariable usage of the fishery, the whale-boat
Title:  pushes off from the ship, with the headsman or whale-killer as
Title:  temporary steersman, and the harpooneer or whale-fastener pulling the
Title:  foremost oar, the one known as the harpooneer-oar.  Now it needs a
Title:  strong, nervous arm to strike the first iron into the fish; for
Title:  often, in what is called a long dart, the heavy implement has to be
Title:  flung to the distance of twenty or thirty feet.  But however
Title:  prolonged and exhausting the chase, the harpooneer is expected to
Title:  pull his oar meanwhile to the uttermost; indeed, he is expected to
Title:  set an example of superhuman activity to the rest, not only by
Title:  incredible rowing, but by repeated loud and intrepid exclamations;
Title:  and what it is to keep shouting at the top of one's compass, while
Title:  all the other muscles are strained and half started--what that is
Title:  none know but those who have tried it.  For one, I cannot bawl very
Title:  heartily and work very recklessly at one and the same time.  In this
Title:  straining, bawling state, then, with his back to the fish, all at
Title:  once the exhausted harpooneer hears the exciting cry--"Stand up, and
Title:  give it to him!"  He now has to drop and secure his oar, turn round
Title:  on his centre half way, seize his harpoon from the crotch, and with
Title:  what little strength may remain, he essays to pitch it somehow into
Title:  the whale.  No wonder, taking the whole fleet of whalemen in a body,
Title:  that out of fifty fair chances for a dart, not five are successful;
Title:  no wonder that so many hapless harpooneers are madly cursed and
Title:  disrated; no wonder that some of them actually burst their
Title:  blood-vessels in the boat; no wonder that some sperm whalemen are
Title:  absent four years with four barrels; no wonder that to many ship
Title:  owners, whaling is but a losing concern; for it is the harpooneer
Title:  that makes the voyage, and if you take the breath out of his body how
Title:  can you expect to find it there when most wanted!
Title:  
Title:  Again, if the dart be successful, then at the second critical
Title:  instant, that is, when the whale starts to run, the boatheader and
Title:  harpooneer likewise start to running fore and aft, to the imminent
Title:  jeopardy of themselves and every one else.  It is then they change
Title:  places; and the headsman, the chief officer of the little craft,
Title:  takes his proper station in the bows of the boat.
Title:  
Title:  Now, I care not who maintains the contrary, but all this is both
Title:  foolish and unnecessary.  The headsman should stay in the bows from
Title:  first to last; he should both dart the harpoon and the lance, and no
Title:  rowing whatever should be expected of him, except under circumstances
Title:  obvious to any fisherman.  I know that this would sometimes involve a
Title:  slight loss of speed in the chase; but long experience in various
Title:  whalemen of more than one nation has convinced me that in the vast
Title:  majority of failures in the fishery, it has not by any means been so
Title:  much the speed of the whale as the before described exhaustion of the
Title:  harpooneer that has caused them.
Title:  
Title:  To insure the greatest efficiency in the dart, the harpooneers of
Title:  this world must start to their feet from out of idleness, and not
Title:  from out of toil.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 63
Title:  
Title:  The Crotch.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Out of the trunk, the branches grow; out of them, the twigs.  So, in
Title:  productive subjects, grow the chapters.
Title:  
Title:  The crotch alluded to on a previous page deserves independent
Title:  mention.  It is a notched stick of a peculiar form, some two feet in
Title:  length, which is perpendicularly inserted into the starboard gunwale
Title:  near the bow, for the purpose of furnishing a rest for the wooden
Title:  extremity of the harpoon, whose other naked, barbed end slopingly
Title:  projects from the prow.  Thereby the weapon is instantly at hand to
Title:  its hurler, who snatches it up as readily from its rest as a
Title:  backwoodsman swings his rifle from the wall.  It is customary to have
Title:  two harpoons reposing in the crotch, respectively called the first
Title:  and second irons.
Title:  
Title:  But these two harpoons, each by its own cord, are both connected with
Title:  the line; the object being this: to dart them both, if possible, one
Title:  instantly after the other into the same whale; so that if, in the
Title:  coming drag, one should draw out, the other may still retain a hold.
Title:  It is a doubling of the chances.  But it very often happens that
Title:  owing to the instantaneous, violent, convulsive running of the whale
Title:  upon receiving the first iron, it becomes impossible for the
Title:  harpooneer, however lightning-like in his movements, to pitch the
Title:  second iron into him.  Nevertheless, as the second iron is already
Title:  connected with the line, and the line is running, hence that weapon
Title:  must, at all events, be anticipatingly tossed out of the boat,
Title:  somehow and somewhere; else the most terrible jeopardy would involve
Title:  all hands.  Tumbled into the water, it accordingly is in such cases;
Title:  the spare coils of box line (mentioned in a preceding chapter) making
Title:  this feat, in most instances, prudently practicable.  But this
Title:  critical act is not always unattended with the saddest and most fatal
Title:  casualties.
Title:  
Title:  Furthermore: you must know that when the second iron is thrown
Title:  overboard, it thenceforth becomes a dangling, sharp-edged terror,
Title:  skittishly curvetting about both boat and whale, entangling the
Title:  lines, or cutting them, and making a prodigious sensation in all
Title:  directions.  Nor, in general, is it possible to secure it again until
Title:  the whale is fairly captured and a corpse.
Title:  
Title:  Consider, now, how it must be in the case of four boats all engaging
Title:  one unusually strong, active, and knowing whale; when owing to these
Title:  qualities in him, as well as to the thousand concurring accidents of
Title:  such an audacious enterprise, eight or ten loose second irons may be
Title:  simultaneously dangling about him.  For, of course, each boat is
Title:  supplied with several harpoons to bend on to the line should the
Title:  first one be ineffectually darted without recovery.  All these
Title:  particulars are faithfully narrated here, as they will not fail to
Title:  elucidate several most important, however intricate passages, in
Title:  scenes hereafter to be painted.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 64
Title:  
Title:  Stubb's Supper.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Stubb's whale had been killed some distance from the ship.  It was a
Title:  calm; so, forming a tandem of three boats, we commenced the slow
Title:  business of towing the trophy to the Pequod.  And now, as we eighteen
Title:  men with our thirty-six arms, and one hundred and eighty thumbs and
Title:  fingers, slowly toiled hour after hour upon that inert, sluggish
Title:  corpse in the sea; and it seemed hardly to budge at all, except at
Title:  long intervals; good evidence was hereby furnished of the
Title:  enormousness of the mass we moved.  For, upon the great canal of
Title:  Hang-Ho, or whatever they call it, in China, four or five laborers on
Title:  the foot-path will draw a bulky freighted junk at the rate of a mile
Title:  an hour; but this grand argosy we towed heavily forged along, as if
Title:  laden with pig-lead in bulk.
Title:  
Title:  Darkness came on; but three lights up and down in the Pequod's
Title:  main-rigging dimly guided our way; till drawing nearer we saw Ahab
Title:  dropping one of several more lanterns over the bulwarks.  Vacantly
Title:  eyeing the heaving whale for a moment, he issued the usual orders for
Title:  securing it for the night, and then handing his lantern to a seaman,
Title:  went his way into the cabin, and did not come forward again until
Title:  morning.
Title:  
Title:  Though, in overseeing the pursuit of this whale, Captain Ahab had
Title:  evinced his customary activity, to call it so; yet now that the
Title:  creature was dead, some vague dissatisfaction, or impatience, or
Title:  despair, seemed working in him; as if the sight of that dead body
Title:  reminded him that Moby Dick was yet to be slain; and though a
Title:  thousand other whales were brought to his ship, all that would not
Title:  one jot advance his grand, monomaniac object.  Very soon you would
Title:  have thought from the sound on the Pequod's decks, that all hands
Title:  were preparing to cast anchor in the deep; for heavy chains are being
Title:  dragged along the deck, and thrust rattling out of the port-holes.
Title:  But by those clanking links, the vast corpse itself, not the ship, is
Title:  to be moored.  Tied by the head to the stern, and by the tail to the
Title:  bows, the whale now lies with its black hull close to the vessel's
Title:  and seen through the darkness of the night, which obscured the spars
Title:  and rigging aloft, the two--ship and whale, seemed yoked together
Title:  like colossal bullocks, whereof one reclines while the other remains
Title:  standing.*
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *A little item may as well be related here.  The strongest and most
Title:  reliable hold which the ship has upon the whale when moored
Title:  alongside, is by the flukes or tail; and as from its greater density
Title:  that part is relatively heavier than any other (excepting the
Title:  side-fins), its flexibility even in death, causes it to sink low
Title:  beneath the surface; so that with the hand you cannot get at it from
Title:  the boat, in order to put the chain round it.  But this difficulty is
Title:  ingeniously overcome: a small, strong line is prepared with a wooden
Title:  float at its outer end, and a weight in its middle, while the other
Title:  end is secured to the ship.  By adroit management the wooden float is
Title:  made to rise on the other side of the mass, so that now having
Title:  girdled the whale, the chain is readily made to follow suit; and
Title:  being slipped along the body, is at last locked fast round the
Title:  smallest part of the tail, at the point of junction with its broad
Title:  flukes or lobes.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  If moody Ahab was now all quiescence, at least so far as could be
Title:  known on deck, Stubb, his second mate, flushed with conquest,
Title:  betrayed an unusual but still good-natured excitement.  Such an
Title:  unwonted bustle was he in that the staid Starbuck, his official
Title:  superior, quietly resigned to him for the time the sole management of
Title:  affairs.  One small, helping cause of all this liveliness in Stubb,
Title:  was soon made strangely manifest.  Stubb was a high liver; he was
Title:  somewhat intemperately fond of the whale as a flavorish thing to his
Title:  palate.
Title:  
Title:  "A steak, a steak, ere I sleep!  You, Daggoo! overboard you go, and
Title:  cut me one from his small!"
Title:  
Title:  Here be it known, that though these wild fishermen do not, as a
Title:  general thing, and according to the great military maxim, make the
Title:  enemy defray the current expenses of the war (at least before
Title:  realizing the proceeds of the voyage), yet now and then you find some
Title:  of these Nantucketers who have a genuine relish for that particular
Title:  part of the Sperm Whale designated by Stubb; comprising the tapering
Title:  extremity of the body.
Title:  
Title:  About midnight that steak was cut and cooked; and lighted by two
Title:  lanterns of sperm oil, Stubb stoutly stood up to his spermaceti
Title:  supper at the capstan-head, as if that capstan were a sideboard.  Nor
Title:  was Stubb the only banqueter on whale's flesh that night.  Mingling
Title:  their mumblings with his own mastications, thousands on thousands of
Title:  sharks, swarming round the dead leviathan, smackingly feasted on its
Title:  fatness.  The few sleepers below in their bunks were often startled
Title:  by the sharp slapping of their tails against the hull, within a few
Title:  inches of the sleepers' hearts.  Peering over the side you could just
Title:  see them (as before you heard them) wallowing in the sullen, black
Title:  waters, and turning over on their backs as they scooped out huge
Title:  globular pieces of the whale of the bigness of a human head.  This
Title:  particular feat of the shark seems all but miraculous.  How at such
Title:  an apparently unassailable surface, they contrive to gouge out such
Title:  symmetrical mouthfuls, remains a part of the universal problem of all
Title:  things.  The mark they thus leave on the whale, may best be likened
Title:  to the hollow made by a carpenter in countersinking for a screw.
Title:  
Title:  Though amid all the smoking horror and diabolism of a sea-fight,
Title:  sharks will be seen longingly gazing up to the ship's decks, like
Title:  hungry dogs round a table where red meat is being carved, ready to
Title:  bolt down every killed man that is tossed to them; and though, while
Title:  the valiant butchers over the deck-table are thus cannibally carving
Title:  each other's live meat with carving-knives all gilded and tasselled,
Title:  the sharks, also, with their jewel-hilted mouths, are quarrelsomely
Title:  carving away under the table at the dead meat; and though, were you
Title:  to turn the whole affair upside down, it would still be pretty much
Title:  the same thing, that is to say, a shocking sharkish business enough
Title:  for all parties; and though sharks also are the invariable outriders
Title:  of all slave ships crossing the Atlantic, systematically trotting
Title:  alongside, to be handy in case a parcel is to be carried anywhere, or
Title:  a dead slave to be decently buried; and though one or two other like
Title:  instances might be set down, touching the set terms, places, and
Title:  occasions, when sharks do most socially congregate, and most
Title:  hilariously feast; yet is there no conceivable time or occasion when
Title:  you will find them in such countless numbers, and in gayer or more
Title:  jovial spirits, than around a dead sperm whale, moored by night to a
Title:  whaleship at sea.  If you have never seen that sight, then suspend
Title:  your decision about the propriety of devil-worship, and the
Title:  expediency of conciliating the devil.
Title:  
Title:  But, as yet, Stubb heeded not the mumblings of the banquet that was
Title:  going on so nigh him, no more than the sharks heeded the smacking of
Title:  his own epicurean lips.
Title:  
Title:  "Cook, cook!--where's that old Fleece?" he cried at length, widening
Title:  his legs still further, as if to form a more secure base for his
Title:  supper; and, at the same time darting his fork into the dish, as if
Title:  stabbing with his lance; "cook, you cook!--sail this way, cook!"
Title:  
Title:  The old black, not in any very high glee at having been previously
Title:  roused from his warm hammock at a most unseasonable hour, came
Title:  shambling along from his galley, for, like many old blacks, there was
Title:  something the matter with his knee-pans, which he did not keep well
Title:  scoured like his other pans; this old Fleece, as they called him,
Title:  came shuffling and limping along, assisting his step with his tongs,
Title:  which, after a clumsy fashion, were made of straightened iron hoops;
Title:  this old Ebony floundered along, and in obedience to the word of
Title:  command, came to a dead stop on the opposite side of Stubb's
Title:  sideboard; when, with both hands folded before him, and resting on
Title:  his two-legged cane, he bowed his arched back still further over, at
Title:  the same time sideways inclining his head, so as to bring his best
Title:  ear into play.
Title:  
Title:  "Cook," said Stubb, rapidly lifting a rather reddish morsel to his
Title:  mouth, "don't you think this steak is rather overdone?  You've been
Title:  beating this steak too much, cook; it's too tender.  Don't I always
Title:  say that to be good, a whale-steak must be tough?  There are those
Title:  sharks now over the side, don't you see they prefer it tough and
Title:  rare?  What a shindy they are kicking up!  Cook, go and talk to 'em;
Title:  tell 'em they are welcome to help themselves civilly, and in
Title:  moderation, but they must keep quiet.  Blast me, if I can hear my own
Title:  voice.  Away, cook, and deliver my message.  Here, take this
Title:  lantern," snatching one from his sideboard; "now then, go and preach
Title:  to 'em!"
Title:  
Title:  Sullenly taking the offered lantern, old Fleece limped across the
Title:  deck to the bulwarks; and then, with one hand dropping his light low
Title:  over the sea, so as to get a good view of his congregation, with the
Title:  other hand he solemnly flourished his tongs, and leaning far over the
Title:  side in a mumbling voice began addressing the sharks, while Stubb,
Title:  softly crawling behind, overheard all that was said.
Title:  
Title:  "Fellow-critters: I'se ordered here to say dat you must stop dat dam
Title:  noise dare.  You hear?  Stop dat dam smackin' ob de lips!  Massa
Title:  Stubb say dat you can fill your dam bellies up to de hatchings, but
Title:  by Gor! you must stop dat dam racket!"
Title:  
Title:  "Cook," here interposed Stubb, accompanying the word with a sudden
Title:  slap on the shoulder,--"Cook! why, damn your eyes, you mustn't swear
Title:  that way when you're preaching.  That's no way to convert sinners,
Title:  cook!"
Title:  
Title:  "Who dat?  Den preach to him yourself," sullenly turning to go.
Title:  
Title:  "No, cook; go on, go on."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, den, Belubed fellow-critters:"-
Title:  
Title:  "Right!" exclaimed Stubb, approvingly, "coax 'em to it; try that,"
Title:  and Fleece continued.
Title:  
Title:  "Do you is all sharks, and by natur wery woracious, yet I zay to you,
Title:  fellow-critters, dat dat woraciousness--'top dat dam slappin' ob de
Title:  tail!  How you tink to hear, spose you keep up such a dam slappin'
Title:  and bitin' dare?"
Title:  
Title:  "Cook," cried Stubb, collaring him, "I won't have that swearing.
Title:  Talk to 'em gentlemanly."
Title:  
Title:  Once more the sermon proceeded.
Title:  
Title:  "Your woraciousness, fellow-critters, I don't blame ye so much for;
Title:  dat is natur, and can't be helped; but to gobern dat wicked natur,
Title:  dat is de pint.  You is sharks, sartin; but if you gobern de shark in
Title:  you, why den you be angel; for all angel is not'ing more dan de shark
Title:  well goberned.  Now, look here, bred'ren, just try wonst to be cibil,
Title:  a helping yourselbs from dat whale.  Don't be tearin' de blubber out
Title:  your neighbour's mout, I say.  Is not one shark dood right as toder
Title:  to dat whale?  And, by Gor, none on you has de right to dat whale;
Title:  dat whale belong to some one else.  I know some o' you has berry brig
Title:  mout, brigger dan oders; but den de brig mouts sometimes has de
Title:  small bellies; so dat de brigness of de mout is not to swaller wid,
Title:  but to bit off de blubber for de small fry ob sharks, dat can't get
Title:  into de scrouge to help demselves."
Title:  
Title:  "Well done, old Fleece!" cried Stubb, "that's Christianity; go on."
Title:  
Title:  "No use goin' on; de dam willains will keep a scougin' and slappin'
Title:  each oder, Massa Stubb; dey don't hear one word; no use a-preaching
Title:  to such dam g'uttons as you call 'em, till dare bellies is full, and
Title:  dare bellies is bottomless; and when dey do get 'em full, dey wont
Title:  hear you den; for den dey sink in the sea, go fast to sleep on de
Title:  coral, and can't hear noting at all, no more, for eber and eber."
Title:  
Title:  "Upon my soul, I am about of the same opinion; so give the
Title:  benediction, Fleece, and I'll away to my supper."
Title:  
Title:  Upon this, Fleece, holding both hands over the fishy mob, raised his
Title:  shrill voice, and cried--
Title:  
Title:  "Cussed fellow-critters!  Kick up de damndest row as ever you can;
Title:  fill your dam bellies 'till dey bust--and den die."
Title:  
Title:  "Now, cook," said Stubb, resuming his supper at the capstan; "stand
Title:  just where you stood before, there, over against me, and pay
Title:  particular attention."
Title:  
Title:  "All 'dention," said Fleece, again stooping over upon his tongs in
Title:  the desired position.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said Stubb, helping himself freely meanwhile; "I shall now go
Title:  back to the subject of this steak.  In the first place, how old are
Title:  you, cook?"
Title:  
Title:  "What dat do wid de 'teak," said the old black, testily.
Title:  
Title:  "Silence!  How old are you, cook?"
Title:  
Title:  "'Bout ninety, dey say," he gloomily muttered.
Title:  
Title:  "And you have lived in this world hard upon one hundred years, cook,
Title:  and don't know yet how to cook a whale-steak?" rapidly bolting
Title:  another mouthful at the last word, so that morsel seemed a
Title:  continuation of the question.  "Where were you born, cook?"
Title:  
Title:  "'Hind de hatchway, in ferry-boat, goin' ober de Roanoke."
Title:  
Title:  "Born in a ferry-boat!  That's queer, too.  But I want to know what
Title:  country you were born in, cook!"
Title:  
Title:  "Didn't I say de Roanoke country?" he cried sharply.
Title:  
Title:  "No, you didn't, cook; but I'll tell you what I'm coming to, cook.
Title:  You must go home and be born over again; you don't know how to cook a
Title:  whale-steak yet."
Title:  
Title:  "Bress my soul, if I cook noder one," he growled, angrily, turning
Title:  round to depart.
Title:  
Title:  "Come back here, cook;--here, hand me those tongs;--now take that bit
Title:  of steak there, and tell me if you think that steak cooked as it
Title:  should be?  Take it, I say"--holding the tongs towards him--"take it,
Title:  and taste it."
Title:
