Title:  Faintly smacking his withered lips over it for a moment, the old
Title:  negro muttered, "Best cooked 'teak I eber taste; joosy, berry joosy."
Title:  
Title:  "Cook," said Stubb, squaring himself once more; "do you belong to the
Title:  church?"
Title:  
Title:  "Passed one once in Cape-Down," said the old man sullenly.
Title:  
Title:  "And you have once in your life passed a holy church in Cape-Town,
Title:  where you doubtless overheard a holy parson addressing his hearers as
Title:  his beloved fellow-creatures, have you, cook!  And yet you come here,
Title:  and tell me such a dreadful lie as you did just now, eh?" said Stubb.
Title:  "Where do you expect to go to, cook?"
Title:  
Title:  "Go to bed berry soon," he mumbled, half-turning as he spoke.
Title:  
Title:  "Avast! heave to!  I mean when you die, cook.  It's an awful
Title:  question.  Now what's your answer?"
Title:  
Title:  "When dis old brack man dies," said the negro slowly, changing his
Title:  whole air and demeanor, "he hisself won't go nowhere; but some
Title:  bressed angel will come and fetch him."
Title:  
Title:  "Fetch him?  How?  In a coach and four, as they fetched Elijah?  And
Title:  fetch him where?"
Title:  
Title:  "Up dere," said Fleece, holding his tongs straight over his head, and
Title:  keeping it there very solemnly.
Title:  
Title:  "So, then, you expect to go up into our main-top, do you, cook, when
Title:  you are dead?  But don't you know the higher you climb, the colder it
Title:  gets?  Main-top, eh?"
Title:  
Title:  "Didn't say dat t'all," said Fleece, again in the sulks.
Title:  
Title:  "You said up there, didn't you? and now look yourself, and see where
Title:  your tongs are pointing.  But, perhaps you expect to get into heaven
Title:  by crawling through the lubber's hole, cook; but, no, no, cook, you
Title:  don't get there, except you go the regular way, round by the rigging.
Title:  It's a ticklish business, but must be done, or else it's no go.  But
Title:  none of us are in heaven yet.  Drop your tongs, cook, and hear my
Title:  orders.  Do ye hear?  Hold your hat in one hand, and clap t'other
Title:  a'top of your heart, when I'm giving my orders, cook.  What! that
Title:  your heart, there?--that's your gizzard!  Aloft! aloft!--that's
Title:  it--now you have it.  Hold it there now, and pay attention."
Title:  
Title:  "All 'dention," said the old black, with both hands placed as
Title:  desired, vainly wriggling his grizzled head, as if to get both ears
Title:  in front at one and the same time.
Title:  
Title:  "Well then, cook, you see this whale-steak of yours was so very bad,
Title:  that I have put it out of sight as soon as possible; you see that,
Title:  don't you?  Well, for the future, when you cook another whale-steak
Title:  for my private table here, the capstan, I'll tell you what to do so
Title:  as not to spoil it by overdoing.  Hold the steak in one hand, and
Title:  show a live coal to it with the other; that done, dish it; d'ye hear?
Title:  And now to-morrow, cook, when we are cutting in the fish, be sure
Title:  you stand by to get the tips of his fins; have them put in pickle.
Title:  As for the ends of the flukes, have them soused, cook.  There, now ye
Title:  may go."
Title:  
Title:  But Fleece had hardly got three paces off, when he was recalled.
Title:  
Title:  "Cook, give me cutlets for supper to-morrow night in the mid-watch.
Title:  D'ye hear? away you sail, then.--Halloa! stop! make a bow before you
Title:  go.--Avast heaving again!  Whale-balls for breakfast--don't forget."
Title:  
Title:  "Wish, by gor! whale eat him, 'stead of him eat whale.  I'm bressed
Title:  if he ain't more of shark dan Massa Shark hisself," muttered the old
Title:  man, limping away; with which sage ejaculation he went to his
Title:  hammock.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 65
Title:  
Title:  The Whale as a Dish.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  That mortal man should feed upon the creature that feeds his lamp,
Title:  and, like Stubb, eat him by his own light, as you may say; this seems
Title:  so outlandish a thing that one must needs go a little into the
Title:  history and philosophy of it.
Title:  
Title:  It is upon record, that three centuries ago the tongue of the Right
Title:  Whale was esteemed a great delicacy in France, and commanded large
Title:  prices there.  Also, that in Henry VIIIth's time, a certain cook of
Title:  the court obtained a handsome reward for inventing an admirable sauce
Title:  to be eaten with barbacued porpoises, which, you remember, are a
Title:  species of whale.  Porpoises, indeed, are to this day considered fine
Title:  eating.  The meat is made into balls about the size of billiard
Title:  balls, and being well seasoned and spiced might be taken for
Title:  turtle-balls or veal balls.  The old monks of Dunfermline were very
Title:  fond of them.  They had a great porpoise grant from the crown.
Title:  
Title:  The fact is, that among his hunters at least, the whale would by all
Title:  hands be considered a noble dish, were there not so much of him; but
Title:  when you come to sit down before a meat-pie nearly one hundred feet
Title:  long, it takes away your appetite.  Only the most unprejudiced of men
Title:  like Stubb, nowadays partake of cooked whales; but the Esquimaux are
Title:  not so fastidious.  We all know how they live upon whales, and have
Title:  rare old vintages of prime old train oil.  Zogranda, one of their
Title:  most famous doctors, recommends strips of blubber for infants, as
Title:  being exceedingly juicy and nourishing.  And this reminds me that
Title:  certain Englishmen, who long ago were accidentally left in Greenland
Title:  by a whaling vessel--that these men actually lived for several months
Title:  on the mouldy scraps of whales which had been left ashore after
Title:  trying out the blubber.  Among the Dutch whalemen these scraps are
Title:  called "fritters"; which, indeed, they greatly resemble, being brown
Title:  and crisp, and smelling something like old Amsterdam housewives'
Title:  dough-nuts or oly-cooks, when fresh.  They have such an eatable look
Title:  that the most self-denying stranger can hardly keep his hands off.
Title:  
Title:  But what further depreciates the whale as a civilized dish, is his
Title:  exceeding richness.  He is the great prize ox of the sea, too fat to
Title:  be delicately good.  Look at his hump, which would be as fine eating
Title:  as the buffalo's (which is esteemed a rare dish), were it not such a
Title:  solid pyramid of fat.  But the spermaceti itself, how bland and
Title:  creamy that is; like the transparent, half-jellied, white meat of a
Title:  cocoanut in the third month of its growth, yet far too rich to supply
Title:  a substitute for butter.  Nevertheless, many whalemen have a method
Title:  of absorbing it into some other substance, and then partaking of it.
Title:  In the long try watches of the night it is a common thing for the
Title:  seamen to dip their ship-biscuit into the huge oil-pots and let them
Title:  fry there awhile.  Many a good supper have I thus made.
Title:  
Title:  In the case of a small Sperm Whale the brains are accounted a fine
Title:  dish.  The casket of the skull is broken into with an axe, and the
Title:  two plump, whitish lobes being withdrawn (precisely resembling two
Title:  large puddings), they are then mixed with flour, and cooked into a
Title:  most delectable mess, in flavor somewhat resembling calves' head,
Title:  which is quite a dish among some epicures; and every one knows that
Title:  some young bucks among the epicures, by continually dining upon
Title:  calves' brains, by and by get to have a little brains of their own,
Title:  so as to be able to tell a calf's head from their own heads; which,
Title:  indeed, requires uncommon discrimination.  And that is the reason why
Title:  a young buck with an intelligent looking calf's head before him, is
Title:  somehow one of the saddest sights you can see.  The head looks a sort
Title:  of reproachfully at him, with an "Et tu Brute!" expression.
Title:  
Title:  It is not, perhaps, entirely because the whale is so excessively
Title:  unctuous that landsmen seem to regard the eating of him with
Title:  abhorrence; that appears to result, in some way, from the
Title:  consideration before mentioned: i.e. that a man should eat a newly
Title:  murdered thing of the sea, and eat it too by its own light.  But no
Title:  doubt the first man that ever murdered an ox was regarded as a
Title:  murderer; perhaps he was hung; and if he had been put on his trial by
Title:  oxen, he certainly would have been; and he certainly deserved it if
Title:  any murderer does.  Go to the meat-market of a Saturday night and see
Title:  the crowds of live bipeds staring up at the long rows of dead
Title:  quadrupeds.  Does not that sight take a tooth out of the cannibal's
Title:  jaw?  Cannibals? who is not a cannibal?  I tell you it will be more
Title:  tolerable for the Fejee that salted down a lean missionary in his
Title:  cellar against a coming famine; it will be more tolerable for that
Title:  provident Fejee, I say, in the day of judgment, than for thee,
Title:  civilized and enlightened gourmand, who nailest geese to the ground
Title:  and feastest on their bloated livers in thy pate-de-foie-gras.
Title:  
Title:  But Stubb, he eats the whale by its own light, does he? and that is
Title:  adding insult to injury, is it?  Look at your knife-handle, there, my
Title:  civilized and enlightened gourmand dining off that roast beef, what
Title:  is that handle made of?--what but the bones of the brother of the
Title:  very ox you are eating?  And what do you pick your teeth with, after
Title:  devouring that fat goose?  With a feather of the same fowl.  And with
Title:  what quill did the Secretary of the Society for the Suppression of
Title:  Cruelty to Ganders formally indite his circulars?  It is only within
Title:  the last month or two that that society passed a resolution to
Title:  patronise nothing but steel pens.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 66
Title:  
Title:  The Shark Massacre.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  When in the Southern Fishery, a captured Sperm Whale, after long and
Title:  weary toil, is brought alongside late at night, it is not, as a
Title:  general thing at least, customary to proceed at once to the business
Title:  of cutting him in.  For that business is an exceedingly laborious
Title:  one; is not very soon completed; and requires all hands to set about
Title:  it.  Therefore, the common usage is to take in all sail; lash the
Title:  helm a'lee; and then send every one below to his hammock till
Title:  daylight, with the reservation that, until that time, anchor-watches
Title:  shall be kept; that is, two and two for an hour, each couple, the
Title:  crew in rotation shall mount the deck to see that all goes well.
Title:  
Title:  But sometimes, especially upon the Line in the Pacific, this plan
Title:  will not answer at all; because such incalculable hosts of sharks
Title:  gather round the moored carcase, that were he left so for six hours,
Title:  say, on a stretch, little more than the skeleton would be visible by
Title:  morning.  In most other parts of the ocean, however, where these fish
Title:  do not so largely abound, their wondrous voracity can be at times
Title:  considerably diminished, by vigorously stirring them up with sharp
Title:  whaling-spades, a procedure notwithstanding, which, in some
Title:  instances, only seems to tickle them into still greater activity.
Title:  But it was not thus in the present case with the Pequod's sharks;
Title:  though, to be sure, any man unaccustomed to such sights, to have
Title:  looked over her side that night, would have almost thought the whole
Title:  round sea was one huge cheese, and those sharks the maggots in it.
Title:  
Title:  Nevertheless, upon Stubb setting the anchor-watch after his supper
Title:  was concluded; and when, accordingly, Queequeg and a forecastle
Title:  seaman came on deck, no small excitement was created among the
Title:  sharks; for immediately suspending the cutting stages over the side,
Title:  and lowering three lanterns, so that they cast long gleams of light
Title:  over the turbid sea, these two mariners, darting their long
Title:  whaling-spades, kept up an incessant murdering of the sharks,* by
Title:  striking the keen steel deep into their skulls, seemingly their only
Title:  vital part.  But in the foamy confusion of their mixed and struggling
Title:  hosts, the marksmen could not always hit their mark; and this brought
Title:  about new revelations of the incredible ferocity of the foe.  They
Title:  viciously snapped, not only at each other's disembowelments, but like
Title:  flexible bows, bent round, and bit their own; till those entrails
Title:  seemed swallowed over and over again by the same mouth, to be
Title:  oppositely voided by the gaping wound.  Nor was this all.  It was
Title:  unsafe to meddle with the corpses and ghosts of these creatures.  A
Title:  sort of generic or Pantheistic vitality seemed to lurk in their very
Title:  joints and bones, after what might be called the individual life had
Title:  departed.  Killed and hoisted on deck for the sake of his skin, one
Title:  of these sharks almost took poor Queequeg's hand off, when he tried
Title:  to shut down the dead lid of his murderous jaw.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *The whaling-spade used for cutting-in is made of the very best
Title:  steel; is about the bigness of a man's spread hand; and in general
Title:  shape, corresponds to the garden implement after which it is named;
Title:  only its sides are perfectly flat, and its upper end considerably
Title:  narrower than the lower.  This weapon is always kept as sharp as
Title:  possible; and when being used is occasionally honed, just like a
Title:  razor.  In its socket, a stiff pole, from twenty to thirty feet long,
Title:  is inserted for a handle.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "Queequeg no care what god made him shark," said the savage,
Title:  agonizingly lifting his hand up and down; "wedder Fejee god or
Title:  Nantucket god; but de god wat made shark must be one dam Ingin."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 67
Title:  
Title:  Cutting In.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  It was a Saturday night, and such a Sabbath as followed!  Ex officio
Title:  professors of Sabbath breaking are all whalemen.  The ivory Pequod
Title:  was turned into what seemed a shamble; every sailor a butcher.  You
Title:  would have thought we were offering up ten thousand red oxen to the
Title:  sea gods.
Title:  
Title:  In the first place, the enormous cutting tackles, among other
Title:  ponderous things comprising a cluster of blocks generally painted
Title:  green, and which no single man can possibly lift--this vast bunch of
Title:  grapes was swayed up to the main-top and firmly lashed to the lower
Title:  mast-head, the strongest point anywhere above a ship's deck.  The end
Title:  of the hawser-like rope winding through these intricacies, was then
Title:  conducted to the windlass, and the huge lower block of the tackles
Title:  was swung over the whale; to this block the great blubber hook,
Title:  weighing some one hundred pounds, was attached.  And now suspended in
Title:  stages over the side, Starbuck and Stubb, the mates, armed with their
Title:  long spades, began cutting a hole in the body for the insertion of
Title:  the hook just above the nearest of the two side-fins.  This done, a
Title:  broad, semicircular line is cut round the hole, the hook is inserted,
Title:  and the main body of the crew striking up a wild chorus, now commence
Title:  heaving in one dense crowd at the windlass.  When instantly, the
Title:  entire ship careens over on her side; every bolt in her starts like
Title:  the nail-heads of an old house in frosty weather; she trembles,
Title:  quivers, and nods her frighted mast-heads to the sky.  More and more
Title:  she leans over to the whale, while every gasping heave of the
Title:  windlass is answered by a helping heave from the billows; till at
Title:  last, a swift, startling snap is heard; with a great swash the ship
Title:  rolls upwards and backwards from the whale, and the triumphant tackle
Title:  rises into sight dragging after it the disengaged semicircular end of
Title:  the first strip of blubber.  Now as the blubber envelopes the whale
Title:  precisely as the rind does an orange, so is it stripped off from the
Title:  body precisely as an orange is sometimes stripped by spiralizing it.
Title:  For the strain constantly kept up by the windlass continually keeps
Title:  the whale rolling over and over in the water, and as the blubber in
Title:  one strip uniformly peels off along the line called the "scarf,"
Title:  simultaneously cut by the spades of Starbuck and Stubb, the mates;
Title:  and just as fast as it is thus peeled off, and indeed by that very
Title:  act itself, it is all the time being hoisted higher and higher aloft
Title:  till its upper end grazes the main-top; the men at the windlass then
Title:  cease heaving, and for a moment or two the prodigious blood-dripping
Title:  mass sways to and fro as if let down from the sky, and every one
Title:  present must take good heed to dodge it when it swings, else it may
Title:  box his ears and pitch him headlong overboard.
Title:  
Title:  One of the attending harpooneers now advances with a long, keen
Title:  weapon called a boarding-sword, and watching his chance he
Title:  dexterously slices out a considerable hole in the lower part of the
Title:  swaying mass.  Into this hole, the end of the second alternating
Title:  great tackle is then hooked so as to retain a hold upon the blubber,
Title:  in order to prepare for what follows.  Whereupon, this accomplished
Title:  swordsman, warning all hands to stand off, once more makes a
Title:  scientific dash at the mass, and with a few sidelong, desperate,
Title:  lunging slicings, severs it completely in twain; so that while the
Title:  short lower part is still fast, the long upper strip, called a
Title:  blanket-piece, swings clear, and is all ready for lowering.  The
Title:  heavers forward now resume their song, and while the one tackle is
Title:  peeling and hoisting a second strip from the whale, the other is
Title:  slowly slackened away, and down goes the first strip through the main
Title:  hatchway right beneath, into an unfurnished parlor called the
Title:  blubber-room.  Into this twilight apartment sundry nimble hands keep
Title:  coiling away the long blanket-piece as if it were a great live mass
Title:  of plaited serpents.  And thus the work proceeds; the two tackles
Title:  hoisting and lowering simultaneously; both whale and windlass
Title:  heaving, the heavers singing, the blubber-room gentlemen coiling, the
Title:  mates scarfing, the ship straining, and all hands swearing
Title:  occasionally, by way of assuaging the general friction.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 68
Title:  
Title:  The Blanket.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  I have given no small attention to that not unvexed subject, the skin
Title:  of the whale.  I have had controversies about it with experienced
Title:  whalemen afloat, and learned naturalists ashore.  My original opinion
Title:  remains unchanged; but it is only an opinion.
Title:  
Title:  The question is, what and where is the skin of the whale?  Already
Title:  you know what his blubber is.  That blubber is something of the
Title:  consistence of firm, close-grained beef, but tougher, more elastic
Title:  and compact, and ranges from eight or ten to twelve and fifteen
Title:  inches in thickness.
Title:  
Title:  Now, however preposterous it may at first seem to talk of any
Title:  creature's skin as being of that sort of consistence and thickness,
Title:  yet in point of fact these are no arguments against such a
Title:  presumption; because you cannot raise any other dense enveloping
Title:  layer from the whale's body but that same blubber; and the outermost
Title:  enveloping layer of any animal, if reasonably dense, what can that be
Title:  but the skin?  True, from the unmarred dead body of the whale, you
Title:  may scrape off with your hand an infinitely thin, transparent
Title:  substance, somewhat resembling the thinnest shreds of isinglass, only
Title:  it is almost as flexible and soft as satin; that is, previous to
Title:  being dried, when it not only contracts and thickens, but becomes
Title:  rather hard and brittle.  I have several such dried bits, which I use
Title:  for marks in my whale-books.  It is transparent, as I said before;
Title:  and being laid upon the printed page, I have sometimes pleased myself
Title:  with fancying it exerted a magnifying influence.  At any rate, it is
Title:  pleasant to read about whales through their own spectacles, as you
Title:  may say.  But what I am driving at here is this.  That same
Title:  infinitely thin, isinglass substance, which, I admit, invests the
Title:  entire body of the whale, is not so much to be regarded as the skin
Title:  of the creature, as the skin of the skin, so to speak; for it were
Title:  simply ridiculous to say, that the proper skin of the tremendous
Title:  whale is thinner and more tender than the skin of a new-born child.
Title:  But no more of this.
Title:  
Title:  Assuming the blubber to be the skin of the whale; then, when this
Title:  skin, as in the case of a very large Sperm Whale, will yield the bulk
Title:  of one hundred barrels of oil; and, when it is considered that, in
Title:  quantity, or rather weight, that oil, in its expressed state, is only
Title:  three fourths, and not the entire substance of the coat; some idea
Title:  may hence be had of the enormousness of that animated mass, a mere
Title:  part of whose mere integument yields such a lake of liquid as that.
Title:  Reckoning ten barrels to the ton, you have ten tons for the net
Title:  weight of only three quarters of the stuff of the whale's skin.
Title:  
Title:  In life, the visible surface of the Sperm Whale is not the least
Title:  among the many marvels he presents.  Almost invariably it is all over
Title:  obliquely crossed and re-crossed with numberless straight marks in
Title:  thick array, something like those in the finest Italian line
Title:  engravings.  But these marks do not seem to be impressed upon the
Title:  isinglass substance above mentioned, but seem to be seen through it,
Title:  as if they were engraved upon the body itself.  Nor is this all.  In
Title:  some instances, to the quick, observant eye, those linear marks, as
Title:  in a veritable engraving, but afford the ground for far other
Title:  delineations.  These are hieroglyphical; that is, if you call those
Title:  mysterious cyphers on the walls of pyramids hieroglyphics, then that
Title:  is the proper word to use in the present connexion.  By my retentive
Title:  memory of the hieroglyphics upon one Sperm Whale in particular, I was
Title:  much struck with a plate representing the old Indian characters
Title:  chiselled on the famous hieroglyphic palisades on the banks of the
Title:  Upper Mississippi.  Like those mystic rocks, too, the mystic-marked
Title:  whale remains undecipherable.  This allusion to the Indian rocks
Title:  reminds me of another thing.  Besides all the other phenomena which
Title:  the exterior of the Sperm Whale presents, he not seldom displays the
Title:  back, and more especially his flanks, effaced in great part of the
Title:  regular linear appearance, by reason of numerous rude scratches,
Title:  altogether of an irregular, random aspect.  I should say that those
Title:  New England rocks on the sea-coast, which Agassiz imagines to bear
Title:  the marks of violent scraping contact with vast floating icebergs--I
Title:  should say, that those rocks must not a little resemble the Sperm
Title:  Whale in this particular.  It also seems to me that such scratches in
Title:  the whale are probably made by hostile contact with other whales; for
Title:  I have most remarked them in the large, full-grown bulls of the
Title:  species.
Title:  
Title:  A word or two more concerning this matter of the skin or blubber of
Title:  the whale.  It has already been said, that it is stript from him in
Title:  long pieces, called blanket-pieces.  Like most sea-terms, this one is
Title:  very happy and significant.  For the whale is indeed wrapt up in his
Title:  blubber as in a real blanket or counterpane; or, still better, an
Title:  Indian poncho slipt over his head, and skirting his extremity.  It is
Title:  by reason of this cosy blanketing of his body, that the whale is
Title:  enabled to keep himself comfortable in all weathers, in all seas,
Title:  times, and tides.  What would become of a Greenland whale, say, in
Title:  those shuddering, icy seas of the North, if unsupplied with his cosy
Title:  surtout?  True, other fish are found exceedingly brisk in those
Title:  Hyperborean waters; but these, be it observed, are your cold-blooded,
Title:  lungless fish, whose very bellies are refrigerators; creatures, that
Title:  warm themselves under the lee of an iceberg, as a traveller in winter
Title:  would bask before an inn fire; whereas, like man, the whale has lungs
Title:  and warm blood.  Freeze his blood, and he dies.  How wonderful is it
Title:  then--except after explanation--that this great monster, to whom
Title:  corporeal warmth is as indispensable as it is to man; how wonderful
Title:  that he should be found at home, immersed to his lips for life in
Title:  those Arctic waters! where, when seamen fall overboard, they are
Title:  sometimes found, months afterwards, perpendicularly frozen into the
Title:  hearts of fields of ice, as a fly is found glued in amber.  But more
Title:  surprising is it to know, as has been proved by experiment, that the
Title:  blood of a Polar whale is warmer than that of a Borneo negro in
Title:  summer.
Title:  
Title:  It does seem to me, that herein we see the rare virtue of a strong
Title:  individual vitality, and the rare virtue of thick walls, and the rare
Title:  virtue of interior spaciousness.  Oh, man! admire and model thyself
Title:  after the whale!  Do thou, too, remain warm among ice.  Do thou, too,
Title:  live in this world without being of it.  Be cool at the equator; keep
Title:  thy blood fluid at the Pole.  Like the great dome of St. Peter's, and
Title:  like the great whale, retain, O man! in all seasons a temperature of
Title:  thine own.
Title:  
Title:  But how easy and how hopeless to teach these fine things!  Of
Title:  erections, how few are domed like St. Peter's! of creatures, how few
Title:  vast as the whale!
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 69
Title:  
Title:  The Funeral.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Haul in the chains!  Let the carcase go astern!
Title:  
Title:  The vast tackles have now done their duty.  The peeled white body of
Title:  the beheaded whale flashes like a marble sepulchre; though changed in
Title:  hue, it has not perceptibly lost anything in bulk.  It is still
Title:  colossal.  Slowly it floats more and more away, the water round it
Title:  torn and splashed by the insatiate sharks, and the air above vexed
Title:  with rapacious flights of screaming fowls, whose beaks are like so
Title:  many insulting poniards in the whale.  The vast white headless
Title:  phantom floats further and further from the ship, and every rod that
Title:  it so floats, what seem square roods of sharks and cubic roods of
Title:  fowls, augment the murderous din.  For hours and hours from the
Title:  almost stationary ship that hideous sight is seen.  Beneath the
Title:  unclouded and mild azure sky, upon the fair face of the pleasant sea,
Title:  wafted by the joyous breezes, that great mass of death floats on and
Title:  on, till lost in infinite perspectives.
Title:  
Title:  There's a most doleful and most mocking funeral!  The sea-vultures
Title:  all in pious mourning, the air-sharks all punctiliously in black or
Title:  speckled.  In life but few of them would have helped the whale, I
Title:  ween, if peradventure he had needed it; but upon the banquet of his
Title:  funeral they most piously do pounce.  Oh, horrible vultureism of
Title:  earth! from which not the mightiest whale is free.
Title:  
Title:  Nor is this the end.  Desecrated as the body is, a vengeful ghost
Title:  survives and hovers over it to scare.  Espied by some timid
Title:  man-of-war or blundering discovery-vessel from afar, when the
Title:  distance obscuring the swarming fowls, nevertheless still shows the
Title:  white mass floating in the sun, and the white spray heaving high
Title:  against it; straightway the whale's unharming corpse, with trembling
Title:  fingers is set down in the log--SHOALS, ROCKS, AND BREAKERS
Title:  HEREABOUTS: BEWARE!  And for years afterwards, perhaps, ships shun
Title:  the place; leaping over it as silly sheep leap over a vacuum, because
Title:  their leader originally leaped there when a stick was held.  There's
Title:  your law of precedents; there's your utility of traditions; there's
Title:  the story of your obstinate survival of old beliefs never bottomed on
Title:  the earth, and now not even hovering in the air!  There's orthodoxy!
Title:  
Title:  Thus, while in life the great whale's body may have been a real
Title:  terror to his foes, in his death his ghost becomes a powerless panic
Title:  to a world.
Title:  
Title:  Are you a believer in ghosts, my friend?  There are other ghosts than
Title:  the Cock-Lane one, and far deeper men than Doctor Johnson who believe
Title:  in them.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 70
Title:  
Title:  The Sphynx.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  It should not have been omitted that previous to completely stripping
Title:  the body of the leviathan, he was beheaded.  Now, the beheading of
Title:  the Sperm Whale is a scientific anatomical feat, upon which
Title:  experienced whale surgeons very much pride themselves: and not
Title:  without reason.
Title:  
Title:  Consider that the whale has nothing that can properly be called a
Title:  neck; on the contrary, where his head and body seem to join, there,
Title:  in that very place, is the thickest part of him.  Remember, also,
Title:  that the surgeon must operate from above, some eight or ten feet
Title:  intervening between him and his subject, and that subject almost
Title:  hidden in a discoloured, rolling, and oftentimes tumultuous and
Title:  bursting sea.  Bear in mind, too, that under these untoward
Title:  circumstances he has to cut many feet deep in the flesh; and in that
Title:  subterraneous manner, without so much as getting one single peep into
Title:  the ever-contracting gash thus made, he must skilfully steer clear
Title:  of all adjacent, interdicted parts, and exactly divide the spine at a
Title:  critical point hard by its insertion into the skull.  Do you not
Title:  marvel, then, at Stubb's boast, that he demanded but ten minutes to
Title:  behead a sperm whale?
Title:  
Title:  When first severed, the head is dropped astern and held there by a
Title:  cable till the body is stripped.  That done, if it belong to a small
Title:  whale it is hoisted on deck to be deliberately disposed of.  But,
Title:  with a full grown leviathan this is impossible; for the sperm whale's
Title:  head embraces nearly one third of his entire bulk, and completely to
Title:  suspend such a burden as that, even by the immense tackles of a
Title:  whaler, this were as vain a thing as to attempt weighing a Dutch barn
Title:  in jewellers' scales.
Title:  
Title:  The Pequod's whale being decapitated and the body stripped, the head
Title:  was hoisted against the ship's side--about half way out of the sea,
Title:  so that it might yet in great part be buoyed up by its native
Title:  element.  And there with the strained craft steeply leaning over to it,
Title:  by reason of the enormous downward drag from the lower mast-head, and
Title:  every yard-arm on that side projecting like a crane over the waves;
Title:  there, that blood-dripping head hung to the Pequod's waist like the
Title:  giant Holofernes's from the girdle of Judith.
Title:  
Title:  When this last task was accomplished it was noon, and the seamen went
Title:  below to their dinner.  Silence reigned over the before tumultuous
Title:  but now deserted deck.  An intense copper calm, like a universal
Title:  yellow lotus, was more and more unfolding its noiseless measureless
Title:  leaves upon the sea.
Title:  
Title:  A short space elapsed, and up into this noiselessness came Ahab alone
Title:  from his cabin.  Taking a few turns on the quarter-deck, he paused to
Title:  gaze over the side, then slowly getting into the main-chains he took
Title:  Stubb's long spade--still remaining there after the whale's
Title:  Decapitation--and striking it into the lower part of the
Title:  half-suspended mass, placed its other end crutch-wise under one arm,
Title:  and so stood leaning over with eyes attentively fixed on this head.
Title:  
Title:  It was a black and hooded head; and hanging there in the midst of so
Title:  intense a calm, it seemed the Sphynx's in the desert.  "Speak, thou
Title:  vast and venerable head," muttered Ahab, "which, though ungarnished
Title:  with a beard, yet here and there lookest hoary with mosses; speak,
Title:  mighty head, and tell us the secret thing that is in thee.  Of all
Title:  divers, thou hast dived the deepest.  That head upon which the upper
Title:  sun now gleams, has moved amid this world's foundations.  Where
Title:  unrecorded names and navies rust, and untold hopes and anchors rot;
Title:  where in her murderous hold this frigate earth is ballasted with
Title:  bones of millions of the drowned; there, in that awful water-land,
Title:  there was thy most familiar home.  Thou hast been where bell or diver
Title:  never went; hast slept by many a sailor's side, where sleepless
Title:  mothers would give their lives to lay them down.  Thou saw'st the
Title:  locked lovers when leaping from their flaming ship; heart to heart
Title:  they sank beneath the exulting wave; true to each other, when heaven
Title:  seemed false to them.  Thou saw'st the murdered mate when tossed by
Title:  pirates from the midnight deck; for hours he fell into the deeper
Title:  midnight of the insatiate maw; and his murderers still sailed on
Title:  unharmed--while swift lightnings shivered the neighboring ship that
Title:  would have borne a righteous husband to outstretched, longing arms.
Title:  O head! thou hast seen enough to split the planets and make an
Title:  infidel of Abraham, and not one syllable is thine!"
Title:  
Title:  "Sail ho!" cried a triumphant voice from the main-mast-head.
Title:  
Title:  "Aye?  Well, now, that's cheering," cried Ahab, suddenly erecting
Title:  himself, while whole thunder-clouds swept aside from his brow.  "That
Title:  lively cry upon this deadly calm might almost convert a better
Title:  man.--Where away?"
Title:  
Title:  "Three points on the starboard bow, sir, and bringing down her breeze
Title:  to us!
Title:  
Title:  "Better and better, man.  Would now St. Paul would come along that
Title:  way, and to my breezelessness bring his breeze!  O Nature, and O soul
Title:  of man! how far beyond all utterance are your linked analogies! not
Title:  the smallest atom stirs or lives on matter, but has its cunning
Title:  duplicate in mind."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 71
Title:  
Title:  The Jeroboam's Story.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Hand in hand, ship and breeze blew on; but the breeze came faster
Title:  than the ship, and soon the Pequod began to rock.
Title:  
Title:  By and by, through the glass the stranger's boats and manned
Title:  mast-heads proved her a whale-ship.  But as she was so far to
Title:  windward, and shooting by, apparently making a passage to some other
Title:  ground, the Pequod could not hope to reach her.  So the signal was
Title:  set to see what response would be made.
Title:  
Title:  Here be it said, that like the vessels of military marines, the ships
Title:  of the American Whale Fleet have each a private signal; all which
Title:  signals being collected in a book with the names of the respective
Title:  vessels attached, every captain is provided with it.  Thereby, the
Title:  whale commanders are enabled to recognise each other upon the ocean,
Title:  even at considerable distances and with no small facility.
Title:  
Title:  The Pequod's signal was at last responded to by the stranger's
Title:  setting her own; which proved the ship to be the Jeroboam of
Title:  Nantucket.  Squaring her yards, she bore down, ranged abeam under the
Title:  Pequod's lee, and lowered a boat; it soon drew nigh; but, as the
Title:  side-ladder was being rigged by Starbuck's order to accommodate the
Title:  visiting captain, the stranger in question waved his hand from his
Title:  boat's stern in token of that proceeding being entirely unnecessary.
Title:  It turned out that the Jeroboam had a malignant epidemic on board,
Title:  and that Mayhew, her captain, was fearful of infecting the Pequod's
Title:  company.  For, though himself and boat's crew remained untainted, and
Title:  though his ship was half a rifle-shot off, and an incorruptible sea
Title:  and air rolling and flowing between; yet conscientiously adhering to
Title:  the timid quarantine of the land, he peremptorily refused to come
Title:  into direct contact with the Pequod.
Title:  
Title:  But this did by no means prevent all communications.  Preserving an
Title:  interval of some few yards between itself and the ship, the
Title:  Jeroboam's boat by the occasional use of its oars contrived to keep
Title:  parallel to the Pequod, as she heavily forged through the sea (for by
Title:  this time it blew very fresh), with her main-topsail aback; though,
Title:  indeed, at times by the sudden onset of a large rolling wave, the
Title:  boat would be pushed some way ahead; but would be soon skilfully
Title:  brought to her proper bearings again.  Subject to this, and other the
Title:  like interruptions now and then, a conversation was sustained between
Title:  the two parties; but at intervals not without still another
Title:  interruption of a very different sort.
Title:  
Title:  Pulling an oar in the Jeroboam's boat, was a man of a singular
Title:  appearance, even in that wild whaling life where individual
Title:  notabilities make up all totalities.  He was a small, short, youngish
Title:  man, sprinkled all over his face with freckles, and wearing redundant
Title:  yellow hair.  A long-skirted, cabalistically-cut coat of a faded
Title:  walnut tinge enveloped him; the overlapping sleeves of which were
Title:  rolled up on his wrists.  A deep, settled, fanatic delirium was in
Title:  his eyes.
Title:  
Title:  So soon as this figure had been first descried, Stubb had
Title:  exclaimed--"That's he! that's he!--the long-togged scaramouch the
Title:  Town-Ho's company told us of!"  Stubb here alluded to a strange story
Title:  told of the Jeroboam, and a certain man among her crew, some time
Title:  previous when the Pequod spoke the Town-Ho.  According to this
Title:  account and what was subsequently learned, it seemed that the
Title:  scaramouch in question had gained a wonderful ascendency over almost
Title:  everybody in the Jeroboam.  His story was this:
Title:  
Title:  He had been originally nurtured among the crazy society of Neskyeuna
Title:  Shakers, where he had been a great prophet; in their cracked, secret
Title:  meetings having several times descended from heaven by the way of a
Title:  trap-door, announcing the speedy opening of the seventh vial, which
Title:  he carried in his vest-pocket; but, which, instead of containing
Title:  gunpowder, was supposed to be charged with laudanum.  A strange,
Title:  apostolic whim having seized him, he had left Neskyeuna for
Title:  Nantucket, where, with that cunning peculiar to craziness, he assumed
Title:  a steady, common-sense exterior, and offered himself as a green-hand
Title:  candidate for the Jeroboam's whaling voyage.  They engaged him; but
Title:  straightway upon the ship's getting out of sight of land, his
Title:  insanity broke out in a freshet.  He announced himself as the
Title:  archangel Gabriel, and commanded the captain to jump overboard.  He
Title:  published his manifesto, whereby he set himself forth as the
Title:  deliverer of the isles of the sea and vicar-general of all Oceanica.
Title:  The unflinching earnestness with which he declared these things;--the
Title:  dark, daring play of his sleepless, excited imagination, and all the
Title:  preternatural terrors of real delirium, united to invest this Gabriel
Title:  in the minds of the majority of the ignorant crew, with an atmosphere
Title:  of sacredness.  Moreover, they were afraid of him.  As such a man,
Title:  however, was not of much practical use in the ship, especially as he
Title:  refused to work except when he pleased, the incredulous captain would
Title:  fain have been rid of him; but apprised that that individual's
Title:  intention was to land him in the first convenient port, the archangel
Title:  forthwith opened all his seals and vials--devoting the ship and all
Title:  hands to unconditional perdition, in case this intention was carried
Title:  out.  So strongly did he work upon his disciples among the crew, that
Title:  at last in a body they went to the captain and told him if Gabriel
Title:  was sent from the ship, not a man of them would remain.  He was
Title:  therefore forced to relinquish his plan.  Nor would they permit
Title:  Gabriel to be any way maltreated, say or do what he would; so that it
Title:  came to pass that Gabriel had the complete freedom of the ship.  The
Title:  consequence of all this was, that the archangel cared little or
Title:  nothing for the captain and mates; and since the epidemic had broken
Title:  out, he carried a higher hand than ever; declaring that the plague,
Title:  as he called it, was at his sole command; nor should it be stayed but
Title:  according to his good pleasure.  The sailors, mostly poor devils,
Title:  cringed, and some of them fawned before him; in obedience to his
Title:  instructions, sometimes rendering him personal homage, as to a god.
Title:  Such things may seem incredible; but, however wondrous, they are
Title:  true.  Nor is the history of fanatics half so striking in respect to
Title:  the measureless self-deception of the fanatic himself, as his
Title:  measureless power of deceiving and bedevilling so many others.  But
Title:  it is time to return to the Pequod.
Title:  
Title:  "I fear not thy epidemic, man," said Ahab from the bulwarks, to
Title:  Captain Mayhew, who stood in the boat's stern; "come on board."
Title:  
Title:  But now Gabriel started to his feet.
Title:  
Title:  "Think, think of the fevers, yellow and bilious!  Beware of the
Title:  horrible plague!"
Title:  
Title:  "Gabriel!  Gabriel!" cried Captain Mayhew; "thou must either--"  But
Title:  that instant a headlong wave shot the boat far ahead, and its
Title:  seethings drowned all speech.
Title:  
Title:  "Hast thou seen the White Whale?" demanded Ahab, when the boat
Title:  drifted back.
Title:  
Title:  "Think, think of thy whale-boat, stoven and sunk!  Beware of the
Title:  horrible tail!"
Title:  
Title:  "I tell thee again, Gabriel, that--"  But again the boat tore ahead
Title:  as if dragged by fiends.  Nothing was said for some moments, while a
Title:  succession of riotous waves rolled by, which by one of those
Title:  occasional caprices of the seas were tumbling, not heaving it.
Title:  Meantime, the hoisted sperm whale's head jogged about very violently,
Title:  and Gabriel was seen eyeing it with rather more apprehensiveness than
Title:  his archangel nature seemed to warrant.
Title:  
Title:  When this interlude was over, Captain Mayhew began a dark story
Title:  concerning Moby Dick; not, however, without frequent interruptions
Title:  from Gabriel, whenever his name was mentioned, and the crazy sea that
Title:  seemed leagued with him.
Title:  
Title:  It seemed that the Jeroboam had not long left home, when upon
Title:  speaking a whale-ship, her people were reliably apprised of the
Title:  existence of Moby Dick, and the havoc he had made.  Greedily sucking
Title:  in this intelligence, Gabriel solemnly warned the captain against
Title:  attacking the White Whale, in case the monster should be seen; in his
Title:  gibbering insanity, pronouncing the White Whale to be no less a being
Title:  than the Shaker God incarnated; the Shakers receiving the Bible.  But
Title:  when, some year or two afterwards, Moby Dick was fairly sighted from
Title:  the mast-heads, Macey, the chief mate, burned with ardour to encounter
Title:  him; and the captain himself being not unwilling to let him have the
Title:  opportunity, despite all the archangel's denunciations and
Title:  forewarnings, Macey succeeded in persuading five men to man his boat.
Title:  With them he pushed off; and, after much weary pulling, and many
Title:  perilous, unsuccessful onsets, he at last succeeded in getting one
Title:  iron fast.  Meantime, Gabriel, ascending to the main-royal mast-head,
Title:  was tossing one arm in frantic gestures, and hurling forth prophecies
Title:  of speedy doom to the sacrilegious assailants of his divinity.  Now,
Title:  while Macey, the mate, was standing up in his boat's bow, and with
Title:  all the reckless energy of his tribe was venting his wild
Title:  exclamations upon the whale, and essaying to get a fair chance for
Title:  his poised lance, lo! a broad white shadow rose from the sea; by its
Title:  quick, fanning motion, temporarily taking the breath out of the
Title:  bodies of the oarsmen.  Next instant, the luckless mate, so full of
Title:  furious life, was smitten bodily into the air, and making a long arc
Title:  in his descent, fell into the sea at the distance of about fifty
Title:  yards.  Not a chip of the boat was harmed, nor a hair of any
Title:  oarsman's head; but the mate for ever sank.
Title:  
Title:  It is well to parenthesize here, that of the fatal accidents in the
Title:  Sperm-Whale Fishery, this kind is perhaps almost as frequent as any.
Title:  Sometimes, nothing is injured but the man who is thus annihilated;
Title:  oftener the boat's bow is knocked off, or the thigh-board, in which
Title:  the headsman stands, is torn from its place and accompanies the body.
Title:  But strangest of all is the circumstance, that in more instances
Title:  than one, when the body has been recovered, not a single mark of
Title:  violence is discernible; the man being stark dead.
Title:  
Title:  The whole calamity, with the falling form of Macey, was plainly
Title:  descried from the ship.  Raising a piercing shriek--"The vial! the
Title:  vial!"  Gabriel called off the terror-stricken crew from the further
Title:  hunting of the whale.  This terrible event clothed the archangel with
Title:  added influence; because his credulous disciples believed that he had
Title:  specifically fore-announced it, instead of only making a general
Title:  prophecy, which any one might have done, and so have chanced to hit
Title:  one of many marks in the wide margin allowed.  He became a nameless
Title:  terror to the ship.
Title:  
Title:  Mayhew having concluded his narration, Ahab put such questions to
Title:  him, that the stranger captain could not forbear inquiring whether he
Title:  intended to hunt the White Whale, if opportunity should offer.  To
Title:  which Ahab answered--"Aye."  Straightway, then, Gabriel once more
Title:  started to his feet, glaring upon the old man, and vehemently
Title:  exclaimed, with downward pointed finger--"Think, think of the
Title:  blasphemer--dead, and down there!--beware of the blasphemer's end!"
Title:  
Title:  Ahab stolidly turned aside; then said to Mayhew, "Captain, I have
Title:  just bethought me of my letter-bag; there is a letter for one of thy
Title:  officers, if I mistake not.  Starbuck, look over the bag."
Title:  
Title:  Every whale-ship takes out a goodly number of letters for various
Title:  ships, whose delivery to the persons to whom they may be addressed,
Title:  depends upon the mere chance of encountering them in the four oceans.
Title:  Thus, most letters never reach their mark; and many are only
Title:  received after attaining an age of two or three years or more.
Title:  
Title:  Soon Starbuck returned with a letter in his hand.  It was sorely
Title:  tumbled, damp, and covered with a dull, spotted, green mould, in
Title:  consequence of being kept in a dark locker of the cabin.  Of such a
Title:  letter, Death himself might well have been the post-boy.
Title:  
Title:  "Can'st not read it?" cried Ahab.  "Give it me, man.  Aye, aye, it's
Title:  but a dim scrawl;--what's this?"  As he was studying it out, Starbuck
Title:  took a long cutting-spade pole, and with his knife slightly split the
Title:  end, to insert the letter there, and in that way, hand it to the
Title:  boat, without its coming any closer to the ship.
Title:  
Title:  Meantime, Ahab holding the letter, muttered, "Mr. Har--yes, Mr.
Title:  Harry--(a woman's pinny hand,--the man's wife, I'll wager)--Aye--Mr.
Title:  Harry Macey, Ship Jeroboam;--why it's Macey, and he's dead!"
Title:  
Title:  "Poor fellow! poor fellow! and from his wife," sighed Mayhew; "but
Title:  let me have it."
Title:  
Title:  "Nay, keep it thyself," cried Gabriel to Ahab; "thou art soon going
Title:  that way."
Title:  
Title:  "Curses throttle thee!" yelled Ahab.  "Captain Mayhew, stand by now
Title:  to receive it"; and taking the fatal missive from Starbuck's hands,
Title:  he caught it in the slit of the pole, and reached it over towards the
Title:  boat.  But as he did so, the oarsmen expectantly desisted from
Title:  rowing; the boat drifted a little towards the ship's stern; so that,
Title:  as if by magic, the letter suddenly ranged along with Gabriel's eager
Title:  hand.  He clutched it in an instant, seized the boat-knife, and
Title:  impaling the letter on it, sent it thus loaded back into the ship.
Title:  It fell at Ahab's feet.  Then Gabriel shrieked out to his comrades to
Title:  give way with their oars, and in that manner the mutinous boat
Title:  rapidly shot away from the Pequod.
Title:  
Title:  As, after this interlude, the seamen resumed their work upon the
Title:  jacket of the whale, many strange things were hinted in reference to
Title:  this wild affair.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 72
Title:  
Title:  The Monkey-Rope.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  In the tumultuous business of cutting-in and attending to a whale,
Title:  there is much running backwards and forwards among the crew.  Now
Title:  hands are wanted here, and then again hands are wanted there.  There
Title:  is no staying in any one place; for at one and the same time
Title:  everything has to be done everywhere.  It is much the same with him
Title:  who endeavors the description of the scene.  We must now retrace our
Title:  way a little.  It was mentioned that upon first breaking ground in
Title:  the whale's back, the blubber-hook was inserted into the original
Title:  hole there cut by the spades of the mates.  But how did so clumsy and
Title:  weighty a mass as that same hook get fixed in that hole?  It was
Title:  inserted there by my particular friend Queequeg, whose duty it was,
Title:  as harpooneer, to descend upon the monster's back for the special
Title:  purpose referred to.  But in very many cases, circumstances require
Title:  that the harpooneer shall remain on the whale till the whole tensing
Title:  or stripping operation is concluded.  The whale, be it observed, lies
Title:  almost entirely submerged, excepting the immediate parts operated
Title:  upon.  So down there, some ten feet below the level of the deck, the
Title:  poor harpooneer flounders about, half on the whale and half in the
Title:  water, as the vast mass revolves like a tread-mill beneath him.  On
Title:  the occasion in question, Queequeg figured in the Highland costume--a
Title:  shirt and socks--in which to my eyes, at least, he appeared to
Title:  uncommon advantage; and no one had a better chance to observe him, as
Title:  will presently be seen.
Title:  
Title:  Being the savage's bowsman, that is, the person who pulled the
Title:  bow-oar in his boat (the second one from forward), it was my cheerful
Title:  duty to attend upon him while taking that hard-scrabble scramble upon
Title:  the dead whale's back.  You have seen Italian organ-boys holding a
Title:  dancing-ape by a long cord.  Just so, from the ship's steep side, did
Title:  I hold Queequeg down there in the sea, by what is technically called
Title:  in the fishery a monkey-rope, attached to a strong strip of canvas
Title:  belted round his waist.
Title:  
Title:  It was a humorously perilous business for both of us.  For, before we
Title:  proceed further, it must be said that the monkey-rope was fast at
Title:  both ends; fast to Queequeg's broad canvas belt, and fast to my
Title:  narrow leather one.  So that for better or for worse, we two, for the
Title:  time, were wedded; and should poor Queequeg sink to rise no more,
Title:  then both usage and honour demanded, that instead of cutting the cord,
Title:  it should drag me down in his wake.  So, then, an elongated Siamese
Title:  ligature united us.  Queequeg was my own inseparable twin brother;
Title:  nor could I any way get rid of the dangerous liabilities which the
Title:  hempen bond entailed.
Title:  
Title:  So strongly and metaphysically did I conceive of my situation then,
Title:  that while earnestly watching his motions, I seemed distinctly to
Title:  perceive that my own individuality was now merged in a joint stock
Title:  company of two; that my free will had received a mortal wound; and
Title:  that another's mistake or misfortune might plunge innocent me into
Title:  unmerited disaster and death.  Therefore, I saw that here was a sort
Title:  of interregnum in Providence; for its even-handed equity never could
Title:  have so gross an injustice.  And yet still further pondering--while I
Title:  jerked him now and then from between the whale and ship, which would
Title:  threaten to jam him--still further pondering, I say, I saw that this
Title:  situation of mine was the precise situation of every mortal that
Title:  breathes; only, in most cases, he, one way or other, has this Siamese
Title:  connexion with a plurality of other mortals.  If your banker breaks,
Title:  you snap; if your apothecary by mistake sends you poison in your
Title:  pills, you die.  True, you may say that, by exceeding caution, you
Title:  may possibly escape these and the multitudinous other evil chances of
Title:  life.  But handle Queequeg's monkey-rope heedfully as I would,
Title:  sometimes he jerked it so, that I came very near sliding overboard.
Title:  Nor could I possibly forget that, do what I would, I only had the
Title:  management of one end of it.*
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *The monkey-rope is found in all whalers; but it was only in the
Title:  Pequod that the monkey and his holder were ever tied together.  This
Title:  improvement upon the original usage was introduced by no less a man
Title:  than Stubb, in order to afford the imperilled harpooneer the strongest
Title:  possible guarantee for the faithfulness and vigilance of his
Title:  monkey-rope holder.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  I have hinted that I would often jerk poor Queequeg from between the
Title:  whale and the ship--where he would occasionally fall, from the
Title:  incessant rolling and swaying of both.  But this was not the only
Title:  jamming jeopardy he was exposed to.  Unappalled by the massacre made
Title:  upon them during the night, the sharks now freshly and more keenly
Title:  allured by the before pent blood which began to flow from the
Title:  carcass--the rabid creatures swarmed round it like bees in a beehive.
Title:  
Title:  And right in among those sharks was Queequeg; who often pushed them
Title:  aside with his floundering feet.  A thing altogether incredible were
Title:  it not that attracted by such prey as a dead whale, the otherwise
Title:  miscellaneously carnivorous shark will seldom touch a man.
Title:  
Title:  Nevertheless, it may well be believed that since they have such a
Title:  ravenous finger in the pie, it is deemed but wise to look sharp to
Title:  them.  Accordingly, besides the monkey-rope, with which I now and
Title:  then jerked the poor fellow from too close a vicinity to the maw of
Title:  what seemed a peculiarly ferocious shark--he was provided with still
Title:  another protection.  Suspended over the side in one of the stages,
Title:  Tashtego and Daggoo continually flourished over his head a couple of
Title:  keen whale-spades, wherewith they slaughtered as many sharks as they
Title:  could reach.  This procedure of theirs, to be sure, was very
Title:  disinterested and benevolent of them.  They meant Queequeg's best
Title:  happiness, I admit; but in their hasty zeal to befriend him, and from
Title:  the circumstance that both he and the sharks were at times half
Title:  hidden by the blood-muddled water, those indiscreet spades of theirs
Title:  would come nearer amputating a leg than a tall.  But poor Queequeg, I
Title:  suppose, straining and gasping there with that great iron hook--poor
Title:  Queequeg, I suppose, only prayed to his Yojo, and gave up his life
Title:  into the hands of his gods.
Title:  
Title:  Well, well, my dear comrade and twin-brother, thought I, as I drew in
Title:  and then slacked off the rope to every swell of the sea--what matters
Title:  it, after all?  Are you not the precious image of each and all of us
Title:  men in this whaling world?  That unsounded ocean you gasp in, is
Title:  Life; those sharks, your foes; those spades, your friends; and what
Title:  between sharks and spades you are in a sad pickle and peril, poor
Title:  lad.
Title:  
Title:  But courage! there is good cheer in store for you, Queequeg.  For
Title:  now, as with blue lips and blood-shot eyes the exhausted savage at
Title:  last climbs up the chains and stands all dripping and involuntarily
Title:  trembling over the side; the steward advances, and with a benevolent,
Title:  consolatory glance hands him--what?  Some hot Cognac?  No! hands him,
Title:  ye gods! hands him a cup of tepid ginger and water!
Title:  
Title:  "Ginger?  Do I smell ginger?" suspiciously asked Stubb, coming near.
Title:  "Yes, this must be ginger," peering into the as yet untasted cup.
Title:  Then standing as if incredulous for a while, he calmly walked towards
Title:  the astonished steward slowly saying, "Ginger? ginger? and will you
Title:  have the goodness to tell me, Mr. Dough-Boy, where lies the virtue of
Title:  ginger?  Ginger! is ginger the sort of fuel you use, Dough-boy, to
Title:  kindle a fire in this shivering cannibal?  Ginger!--what the devil is
Title:  ginger?--sea-coal? firewood?--lucifer
Title:  matches?--tinder?--gunpowder?--what the devil is ginger, I say, that
Title:  you offer this cup to our poor Queequeg here."
Title:  
Title:  "There is some sneaking Temperance Society movement about this
Title:  business," he suddenly added, now approaching Starbuck, who had just
Title:  come from forward.  "Will you look at that kannakin, sir; smell of
Title:  it, if you please."  Then watching the mate's countenance, he added,
Title:  "The steward, Mr. Starbuck, had the face to offer that calomel and
Title:  jalap to Queequeg, there, this instant off the whale.  Is the steward
Title:  an apothecary, sir? and may I ask whether this is the sort of bitters
Title:  by which he blows back the life into a half-drowned man?"
Title:  
Title:  "I trust not," said Starbuck, "it is poor stuff enough."
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, aye, steward," cried Stubb, "we'll teach you to drug it
Title:  harpooneer; none of your apothecary's medicine here; you want to
Title:  poison us, do ye?  You have got out insurances on our lives and want
Title:  to murder us all, and pocket the proceeds, do ye?"
Title:  
Title:  "It was not me," cried Dough-Boy, "it was Aunt Charity that brought
Title:  the ginger on board; and bade me never give the harpooneers any
Title:  spirits, but only this ginger-jub--so she called it."
Title:  
Title:  "Ginger-jub! you gingerly rascal! take that! and run along with ye to
Title:  the lockers, and get something better.  I hope I do no wrong, Mr.
Title:  Starbuck.  It is the captain's orders--grog for the harpooneer on a
Title:  whale."
Title:  
Title:  "Enough," replied Starbuck, "only don't hit him again, but--"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, I never hurt when I hit, except when I hit a whale or something
Title:  of that sort; and this fellow's a weazel.  What were you about
Title:  saying, sir?"
Title:  
Title:  "Only this: go down with him, and get what thou wantest thyself."
Title:  
Title:  When Stubb reappeared, he came with a dark flask in one hand, and a
Title:  sort of tea-caddy in the other.  The first contained strong spirits,
Title:  and was handed to Queequeg; the second was Aunt Charity's gift, and
Title:  that was freely given to the waves.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 73
Title:  
Title:  Stubb and Flask Kill a Right Whale; and Then Have a Talk Over Him.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  It must be borne in mind that all this time we have a Sperm Whale's
Title:  prodigious head hanging to the Pequod's side.  But we must let it
Title:  continue hanging there a while till we can get a chance to attend to
Title:  it.  For the present other matters press, and the best we can do now
Title:  for the head, is to pray heaven the tackles may hold.
Title:  
Title:  Now, during the past night and forenoon, the Pequod had gradually
Title:  drifted into a sea, which, by its occasional patches of yellow brit,
Title:  gave unusual tokens of the vicinity of Right Whales, a species of the
Title:  Leviathan that but few supposed to be at this particular time lurking
Title:  anywhere near.  And though all hands commonly disdained the capture
Title:  of those inferior creatures; and though the Pequod was not
Title:  commissioned to cruise for them at all, and though she had passed
Title:  numbers of them near the Crozetts without lowering a boat; yet now
Title:  that a Sperm Whale had been brought alongside and beheaded, to the
Title:  surprise of all, the announcement was made that a Right Whale should
Title:  be captured that day, if opportunity offered.
Title:  
Title:  Nor was this long wanting.  Tall spouts were seen to leeward; and two
Title:  boats, Stubb's and Flask's, were detached in pursuit.  Pulling
Title:  further and further away, they at last became almost invisible to the
Title:  men at the mast-head.  But suddenly in the distance, they saw a great
Title:  heap of tumultuous white water, and soon after news came from aloft
Title:  that one or both the boats must be fast.  An interval passed and the
Title:  boats were in plain sight, in the act of being dragged right towards
Title:  the ship by the towing whale.  So close did the monster come to the
Title:  hull, that at first it seemed as if he meant it malice; but suddenly
Title:  going down in a maelstrom, within three rods of the planks, he wholly
Title:  disappeared from view, as if diving under the keel.  "Cut, cut!" was
Title:  the cry from the ship to the boats, which, for one instant, seemed on
Title:  the point of being brought with a deadly dash against the vessel's
Title:  side.  But having plenty of line yet in the tubs, and the whale not
Title:  sounding very rapidly, they paid out abundance of rope, and at the
Title:  same time pulled with all their might so as to get ahead of the ship.
Title:  For a few minutes the struggle was intensely critical; for while
Title:  they still slacked out the tightened line in one direction, and still
Title:  plied their oars in another, the contending strain threatened to take
Title:  them under.  But it was only a few feet advance they sought to gain.
Title:  And they stuck to it till they did gain it; when instantly, a swift
Title:  tremor was felt running like lightning along the keel, as the
Title:  strained line, scraping beneath the ship, suddenly rose to view under
Title:  her bows, snapping and quivering; and so flinging off its drippings,
Title:  that the drops fell like bits of broken glass on the water, while the
Title:  whale beyond also rose to sight, and once more the boats were free to
Title:  fly.  But the fagged whale abated his speed, and blindly altering his
Title:  course, went round the stern of the ship towing the two boats after
Title:  him, so that they performed a complete circuit.
Title:  
Title:  Meantime, they hauled more and more upon their lines, till close
Title:  flanking him on both sides, Stubb answered Flask with lance for
Title:  lance; and thus round and round the Pequod the battle went, while the
Title:  multitudes of sharks that had before swum round the Sperm Whale's
Title:  body, rushed to the fresh blood that was spilled, thirstily drinking
Title:  at every new gash, as the eager Israelites did at the new bursting
Title:  fountains that poured from the smitten rock.
Title:  
Title:  At last his spout grew thick, and with a frightful roll and vomit, he
Title:  turned upon his back a corpse.
Title:  
Title:  While the two headsmen were engaged in making fast cords to his
Title:  flukes, and in other ways getting the mass in readiness for towing,
Title:  some conversation ensued between them.
Title:  
Title:  "I wonder what the old man wants with this lump of foul lard," said
Title:  Stubb, not without some disgust at the thought of having to do with
Title:  so ignoble a leviathan.
Title:  
Title:  "Wants with it?" said Flask, coiling some spare line in the boat's
Title:  bow, "did you never hear that the ship which but once has a Sperm
Title:  Whale's head hoisted on her starboard side, and at the same time a
Title:  Right Whale's on the larboard; did you never hear, Stubb, that that
Title:  ship can never afterwards capsize?"
Title:  
Title:  "Why not?
Title:  
Title:  "I don't know, but I heard that gamboge ghost of a Fedallah saying
Title:  so, and he seems to know all about ships' charms.  But I sometimes
Title:  think he'll charm the ship to no good at last.  I don't half like
Title:  that chap, Stubb.  Did you ever notice how that tusk of his is a sort
Title:  of carved into a snake's head, Stubb?"
Title:  
Title:  "Sink him!  I never look at him at all; but if ever I get a chance of
Title:  a dark night, and he standing hard by the bulwarks, and no one by;
Title:  look down there, Flask"--pointing into the sea with a peculiar motion
Title:  of both hands--"Aye, will I!  Flask, I take that Fedallah to be the
Title:  devil in disguise.  Do you believe that cock and bull story about his
Title:  having been stowed away on board ship?  He's the devil, I say.  The
Title:  reason why you don't see his tail, is because he tucks it up out of
Title:  sight; he carries it coiled away in his pocket, I guess.  Blast him!
Title:  now that I think of it, he's always wanting oakum to stuff into the
Title:  toes of his boots."
Title:  
Title:  "He sleeps in his boots, don't he?  He hasn't got any hammock; but
Title:  I've seen him lay of nights in a coil of rigging."
Title:  
Title:  "No doubt, and it's because of his cursed tail; he coils it down, do
Title:  ye see, in the eye of the rigging."
Title:  
Title:  "What's the old man have so much to do with him for?"
Title:  
Title:  "Striking up a swap or a bargain, I suppose."
Title:  
Title:  "Bargain?--about what?"
Title:  
Title:  "Why, do ye see, the old man is hard bent after that White Whale, and
Title:  the devil there is trying to come round him, and get him to swap away
Title:  his silver watch, or his soul, or something of that sort, and then
Title:  he'll surrender Moby Dick."
Title:  
Title:  "Pooh!  Stubb, you are skylarking; how can Fedallah do that?"
Title:  
Title:  "I don't know, Flask, but the devil is a curious chap, and a wicked
Title:  one, I tell ye.  Why, they say as how he went a sauntering into the
Title:  old flag-ship once, switching his tail about devilish easy and
Title:  gentlemanlike, and inquiring if the old governor was at home.  Well,
Title:  he was at home, and asked the devil what he wanted.  The devil,
Title:  switching his hoofs, up and says, 'I want John.'  'What for?' says
Title:  the old governor.  'What business is that of yours,' says the devil,
Title:  getting mad,--'I want to use him.'  'Take him,' says the
Title:  governor--and by the Lord, Flask, if the devil didn't give John the
Title:  Asiatic cholera before he got through with him, I'll eat this whale
Title:  in one mouthful.  But look sharp--ain't you all ready there?  Well,
Title:  then, pull ahead, and let's get the whale alongside."
Title:  
Title:  "I think I remember some such story as you were telling," said Flask,
Title:  when at last the two boats were slowly advancing with their burden
Title:  towards the ship, "but I can't remember where."
Title:  
Title:  "Three Spaniards?  Adventures of those three bloody-minded soladoes?
Title:  Did ye read it there, Flask?  I guess ye did?"
Title:  
Title:  "No: never saw such a book; heard of it, though.  But now, tell me,
Title:  Stubb, do you suppose that that devil you was speaking of just now,
Title:  was the same you say is now on board the Pequod?"
Title:  
Title:  "Am I the same man that helped kill this whale?  Doesn't the devil
Title:  live for ever; who ever heard that the devil was dead?  Did you ever
Title:  see any parson a wearing mourning for the devil?  And if the devil
Title:  has a latch-key to get into the admiral's cabin, don't you suppose he
Title:  can crawl into a porthole?  Tell me that, Mr. Flask?"
Title:  
Title:  "How old do you suppose Fedallah is, Stubb?"
Title:  
Title:  "Do you see that mainmast there?" pointing to the ship; "well, that's
Title:  the figure one; now take all the hoops in the Pequod's hold, and
Title:  string along in a row with that mast, for oughts, do you see; well,
Title:  that wouldn't begin to be Fedallah's age.  Nor all the coopers in
Title:  creation couldn't show hoops enough to make oughts enough."
Title:  
Title:  "But see here, Stubb, I thought you a little boasted just now, that
Title:  you meant to give Fedallah a sea-toss, if you got a good chance.
Title:  Now, if he's so old as all those hoops of yours come to, and if he is
Title:  going to live for ever, what good will it do to pitch him
Title:  overboard--tell me that?
Title:  
Title:  "Give him a good ducking, anyhow."
Title:  
Title:  "But he'd crawl back."
Title:  
Title:  "Duck him again; and keep ducking him."
Title:  
Title:  "Suppose he should take it into his head to duck you, though--yes,
Title:  and drown you--what then?"
Title:  
Title:  "I should like to see him try it; I'd give him such a pair of black
Title:  eyes that he wouldn't dare to show his face in the admiral's cabin
Title:  again for a long while, let alone down in the orlop there, where he
Title:  lives, and hereabouts on the upper decks where he sneaks so much.
Title:  Damn the devil, Flask; so you suppose I'm afraid of the devil?  Who's
Title:  afraid of him, except the old governor who daresn't catch him and put
Title:  him in double-darbies, as he deserves, but lets him go about
Title:  kidnapping people; aye, and signed a bond with him, that all the
Title:  people the devil kidnapped, he'd roast for him?  There's a governor!"
Title:  
Title:  "Do you suppose Fedallah wants to kidnap Captain Ahab?"
Title:  
Title:  "Do I suppose it?  You'll know it before long, Flask.  But I am going
Title:  now to keep a sharp look-out on him; and if I see anything very
Title:  suspicious going on, I'll just take him by the nape of his neck, and
Title:  say--Look here, Beelzebub, you don't do it; and if he makes any fuss,
Title:  by the Lord I'll make a grab into his pocket for his tail, take it to
Title:  the capstan, and give him such a wrenching and heaving, that his tail
Title:  will come short off at the stump--do you see; and then, I rather
Title:  guess when he finds himself docked in that queer fashion, he'll sneak
Title:  off without the poor satisfaction of feeling his tail between his
Title:  legs."
Title:  
Title:  "And what will you do with the tail, Stubb?"
Title:  
Title:  "Do with it?  Sell it for an ox whip when we get home;--what else?"
Title:  
Title:  "Now, do you mean what you say, and have been saying all along,
Title:  Stubb?"
Title:  
Title:  "Mean or not mean, here we are at the ship."
Title:  
Title:  The boats were here hailed, to tow the whale on the larboard side,
Title:  where fluke chains and other necessaries were already prepared for
Title:  securing him.
Title:  
Title:  "Didn't I tell you so?" said Flask; "yes, you'll soon see this right
Title:  whale's head hoisted up opposite that parmacetti's."
Title:  
Title:  In good time, Flask's saying proved true.  As before, the Pequod
Title:  steeply leaned over towards the sperm whale's head, now, by the
Title:  counterpoise of both heads, she regained her even keel; though sorely
Title:  strained, you may well believe.  So, when on one side you hoist in
Title:  Locke's head, you go over that way; but now, on the other side, hoist
Title:  in Kant's and you come back again; but in very poor plight.  Thus,
Title:  some minds for ever keep trimming boat.  Oh, ye foolish! throw all
Title:  these thunder-heads overboard, and then you will float light and
Title:  right.
Title:  
Title:  In disposing of the body of a right whale, when brought alongside the
Title:  ship, the same preliminary proceedings commonly take place as in the
Title:  case of a sperm whale; only, in the latter instance, the head is cut
Title:  off whole, but in the former the lips and tongue are separately
Title:  removed and hoisted on deck, with all the well known black bone
Title:  attached to what is called the crown-piece.  But nothing like this,
Title:  in the present case, had been done.  The carcases of both whales had
Title:  dropped astern; and the head-laden ship not a little resembled a mule
Title:  carrying a pair of overburdening panniers.
Title:  
Title:  Meantime, Fedallah was calmly eyeing the right whale's head, and ever
Title:  and anon glancing from the deep wrinkles there to the lines in his
Title:  own hand.  And Ahab chanced so to stand, that the Parsee occupied his
Title:  shadow; while, if the Parsee's shadow was there at all it seemed only
Title:  to blend with, and lengthen Ahab's.  As the crew toiled on,
Title:  Laplandish speculations were bandied among them, concerning all these
Title:  passing things.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 74
Title:  
Title:  The Sperm Whale's Head--Contrasted View.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Here, now, are two great whales, laying their heads together; let us
Title:  join them, and lay together our own.
Title:  
Title:  Of the grand order of folio leviathans, the Sperm Whale and the Right
Title:  Whale are by far the most noteworthy.  They are the only whales
Title:  regularly hunted by man.  To the Nantucketer, they present the two
Title:  extremes of all the known varieties of the whale.  As the external
Title:  difference between them is mainly observable in their heads; and as a
Title:  head of each is this moment hanging from the Pequod's side; and as we
Title:  may freely go from one to the other, by merely stepping across the
Title:  deck:--where, I should like to know, will you obtain a better chance
Title:  to study practical cetology than here?
Title:  
Title:  In the first place, you are struck by the general contrast between
Title:  these heads.  Both are massive enough in all conscience; but there
Title:  is a certain mathematical symmetry in the Sperm Whale's which the
Title:  Right Whale's sadly lacks.  There is more character in the Sperm
Title:  Whale's head.  As you behold it, you involuntarily yield the immense
Title:  superiority to him, in point of pervading dignity.  In the present
Title:  instance, too, this dignity is heightened by the pepper and salt
Title:  colour of his head at the summit, giving token of advanced age and
Title:  large experience.  In short, he is what the fishermen technically
Title:  call a "grey-headed whale."
Title:  
Title:  Let us now note what is least dissimilar in these heads--namely, the
Title:  two most important organs, the eye and the ear.  Far back on the side
Title:  of the head, and low down, near the angle of either whale's jaw, if
Title:  you narrowly search, you will at last see a lashless eye, which you
Title:  would fancy to be a young colt's eye; so out of all proportion is it
Title:  to the magnitude of the head.
Title:  
Title:  Now, from this peculiar sideway position of the whale's eyes, it is
Title:  plain that he can never see an object which is exactly ahead, no more
Title:  than he can one exactly astern.  In a word, the position of the
Title:  whale's eyes corresponds to that of a man's ears; and you may fancy,
Title:  for yourself, how it would fare with you, did you sideways survey
Title:  objects through your ears.  You would find that you could only
Title:  command some thirty degrees of vision in advance of the straight
Title:  side-line of sight; and about thirty more behind it.  If your
Title:  bitterest foe were walking straight towards you, with dagger uplifted
Title:  in broad day, you would not be able to see him, any more than if he
Title:  were stealing upon you from behind.  In a word, you would have two
Title:  backs, so to speak; but, at the same time, also, two fronts (side
Title:  fronts): for what is it that makes the front of a man--what, indeed,
Title:  but his eyes?
Title:  
Title:  Moreover, while in most other animals that I can now think of, the
Title:  eyes are so planted as imperceptibly to blend their visual power, so
Title:  as to produce one picture and not two to the brain; the peculiar
Title:  position of the whale's eyes, effectually divided as they are by many
Title:  cubic feet of solid head, which towers between them like a great
Title:  mountain separating two lakes in valleys; this, of course, must
Title:  wholly separate the impressions which each independent organ imparts.
Title:  The whale, therefore, must see one distinct picture on this side,
Title:  and another distinct picture on that side; while all between must be
Title:  profound darkness and nothingness to him.  Man may, in effect, be
Title:  said to look out on the world from a sentry-box with two joined
Title:  sashes for his window.  But with the whale, these two sashes are
Title:  separately inserted, making two distinct windows, but sadly impairing
Title:  the view.  This peculiarity of the whale's eyes is a thing always to
Title:  be borne in mind in the fishery; and to be remembered by the reader
Title:  in some subsequent scenes.
Title:  
Title:  A curious and most puzzling question might be started concerning this
Title:  visual matter as touching the Leviathan.  But I must be content with
Title:  a hint.  So long as a man's eyes are open in the light, the act of
Title:  seeing is involuntary; that is, he cannot then help mechanically
Title:  seeing whatever objects are before him.  Nevertheless, any one's
