Title:  experience will teach him, that though he can take in an
Title:  undiscriminating sweep of things at one glance, it is quite
Title:  impossible for him, attentively, and completely, to examine any two
Title:  things--however large or however small--at one and the same instant
Title:  of time; never mind if they lie side by side and touch each other.
Title:  But if you now come to separate these two objects, and surround each
Title:  by a circle of profound darkness; then, in order to see one of them,
Title:  in such a manner as to bring your mind to bear on it, the other will
Title:  be utterly excluded from your contemporary consciousness.  How is it,
Title:  then, with the whale?  True, both his eyes, in themselves, must
Title:  simultaneously act; but is his brain so much more comprehensive,
Title:  combining, and subtle than man's, that he can at the same moment of
Title:  time attentively examine two distinct prospects, one on one side of
Title:  him, and the other in an exactly opposite direction?  If he can, then
Title:  is it as marvellous a thing in him, as if a man were able
Title:  simultaneously to go through the demonstrations of two distinct
Title:  problems in Euclid.  Nor, strictly investigated, is there any
Title:  incongruity in this comparison.
Title:  
Title:  It may be but an idle whim, but it has always seemed to me, that the
Title:  extraordinary vacillations of movement displayed by some whales when
Title:  beset by three or four boats; the timidity and liability to queer
Title:  frights, so common to such whales; I think that all this indirectly
Title:  proceeds from the helpless perplexity of volition, in which their
Title:  divided and diametrically opposite powers of vision must involve
Title:  them.
Title:  
Title:  But the ear of the whale is full as curious as the eye.  If you are
Title:  an entire stranger to their race, you might hunt over these two heads
Title:  for hours, and never discover that organ.  The ear has no external
Title:  leaf whatever; and into the hole itself you can hardly insert a
Title:  quill, so wondrously minute is it.  It is lodged a little behind the
Title:  eye.  With respect to their ears, this important difference is to be
Title:  observed between the sperm whale and the right.  While the ear of
Title:  the former has an external opening, that of the latter is entirely
Title:  and evenly covered over with a membrane, so as to be quite
Title:  imperceptible from without.
Title:  
Title:  Is it not curious, that so vast a being as the whale should see the
Title:  world through so small an eye, and hear the thunder through an ear
Title:  which is smaller than a hare's?  But if his eyes were broad as the
Title:  lens of Herschel's great telescope; and his ears capacious as the
Title:  porches of cathedrals; would that make him any longer of sight, or
Title:  sharper of hearing?  Not at all.--Why then do you try to "enlarge"
Title:  your mind?  Subtilize it.
Title:  
Title:  Let us now with whatever levers and steam-engines we have at hand,
Title:  cant over the sperm whale's head, that it may lie bottom up;
Title:  then, ascending by a ladder to the summit, have a peep down the
Title:  mouth; and were it not that the body is now completely separated from
Title:  it, with a lantern we might descend into the great Kentucky Mammoth
Title:  Cave of his stomach.  But let us hold on here by this tooth, and look
Title:  about us where we are.  What a really beautiful and chaste-looking
Title:  mouth! from floor to ceiling, lined, or rather papered with a
Title:  glistening white membrane, glossy as bridal satins.
Title:  
Title:  But come out now, and look at this portentous lower jaw, which seems
Title:  like the long narrow lid of an immense snuff-box, with the hinge at
Title:  one end, instead of one side.  If you pry it up, so as to get it
Title:  overhead, and expose its rows of teeth, it seems a terrific
Title:  portcullis; and such, alas! it proves to many a poor wight in the
Title:  fishery, upon whom these spikes fall with impaling force.  But far
Title:  more terrible is it to behold, when fathoms down in the sea, you see
Title:  some sulky whale, floating there suspended, with his prodigious jaw,
Title:  some fifteen feet long, hanging straight down at right-angles with
Title:  his body, for all the world like a ship's jib-boom.  This whale is
Title:  not dead; he is only dispirited; out of sorts, perhaps;
Title:  hypochondriac; and so supine, that the hinges of his jaw have
Title:  relaxed, leaving him there in that ungainly sort of plight, a
Title:  reproach to all his tribe, who must, no doubt, imprecate lock-jaws
Title:  upon him.
Title:  
Title:  In most cases this lower jaw--being easily unhinged by a practised
Title:  artist--is disengaged and hoisted on deck for the purpose of
Title:  extracting the ivory teeth, and furnishing a supply of that hard
Title:  white whalebone with which the fishermen fashion all sorts of curious
Title:  articles, including canes, umbrella-stocks, and handles to
Title:  riding-whips.
Title:  
Title:  With a long, weary hoist the jaw is dragged on board, as if it were
Title:  an anchor; and when the proper time comes--some few days after the
Title:  other work--Queequeg, Daggoo, and Tashtego, being all accomplished
Title:  dentists, are set to drawing teeth.  With a keen cutting-spade,
Title:  Queequeg lances the gums; then the jaw is lashed down to ringbolts,
Title:  and a tackle being rigged from aloft, they drag out these teeth, as
Title:  Michigan oxen drag stumps of old oaks out of wild wood lands.  There
Title:  are generally forty-two teeth in all; in old whales, much worn down,
Title:  but undecayed; nor filled after our artificial fashion.  The jaw is
Title:  afterwards sawn into slabs, and piled away like joists for building
Title:  houses.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 75
Title:  
Title:  The Right Whale's Head--Contrasted View.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Crossing the deck, let us now have a good long look at the Right
Title:  Whale's head.
Title:  
Title:  As in general shape the noble Sperm Whale's head may be compared to a
Title:  Roman war-chariot (especially in front, where it is so broadly
Title:  rounded); so, at a broad view, the Right Whale's head bears a rather
Title:  inelegant resemblance to a gigantic galliot-toed shoe.  Two hundred
Title:  years ago an old Dutch voyager likened its shape to that of a
Title:  shoemaker's last.  And in this same last or shoe, that old woman of
Title:  the nursery tale, with the swarming brood, might very comfortably be
Title:  lodged, she and all her progeny.
Title:  
Title:  But as you come nearer to this great head it begins to assume
Title:  different aspects, according to your point of view.  If you stand on
Title:  its summit and look at these two F-shaped spoutholes, you would take
Title:  the whole head for an enormous bass-viol, and these spiracles, the
Title:  apertures in its sounding-board.  Then, again, if you fix your eye
Title:  upon this strange, crested, comb-like incrustation on the top of the
Title:  mass--this green, barnacled thing, which the Greenlanders call the
Title:  "crown," and the Southern fishers the "bonnet" of the Right Whale;
Title:  fixing your eyes solely on this, you would take the head for the
Title:  trunk of some huge oak, with a bird's nest in its crotch.  At any
Title:  rate, when you watch those live crabs that nestle here on this
Title:  bonnet, such an idea will be almost sure to occur to you; unless,
Title:  indeed, your fancy has been fixed by the technical term "crown" also
Title:  bestowed upon it; in which case you will take great interest in
Title:  thinking how this mighty monster is actually a diademed king of the
Title:  sea, whose green crown has been put together for him in this
Title:  marvellous manner.  But if this whale be a king, he is a very sulky
Title:  looking fellow to grace a diadem.  Look at that hanging lower lip!
Title:  what a huge sulk and pout is there! a sulk and pout, by carpenter's
Title:  measurement, about twenty feet long and five feet deep; a sulk and
Title:  pout that will yield you some 500 gallons of oil and more.
Title:  
Title:  A great pity, now, that this unfortunate whale should be hare-lipped.
Title:  The fissure is about a foot across.  Probably the mother during an
Title:  important interval was sailing down the Peruvian coast, when
Title:  earthquakes caused the beach to gape.  Over this lip, as over a
Title:  slippery threshold, we now slide into the mouth.  Upon my word were I
Title:  at Mackinaw, I should take this to be the inside of an Indian wigwam.
Title:  Good Lord! is this the road that Jonah went?  The roof is about
Title:  twelve feet high, and runs to a pretty sharp angle, as if there were
Title:  a regular ridge-pole there; while these ribbed, arched, hairy sides,
Title:  present us with those wondrous, half vertical, scimetar-shaped slats
Title:  of whalebone, say three hundred on a side, which depending from the
Title:  upper part of the head or crown bone, form those Venetian blinds
Title:  which have elsewhere been cursorily mentioned.  The edges of these
Title:  bones are fringed with hairy fibres, through which the Right Whale
Title:  strains the water, and in whose intricacies he retains the small
Title:  fish, when openmouthed he goes through the seas of brit in feeding
Title:  time.  In the central blinds of bone, as they stand in their natural
Title:  order, there are certain curious marks, curves, hollows, and ridges,
Title:  whereby some whalemen calculate the creature's age, as the age of an
Title:  oak by its circular rings.  Though the certainty of this criterion is
Title:  far from demonstrable, yet it has the savor of analogical
Title:  probability.  At any rate, if we yield to it, we must grant a far
Title:  greater age to the Right Whale than at first glance will seem
Title:  reasonable.
Title:  
Title:  In old times, there seem to have prevailed the most curious fancies
Title:  concerning these blinds.  One voyager in Purchas calls them the
Title:  wondrous "whiskers" inside of the whale's mouth;* another, "hogs'
Title:  bristles"; a third old gentleman in Hackluyt uses the following
Title:  elegant language: "There are about two hundred and fifty fins growing
Title:  on each side of his upper CHOP, which arch over his tongue on each
Title:  side of his mouth."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *This reminds us that the Right Whale really has a sort of whisker,
Title:  or rather a moustache, consisting of a few scattered white hairs on
Title:  the upper part of the outer end of the lower jaw.  Sometimes these
Title:  tufts impart a rather brigandish expression to his otherwise solemn
Title:  countenance.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  As every one knows, these same "hogs' bristles," "fins," "whiskers,"
Title:  "blinds," or whatever you please, furnish to the ladies their busks
Title:  and other stiffening contrivances.  But in this particular, the
Title:  demand has long been on the decline.  It was in Queen Anne's time
Title:  that the bone was in its glory, the farthingale being then all the
Title:  fashion.  And as those ancient dames moved about gaily, though in the
Title:  jaws of the whale, as you may say; even so, in a shower, with the
Title:  like thoughtlessness, do we nowadays fly under the same jaws for
Title:  protection; the umbrella being a tent spread over the same bone.
Title:  
Title:  But now forget all about blinds and whiskers for a moment, and,
Title:  standing in the Right Whale's mouth, look around you afresh.  Seeing
Title:  all these colonnades of bone so methodically ranged about, would you
Title:  not think you were inside of the great Haarlem organ, and gazing
Title:  upon its thousand pipes?  For a carpet to the organ we have a rug of
Title:  the softest Turkey--the tongue, which is glued, as it were, to the
Title:  floor of the mouth.  It is very fat and tender, and apt to tear in
Title:  pieces in hoisting it on deck.  This particular tongue now before us;
Title:  at a passing glance I should say it was a six-barreler; that is, it
Title:  will yield you about that amount of oil.
Title:  
Title:  Ere this, you must have plainly seen the truth of what I started
Title:  with--that the Sperm Whale and the Right Whale have almost entirely
Title:  different heads.  To sum up, then: in the Right Whale's there is no
Title:  great well of sperm; no ivory teeth at all; no long, slender mandible
Title:  of a lower jaw, like the Sperm Whale's.  Nor in the Sperm Whale are
Title:  there any of those blinds of bone; no huge lower lip; and scarcely
Title:  anything of a tongue.  Again, the Right Whale has two external
Title:  spout-holes, the Sperm Whale only one.
Title:  
Title:  Look your last, now, on these venerable hooded heads, while they yet
Title:  lie together; for one will soon sink, unrecorded, in the sea; the
Title:  other will not be very long in following.
Title:  
Title:  Can you catch the expression of the Sperm Whale's there?  It is the
Title:  same he died with, only some of the longer wrinkles in the forehead
Title:  seem now faded away.  I think his broad brow to be full of a
Title:  prairie-like placidity, born of a speculative indifference as to
Title:  death.  But mark the other head's expression.  See that amazing lower
Title:  lip, pressed by accident against the vessel's side, so as firmly to
Title:  embrace the jaw.  Does not this whole head seem to speak of an
Title:  enormous practical resolution in facing death?  This Right Whale I
Title:  take to have been a Stoic; the Sperm Whale, a Platonian, who might
Title:  have taken up Spinoza in his latter years.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 76
Title:  
Title:  The Battering-Ram.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Ere quitting, for the nonce, the Sperm Whale's head, I would have
Title:  you, as a sensible physiologist, simply--particularly remark its
Title:  front aspect, in all its compacted collectedness.  I would have you
Title:  investigate it now with the sole view of forming to yourself some
Title:  unexaggerated, intelligent estimate of whatever battering-ram power
Title:  may be lodged there.  Here is a vital point; for you must either
Title:  satisfactorily settle this matter with yourself, or for ever remain
Title:  an infidel as to one of the most appalling, but not the less true
Title:  events, perhaps anywhere to be found in all recorded history.
Title:  
Title:  You observe that in the ordinary swimming position of the Sperm
Title:  Whale, the front of his head presents an almost wholly vertical plane
Title:  to the water; you observe that the lower part of that front slopes
Title:  considerably backwards, so as to furnish more of a retreat for the
Title:  long socket which receives the boom-like lower jaw; you observe that
Title:  the mouth is entirely under the head, much in the same way, indeed,
Title:  as though your own mouth were entirely under your chin.  Moreover you
Title:  observe that the whale has no external nose; and that what nose he
Title:  has--his spout hole--is on the top of his head; you observe that his
Title:  eyes and ears are at the sides of his head, nearly one third of his
Title:  entire length from the front.  Wherefore, you must now have perceived
Title:  that the front of the Sperm Whale's head is a dead, blind wall,
Title:  without a single organ or tender prominence of any sort whatsoever.
Title:  Furthermore, you are now to consider that only in the extreme, lower,
Title:  backward sloping part of the front of the head, is there the
Title:  slightest vestige of bone; and not till you get near twenty feet from
Title:  the forehead do you come to the full cranial development.  So that
Title:  this whole enormous boneless mass is as one wad.  Finally, though, as
Title:  will soon be revealed, its contents partly comprise the most delicate
Title:  oil; yet, you are now to be apprised of the nature of the substance
Title:  which so impregnably invests all that apparent effeminacy.  In some
Title:  previous place I have described to you how the blubber wraps the body
Title:  of the whale, as the rind wraps an orange.  Just so with the head;
Title:  but with this difference: about the head this envelope, though not so
Title:  thick, is of a boneless toughness, inestimable by any man who has not
Title:  handled it.  The severest pointed harpoon, the sharpest lance darted
Title:  by the strongest human arm, impotently rebounds from it.  It is as
Title:  though the forehead of the Sperm Whale were paved with horses' hoofs.
Title:  I do not think that any sensation lurks in it.
Title:  
Title:  Bethink yourself also of another thing.  When two large, loaded
Title:  Indiamen chance to crowd and crush towards each other in the
Title:  docks, what do the sailors do?  They do not suspend between them, at
Title:  the point of coming contact, any merely hard substance, like iron or
Title:  wood.  No, they hold there a large, round wad of tow and cork,
Title:  enveloped in the thickest and toughest of ox-hide.  That bravely and
Title:  uninjured takes the jam which would have snapped all their oaken
Title:  handspikes and iron crow-bars.  By itself this sufficiently
Title:  illustrates the obvious fact I drive at.  But supplementary to this,
Title:  it has hypothetically occurred to me, that as ordinary fish possess
Title:  what is called a swimming bladder in them, capable, at will, of
Title:  distension or contraction; and as the Sperm Whale, as far as I know,
Title:  has no such provision in him; considering, too, the otherwise
Title:  inexplicable manner in which he now depresses his head altogether
Title:  beneath the surface, and anon swims with it high elevated out of the
Title:  water; considering the unobstructed elasticity of its envelope;
Title:  considering the unique interior of his head; it has hypothetically
Title:  occurred to me, I say, that those mystical lung-celled honeycombs
Title:  there may possibly have some hitherto unknown and unsuspected
Title:  connexion with the outer air, so as to be susceptible to atmospheric
Title:  distension and contraction.  If this be so, fancy the
Title:  irresistibleness of that might, to which the most impalpable and
Title:  destructive of all elements contributes.
Title:  
Title:  Now, mark.  Unerringly impelling this dead, impregnable, uninjurable
Title:  wall, and this most buoyant thing within; there swims behind it all a
Title:  mass of tremendous life, only to be adequately estimated as piled
Title:  wood is--by the cord; and all obedient to one volition, as the
Title:  smallest insect.  So that when I shall hereafter detail to you all
Title:  the specialities and concentrations of potency everywhere lurking in
Title:  this expansive monster; when I shall show you some of his more
Title:  inconsiderable braining feats; I trust you will have renounced all
Title:  ignorant incredulity, and be ready to abide by this; that though the
Title:  Sperm Whale stove a passage through the Isthmus of Darien, and mixed
Title:  the Atlantic with the Pacific, you would not elevate one hair of your
Title:  eye-brow.  For unless you own the whale, you are but a provincial and
Title:  sentimentalist in Truth.  But clear Truth is a thing for salamander
Title:  giants only to encounter; how small the chances for the provincials
Title:  then?  What befell the weakling youth lifting the dread goddess's
Title:  veil at Lais?
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 77
Title:  
Title:  The Great Heidelburgh Tun.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Now comes the Baling of the Case.  But to comprehend it aright, you
Title:  must know something of the curious internal structure of the thing
Title:  operated upon.
Title:  
Title:  Regarding the Sperm Whale's head as a solid oblong, you may, on an
Title:  inclined plane, sideways divide it into two quoins,* whereof the
Title:  lower is the bony structure, forming the cranium and jaws, and the
Title:  upper an unctuous mass wholly free from bones; its broad forward end
Title:  forming the expanded vertical apparent forehead of the whale.  At the
Title:  middle of the forehead horizontally subdivide this upper quoin, and
Title:  then you have two almost equal parts, which before were naturally
Title:  divided by an internal wall of a thick tendinous substance.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *Quoin is not a Euclidean term.  It belongs to the pure nautical
Title:  mathematics.  I know not that it has been defined before.  A quoin is
Title:  a solid which differs from a wedge in having its sharp end formed by
Title:  the steep inclination of one side, instead of the mutual tapering of
Title:  both sides.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  The lower subdivided part, called the junk, is one immense honeycomb
Title:  of oil, formed by the crossing and recrossing, into ten thousand
Title:  infiltrated cells, of tough elastic white fibres throughout its whole
Title:  extent.  The upper part, known as the Case, may be regarded as the
Title:  great Heidelburgh Tun of the Sperm Whale.  And as that famous great
Title:  tierce is mystically carved in front, so the whale's vast plaited
Title:  forehead forms innumerable strange devices for the emblematical
Title:  adornment of his wondrous tun.  Moreover, as that of Heidelburgh was
Title:  always replenished with the most excellent of the wines of the
Title:  Rhenish valleys, so the tun of the whale contains by far the most
Title:  precious of all his oily vintages; namely, the highly-prized
Title:  spermaceti, in its absolutely pure, limpid, and odoriferous state.
Title:  Nor is this precious substance found unalloyed in any other part of
Title:  the creature.  Though in life it remains perfectly fluid, yet, upon
Title:  exposure to the air, after death, it soon begins to concrete; sending
Title:  forth beautiful crystalline shoots, as when the first thin delicate
Title:  ice is just forming in water.  A large whale's case generally yields
Title:  about five hundred gallons of sperm, though from unavoidable
Title:  circumstances, considerable of it is spilled, leaks, and dribbles
Title:  away, or is otherwise irrevocably lost in the ticklish business of
Title:  securing what you can.
Title:  
Title:  I know not with what fine and costly material the Heidelburgh Tun was
Title:  coated within, but in superlative richness that coating could not
Title:  possibly have compared with the silken pearl-coloured membrane, like
Title:  the lining of a fine pelisse, forming the inner surface of the Sperm
Title:  Whale's case.
Title:  
Title:  It will have been seen that the Heidelburgh Tun of the Sperm Whale
Title:  embraces the entire length of the entire top of the head; and
Title:  since--as has been elsewhere set forth--the head embraces one third
Title:  of the whole length of the creature, then setting that length down at
Title:  eighty feet for a good sized whale, you have more than twenty-six
Title:  feet for the depth of the tun, when it is lengthwise hoisted up and
Title:  down against a ship's side.
Title:  
Title:  As in decapitating the whale, the operator's instrument is brought
Title:  close to the spot where an entrance is subsequently forced into the
Title:  spermaceti magazine; he has, therefore, to be uncommonly heedful,
Title:  lest a careless, untimely stroke should invade the sanctuary and
Title:  wastingly let out its invaluable contents.  It is this decapitated
Title:  end of the head, also, which is at last elevated out of the water,
Title:  and retained in that position by the enormous cutting tackles, whose
Title:  hempen combinations, on one side, make quite a wilderness of ropes in
Title:  that quarter.
Title:  
Title:  Thus much being said, attend now, I pray you, to that marvellous
Title:  and--in this particular instance--almost fatal operation whereby the
Title:  Sperm Whale's great Heidelburgh Tun is tapped.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 78
Title:  
Title:  Cistern and Buckets.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Nimble as a cat, Tashtego mounts aloft; and without altering his
Title:  erect posture, runs straight out upon the overhanging mainyard-arm,
Title:  to the part where it exactly projects over the hoisted Tun.  He has
Title:  carried with him a light tackle called a whip, consisting of only two
Title:  parts, travelling through a single-sheaved block.  Securing this
Title:  block, so that it hangs down from the yard-arm, he swings one end of
Title:  the rope, till it is caught and firmly held by a hand on deck.
Title:  Then, hand-over-hand, down the other part, the Indian drops through
Title:  the air, till dexterously he lands on the summit of the head.
Title:  There--still high elevated above the rest of the company, to whom he
Title:  vivaciously cries--he seems some Turkish Muezzin calling the good
Title:  people to prayers from the top of a tower.  A short-handled sharp
Title:  spade being sent up to him, he diligently searches for the proper
Title:  place to begin breaking into the Tun.  In this business he proceeds
Title:  very heedfully, like a treasure-hunter in some old house, sounding
Title:  the walls to find where the gold is masoned in.  By the time this
Title:  cautious search is over, a stout iron-bound bucket, precisely like a
Title:  well-bucket, has been attached to one end of the whip; while the
Title:  other end, being stretched across the deck, is there held by two or
Title:  three alert hands.  These last now hoist the bucket within grasp of
Title:  the Indian, to whom another person has reached up a very long pole.
Title:  Inserting this pole into the bucket, Tashtego downward guides the
Title:  bucket into the Tun, till it entirely disappears; then giving the
Title:  word to the seamen at the whip, up comes the bucket again, all
Title:  bubbling like a dairy-maid's pail of new milk.  Carefully lowered
Title:  from its height, the full-freighted vessel is caught by an appointed
Title:  hand, and quickly emptied into a large tub.  Then remounting aloft,
Title:  it again goes through the same round until the deep cistern will
Title:  yield no more.  Towards the end, Tashtego has to ram his long pole
Title:  harder and harder, and deeper and deeper into the Tun, until some
Title:  twenty feet of the pole have gone down.
Title:  
Title:  Now, the people of the Pequod had been baling some time in this way;
Title:  several tubs had been filled with the fragrant sperm; when all at
Title:  once a queer accident happened.  Whether it was that Tashtego, that
Title:  wild Indian, was so heedless and reckless as to let go for a moment
Title:  his one-handed hold on the great cabled tackles suspending the head;
Title:  or whether the place where he stood was so treacherous and oozy; or
Title:  whether the Evil One himself would have it to fall out so, without
Title:  stating his particular reasons; how it was exactly, there is no
Title:  telling now; but, on a sudden, as the eightieth or ninetieth bucket
Title:  came suckingly up--my God! poor Tashtego--like the twin reciprocating
Title:  bucket in a veritable well, dropped head-foremost down into this
Title:  great Tun of Heidelburgh, and with a horrible oily gurgling, went
Title:  clean out of sight!
Title:  
Title:  "Man overboard!" cried Daggoo, who amid the general consternation
Title:  first came to his senses.  "Swing the bucket this way!" and putting
Title:  one foot into it, so as the better to secure his slippery hand-hold
Title:  on the whip itself, the hoisters ran him high up to the top of the
Title:  head, almost before Tashtego could have reached its interior bottom.
Title:  Meantime, there was a terrible tumult.  Looking over the side, they
Title:  saw the before lifeless head throbbing and heaving just below the
Title:  surface of the sea, as if that moment seized with some momentous
Title:  idea; whereas it was only the poor Indian unconsciously revealing by
Title:  those struggles the perilous depth to which he had sunk.
Title:  
Title:  At this instant, while Daggoo, on the summit of the head, was
Title:  clearing the whip--which had somehow got foul of the great cutting
Title:  tackles--a sharp cracking noise was heard; and to the unspeakable
Title:  horror of all, one of the two enormous hooks suspending the head tore
Title:  out, and with a vast vibration the enormous mass sideways swung, till
Title:  the drunk ship reeled and shook as if smitten by an iceberg.  The one
Title:  remaining hook, upon which the entire strain now depended, seemed
Title:  every instant to be on the point of giving way; an event still more
Title:  likely from the violent motions of the head.
Title:  
Title:  "Come down, come down!" yelled the seamen to Daggoo, but with one
Title:  hand holding on to the heavy tackles, so that if the head should
Title:  drop, he would still remain suspended; the negro having cleared the
Title:  foul line, rammed down the bucket into the now collapsed well,
Title:  meaning that the buried harpooneer should grasp it, and so be hoisted
Title:  out.
Title:  
Title:  "In heaven's name, man," cried Stubb, "are you ramming home a
Title:  cartridge there?--Avast!  How will that help him; jamming that
Title:  iron-bound bucket on top of his head?  Avast, will ye!"
Title:  
Title:  "Stand clear of the tackle!" cried a voice like the bursting of a
Title:  rocket.
Title:  
Title:  Almost in the same instant, with a thunder-boom, the enormous mass
Title:  dropped into the sea, like Niagara's Table-Rock into the whirlpool;
Title:  the suddenly relieved hull rolled away from it, to far down her
Title:  glittering copper; and all caught their breath, as half swinging--now
Title:  over the sailors' heads, and now over the water--Daggoo, through a
Title:  thick mist of spray, was dimly beheld clinging to the pendulous
Title:  tackles, while poor, buried-alive Tashtego was sinking utterly down
Title:  to the bottom of the sea!  But hardly had the blinding vapour cleared
Title:  away, when a naked figure with a boarding-sword in his hand, was for
Title:  one swift moment seen hovering over the bulwarks.  The next, a loud
Title:  splash announced that my brave Queequeg had dived to the rescue.  One
Title:  packed rush was made to the side, and every eye counted every ripple,
Title:  as moment followed moment, and no sign of either the sinker or the
Title:  diver could be seen.  Some hands now jumped into a boat alongside,
Title:  and pushed a little off from the ship.
Title:  
Title:  "Ha! ha!" cried Daggoo, all at once, from his now quiet, swinging
Title:  perch overhead; and looking further off from the side, we saw an arm
Title:  thrust upright from the blue waves; a sight strange to see, as an arm
Title:  thrust forth from the grass over a grave.
Title:  
Title:  "Both! both!--it is both!"--cried Daggoo again with a joyful shout;
Title:  and soon after, Queequeg was seen boldly striking out with one hand,
Title:  and with the other clutching the long hair of the Indian.  Drawn into
Title:  the waiting boat, they were quickly brought to the deck; but Tashtego
Title:  was long in coming to, and Queequeg did not look very brisk.
Title:  
Title:  Now, how had this noble rescue been accomplished?  Why, diving after
Title:  the slowly descending head, Queequeg with his keen sword had made
Title:  side lunges near its bottom, so as to scuttle a large hole there;
Title:  then dropping his sword, had thrust his long arm far inwards and
Title:  upwards, and so hauled out poor Tash by the head.  He averred, that
Title:  upon first thrusting in for him, a leg was presented; but well
Title:  knowing that that was not as it ought to be, and might occasion great
Title:  trouble;--he had thrust back the leg, and by a dexterous heave and
Title:  toss, had wrought a somerset upon the Indian; so that with the next
Title:  trial, he came forth in the good old way--head foremost.  As for the
Title:  great head itself, that was doing as well as could be expected.
Title:  
Title:  And thus, through the courage and great skill in obstetrics of
Title:  Queequeg, the deliverance, or rather, delivery of Tashtego, was
Title:  successfully accomplished, in the teeth, too, of the most untoward
Title:  and apparently hopeless impediments; which is a lesson by no means to
Title:  be forgotten.  Midwifery should be taught in the same course with
Title:  fencing and boxing, riding and rowing.
Title:  
Title:  I know that this queer adventure of the Gay-Header's will be sure to
Title:  seem incredible to some landsmen, though they themselves may have
Title:  either seen or heard of some one's falling into a cistern ashore; an
Title:  accident which not seldom happens, and with much less reason too than
Title:  the Indian's, considering the exceeding slipperiness of the curb of
Title:  the Sperm Whale's well.
Title:  
Title:  But, peradventure, it may be sagaciously urged, how is this?  We
Title:  thought the tissued, infiltrated head of the Sperm Whale, was the
Title:  lightest and most corky part about him; and yet thou makest it sink
Title:  in an element of a far greater specific gravity than itself.  We have
Title:  thee there.  Not at all, but I have ye; for at the time poor Tash
Title:  fell in, the case had been nearly emptied of its lighter contents,
Title:  leaving little but the dense tendinous wall of the well--a double
Title:  welded, hammered substance, as I have before said, much heavier than
Title:  the sea water, and a lump of which sinks in it like lead almost.  But
Title:  the tendency to rapid sinking in this substance was in the present
Title:  instance materially counteracted by the other parts of the head
Title:  remaining undetached from it, so that it sank very slowly and
Title:  deliberately indeed, affording Queequeg a fair chance for performing
Title:  his agile obstetrics on the run, as you may say.  Yes, it was a
Title:  running delivery, so it was.
Title:  
Title:  Now, had Tashtego perished in that head, it had been a very precious
Title:  perishing; smothered in the very whitest and daintiest of fragrant
Title:  spermaceti; coffined, hearsed, and tombed in the secret inner chamber
Title:  and sanctum sanctorum of the whale.  Only one sweeter end can readily
Title:  be recalled--the delicious death of an Ohio honey-hunter, who seeking
Title:  honey in the crotch of a hollow tree, found such exceeding store of
Title:  it, that leaning too far over, it sucked him in, so that he died
Title:  embalmed.  How many, think ye, have likewise fallen into Plato's
Title:  honey head, and sweetly perished there?
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 79
Title:  
Title:  The Prairie.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  To scan the lines of his face, or feel the bumps on the head of this
Title:  Leviathan; this is a thing which no Physiognomist or Phrenologist has
Title:  as yet undertaken.  Such an enterprise would seem almost as hopeful
Title:  as for Lavater to have scrutinized the wrinkles on the Rock of
Title:  Gibraltar, or for Gall to have mounted a ladder and manipulated the
Title:  Dome of the Pantheon.  Still, in that famous work of his, Lavater
Title:  not only treats of the various faces of men, but also attentively
Title:  studies the faces of horses, birds, serpents, and fish; and dwells in
Title:  detail upon the modifications of expression discernible therein.  Nor
Title:  have Gall and his disciple Spurzheim failed to throw out some hints
Title:  touching the phrenological characteristics of other beings than man.
Title:  Therefore, though I am but ill qualified for a pioneer, in the
Title:  application of these two semi-sciences to the whale, I will do my
Title:  endeavor.  I try all things; I achieve what I can.
Title:  
Title:  Physiognomically regarded, the Sperm Whale is an anomalous creature.
Title:  He has no proper nose.  And since the nose is the central and most
Title:  conspicuous of the features; and since it perhaps most modifies and
Title:  finally controls their combined expression; hence it would seem that
Title:  its entire absence, as an external appendage, must very largely
Title:  affect the countenance of the whale.  For as in landscape gardening,
Title:  a spire, cupola, monument, or tower of some sort, is deemed almost
Title:  indispensable to the completion of the scene; so no face can be
Title:  physiognomically in keeping without the elevated open-work belfry of
Title:  the nose.  Dash the nose from Phidias's marble Jove, and what a sorry
Title:  remainder!  Nevertheless, Leviathan is of so mighty a magnitude, all
Title:  his proportions are so stately, that the same deficiency which in the
Title:  sculptured Jove were hideous, in him is no blemish at all.  Nay, it
Title:  is an added grandeur.  A nose to the whale would have been
Title:  impertinent.  As on your physiognomical voyage you sail round his
Title:  vast head in your jolly-boat, your noble conceptions of him are never
Title:  insulted by the reflection that he has a nose to be pulled.  A
Title:  pestilent conceit, which so often will insist upon obtruding even
Title:  when beholding the mightiest royal beadle on his throne.
Title:  
Title:  In some particulars, perhaps the most imposing physiognomical view
Title:  to be had of the Sperm Whale, is that of the full front of his head.
Title:  This aspect is sublime.
Title:  
Title:  In thought, a fine human brow is like the East when troubled with
Title:  the morning.  In the repose of the pasture, the curled brow of the
Title:  bull has a touch of the grand in it.  Pushing heavy cannon up
Title:  mountain defiles, the elephant's brow is majestic.  Human or animal,
Title:  the mystical brow is as that great golden seal affixed by the German
Title:  Emperors to their decrees.  It signifies--"God: done this day by my
Title:  hand."  But in most creatures, nay in man himself, very often the
Title:  brow is but a mere strip of alpine land lying along the snow line.
Title:  Few are the foreheads which like Shakespeare's or Melancthon's rise
Title:  so high, and descend so low, that the eyes themselves seem clear,
Title:  eternal, tideless mountain lakes; and all above them in the forehead's
Title:  wrinkles, you seem to track the antlered thoughts descending there to
Title:  drink, as the Highland hunters track the snow prints of the deer.
Title:  But in the great Sperm Whale, this high and mighty god-like dignity
Title:  inherent in the brow is so immensely amplified, that gazing on it, in
Title:  that full front view, you feel the Deity and the dread powers more
Title:  forcibly than in beholding any other object in living nature.  For
Title:  you see no one point precisely; not one distinct feature is revealed;
Title:  no nose, eyes, ears, or mouth; no face; he has none, proper; nothing
Title:  but that one broad firmament of a forehead, pleated with riddles;
Title:  dumbly lowering with the doom of boats, and ships, and men.  Nor, in
Title:  profile, does this wondrous brow diminish; though that way viewed its
Title:  grandeur does not domineer upon you so.  In profile, you plainly
Title:  perceive that horizontal, semi-crescentic depression in the
Title:  forehead's middle, which, in man, is Lavater's mark of genius.
Title:  
Title:  But how?  Genius in the Sperm Whale?  Has the Sperm Whale ever
Title:  written a book, spoken a speech?  No, his great genius is declared in
Title:  his doing nothing particular to prove it.  It is moreover declared in
Title:  his pyramidical silence.  And this reminds me that had the great
Title:  Sperm Whale been known to the young Orient World, he would have been
Title:  deified by their child-magian thoughts.  They deified the crocodile
Title:  of the Nile, because the crocodile is tongueless; and the Sperm Whale
Title:  has no tongue, or at least it is so exceedingly small, as to be
Title:  incapable of protrusion.  If hereafter any highly cultured, poetical
Title:  nation shall lure back to their birth-right, the merry May-day gods
Title:  of old; and livingly enthrone them again in the now egotistical sky;
Title:  in the now unhaunted hill; then be sure, exalted to Jove's high seat,
Title:  the great Sperm Whale shall lord it.
Title:  
Title:  Champollion deciphered the wrinkled granite hieroglyphics.  But there
Title:  is no Champollion to decipher the Egypt of every man's and every
Title:  being's face.  Physiognomy, like every other human science, is but a
Title:  passing fable.  If then, Sir William Jones, who read in thirty
Title:  languages, could not read the simplest peasant's face in its
Title:  profounder and more subtle meanings, how may unlettered Ishmael hope
Title:  to read the awful Chaldee of the Sperm Whale's brow?  I but put that
Title:  brow before you.  Read it if you can.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 80
Title:  
Title:  The Nut.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  If the Sperm Whale be physiognomically a Sphinx, to the phrenologist
Title:  his brain seems that geometrical circle which it is impossible to
Title:  square.
Title:  
Title:  In the full-grown creature the skull will measure at least twenty
Title:  feet in length.  Unhinge the lower jaw, and the side view of this
Title:  skull is as the side of a moderately inclined plane resting
Title:  throughout on a level base.  But in life--as we have elsewhere
Title:  seen--this inclined plane is angularly filled up, and almost squared
Title:  by the enormous superincumbent mass of the junk and sperm.  At the
Title:  high end the skull forms a crater to bed that part of the mass; while
Title:  under the long floor of this crater--in another cavity seldom
Title:  exceeding ten inches in length and as many in depth--reposes the
Title:  mere handful of this monster's brain.  The brain is at least twenty
Title:  feet from his apparent forehead in life; it is hidden away behind its
Title:  vast outworks, like the innermost citadel within the amplified
Title:  fortifications of Quebec.  So like a choice casket is it secreted in
Title:  him, that I have known some whalemen who peremptorily deny that the
Title:  Sperm Whale has any other brain than that palpable semblance of one
Title:  formed by the cubic-yards of his sperm magazine.  Lying in strange
Title:  folds, courses, and convolutions, to their apprehensions, it seems
Title:  more in keeping with the idea of his general might to regard that
Title:  mystic part of him as the seat of his intelligence.
Title:  
Title:  It is plain, then, that phrenologically the head of this Leviathan,
Title:  in the creature's living intact state, is an entire delusion.  As for
Title:  his true brain, you can then see no indications of it, nor feel any.
Title:  The whale, like all things that are mighty, wears a false brow to the
Title:  common world.
Title:  
Title:  If you unload his skull of its spermy heaps and then take a rear view
Title:  of its rear end, which is the high end, you will be struck by its
Title:  resemblance to the human skull, beheld in the same situation, and
Title:  from the same point of view.  Indeed, place this reversed skull
Title:  (scaled down to the human magnitude) among a plate of men's skulls,
Title:  and you would involuntarily confound it with them; and remarking the
Title:  depressions on one part of its summit, in phrenological phrase you
Title:  would say--This man had no self-esteem, and no veneration.  And by
Title:  those negations, considered along with the affirmative fact of his
Title:  prodigious bulk and power, you can best form to yourself the truest,
Title:  though not the most exhilarating conception of what the most exalted
Title:  potency is.
Title:  
Title:  But if from the comparative dimensions of the whale's proper brain,
Title:  you deem it incapable of being adequately charted, then I have
Title:  another idea for you.  If you attentively regard almost any
Title:  quadruped's spine, you will be struck with the resemblance of its
Title:  vertebrae to a strung necklace of dwarfed skulls, all bearing
Title:  rudimental resemblance to the skull proper.  It is a German conceit,
Title:  that the vertebrae are absolutely undeveloped skulls.  But the
Title:  curious external resemblance, I take it the Germans were not the
Title:  first men to perceive.  A foreign friend once pointed it out to me,
Title:  in the skeleton of a foe he had slain, and with the vertebrae of
Title:  which he was inlaying, in a sort of basso-relievo, the beaked prow
Title:  of his canoe.  Now, I consider that the phrenologists have omitted an
Title:  important thing in not pushing their investigations from the
Title:  cerebellum through the spinal canal.  For I believe that much of a
Title:  man's character will be found betokened in his backbone.  I would
Title:  rather feel your spine than your skull, whoever you are.  A thin
Title:  joist of a spine never yet upheld a full and noble soul.  I rejoice
Title:  in my spine, as in the firm audacious staff of that flag which I
Title:  fling half out to the world.
Title:  
Title:  Apply this spinal branch of phrenology to the Sperm Whale.  His
Title:  cranial cavity is continuous with the first neck-vertebra; and in
Title:  that vertebra the bottom of the spinal canal will measure ten inches
Title:  across, being eight in height, and of a triangular figure with the
Title:  base downwards.  As it passes through the remaining vertebrae the
Title:  canal tapers in size, but for a considerable distance remains of
Title:  large capacity.  Now, of course, this canal is filled with much the
Title:  same strangely fibrous substance--the spinal cord--as the brain; and
Title:  directly communicates with the brain.  And what is still more, for
Title:  many feet after emerging from the brain's cavity, the spinal cord
Title:  remains of an undecreasing girth, almost equal to that of the brain.
Title:  Under all these circumstances, would it be unreasonable to survey and
Title:  map out the whale's spine phrenologically?  For, viewed in this
Title:  light, the wonderful comparative smallness of his brain proper is
Title:  more than compensated by the wonderful comparative magnitude of his
Title:  spinal cord.
Title:  
Title:  But leaving this hint to operate as it may with the phrenologists, I
Title:  would merely assume the spinal theory for a moment, in reference to
Title:  the Sperm Whale's hump.  This august hump, if I mistake not, rises
Title:  over one of the larger vertebrae, and is, therefore, in some sort,
Title:  the outer convex mould of it.  From its relative situation then, I
Title:  should call this high hump the organ of firmness or indomitableness
Title:  in the Sperm Whale.  And that the great monster is indomitable, you
Title:  will yet have reason to know.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 81
Title:  
Title:  The Pequod Meets The Virgin.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  The predestinated day arrived, and we duly met the ship Jungfrau,
Title:  Derick De Deer, master, of Bremen.
Title:  
Title:  At one time the greatest whaling people in the world, the Dutch and
Title:  Germans are now among the least; but here and there at very wide
Title:  intervals of latitude and longitude, you still occasionally meet with
Title:  their flag in the Pacific.
Title:  
Title:  For some reason, the Jungfrau seemed quite eager to pay her respects.
Title:  While yet some distance from the Pequod, she rounded to, and
Title:  dropping a boat, her captain was impelled towards us, impatiently
Title:  standing in the bows instead of the stern.
Title:  
Title:  "What has he in his hand there?" cried Starbuck, pointing to
Title:  something wavingly held by the German.  "Impossible!--a lamp-feeder!"
Title:  
Title:  "Not that," said Stubb, "no, no, it's a coffee-pot, Mr. Starbuck;
Title:  he's coming off to make us our coffee, is the Yarman; don't you see
Title:  that big tin can there alongside of him?--that's his boiling water.
Title:  Oh! he's all right, is the Yarman."
Title:  
Title:  "Go along with you," cried Flask, "it's a lamp-feeder and an oil-can.
Title:  He's out of oil, and has come a-begging."
Title:  
Title:  However curious it may seem for an oil-ship to be borrowing oil on
Title:  the whale-ground, and however much it may invertedly contradict the
Title:  old proverb about carrying coals to Newcastle, yet sometimes such a
Title:  thing really happens; and in the present case Captain Derick De Deer
Title:  did indubitably conduct a lamp-feeder as Flask did declare.
Title:  
Title:  As he mounted the deck, Ahab abruptly accosted him, without at all
Title:  heeding what he had in his hand; but in his broken lingo, the German
Title:  soon evinced his complete ignorance of the White Whale; immediately
Title:  turning the conversation to his lamp-feeder and oil can, with some
Title:  remarks touching his having to turn into his hammock at night in
Title:  profound darkness--his last drop of Bremen oil being gone, and not a
Title:  single flying-fish yet captured to supply the deficiency; concluding
Title:  by hinting that his ship was indeed what in the Fishery is
Title:  technically called a CLEAN one (that is, an empty one), well
Title:  deserving the name of Jungfrau or the Virgin.
Title:  
Title:  His necessities supplied, Derick departed; but he had not gained his
Title:  ship's side, when whales were almost simultaneously raised from the
Title:  mast-heads of both vessels; and so eager for the chase was Derick,
Title:  that without pausing to put his oil-can and lamp-feeder aboard, he
Title:  slewed round his boat and made after the leviathan lamp-feeders.
Title:  
Title:  Now, the game having risen to leeward, he and the other three German
Title:  boats that soon followed him, had considerably the start of the
Title:  Pequod's keels.  There were eight whales, an average pod.  Aware of
Title:  their danger, they were going all abreast with great speed straight
Title:  before the wind, rubbing their flanks as closely as so many spans of
Title:  horses in harness.  They left a great, wide wake, as though
Title:  continually unrolling a great wide parchment upon the sea.
Title:  
Title:  Full in this rapid wake, and many fathoms in the rear, swam a huge,
Title:  humped old bull, which by his comparatively slow progress, as well as
Title:  by the unusual yellowish incrustations overgrowing him, seemed
Title:  afflicted with the jaundice, or some other infirmity.  Whether this
Title:  whale belonged to the pod in advance, seemed questionable; for it is
Title:  not customary for such venerable leviathans to be at all social.
Title:  Nevertheless, he stuck to their wake, though indeed their back water
Title:  must have retarded him, because the white-bone or swell at his broad
Title:  muzzle was a dashed one, like the swell formed when two hostile
Title:  currents meet.  His spout was short, slow, and laborious; coming
Title:  forth with a choking sort of gush, and spending itself in torn
Title:  shreds, followed by strange subterranean commotions in him, which
Title:  seemed to have egress at his other buried extremity, causing the
Title:  waters behind him to upbubble.
Title:  
Title:  "Who's got some paregoric?" said Stubb, "he has the stomach-ache, I'm
Title:  afraid.  Lord, think of having half an acre of stomach-ache!  Adverse
Title:  winds are holding mad Christmas in him, boys.  It's the first foul
Title:  wind I ever knew to blow from astern; but look, did ever whale yaw
Title:  so before? it must be, he's lost his tiller."
Title:  
Title:  As an overladen Indiaman bearing down the Hindostan coast with a deck
Title:  load of frightened horses, careens, buries, rolls, and wallows on her
Title:  way; so did this old whale heave his aged bulk, and now and then
Title:  partly turning over on his cumbrous rib-ends, expose the cause of his
Title:  devious wake in the unnatural stump of his starboard fin.  Whether he
Title:  had lost that fin in battle, or had been born without it, it were
Title:  hard to say.
Title:  
Title:  "Only wait a bit, old chap, and I'll give ye a sling for that wounded
Title:  arm," cried cruel Flask, pointing to the whale-line near him.
Title:  
Title:  "Mind he don't sling thee with it," cried Starbuck.  "Give way, or
Title:  the German will have him."
Title:  
Title:  With one intent all the combined rival boats were pointed for this
Title:  one fish, because not only was he the largest, and therefore the most
Title:  valuable whale, but he was nearest to them, and the other whales were
Title:  going with such great velocity, moreover, as almost to defy pursuit
Title:  for the time.  At this juncture the Pequod's keels had shot by the
Title:  three German boats last lowered; but from the great start he had had,
Title:  Derick's boat still led the chase, though every moment neared by his
Title:  foreign rivals.  The only thing they feared, was, that from being
Title:  already so nigh to his mark, he would be enabled to dart his iron
Title:  before they could completely overtake and pass him.  As for Derick,
Title:  he seemed quite confident that this would be the case, and
Title:  occasionally with a deriding gesture shook his lamp-feeder at the
Title:  other boats.
Title:  
Title:  "The ungracious and ungrateful dog!" cried Starbuck; "he mocks and
Title:  dares me with the very poor-box I filled for him not five minutes
Title:  ago!"--then in his old intense whisper--"Give way, greyhounds!  Dog
Title:  to it!"
Title:  
Title:  "I tell ye what it is, men"--cried Stubb to his crew--"it's against
Title:  my religion to get mad; but I'd like to eat that villainous
Title:  Yarman--Pull--won't ye?  Are ye going to let that rascal beat ye?  Do
Title:  ye love brandy?  A hogshead of brandy, then, to the best man.  Come,
Title:  why don't some of ye burst a blood-vessel?  Who's that been dropping
Title:  an anchor overboard--we don't budge an inch--we're becalmed.  Halloo,
Title:  here's grass growing in the boat's bottom--and by the Lord, the mast
Title:  there's budding.  This won't do, boys.  Look at that Yarman!  The
Title:  short and long of it is, men, will ye spit fire or not?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh! see the suds he makes!" cried Flask, dancing up and down--"What
Title:  a hump--Oh, DO pile on the beef--lays like a log!  Oh! my lads, DO
Title:  spring--slap-jacks and quahogs for supper, you know, my lads--baked
Title:  clams and muffins--oh, DO, DO, spring,--he's a hundred barreller--don't
Title:  lose him now--don't oh, DON'T!--see that Yarman--Oh,
Title:  won't ye pull for your duff, my lads--such a sog! such a sogger!
Title:  Don't ye love sperm?  There goes three thousand dollars, men!--a
Title:  bank!--a whole bank!  The bank of England!--Oh, DO, DO, DO!--What's
Title:  that Yarman about now?"
Title:  
Title:  At this moment Derick was in the act of pitching his lamp-feeder at
Title:  the advancing boats, and also his oil-can; perhaps with the double
Title:  view of retarding his rivals' way, and at the same time economically
Title:  accelerating his own by the momentary impetus of the backward toss.
Title:  
Title:  "The unmannerly Dutch dogger!" cried Stubb.  "Pull now, men, like
Title:  fifty thousand line-of-battle-ship loads of red-haired devils.  What
Title:  d'ye say, Tashtego; are you the man to snap your spine in
Title:  two-and-twenty pieces for the honour of old Gayhead?  What d'ye say?"
Title:  
Title:  "I say, pull like god-dam,"--cried the Indian.
Title:  
Title:  Fiercely, but evenly incited by the taunts of the German, the
Title:  Pequod's three boats now began ranging almost abreast; and, so
Title:  disposed, momentarily neared him.  In that fine, loose, chivalrous
Title:  attitude of the headsman when drawing near to his prey, the three
Title:  mates stood up proudly, occasionally backing the after oarsman with
Title:  an exhilarating cry of, "There she slides, now!  Hurrah for the
Title:  white-ash breeze!  Down with the Yarman!  Sail over him!"
Title:  
Title:  But so decided an original start had Derick had, that spite of all
Title:  their gallantry, he would have proved the victor in this race, had
Title:  not a righteous judgment descended upon him in a crab which caught
Title:  the blade of his midship oarsman.  While this clumsy lubber was
Title:  striving to free his white-ash, and while, in consequence, Derick's
Title:  boat was nigh to capsizing, and he thundering away at his men in a
Title:  mighty rage;--that was a good time for Starbuck, Stubb, and Flask.
Title:  With a shout, they took a mortal start forwards, and slantingly
Title:  ranged up on the German's quarter.  An instant more, and all four
Title:  boats were diagonically in the whale's immediate wake, while
Title:  stretching from them, on both sides, was the foaming swell that he
Title:  made.
Title:  
Title:  It was a terrific, most pitiable, and maddening sight.  The whale was
Title:  now going head out, and sending his spout before him in a continual
Title:  tormented jet; while his one poor fin beat his side in an agony of
Title:  fright.  Now to this hand, now to that, he yawed in his faltering
Title:  flight, and still at every billow that he broke, he spasmodically
Title:  sank in the sea, or sideways rolled towards the sky his one beating
Title:  fin.  So have I seen a bird with clipped wing making affrighted
Title:  broken circles in the air, vainly striving to escape the piratical
Title:  hawks.  But the bird has a voice, and with plaintive cries will make
Title:  known her fear; but the fear of this vast dumb brute of the sea, was
Title:  chained up and enchanted in him; he had no voice, save that choking
Title:  respiration through his spiracle, and this made the sight of him
Title:  unspeakably pitiable; while still, in his amazing bulk, portcullis
Title:  jaw, and omnipotent tail, there was enough to appal the stoutest man
Title:  who so pitied.
Title:  
Title:  Seeing now that but a very few moments more would give the Pequod's
Title:  boats the advantage, and rather than be thus foiled of his game,
Title:  Derick chose to hazard what to him must have seemed a most unusually
Title:  long dart, ere the last chance would for ever escape.
Title:  
Title:  But no sooner did his harpooneer stand up for the stroke, than all
Title:  three tigers--Queequeg, Tashtego, Daggoo--instinctively sprang to
Title:  their feet, and standing in a diagonal row, simultaneously pointed
Title:  their barbs; and darted over the head of the German harpooneer, their
Title:  three Nantucket irons entered the whale.  Blinding vapours of foam and
Title:  white-fire!  The three boats, in the first fury of the whale's
Title:  headlong rush, bumped the German's aside with such force, that both
Title:  Derick and his baffled harpooneer were spilled out, and sailed over
Title:  by the three flying keels.
Title:  
Title:  "Don't be afraid, my butter-boxes," cried Stubb, casting a passing
Title:  glance upon them as he shot by; "ye'll be picked up presently--all
Title:  right--I saw some sharks astern--St. Bernard's dogs, you
Title:  know--relieve distressed travellers.  Hurrah! this is the way to sail
Title:  now.  Every keel a sunbeam!  Hurrah!--Here we go like three tin
Title:  kettles at the tail of a mad cougar!  This puts me in mind of
Title:  fastening to an elephant in a tilbury on a plain--makes the
Title:  wheel-spokes fly, boys, when you fasten to him that way; and there's
Title:  danger of being pitched out too, when you strike a hill.  Hurrah!
Title:  this is the way a fellow feels when he's going to Davy Jones--all a
Title:  rush down an endless inclined plane!  Hurrah! this whale carries the
Title:  everlasting mail!"
Title:  
Title:  But the monster's run was a brief one.  Giving a sudden gasp, he
Title:  tumultuously sounded.  With a grating rush, the three lines flew
Title:  round the loggerheads with such a force as to gouge deep grooves in
Title:  them; while so fearful were the harpooneers that this rapid sounding
Title:  would soon exhaust the lines, that using all their dexterous might,
Title:  they caught repeated smoking turns with the rope to hold on; till at
Title:  last--owing to the perpendicular strain from the lead-lined chocks of
Title:  the boats, whence the three ropes went straight down into the
Title:  blue--the gunwales of the bows were almost even with the water, while
Title:  the three sterns tilted high in the air.  And the whale soon ceasing
Title:  to sound, for some time they remained in that attitude, fearful of
Title:  expending more line, though the position was a little ticklish.  But
Title:  though boats have been taken down and lost in this way, yet it is
Title:  this "holding on," as it is called; this hooking up by the sharp
Title:  barbs of his live flesh from the back; this it is that often torments
Title:  the Leviathan into soon rising again to meet the sharp lance of his
Title:  foes.  Yet not to speak of the peril of the thing, it is to be
Title:  doubted whether this course is always the best; for it is but
Title:  reasonable to presume, that the longer the stricken whale stays under
Title:  water, the more he is exhausted.  Because, owing to the enormous
Title:  surface of him--in a full grown sperm whale something less than 2000
Title:  square feet--the pressure of the water is immense.  We all know what
Title:  an astonishing atmospheric weight we ourselves stand up under; even
Title:  here, above-ground, in the air; how vast, then, the burden of a
Title:  whale, bearing on his back a column of two hundred fathoms of ocean!
Title:  It must at least equal the weight of fifty atmospheres.  One whaleman
Title:  has estimated it at the weight of twenty line-of-battle ships, with
Title:  all their guns, and stores, and men on board.
Title:  
Title:  As the three boats lay there on that gently rolling sea, gazing down
Title:  into its eternal blue noon; and as not a single groan or cry of any
Title:  sort, nay, not so much as a ripple or a bubble came up from its
Title:  depths; what landsman would have thought, that beneath all that
Title:  silence and placidity, the utmost monster of the seas was writhing
Title:  and wrenching in agony!  Not eight inches of perpendicular rope were
Title:  visible at the bows.  Seems it credible that by three such thin
Title:  threads the great Leviathan was suspended like the big weight to an
Title:  eight day clock.  Suspended? and to what?  To three bits of board.
Title:  Is this the creature of whom it was once so triumphantly said--"Canst
Title:  thou fill his skin with barbed irons? or his head with fish-spears?
Title:  The sword of him that layeth at him cannot hold, the spear, the dart,
Title:  nor the habergeon: he esteemeth iron as straw; the arrow cannot make
Title:  him flee; darts are counted as stubble; he laugheth at the shaking of
Title:  a spear!"  This the creature? this he?  Oh! that unfulfilments should
Title:  follow the prophets.  For with the strength of a thousand thighs in
Title:  his tail, Leviathan had run his head under the mountains of the sea,
Title:  to hide him from the Pequod's fish-spears!
Title:  
Title:  In that sloping afternoon sunlight, the shadows that the three boats
Title:  sent down beneath the surface, must have been long enough and broad
Title:  enough to shade half Xerxes' army.  Who can tell how appalling to the
Title:  wounded whale must have been such huge phantoms flitting over his
Title:  head!
Title:  
Title:  "Stand by, men; he stirs," cried Starbuck, as the three lines
Title:  suddenly vibrated in the water, distinctly conducting upwards to
Title:  them, as by magnetic wires, the life and death throbs of the whale,
Title:  so that every oarsman felt them in his seat.  The next moment,
Title:  relieved in great part from the downward strain at the bows, the
Title:  boats gave a sudden bounce upwards, as a small icefield will, when a
Title:  dense herd of white bears are scared from it into the sea.
Title:  
Title:  "Haul in!  Haul in!" cried Starbuck again; "he's rising."
Title:  
Title:  The lines, of which, hardly an instant before, not one hand's breadth
Title:  could have been gained, were now in long quick coils flung back all
Title:  dripping into the boats, and soon the whale broke water within two
Title:  ship's lengths of the hunters.
Title:  
Title:  His motions plainly denoted his extreme exhaustion.  In most land
Title:  animals there are certain valves or flood-gates in many of their
Title:  veins, whereby when wounded, the blood is in some degree at least
Title:  instantly shut off in certain directions.  Not so with the whale; one
Title:  of whose peculiarities it is to have an entire non-valvular structure
Title:  of the blood-vessels, so that when pierced even by so small a point
Title:  as a harpoon, a deadly drain is at once begun upon his whole
Title:  arterial system; and when this is heightened by the extraordinary
Title:  pressure of water at a great distance below the surface, his life may
Title:  be said to pour from him in incessant streams.  Yet so vast is the
Title:  quantity of blood in him, and so distant and numerous its interior
Title:  fountains, that he will keep thus bleeding and bleeding for a
Title:  considerable period; even as in a drought a river will flow, whose
Title:  source is in the well-springs of far-off and undiscernible hills.
Title:  Even now, when the boats pulled upon this whale, and perilously drew
Title:  over his swaying flukes, and the lances were darted into him, they
Title:  were followed by steady jets from the new made wound, which kept
Title:  continually playing, while the natural spout-hole in his head was
Title:  only at intervals, however rapid, sending its affrighted moisture
Title:  into the air.  From this last vent no blood yet came, because no
Title:  vital part of him had thus far been struck.  His life, as they
Title:  significantly call it, was untouched.
Title:  
Title:  As the boats now more closely surrounded him, the whole upper part of
Title:  his form, with much of it that is ordinarily submerged, was plainly
Title:  revealed.  His eyes, or rather the places where his eyes had been,
Title:  were beheld.  As strange misgrown masses gather in the knot-holes of
Title:  the noblest oaks when prostrate, so from the points which the whale's
Title:  eyes had once occupied, now protruded blind bulbs, horribly pitiable
Title:  to see.  But pity there was none.  For all his old age, and his one
Title:  arm, and his blind eyes, he must die the death and be murdered, in
Title:  order to light the gay bridals and other merry-makings of men, and
Title:  also to illuminate the solemn churches that preach unconditional
Title:  inoffensiveness by all to all.  Still rolling in his blood, at last
Title:  he partially disclosed a strangely discoloured bunch or protuberance,
Title:  the size of a bushel, low down on the flank.
Title:  
Title:  "A nice spot," cried Flask; "just let me prick him there once."
Title:  
Title:  "Avast!" cried Starbuck, "there's no need of that!"
Title:  
Title:  But humane Starbuck was too late.  At the instant of the dart an
Title:  ulcerous jet shot from this cruel wound, and goaded by it into more
Title:  than sufferable anguish, the whale now spouting thick blood, with
Title:  swift fury blindly darted at the craft, bespattering them and their
Title:  glorying crews all over with showers of gore, capsizing Flask's boat
Title:  and marring the bows.  It was his death stroke.  For, by this time,
Title:  so spent was he by loss of blood, that he helplessly rolled away from
Title:  the wreck he had made; lay panting on his side, impotently flapped
Title:  with his stumped fin, then over and over slowly revolved like a
Title:  waning world; turned up the white secrets of his belly; lay like a
Title:  log, and died.  It was most piteous, that last expiring spout.  As
Title:  when by unseen hands the water is gradually drawn off from some
Title:  mighty fountain, and with half-stifled melancholy gurglings the
Title:  spray-column lowers and lowers to the ground--so the last long dying
Title:  spout of the whale.
Title:  
Title:  Soon, while the crews were awaiting the arrival of the ship, the body
Title:  showed symptoms of sinking with all its treasures unrifled.
Title:  Immediately, by Starbuck's orders, lines were secured to it at
Title:  different points, so that ere long every boat was a buoy; the sunken
Title:  whale being suspended a few inches beneath them by the cords.  By
Title:  very heedful management, when the ship drew nigh, the whale was
Title:  transferred to her side, and was strongly secured there by the
Title:  stiffest fluke-chains, for it was plain that unless artificially
Title:  upheld, the body would at once sink to the bottom.
Title:  
Title:  It so chanced that almost upon first cutting into him with the
Title:  spade, the entire length of a corroded harpoon was found imbedded in
Title:  his flesh, on the lower part of the bunch before described.  But as
Title:  the stumps of harpoons are frequently found in the dead bodies of
Title:  captured whales, with the flesh perfectly healed around them, and no
Title:  prominence of any kind to denote their place; therefore, there must
Title:  needs have been some other unknown reason in the present case fully
Title:  to account for the ulceration alluded to.  But still more curious was
Title:  the fact of a lance-head of stone being found in him, not far from
Title:  the buried iron, the flesh perfectly firm about it.  Who had darted
Title:  that stone lance?  And when?  It might have been darted by some Nor'
Title:  West Indian long before America was discovered.
Title:  
Title:  What other marvels might have been rummaged out of this monstrous
Title:  cabinet there is no telling.  But a sudden stop was put to further
Title:  discoveries, by the ship's being unprecedentedly dragged over
Title:  sideways to the sea, owing to the body's immensely increasing
Title:  tendency to sink.  However, Starbuck, who had the ordering of
Title:  affairs, hung on to it to the last; hung on to it so resolutely,
Title:  indeed, that when at length the ship would have been capsized, if
Title:  still persisting in locking arms with the body; then, when the
Title:  command was given to break clear from it, such was the immovable
Title:  strain upon the timber-heads to which the fluke-chains and cables
Title:  were fastened, that it was impossible to cast them off.  Meantime
Title:  everything in the Pequod was aslant.  To cross to the other side of
Title:  the deck was like walking up the steep gabled roof of a house.  The
Title:  ship groaned and gasped.  Many of the ivory inlayings of her bulwarks
Title:  and cabins were started from their places, by the unnatural
Title:  dislocation.  In vain handspikes and crows were brought to bear upon
Title:  the immovable fluke-chains, to pry them adrift from the timberheads;
Title:  and so low had the whale now settled that the submerged ends could
Title:  not be at all approached, while every moment whole tons of
Title:  ponderosity seemed added to the sinking bulk, and the ship seemed on
Title:  the point of going over.
Title:  
Title:  "Hold on, hold on, won't ye?" cried Stubb to the body, "don't be in
Title:  such a devil of a hurry to sink!  By thunder, men, we must do
Title:  something or go for it.  No use prying there; avast, I say with your
Title:  handspikes, and run one of ye for a prayer book and a pen-knife, and
Title:  cut the big chains."
Title:  
Title:  "Knife?  Aye, aye," cried Queequeg, and seizing the carpenter's heavy
Title:  hatchet, he leaned out of a porthole, and steel to iron, began
Title:  slashing at the largest fluke-chains.  But a few strokes, full of
Title:  sparks, were given, when the exceeding strain effected the rest.
Title:  With a terrific snap, every fastening went adrift; the ship righted,
Title:  the carcase sank.
Title:  
Title:  Now, this occasional inevitable sinking of the recently killed Sperm
Title:  Whale is a very curious thing; nor has any fisherman yet adequately
Title:  accounted for it.  Usually the dead Sperm Whale floats with great
Title:  buoyancy, with its side or belly considerably elevated above the
Title:  surface.  If the only whales that thus sank were old, meagre, and
Title:  broken-hearted creatures, their pads of lard diminished and all their
Title:  bones heavy and rheumatic; then you might with some reason assert
Title:  that this sinking is caused by an uncommon specific gravity in the
Title:  fish so sinking, consequent upon this absence of buoyant matter in
Title:  him.  But it is not so.  For young whales, in the highest health, and
Title:  swelling with noble aspirations, prematurely cut off in the warm
Title:  flush and May of life, with all their panting lard about them; even
Title:  these brawny, buoyant heroes do sometimes sink.
Title:  
Title:  Be it said, however, that the Sperm Whale is far less liable to this
Title:  accident than any other species.  Where one of that sort go down,
Title:  twenty Right Whales do.  This difference in the species is no doubt
Title:  imputable in no small degree to the greater quantity of bone in the
Title:  Right Whale; his Venetian blinds alone sometimes weighing more than a
Title:  ton; from this incumbrance the Sperm Whale is wholly free.  But there
Title:  are instances where, after the lapse of many hours or several days,
Title:  the sunken whale again rises, more buoyant than in life.  But the
Title:  reason of this is obvious.  Gases are generated in him; he swells to
Title:  a prodigious magnitude; becomes a sort of animal balloon.  A
Title:  line-of-battle ship could hardly keep him under then.  In the Shore
Title:  Whaling, on soundings, among the Bays of New Zealand, when a Right
Title:  Whale gives token of sinking, they fasten buoys to him, with plenty
Title:  of rope; so that when the body has gone down, they know where to look
Title:  for it when it shall have ascended again.
Title:  
Title:  It was not long after the sinking of the body that a cry was heard
Title:  from the Pequod's mast-heads, announcing that the Jungfrau was again
Title:  lowering her boats; though the only spout in sight was that of a
Title:  Fin-Back, belonging to the species of uncapturable whales, because of
Title:  its incredible power of swimming.  Nevertheless, the Fin-Back's spout
Title:  is so similar to the Sperm Whale's, that by unskilful fishermen it is
Title:  often mistaken for it.  And consequently Derick and all his host were
Title:  now in valiant chase of this unnearable brute.  The Virgin crowding
Title:  all sail, made after her four young keels, and thus they all
Title:  disappeared far to leeward, still in bold, hopeful chase.
Title:  
Title:  Oh! many are the Fin-Backs, and many are the Dericks, my friend.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 82
Title:  
Title:  The Honour and Glory of Whaling.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  There are some enterprises in which a careful disorderliness is the
Title:  true method.
Title:  
Title:  The more I dive into this matter of whaling, and push my researches
Title:  up to the very spring-head of it so much the more am I impressed with
Title:  its great honourableness and antiquity; and especially when I find so
Title:  many great demi-gods and heroes, prophets of all sorts, who one way
Title:  or other have shed distinction upon it, I am transported with the
Title:  reflection that I myself belong, though but subordinately, to so
Title:  emblazoned a fraternity.
Title:  
Title:  The gallant Perseus, a son of Jupiter, was the first whaleman; and to
Title:  the eternal honour of our calling be it said, that the first whale
Title:  attacked by our brotherhood was not killed with any sordid intent.
Title:  Those were the knightly days of our profession, when we only bore
Title:  arms to succor the distressed, and not to fill men's lamp-feeders.
Title:  Every one knows the fine story of Perseus and Andromeda; how the
Title:  lovely Andromeda, the daughter of a king, was tied to a rock on the
Title:  sea-coast, and as Leviathan was in the very act of carrying her off,
Title:  Perseus, the prince of whalemen, intrepidly advancing, harpooned the
Title:  monster, and delivered and married the maid.  It was an admirable
Title:  artistic exploit, rarely achieved by the best harpooneers of the
Title:  present day; inasmuch as this Leviathan was slain at the very first
Title:  dart.  And let no man doubt this Arkite story; for in the ancient
Title:  Joppa, now Jaffa, on the Syrian coast, in one of the Pagan temples,
Title:  there stood for many ages the vast skeleton of a whale, which the
Title:  city's legends and all the inhabitants asserted to be the identical
Title:  bones of the monster that Perseus slew.  When the Romans took Joppa,
Title:  the same skeleton was carried to Italy in triumph.  What seems most
Title:  singular and suggestively important in this story, is this: it was
Title:  from Joppa that Jonah set sail.
Title:  
Title:  Akin to the adventure of Perseus and Andromeda--indeed, by some
Title:  supposed to be indirectly derived from it--is that famous story of
Title:  St. George and the Dragon; which dragon I maintain to have been a
Title:  whale; for in many old chronicles whales and dragons are strangely
Title:  jumbled together, and often stand for each other.  "Thou art as a
Title:  lion of the waters, and as a dragon of the sea," saith Ezekiel;
Title:  hereby, plainly meaning a whale; in truth, some versions of the Bible
Title:  use that word itself.  Besides, it would much subtract from the glory
Title:  of the exploit had St. George but encountered a crawling reptile of
Title:  the land, instead of doing battle with the great monster of the deep.
Title:  Any man may kill a snake, but only a Perseus, a St. George, a
Title:  Coffin, have the heart in them to march boldly up to a whale.
Title:  
Title:  Let not the modern paintings of this scene mislead us; for though the
Title:  creature encountered by that valiant whaleman of old is vaguely
Title:  represented of a griffin-like shape, and though the battle is
Title:  depicted on land and the saint on horseback, yet considering the
Title:  great ignorance of those times, when the true form of the whale was
Title:  unknown to artists; and considering that as in Perseus' case, St.
Title:  George's whale might have crawled up out of the sea on the beach; and
Title:  considering that the animal ridden by St. George might have been only
Title:  a large seal, or sea-horse; bearing all this in mind, it will not
Title:  appear altogether incompatible with the sacred legend and the
Title:  ancientest draughts of the scene, to hold this so-called dragon no
Title:  other than the great Leviathan himself.  In fact, placed before the
Title:  strict and piercing truth, this whole story will fare like that fish,
Title:  flesh, and fowl idol of the Philistines, Dagon by name; who being
Title:  planted before the ark of Israel, his horse's head and both the palms
Title:  of his hands fell off from him, and only the stump or fishy part of
Title:  him remained.  Thus, then, one of our own noble stamp, even a
Title:  whaleman, is the tutelary guardian of England; and by good rights, we
Title:  harpooneers of Nantucket should be enrolled in the most noble order
Title:  of St. George.  And therefore, let not the knights of that honourable
Title:  company (none of whom, I venture to say, have ever had to do with a
Title:  whale like their great patron), let them never eye a Nantucketer with
Title:  disdain, since even in our woollen frocks and tarred trowsers we are
Title:  much better entitled to St. George's decoration than they.
Title:  
Title:  Whether to admit Hercules among us or not, concerning this I long
Title:  remained dubious: for though according to the Greek mythologies, that
