Title:  antique Crockett and Kit Carson--that brawny doer of rejoicing good
Title:  deeds, was swallowed down and thrown up by a whale; still, whether
Title:  that strictly makes a whaleman of him, that might be mooted.  It
Title:  nowhere appears that he ever actually harpooned his fish, unless,
Title:  indeed, from the inside.  Nevertheless, he may be deemed a sort of
Title:  involuntary whaleman; at any rate the whale caught him, if he did not
Title:  the whale.  I claim him for one of our clan.
Title:  
Title:  But, by the best contradictory authorities, this Grecian story of
Title:  Hercules and the whale is considered to be derived from the still
Title:  more ancient Hebrew story of Jonah and the whale; and vice versa;
Title:  certainly they are very similar.  If I claim the demigod then, why
Title:  not the prophet?
Title:  
Title:  Nor do heroes, saints, demigods, and prophets alone comprise the
Title:  whole roll of our order.  Our grand master is still to be named; for
Title:  like royal kings of old times, we find the head waters of our
Title:  fraternity in nothing short of the great gods themselves.  That
Title:  wondrous oriental story is now to be rehearsed from the Shaster,
Title:  which gives us the dread Vishnoo, one of the three persons in the
Title:  godhead of the Hindoos; gives us this divine Vishnoo himself for our
Title:  Lord;--Vishnoo, who, by the first of his ten earthly incarnations,
Title:  has for ever set apart and sanctified the whale.  When Brahma, or the
Title:  God of Gods, saith the Shaster, resolved to recreate the world after
Title:  one of its periodical dissolutions, he gave birth to Vishnoo, to
Title:  preside over the work; but the Vedas, or mystical books, whose
Title:  perusal would seem to have been indispensable to Vishnoo before
Title:  beginning the creation, and which therefore must have contained
Title:  something in the shape of practical hints to young architects, these
Title:  Vedas were lying at the bottom of the waters; so Vishnoo became
Title:  incarnate in a whale, and sounding down in him to the uttermost
Title:  depths, rescued the sacred volumes.  Was not this Vishnoo a whaleman,
Title:  then? even as a man who rides a horse is called a horseman?
Title:  
Title:  Perseus, St. George, Hercules, Jonah, and Vishnoo! there's a
Title:  member-roll for you!  What club but the whaleman's can head off like
Title:  that?
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 83
Title:  
Title:  Jonah Historically Regarded.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Reference was made to the historical story of Jonah and the whale in
Title:  the preceding chapter.  Now some Nantucketers rather distrust this
Title:  historical story of Jonah and the whale.  But then there were some
Title:  sceptical Greeks and Romans, who, standing out from the orthodox
Title:  pagans of their times, equally doubted the story of Hercules and the
Title:  whale, and Arion and the dolphin; and yet their doubting those
Title:  traditions did not make those traditions one whit the less facts, for
Title:  all that.
Title:  
Title:  One old Sag-Harbor whaleman's chief reason for questioning the Hebrew
Title:  story was this:--He had one of those quaint old-fashioned Bibles,
Title:  embellished with curious, unscientific plates; one of which
Title:  represented Jonah's whale with two spouts in his head--a peculiarity
Title:  only true with respect to a species of the Leviathan (the Right
Title:  Whale, and the varieties of that order), concerning which the
Title:  fishermen have this saying, "A penny roll would choke him"; his
Title:  swallow is so very small.  But, to this, Bishop Jebb's anticipative
Title:  answer is ready.  It is not necessary, hints the Bishop, that we
Title:  consider Jonah as tombed in the whale's belly, but as temporarily
Title:  lodged in some part of his mouth.  And this seems reasonable enough
Title:  in the good Bishop.  For truly, the Right Whale's mouth would
Title:  accommodate a couple of whist-tables, and comfortably seat all the
Title:  players.  Possibly, too, Jonah might have ensconced himself in a
Title:  hollow tooth; but, on second thoughts, the Right Whale is toothless.
Title:  
Title:  Another reason which Sag-Harbor (he went by that name) urged for his
Title:  want of faith in this matter of the prophet, was something obscurely
Title:  in reference to his incarcerated body and the whale's gastric juices.
Title:  But this objection likewise falls to the ground, because a German
Title:  exegetist supposes that Jonah must have taken refuge in the floating
Title:  body of a DEAD whale--even as the French soldiers in the Russian
Title:  campaign turned their dead horses into tents, and crawled into them.
Title:  Besides, it has been divined by other continental commentators, that
Title:  when Jonah was thrown overboard from the Joppa ship, he straightway
Title:  effected his escape to another vessel near by, some vessel with a
Title:  whale for a figure-head; and, I would add, possibly called "The
Title:  Whale," as some craft are nowadays christened the "Shark," the
Title:  "Gull," the "Eagle."  Nor have there been wanting learned exegetists
Title:  who have opined that the whale mentioned in the book of Jonah merely
Title:  meant a life-preserver--an inflated bag of wind--which the endangered
Title:  prophet swam to, and so was saved from a watery doom.  Poor
Title:  Sag-Harbor, therefore, seems worsted all round.  But he had still
Title:  another reason for his want of faith.  It was this, if I remember
Title:  right: Jonah was swallowed by the whale in the Mediterranean Sea, and
Title:  after three days he was vomited up somewhere within three days'
Title:  journey of Nineveh, a city on the Tigris, very much more than three
Title:  days' journey across from the nearest point of the Mediterranean
Title:  coast.  How is that?
Title:  
Title:  But was there no other way for the whale to land the prophet within
Title:  that short distance of Nineveh?  Yes.  He might have carried him
Title:  round by the way of the Cape of Good Hope.  But not to speak of the
Title:  passage through the whole length of the Mediterranean, and another
Title:  passage up the Persian Gulf and Red Sea, such a supposition would
Title:  involve the complete circumnavigation of all Africa in three days,
Title:  not to speak of the Tigris waters, near the site of Nineveh, being
Title:  too shallow for any whale to swim in.  Besides, this idea of Jonah's
Title:  weathering the Cape of Good Hope at so early a day would wrest the
Title:  honour of the discovery of that great headland from Bartholomew Diaz,
Title:  its reputed discoverer, and so make modern history a liar.
Title:  
Title:  But all these foolish arguments of old Sag-Harbor only evinced his
Title:  foolish pride of reason--a thing still more reprehensible in him,
Title:  seeing that he had but little learning except what he had picked up
Title:  from the sun and the sea.  I say it only shows his foolish, impious
Title:  pride, and abominable, devilish rebellion against the reverend
Title:  clergy.  For by a Portuguese Catholic priest, this very idea of
Title:  Jonah's going to Nineveh via the Cape of Good Hope was advanced as a
Title:  signal magnification of the general miracle.  And so it was.
Title:  Besides, to this day, the highly enlightened Turks devoutly believe
Title:  in the historical story of Jonah.  And some three centuries ago, an
Title:  English traveller in old Harris's Voyages, speaks of a Turkish Mosque
Title:  built in honour of Jonah, in which Mosque was a miraculous lamp that
Title:  burnt without any oil.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 84
Title:  
Title:  Pitchpoling.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  To make them run easily and swiftly, the axles of carriages are
Title:  anointed; and for much the same purpose, some whalers perform an
Title:  analogous operation upon their boat; they grease the bottom.  Nor is
Title:  it to be doubted that as such a procedure can do no harm, it may
Title:  possibly be of no contemptible advantage; considering that oil and
Title:  water are hostile; that oil is a sliding thing, and that the object
Title:  in view is to make the boat slide bravely.  Queequeg believed
Title:  strongly in anointing his boat, and one morning not long after the
Title:  German ship Jungfrau disappeared, took more than customary pains in
Title:  that occupation; crawling under its bottom, where it hung over the
Title:  side, and rubbing in the unctuousness as though diligently seeking to
Title:  insure a crop of hair from the craft's bald keel.  He seemed to be
Title:  working in obedience to some particular presentiment.  Nor did it
Title:  remain unwarranted by the event.
Title:  
Title:  Towards noon whales were raised; but so soon as the ship sailed down
Title:  to them, they turned and fled with swift precipitancy; a disordered
Title:  flight, as of Cleopatra's barges from Actium.
Title:  
Title:  Nevertheless, the boats pursued, and Stubb's was foremost.  By great
Title:  exertion, Tashtego at last succeeded in planting one iron; but the
Title:  stricken whale, without at all sounding, still continued his
Title:  horizontal flight, with added fleetness.  Such unintermitted
Title:  strainings upon the planted iron must sooner or later inevitably
Title:  extract it.  It became imperative to lance the flying whale, or be
Title:  content to lose him.  But to haul the boat up to his flank was
Title:  impossible, he swam so fast and furious.  What then remained?
Title:  
Title:  Of all the wondrous devices and dexterities, the sleights of hand and
Title:  countless subtleties, to which the veteran whaleman is so often
Title:  forced, none exceed that fine manoeuvre with the lance called
Title:  pitchpoling.  Small sword, or broad sword, in all its exercises
Title:  boasts nothing like it.  It is only indispensable with an inveterate
Title:  running whale; its grand fact and feature is the wonderful distance
Title:  to which the long lance is accurately darted from a violently
Title:  rocking, jerking boat, under extreme headway.  Steel and wood
Title:  included, the entire spear is some ten or twelve feet in length; the
Title:  staff is much slighter than that of the harpoon, and also of a
Title:  lighter material--pine.  It is furnished with a small rope called a
Title:  warp, of considerable length, by which it can be hauled back to the
Title:  hand after darting.
Title:  
Title:  But before going further, it is important to mention here, that
Title:  though the harpoon may be pitchpoled in the same way with the lance,
Title:  yet it is seldom done; and when done, is still less frequently
Title:  successful, on account of the greater weight and inferior length of
Title:  the harpoon as compared with the lance, which in effect become
Title:  serious drawbacks.  As a general thing, therefore, you must first
Title:  get fast to a whale, before any pitchpoling comes into play.
Title:  
Title:  Look now at Stubb; a man who from his humorous, deliberate coolness
Title:  and equanimity in the direst emergencies, was specially qualified to
Title:  excel in pitchpoling.  Look at him; he stands upright in the tossed
Title:  bow of the flying boat; wrapt in fleecy foam, the towing whale is
Title:  forty feet ahead.  Handling the long lance lightly, glancing twice or
Title:  thrice along its length to see if it be exactly straight, Stubb
Title:  whistlingly gathers up the coil of the warp in one hand, so as to
Title:  secure its free end in his grasp, leaving the rest unobstructed.
Title:  Then holding the lance full before his waistband's middle, he levels
Title:  it at the whale; when, covering him with it, he steadily depresses
Title:  the butt-end in his hand, thereby elevating the point till the weapon
Title:  stands fairly balanced upon his palm, fifteen feet in the air.  He
Title:  minds you somewhat of a juggler, balancing a long staff on his chin.
Title:  Next moment with a rapid, nameless impulse, in a superb lofty arch the
Title:  bright steel spans the foaming distance, and quivers in the life spot
Title:  of the whale.  Instead of sparkling water, he now spouts red blood.
Title:  
Title:  "That drove the spigot out of him!" cried Stubb.  "'Tis July's
Title:  immortal Fourth; all fountains must run wine today!  Would now, it
Title:  were old Orleans whiskey, or old Ohio, or unspeakable old
Title:  Monongahela!  Then, Tashtego, lad, I'd have ye hold a canakin to the
Title:  jet, and we'd drink round it!  Yea, verily, hearts alive, we'd brew
Title:  choice punch in the spread of his spout-hole there, and from that
Title:  live punch-bowl quaff the living stuff."
Title:  
Title:  Again and again to such gamesome talk, the dexterous dart is
Title:  repeated, the spear returning to its master like a greyhound held in
Title:  skilful leash.  The agonized whale goes into his flurry; the tow-line
Title:  is slackened, and the pitchpoler dropping astern, folds his hands,
Title:  and mutely watches the monster die.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 85
Title:  
Title:  The Fountain.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  That for six thousand years--and no one knows how many millions of
Title:  ages before--the great whales should have been spouting all over the
Title:  sea, and sprinkling and mistifying the gardens of the deep, as with
Title:  so many sprinkling or mistifying pots; and that for some centuries
Title:  back, thousands of hunters should have been close by the fountain of
Title:  the whale, watching these sprinklings and spoutings--that all this
Title:  should be, and yet, that down to this blessed minute (fifteen and a
Title:  quarter minutes past one o'clock P.M. of this sixteenth day of
Title:  December, A.D. 1851), it should still remain a problem, whether these
Title:  spoutings are, after all, really water, or nothing but vapour--this is
Title:  surely a noteworthy thing.
Title:  
Title:  Let us, then, look at this matter, along with some interesting items
Title:  contingent.  Every one knows that by the peculiar cunning of their
Title:  gills, the finny tribes in general breathe the air which at all times
Title:  is combined with the element in which they swim; hence, a herring or
Title:  a cod might live a century, and never once raise its head above the
Title:  surface.  But owing to his marked internal structure which gives him
Title:  regular lungs, like a human being's, the whale can only live by
Title:  inhaling the disengaged air in the open atmosphere.  Wherefore the
Title:  necessity for his periodical visits to the upper world.  But he
Title:  cannot in any degree breathe through his mouth, for, in his ordinary
Title:  attitude, the Sperm Whale's mouth is buried at least eight feet
Title:  beneath the surface; and what is still more, his windpipe has no
Title:  connexion with his mouth.  No, he breathes through his spiracle
Title:  alone; and this is on the top of his head.
Title:  
Title:  If I say, that in any creature breathing is only a function
Title:  indispensable to vitality, inasmuch as it withdraws from the air a
Title:  certain element, which being subsequently brought into contact with
Title:  the blood imparts to the blood its vivifying principle, I do not
Title:  think I shall err; though I may possibly use some superfluous
Title:  scientific words.  Assume it, and it follows that if all the blood in
Title:  a man could be aerated with one breath, he might then seal up his
Title:  nostrils and not fetch another for a considerable time.  That is to
Title:  say, he would then live without breathing.  Anomalous as it may seem,
Title:  this is precisely the case with the whale, who systematically lives,
Title:  by intervals, his full hour and more (when at the bottom) without
Title:  drawing a single breath, or so much as in any way inhaling a particle
Title:  of air; for, remember, he has no gills.  How is this?  Between his
Title:  ribs and on each side of his spine he is supplied with a remarkable
Title:  involved Cretan labyrinth of vermicelli-like vessels, which vessels,
Title:  when he quits the surface, are completely distended with oxygenated
Title:  blood.  So that for an hour or more, a thousand fathoms in the sea,
Title:  he carries a surplus stock of vitality in him, just as the camel
Title:  crossing the waterless desert carries a surplus supply of drink for
Title:  future use in its four supplementary stomachs.  The anatomical fact
Title:  of this labyrinth is indisputable; and that the supposition founded
Title:  upon it is reasonable and true, seems the more cogent to me, when I
Title:  consider the otherwise inexplicable obstinacy of that leviathan in
Title:  HAVING HIS SPOUTINGS OUT, as the fishermen phrase it.  This is what I
Title:  mean.  If unmolested, upon rising to the surface, the Sperm Whale
Title:  will continue there for a period of time exactly uniform with all his
Title:  other unmolested risings.  Say he stays eleven minutes, and jets
Title:  seventy times, that is, respires seventy breaths; then whenever he
Title:  rises again, he will be sure to have his seventy breaths over again,
Title:  to a minute.  Now, if after he fetches a few breaths you alarm him,
Title:  so that he sounds, he will be always dodging up again to make good
Title:  his regular allowance of air.  And not till those seventy breaths are
Title:  told, will he finally go down to stay out his full term below.
Title:  Remark, however, that in different individuals these rates are
Title:  different; but in any one they are alike.  Now, why should the whale
Title:  thus insist upon having his spoutings out, unless it be to replenish
Title:  his reservoir of air, ere descending for good?  How obvious is it,
Title:  too, that this necessity for the whale's rising exposes him to all
Title:  the fatal hazards of the chase.  For not by hook or by net could
Title:  this vast leviathan be caught, when sailing a thousand fathoms
Title:  beneath the sunlight.  Not so much thy skill, then, O hunter, as the
Title:  great necessities that strike the victory to thee!
Title:  
Title:  In man, breathing is incessantly going on--one breath only serving
Title:  for two or three pulsations; so that whatever other business he has
Title:  to attend to, waking or sleeping, breathe he must, or die he will.
Title:  But the Sperm Whale only breathes about one seventh or Sunday of his
Title:  time.
Title:  
Title:  It has been said that the whale only breathes through his spout-hole;
Title:  if it could truthfully be added that his spouts are mixed with water,
Title:  then I opine we should be furnished with the reason why his sense of
Title:  smell seems obliterated in him; for the only thing about him that at
Title:  all answers to his nose is that identical spout-hole; and being so
Title:  clogged with two elements, it could not be expected to have the power
Title:  of smelling.  But owing to the mystery of the spout--whether it be
Title:  water or whether it be vapour--no absolute certainty can as yet be
Title:  arrived at on this head.  Sure it is, nevertheless, that the Sperm
Title:  Whale has no proper olfactories.  But what does he want of them?  No
Title:  roses, no violets, no Cologne-water in the sea.
Title:  
Title:  Furthermore, as his windpipe solely opens into the tube of his
Title:  spouting canal, and as that long canal--like the grand Erie Canal--is
Title:  furnished with a sort of locks (that open and shut) for the downward
Title:  retention of air or the upward exclusion of water, therefore the
Title:  whale has no voice; unless you insult him by saying, that when he so
Title:  strangely rumbles, he talks through his nose.  But then again, what
Title:  has the whale to say?  Seldom have I known any profound being that
Title:  had anything to say to this world, unless forced to stammer out
Title:  something by way of getting a living.  Oh! happy that the world is
Title:  such an excellent listener!
Title:  
Title:  Now, the spouting canal of the Sperm Whale, chiefly intended as it is
Title:  for the conveyance of air, and for several feet laid along,
Title:  horizontally, just beneath the upper surface of his head, and a
Title:  little to one side; this curious canal is very much like a gas-pipe
Title:  laid down in a city on one side of a street.  But the question
Title:  returns whether this gas-pipe is also a water-pipe; in other words,
Title:  whether the spout of the Sperm Whale is the mere vapour of the exhaled
Title:  breath, or whether that exhaled breath is mixed with water taken in
Title:  at the mouth, and discharged through the spiracle.  It is certain
Title:  that the mouth indirectly communicates with the spouting canal; but
Title:  it cannot be proved that this is for the purpose of discharging water
Title:  through the spiracle.  Because the greatest necessity for so doing
Title:  would seem to be, when in feeding he accidentally takes in water.
Title:  But the Sperm Whale's food is far beneath the surface, and there he
Title:  cannot spout even if he would.  Besides, if you regard him very
Title:  closely, and time him with your watch, you will find that when
Title:  unmolested, there is an undeviating rhyme between the periods of his
Title:  jets and the ordinary periods of respiration.
Title:  
Title:  But why pester one with all this reasoning on the subject?  Speak
Title:  out!  You have seen him spout; then declare what the spout is; can
Title:  you not tell water from air?  My dear sir, in this world it is not so
Title:  easy to settle these plain things.  I have ever found your plain
Title:  things the knottiest of all.  And as for this whale spout, you might
Title:  almost stand in it, and yet be undecided as to what it is precisely.
Title:  
Title:  The central body of it is hidden in the snowy sparkling mist
Title:  enveloping it; and how can you certainly tell whether any water falls
Title:  from it, when, always, when you are close enough to a whale to get a
Title:  close view of his spout, he is in a prodigious commotion, the water
Title:  cascading all around him.  And if at such times you should think that
Title:  you really perceived drops of moisture in the spout, how do you know
Title:  that they are not merely condensed from its vapour; or how do you know
Title:  that they are not those identical drops superficially lodged in the
Title:  spout-hole fissure, which is countersunk into the summit of the
Title:  whale's head?  For even when tranquilly swimming through the mid-day
Title:  sea in a calm, with his elevated hump sun-dried as a dromedary's in
Title:  the desert; even then, the whale always carries a small basin of
Title:  water on his head, as under a blazing sun you will sometimes see a
Title:  cavity in a rock filled up with rain.
Title:  
Title:  Nor is it at all prudent for the hunter to be over curious touching
Title:  the precise nature of the whale spout.  It will not do for him to be
Title:  peering into it, and putting his face in it.  You cannot go with your
Title:  pitcher to this fountain and fill it, and bring it away.  For even
Title:  when coming into slight contact with the outer, vapoury shreds of the
Title:  jet, which will often happen, your skin will feverishly smart, from
Title:  the acridness of the thing so touching it.  And I know one, who
Title:  coming into still closer contact with the spout, whether with some
Title:  scientific object in view, or otherwise, I cannot say, the skin
Title:  peeled off from his cheek and arm.  Wherefore, among whalemen, the
Title:  spout is deemed poisonous; they try to evade it.  Another thing; I
Title:  have heard it said, and I do not much doubt it, that if the jet is
Title:  fairly spouted into your eyes, it will blind you.  The wisest thing
Title:  the investigator can do then, it seems to me, is to let this deadly
Title:  spout alone.
Title:  
Title:  Still, we can hypothesize, even if we cannot prove and establish.  My
Title:  hypothesis is this: that the spout is nothing but mist.  And besides
Title:  other reasons, to this conclusion I am impelled, by considerations
Title:  touching the great inherent dignity and sublimity of the Sperm Whale;
Title:  I account him no common, shallow being, inasmuch as it is an
Title:  undisputed fact that he is never found on soundings, or near shores;
Title:  all other whales sometimes are.  He is both ponderous and profound.
Title:  And I am convinced that from the heads of all ponderous profound
Title:  beings, such as Plato, Pyrrho, the Devil, Jupiter, Dante, and so on,
Title:  there always goes up a certain semi-visible steam, while in the act
Title:  of thinking deep thoughts.  While composing a little treatise on
Title:  Eternity, I had the curiosity to place a mirror before me; and ere
Title:  long saw reflected there, a curious involved worming and undulation
Title:  in the atmosphere over my head.  The invariable moisture of my hair,
Title:  while plunged in deep thought, after six cups of hot tea in my thin
Title:  shingled attic, of an August noon; this seems an additional argument
Title:  for the above supposition.
Title:  
Title:  And how nobly it raises our conceit of the mighty, misty monster, to
Title:  behold him solemnly sailing through a calm tropical sea; his vast,
Title:  mild head overhung by a canopy of vapour, engendered by his
Title:  incommunicable contemplations, and that vapour--as you will sometimes
Title:  see it--glorified by a rainbow, as if Heaven itself had put its seal
Title:  upon his thoughts.  For, d'ye see, rainbows do not visit the clear
Title:  air; they only irradiate vapour.  And so, through all the thick mists
Title:  of the dim doubts in my mind, divine intuitions now and then shoot,
Title:  enkindling my fog with a heavenly ray.  And for this I thank God; for
Title:  all have doubts; many deny; but doubts or denials, few along with
Title:  them, have intuitions.  Doubts of all things earthly, and intuitions
Title:  of some things heavenly; this combination makes neither believer nor
Title:  infidel, but makes a man who regards them both with equal eye.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 86
Title:  
Title:  The Tail.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Other poets have warbled the praises of the soft eye of the antelope,
Title:  and the lovely plumage of the bird that never alights; less
Title:  celestial, I celebrate a tail.
Title:  
Title:  Reckoning the largest sized Sperm Whale's tail to begin at that point
Title:  of the trunk where it tapers to about the girth of a man, it
Title:  comprises upon its upper surface alone, an area of at least fifty
Title:  square feet.  The compact round body of its root expands into two
Title:  broad, firm, flat palms or flukes, gradually shoaling away to less
Title:  than an inch in thickness.  At the crotch or junction, these flukes
Title:  slightly overlap, then sideways recede from each other like wings,
Title:  leaving a wide vacancy between.  In no living thing are the lines of
Title:  beauty more exquisitely defined than in the crescentic borders of
Title:  these flukes.  At its utmost expansion in the full grown whale, the
Title:  tail will considerably exceed twenty feet across.
Title:  
Title:  The entire member seems a dense webbed bed of welded sinews; but cut
Title:  into it, and you find that three distinct strata compose it:--upper,
Title:  middle, and lower.  The fibres in the upper and lower layers, are
Title:  long and horizontal; those of the middle one, very short, and running
Title:  crosswise between the outside layers.  This triune structure, as much
Title:  as anything else, imparts power to the tail.  To the student of old
Title:  Roman walls, the middle layer will furnish a curious parallel to the
Title:  thin course of tiles always alternating with the stone in those
Title:  wonderful relics of the antique, and which undoubtedly contribute so
Title:  much to the great strength of the masonry.
Title:  
Title:  But as if this vast local power in the tendinous tail were not
Title:  enough, the whole bulk of the leviathan is knit over with a warp and
Title:  woof of muscular fibres and filaments, which passing on either side
Title:  the loins and running down into the flukes, insensibly blend with
Title:  them, and largely contribute to their might; so that in the tail the
Title:  confluent measureless force of the whole whale seems concentrated to
Title:  a point.  Could annihilation occur to matter, this were the thing to
Title:  do it.
Title:  
Title:  Nor does this--its amazing strength, at all tend to cripple the
Title:  graceful flexion of its motions; where infantileness of ease
Title:  undulates through a Titanism of power.  On the contrary, those
Title:  motions derive their most appalling beauty from it.  Real strength
Title:  never impairs beauty or harmony, but it often bestows it; and in
Title:  everything imposingly beautiful, strength has much to do with the
Title:  magic.  Take away the tied tendons that all over seem bursting from
Title:  the marble in the carved Hercules, and its charm would be gone.  As
Title:  devout Eckerman lifted the linen sheet from the naked corpse of
Title:  Goethe, he was overwhelmed with the massive chest of the man, that
Title:  seemed as a Roman triumphal arch.  When Angelo paints even God the
Title:  Father in human form, mark what robustness is there.  And whatever
Title:  they may reveal of the divine love in the Son, the soft, curled,
Title:  hermaphroditical Italian pictures, in which his idea has been most
Title:  successfully embodied; these pictures, so destitute as they are of
Title:  all brawniness, hint nothing of any power, but the mere negative,
Title:  feminine one of submission and endurance, which on all hands it is
Title:  conceded, form the peculiar practical virtues of his teachings.
Title:  
Title:  Such is the subtle elasticity of the organ I treat of, that whether
Title:  wielded in sport, or in earnest, or in anger, whatever be the mood it
Title:  be in, its flexions are invariably marked by exceeding grace.
Title:  Therein no fairy's arm can transcend it.
Title:  
Title:  Five great motions are peculiar to it.  First, when used as a fin for
Title:  progression; Second, when used as a mace in battle; Third, in
Title:  sweeping; Fourth, in lobtailing; Fifth, in peaking flukes.
Title:  
Title:  First: Being horizontal in its position, the Leviathan's tail acts in
Title:  a different manner from the tails of all other sea creatures.  It
Title:  never wriggles.  In man or fish, wriggling is a sign of inferiority.
Title:  To the whale, his tail is the sole means of propulsion.  Scroll-wise
Title:  coiled forwards beneath the body, and then rapidly sprung backwards,
Title:  it is this which gives that singular darting, leaping motion to the
Title:  monster when furiously swimming.  His side-fins only serve to steer
Title:  by.
Title:  
Title:  Second: It is a little significant, that while one sperm whale only
Title:  fights another sperm whale with his head and jaw, nevertheless, in
Title:  his conflicts with man, he chiefly and contemptuously uses his tail.
Title:  In striking at a boat, he swiftly curves away his flukes from it, and
Title:  the blow is only inflicted by the recoil.  If it be made in the
Title:  unobstructed air, especially if it descend to its mark, the stroke is
Title:  then simply irresistible.  No ribs of man or boat can withstand it.
Title:  Your only salvation lies in eluding it; but if it comes sideways
Title:  through the opposing water, then partly owing to the light buoyancy
Title:  of the whale boat, and the elasticity of its materials, a cracked
Title:  rib or a dashed plank or two, a sort of stitch in the side, is
Title:  generally the most serious result.  These submerged side blows are so
Title:  often received in the fishery, that they are accounted mere child's
Title:  play.  Some one strips off a frock, and the hole is stopped.
Title:  
Title:  Third: I cannot demonstrate it, but it seems to me, that in the whale
Title:  the sense of touch is concentrated in the tail; for in this respect
Title:  there is a delicacy in it only equalled by the daintiness of the
Title:  elephant's trunk.  This delicacy is chiefly evinced in the action of
Title:  sweeping, when in maidenly gentleness the whale with a certain soft
Title:  slowness moves his immense flukes from side to side upon the surface of
Title:  the sea; and if he feel but a sailor's whisker, woe to that sailor,
Title:  whiskers and all.  What tenderness there is in that preliminary
Title:  touch!  Had this tail any prehensile power, I should straightway
Title:  bethink me of Darmonodes' elephant that so frequented the
Title:  flower-market, and with low salutations presented nosegays to
Title:  damsels, and then caressed their zones.  On more accounts than one, a
Title:  pity it is that the whale does not possess this prehensile virtue in
Title:  his tail; for I have heard of yet another elephant, that when wounded
Title:  in the fight, curved round his trunk and extracted the dart.
Title:  
Title:  Fourth: Stealing unawares upon the whale in the fancied security of
Title:  the middle of solitary seas, you find him unbent from the vast
Title:  corpulence of his dignity, and kitten-like, he plays on the ocean as
Title:  if it were a hearth.  But still you see his power in his play.  The
Title:  broad palms of his tail are flirted high into the air; then smiting
Title:  the surface, the thunderous concussion resounds for miles.  You would
Title:  almost think a great gun had been discharged; and if you noticed the
Title:  light wreath of vapour from the spiracle at his other extremity, you
Title:  would think that that was the smoke from the touch-hole.
Title:  
Title:  Fifth: As in the ordinary floating posture of the leviathan the
Title:  flukes lie considerably below the level of his back, they are then
Title:  completely out of sight beneath the surface; but when he is about to
Title:  plunge into the deeps, his entire flukes with at least thirty feet of
Title:  his body are tossed erect in the air, and so remain vibrating a
Title:  moment, till they downwards shoot out of view.  Excepting the sublime
Title:  BREACH--somewhere else to be described--this peaking of the whale's
Title:  flukes is perhaps the grandest sight to be seen in all animated
Title:  nature.  Out of the bottomless profundities the gigantic tail seems
Title:  spasmodically snatching at the highest heaven.  So in dreams, have I
Title:  seen majestic Satan thrusting forth his tormented colossal claw from
Title:  the flame Baltic of Hell.  But in gazing at such scenes, it is all in
Title:  all what mood you are in; if in the Dantean, the devils will occur to
Title:  you; if in that of Isaiah, the archangels.  Standing at the mast-head
Title:  of my ship during a sunrise that crimsoned sky and sea, I once saw a
Title:  large herd of whales in the east, all heading towards the sun, and
Title:  for a moment vibrating in concert with peaked flukes.  As it seemed
Title:  to me at the time, such a grand embodiment of adoration of the gods
Title:  was never beheld, even in Persia, the home of the fire worshippers.
Title:  As Ptolemy Philopater testified of the African elephant, I then
Title:  testified of the whale, pronouncing him the most devout of all
Title:  beings.  For according to King Juba, the military elephants of
Title:  antiquity often hailed the morning with their trunks uplifted in the
Title:  profoundest silence.
Title:  
Title:  The chance comparison in this chapter, between the whale and the
Title:  elephant, so far as some aspects of the tail of the one and the trunk
Title:  of the other are concerned, should not tend to place those two
Title:  opposite organs on an equality, much less the creatures to which they
Title:  respectively belong.  For as the mightiest elephant is but a terrier
Title:  to Leviathan, so, compared with Leviathan's tail, his trunk is but
Title:  the stalk of a lily.  The most direful blow from the elephant's trunk
Title:  were as the playful tap of a fan, compared with the measureless crush
Title:  and crash of the sperm whale's ponderous flukes, which in repeated
Title:  instances have one after the other hurled entire boats with all their
Title:  oars and crews into the air, very much as an Indian juggler tosses
Title:  his balls.*
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *Though all comparison in the way of general bulk between the whale
Title:  and the elephant is preposterous, inasmuch as in that particular the
Title:  elephant stands in much the same respect to the whale that a dog does
Title:  to the elephant; nevertheless, there are not wanting some points of
Title:  curious similitude; among these is the spout.  It is well known that
Title:  the elephant will often draw up water or dust in his trunk, and then
Title:  elevating it, jet it forth in a stream.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  The more I consider this mighty tail, the more do I deplore my
Title:  inability to express it.  At times there are gestures in it, which,
Title:  though they would well grace the hand of man, remain wholly
Title:  inexplicable.  In an extensive herd, so remarkable, occasionally, are
Title:  these mystic gestures, that I have heard hunters who have declared
Title:  them akin to Free-Mason signs and symbols; that the whale, indeed, by
Title:  these methods intelligently conversed with the world.  Nor are there
Title:  wanting other motions of the whale in his general body, full of
Title:  strangeness, and unaccountable to his most experienced assailant.
Title:  Dissect him how I may, then, I but go skin deep; I know him not,
Title:  and never will.  But if I know not even the tail of this whale, how
Title:  understand his head? much more, how comprehend his face, when face he
Title:  has none?  Thou shalt see my back parts, my tail, he seems to say,
Title:  but my face shall not be seen.  But I cannot completely make out his
Title:  back parts; and hint what he will about his face, I say again he has
Title:  no face.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 87
Title:  
Title:  The Grand Armada.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  The long and narrow peninsula of Malacca, extending south-eastward
Title:  from the territories of Birmah, forms the most southerly point of all
Title:  Asia.  In a continuous line from that peninsula stretch the long
Title:  islands of Sumatra, Java, Bally, and Timor; which, with many others,
Title:  form a vast mole, or rampart, lengthwise connecting Asia with
Title:  Australia, and dividing the long unbroken Indian ocean from the
Title:  thickly studded oriental archipelagoes.  This rampart is pierced by
Title:  several sally-ports for the convenience of ships and whales;
Title:  conspicuous among which are the straits of Sunda and Malacca.  By the
Title:  straits of Sunda, chiefly, vessels bound to China from the west,
Title:  emerge into the China seas.
Title:  
Title:  Those narrow straits of Sunda divide Sumatra from Java; and standing
Title:  midway in that vast rampart of islands, buttressed by that bold green
Title:  promontory, known to seamen as Java Head; they not a little
Title:  correspond to the central gateway opening into some vast walled
Title:  empire: and considering the inexhaustible wealth of spices, and
Title:  silks, and jewels, and gold, and ivory, with which the thousand
Title:  islands of that oriental sea are enriched, it seems a significant
Title:  provision of nature, that such treasures, by the very formation of
Title:  the land, should at least bear the appearance, however ineffectual,
Title:  of being guarded from the all-grasping western world.  The shores of
Title:  the Straits of Sunda are unsupplied with those domineering fortresses
Title:  which guard the entrances to the Mediterranean, the Baltic, and the
Title:  Propontis.  Unlike the Danes, these Orientals do not demand the
Title:  obsequious homage of lowered top-sails from the endless procession of
Title:  ships before the wind, which for centuries past, by night and by day,
Title:  have passed between the islands of Sumatra and Java, freighted with
Title:  the costliest cargoes of the east.  But while they freely waive a
Title:  ceremonial like this, they do by no means renounce their claim to
Title:  more solid tribute.
Title:  
Title:  Time out of mind the piratical proas of the Malays, lurking among the
Title:  low shaded coves and islets of Sumatra, have sallied out upon the
Title:  vessels sailing through the straits, fiercely demanding tribute at
Title:  the point of their spears.  Though by the repeated bloody
Title:  chastisements they have received at the hands of European cruisers,
Title:  the audacity of these corsairs has of late been somewhat repressed;
Title:  yet, even at the present day, we occasionally hear of English and
Title:  American vessels, which, in those waters, have been remorselessly
Title:  boarded and pillaged.
Title:  
Title:  With a fair, fresh wind, the Pequod was now drawing nigh to these
Title:  straits; Ahab purposing to pass through them into the Javan sea, and
Title:  thence, cruising northwards, over waters known to be frequented here
Title:  and there by the Sperm Whale, sweep inshore by the Philippine
Title:  Islands, and gain the far coast of Japan, in time for the great
Title:  whaling season there.  By these means, the circumnavigating Pequod
Title:  would sweep almost all the known Sperm Whale cruising grounds of the
Title:  world, previous to descending upon the Line in the Pacific; where
Title:  Ahab, though everywhere else foiled in his pursuit, firmly counted
Title:  upon giving battle to Moby Dick, in the sea he was most known to
Title:  frequent; and at a season when he might most reasonably be presumed
Title:  to be haunting it.
Title:  
Title:  But how now? in this zoned quest, does Ahab touch no land? does his
Title:  crew drink air?  Surely, he will stop for water.  Nay.  For a long
Title:  time, now, the circus-running sun has raced within his fiery ring,
Title:  and needs no sustenance but what's in himself.  So Ahab.  Mark this,
Title:  too, in the whaler.  While other hulls are loaded down with alien
Title:  stuff, to be transferred to foreign wharves; the world-wandering
Title:  whale-ship carries no cargo but herself and crew, their weapons and
Title:  their wants.  She has a whole lake's contents bottled in her ample
Title:  hold.  She is ballasted with utilities; not altogether with unusable
Title:  pig-lead and kentledge.  She carries years' water in her.  Clear old
Title:  prime Nantucket water; which, when three years afloat, the
Title:  Nantucketer, in the Pacific, prefers to drink before the brackish
Title:  fluid, but yesterday rafted off in casks, from the Peruvian or Indian
Title:  streams.  Hence it is, that, while other ships may have gone to China
Title:  from New York, and back again, touching at a score of ports, the
Title:  whale-ship, in all that interval, may not have sighted one grain of
Title:  soil; her crew having seen no man but floating seamen like
Title:  themselves.  So that did you carry them the news that another flood
Title:  had come; they would only answer--"Well, boys, here's the ark!"
Title:  
Title:  Now, as many Sperm Whales had been captured off the western coast of
Title:  Java, in the near vicinity of the Straits of Sunda; indeed, as most
Title:  of the ground, roundabout, was generally recognised by the fishermen
Title:  as an excellent spot for cruising; therefore, as the Pequod gained
Title:  more and more upon Java Head, the look-outs were repeatedly hailed,
Title:  and admonished to keep wide awake.  But though the green palmy cliffs
Title:  of the land soon loomed on the starboard bow, and with delighted
Title:  nostrils the fresh cinnamon was snuffed in the air, yet not a single
Title:  jet was descried.  Almost renouncing all thought of falling in with
Title:  any game hereabouts, the ship had well nigh entered the straits, when
Title:  the customary cheering cry was heard from aloft, and ere long a
Title:  spectacle of singular magnificence saluted us.
Title:  
Title:  But here be it premised, that owing to the unwearied activity with
Title:  which of late they have been hunted over all four oceans, the Sperm
Title:  Whales, instead of almost invariably sailing in small detached
Title:  companies, as in former times, are now frequently met with in
Title:  extensive herds, sometimes embracing so great a multitude, that it
Title:  would almost seem as if numerous nations of them had sworn solemn
Title:  league and covenant for mutual assistance and protection.  To this
Title:  aggregation of the Sperm Whale into such immense caravans, may be
Title:  imputed the circumstance that even in the best cruising grounds, you
Title:  may now sometimes sail for weeks and months together, without being
Title:  greeted by a single spout; and then be suddenly saluted by what
Title:  sometimes seems thousands on thousands.
Title:  
Title:  Broad on both bows, at the distance of some two or three miles, and
Title:  forming a great semicircle, embracing one half of the level horizon,
Title:  a continuous chain of whale-jets were up-playing and sparkling in the
Title:  noon-day air.  Unlike the straight perpendicular twin-jets of the
Title:  Right Whale, which, dividing at top, fall over in two branches, like
Title:  the cleft drooping boughs of a willow, the single forward-slanting
Title:  spout of the Sperm Whale presents a thick curled bush of white mist,
Title:  continually rising and falling away to leeward.
Title:  
Title:  Seen from the Pequod's deck, then, as she would rise on a high hill
Title:  of the sea, this host of vapoury spouts, individually curling up into
Title:  the air, and beheld through a blending atmosphere of bluish haze,
Title:  showed like the thousand cheerful chimneys of some dense metropolis,
Title:  descried of a balmy autumnal morning, by some horseman on a height.
Title:  
Title:  As marching armies approaching an unfriendly defile in the mountains,
Title:  accelerate their march, all eagerness to place that perilous passage
Title:  in their rear, and once more expand in comparative security upon the
Title:  plain; even so did this vast fleet of whales now seem hurrying
Title:  forward through the straits; gradually contracting the wings of their
Title:  semicircle, and swimming on, in one solid, but still crescentic
Title:  centre.
Title:  
Title:  Crowding all sail the Pequod pressed after them; the harpooneers
Title:  handling their weapons, and loudly cheering from the heads of their
Title:  yet suspended boats.  If the wind only held, little doubt had they,
Title:  that chased through these Straits of Sunda, the vast host would only
Title:  deploy into the Oriental seas to witness the capture of not a few of
Title:  their number.  And who could tell whether, in that congregated
Title:  caravan, Moby Dick himself might not temporarily be swimming, like
Title:  the worshipped white-elephant in the coronation procession of the
Title:  Siamese!  So with stun-sail piled on stun-sail, we sailed along,
Title:  driving these leviathans before us; when, of a sudden, the voice of
Title:  Tashtego was heard, loudly directing attention to something in our
Title:  wake.
Title:  
Title:  Corresponding to the crescent in our van, we beheld another in our
Title:  rear.  It seemed formed of detached white vapours, rising and falling
Title:  something like the spouts of the whales; only they did not so
Title:  completely come and go; for they constantly hovered, without finally
Title:  disappearing.  Levelling his glass at this sight, Ahab quickly
Title:  revolved in his pivot-hole, crying, "Aloft there, and rig whips and
Title:  buckets to wet the sails;--Malays, sir, and after us!"
Title:  
Title:  As if too long lurking behind the headlands, till the Pequod should
Title:  fairly have entered the straits, these rascally Asiatics were now in
Title:  hot pursuit, to make up for their over-cautious delay.  But when the
Title:  swift Pequod, with a fresh leading wind, was herself in hot chase;
Title:  how very kind of these tawny philanthropists to assist in speeding
Title:  her on to her own chosen pursuit,--mere riding-whips and rowels to
Title:  her, that they were.  As with glass under arm, Ahab to-and-fro paced
Title:  the deck; in his forward turn beholding the monsters he chased, and
Title:  in the after one the bloodthirsty pirates chasing him; some such
Title:  fancy as the above seemed his.  And when he glanced upon the green
Title:  walls of the watery defile in which the ship was then sailing, and
Title:  bethought him that through that gate lay the route to his vengeance,
Title:  and beheld, how that through that same gate he was now both chasing
Title:  and being chased to his deadly end; and not only that, but a herd of
Title:  remorseless wild pirates and inhuman atheistical devils were
Title:  infernally cheering him on with their curses;--when all these
Title:  conceits had passed through his brain, Ahab's brow was left gaunt and
Title:  ribbed, like the black sand beach after some stormy tide has been
Title:  gnawing it, without being able to drag the firm thing from its place.
Title:  
Title:  But thoughts like these troubled very few of the reckless crew; and
Title:  when, after steadily dropping and dropping the pirates astern, the
Title:  Pequod at last shot by the vivid green Cockatoo Point on the Sumatra
Title:  side, emerging at last upon the broad waters beyond; then, the
Title:  harpooneers seemed more to grieve that the swift whales had been
Title:  gaining upon the ship, than to rejoice that the ship had so
Title:  victoriously gained upon the Malays.  But still driving on in the
Title:  wake of the whales, at length they seemed abating their speed;
Title:  gradually the ship neared them; and the wind now dying away, word was
Title:  passed to spring to the boats.  But no sooner did the herd, by some
Title:  presumed wonderful instinct of the Sperm Whale, become notified of
Title:  the three keels that were after them,--though as yet a mile in their
Title:  rear,--than they rallied again, and forming in close ranks and
Title:  battalions, so that their spouts all looked like flashing lines of
Title:  stacked bayonets, moved on with redoubled velocity.
Title:  
Title:  Stripped to our shirts and drawers, we sprang to the white-ash, and
Title:  after several hours' pulling were almost disposed to renounce the
Title:  chase, when a general pausing commotion among the whales gave
Title:  animating token that they were now at last under the influence of
Title:  that strange perplexity of inert irresolution, which, when the
Title:  fishermen perceive it in the whale, they say he is gallied.  The
Title:  compact martial columns in which they had been hitherto rapidly and
Title:  steadily swimming, were now broken up in one measureless rout; and
Title:  like King Porus' elephants in the Indian battle with Alexander, they
Title:  seemed going mad with consternation.  In all directions expanding in
Title:  vast irregular circles, and aimlessly swimming hither and thither, by
Title:  their short thick spoutings, they plainly betrayed their distraction
Title:  of panic.  This was still more strangely evinced by those of their
Title:  number, who, completely paralysed as it were, helplessly floated like
Title:  water-logged dismantled ships on the sea.  Had these Leviathans been
Title:  but a flock of simple sheep, pursued over the pasture by three fierce
Title:  wolves, they could not possibly have evinced such excessive dismay.
Title:  But this occasional timidity is characteristic of almost all herding
Title:  creatures.  Though banding together in tens of thousands, the
Title:  lion-maned buffaloes of the West have fled before a solitary
Title:  horseman.  Witness, too, all human beings, how when herded together
Title:  in the sheepfold of a theatre's pit, they will, at the slightest
Title:  alarm of fire, rush helter-skelter for the outlets, crowding,
Title:  trampling, jamming, and remorselessly dashing each other to death.
Title:  Best, therefore, withhold any amazement at the strangely gallied
Title:  whales before us, for there is no folly of the beasts of the earth
Title:  which is not infinitely outdone by the madness of men.
Title:  
Title:  Though many of the whales, as has been said, were in violent motion,
Title:  yet it is to be observed that as a whole the herd neither advanced
Title:  nor retreated, but collectively remained in one place.  As is
Title:  customary in those cases, the boats at once separated, each making
Title:  for some one lone whale on the outskirts of the shoal.  In about
Title:  three minutes' time, Queequeg's harpoon was flung; the stricken fish
Title:  darted blinding spray in our faces, and then running away with us like
Title:  light, steered straight for the heart of the herd.  Though such a
Title:  movement on the part of the whale struck under such circumstances, is
Title:  in no wise unprecedented; and indeed is almost always more or less
Title:  anticipated; yet does it present one of the more perilous
Title:  vicissitudes of the fishery.  For as the swift monster drags you
Title:  deeper and deeper into the frantic shoal, you bid adieu to
Title:  circumspect life and only exist in a delirious throb.
Title:  
Title:  As, blind and deaf, the whale plunged forward, as if by sheer power
Title:  of speed to rid himself of the iron leech that had fastened to him;
Title:  as we thus tore a white gash in the sea, on all sides menaced as we
Title:  flew, by the crazed creatures to and fro rushing about us; our beset
Title:  boat was like a ship mobbed by ice-isles in a tempest, and striving
Title:  to steer through their complicated channels and straits, knowing not at
Title:  what moment it may be locked in and crushed.
Title:  
Title:  But not a bit daunted, Queequeg steered us manfully; now sheering off
Title:  from this monster directly across our route in advance; now edging
Title:  away from that, whose colossal flukes were suspended overhead, while
Title:  all the time, Starbuck stood up in the bows, lance in hand, pricking
Title:  out of our way whatever whales he could reach by short darts, for
Title:  there was no time to make long ones.  Nor were the oarsmen quite
Title:  idle, though their wonted duty was now altogether dispensed with.
Title:  They chiefly attended to the shouting part of the business.  "Out of
Title:  the way, Commodore!" cried one, to a great dromedary that of a sudden
Title:  rose bodily to the surface, and for an instant threatened to swamp
Title:  us.  "Hard down with your tail, there!" cried a second to another,
Title:  which, close to our gunwale, seemed calmly cooling himself with his
Title:  own fan-like extremity.
Title:  
Title:  All whaleboats carry certain curious contrivances, originally
Title:  invented by the Nantucket Indians, called druggs.  Two thick squares
Title:  of wood of equal size are stoutly clenched together, so that they
Title:  cross each other's grain at right angles; a line of considerable
Title:  length is then attached to the middle of this block, and the other
Title:  end of the line being looped, it can in a moment be fastened to a
Title:  harpoon.  It is chiefly among gallied whales that this drugg is used.
Title:  For then, more whales are close round you than you can possibly
Title:  chase at one time.  But sperm whales are not every day encountered;
Title:  while you may, then, you must kill all you can.  And if you cannot
Title:  kill them all at once, you must wing them, so that they can be
Title:  afterwards killed at your leisure.  Hence it is, that at times like
Title:  these the drugg, comes into requisition.  Our boat was furnished with
Title:  three of them.  The first and second were successfully darted, and we
Title:  saw the whales staggeringly running off, fettered by the enormous
Title:  sidelong resistance of the towing drugg.  They were cramped like
Title:  malefactors with the chain and ball.  But upon flinging the third, in
Title:  the act of tossing overboard the clumsy wooden block, it caught under
Title:  one of the seats of the boat, and in an instant tore it out and
Title:  carried it away, dropping the oarsman in the boat's bottom as the
Title:  seat slid from under him.  On both sides the sea came in at the
Title:  wounded planks, but we stuffed two or three drawers and shirts in,
Title:  and so stopped the leaks for the time.
Title:  
Title:  It had been next to impossible to dart these drugged-harpoons, were
Title:  it not that as we advanced into the herd, our whale's way greatly
Title:  diminished; moreover, that as we went still further and further from
Title:  the circumference of commotion, the direful disorders seemed waning.
Title:  So that when at last the jerking harpoon drew out, and the towing
Title:  whale sideways vanished; then, with the tapering force of his parting
Title:  momentum, we glided between two whales into the innermost heart of
Title:  the shoal, as if from some mountain torrent we had slid into a serene
Title:  valley lake.  Here the storms in the roaring glens between the
Title:  outermost whales, were heard but not felt.  In this central expanse
Title:  the sea presented that smooth satin-like surface, called a sleek,
Title:  produced by the subtle moisture thrown off by the whale in his more
Title:  quiet moods.  Yes, we were now in that enchanted calm which they say
Title:  lurks at the heart of every commotion.  And still in the distracted
Title:  distance we beheld the tumults of the outer concentric circles, and
Title:  saw successive pods of whales, eight or ten in each, swiftly going
Title:  round and round, like multiplied spans of horses in a ring; and so
Title:  closely shoulder to shoulder, that a Titanic circus-rider might
Title:  easily have over-arched the middle ones, and so have gone round on
Title:  their backs.  Owing to the density of the crowd of reposing whales,
Title:  more immediately surrounding the embayed axis of the herd, no
Title:  possible chance of escape was at present afforded us.  We must watch
Title:  for a breach in the living wall that hemmed us in; the wall that had
Title:  only admitted us in order to shut us up.  Keeping at the centre of
Title:  the lake, we were occasionally visited by small tame cows and calves;
Title:  the women and children of this routed host.
Title:  
Title:  Now, inclusive of the occasional wide intervals between the revolving
Title:  outer circles, and inclusive of the spaces between the various pods
Title:  in any one of those circles, the entire area at this juncture,
Title:  embraced by the whole multitude, must have contained at least two or
Title:  three square miles.  At any rate--though indeed such a test at such a
Title:  time might be deceptive--spoutings might be discovered from our low
Title:  boat that seemed playing up almost from the rim of the horizon.  I
Title:  mention this circumstance, because, as if the cows and calves had
Title:  been purposely locked up in this innermost fold; and as if the wide
Title:  extent of the herd had hitherto prevented them from learning the
Title:  precise cause of its stopping; or, possibly, being so young,
Title:  unsophisticated, and every way innocent and inexperienced; however it
Title:  may have been, these smaller whales--now and then visiting our
Title:  becalmed boat from the margin of the lake--evinced a wondrous
Title:  fearlessness and confidence, or else a still becharmed panic which it
Title:  was impossible not to marvel at.  Like household dogs they came
Title:  snuffling round us, right up to our gunwales, and touching them; till
Title:  it almost seemed that some spell had suddenly domesticated them.
Title:  Queequeg patted their foreheads; Starbuck scratched their backs with
Title:  his lance; but fearful of the consequences, for the time refrained
Title:  from darting it.
Title:  
Title:  But far beneath this wondrous world upon the surface, another and
Title:  still stranger world met our eyes as we gazed over the side.  For,
Title:  suspended in those watery vaults, floated the forms of the nursing
Title:  mothers of the whales, and those that by their enormous girth seemed
Title:  shortly to become mothers.  The lake, as I have hinted, was to a
Title:  considerable depth exceedingly transparent; and as human infants
Title:  while suckling will calmly and fixedly gaze away from the breast, as
Title:  if leading two different lives at the time; and while yet drawing
Title:  mortal nourishment, be still spiritually feasting upon some unearthly
Title:  reminiscence;--even so did the young of these whales seem looking up
Title:  towards us, but not at us, as if we were but a bit of Gulfweed in
Title:  their new-born sight.  Floating on their sides, the mothers also
Title:  seemed quietly eyeing us.  One of these little infants, that from
Title:  certain queer tokens seemed hardly a day old, might have measured
Title:  some fourteen feet in length, and some six feet in girth.  He was a
Title:  little frisky; though as yet his body seemed scarce yet recovered
Title:  from that irksome position it had so lately occupied in the maternal
Title:  reticule; where, tail to head, and all ready for the final spring,
Title:  the unborn whale lies bent like a Tartar's bow.  The delicate
Title:  side-fins, and the palms of his flukes, still freshly retained the
Title:  plaited crumpled appearance of a baby's ears newly arrived from
Title:  foreign parts.
Title:  
Title:  "Line! line!" cried Queequeg, looking over the gunwale; "him fast!
Title:  him fast!--Who line him!  Who struck?--Two whale; one big, one
Title:  little!"
Title:  
Title:  "What ails ye, man?" cried Starbuck.
Title:  
Title:  "Look-e here," said Queequeg, pointing down.
Title:  
Title:  As when the stricken whale, that from the tub has reeled out hundreds
Title:  of fathoms of rope; as, after deep sounding, he floats up again, and
Title:  shows the slackened curling line buoyantly rising and spiralling
Title:  towards the air; so now, Starbuck saw long coils of the umbilical
Title:  cord of Madame Leviathan, by which the young cub seemed still
Title:  tethered to its dam.  Not seldom in the rapid vicissitudes of the
Title:  chase, this natural line, with the maternal end loose, becomes
Title:  entangled with the hempen one, so that the cub is thereby trapped.
Title:  Some of the subtlest secrets of the seas seemed divulged to us in
Title:  this enchanted pond.  We saw young Leviathan amours in the deep.*
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *The sperm whale, as with all other species of the Leviathan, but
Title:  unlike most other fish, breeds indifferently at all seasons; after a
Title:  gestation which may probably be set down at nine months, producing
Title:  but one at a time; though in some few known instances giving birth to
Title:  an Esau and Jacob:--a contingency provided for in suckling by two
Title:  teats, curiously situated, one on each side of the anus; but the
Title:  breasts themselves extend upwards from that.  When by chance these
Title:  precious parts in a nursing whale are cut by the hunter's lance, the
Title:  mother's pouring milk and blood rivallingly discolour the sea for
Title:  rods.  The milk is very sweet and rich; it has been tasted by man; it
Title:  might do well with strawberries.  When overflowing with mutual
Title:  esteem, the whales salute MORE HOMINUM.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  And thus, though surrounded by circle upon circle of consternations
Title:  and affrights, did these inscrutable creatures at the centre freely
Title:  and fearlessly indulge in all peaceful concernments; yea, serenely
Title:  revelled in dalliance and delight.  But even so, amid the tornadoed
Title:  Atlantic of my being, do I myself still for ever centrally disport in
Title:  mute calm; and while ponderous planets of unwaning woe revolve round
Title:  me, deep down and deep inland there I still bathe me in eternal
Title:  mildness of joy.
Title:  
Title:  Meanwhile, as we thus lay entranced, the occasional sudden frantic
Title:  spectacles in the distance evinced the activity of the other boats,
Title:  still engaged in drugging the whales on the frontier of the host; or
Title:  possibly carrying on the war within the first circle, where abundance
Title:  of room and some convenient retreats were afforded them.  But the
Title:  sight of the enraged drugged whales now and then blindly darting to
Title:  and fro across the circles, was nothing to what at last met our eyes.
Title:  It is sometimes the custom when fast to a whale more than commonly
Title:  powerful and alert, to seek to hamstring him, as it were, by
Title:  sundering or maiming his gigantic tail-tendon.  It is done by darting
Title:  a short-handled cutting-spade, to which is attached a rope for
Title:  hauling it back again.  A whale wounded (as we afterwards learned) in
Title:  this part, but not effectually, as it seemed, had broken away from
Title:  the boat, carrying along with him half of the harpoon line; and in
Title:  the extraordinary agony of the wound, he was now dashing among the
Title:  revolving circles like the lone mounted desperado Arnold, at the
Title:  battle of Saratoga, carrying dismay wherever he went.
Title:  
Title:  But agonizing as was the wound of this whale, and an appalling
Title:  spectacle enough, any way; yet the peculiar horror with which he
Title:  seemed to inspire the rest of the herd, was owing to a cause which at
Title:  first the intervening distance obscured from us.  But at length we
Title:  perceived that by one of the unimaginable accidents of the fishery,
Title:  this whale had become entangled in the harpoon-line that he towed; he
Title:  had also run away with the cutting-spade in him; and while the free
Title:  end of the rope attached to that weapon, had permanently caught in
Title:  the coils of the harpoon-line round his tail, the cutting-spade
Title:  itself had worked loose from his flesh.  So that tormented to
Title:  madness, he was now churning through the water, violently flailing
Title:  with his flexible tail, and tossing the keen spade about him,
Title:  wounding and murdering his own comrades.
Title:  
Title:  This terrific object seemed to recall the whole herd from their
Title:  stationary fright.  First, the whales forming the margin of our lake
Title:  began to crowd a little, and tumble against each other, as if lifted
Title:  by half spent billows from afar; then the lake itself began faintly
Title:  to heave and swell; the submarine bridal-chambers and nurseries
Title:  vanished; in more and more contracting orbits the whales in the more
Title:  central circles began to swim in thickening clusters.  Yes, the long
Title:  calm was departing.  A low advancing hum was soon heard; and then
Title:  like to the tumultuous masses of block-ice when the great river
Title:  Hudson breaks up in Spring, the entire host of whales came tumbling
Title:  upon their inner centre, as if to pile themselves up in one common
Title:  mountain.  Instantly Starbuck and Queequeg changed places; Starbuck
Title:  taking the stern.
Title:  
Title:  "Oars!  Oars!" he intensely whispered, seizing the helm--"gripe your
Title:  oars, and clutch your souls, now!  My God, men, stand by!  Shove him
Title:  off, you Queequeg--the whale there!--prick him!--hit him!  Stand
Title:  up--stand up, and stay so!  Spring, men--pull, men; never mind their
Title:  backs--scrape them!--scrape away!"
Title:  
Title:  The boat was now all but jammed between two vast black bulks, leaving
Title:  a narrow Dardanelles between their long lengths.  But by desperate
Title:  endeavor we at last shot into a temporary opening; then giving way
Title:  rapidly, and at the same time earnestly watching for another outlet.
Title:  After many similar hair-breadth escapes, we at last swiftly glided
Title:  into what had just been one of the outer circles, but now crossed by
Title:  random whales, all violently making for one centre.  This lucky
Title:  salvation was cheaply purchased by the loss of Queequeg's hat, who,
Title:  while standing in the bows to prick the fugitive whales, had his hat
Title:  taken clean from his head by the air-eddy made by the sudden tossing
Title:  of a pair of broad flukes close by.
Title:  
Title:  Riotous and disordered as the universal commotion now was, it soon
Title:  resolved itself into what seemed a systematic movement; for having
Title:  clumped together at last in one dense body, they then renewed their
Title:  onward flight with augmented fleetness.  Further pursuit was useless;
Title:  but the boats still lingered in their wake to pick up what drugged
Title:  whales might be dropped astern, and likewise to secure one which
Title:  Flask had killed and waifed.  The waif is a pennoned pole, two or
Title:  three of which are carried by every boat; and which, when additional
Title:  game is at hand, are inserted upright into the floating body of a
Title:  dead whale, both to mark its place on the sea, and also as token of
Title:  prior possession, should the boats of any other ship draw near.
Title:  
Title:  The result of this lowering was somewhat illustrative of that
Title:  sagacious saying in the Fishery,--the more whales the less fish.  Of
Title:  all the drugged whales only one was captured.  The rest contrived to
Title:  escape for the time, but only to be taken, as will hereafter be seen,
Title:  by some other craft than the Pequod.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 88
Title:  
Title:  Schools and Schoolmasters.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  The previous chapter gave account of an immense body or herd of Sperm
Title:  Whales, and there was also then given the probable cause inducing
Title:  those vast aggregations.
Title:  
Title:  Now, though such great bodies are at times encountered, yet, as must
Title:  have been seen, even at the present day, small detached bands are
Title:  occasionally observed, embracing from twenty to fifty individuals
Title:  each.  Such bands are known as schools.  They generally are of two
Title:  sorts; those composed almost entirely of females, and those mustering
Title:  none but young vigorous males, or bulls, as they are familiarly
Title:  designated.
Title:  
Title:  In cavalier attendance upon the school of females, you invariably see
Title:  a male of full grown magnitude, but not old; who, upon any alarm,
Title:  evinces his gallantry by falling in the rear and covering the flight
Title:  of his ladies.  In truth, this gentleman is a luxurious Ottoman,
Title:  swimming about over the watery world, surroundingly accompanied by
Title:  all the solaces and endearments of the harem.  The contrast between
Title:  this Ottoman and his concubines is striking; because, while he is
Title:  always of the largest leviathanic proportions, the ladies, even at
Title:  full growth, are not more than one-third of the bulk of an
Title:  average-sized male.  They are comparatively delicate, indeed; I dare
Title:  say, not to exceed half a dozen yards round the waist.  Nevertheless,
Title:  it cannot be denied, that upon the whole they are hereditarily
Title:  entitled to EMBONPOINT.
Title:  
Title:  It is very curious to watch this harem and its lord in their indolent
Title:  ramblings.  Like fashionables, they are for ever on the move in
Title:  leisurely search of variety.  You meet them on the Line in time for
Title:  the full flower of the Equatorial feeding season, having just
Title:  returned, perhaps, from spending the summer in the Northern seas, and
Title:  so cheating summer of all unpleasant weariness and warmth.  By the
Title:  time they have lounged up and down the promenade of the Equator
Title:  awhile, they start for the Oriental waters in anticipation of the
Title:  cool season there, and so evade the other excessive temperature of
Title:  the year.
Title:  
Title:  When serenely advancing on one of these journeys, if any strange
Title:  suspicious sights are seen, my lord whale keeps a wary eye on his
Title:  interesting family.  Should any unwarrantably pert young Leviathan
Title:  coming that way, presume to draw confidentially close to one of the
Title:  ladies, with what prodigious fury the Bashaw assails him, and chases
Title:  him away!  High times, indeed, if unprincipled young rakes like him
Title:  are to be permitted to invade the sanctity of domestic bliss; though
Title:  do what the Bashaw will, he cannot keep the most notorious Lothario
Title:  out of his bed; for, alas! all fish bed in common.  As ashore, the
Title:  ladies often cause the most terrible duels among their rival
Title:  admirers; just so with the whales, who sometimes come to deadly
Title:  battle, and all for love.  They fence with their long lower jaws,
Title:  sometimes locking them together, and so striving for the supremacy
Title:  like elks that warringly interweave their antlers.  Not a few are
Title:  captured having the deep scars of these encounters,--furrowed heads,
Title:  broken teeth, scolloped fins; and in some instances, wrenched and
Title:  dislocated mouths.
Title:  
Title:  But supposing the invader of domestic bliss to betake himself away at
Title:  the first rush of the harem's lord, then is it very diverting to
Title:  watch that lord.  Gently he insinuates his vast bulk among them again
Title:  and revels there awhile, still in tantalizing vicinity to young
Title:  Lothario, like pious Solomon devoutly worshipping among his thousand
Title:  concubines.  Granting other whales to be in sight, the fishermen
Title:  will seldom give chase to one of these Grand Turks; for these Grand
Title:  Turks are too lavish of their strength, and hence their unctuousness
Title:  is small.  As for the sons and the daughters they beget, why, those sons
Title:  and daughters must take care of themselves; at least, with only the
Title:  maternal help.  For like certain other omnivorous roving lovers that
Title:  might be named, my Lord Whale has no taste for the nursery, however
Title:  much for the bower; and so, being a great traveller, he leaves his
Title:  anonymous babies all over the world; every baby an exotic.  In good
Title:  time, nevertheless, as the ardour of youth declines; as years and
Title:  dumps increase; as reflection lends her solemn pauses; in short, as a
Title:  general lassitude overtakes the sated Turk; then a love of ease and
Title:  virtue supplants the love for maidens; our Ottoman enters upon the
Title:  impotent, repentant, admonitory stage of life, forswears, disbands
Title:  the harem, and grown to an exemplary, sulky old soul, goes about all
Title:  alone among the meridians and parallels saying his prayers, and
Title:  warning each young Leviathan from his amorous errors.
Title:  
Title:  Now, as the harem of whales is called by the fishermen a school, so
Title:  is the lord and master of that school technically known as the
Title:  schoolmaster.  It is therefore not in strict character, however
Title:  admirably satirical, that after going to school himself, he should
Title:  then go abroad inculcating not what he learned there, but the folly
Title:  of it.  His title, schoolmaster, would very naturally seem derived
Title:  from the name bestowed upon the harem itself, but some have surmised
Title:  that the man who first thus entitled this sort of Ottoman whale, must
Title:  have read the memoirs of Vidocq, and informed himself what sort of a
Title:  country-schoolmaster that famous Frenchman was in his younger days,
Title:  and what was the nature of those occult lessons he inculcated into
Title:  some of his pupils.
Title:  
Title:  The same secludedness and isolation to which the schoolmaster whale
Title:  betakes himself in his advancing years, is true of all aged Sperm
Title:  Whales.  Almost universally, a lone whale--as a solitary Leviathan is
Title:  called--proves an ancient one.  Like venerable moss-bearded Daniel
Title:  Boone, he will have no one near him but Nature herself; and her he
Title:  takes to wife in the wilderness of waters, and the best of wives she
Title:  is, though she keeps so many moody secrets.
Title:  
Title:  The schools composing none but young and vigorous males, previously
Title:  mentioned, offer a strong contrast to the harem schools.  For while
Title:  those female whales are characteristically timid, the young males, or
Title:  forty-barrel-bulls, as they call them, are by far the most pugnacious
Title:  of all Leviathans, and proverbially the most dangerous to encounter;
Title:  excepting those wondrous grey-headed, grizzled whales, sometimes met,
Title:  and these will fight you like grim fiends exasperated by a penal
Title:  gout.
Title:  
Title:  The Forty-barrel-bull schools are larger than the harem schools.
Title:  Like a mob of young collegians, they are full of fight, fun, and
Title:  wickedness, tumbling round the world at such a reckless, rollicking
Title:  rate, that no prudent underwriter would insure them any more than he
Title:  would a riotous lad at Yale or Harvard.  They soon relinquish this
Title:  turbulence though, and when about three-fourths grown, break up, and
Title:  separately go about in quest of settlements, that is, harems.
Title:  
Title:  Another point of difference between the male and female schools is
Title:  still more characteristic of the sexes.  Say you strike a
Title:  Forty-barrel-bull--poor devil! all his comrades quit him.  But strike
Title:  a member of the harem school, and her companions swim around her with
Title:  every token of concern, sometimes lingering so near her and so long,
Title:  as themselves to fall a prey.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 89
Title:  
Title:  Fast-Fish and Loose-Fish.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  The allusion to the waif and waif-poles in the last chapter but one,
Title:  necessitates some account of the laws and regulations of the whale
Title:  fishery, of which the waif may be deemed the grand symbol and badge.
Title:  
Title:  It frequently happens that when several ships are cruising in
Title:  company, a whale may be struck by one vessel, then escape, and be
Title:  finally killed and captured by another vessel; and herein are
Title:  indirectly comprised many minor contingencies, all partaking of this
Title:  one grand feature.  For example,--after a weary and perilous chase
Title:  and capture of a whale, the body may get loose from the ship by
Title:  reason of a violent storm; and drifting far away to leeward, be
Title:  retaken by a second whaler, who, in a calm, snugly tows it alongside,
Title:  without risk of life or line.  Thus the most vexatious and violent
Title:  disputes would often arise between the fishermen, were there not some
Title:  written or unwritten, universal, undisputed law applicable to all
Title:  cases.
Title:  
Title:  Perhaps the only formal whaling code authorized by legislative
Title:  enactment, was that of Holland.  It was decreed by the States-General
Title:  in A.D. 1695.  But though no other nation has ever had any written
Title:  whaling law, yet the American fishermen have been their own
Title:  legislators and lawyers in this matter.  They have provided a system
Title:  which for terse comprehensiveness surpasses Justinian's Pandects and
Title:  the By-laws of the Chinese Society for the Suppression of Meddling
Title:  with other People's Business.  Yes; these laws might be engraven on a
Title:  Queen Anne's forthing, or the barb of a harpoon, and worn round the
Title:  neck, so small are they.
Title:  
Title:  I.  A Fast-Fish belongs to the party fast to it.
Title:
