Title:  II.  A Loose-Fish is fair game for anybody who can soonest catch it.
Title:  
Title:  But what plays the mischief with this masterly code is the admirable
Title:  brevity of it, which necessitates a vast volume of commentaries to
Title:  expound it.
Title:  
Title:  First: What is a Fast-Fish?  Alive or dead a fish is technically
Title:  fast, when it is connected with an occupied ship or boat, by any
Title:  medium at all controllable by the occupant or occupants,--a mast, an
Title:  oar, a nine-inch cable, a telegraph wire, or a strand of cobweb, it
Title:  is all the same.  Likewise a fish is technically fast when it bears a
Title:  waif, or any other recognised symbol of possession; so long as the
Title:  party waifing it plainly evince their ability at any time to take it
Title:  alongside, as well as their intention so to do.
Title:  
Title:  These are scientific commentaries; but the commentaries of the
Title:  whalemen themselves sometimes consist in hard words and harder
Title:  knocks--the Coke-upon-Littleton of the fist.  True, among the more
Title:  upright and honourable whalemen allowances are always made for
Title:  peculiar cases, where it would be an outrageous moral injustice for
Title:  one party to claim possession of a whale previously chased or killed
Title:  by another party.  But others are by no means so scrupulous.
Title:  
Title:  Some fifty years ago there was a curious case of whale-trover
Title:  litigated in England, wherein the plaintiffs set forth that after a
Title:  hard chase of a whale in the Northern seas; and when indeed they (the
Title:  plaintiffs) had succeeded in harpooning the fish; they were at last,
Title:  through peril of their lives, obliged to forsake not only their
Title:  lines, but their boat itself.  Ultimately the defendants (the crew of
Title:  another ship) came up with the whale, struck, killed, seized, and
Title:  finally appropriated it before the very eyes of the plaintiffs.  And
Title:  when those defendants were remonstrated with, their captain snapped
Title:  his fingers in the plaintiffs' teeth, and assured them that by way of
Title:  doxology to the deed he had done, he would now retain their line,
Title:  harpoons, and boat, which had remained attached to the whale at the
Title:  time of the seizure.  Wherefore the plaintiffs now sued for the
Title:  recovery of the value of their whale, line, harpoons, and boat.
Title:  
Title:  Mr. Erskine was counsel for the defendants; Lord Ellenborough was the
Title:  judge.  In the course of the defence, the witty Erskine went on to
Title:  illustrate his position, by alluding to a recent crim. con. case,
Title:  wherein a gentleman, after in vain trying to bridle his wife's
Title:  viciousness, had at last abandoned her upon the seas of life; but in
Title:  the course of years, repenting of that step, he instituted an action
Title:  to recover possession of her.  Erskine was on the other side; and he
Title:  then supported it by saying, that though the gentleman had originally
Title:  harpooned the lady, and had once had her fast, and only by reason of
Title:  the great stress of her plunging viciousness, had at last abandoned
Title:  her; yet abandon her he did, so that she became a loose-fish; and
Title:  therefore when a subsequent gentleman re-harpooned her, the lady then
Title:  became that subsequent gentleman's property, along with whatever
Title:  harpoon might have been found sticking in her.
Title:  
Title:  Now in the present case Erskine contended that the examples of the
Title:  whale and the lady were reciprocally illustrative of each other.
Title:  
Title:  These pleadings, and the counter pleadings, being duly heard, the
Title:  very learned Judge in set terms decided, to wit,--That as for the
Title:  boat, he awarded it to the plaintiffs, because they had merely
Title:  abandoned it to save their lives; but that with regard to the
Title:  controverted whale, harpoons, and line, they belonged to the
Title:  defendants; the whale, because it was a Loose-Fish at the time of the
Title:  final capture; and the harpoons and line because when the fish made
Title:  off with them, it (the fish) acquired a property in those articles;
Title:  and hence anybody who afterwards took the fish had a right to them.
Title:  Now the defendants afterwards took the fish; ergo, the aforesaid
Title:  articles were theirs.
Title:  
Title:  A common man looking at this decision of the very learned Judge,
Title:  might possibly object to it.  But ploughed up to the primary rock of
Title:  the matter, the two great principles laid down in the twin whaling
Title:  laws previously quoted, and applied and elucidated by Lord
Title:  Ellenborough in the above cited case; these two laws touching
Title:  Fast-Fish and Loose-Fish, I say, will, on reflection, be found the
Title:  fundamentals of all human jurisprudence; for notwithstanding its
Title:  complicated tracery of sculpture, the Temple of the Law, like the
Title:  Temple of the Philistines, has but two props to stand on.
Title:  
Title:  Is it not a saying in every one's mouth, Possession is half of the
Title:  law: that is, regardless of how the thing came into possession?  But
Title:  often possession is the whole of the law.  What are the sinews and
Title:  souls of Russian serfs and Republican slaves but Fast-Fish, whereof
Title:  possession is the whole of the law?  What to the rapacious landlord
Title:  is the widow's last mite but a Fast-Fish?  What is yonder undetected
Title:  villain's marble mansion with a door-plate for a waif; what is that
Title:  but a Fast-Fish?  What is the ruinous discount which Mordecai, the
Title:  broker, gets from poor Woebegone, the bankrupt, on a loan to
Title:  keep Woebegone's family from starvation; what is that ruinous
Title:  discount but a Fast-Fish?  What is the Archbishop of Savesoul's
Title:  income of L100,000 seized from the scant bread and cheese of
Title:  hundreds of thousands of broken-backed laborers (all sure of heaven
Title:  without any of Savesoul's help) what is that globular L100,000 but a
Title:  Fast-Fish?  What are the Duke of Dunder's hereditary towns and
Title:  hamlets but Fast-Fish?  What to that redoubted harpooneer, John Bull,
Title:  is poor Ireland, but a Fast-Fish?  What to that apostolic lancer,
Title:  Brother Jonathan, is Texas but a Fast-Fish?  And concerning all
Title:  these, is not Possession the whole of the law?
Title:  
Title:  But if the doctrine of Fast-Fish be pretty generally applicable, the
Title:  kindred doctrine of Loose-Fish is still more widely so.  That is
Title:  internationally and universally applicable.
Title:  
Title:  What was America in 1492 but a Loose-Fish, in which Columbus struck
Title:  the Spanish standard by way of waifing it for his royal master and
Title:  mistress?  What was Poland to the Czar?  What Greece to the Turk?
Title:  What India to England?  What at last will Mexico be to the United
Title:  States?  All Loose-Fish.
Title:  
Title:  What are the Rights of Man and the Liberties of the World but
Title:  Loose-Fish?  What all men's minds and opinions but Loose-Fish?  What
Title:  is the principle of religious belief in them but a Loose-Fish?  What
Title:  to the ostentatious smuggling verbalists are the thoughts of thinkers
Title:  but Loose-Fish?  What is the great globe itself but a Loose-Fish?
Title:  And what are you, reader, but a Loose-Fish and a Fast-Fish, too?
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 90
Title:  
Title:  Heads or Tails.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "De balena vero sufficit, si rex habeat caput, et regina caudam."
Title:  BRACTON, L. 3, C. 3.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Latin from the books of the Laws of England, which taken along with
Title:  the context, means, that of all whales captured by anybody on the
Title:  coast of that land, the King, as Honourary Grand Harpooneer, must have
Title:  the head, and the Queen be respectfully presented with the tail.  A
Title:  division which, in the whale, is much like halving an apple; there is
Title:  no intermediate remainder.  Now as this law, under a modified form,
Title:  is to this day in force in England; and as it offers in various
Title:  respects a strange anomaly touching the general law of Fast and
Title:  Loose-Fish, it is here treated of in a separate chapter, on the same
Title:  courteous principle that prompts the English railways to be at the
Title:  expense of a separate car, specially reserved for the accommodation
Title:  of royalty.  In the first place, in curious proof of the fact that
Title:  the above-mentioned law is still in force, I proceed to lay before
Title:  you a circumstance that happened within the last two years.
Title:  
Title:  It seems that some honest mariners of Dover, or Sandwich, or some one
Title:  of the Cinque Ports, had after a hard chase succeeded in killing and
Title:  beaching a fine whale which they had originally descried afar off
Title:  from the shore.  Now the Cinque Ports are partially or somehow under
Title:  the jurisdiction of a sort of policeman or beadle, called a Lord
Title:  Warden.  Holding the office directly from the crown, I believe, all
Title:  the royal emoluments incident to the Cinque Port territories become
Title:  by assignment his.  By some writers this office is called a sinecure.
Title:  But not so.  Because the Lord Warden is busily employed at times in
Title:  fobbing his perquisites; which are his chiefly by virtue of that same
Title:  fobbing of them.
Title:  
Title:  Now when these poor sun-burnt mariners, bare-footed, and with their
Title:  trowsers rolled high up on their eely legs, had wearily hauled their
Title:  fat fish high and dry, promising themselves a good L150 from the
Title:  precious oil and bone; and in fantasy sipping rare tea with their
Title:  wives, and good ale with their cronies, upon the strength of their
Title:  respective shares; up steps a very learned and most Christian and
Title:  charitable gentleman, with a copy of Blackstone under his arm; and
Title:  laying it upon the whale's head, he says--"Hands off! this fish, my
Title:  masters, is a Fast-Fish.  I seize it as the Lord Warden's."  Upon
Title:  this the poor mariners in their respectful consternation--so truly
Title:  English--knowing not what to say, fall to vigorously scratching their
Title:  heads all round; meanwhile ruefully glancing from the whale to the
Title:  stranger.  But that did in nowise mend the matter, or at all soften
Title:  the hard heart of the learned gentleman with the copy of Blackstone.
Title:  At length one of them, after long scratching about for his ideas,
Title:  made bold to speak,
Title:  
Title:  "Please, sir, who is the Lord Warden?"
Title:  
Title:  "The Duke."
Title:  
Title:  "But the duke had nothing to do with taking this fish?"
Title:  
Title:  "It is his."
Title:  
Title:  "We have been at great trouble, and peril, and some expense, and is
Title:  all that to go to the Duke's benefit; we getting nothing at all for
Title:  our pains but our blisters?"
Title:  
Title:  "It is his."
Title:  
Title:  "Is the Duke so very poor as to be forced to this desperate mode of
Title:  getting a livelihood?"
Title:  
Title:  "It is his."
Title:  
Title:  "I thought to relieve my old bed-ridden mother by part of my share of
Title:  this whale."
Title:  
Title:  "It is his."
Title:  
Title:  "Won't the Duke be content with a quarter or a half?"
Title:  
Title:  "It is his."
Title:  
Title:  In a word, the whale was seized and sold, and his Grace the Duke of
Title:  Wellington received the money.  Thinking that viewed in some
Title:  particular lights, the case might by a bare possibility in some small
Title:  degree be deemed, under the circumstances, a rather hard one, an
Title:  honest clergyman of the town respectfully addressed a note to his
Title:  Grace, begging him to take the case of those unfortunate mariners
Title:  into full consideration.  To which my Lord Duke in substance replied
Title:  (both letters were published) that he had already done so, and
Title:  received the money, and would be obliged to the reverend gentleman if
Title:  for the future he (the reverend gentleman) would decline meddling
Title:  with other people's business.  Is this the still militant old man,
Title:  standing at the corners of the three kingdoms, on all hands coercing
Title:  alms of beggars?
Title:  
Title:  It will readily be seen that in this case the alleged right of the
Title:  Duke to the whale was a delegated one from the Sovereign.  We must
Title:  needs inquire then on what principle the Sovereign is originally
Title:  invested with that right.  The law itself has already been set forth.
Title:  But Plowdon gives us the reason for it.  Says Plowdon, the whale so
Title:  caught belongs to the King and Queen, "because of its superior
Title:  excellence."  And by the soundest commentators this has ever been
Title:  held a cogent argument in such matters.
Title:  
Title:  But why should the King have the head, and the Queen the tail?  A
Title:  reason for that, ye lawyers!
Title:  
Title:  In his treatise on "Queen-Gold," or Queen-pinmoney, an old King's
Title:  Bench author, one William Prynne, thus discourseth: "Ye tail is ye
Title:  Queen's, that ye Queen's wardrobe may be supplied with ye whalebone."
Title:  Now this was written at a time when the black limber bone of the
Title:  Greenland or Right whale was largely used in ladies' bodices.  But
Title:  this same bone is not in the tail; it is in the head, which is a sad
Title:  mistake for a sagacious lawyer like Prynne.  But is the Queen a
Title:  mermaid, to be presented with a tail?  An allegorical meaning may
Title:  lurk here.
Title:  
Title:  There are two royal fish so styled by the English law writers--the
Title:  whale and the sturgeon; both royal property under certain
Title:  limitations, and nominally supplying the tenth branch of the crown's
Title:  ordinary revenue.  I know not that any other author has hinted of the
Title:  matter; but by inference it seems to me that the sturgeon must be
Title:  divided in the same way as the whale, the King receiving the highly
Title:  dense and elastic head peculiar to that fish, which, symbolically
Title:  regarded, may possibly be humorously grounded upon some presumed
Title:  congeniality.  And thus there seems a reason in all things, even in
Title:  law.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 91
Title:  
Title:  The Pequod Meets The Rose-Bud.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "In vain it was to rake for Ambergriese in the paunch of this
Title:  Leviathan, insufferable fetor denying not inquiry."
Title:  SIR T. BROWNE, V.E.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  It was a week or two after the last whaling scene recounted, and when
Title:  we were slowly sailing over a sleepy, vapoury, mid-day sea, that the
Title:  many noses on the Pequod's deck proved more vigilant discoverers than
Title:  the three pairs of eyes aloft.  A peculiar and not very pleasant
Title:  smell was smelt in the sea.
Title:  
Title:  "I will bet something now," said Stubb, "that somewhere hereabouts
Title:  are some of those drugged whales we tickled the other day.  I thought
Title:  they would keel up before long."
Title:  
Title:  Presently, the vapours in advance slid aside; and there in the
Title:  distance lay a ship, whose furled sails betokened that some sort of
Title:  whale must be alongside.  As we glided nearer, the stranger showed
Title:  French colours from his peak; and by the eddying cloud of vulture
Title:  sea-fowl that circled, and hovered, and swooped around him, it was
Title:  plain that the whale alongside must be what the fishermen call a
Title:  blasted whale, that is, a whale that has died unmolested on the sea,
Title:  and so floated an unappropriated corpse.  It may well be conceived,
Title:  what an unsavory odor such a mass must exhale; worse than an Assyrian
Title:  city in the plague, when the living are incompetent to bury the
Title:  departed.  So intolerable indeed is it regarded by some, that no
Title:  cupidity could persuade them to moor alongside of it.  Yet are there
Title:  those who will still do it; notwithstanding the fact that the oil
Title:  obtained from such subjects is of a very inferior quality, and by no
Title:  means of the nature of attar-of-rose.
Title:  
Title:  Coming still nearer with the expiring breeze, we saw that the
Title:  Frenchman had a second whale alongside; and this second whale seemed
Title:  even more of a nosegay than the first.  In truth, it turned out to be
Title:  one of those problematical whales that seem to dry up and die with a
Title:  sort of prodigious dyspepsia, or indigestion; leaving their defunct
Title:  bodies almost entirely bankrupt of anything like oil.  Nevertheless,
Title:  in the proper place we shall see that no knowing fisherman will ever
Title:  turn up his nose at such a whale as this, however much he may shun
Title:  blasted whales in general.
Title:  
Title:  The Pequod had now swept so nigh to the stranger, that Stubb vowed he
Title:  recognised his cutting spade-pole entangled in the lines that were
Title:  knotted round the tail of one of these whales.
Title:  
Title:  "There's a pretty fellow, now," he banteringly laughed, standing in
Title:  the ship's bows, "there's a jackal for ye!  I well know that these
Title:  Crappoes of Frenchmen are but poor devils in the fishery; sometimes
Title:  lowering their boats for breakers, mistaking them for Sperm Whale
Title:  spouts; yes, and sometimes sailing from their port with their hold
Title:  full of boxes of tallow candles, and cases of snuffers, foreseeing
Title:  that all the oil they will get won't be enough to dip the Captain's
Title:  wick into; aye, we all know these things; but look ye, here's a
Title:  Crappo that is content with our leavings, the drugged whale there, I
Title:  mean; aye, and is content too with scraping the dry bones of that
Title:  other precious fish he has there.  Poor devil!  I say, pass round a
Title:  hat, some one, and let's make him a present of a little oil for dear
Title:  charity's sake.  For what oil he'll get from that drugged whale
Title:  there, wouldn't be fit to burn in a jail; no, not in a condemned
Title:  cell.  And as for the other whale, why, I'll agree to get more oil by
Title:  chopping up and trying out these three masts of ours, than he'll get
Title:  from that bundle of bones; though, now that I think of it, it may
Title:  contain something worth a good deal more than oil; yes, ambergris.  I
Title:  wonder now if our old man has thought of that.  It's worth trying.
Title:  Yes, I'm for it;" and so saying he started for the quarter-deck.
Title:  
Title:  By this time the faint air had become a complete calm; so that
Title:  whether or no, the Pequod was now fairly entrapped in the smell, with
Title:  no hope of escaping except by its breezing up again.  Issuing from
Title:  the cabin, Stubb now called his boat's crew, and pulled off for the
Title:  stranger.  Drawing across her bow, he perceived that in accordance
Title:  with the fanciful French taste, the upper part of her stem-piece was
Title:  carved in the likeness of a huge drooping stalk, was painted green,
Title:  and for thorns had copper spikes projecting from it here and there;
Title:  the whole terminating in a symmetrical folded bulb of a bright red
Title:  colour.  Upon her head boards, in large gilt letters, he read "Bouton
Title:  de Rose,"--Rose-button, or Rose-bud; and this was the romantic name
Title:  of this aromatic ship.
Title:  
Title:  Though Stubb did not understand the BOUTON part of the inscription,
Title:  yet the word ROSE, and the bulbous figure-head put together,
Title:  sufficiently explained the whole to him.
Title:  
Title:  "A wooden rose-bud, eh?" he cried with his hand to his nose, "that
Title:  will do very well; but how like all creation it smells!"
Title:  
Title:  Now in order to hold direct communication with the people on deck, he
Title:  had to pull round the bows to the starboard side, and thus come close
Title:  to the blasted whale; and so talk over it.
Title:  
Title:  Arrived then at this spot, with one hand still to his nose, he
Title:  bawled--"Bouton-de-Rose, ahoy! are there any of you Bouton-de-Roses
Title:  that speak English?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," rejoined a Guernsey-man from the bulwarks, who turned out to
Title:  be the chief-mate.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then, my Bouton-de-Rose-bud, have you seen the White Whale?"
Title:  
Title:  "WHAT whale?"
Title:  
Title:  "The WHITE Whale--a Sperm Whale--Moby Dick, have ye seen him?
Title:  
Title:  "Never heard of such a whale.  Cachalot Blanche!  White Whale--no."
Title:  
Title:  "Very good, then; good bye now, and I'll call again in a minute."
Title:  
Title:  Then rapidly pulling back towards the Pequod, and seeing Ahab leaning
Title:  over the quarter-deck rail awaiting his report, he moulded his two
Title:  hands into a trumpet and shouted--"No, Sir!  No!"  Upon which Ahab
Title:  retired, and Stubb returned to the Frenchman.
Title:  
Title:  He now perceived that the Guernsey-man, who had just got into the
Title:  chains, and was using a cutting-spade, had slung his nose in a sort
Title:  of bag.
Title:  
Title:  "What's the matter with your nose, there?" said Stubb.  "Broke it?"
Title:  
Title:  "I wish it was broken, or that I didn't have any nose at all!"
Title:  answered the Guernsey-man, who did not seem to relish the job he was
Title:  at very much.  "But what are you holding YOURS for?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, nothing!  It's a wax nose; I have to hold it on.  Fine day,
Title:  ain't it?  Air rather gardenny, I should say; throw us a bunch of
Title:  posies, will ye, Bouton-de-Rose?"
Title:  
Title:  "What in the devil's name do you want here?" roared the Guernseyman,
Title:  flying into a sudden passion.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh! keep cool--cool? yes, that's the word! why don't you pack those
Title:  whales in ice while you're working at 'em?  But joking aside, though;
Title:  do you know, Rose-bud, that it's all nonsense trying to get any oil
Title:  out of such whales?  As for that dried up one, there, he hasn't a
Title:  gill in his whole carcase."
Title:  
Title:  "I know that well enough; but, d'ye see, the Captain here won't
Title:  believe it; this is his first voyage; he was a Cologne manufacturer
Title:  before.  But come aboard, and mayhap he'll believe you, if he won't
Title:  me; and so I'll get out of this dirty scrape."
Title:  
Title:  "Anything to oblige ye, my sweet and pleasant fellow," rejoined
Title:  Stubb, and with that he soon mounted to the deck.  There a queer
Title:  scene presented itself.  The sailors, in tasselled caps of red
Title:  worsted, were getting the heavy tackles in readiness for the whales.
Title:  But they worked rather slow and talked very fast, and seemed in
Title:  anything but a good humor.  All their noses upwardly projected from
Title:  their faces like so many jib-booms.  Now and then pairs of them would
Title:  drop their work, and run up to the mast-head to get some fresh air.
Title:  Some thinking they would catch the plague, dipped oakum in coal-tar,
Title:  and at intervals held it to their nostrils.  Others having broken the
Title:  stems of their pipes almost short off at the bowl, were vigorously
Title:  puffing tobacco-smoke, so that it constantly filled their
Title:  olfactories.
Title:  
Title:  Stubb was struck by a shower of outcries and anathemas proceeding
Title:  from the Captain's round-house abaft; and looking in that direction
Title:  saw a fiery face thrust from behind the door, which was held ajar
Title:  from within.  This was the tormented surgeon, who, after in vain
Title:  remonstrating against the proceedings of the day, had betaken himself
Title:  to the Captain's round-house (CABINET he called it) to avoid the
Title:  pest; but still, could not help yelling out his entreaties and
Title:  indignations at times.
Title:  
Title:  Marking all this, Stubb argued well for his scheme, and turning to
Title:  the Guernsey-man had a little chat with him, during which the
Title:  stranger mate expressed his detestation of his Captain as a conceited
Title:  ignoramus, who had brought them all into so unsavory and unprofitable
Title:  a pickle.  Sounding him carefully, Stubb further perceived that the
Title:  Guernsey-man had not the slightest suspicion concerning the
Title:  ambergris.  He therefore held his peace on that head, but otherwise
Title:  was quite frank and confidential with him, so that the two quickly
Title:  concocted a little plan for both circumventing and satirizing the
Title:  Captain, without his at all dreaming of distrusting their sincerity.
Title:  According to this little plan of theirs, the Guernsey-man, under
Title:  cover of an interpreter's office, was to tell the Captain what he
Title:  pleased, but as coming from Stubb; and as for Stubb, he was to utter
Title:  any nonsense that should come uppermost in him during the interview.
Title:  
Title:  By this time their destined victim appeared from his cabin.  He was a
Title:  small and dark, but rather delicate looking man for a sea-captain,
Title:  with large whiskers and moustache, however; and wore a red cotton
Title:  velvet vest with watch-seals at his side.  To this gentleman, Stubb
Title:  was now politely introduced by the Guernsey-man, who at once
Title:  ostentatiously put on the aspect of interpreting between them.
Title:  
Title:  "What shall I say to him first?" said he.
Title:  
Title:  "Why," said Stubb, eyeing the velvet vest and the watch and seals,
Title:  "you may as well begin by telling him that he looks a sort of babyish
Title:  to me, though I don't pretend to be a judge."
Title:  
Title:  "He says, Monsieur," said the Guernsey-man, in French, turning to his
Title:  captain, "that only yesterday his ship spoke a vessel, whose captain
Title:  and chief-mate, with six sailors, had all died of a fever caught from
Title:  a blasted whale they had brought alongside."
Title:  
Title:  Upon this the captain started, and eagerly desired to know more.
Title:  
Title:  "What now?" said the Guernsey-man to Stubb.
Title:  
Title:  "Why, since he takes it so easy, tell him that now I have eyed him
Title:  carefully, I'm quite certain that he's no more fit to command a
Title:  whale-ship than a St. Jago monkey.  In fact, tell him from me he's a
Title:  baboon."
Title:  
Title:  "He vows and declares, Monsieur, that the other whale, the dried one,
Title:  is far more deadly than the blasted one; in fine, Monsieur, he
Title:  conjures us, as we value our lives, to cut loose from these fish."
Title:  
Title:  Instantly the captain ran forward, and in a loud voice commanded his
Title:  crew to desist from hoisting the cutting-tackles, and at once cast
Title:  loose the cables and chains confining the whales to the ship.
Title:  
Title:  "What now?" said the Guernsey-man, when the Captain had returned to
Title:  them.
Title:  
Title:  "Why, let me see; yes, you may as well tell him now that--that--in
Title:  fact, tell him I've diddled him, and (aside to himself) perhaps
Title:  somebody else."
Title:  
Title:  "He says, Monsieur, that he's very happy to have been of any service
Title:  to us."
Title:  
Title:  Hearing this, the captain vowed that they were the grateful parties
Title:  (meaning himself and mate) and concluded by inviting Stubb down
Title:  into his cabin to drink a bottle of Bordeaux.
Title:  
Title:  "He wants you to take a glass of wine with him," said the
Title:  interpreter.
Title:  
Title:  "Thank him heartily; but tell him it's against my principles to drink
Title:  with the man I've diddled.  In fact, tell him I must go."
Title:  
Title:  "He says, Monsieur, that his principles won't admit of his drinking;
Title:  but that if Monsieur wants to live another day to drink, then
Title:  Monsieur had best drop all four boats, and pull the ship away from
Title:  these whales, for it's so calm they won't drift."
Title:  
Title:  By this time Stubb was over the side, and getting into his boat,
Title:  hailed the Guernsey-man to this effect,--that having a long tow-line
Title:  in his boat, he would do what he could to help them, by pulling out
Title:  the lighter whale of the two from the ship's side.  While the
Title:  Frenchman's boats, then, were engaged in towing the ship one way,
Title:  Stubb benevolently towed away at his whale the other way,
Title:  ostentatiously slacking out a most unusually long tow-line.
Title:  
Title:  Presently a breeze sprang up; Stubb feigned to cast off from the
Title:  whale; hoisting his boats, the Frenchman soon increased his distance,
Title:  while the Pequod slid in between him and Stubb's whale.  Whereupon
Title:  Stubb quickly pulled to the floating body, and hailing the Pequod to
Title:  give notice of his intentions, at once proceeded to reap the fruit of
Title:  his unrighteous cunning.  Seizing his sharp boat-spade, he commenced
Title:  an excavation in the body, a little behind the side fin.  You would
Title:  almost have thought he was digging a cellar there in the sea; and
Title:  when at length his spade struck against the gaunt ribs, it was like
Title:  turning up old Roman tiles and pottery buried in fat English loam.
Title:  His boat's crew were all in high excitement, eagerly helping their
Title:  chief, and looking as anxious as gold-hunters.
Title:  
Title:  And all the time numberless fowls were diving, and ducking, and
Title:  screaming, and yelling, and fighting around them.  Stubb was
Title:  beginning to look disappointed, especially as the horrible nosegay
Title:  increased, when suddenly from out the very heart of this plague,
Title:  there stole a faint stream of perfume, which flowed through the tide
Title:  of bad smells without being absorbed by it, as one river will flow
Title:  into and then along with another, without at all blending with it for
Title:  a time.
Title:  
Title:  "I have it, I have it," cried Stubb, with delight, striking something
Title:  in the subterranean regions, "a purse! a purse!"
Title:  
Title:  Dropping his spade, he thrust both hands in, and drew out handfuls of
Title:  something that looked like ripe Windsor soap, or rich mottled old
Title:  cheese; very unctuous and savory withal.  You might easily dent it
Title:  with your thumb; it is of a hue between yellow and ash colour.  And
Title:  this, good friends, is ambergris, worth a gold guinea an ounce to any
Title:  druggist.  Some six handfuls were obtained; but more was unavoidably
Title:  lost in the sea, and still more, perhaps, might have been secured
Title:  were it not for impatient Ahab's loud command to Stubb to desist, and
Title:  come on board, else the ship would bid them good bye.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 92
Title:  
Title:  Ambergris.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Now this ambergris is a very curious substance, and so important as
Title:  an article of commerce, that in 1791 a certain Nantucket-born Captain
Title:  Coffin was examined at the bar of the English House of Commons on
Title:  that subject.  For at that time, and indeed until a comparatively
Title:  late day, the precise origin of ambergris remained, like amber
Title:  itself, a problem to the learned.  Though the word ambergris is but
Title:  the French compound for grey amber, yet the two substances are quite
Title:  distinct.  For amber, though at times found on the sea-coast, is also
Title:  dug up in some far inland soils, whereas ambergris is never found
Title:  except upon the sea.  Besides, amber is a hard, transparent, brittle,
Title:  odorless substance, used for mouth-pieces to pipes, for beads and
Title:  ornaments; but ambergris is soft, waxy, and so highly fragrant and
Title:  spicy, that it is largely used in perfumery, in pastiles, precious
Title:  candles, hair-powders, and pomatum.  The Turks use it in cooking, and
Title:  also carry it to Mecca, for the same purpose that frankincense is
Title:  carried to St. Peter's in Rome.  Some wine merchants drop a few
Title:  grains into claret, to flavor it.
Title:  
Title:  Who would think, then, that such fine ladies and gentlemen should
Title:  regale themselves with an essence found in the inglorious bowels of a
Title:  sick whale!  Yet so it is.  By some, ambergris is supposed to be the
Title:  cause, and by others the effect, of the dyspepsia in the whale.  How
Title:  to cure such a dyspepsia it were hard to say, unless by administering
Title:  three or four boat loads of Brandreth's pills, and then running out
Title:  of harm's way, as laborers do in blasting rocks.
Title:  
Title:  I have forgotten to say that there were found in this ambergris,
Title:  certain hard, round, bony plates, which at first Stubb thought might
Title:  be sailors' trowsers buttons; but it afterwards turned out that they
Title:  were nothing more than pieces of small squid bones embalmed in that
Title:  manner.
Title:  
Title:  Now that the incorruption of this most fragrant ambergris should be
Title:  found in the heart of such decay; is this nothing?  Bethink thee of
Title:  that saying of St. Paul in Corinthians, about corruption and
Title:  incorruption; how that we are sown in dishonour, but raised in glory.
Title:  And likewise call to mind that saying of Paracelsus about what it is
Title:  that maketh the best musk.  Also forget not the strange fact that of
Title:  all things of ill-savor, Cologne-water, in its rudimental
Title:  manufacturing stages, is the worst.
Title:  
Title:  I should like to conclude the chapter with the above appeal, but
Title:  cannot, owing to my anxiety to repel a charge often made against
Title:  whalemen, and which, in the estimation of some already biased minds,
Title:  might be considered as indirectly substantiated by what has been said
Title:  of the Frenchman's two whales.  Elsewhere in this volume the
Title:  slanderous aspersion has been disproved, that the vocation of whaling
Title:  is throughout a slatternly, untidy business.  But there is another
Title:  thing to rebut.  They hint that all whales always smell bad.  Now how
Title:  did this odious stigma originate?
Title:  
Title:  I opine, that it is plainly traceable to the first arrival of the
Title:  Greenland whaling ships in London, more than two centuries ago.
Title:  Because those whalemen did not then, and do not now, try out their
Title:  oil at sea as the Southern ships have always done; but cutting up the
Title:  fresh blubber in small bits, thrust it through the bung holes of
Title:  large casks, and carry it home in that manner; the shortness of the
Title:  season in those Icy Seas, and the sudden and violent storms to which
Title:  they are exposed, forbidding any other course.  The consequence is,
Title:  that upon breaking into the hold, and unloading one of these whale
Title:  cemeteries, in the Greenland dock, a savor is given forth somewhat
Title:  similar to that arising from excavating an old city grave-yard, for
Title:  the foundations of a Lying-in-Hospital.
Title:  
Title:  I partly surmise also, that this wicked charge against whalers may be
Title:  likewise imputed to the existence on the coast of Greenland, in
Title:  former times, of a Dutch village called Schmerenburgh or Smeerenberg,
Title:  which latter name is the one used by the learned Fogo Von Slack, in
Title:  his great work on Smells, a text-book on that subject.  As its name
Title:  imports (smeer, fat; berg, to put up), this village was founded in
Title:  order to afford a place for the blubber of the Dutch whale fleet to
Title:  be tried out, without being taken home to Holland for that purpose.
Title:  It was a collection of furnaces, fat-kettles, and oil sheds; and when
Title:  the works were in full operation certainly gave forth no very
Title:  pleasant savor.  But all this is quite different with a South Sea
Title:  Sperm Whaler; which in a voyage of four years perhaps, after
Title:  completely filling her hold with oil, does not, perhaps, consume
Title:  fifty days in the business of boiling out; and in the state that it
Title:  is casked, the oil is nearly scentless.  The truth is, that living or
Title:  dead, if but decently treated, whales as a species are by no means
Title:  creatures of ill odor; nor can whalemen be recognised, as the people
Title:  of the middle ages affected to detect a Jew in the company, by the
Title:  nose.  Nor indeed can the whale possibly be otherwise than fragrant,
Title:  when, as a general thing, he enjoys such high health; taking
Title:  abundance of exercise; always out of doors; though, it is true,
Title:  seldom in the open air.  I say, that the motion of a Sperm Whale's
Title:  flukes above water dispenses a perfume, as when a musk-scented lady
Title:  rustles her dress in a warm parlor.  What then shall I liken the
Title:  Sperm Whale to for fragrance, considering his magnitude?  Must it not
Title:  be to that famous elephant, with jewelled tusks, and redolent with
Title:  myrrh, which was led out of an Indian town to do honour to Alexander
Title:  the Great?
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 93
Title:  
Title:  The Castaway.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  It was but some few days after encountering the Frenchman, that a
Title:  most significant event befell the most insignificant of the Pequod's
Title:  crew; an event most lamentable; and which ended in providing the
Title:  sometimes madly merry and predestinated craft with a living and ever
Title:  accompanying prophecy of whatever shattered sequel might prove her
Title:  own.
Title:  
Title:  Now, in the whale ship, it is not every one that goes in the boats.
Title:  Some few hands are reserved called ship-keepers, whose province it is
Title:  to work the vessel while the boats are pursuing the whale.  As a
Title:  general thing, these ship-keepers are as hardy fellows as the men
Title:  comprising the boats' crews.  But if there happen to be an unduly
Title:  slender, clumsy, or timorous wight in the ship, that wight is certain
Title:  to be made a ship-keeper.  It was so in the Pequod with the little
Title:  negro Pippin by nick-name, Pip by abbreviation.  Poor Pip! ye have
Title:  heard of him before; ye must remember his tambourine on that dramatic
Title:  midnight, so gloomy-jolly.
Title:  
Title:  In outer aspect, Pip and Dough-Boy made a match, like a black pony
Title:  and a white one, of equal developments, though of dissimilar colour,
Title:  driven in one eccentric span.  But while hapless Dough-Boy was by
Title:  nature dull and torpid in his intellects, Pip, though over
Title:  tender-hearted, was at bottom very bright, with that pleasant,
Title:  genial, jolly brightness peculiar to his tribe; a tribe, which ever
Title:  enjoy all holidays and festivities with finer, freer relish than any
Title:  other race.  For blacks, the year's calendar should show naught but
Title:  three hundred and sixty-five Fourth of Julys and New Year's Days.
Title:  Nor smile so, while I write that this little black was brilliant, for
Title:  even blackness has its brilliancy; behold yon lustrous ebony,
Title:  panelled in king's cabinets.  But Pip loved life, and all life's
Title:  peaceable securities; so that the panic-striking business in which he
Title:  had somehow unaccountably become entrapped, had most sadly blurred
Title:  his brightness; though, as ere long will be seen, what was thus
Title:  temporarily subdued in him, in the end was destined to be luridly
Title:  illumined by strange wild fires, that fictitiously showed him off to
Title:  ten times the natural lustre with which in his native Tolland County
Title:  in Connecticut, he had once enlivened many a fiddler's frolic on the
Title:  green; and at melodious even-tide, with his gay ha-ha! had turned the
Title:  round horizon into one star-belled tambourine.  So, though in the
Title:  clear air of day, suspended against a blue-veined neck, the
Title:  pure-watered diamond drop will healthful glow; yet, when the cunning
Title:  jeweller would show you the diamond in its most impressive lustre, he
Title:  lays it against a gloomy ground, and then lights it up, not by the
Title:  sun, but by some unnatural gases.  Then come out those fiery
Title:  effulgences, infernally superb; then the evil-blazing diamond, once
Title:  the divinest symbol of the crystal skies, looks like some crown-jewel
Title:  stolen from the King of Hell.  But let us to the story.
Title:  
Title:  It came to pass, that in the ambergris affair Stubb's after-oarsman
Title:  chanced so to sprain his hand, as for a time to become quite maimed;
Title:  and, temporarily, Pip was put into his place.
Title:  
Title:  The first time Stubb lowered with him, Pip evinced much nervousness;
Title:  but happily, for that time, escaped close contact with the whale; and
Title:  therefore came off not altogether discreditably; though Stubb
Title:  observing him, took care, afterwards, to exhort him to cherish his
Title:  courageousness to the utmost, for he might often find it needful.
Title:  
Title:  Now upon the second lowering, the boat paddled upon the whale; and as
Title:  the fish received the darted iron, it gave its customary rap, which
Title:  happened, in this instance, to be right under poor Pip's seat.  The
Title:  involuntary consternation of the moment caused him to leap, paddle in
Title:  hand, out of the boat; and in such a way, that part of the slack
Title:  whale line coming against his chest, he breasted it overboard with
Title:  him, so as to become entangled in it, when at last plumping into the
Title:  water.  That instant the stricken whale started on a fierce run, the
Title:  line swiftly straightened; and presto! poor Pip came all foaming up
Title:  to the chocks of the boat, remorselessly dragged there by the line,
Title:  which had taken several turns around his chest and neck.
Title:  
Title:  Tashtego stood in the bows.  He was full of the fire of the hunt.  He
Title:  hated Pip for a poltroon.  Snatching the boat-knife from its sheath,
Title:  he suspended its sharp edge over the line, and turning towards Stubb,
Title:  exclaimed interrogatively, "Cut?"  Meantime Pip's blue, choked face
Title:  plainly looked, Do, for God's sake!  All passed in a flash.  In less
Title:  than half a minute, this entire thing happened.
Title:  
Title:  "Damn him, cut!" roared Stubb; and so the whale was lost and Pip was
Title:  saved.
Title:  
Title:  So soon as he recovered himself, the poor little negro was assailed
Title:  by yells and execrations from the crew.  Tranquilly permitting these
Title:  irregular cursings to evaporate, Stubb then in a plain,
Title:  business-like, but still half humorous manner, cursed Pip officially;
Title:  and that done, unofficially gave him much wholesome advice.  The
Title:  substance was, Never jump from a boat, Pip, except--but all the rest
Title:  was indefinite, as the soundest advice ever is.  Now, in general,
Title:  STICK TO THE BOAT, is your true motto in whaling; but cases will
Title:  sometimes happen when LEAP FROM THE BOAT, is still better.  Moreover,
Title:  as if perceiving at last that if he should give undiluted
Title:  conscientious advice to Pip, he would be leaving him too wide a
Title:  margin to jump in for the future; Stubb suddenly dropped all advice,
Title:  and concluded with a peremptory command, "Stick to the boat, Pip, or
Title:  by the Lord, I won't pick you up if you jump; mind that.  We can't
Title:  afford to lose whales by the likes of you; a whale would sell for
Title:  thirty times what you would, Pip, in Alabama.  Bear that in mind, and
Title:  don't jump any more."  Hereby perhaps Stubb indirectly hinted, that
Title:  though man loved his fellow, yet man is a money-making animal, which
Title:  propensity too often interferes with his benevolence.
Title:  
Title:  But we are all in the hands of the Gods; and Pip jumped again.  It
Title:  was under very similar circumstances to the first performance; but
Title:  this time he did not breast out the line; and hence, when the whale
Title:  started to run, Pip was left behind on the sea, like a hurried
Title:  traveller's trunk.  Alas!  Stubb was but too true to his word.  It
Title:  was a beautiful, bounteous, blue day; the spangled sea calm and
Title:  cool, and flatly stretching away, all round, to the horizon, like
Title:  gold-beater's skin hammered out to the extremest.  Bobbing up and
Title:  down in that sea, Pip's ebon head showed like a head of cloves.  No
Title:  boat-knife was lifted when he fell so rapidly astern.  Stubb's
Title:  inexorable back was turned upon him; and the whale was winged.  In
Title:  three minutes, a whole mile of shoreless ocean was between Pip and
Title:  Stubb.  Out from the centre of the sea, poor Pip turned his crisp,
Title:  curling, black head to the sun, another lonely castaway, though the
Title:  loftiest and the brightest.
Title:  
Title:  Now, in calm weather, to swim in the open ocean is as easy to the
Title:  practised swimmer as to ride in a spring-carriage ashore.  But the
Title:  awful lonesomeness is intolerable.  The intense concentration of self
Title:  in the middle of such a heartless immensity, my God! who can tell it?
Title:  Mark, how when sailors in a dead calm bathe in the open sea--mark
Title:  how closely they hug their ship and only coast along her sides.
Title:  
Title:  But had Stubb really abandoned the poor little negro to his fate?
Title:  No; he did not mean to, at least.  Because there were two boats in
Title:  his wake, and he supposed, no doubt, that they would of course come
Title:  up to Pip very quickly, and pick him up; though, indeed, such
Title:  considerations towards oarsmen jeopardized through their own
Title:  timidity, is not always manifested by the hunters in all similar
Title:  instances; and such instances not unfrequently occur; almost
Title:  invariably in the fishery, a coward, so called, is marked with the
Title:  same ruthless detestation peculiar to military navies and armies.
Title:  
Title:  But it so happened, that those boats, without seeing Pip, suddenly
Title:  spying whales close to them on one side, turned, and gave chase; and
Title:  Stubb's boat was now so far away, and he and all his crew so intent
Title:  upon his fish, that Pip's ringed horizon began to expand around him
Title:  miserably.  By the merest chance the ship itself at last rescued him;
Title:  but from that hour the little negro went about the deck an idiot;
Title:  such, at least, they said he was.  The sea had jeeringly kept his
Title:  finite body up, but drowned the infinite of his soul.  Not drowned
Title:  entirely, though.  Rather carried down alive to wondrous depths,
Title:  where strange shapes of the unwarped primal world glided to and fro
Title:  before his passive eyes; and the miser-merman, Wisdom, revealed his
Title:  hoarded heaps; and among the joyous, heartless, ever-juvenile
Title:  eternities, Pip saw the multitudinous, God-omnipresent, coral
Title:  insects, that out of the firmament of waters heaved the colossal
Title:  orbs.  He saw God's foot upon the treadle of the loom, and spoke it;
Title:  and therefore his shipmates called him mad.  So man's insanity is
Title:  heaven's sense; and wandering from all mortal reason, man comes at
Title:  last to that celestial thought, which, to reason, is absurd and
Title:  frantic; and weal or woe, feels then uncompromised, indifferent as
Title:  his God.
Title:  
Title:  For the rest, blame not Stubb too hardly.  The thing is common in
Title:  that fishery; and in the sequel of the narrative, it will then be
Title:  seen what like abandonment befell myself.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 94
Title:  
Title:  A Squeeze of the Hand.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  That whale of Stubb's, so dearly purchased, was duly brought to the
Title:  Pequod's side, where all those cutting and hoisting operations
Title:  previously detailed, were regularly gone through, even to the baling
Title:  of the Heidelburgh Tun, or Case.
Title:  
Title:  While some were occupied with this latter duty, others were employed
Title:  in dragging away the larger tubs, so soon as filled with the sperm;
Title:  and when the proper time arrived, this same sperm was carefully
Title:  manipulated ere going to the try-works, of which anon.
Title:  
Title:  It had cooled and crystallized to such a degree, that when, with
Title:  several others, I sat down before a large Constantine's bath of it, I
Title:  found it strangely concreted into lumps, here and there rolling about
Title:  in the liquid part.  It was our business to squeeze these lumps back
Title:  into fluid.  A sweet and unctuous duty!  No wonder that in old times
Title:  this sperm was such a favourite cosmetic.  Such a clearer! such a
Title:  sweetener! such a softener! such a delicious molifier!  After
Title:  having my hands in it for only a few minutes, my fingers felt like
Title:  eels, and began, as it were, to serpentine and spiralise.
Title:  
Title:  As I sat there at my ease, cross-legged on the deck; after the bitter
Title:  exertion at the windlass; under a blue tranquil sky; the ship under
Title:  indolent sail, and gliding so serenely along; as I bathed my hands
Title:  among those soft, gentle globules of infiltrated tissues, woven
Title:  almost within the hour; as they richly broke to my fingers, and
Title:  discharged all their opulence, like fully ripe grapes their wine; as
Title:  I snuffed up that uncontaminated aroma,--literally and truly, like
Title:  the smell of spring violets; I declare to you, that for the time I
Title:  lived as in a musky meadow; I forgot all about our horrible oath; in
Title:  that inexpressible sperm, I washed my hands and my heart of it; I
Title:  almost began to credit the old Paracelsan superstition that sperm is
Title:  of rare virtue in allaying the heat of anger; while bathing in that
Title:  bath, I felt divinely free from all ill-will, or petulance, or
Title:  malice, of any sort whatsoever.
Title:  
Title:  Squeeze! squeeze! squeeze! all the morning long; I squeezed that
Title:  sperm till I myself almost melted into it; I squeezed that sperm till
Title:  a strange sort of insanity came over me; and I found myself
Title:  unwittingly squeezing my co-laborers' hands in it, mistaking their
Title:  hands for the gentle globules.  Such an abounding, affectionate,
Title:  friendly, loving feeling did this avocation beget; that at last I was
Title:  continually squeezing their hands, and looking up into their eyes
Title:  sentimentally; as much as to say,--Oh! my dear fellow beings, why
Title:  should we longer cherish any social acerbities, or know the slightest
Title:  ill-humor or envy!  Come; let us squeeze hands all round; nay, let us
Title:  all squeeze ourselves into each other; let us squeeze ourselves
Title:  universally into the very milk and sperm of kindness.
Title:  
Title:  Would that I could keep squeezing that sperm for ever!  For now,
Title:  since by many prolonged, repeated experiences, I have perceived that
Title:  in all cases man must eventually lower, or at least shift, his
Title:  conceit of attainable felicity; not placing it anywhere in the
Title:  intellect or the fancy; but in the wife, the heart, the bed, the
Title:  table, the saddle, the fireside, the country; now that I have
Title:  perceived all this, I am ready to squeeze case eternally.  In
Title:  thoughts of the visions of the night, I saw long rows of angels in
Title:  paradise, each with his hands in a jar of spermaceti.
Title:  
Title:  Now, while discoursing of sperm, it behooves to speak of other things
Title:  akin to it, in the business of preparing the sperm whale for the
Title:  try-works.
Title:  
Title:  First comes white-horse, so called, which is obtained from the
Title:  tapering part of the fish, and also from the thicker portions of his
Title:  flukes.  It is tough with congealed tendons--a wad of muscle--but
Title:  still contains some oil.  After being severed from the whale, the
Title:  white-horse is first cut into portable oblongs ere going to the
Title:  mincer.  They look much like blocks of Berkshire marble.
Title:  
Title:  Plum-pudding is the term bestowed upon certain fragmentary parts of
Title:  the whale's flesh, here and there adhering to the blanket of blubber,
Title:  and often participating to a considerable degree in its unctuousness.
Title:  It is a most refreshing, convivial, beautiful object to behold.  As
Title:  its name imports, it is of an exceedingly rich, mottled tint, with a
Title:  bestreaked snowy and golden ground, dotted with spots of the deepest
Title:  crimson and purple.  It is plums of rubies, in pictures of citron.
Title:  Spite of reason, it is hard to keep yourself from eating it.  I
Title:  confess, that once I stole behind the foremast to try it.  It tasted
Title:  something as I should conceive a royal cutlet from the thigh of Louis
Title:  le Gros might have tasted, supposing him to have been killed the
Title:  first day after the venison season, and that particular venison
Title:  season contemporary with an unusually fine vintage of the vineyards
Title:  of Champagne.
Title:  
Title:  There is another substance, and a very singular one, which turns up
Title:  in the course of this business, but which I feel it to be very
Title:  puzzling adequately to describe.  It is called slobgollion; an
Title:  appellation original with the whalemen, and even so is the nature of
Title:  the substance.  It is an ineffably oozy, stringy affair, most
Title:  frequently found in the tubs of sperm, after a prolonged squeezing,
Title:  and subsequent decanting.  I hold it to be the wondrously thin,
Title:  ruptured membranes of the case, coalescing.
Title:  
Title:  Gurry, so called, is a term properly belonging to right whalemen, but
Title:  sometimes incidentally used by the sperm fishermen.  It designates
Title:  the dark, glutinous substance which is scraped off the back of the
Title:  Greenland or right whale, and much of which covers the decks of those
Title:  inferior souls who hunt that ignoble Leviathan.
Title:  
Title:  Nippers.  Strictly this word is not indigenous to the whale's
Title:  vocabulary.  But as applied by whalemen, it becomes so.  A whaleman's
Title:  nipper is a short firm strip of tendinous stuff cut from the tapering
Title:  part of Leviathan's tail: it averages an inch in thickness, and for
Title:  the rest, is about the size of the iron part of a hoe.  Edgewise
Title:  moved along the oily deck, it operates like a leathern squilgee; and
Title:  by nameless blandishments, as of magic, allures along with it all
Title:  impurities.
Title:  
Title:  But to learn all about these recondite matters, your best way is at
Title:  once to descend into the blubber-room, and have a long talk with its
Title:  inmates.  This place has previously been mentioned as the receptacle
Title:  for the blanket-pieces, when stript and hoisted from the whale.  When
Title:  the proper time arrives for cutting up its contents, this apartment
Title:  is a scene of terror to all tyros, especially by night.  On one side,
Title:  lit by a dull lantern, a space has been left clear for the workmen.
Title:  They generally go in pairs,--a pike-and-gaffman and a spade-man.
Title:  The whaling-pike is similar to a frigate's boarding-weapon of the
Title:  same name.  The gaff is something like a boat-hook.  With his gaff,
Title:  the gaffman hooks on to a sheet of blubber, and strives to hold it
Title:  from slipping, as the ship pitches and lurches about.  Meanwhile, the
Title:  spade-man stands on the sheet itself, perpendicularly chopping it
Title:  into the portable horse-pieces.  This spade is sharp as hone can make
Title:  it; the spademan's feet are shoeless; the thing he stands on will
Title:  sometimes irresistibly slide away from him, like a sledge.  If he
Title:  cuts off one of his own toes, or one of his assistants', would you be
Title:  very much astonished?  Toes are scarce among veteran blubber-room
Title:  men.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 95
Title:  
Title:  The Cassock.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Had you stepped on board the Pequod at a certain juncture of this
Title:  post-mortemizing of the whale; and had you strolled forward nigh the
Title:  windlass, pretty sure am I that you would have scanned with no small
Title:  curiosity a very strange, enigmatical object, which you would have
Title:  seen there, lying along lengthwise in the lee scuppers.  Not the
Title:  wondrous cistern in the whale's huge head; not the prodigy of his
Title:  unhinged lower jaw; not the miracle of his symmetrical tail; none of
Title:  these would so surprise you, as half a glimpse of that unaccountable
Title:  cone,--longer than a Kentuckian is tall, nigh a foot in diameter at
Title:  the base, and jet-black as Yojo, the ebony idol of Queequeg.  And an
Title:  idol, indeed, it is; or, rather, in old times, its likeness was.
Title:  Such an idol as that found in the secret groves of Queen Maachah in
Title:  Judea; and for worshipping which, King Asa, her son, did depose her,
Title:  and destroyed the idol, and burnt it for an abomination at the brook
Title:  Kedron, as darkly set forth in the 15th chapter of the First Book of
Title:  Kings.
Title:  
Title:  Look at the sailor, called the mincer, who now comes along, and
Title:  assisted by two allies, heavily backs the grandissimus, as the
Title:  mariners call it, and with bowed shoulders, staggers off with it as
Title:  if he were a grenadier carrying a dead comrade from the field.
Title:  Extending it upon the forecastle deck, he now proceeds cylindrically
Title:  to remove its dark pelt, as an African hunter the pelt of a boa.
Title:  This done he turns the pelt inside out, like a pantaloon leg; gives
Title:  it a good stretching, so as almost to double its diameter; and at
Title:  last hangs it, well spread, in the rigging, to dry.  Ere long, it is
Title:  taken down; when removing some three feet of it, towards the pointed
Title:  extremity, and then cutting two slits for arm-holes at the other end,
Title:  he lengthwise slips himself bodily into it.  The mincer now stands
Title:  before you invested in the full canonicals of his calling.
Title:  Immemorial to all his order, this investiture alone will adequately
Title:  protect him, while employed in the peculiar functions of his office.
Title:  
Title:  That office consists in mincing the horse-pieces of blubber for the
Title:  pots; an operation which is conducted at a curious wooden horse,
Title:  planted endwise against the bulwarks, and with a capacious tub
Title:  beneath it, into which the minced pieces drop, fast as the sheets
Title:  from a rapt orator's desk.  Arrayed in decent black; occupying a
Title:  conspicuous pulpit; intent on bible leaves; what a candidate for an
Title:  archbishopric, what a lad for a Pope were this mincer!*
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *Bible leaves!  Bible leaves!  This is the invariable cry from the
Title:  mates to the mincer.  It enjoins him to be careful, and cut his work
Title:  into as thin slices as possible, inasmuch as by so doing the business
Title:  of boiling out the oil is much accelerated, and its quantity
Title:  considerably increased, besides perhaps improving it in quality.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 96
Title:  
Title:  The Try-Works.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Besides her hoisted boats, an American whaler is outwardly
Title:  distinguished by her try-works.  She presents the curious anomaly of
Title:  the most solid masonry joining with oak and hemp in constituting the
Title:  completed ship.  It is as if from the open field a brick-kiln were
Title:  transported to her planks.
Title:  
Title:  The try-works are planted between the foremast and mainmast, the
Title:  most roomy part of the deck.  The timbers beneath are of a peculiar
Title:  strength, fitted to sustain the weight of an almost solid mass of
Title:  brick and mortar, some ten feet by eight square, and five in height.
Title:  The foundation does not penetrate the deck, but the masonry is firmly
Title:  secured to the surface by ponderous knees of iron bracing it on all
Title:  sides, and screwing it down to the timbers.  On the flanks it is
Title:  cased with wood, and at top completely covered by a large, sloping,
Title:  battened hatchway.  Removing this hatch we expose the great try-pots,
Title:  two in number, and each of several barrels' capacity.  When not in
Title:  use, they are kept remarkably clean.  Sometimes they are polished
Title:  with soapstone and sand, till they shine within like silver
Title:  punch-bowls.  During the night-watches some cynical old sailors will
Title:  crawl into them and coil themselves away there for a nap.  While
Title:  employed in polishing them--one man in each pot, side by side--many
Title:  confidential communications are carried on, over the iron lips.  It
Title:  is a place also for profound mathematical meditation.  It was in the
Title:  left hand try-pot of the Pequod, with the soapstone diligently
Title:  circling round me, that I was first indirectly struck by the
Title:  remarkable fact, that in geometry all bodies gliding along the
Title:  cycloid, my soapstone for example, will descend from any point in
Title:  precisely the same time.
Title:  
Title:  Removing the fire-board from the front of the try-works, the bare
Title:  masonry of that side is exposed, penetrated by the two iron mouths of
Title:  the furnaces, directly underneath the pots.  These mouths are fitted
Title:  with heavy doors of iron.  The intense heat of the fire is prevented
Title:  from communicating itself to the deck, by means of a shallow
Title:  reservoir extending under the entire inclosed surface of the works.
Title:  By a tunnel inserted at the rear, this reservoir is kept replenished
Title:  with water as fast as it evaporates.  There are no external chimneys;
Title:  they open direct from the rear wall.  And here let us go back for a
Title:  moment.
Title:  
Title:  It was about nine o'clock at night that the Pequod's try-works were
Title:  first started on this present voyage.  It belonged to Stubb to
Title:  oversee the business.
Title:  
Title:  "All ready there?  Off hatch, then, and start her.  You cook, fire
Title:  the works."  This was an easy thing, for the carpenter had been
Title:  thrusting his shavings into the furnace throughout the passage.  Here
Title:  be it said that in a whaling voyage the first fire in the try-works has
Title:  to be fed for a time with wood.  After that no wood is used, except
Title:  as a means of quick ignition to the staple fuel.  In a word, after
Title:  being tried out, the crisp, shrivelled blubber, now called scraps or
Title:  fritters, still contains considerable of its unctuous properties.
Title:  These fritters feed the flames.  Like a plethoric burning martyr, or
Title:  a self-consuming misanthrope, once ignited, the whale supplies his
Title:  own fuel and burns by his own body.  Would that he consumed his own
Title:  smoke! for his smoke is horrible to inhale, and inhale it you must,
Title:  and not only that, but you must live in it for the time.  It has an
Title:  unspeakable, wild, Hindoo odor about it, such as may lurk in the
Title:  vicinity of funereal pyres.  It smells like the left wing of the day
Title:  of judgment; it is an argument for the pit.
Title:  
Title:  By midnight the works were in full operation.  We were clear from the
Title:  carcase; sail had been made; the wind was freshening; the wild ocean
Title:  darkness was intense.  But that darkness was licked up by the fierce
Title:  flames, which at intervals forked forth from the sooty flues, and
Title:  illuminated every lofty rope in the rigging, as with the famed Greek
Title:  fire.  The burning ship drove on, as if remorselessly commissioned to
Title:  some vengeful deed.  So the pitch and sulphur-freighted brigs of the
Title:  bold Hydriote, Canaris, issuing from their midnight harbors, with
Title:  broad sheets of flame for sails, bore down upon the Turkish frigates,
Title:  and folded them in conflagrations.
Title:  
Title:  The hatch, removed from the top of the works, now afforded a wide
Title:  hearth in front of them.  Standing on this were the Tartarean shapes
Title:  of the pagan harpooneers, always the whale-ship's stokers.  With huge
Title:  pronged poles they pitched hissing masses of blubber into the
Title:  scalding pots, or stirred up the fires beneath, till the snaky flames
Title:  darted, curling, out of the doors to catch them by the feet.  The
Title:  smoke rolled away in sullen heaps.  To every pitch of the ship there
Title:  was a pitch of the boiling oil, which seemed all eagerness to leap
Title:  into their faces.  Opposite the mouth of the works, on the further
Title:  side of the wide wooden hearth, was the windlass.  This served for a
Title:  sea-sofa.  Here lounged the watch, when not otherwise employed,
Title:  looking into the red heat of the fire, till their eyes felt scorched
Title:  in their heads.  Their tawny features, now all begrimed with smoke
Title:  and sweat, their matted beards, and the contrasting barbaric
Title:  brilliancy of their teeth, all these were strangely revealed in the
Title:  capricious emblazonings of the works.  As they narrated to each other
Title:  their unholy adventures, their tales of terror told in words of
Title:  mirth; as their uncivilized laughter forked upwards out of them, like
Title:  the flames from the furnace; as to and fro, in their front, the
Title:  harpooneers wildly gesticulated with their huge pronged forks and
Title:  dippers; as the wind howled on, and the sea leaped, and the ship
Title:  groaned and dived, and yet steadfastly shot her red hell further and
Title:  further into the blackness of the sea and the night, and scornfully
Title:  champed the white bone in her mouth, and viciously spat round her on
Title:  all sides; then the rushing Pequod, freighted with savages, and laden
Title:  with fire, and burning a corpse, and plunging into that blackness of
Title:  darkness, seemed the material counterpart of her monomaniac
Title:  commander's soul.
Title:  
Title:  So seemed it to me, as I stood at her helm, and for long hours
Title:  silently guided the way of this fire-ship on the sea.  Wrapped, for
Title:  that interval, in darkness myself, I but the better saw the redness,
Title:  the madness, the ghastliness of others.  The continual sight of the
Title:  fiend shapes before me, capering half in smoke and half in fire,
Title:  these at last begat kindred visions in my soul, so soon as I began to
Title:  yield to that unaccountable drowsiness which ever would come over me
Title:  at a midnight helm.
Title:  
Title:  But that night, in particular, a strange (and ever since
Title:  inexplicable) thing occurred to me.  Starting from a brief standing
Title:  sleep, I was horribly conscious of something fatally wrong.  The
Title:  jaw-bone tiller smote my side, which leaned against it; in my ears
Title:  was the low hum of sails, just beginning to shake in the wind; I
Title:  thought my eyes were open; I was half conscious of putting my fingers
Title:  to the lids and mechanically stretching them still further apart.
Title:  But, spite of all this, I could see no compass before me to steer by;
Title:  though it seemed but a minute since I had been watching the card, by
Title:  the steady binnacle lamp illuminating it.  Nothing seemed before me
Title:  but a jet gloom, now and then made ghastly by flashes of redness.
Title:  Uppermost was the impression, that whatever swift, rushing thing I
Title:  stood on was not so much bound to any haven ahead as rushing from all
Title:  havens astern.  A stark, bewildered feeling, as of death, came over
Title:  me.  Convulsively my hands grasped the tiller, but with the crazy
Title:  conceit that the tiller was, somehow, in some enchanted way,
Title:  inverted.  My God! what is the matter with me? thought I.  Lo! in my
Title:  brief sleep I had turned myself about, and was fronting the ship's
Title:  stern, with my back to her prow and the compass.  In an instant I
Title:  faced back, just in time to prevent the vessel from flying up into
Title:  the wind, and very probably capsizing her.  How glad and how grateful
Title:  the relief from this unnatural hallucination of the night, and the
Title:  fatal contingency of being brought by the lee!
Title:  
Title:  Look not too long in the face of the fire, O man!  Never dream with
Title:  thy hand on the helm!  Turn not thy back to the compass; accept the
Title:  first hint of the hitching tiller; believe not the artificial fire,
Title:  when its redness makes all things look ghastly.  To-morrow, in the
Title:  natural sun, the skies will be bright; those who glared like devils
Title:  in the forking flames, the morn will show in far other, at least
Title:  gentler, relief; the glorious, golden, glad sun, the only true
Title:  lamp--all others but liars!
Title:  
Title:  Nevertheless the sun hides not Virginia's Dismal Swamp, nor Rome's
Title:  accursed Campagna, nor wide Sahara, nor all the millions of miles of
Title:  deserts and of griefs beneath the moon.  The sun hides not the ocean,
Title:  which is the dark side of this earth, and which is two thirds of this
Title:  earth.  So, therefore, that mortal man who hath more of joy than
Title:  sorrow in him, that mortal man cannot be true--not true, or
Title:  undeveloped.  With books the same.  The truest of all men was the Man
Title:  of Sorrows, and the truest of all books is Solomon's, and
Title:  Ecclesiastes is the fine hammered steel of woe.  "All is vanity."
Title:  ALL.  This wilful world hath not got hold of unchristian Solomon's
Title:  wisdom yet.  But he who dodges hospitals and jails, and walks fast
Title:  crossing graveyards, and would rather talk of operas than hell;
Title:  calls Cowper, Young, Pascal, Rousseau, poor devils all of sick men;
Title:  and throughout a care-free lifetime swears by Rabelais as passing
Title:  wise, and therefore jolly;--not that man is fitted to sit down on
Title:  tomb-stones, and break the green damp mould with unfathomably
Title:  wondrous Solomon.
Title:  
Title:  But even Solomon, he says, "the man that wandereth out of the way of
Title:  understanding shall remain" (I.E., even while living) "in the
Title:  congregation of the dead."  Give not thyself up, then, to fire, lest
Title:  it invert thee, deaden thee; as for the time it did me.  There is a
Title:  wisdom that is woe; but there is a woe that is madness.  And there is
Title:  a Catskill eagle in some souls that can alike dive down into the
Title:  blackest gorges, and soar out of them again and become invisible in
Title:  the sunny spaces.  And even if he for ever flies within the gorge,
Title:  that gorge is in the mountains; so that even in his lowest swoop the
Title:  mountain eagle is still higher than other birds upon the plain, even
Title:  though they soar.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 97
Title:  
Title:  The Lamp.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Had you descended from the Pequod's try-works to the Pequod's
Title:  forecastle, where the off duty watch were sleeping, for one single
Title:  moment you would have almost thought you were standing in some
Title:  illuminated shrine of canonized kings and counsellors.  There they
Title:  lay in their triangular oaken vaults, each mariner a chiselled
Title:  muteness; a score of lamps flashing upon his hooded eyes.
Title:  
Title:  In merchantmen, oil for the sailor is more scarce than the milk of
Title:  queens.  To dress in the dark, and eat in the dark, and stumble in
Title:  darkness to his pallet, this is his usual lot.  But the whaleman, as
Title:  he seeks the food of light, so he lives in light.  He makes his berth
Title:  an Aladdin's lamp, and lays him down in it; so that in the pitchiest
Title:  night the ship's black hull still houses an illumination.
Title:  
Title:  See with what entire freedom the whaleman takes his handful of
Title:  lamps--often but old bottles and vials, though--to the copper cooler
Title:  at the try-works, and replenishes them there, as mugs of ale at a
Title:  vat.  He burns, too, the purest of oil, in its unmanufactured, and,
Title:  therefore, unvitiated state; a fluid unknown to solar, lunar, or
Title:  astral contrivances ashore.  It is sweet as early grass butter in
Title:  April.  He goes and hunts for his oil, so as to be sure of its
Title:  freshness and genuineness, even as the traveller on the prairie hunts
Title:  up his own supper of game.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 98
Title:  
Title:  Stowing Down and Clearing Up.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Already has it been related how the great leviathan is afar off
Title:  descried from the mast-head; how he is chased over the watery moors,
Title:  and slaughtered in the valleys of the deep; how he is then towed
Title:  alongside and beheaded; and how (on the principle which entitled the
Title:  headsman of old to the garments in which the beheaded was killed) his
Title:  great padded surtout becomes the property of his executioner; how, in
Title:  due time, he is condemned to the pots, and, like Shadrach, Meshach,
Title:  and Abednego, his spermaceti, oil, and bone pass unscathed through
Title:  the fire;--but now it remains to conclude the last chapter of this
Title:  part of the description by rehearsing--singing, if I may--the
Title:  romantic proceeding of decanting off his oil into the casks and
Title:  striking them down into the hold, where once again leviathan returns
Title:  to his native profundities, sliding along beneath the surface as
Title:  before; but, alas! never more to rise and blow.
Title:  
Title:  While still warm, the oil, like hot punch, is received into the
Title:  six-barrel casks; and while, perhaps, the ship is pitching and
Title:  rolling this way and that in the midnight sea, the enormous casks are
Title:  slewed round and headed over, end for end, and sometimes perilously
Title:  scoot across the slippery deck, like so many land slides, till at
Title:  last man-handled and stayed in their course; and all round the hoops,
Title:  rap, rap, go as many hammers as can play upon them, for now, EX
Title:  OFFICIO, every sailor is a cooper.
Title:  
Title:  At length, when the last pint is casked, and all is cool, then the
Title:  great hatchways are unsealed, the bowels of the ship are thrown open,
Title:  and down go the casks to their final rest in the sea.  This done, the
Title:  hatches are replaced, and hermetically closed, like a closet walled
Title:  up.
Title:  
Title:  In the sperm fishery, this is perhaps one of the most remarkable
Title:  incidents in all the business of whaling.  One day the planks stream
Title:  with freshets of blood and oil; on the sacred quarter-deck enormous
Title:  masses of the whale's head are profanely piled; great rusty casks lie
Title:  about, as in a brewery yard; the smoke from the try-works has
Title:  besooted all the bulwarks; the mariners go about suffused with
Title:  unctuousness; the entire ship seems great leviathan himself; while on
Title:  all hands the din is deafening.
Title:  
Title:  But a day or two after, you look about you, and prick your ears in
Title:  this self-same ship; and were it not for the tell-tale boats and
Title:  try-works, you would all but swear you trod some silent merchant
Title:  vessel, with a most scrupulously neat commander.  The unmanufactured
Title:  sperm oil possesses a singularly cleansing virtue.  This is the
Title:  reason why the decks never look so white as just after what they call
Title:  an affair of oil.  Besides, from the ashes of the burned scraps of
Title:  the whale, a potent lye is readily made; and whenever any
Title:  adhesiveness from the back of the whale remains clinging to the side,
Title:  that lye quickly exterminates it.  Hands go diligently along the
Title:  bulwarks, and with buckets of water and rags restore them to their
Title:  full tidiness.  The soot is brushed from the lower rigging.  All the
Title:  numerous implements which have been in use are likewise faithfully
Title:  cleansed and put away.  The great hatch is scrubbed and placed upon
Title:  the try-works, completely hiding the pots; every cask is out of
Title:  sight; all tackles are coiled in unseen nooks; and when by the
Title:  combined and simultaneous industry of almost the entire ship's
Title:  company, the whole of this conscientious duty is at last concluded,
Title:  then the crew themselves proceed to their own ablutions; shift
Title:  themselves from top to toe; and finally issue to the immaculate deck,
Title:  fresh and all aglow, as bridegrooms new-leaped from out the daintiest
Title:  Holland.
Title:  
Title:  Now, with elated step, they pace the planks in twos and threes, and
Title:  humorously discourse of parlors, sofas, carpets, and fine cambrics;
Title:  propose to mat the deck; think of having hanging to the top; object
Title:  not to taking tea by moonlight on the piazza of the forecastle.  To
Title:  hint to such musked mariners of oil, and bone, and blubber, were
Title:  little short of audacity.  They know not the thing you distantly
Title:  allude to.  Away, and bring us napkins!
Title:  
Title:  But mark: aloft there, at the three mast heads, stand three men
Title:  intent on spying out more whales, which, if caught, infallibly will
Title:  again soil the old oaken furniture, and drop at least one small
Title:  grease-spot somewhere.  Yes; and many is the time, when, after the
Title:  severest uninterrupted labors, which know no night; continuing
Title:  straight through for ninety-six hours; when from the boat, where they
Title:  have swelled their wrists with all day rowing on the Line,--they only
Title:  step to the deck to carry vast chains, and heave the heavy windlass,
Title:  and cut and slash, yea, and in their very sweatings to be smoked and
Title:  burned anew by the combined fires of the equatorial sun and the
Title:  equatorial try-works; when, on the heel of all this, they have
Title:  finally bestirred themselves to cleanse the ship, and make a spotless
Title:  dairy room of it; many is the time the poor fellows, just buttoning
Title:  the necks of their clean frocks, are startled by the cry of "There
Title:  she blows!" and away they fly to fight another whale, and go through
Title:  the whole weary thing again.  Oh! my friends, but this is
Title:  man-killing!  Yet this is life.  For hardly have we mortals by long
Title:  toilings extracted from this world's vast bulk its small but
Title:  valuable sperm; and then, with weary patience, cleansed ourselves
Title:  from its defilements, and learned to live here in clean tabernacles
Title:  of the soul; hardly is this done, when--THERE SHE BLOWS!--the ghost
Title:  is spouted up, and away we sail to fight some other world, and go
Title:  through young life's old routine again.
Title:  
Title:  Oh! the metempsychosis!  Oh!  Pythagoras, that in bright Greece, two
Title:  thousand years ago, did die, so good, so wise, so mild; I sailed with
Title:  thee along the Peruvian coast last voyage--and, foolish as I am,
Title:  taught thee, a green simple boy, how to splice a rope!
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 99
Title:  
Title:  The Doubloon.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Ere now it has been related how Ahab was wont to pace his
Title:  quarter-deck, taking regular turns at either limit, the binnacle and
