Title:  mainmast; but in the multiplicity of other things requiring narration
Title:  it has not been added how that sometimes in these walks, when most
Title:  plunged in his mood, he was wont to pause in turn at each spot, and
Title:  stand there strangely eyeing the particular object before him.  When
Title:  he halted before the binnacle, with his glance fastened on the
Title:  pointed needle in the compass, that glance shot like a javelin with
Title:  the pointed intensity of his purpose; and when resuming his walk he
Title:  again paused before the mainmast, then, as the same riveted glance
Title:  fastened upon the riveted gold coin there, he still wore the same
Title:  aspect of nailed firmness, only dashed with a certain wild longing,
Title:  if not hopefulness.
Title:  
Title:  But one morning, turning to pass the doubloon, he seemed to be newly
Title:  attracted by the strange figures and inscriptions stamped on it, as
Title:  though now for the first time beginning to interpret for himself in
Title:  some monomaniac way whatever significance might lurk in them.  And
Title:  some certain significance lurks in all things, else all things are
Title:  little worth, and the round world itself but an empty cipher, except
Title:  to sell by the cartload, as they do hills about Boston, to fill up
Title:  some morass in the Milky Way.
Title:  
Title:  Now this doubloon was of purest, virgin gold, raked somewhere out of
Title:  the heart of gorgeous hills, whence, east and west, over golden
Title:  sands, the head-waters of many a Pactolus flows.  And though now
Title:  nailed amidst all the rustiness of iron bolts and the verdigris of
Title:  copper spikes, yet, untouchable and immaculate to any foulness, it
Title:  still preserved its Quito glow.  Nor, though placed amongst a
Title:  ruthless crew and every hour passed by ruthless hands, and through
Title:  the livelong nights shrouded with thick darkness which might cover
Title:  any pilfering approach, nevertheless every sunrise found the doubloon
Title:  where the sunset left it last.  For it was set apart and sanctified
Title:  to one awe-striking end; and however wanton in their sailor ways, one
Title:  and all, the mariners revered it as the white whale's talisman.
Title:  Sometimes they talked it over in the weary watch by night, wondering
Title:  whose it was to be at last, and whether he would ever live to spend
Title:  it.
Title:  
Title:  Now those noble golden coins of South America are as medals of the
Title:  sun and tropic token-pieces.  Here palms, alpacas, and volcanoes;
Title:  sun's disks and stars; ecliptics, horns-of-plenty, and rich banners
Title:  waving, are in luxuriant profusion stamped; so that the precious gold
Title:  seems almost to derive an added preciousness and enhancing glories,
Title:  by passing through those fancy mints, so Spanishly poetic.
Title:  
Title:  It so chanced that the doubloon of the Pequod was a most wealthy
Title:  example of these things.  On its round border it bore the letters,
Title:  REPUBLICA DEL ECUADOR: QUITO.  So this bright coin came from a
Title:  country planted in the middle of the world, and beneath the great
Title:  equator, and named after it; and it had been cast midway up the
Title:  Andes, in the unwaning clime that knows no autumn.  Zoned by those
Title:  letters you saw the likeness of three Andes' summits; from one a
Title:  flame; a tower on another; on the third a crowing cock; while arching
Title:  over all was a segment of the partitioned zodiac, the signs all
Title:  marked with their usual cabalistics, and the keystone sun entering
Title:  the equinoctial point at Libra.
Title:  
Title:  Before this equatorial coin, Ahab, not unobserved by others, was now
Title:  pausing.
Title:  
Title:  "There's something ever egotistical in mountain-tops and towers, and
Title:  all other grand and lofty things; look here,--three peaks as proud as
Title:  Lucifer.  The firm tower, that is Ahab; the volcano, that is Ahab;
Title:  the courageous, the undaunted, and victorious fowl, that, too, is
Title:  Ahab; all are Ahab; and this round gold is but the image of the
Title:  rounder globe, which, like a magician's glass, to each and every man
Title:  in turn but mirrors back his own mysterious self.  Great pains, small
Title:  gains for those who ask the world to solve them; it cannot solve
Title:  itself.  Methinks now this coined sun wears a ruddy face; but see!
Title:  aye, he enters the sign of storms, the equinox! and but six months
Title:  before he wheeled out of a former equinox at Aries!  From storm to
Title:  storm!  So be it, then.  Born in throes, 't is fit that man should
Title:  live in pains and die in pangs!  So be it, then!  Here's stout stuff
Title:  for woe to work on.  So be it, then."
Title:  
Title:  "No fairy fingers can have pressed the gold, but devil's claws must have
Title:  left their mouldings there since yesterday," murmured Starbuck to
Title:  himself, leaning against the bulwarks.  "The old man seems to read
Title:  Belshazzar's awful writing.  I have never marked the coin
Title:  inspectingly.  He goes below; let me read.  A dark valley between
Title:  three mighty, heaven-abiding peaks, that almost seem the Trinity, in
Title:  some faint earthly symbol.  So in this vale of Death, God girds us
Title:  round; and over all our gloom, the sun of Righteousness still shines
Title:  a beacon and a hope.  If we bend down our eyes, the dark vale shows
Title:  her mouldy soil; but if we lift them, the bright sun meets our glance
Title:  half way, to cheer.  Yet, oh, the great sun is no fixture; and if, at
Title:  midnight, we would fain snatch some sweet solace from him, we gaze
Title:  for him in vain!  This coin speaks wisely, mildly, truly, but still
Title:  sadly to me.  I will quit it, lest Truth shake me falsely."
Title:  
Title:  "There now's the old Mogul," soliloquized Stubb by the try-works,
Title:  "he's been twigging it; and there goes Starbuck from the same, and
Title:  both with faces which I should say might be somewhere within nine
Title:  fathoms long.  And all from looking at a piece of gold, which did I
Title:  have it now on Negro Hill or in Corlaer's Hook, I'd not look at it
Title:  very long ere spending it.  Humph! in my poor, insignificant opinion,
Title:  I regard this as queer.  I have seen doubloons before now in my
Title:  voyagings; your doubloons of old Spain, your doubloons of Peru, your
Title:  doubloons of Chili, your doubloons of Bolivia, your doubloons of
Title:  Popayan; with plenty of gold moidores and pistoles, and joes, and
Title:  half joes, and quarter joes.  What then should there be in this
Title:  doubloon of the Equator that is so killing wonderful?  By Golconda!
Title:  let me read it once.  Halloa! here's signs and wonders truly!  That,
Title:  now, is what old Bowditch in his Epitome calls the zodiac, and what
Title:  my almanac below calls ditto.  I'll get the almanac and as I have
Title:  heard devils can be raised with Daboll's arithmetic, I'll try my hand
Title:  at raising a meaning out of these queer curvicues here with the
Title:  Massachusetts calendar.  Here's the book.  Let's see now.  Signs and
Title:  wonders; and the sun, he's always among 'em.  Hem, hem, hem; here
Title:  they are--here they go--all alive:--Aries, or the Ram; Taurus, or the
Title:  Bull and Jimimi! here's Gemini himself, or the Twins.  Well; the sun
Title:  he wheels among 'em.  Aye, here on the coin he's just crossing the
Title:  threshold between two of twelve sitting-rooms all in a ring.  Book!
Title:  you lie there; the fact is, you books must know your places.  You'll
Title:  do to give us the bare words and facts, but we come in to supply the
Title:  thoughts.  That's my small experience, so far as the Massachusetts
Title:  calendar, and Bowditch's navigator, and Daboll's arithmetic go.
Title:  Signs and wonders, eh?  Pity if there is nothing wonderful in signs,
Title:  and significant in wonders!  There's a clue somewhere; wait a bit;
Title:  hist--hark!  By Jove, I have it!  Look you, Doubloon, your zodiac
Title:  here is the life of man in one round chapter; and now I'll read it
Title:  off, straight out of the book.  Come, Almanack!  To begin: there's
Title:  Aries, or the Ram--lecherous dog, he begets us; then, Taurus, or the
Title:  Bull--he bumps us the first thing; then Gemini, or the Twins--that
Title:  is, Virtue and Vice; we try to reach Virtue, when lo! comes Cancer
Title:  the Crab, and drags us back; and here, going from Virtue, Leo, a
Title:  roaring Lion, lies in the path--he gives a few fierce bites and surly
Title:  dabs with his paw; we escape, and hail Virgo, the Virgin! that's our
Title:  first love; we marry and think to be happy for aye, when pop comes
Title:  Libra, or the Scales--happiness weighed and found wanting; and while
Title:  we are very sad about that, Lord! how we suddenly jump, as Scorpio,
Title:  or the Scorpion, stings us in the rear; we are curing the wound, when
Title:  whang come the arrows all round; Sagittarius, or the Archer, is
Title:  amusing himself.  As we pluck out the shafts, stand aside! here's
Title:  the battering-ram, Capricornus, or the Goat; full tilt, he comes
Title:  rushing, and headlong we are tossed; when Aquarius, or the
Title:  Water-bearer, pours out his whole deluge and drowns us; and to wind
Title:  up with Pisces, or the Fishes, we sleep.  There's a sermon now, writ
Title:  in high heaven, and the sun goes through it every year, and yet comes
Title:  out of it all alive and hearty.  Jollily he, aloft there, wheels
Title:  through toil and trouble; and so, alow here, does jolly Stubb.  Oh,
Title:  jolly's the word for aye!  Adieu, Doubloon!  But stop; here comes
Title:  little King-Post; dodge round the try-works, now, and let's hear what
Title:  he'll have to say.  There; he's before it; he'll out with something
Title:  presently.  So, so; he's beginning."
Title:  
Title:  "I see nothing here, but a round thing made of gold, and whoever
Title:  raises a certain whale, this round thing belongs to him.  So, what's
Title:  all this staring been about?  It is worth sixteen dollars, that's
Title:  true; and at two cents the cigar, that's nine hundred and sixty
Title:  cigars.  I won't smoke dirty pipes like Stubb, but I like cigars, and
Title:  here's nine hundred and sixty of them; so here goes Flask aloft to
Title:  spy 'em out."
Title:  
Title:  "Shall I call that wise or foolish, now; if it be really wise it has
Title:  a foolish look to it; yet, if it be really foolish, then has it a
Title:  sort of wiseish look to it.  But, avast; here comes our old
Title:  Manxman--the old hearse-driver, he must have been, that is, before he
Title:  took to the sea.  He luffs up before the doubloon; halloa, and goes
Title:  round on the other side of the mast; why, there's a horse-shoe nailed
Title:  on that side; and now he's back again; what does that mean?  Hark!
Title:  he's muttering--voice like an old worn-out coffee-mill.  Prick ears,
Title:  and listen!"
Title:  
Title:  "If the White Whale be raised, it must be in a month and a day, when
Title:  the sun stands in some one of these signs.  I've studied signs, and
Title:  know their marks; they were taught me two score years ago, by the old
Title:  witch in Copenhagen.  Now, in what sign will the sun then be?  The
Title:  horse-shoe sign; for there it is, right opposite the gold.  And
Title:  what's the horse-shoe sign?  The lion is the horse-shoe sign--the
Title:  roaring and devouring lion.  Ship, old ship! my old head shakes to
Title:  think of thee."
Title:  
Title:  "There's another rendering now; but still one text.  All sorts of men
Title:  in one kind of world, you see.  Dodge again! here comes Queequeg--all
Title:  tattooing--looks like the signs of the Zodiac himself.  What says the
Title:  Cannibal?  As I live he's comparing notes; looking at his thigh bone;
Title:  thinks the sun is in the thigh, or in the calf, or in the bowels, I
Title:  suppose, as the old women talk Surgeon's Astronomy in the back
Title:  country.  And by Jove, he's found something there in the vicinity of
Title:  his thigh--I guess it's Sagittarius, or the Archer.  No: he don't
Title:  know what to make of the doubloon; he takes it for an old button off
Title:  some king's trowsers.  But, aside again! here comes that ghost-devil,
Title:  Fedallah; tail coiled out of sight as usual, oakum in the toes of his
Title:  pumps as usual.  What does he say, with that look of his?  Ah, only
Title:  makes a sign to the sign and bows himself; there is a sun on the
Title:  coin--fire worshipper, depend upon it.  Ho! more and more.  This way
Title:  comes Pip--poor boy! would he had died, or I; he's half horrible to
Title:  me.  He too has been watching all of these interpreters--myself
Title:  included--and look now, he comes to read, with that unearthly idiot
Title:  face.  Stand away again and hear him.  Hark!"
Title:  
Title:  "I look, you look, he looks; we look, ye look, they look."
Title:  
Title:  "Upon my soul, he's been studying Murray's Grammar!  Improving his
Title:  mind, poor fellow!  But what's that he says now--hist!"
Title:  
Title:  "I look, you look, he looks; we look, ye look, they look."
Title:  
Title:  "Why, he's getting it by heart--hist! again."
Title:  
Title:  "I look, you look, he looks; we look, ye look, they look."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, that's funny."
Title:  
Title:  "And I, you, and he; and we, ye, and they, are all bats; and I'm a
Title:  crow, especially when I stand a'top of this pine tree here.  Caw!
Title:  caw! caw! caw! caw! caw!  Ain't I a crow?  And where's the
Title:  scare-crow?  There he stands; two bones stuck into a pair of old
Title:  trowsers, and two more poked into the sleeves of an old jacket."
Title:  
Title:  "Wonder if he means me?--complimentary!--poor lad!--I could go hang
Title:  myself.  Any way, for the present, I'll quit Pip's vicinity.  I can
Title:  stand the rest, for they have plain wits; but he's too crazy-witty
Title:  for my sanity.  So, so, I leave him muttering."
Title:  
Title:  "Here's the ship's navel, this doubloon here, and they are all on
Title:  fire to unscrew it.  But, unscrew your navel, and what's the
Title:  consequence?  Then again, if it stays here, that is ugly, too, for
Title:  when aught's nailed to the mast it's a sign that things grow
Title:  desperate.  Ha, ha! old Ahab! the White Whale; he'll nail ye!  This
Title:  is a pine tree.  My father, in old Tolland county, cut down a pine
Title:  tree once, and found a silver ring grown over in it; some old
Title:  darkey's wedding ring.  How did it get there?  And so they'll say in
Title:  the resurrection, when they come to fish up this old mast, and find a
Title:  doubloon lodged in it, with bedded oysters for the shaggy bark.  Oh,
Title:  the gold! the precious, precious, gold! the green miser'll hoard ye
Title:  soon!  Hish! hish!  God goes 'mong the worlds blackberrying.  Cook!
Title:  ho, cook! and cook us!  Jenny! hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, Jenny, Jenny!
Title:  and get your hoe-cake done!"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 100
Title:  
Title:  Leg and Arm.
Title:  
Title:  The Pequod, of Nantucket, Meets the Samuel Enderby, of London.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "Ship, ahoy!  Hast seen the White Whale?"
Title:  
Title:  So cried Ahab, once more hailing a ship showing English colours,
Title:  bearing down under the stern.  Trumpet to mouth, the old man was
Title:  standing in his hoisted quarter-boat, his ivory leg plainly revealed
Title:  to the stranger captain, who was carelessly reclining in his own
Title:  boat's bow.  He was a darkly-tanned, burly, good-natured,
Title:  fine-looking man, of sixty or thereabouts, dressed in a spacious
Title:  roundabout, that hung round him in festoons of blue pilot-cloth; and
Title:  one empty arm of this jacket streamed behind him like the broidered
Title:  arm of a hussar's surcoat.
Title:  
Title:  "Hast seen the White Whale!"
Title:  
Title:  "See you this?" and withdrawing it from the folds that had hidden
Title:  it, he held up a white arm of sperm whale bone, terminating in a
Title:  wooden head like a mallet.
Title:  
Title:  "Man my boat!" cried Ahab, impetuously, and tossing about the oars
Title:  near him--"Stand by to lower!"
Title:  
Title:  In less than a minute, without quitting his little craft, he and his
Title:  crew were dropped to the water, and were soon alongside of the
Title:  stranger.  But here a curious difficulty presented itself.  In the
Title:  excitement of the moment, Ahab had forgotten that since the loss of
Title:  his leg he had never once stepped on board of any vessel at sea but
Title:  his own, and then it was always by an ingenious and very handy
Title:  mechanical contrivance peculiar to the Pequod, and a thing not to be
Title:  rigged and shipped in any other vessel at a moment's warning.  Now,
Title:  it is no very easy matter for anybody--except those who are almost
Title:  hourly used to it, like whalemen--to clamber up a ship's side from a
Title:  boat on the open sea; for the great swells now lift the boat high up
Title:  towards the bulwarks, and then instantaneously drop it half way down
Title:  to the kelson.  So, deprived of one leg, and the strange ship of
Title:  course being altogether unsupplied with the kindly invention, Ahab
Title:  now found himself abjectly reduced to a clumsy landsman again;
Title:  hopelessly eyeing the uncertain changeful height he could hardly hope
Title:  to attain.
Title:  
Title:  It has before been hinted, perhaps, that every little untoward
Title:  circumstance that befell him, and which indirectly sprang from his
Title:  luckless mishap, almost invariably irritated or exasperated Ahab.
Title:  And in the present instance, all this was heightened by the sight of
Title:  the two officers of the strange ship, leaning over the side, by the
Title:  perpendicular ladder of nailed cleets there, and swinging towards him
Title:  a pair of tastefully-ornamented man-ropes; for at first they did not
Title:  seem to bethink them that a one-legged man must be too much of a
Title:  cripple to use their sea bannisters.  But this awkwardness only
Title:  lasted a minute, because the strange captain, observing at a glance
Title:  how affairs stood, cried out, "I see, I see!--avast heaving there!
Title:  Jump, boys, and swing over the cutting-tackle."
Title:  
Title:  As good luck would have it, they had had a whale alongside a day or
Title:  two previous, and the great tackles were still aloft, and the massive
Title:  curved blubber-hook, now clean and dry, was still attached to the
Title:  end.  This was quickly lowered to Ahab, who at once comprehending it
Title:  all, slid his solitary thigh into the curve of the hook (it was like
Title:  sitting in the fluke of an anchor, or the crotch of an apple tree),
Title:  and then giving the word, held himself fast, and at the same time
Title:  also helped to hoist his own weight, by pulling hand-over-hand upon
Title:  one of the running parts of the tackle.  Soon he was carefully swung
Title:  inside the high bulwarks, and gently landed upon the capstan head.
Title:  With his ivory arm frankly thrust forth in welcome, the other captain
Title:  advanced, and Ahab, putting out his ivory leg, and crossing the ivory
Title:  arm (like two sword-fish blades) cried out in his walrus way, "Aye,
Title:  aye, hearty! let us shake bones together!--an arm and a leg!--an arm
Title:  that never can shrink, d'ye see; and a leg that never can run.  Where
Title:  did'st thou see the White Whale?--how long ago?"
Title:  
Title:  "The White Whale," said the Englishman, pointing his ivory arm
Title:  towards the East, and taking a rueful sight along it, as if it had
Title:  been a telescope; "there I saw him, on the Line, last season."
Title:  
Title:  "And he took that arm off, did he?" asked Ahab, now sliding down from
Title:  the capstan, and resting on the Englishman's shoulder, as he did so.
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, he was the cause of it, at least; and that leg, too?"
Title:  
Title:  "Spin me the yarn," said Ahab; "how was it?"
Title:  
Title:  "It was the first time in my life that I ever cruised on the Line,"
Title:  began the Englishman.  "I was ignorant of the White Whale at that
Title:  time.  Well, one day we lowered for a pod of four or five whales, and
Title:  my boat fastened to one of them; a regular circus horse he was, too,
Title:  that went milling and milling round so, that my boat's crew could
Title:  only trim dish, by sitting all their sterns on the outer gunwale.
Title:  Presently up breaches from the bottom of the sea a bouncing great
Title:  whale, with a milky-white head and hump, all crows' feet and
Title:  wrinkles."
Title:  
Title:  "It was he, it was he!" cried Ahab, suddenly letting out his
Title:  suspended breath.
Title:  
Title:  "And harpoons sticking in near his starboard fin."
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, aye--they were mine--MY irons," cried Ahab, exultingly--"but
Title:  on!"
Title:  
Title:  "Give me a chance, then," said the Englishman, good-humoredly.
Title:  "Well, this old great-grandfather, with the white head and hump, runs
Title:  all afoam into the pod, and goes to snapping furiously at my
Title:  fast-line!
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, I see!--wanted to part it; free the fast-fish--an old trick--I
Title:  know him."
Title:  
Title:  "How it was exactly," continued the one-armed commander, "I do not
Title:  know; but in biting the line, it got foul of his teeth, caught there
Title:  somehow; but we didn't know it then; so that when we afterwards
Title:  pulled on the line, bounce we came plump on to his hump! instead of
Title:  the other whale's; that went off to windward, all fluking.  Seeing
Title:  how matters stood, and what a noble great whale it was--the noblest
Title:  and biggest I ever saw, sir, in my life--I resolved to capture him,
Title:  spite of the boiling rage he seemed to be in.  And thinking the
Title:  hap-hazard line would get loose, or the tooth it was tangled to
Title:  might draw (for I have a devil of a boat's crew for a pull on a
Title:  whale-line); seeing all this, I say, I jumped into my first mate's
Title:  boat--Mr. Mounttop's here (by the way, Captain--Mounttop;
Title:  Mounttop--the captain);--as I was saying, I jumped into Mounttop's
Title:  boat, which, d'ye see, was gunwale and gunwale with mine, then; and
Title:  snatching the first harpoon, let this old great-grandfather have it.
Title:  But, Lord, look you, sir--hearts and souls alive, man--the next
Title:  instant, in a jiff, I was blind as a bat--both eyes out--all befogged
Title:  and bedeadened with black foam--the whale's tail looming straight up
Title:  out of it, perpendicular in the air, like a marble steeple.  No use
Title:  sterning all, then; but as I was groping at midday, with a blinding
Title:  sun, all crown-jewels; as I was groping, I say, after the second
Title:  iron, to toss it overboard--down comes the tail like a Lima tower,
Title:  cutting my boat in two, leaving each half in splinters; and, flukes
Title:  first, the white hump backed through the wreck, as though it was all
Title:  chips.  We all struck out.  To escape his terrible flailings, I
Title:  seized hold of my harpoon-pole sticking in him, and for a moment
Title:  clung to that like a sucking fish.  But a combing sea dashed me off,
Title:  and at the same instant, the fish, taking one good dart forwards,
Title:  went down like a flash; and the barb of that cursed second iron
Title:  towing along near me caught me here" (clapping his hand just below
Title:  his shoulder); "yes, caught me just here, I say, and bore me down to
Title:  Hell's flames, I was thinking; when, when, all of a sudden, thank the
Title:  good God, the barb ript its way along the flesh--clear along the
Title:  whole length of my arm--came out nigh my wrist, and up I
Title:  floated;--and that gentleman there will tell you the rest (by the
Title:  way, captain--Dr. Bunger, ship's surgeon: Bunger, my lad,--the
Title:  captain).  Now, Bunger boy, spin your part of the yarn."
Title:  
Title:  The professional gentleman thus familiarly pointed out, had been all
Title:  the time standing near them, with nothing specific visible, to denote
Title:  his gentlemanly rank on board.  His face was an exceedingly round but
Title:  sober one; he was dressed in a faded blue woollen frock or shirt, and
Title:  patched trowsers; and had thus far been dividing his attention
Title:  between a marlingspike he held in one hand, and a pill-box held in
Title:  the other, occasionally casting a critical glance at the ivory limbs
Title:  of the two crippled captains.  But, at his superior's introduction of
Title:  him to Ahab, he politely bowed, and straightway went on to do his
Title:  captain's bidding.
Title:  
Title:  "It was a shocking bad wound," began the whale-surgeon; "and, taking
Title:  my advice, Captain Boomer here, stood our old Sammy--"
Title:  
Title:  "Samuel Enderby is the name of my ship," interrupted the one-armed
Title:  captain, addressing Ahab; "go on, boy."
Title:  
Title:  "Stood our old Sammy off to the northward, to get out of the blazing
Title:  hot weather there on the Line.  But it was no use--I did all I could;
Title:  sat up with him nights; was very severe with him in the matter of
Title:  diet--"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, very severe!" chimed in the patient himself; then suddenly
Title:  altering his voice, "Drinking hot rum toddies with me every night,
Title:  till he couldn't see to put on the bandages; and sending me to bed,
Title:  half seas over, about three o'clock in the morning.  Oh, ye stars! he
Title:  sat up with me indeed, and was very severe in my diet.  Oh! a great
Title:  watcher, and very dietetically severe, is Dr. Bunger. (Bunger, you
Title:  dog, laugh out! why don't ye?  You know you're a precious jolly
Title:  rascal.) But, heave ahead, boy, I'd rather be killed by you than kept
Title:  alive by any other man."
Title:  
Title:  "My captain, you must have ere this perceived, respected sir"--said
Title:  the imperturbable godly-looking Bunger, slightly bowing to Ahab--"is
Title:  apt to be facetious at times; he spins us many clever things of that
Title:  sort.  But I may as well say--en passant, as the French remark--that
Title:  I myself--that is to say, Jack Bunger, late of the reverend
Title:  clergy--am a strict total abstinence man; I never drink--"
Title:  
Title:  "Water!" cried the captain; "he never drinks it; it's a sort of fits
Title:  to him; fresh water throws him into the hydrophobia; but go on--go on
Title:  with the arm story."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, I may as well," said the surgeon, coolly.  "I was about
Title:  observing, sir, before Captain Boomer's facetious interruption, that
Title:  spite of my best and severest endeavors, the wound kept getting worse
Title:  and worse; the truth was, sir, it was as ugly gaping wound as surgeon
Title:  ever saw; more than two feet and several inches long.  I measured it
Title:  with the lead line.  In short, it grew black; I knew what was
Title:  threatened, and off it came.  But I had no hand in shipping that
Title:  ivory arm there; that thing is against all rule"--pointing at it with
Title:  the marlingspike--"that is the captain's work, not mine; he ordered
Title:  the carpenter to make it; he had that club-hammer there put to the
Title:  end, to knock some one's brains out with, I suppose, as he tried mine
Title:  once.  He flies into diabolical passions sometimes.  Do ye see this
Title:  dent, sir"--removing his hat, and brushing aside his hair, and
Title:  exposing a bowl-like cavity in his skull, but which bore not the
Title:  slightest scarry trace, or any token of ever having been a
Title:  wound--"Well, the captain there will tell you how that came here;
Title:  he knows."
Title:  
Title:  "No, I don't," said the captain, "but his mother did; he was born
Title:  with it.  Oh, you solemn rogue, you--you Bunger! was there ever such
Title:  another Bunger in the watery world?  Bunger, when you die, you ought
Title:  to die in pickle, you dog; you should be preserved to future ages,
Title:  you rascal."
Title:  
Title:  "What became of the White Whale?" now cried Ahab, who thus far had
Title:  been impatiently listening to this by-play between the two
Title:  Englishmen.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh!" cried the one-armed captain, "oh, yes!  Well; after he sounded,
Title:  we didn't see him again for some time; in fact, as I before hinted, I
Title:  didn't then know what whale it was that had served me such a trick,
Title:  till some time afterwards, when coming back to the Line, we heard
Title:  about Moby Dick--as some call him--and then I knew it was he."
Title:  
Title:  "Did'st thou cross his wake again?"
Title:  
Title:  "Twice."
Title:  
Title:  "But could not fasten?"
Title:  
Title:  "Didn't want to try to: ain't one limb enough?  What should I do
Title:  without this other arm?  And I'm thinking Moby Dick doesn't bite so
Title:  much as he swallows."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then," interrupted Bunger, "give him your left arm for bait to
Title:  get the right.  Do you know, gentlemen"--very gravely and
Title:  mathematically bowing to each Captain in succession--"Do you know,
Title:  gentlemen, that the digestive organs of the whale are so inscrutably
Title:  constructed by Divine Providence, that it is quite impossible for him
Title:  to completely digest even a man's arm?  And he knows it too.  So that
Title:  what you take for the White Whale's malice is only his awkwardness.
Title:  For he never means to swallow a single limb; he only thinks to
Title:  terrify by feints.  But sometimes he is like the old juggling fellow,
Title:  formerly a patient of mine in Ceylon, that making believe swallow
Title:  jack-knives, once upon a time let one drop into him in good earnest,
Title:  and there it stayed for a twelvemonth or more; when I gave him an
Title:  emetic, and he heaved it up in small tacks, d'ye see.  No possible
Title:  way for him to digest that jack-knife, and fully incorporate it into
Title:  his general bodily system.  Yes, Captain Boomer, if you are quick
Title:  enough about it, and have a mind to pawn one arm for the sake of the
Title:  privilege of giving decent burial to the other, why in that case
Title:  the arm is yours; only let the whale have another chance at you
Title:  shortly, that's all."
Title:  
Title:  "No, thank ye, Bunger," said the English Captain, "he's welcome to
Title:  the arm he has, since I can't help it, and didn't know him then; but
Title:  not to another one.  No more White Whales for me; I've lowered for
Title:  him once, and that has satisfied me.  There would be great glory in
Title:  killing him, I know that; and there is a ship-load of precious sperm
Title:  in him, but, hark ye, he's best let alone; don't you think so,
Title:  Captain?"--glancing at the ivory leg.
Title:  
Title:  "He is.  But he will still be hunted, for all that.  What is best let
Title:  alone, that accursed thing is not always what least allures.  He's
Title:  all a magnet!  How long since thou saw'st him last?  Which way
Title:  heading?"
Title:  
Title:  "Bless my soul, and curse the foul fiend's," cried Bunger, stoopingly
Title:  walking round Ahab, and like a dog, strangely snuffing; "this man's
Title:  blood--bring the thermometer!--it's at the boiling point!--his pulse
Title:  makes these planks beat!--sir!"--taking a lancet from his pocket, and
Title:  drawing near to Ahab's arm.
Title:  
Title:  "Avast!" roared Ahab, dashing him against the bulwarks--"Man the
Title:  boat!  Which way heading?"
Title:  
Title:  "Good God!" cried the English Captain, to whom the question was put.
Title:  "What's the matter?  He was heading east, I think.--Is your Captain
Title:  crazy?" whispering Fedallah.
Title:  
Title:  But Fedallah, putting a finger on his lip, slid over the bulwarks to
Title:  take the boat's steering oar, and Ahab, swinging the cutting-tackle
Title:  towards him, commanded the ship's sailors to stand by to lower.
Title:  
Title:  In a moment he was standing in the boat's stern, and the Manilla men
Title:  were springing to their oars.  In vain the English Captain hailed
Title:  him.  With back to the stranger ship, and face set like a flint to
Title:  his own, Ahab stood upright till alongside of the Pequod.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 101
Title:  
Title:  The Decanter.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Ere the English ship fades from sight, be it set down here, that she
Title:  hailed from London, and was named after the late Samuel Enderby,
Title:  merchant of that city, the original of the famous whaling house of
Title:  Enderby & Sons; a house which in my poor whaleman's opinion, comes
Title:  not far behind the united royal houses of the Tudors and Bourbons, in
Title:  point of real historical interest.  How long, prior to the year of
Title:  our Lord 1775, this great whaling house was in existence, my numerous
Title:  fish-documents do not make plain; but in that year (1775) it fitted
Title:  out the first English ships that ever regularly hunted the Sperm
Title:  Whale; though for some score of years previous (ever since 1726) our
Title:  valiant Coffins and Maceys of Nantucket and the Vineyard had in large
Title:  fleets pursued that Leviathan, but only in the North and South
Title:  Atlantic: not elsewhere.  Be it distinctly recorded here, that the
Title:  Nantucketers were the first among mankind to harpoon with civilized
Title:  steel the great Sperm Whale; and that for half a century they were
Title:  the only people of the whole globe who so harpooned him.
Title:  
Title:  In 1778, a fine ship, the Amelia, fitted out for the express purpose,
Title:  and at the sole charge of the vigorous Enderbys, boldly rounded Cape
Title:  Horn, and was the first among the nations to lower a whale-boat of
Title:  any sort in the great South Sea.  The voyage was a skilful and lucky
Title:  one; and returning to her berth with her hold full of the precious
Title:  sperm, the Amelia's example was soon followed by other ships, English
Title:  and American, and thus the vast Sperm Whale grounds of the Pacific
Title:  were thrown open.  But not content with this good deed, the
Title:  indefatigable house again bestirred itself: Samuel and all his
Title:  Sons--how many, their mother only knows--and under their immediate
Title:  auspices, and partly, I think, at their expense, the British
Title:  government was induced to send the sloop-of-war Rattler on a whaling
Title:  voyage of discovery into the South Sea.  Commanded by a naval
Title:  Post-Captain, the Rattler made a rattling voyage of it, and did some
Title:  service; how much does not appear.  But this is not all.  In 1819,
Title:  the same house fitted out a discovery whale ship of their own, to go
Title:  on a tasting cruise to the remote waters of Japan.  That ship--well
Title:  called the "Syren"--made a noble experimental cruise; and it was thus
Title:  that the great Japanese Whaling Ground first became generally known.
Title:  The Syren in this famous voyage was commanded by a Captain Coffin, a
Title:  Nantucketer.
Title:  
Title:  All honour to the Enderbies, therefore, whose house, I think, exists
Title:  to the present day; though doubtless the original Samuel must long
Title:  ago have slipped his cable for the great South Sea of the other
Title:  world.
Title:  
Title:  The ship named after him was worthy of the honour, being a very fast
Title:  sailer and a noble craft every way.  I boarded her once at midnight
Title:  somewhere off the Patagonian coast, and drank good flip down in the
Title:  forecastle.  It was a fine gam we had, and they were all
Title:  trumps--every soul on board.  A short life to them, and a jolly
Title:  death.  And that fine gam I had--long, very long after old Ahab
Title:  touched her planks with his ivory heel--it minds me of the noble,
Title:  solid, Saxon hospitality of that ship; and may my parson forget me,
Title:  and the devil remember me, if I ever lose sight of it.  Flip?  Did I
Title:  say we had flip?  Yes, and we flipped it at the rate of ten gallons
Title:  the hour; and when the squall came (for it's squally off there by
Title:  Patagonia), and all hands--visitors and all--were called to reef
Title:  topsails, we were so top-heavy that we had to swing each other aloft
Title:  in bowlines; and we ignorantly furled the skirts of our jackets into
Title:  the sails, so that we hung there, reefed fast in the howling gale, a
Title:  warning example to all drunken tars.  However, the masts did not go
Title:  overboard; and by and by we scrambled down, so sober, that we had to
Title:  pass the flip again, though the savage salt spray bursting down the
Title:  forecastle scuttle, rather too much diluted and pickled it to my
Title:  taste.
Title:  
Title:  The beef was fine--tough, but with body in it.  They said it was
Title:  bull-beef; others, that it was dromedary beef; but I do not know, for
Title:  certain, how that was.  They had dumplings too; small, but
Title:  substantial, symmetrically globular, and indestructible dumplings.  I
Title:  fancied that you could feel them, and roll them about in you after
Title:  they were swallowed.  If you stooped over too far forward, you risked
Title:  their pitching out of you like billiard-balls.  The bread--but that
Title:  couldn't be helped; besides, it was an anti-scorbutic; in short, the
Title:  bread contained the only fresh fare they had.  But the forecastle was
Title:  not very light, and it was very easy to step over into a dark corner
Title:  when you ate it.  But all in all, taking her from truck to helm,
Title:  considering the dimensions of the cook's boilers, including his own
Title:  live parchment boilers; fore and aft, I say, the Samuel Enderby was a
Title:  jolly ship; of good fare and plenty; fine flip and strong; crack
Title:  fellows all, and capital from boot heels to hat-band.
Title:  
Title:  But why was it, think ye, that the Samuel Enderby, and some other
Title:  English whalers I know of--not all though--were such famous,
Title:  hospitable ships; that passed round the beef, and the bread, and the
Title:  can, and the joke; and were not soon weary of eating, and drinking,
Title:  and laughing?  I will tell you.  The abounding good cheer of these
Title:  English whalers is matter for historical research.  Nor have I been
Title:  at all sparing of historical whale research, when it has seemed
Title:  needed.
Title:  
Title:  The English were preceded in the whale fishery by the Hollanders,
Title:  Zealanders, and Danes; from whom they derived many terms still extant
Title:  in the fishery; and what is yet more, their fat old fashions,
Title:  touching plenty to eat and drink.  For, as a general thing, the
Title:  English merchant-ship scrimps her crew; but not so the English
Title:  whaler.  Hence, in the English, this thing of whaling good cheer is
Title:  not normal and natural, but incidental and particular; and,
Title:  therefore, must have some special origin, which is here pointed out,
Title:  and will be still further elucidated.
Title:  
Title:  During my researches in the Leviathanic histories, I stumbled upon an
Title:  ancient Dutch volume, which, by the musty whaling smell of it, I knew
Title:  must be about whalers.  The title was, "Dan Coopman," wherefore I
Title:  concluded that this must be the invaluable memoirs of some Amsterdam
Title:  cooper in the fishery, as every whale ship must carry its cooper.  I
Title:  was reinforced in this opinion by seeing that it was the production
Title:  of one "Fitz Swackhammer."  But my friend Dr. Snodhead, a very
Title:  learned man, professor of Low Dutch and High German in the college of
Title:  Santa Claus and St. Pott's, to whom I handed the work for
Title:  translation, giving him a box of sperm candles for his trouble--this
Title:  same Dr. Snodhead, so soon as he spied the book, assured me that "Dan
Title:  Coopman" did not mean "The Cooper," but "The Merchant."  In short,
Title:  this ancient and learned Low Dutch book treated of the commerce of
Title:  Holland; and, among other subjects, contained a very interesting
Title:  account of its whale fishery.  And in this chapter it was, headed,
Title:  "Smeer," or "Fat," that I found a long detailed list of the outfits
Title:  for the larders and cellars of 180 sail of Dutch whalemen; from which
Title:  list, as translated by Dr. Snodhead, I transcribe the following:
Title:  
Title:  400,000 lbs. of beef.
Title:  60,000 lbs. Friesland pork.
Title:  150,000 lbs. of stock fish.
Title:  550,000 lbs. of biscuit.
Title:  72,000 lbs. of soft bread.
Title:  2,800 firkins of butter.
Title:  20,000 lbs. Texel & Leyden cheese.
Title:  144,000 lbs. cheese (probably an inferior article).
Title:  550 ankers of Geneva.
Title:  10,800 barrels of beer.
Title:  
Title:  Most statistical tables are parchingly dry in the reading; not so in
Title:  the present case, however, where the reader is flooded with whole
Title:  pipes, barrels, quarts, and gills of good gin and good cheer.
Title:  
Title:  At the time, I devoted three days to the studious digesting of all
Title:  this beer, beef, and bread, during which many profound thoughts were
Title:  incidentally suggested to me, capable of a transcendental and
Title:  Platonic application; and, furthermore, I compiled supplementary
Title:  tables of my own, touching the probable quantity of stock-fish, etc.,
Title:  consumed by every Low Dutch harpooneer in that ancient Greenland and
Title:  Spitzbergen whale fishery.  In the first place, the amount of butter,
Title:  and Texel and Leyden cheese consumed, seems amazing.  I impute it,
Title:  though, to their naturally unctuous natures, being rendered still
Title:  more unctuous by the nature of their vocation, and especially by
Title:  their pursuing their game in those frigid Polar Seas, on the very
Title:  coasts of that Esquimaux country where the convivial natives pledge
Title:  each other in bumpers of train oil.
Title:  
Title:  The quantity of beer, too, is very large, 10,800 barrels.  Now,
Title:  as those polar fisheries could only be prosecuted in the short summer
Title:  of that climate, so that the whole cruise of one of these Dutch
Title:  whalemen, including the short voyage to and from the Spitzbergen sea,
Title:  did not much exceed three months, say, and reckoning 30 men to each
Title:  of their fleet of 180 sail, we have 5,400 Low Dutch seamen in all;
Title:  therefore, I say, we have precisely two barrels of beer per man, for
Title:  a twelve weeks' allowance, exclusive of his fair proportion of that
Title:  550 ankers of gin.  Now, whether these gin and beer harpooneers, so
Title:  fuddled as one might fancy them to have been, were the right sort of
Title:  men to stand up in a boat's head, and take good aim at flying whales;
Title:  this would seem somewhat improbable.  Yet they did aim at them, and
Title:  hit them too.  But this was very far North, be it remembered, where
Title:  beer agrees well with the constitution; upon the Equator, in our
Title:  southern fishery, beer would be apt to make the harpooneer sleepy at
Title:  the mast-head and boozy in his boat; and grievous loss might ensue to
Title:  Nantucket and New Bedford.
Title:  
Title:  But no more; enough has been said to show that the old Dutch whalers
Title:  of two or three centuries ago were high livers; and that the English
Title:  whalers have not neglected so excellent an example.  For, say they,
Title:  when cruising in an empty ship, if you can get nothing better out of
Title:  the world, get a good dinner out of it, at least.  And this empties
Title:  the decanter.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 102
Title:  
Title:  A Bower in the Arsacides.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Hitherto, in descriptively treating of the Sperm Whale, I have
Title:  chiefly dwelt upon the marvels of his outer aspect; or separately and
Title:  in detail upon some few interior structural features.  But to a large
Title:  and thorough sweeping comprehension of him, it behooves me now to
Title:  unbutton him still further, and untagging the points of his hose,
Title:  unbuckling his garters, and casting loose the hooks and the eyes of
Title:  the joints of his innermost bones, set him before you in his
Title:  ultimatum; that is to say, in his unconditional skeleton.
Title:  
Title:  But how now, Ishmael?  How is it, that you, a mere oarsman in the
Title:  fishery, pretend to know aught about the subterranean parts of the
Title:  whale?  Did erudite Stubb, mounted upon your capstan, deliver
Title:  lectures on the anatomy of the Cetacea; and by help of the windlass,
Title:  hold up a specimen rib for exhibition?  Explain thyself, Ishmael.
Title:  Can you land a full-grown whale on your deck for examination, as a
Title:  cook dishes a roast-pig?  Surely not.  A veritable witness have you
Title:  hitherto been, Ishmael; but have a care how you seize the privilege
Title:  of Jonah alone; the privilege of discoursing upon the joists and
Title:  beams; the rafters, ridge-pole, sleepers, and under-pinnings, making
Title:  up the frame-work of leviathan; and belike of the tallow-vats,
Title:  dairy-rooms, butteries, and cheeseries in his bowels.
Title:  
Title:  I confess, that since Jonah, few whalemen have penetrated very far
Title:  beneath the skin of the adult whale; nevertheless, I have been
Title:  blessed with an opportunity to dissect him in miniature.  In a ship I
Title:  belonged to, a small cub Sperm Whale was once bodily hoisted to the
Title:  deck for his poke or bag, to make sheaths for the barbs of the
Title:  harpoons, and for the heads of the lances.  Think you I let that
Title:  chance go, without using my boat-hatchet and jack-knife, and breaking
Title:  the seal and reading all the contents of that young cub?
Title:  
Title:  And as for my exact knowledge of the bones of the leviathan in their
Title:  gigantic, full grown development, for that rare knowledge I am
Title:  indebted to my late royal friend Tranquo, king of Tranque, one of
Title:  the Arsacides.  For being at Tranque, years ago, when attached to the
Title:  trading-ship Dey of Algiers, I was invited to spend part of the
Title:  Arsacidean holidays with the lord of Tranque, at his retired palm
Title:  villa at Pupella; a sea-side glen not very far distant from what our
Title:  sailors called Bamboo-Town, his capital.
Title:  
Title:  Among many other fine qualities, my royal friend Tranquo, being
Title:  gifted with a devout love for all matters of barbaric vertu, had
Title:  brought together in Pupella whatever rare things the more ingenious
Title:  of his people could invent; chiefly carved woods of wonderful
Title:  devices, chiselled shells, inlaid spears, costly paddles, aromatic
Title:  canoes; and all these distributed among whatever natural wonders, the
Title:  wonder-freighted, tribute-rendering waves had cast upon his shores.
Title:  
Title:  Chief among these latter was a great Sperm Whale, which, after an
Title:  unusually long raging gale, had been found dead and stranded, with
Title:  his head against a cocoa-nut tree, whose plumage-like, tufted
Title:  droopings seemed his verdant jet.  When the vast body had at last
Title:  been stripped of its fathom-deep enfoldings, and the bones become
Title:  dust dry in the sun, then the skeleton was carefully transported up
Title:  the Pupella glen, where a grand temple of lordly palms now sheltered
Title:  it.
Title:  
Title:  The ribs were hung with trophies; the vertebrae were carved with
Title:  Arsacidean annals, in strange hieroglyphics; in the skull, the
Title:  priests kept up an unextinguished aromatic flame, so that the mystic
Title:  head again sent forth its vapoury spout; while, suspended from a
Title:  bough, the terrific lower jaw vibrated over all the devotees, like
Title:  the hair-hung sword that so affrighted Damocles.
Title:  
Title:  It was a wondrous sight.  The wood was green as mosses of the Icy
Title:  Glen; the trees stood high and haughty, feeling their living sap; the
Title:  industrious earth beneath was as a weaver's loom, with a gorgeous
Title:  carpet on it, whereof the ground-vine tendrils formed the warp and
Title:  woof, and the living flowers the figures.  All the trees, with all
Title:  their laden branches; all the shrubs, and ferns, and grasses; the
Title:  message-carrying air; all these unceasingly were active.  Through the
Title:  lacings of the leaves, the great sun seemed a flying shuttle weaving
Title:  the unwearied verdure.  Oh, busy weaver! unseen weaver!--pause!--one
Title:  word!--whither flows the fabric? what palace may it deck? wherefore
Title:  all these ceaseless toilings?  Speak, weaver!--stay thy hand!--but
Title:  one single word with thee!  Nay--the shuttle flies--the figures float
Title:  from forth the loom; the freshet-rushing carpet for ever slides
Title:  away.  The weaver-god, he weaves; and by that weaving is he deafened,
Title:  that he hears no mortal voice; and by that humming, we, too, who look
Title:  on the loom are deafened; and only when we escape it shall we hear
Title:  the thousand voices that speak through it.  For even so it is in all
Title:  material factories.  The spoken words that are inaudible among the
Title:  flying spindles; those same words are plainly heard without the
Title:  walls, bursting from the opened casements.  Thereby have villainies
Title:  been detected.  Ah, mortal! then, be heedful; for so, in all this din
Title:  of the great world's loom, thy subtlest thinkings may be overheard
Title:  afar.
Title:  
Title:  Now, amid the green, life-restless loom of that Arsacidean wood, the
Title:  great, white, worshipped skeleton lay lounging--a gigantic idler!
Title:  Yet, as the ever-woven verdant warp and woof intermixed and hummed
Title:  around him, the mighty idler seemed the cunning weaver; himself all
Title:  woven over with the vines; every month assuming greener, fresher
Title:  verdure; but himself a skeleton.  Life folded Death; Death trellised
Title:  Life; the grim god wived with youthful Life, and begat him
Title:  curly-headed glories.
Title:  
Title:  Now, when with royal Tranquo I visited this wondrous whale, and saw
Title:  the skull an altar, and the artificial smoke ascending from where the
Title:  real jet had issued, I marvelled that the king should regard a chapel
Title:  as an object of vertu.  He laughed.  But more I marvelled that the
Title:  priests should swear that smoky jet of his was genuine.  To and fro I
Title:  paced before this skeleton--brushed the vines aside--broke through
Title:  the ribs--and with a ball of Arsacidean twine, wandered, eddied long
Title:  amid its many winding, shaded colonnades and arbours.  But soon my
Title:  line was out; and following it back, I emerged from the opening where I
Title:  entered.  I saw no living thing within; naught was there but bones.
Title:  
Title:  Cutting me a green measuring-rod, I once more dived within the
Title:  skeleton.  From their arrow-slit in the skull, the priests perceived
Title:  me taking the altitude of the final rib, "How now!" they shouted;
Title:  "Dar'st thou measure this our god!  That's for us."  "Aye,
Title:  priests--well, how long do ye make him, then?"  But hereupon a fierce
Title:  contest rose among them, concerning feet and inches; they cracked
Title:  each other's sconces with their yard-sticks--the great skull
Title:  echoed--and seizing that lucky chance, I quickly concluded my own
Title:  admeasurements.
Title:  
Title:  These admeasurements I now propose to set before you.  But first, be
Title:  it recorded, that, in this matter, I am not free to utter any fancied
Title:  measurement I please.  Because there are skeleton authorities you
Title:  can refer to, to test my accuracy.  There is a Leviathanic Museum,
Title:  they tell me, in Hull, England, one of the whaling ports of that
Title:  country, where they have some fine specimens of fin-backs and other
Title:  whales.  Likewise, I have heard that in the museum of Manchester, in
Title:  New Hampshire, they have what the proprietors call "the only perfect
Title:  specimen of a Greenland or River Whale in the United States."
Title:  Moreover, at a place in Yorkshire, England, Burton Constable by name,
Title:  a certain Sir Clifford Constable has in his possession the skeleton
Title:  of a Sperm Whale, but of moderate size, by no means of the full-grown
Title:  magnitude of my friend King Tranquo's.
Title:  
Title:  In both cases, the stranded whales to which these two skeletons
Title:  belonged, were originally claimed by their proprietors upon similar
Title:  grounds.  King Tranquo seizing his because he wanted it; and Sir
Title:  Clifford, because he was lord of the seignories of those parts.  Sir
Title:  Clifford's whale has been articulated throughout; so that, like a
Title:  great chest of drawers, you can open and shut him, in all his bony
Title:  cavities--spread out his ribs like a gigantic fan--and swing all day
Title:  upon his lower jaw.  Locks are to be put upon some of his trap-doors
Title:  and shutters; and a footman will show round future visitors with a
Title:  bunch of keys at his side.  Sir Clifford thinks of charging twopence
Title:  for a peep at the whispering gallery in the spinal column; threepence
Title:  to hear the echo in the hollow of his cerebellum; and sixpence for
Title:  the unrivalled view from his forehead.
Title:  
Title:  The skeleton dimensions I shall now proceed to set down are copied
Title:  verbatim from my right arm, where I had them tattooed; as in my wild
Title:  wanderings at that period, there was no other secure way of
Title:  preserving such valuable statistics.  But as I was crowded for space,
Title:  and wished the other parts of my body to remain a blank page for a
Title:  poem I was then composing--at least, what untattooed parts might
Title:  remain--I did not trouble myself with the odd inches; nor, indeed,
Title:  should inches at all enter into a congenial admeasurement of the
Title:  whale.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 103
Title:  
Title:  Measurement of The Whale's Skeleton.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  In the first place, I wish to lay before you a particular, plain
Title:  statement, touching the living bulk of this leviathan, whose skeleton
Title:  we are briefly to exhibit.  Such a statement may prove useful here.
Title:  
Title:  According to a careful calculation I have made, and which I partly
Title:  base upon Captain Scoresby's estimate, of seventy tons for the
Title:  largest sized Greenland whale of sixty feet in length; according to
Title:  my careful calculation, I say, a Sperm Whale of the largest
Title:  magnitude, between eighty-five and ninety feet in length, and
Title:  something less than forty feet in its fullest circumference, such a
Title:  whale will weigh at least ninety tons; so that, reckoning thirteen
Title:  men to a ton, he would considerably outweigh the combined population
Title:  of a whole village of one thousand one hundred inhabitants.
Title:  
Title:  Think you not then that brains, like yoked cattle, should be put to
Title:  this leviathan, to make him at all budge to any landsman's
Title:  imagination?
Title:  
Title:  Having already in various ways put before you his skull, spout-hole,
Title:  jaw, teeth, tail, forehead, fins, and divers other parts, I shall now
Title:  simply point out what is most interesting in the general bulk of his
Title:  unobstructed bones.  But as the colossal skull embraces so very large
Title:  a proportion of the entire extent of the skeleton; as it is by far
Title:  the most complicated part; and as nothing is to be repeated
Title:  concerning it in this chapter, you must not fail to carry it in your
Title:  mind, or under your arm, as we proceed, otherwise you will not gain a
Title:  complete notion of the general structure we are about to view.
Title:  
Title:  In length, the Sperm Whale's skeleton at Tranque measured seventy-two
Title:  Feet; so that when fully invested and extended in life, he must have
Title:  been ninety feet long; for in the whale, the skeleton loses about one
Title:  fifth in length compared with the living body.  Of this seventy-two
Title:  feet, his skull and jaw comprised some twenty feet, leaving some
Title:  fifty feet of plain back-bone.  Attached to this back-bone, for
Title:  something less than a third of its length, was the mighty circular
Title:  basket of ribs which once enclosed his vitals.
Title:  
Title:  To me this vast ivory-ribbed chest, with the long, unrelieved spine,
Title:  extending far away from it in a straight line, not a little resembled
Title:  the hull of a great ship new-laid upon the stocks, when only some
Title:  twenty of her naked bow-ribs are inserted, and the keel is otherwise,
Title:  for the time, but a long, disconnected timber.
Title:  
Title:  The ribs were ten on a side.  The first, to begin from the neck, was
Title:  nearly six feet long; the second, third, and fourth were each
Title:  successively longer, till you came to the climax of the fifth, or one
Title:  of the middle ribs, which measured eight feet and some inches.  From
Title:  that part, the remaining ribs diminished, till the tenth and last
Title:  only spanned five feet and some inches.  In general thickness, they
Title:  all bore a seemly correspondence to their length.  The middle ribs
Title:  were the most arched.  In some of the Arsacides they are used for
Title:  beams whereon to lay footpath bridges over small streams.
Title:  
Title:  In considering these ribs, I could not but be struck anew with the
Title:  circumstance, so variously repeated in this book, that the skeleton
Title:  of the whale is by no means the mould of his invested form.  The
Title:  largest of the Tranque ribs, one of the middle ones, occupied that
Title:  part of the fish which, in life, is greatest in depth.  Now, the
Title:  greatest depth of the invested body of this particular whale must
Title:  have been at least sixteen feet; whereas, the corresponding rib
Title:  measured but little more than eight feet.  So that this rib only
Title:  conveyed half of the true notion of the living magnitude of that
Title:  part.  Besides, for some way, where I now saw but a naked spine, all
Title:  that had been once wrapped round with tons of added bulk in flesh,
Title:  muscle, blood, and bowels.  Still more, for the ample fins, I here
Title:  saw but a few disordered joints; and in place of the weighty and
Title:  majestic, but boneless flukes, an utter blank!
Title:  
Title:  How vain and foolish, then, thought I, for timid untravelled man to
Title:  try to comprehend aright this wondrous whale, by merely poring over
Title:  his dead attenuated skeleton, stretched in this peaceful wood.  No.
Title:  Only in the heart of quickest perils; only when within the eddyings
Title:  of his angry flukes; only on the profound unbounded sea, can the
Title:  fully invested whale be truly and livingly found out.
Title:  
Title:  But the spine.  For that, the best way we can consider it is, with a
Title:  crane, to pile its bones high up on end.  No speedy enterprise.  But
Title:  now it's done, it looks much like Pompey's Pillar.
Title:  
Title:  There are forty and odd vertebrae in all, which in the skeleton are
Title:  not locked together.  They mostly lie like the great knobbed blocks
Title:  on a Gothic spire, forming solid courses of heavy masonry.  The
Title:  largest, a middle one, is in width something less than three feet,
Title:  and in depth more than four.  The smallest, where the spine tapers
Title:  away into the tail, is only two inches in width, and looks something
Title:  like a white billiard-ball.  I was told that there were still smaller
Title:  ones, but they had been lost by some little cannibal urchins, the
Title:  priest's children, who had stolen them to play marbles with.  Thus we
Title:  see how that the spine of even the hugest of living things tapers off
Title:  at last into simple child's play.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 104
Title:  
Title:  The Fossil Whale.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  From his mighty bulk the whale affords a most congenial theme whereon
Title:  to enlarge, amplify, and generally expatiate.  Would you, you could
Title:  not compress him.  By good rights he should only be treated of in
Title:  imperial folio.  Not to tell over again his furlongs from spiracle to
Title:  tail, and the yards he measures about the waist; only think of the
Title:  gigantic involutions of his intestines, where they lie in him like
Title:  great cables and hawsers coiled away in the subterranean orlop-deck
Title:  of a line-of-battle-ship.
Title:  
Title:  Since I have undertaken to manhandle this Leviathan, it behooves me
Title:  to approve myself omnisciently exhaustive in the enterprise; not
Title:  overlooking the minutest seminal germs of his blood, and spinning him
Title:  out to the uttermost coil of his bowels.  Having already described
Title:  him in most of his present habitatory and anatomical peculiarities,
Title:  it now remains to magnify him in an archaeological, fossiliferous,
Title:  and antediluvian point of view.  Applied to any other creature than
Title:  the Leviathan--to an ant or a flea--such portly terms might justly be
Title:  deemed unwarrantably grandiloquent.  But when Leviathan is the text,
Title:  the case is altered.  Fain am I to stagger to this emprise under
Title:  the weightiest words of the dictionary.  And here be it said, that
Title:  whenever it has been convenient to consult one in the course of these
Title:  dissertations, I have invariably used a huge quarto edition of
Title:  Johnson, expressly purchased for that purpose; because that famous
Title:  lexicographer's uncommon personal bulk more fitted him to compile a
Title:  lexicon to be used by a whale author like me.
Title:  
Title:  One often hears of writers that rise and swell with their subject,
Title:  though it may seem but an ordinary one.  How, then, with me, writing
Title:  of this Leviathan?  Unconsciously my chirography expands into placard
Title:  capitals.  Give me a condor's quill!  Give me Vesuvius' crater for an
Title:  inkstand!  Friends, hold my arms!  For in the mere act of penning my
Title:  thoughts of this Leviathan, they weary me, and make me faint with
Title:  their outreaching comprehensiveness of sweep, as if to include the
Title:  whole circle of the sciences, and all the generations of whales, and
Title:  men, and mastodons, past, present, and to come, with all the
Title:  revolving panoramas of empire on earth, and throughout the whole
Title:  universe, not excluding its suburbs.  Such, and so magnifying, is the
Title:  virtue of a large and liberal theme!  We expand to its bulk.  To
Title:  produce a mighty book, you must choose a mighty theme.  No great and
Title:  enduring volume can ever be written on the flea, though many there be
Title:  who have tried it.
Title:  
Title:  Ere entering upon the subject of Fossil Whales, I present my
Title:  credentials as a geologist, by stating that in my miscellaneous time
Title:  I have been a stone-mason, and also a great digger of ditches,
Title:  canals and wells, wine-vaults, cellars, and cisterns of all sorts.
Title:  Likewise, by way of preliminary, I desire to remind the reader, that
Title:  while in the earlier geological strata there are found the fossils of
Title:  monsters now almost completely extinct; the subsequent relics
Title:  discovered in what are called the Tertiary formations seem the
Title:  connecting, or at any rate intercepted links, between the
Title:  antichronical creatures, and those whose remote posterity are said to
Title:  have entered the Ark; all the Fossil Whales hitherto discovered
Title:  belong to the Tertiary period, which is the last preceding the
Title:  superficial formations.  And though none of them precisely answer to
Title:  any known species of the present time, they are yet sufficiently akin
Title:  to them in general respects, to justify their taking rank as
Title:  Cetacean fossils.
Title:  
Title:  Detached broken fossils of pre-adamite whales, fragments of their
Title:  bones and skeletons, have within thirty years past, at various
Title:  intervals, been found at the base of the Alps, in Lombardy, in
Title:  France, in England, in Scotland, and in the States of Louisiana,
Title:  Mississippi, and Alabama.  Among the more curious of such remains is
Title:  part of a skull, which in the year 1779 was disinterred in the Rue
Title:  Dauphine in Paris, a short street opening almost directly upon the
Title:  palace of the Tuileries; and bones disinterred in excavating the
Title:  great docks of Antwerp, in Napoleon's time.  Cuvier pronounced these
Title:  fragments to have belonged to some utterly unknown Leviathanic
Title:  species.
Title:  
Title:  But by far the most wonderful of all Cetacean relics was the almost
Title:  complete vast skeleton of an extinct monster, found in the year 1842,
Title:  on the plantation of Judge Creagh, in Alabama.  The awe-stricken
Title:  credulous slaves in the vicinity took it for the bones of one of the
Title:  fallen angels.  The Alabama doctors declared it a huge reptile, and
Title:  bestowed upon it the name of Basilosaurus.  But some specimen bones
Title:  of it being taken across the sea to Owen, the English Anatomist, it
Title:  turned out that this alleged reptile was a whale, though of a
Title:  departed species.  A significant illustration of the fact, again and
Title:  again repeated in this book, that the skeleton of the whale furnishes
Title:  but little clue to the shape of his fully invested body.  So Owen
Title:  rechristened the monster Zeuglodon; and in his paper read before the
Title:  London Geological Society, pronounced it, in substance, one of the
Title:  most extraordinary creatures which the mutations of the globe have
Title:  blotted out of existence.
Title:  
Title:  When I stand among these mighty Leviathan skeletons, skulls, tusks,
Title:  jaws, ribs, and vertebrae, all characterized by partial resemblances
Title:  to the existing breeds of sea-monsters; but at the same time bearing
Title:  on the other hand similar affinities to the annihilated antichronical
Title:  Leviathans, their incalculable seniors; I am, by a flood, borne back
Title:  to that wondrous period, ere time itself can be said to have begun;
Title:  for time began with man.  Here Saturn's grey chaos rolls over me, and
Title:  I obtain dim, shuddering glimpses into those Polar eternities; when
Title:  wedged bastions of ice pressed hard upon what are now the Tropics;
Title:  and in all the 25,000 miles of this world's circumference, not an
Title:  inhabitable hand's breadth of land was visible.  Then the whole world
Title:  was the whale's; and, king of creation, he left his wake along the
Title:  present lines of the Andes and the Himmalehs.  Who can show a
Title:  pedigree like Leviathan?  Ahab's harpoon had shed older blood than
Title:  the Pharaoh's.  Methuselah seems a school-boy.  I look round to shake
Title:  hands with Shem.  I am horror-struck at this antemosaic, unsourced
Title:  existence of the unspeakable terrors of the whale, which, having been
Title:  before all time, must needs exist after all humane ages are over.
Title:  
Title:  But not alone has this Leviathan left his pre-adamite traces in the
Title:  stereotype plates of nature, and in limestone and marl bequeathed his
Title:  ancient bust; but upon Egyptian tablets, whose antiquity seems to
Title:  claim for them an almost fossiliferous character, we find the
Title:  unmistakable print of his fin.  In an apartment of the great temple
Title:  of Denderah, some fifty years ago, there was discovered upon the
Title:  granite ceiling a sculptured and painted planisphere, abounding in
Title:  centaurs, griffins, and dolphins, similar to the grotesque figures
Title:  on the celestial globe of the moderns.  Gliding among them, old
Title:  Leviathan swam as of yore; was there swimming in that planisphere,
Title:  centuries before Solomon was cradled.
Title:  
Title:  Nor must there be omitted another strange attestation of the
Title:  antiquity of the whale, in his own osseous post-diluvian reality, as
Title:  set down by the venerable John Leo, the old Barbary traveller.
Title:  
Title:  "Not far from the Sea-side, they have a Temple, the Rafters and Beams
Title:  of which are made of Whale-Bones; for Whales of a monstrous size are
Title:  oftentimes cast up dead upon that shore.  The Common People imagine,
Title:  that by a secret Power bestowed by God upon the temple, no Whale can
Title:  pass it without immediate death.  But the truth of the Matter is,
Title:  that on either side of the Temple, there are Rocks that shoot two
Title:  Miles into the Sea, and wound the Whales when they light upon 'em.
Title:  They keep a Whale's Rib of an incredible length for a Miracle, which
Title:  lying upon the Ground with its convex part uppermost, makes an Arch,
Title:  the Head of which cannot be reached by a Man upon a Camel's Back.
Title:  This Rib (says John Leo) is said to have layn there a hundred Years
Title:  before I saw it.  Their Historians affirm, that a Prophet who
Title:  prophesy'd of Mahomet, came from this Temple, and some do not stand
Title:  to assert, that the Prophet Jonas was cast forth by the Whale at the
Title:  Base of the Temple."
Title:  
Title:  In this Afric Temple of the Whale I leave you, reader, and if you be
Title:  a Nantucketer, and a whaleman, you will silently worship there.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 105
Title:  
Title:  Does the Whale's Magnitude Diminish?--Will He Perish?
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Inasmuch, then, as this Leviathan comes floundering down upon us from
Title:  the head-waters of the Eternities, it may be fitly inquired, whether,
Title:  in the long course of his generations, he has not degenerated from
Title:  the original bulk of his sires.
Title:  
Title:  But upon investigation we find, that not only are the whales of the
Title:  present day superior in magnitude to those whose fossil remains are
Title:  found in the Tertiary system (embracing a distinct geological period
Title:  prior to man), but of the whales found in that Tertiary system, those
Title:  belonging to its latter formations exceed in size those of its
Title:  earlier ones.
Title:  
Title:  Of all the pre-adamite whales yet exhumed, by far the largest is the
Title:  Alabama one mentioned in the last chapter, and that was less than
Title:  seventy feet in length in the skeleton.  Whereas, we have already
Title:  seen, that the tape-measure gives seventy-two feet for the skeleton
Title:  of a large sized modern whale.  And I have heard, on whalemen's
Title:  authority, that Sperm Whales have been captured near a hundred feet
Title:  long at the time of capture.
Title:  
Title:  But may it not be, that while the whales of the present hour are an
Title:  advance in magnitude upon those of all previous geological periods;
Title:  may it not be, that since Adam's time they have degenerated?
Title:  
Title:  Assuredly, we must conclude so, if we are to credit the accounts of
Title:  such gentlemen as Pliny, and the ancient naturalists generally.  For
Title:  Pliny tells us of Whales that embraced acres of living bulk, and
Title:  Aldrovandus of others which measured eight hundred feet in
Title:  length--Rope Walks and Thames Tunnels of Whales!  And even in the
Title:  days of Banks and Solander, Cooke's naturalists, we find a Danish
Title:  member of the Academy of Sciences setting down certain Iceland Whales
Title:  (reydan-siskur, or Wrinkled Bellies) at one hundred and twenty yards;
Title:  that is, three hundred and sixty feet.  And Lacepede, the French
Title:  naturalist, in his elaborate history of whales, in the very beginning
Title:  of his work (page 3), sets down the Right Whale at one hundred
Title:  metres, three hundred and twenty-eight feet.  And this work was
Title:  published so late as A.D. 1825.
Title:  
Title:  But will any whaleman believe these stories?  No.  The whale of
Title:  to-day is as big as his ancestors in Pliny's time.  And if ever I go
Title:  where Pliny is, I, a whaleman (more than he was), will make bold to
Title:  tell him so.  Because I cannot understand how it is, that while the
Title:  Egyptian mummies that were buried thousands of years before even
Title:  Pliny was born, do not measure so much in their coffins as a modern
Title:  Kentuckian in his socks; and while the cattle and other animals
Title:  sculptured on the oldest Egyptian and Nineveh tablets, by the
Title:  relative proportions in which they are drawn, just as plainly prove
Title:  that the high-bred, stall-fed, prize cattle of Smithfield, not only
Title:  equal, but far exceed in magnitude the fattest of Pharaoh's fat kine;
Title:  in the face of all this, I will not admit that of all animals the
Title:  whale alone should have degenerated.
Title:  
Title:  But still another inquiry remains; one often agitated by the more
Title:  recondite Nantucketers.  Whether owing to the almost omniscient
Title:  look-outs at the mast-heads of the whaleships, now penetrating even
Title:  through Behring's straits, and into the remotest secret drawers and
Title:  lockers of the world; and the thousand harpoons and lances darted
Title:  along all continental coasts; the moot point is, whether Leviathan
Title:  can long endure so wide a chase, and so remorseless a havoc; whether
Title:  he must not at last be exterminated from the waters, and the last
Title:  whale, like the last man, smoke his last pipe, and then himself
Title:  evaporate in the final puff.
Title:  
Title:  Comparing the humped herds of whales with the humped herds of
Title:  buffalo, which, not forty years ago, overspread by tens of thousands
Title:  the prairies of Illinois and Missouri, and shook their iron manes and
Title:  scowled with their thunder-clotted brows upon the sites of populous
Title:  river-capitals, where now the polite broker sells you land at a
Title:  dollar an inch; in such a comparison an irresistible argument would
Title:  seem furnished, to show that the hunted whale cannot now escape
Title:  speedy extinction.
Title:  
Title:  But you must look at this matter in every light.  Though so short a
Title:  period ago--not a good lifetime--the census of the buffalo in
Title:  Illinois exceeded the census of men now in London, and though at the
Title:  present day not one horn or hoof of them remains in all that region;
Title:  and though the cause of this wondrous extermination was the spear of
Title:  man; yet the far different nature of the whale-hunt peremptorily
Title:  forbids so inglorious an end to the Leviathan.  Forty men in one ship
Title:  hunting the Sperm Whales for forty-eight months think they have done
Title:  extremely well, and thank God, if at last they carry home the oil of
Title:  forty fish.  Whereas, in the days of the old Canadian and Indian
Title:  hunters and trappers of the West, when the far west (in whose sunset
Title:  suns still rise) was a wilderness and a virgin, the same number of
Title:  moccasined men, for the same number of months, mounted on horse
Title:  instead of sailing in ships, would have slain not forty, but forty
Title:  thousand and more buffaloes; a fact that, if need were, could be
Title:  statistically stated.
Title:  
Title:  Nor, considered aright, does it seem any argument in favour of the
Title:  gradual extinction of the Sperm Whale, for example, that in former
Title:  years (the latter part of the last century, say) these Leviathans, in
Title:  small pods, were encountered much oftener than at present, and, in
Title:  consequence, the voyages were not so prolonged, and were also much
Title:  more remunerative.  Because, as has been elsewhere noticed, those
Title:  whales, influenced by some views to safety, now swim the seas in
Title:  immense caravans, so that to a large degree the scattered solitaries,
Title:  yokes, and pods, and schools of other days are now aggregated into
Title:  vast but widely separated, unfrequent armies.  That is all.  And
Title:  equally fallacious seems the conceit, that because the so-called
Title:  whale-bone whales no longer haunt many grounds in former years
Title:  abounding with them, hence that species also is declining.  For they
Title:  are only being driven from promontory to cape; and if one coast is no
Title:  longer enlivened with their jets, then, be sure, some other and
Title:  remoter strand has been very recently startled by the unfamiliar
Title:  spectacle.
Title:  
Title:  Furthermore: concerning these last mentioned Leviathans, they have
Title:  two firm fortresses, which, in all human probability, will for ever
Title:  remain impregnable.  And as upon the invasion of their valleys, the
Title:  frosty Swiss have retreated to their mountains; so, hunted from the
Title:  savannas and glades of the middle seas, the whale-bone whales can at
Title:  last resort to their Polar citadels, and diving under the ultimate
Title:  glassy barriers and walls there, come up among icy fields and floes;
Title:  and in a charmed circle of everlasting December, bid defiance to all
Title:  pursuit from man.
Title:  
Title:  But as perhaps fifty of these whale-bone whales are harpooned for one
Title:  cachalot, some philosophers of the forecastle have concluded that
Title:  this positive havoc has already very seriously diminished their
Title:  battalions.  But though for some time past a number of these whales,
Title:  not less than 13,000, have been annually slain on the nor'-west
Title:  coast by the Americans alone; yet there are considerations which
Title:  render even this circumstance of little or no account as an opposing
Title:  argument in this matter.
Title:  
Title:  Natural as it is to be somewhat incredulous concerning the
Title:  populousness of the more enormous creatures of the globe, yet what
Title:  shall we say to Harto, the historian of Goa, when he tells us that at
Title:  one hunting the King of Siam took 4,000 elephants; that in those
Title:  regions elephants are numerous as droves of cattle in the temperate
Title:  climes.  And there seems no reason to doubt that if these elephants,
Title:  which have now been hunted for thousands of years, by Semiramis, by
Title:  Porus, by Hannibal, and by all the successive monarchs of the
Title:  East--if they still survive there in great numbers, much more may the
Title:  great whale outlast all hunting, since he has a pasture to expatiate
Title:  in, which is precisely twice as large as all Asia, both Americas,
Title:  Europe and Africa, New Holland, and all the Isles of the sea
Title:  combined.
Title:  
Title:  Moreover: we are to consider, that from the presumed great longevity
Title:  of whales, their probably attaining the age of a century and more,
Title:  therefore at any one period of time, several distinct adult
Title:  generations must be contemporary.  And what that is, we may soon
Title:  gain some idea of, by imagining all the grave-yards, cemeteries, and
Title:  family vaults of creation yielding up the live bodies of all the men,
Title:  women, and children who were alive seventy-five years ago; and adding
Title:  this countless host to the present human population of the globe.
Title:  
Title:  Wherefore, for all these things, we account the whale immortal in his
