Title:  species, however perishable in his individuality.  He swam the seas
Title:  before the continents broke water; he once swam over the site of the
Title:  Tuileries, and Windsor Castle, and the Kremlin.  In Noah's flood he
Title:  despised Noah's Ark; and if ever the world is to be again flooded,
Title:  like the Netherlands, to kill off its rats, then the eternal whale
Title:  will still survive, and rearing upon the topmost crest of the
Title:  equatorial flood, spout his frothed defiance to the skies.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 106
Title:  
Title:  Ahab's Leg.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  The precipitating manner in which Captain Ahab had quitted the Samuel
Title:  Enderby of London, had not been unattended with some small violence
Title:  to his own person.  He had lighted with such energy upon a thwart of
Title:  his boat that his ivory leg had received a half-splintering shock.
Title:  And when after gaining his own deck, and his own pivot-hole there, he
Title:  so vehemently wheeled round with an urgent command to the steersman
Title:  (it was, as ever, something about his not steering inflexibly
Title:  enough); then, the already shaken ivory received such an additional
Title:  twist and wrench, that though it still remained entire, and to all
Title:  appearances lusty, yet Ahab did not deem it entirely trustworthy.
Title:  
Title:  And, indeed, it seemed small matter for wonder, that for all his
Title:  pervading, mad recklessness, Ahab did at times give careful heed to
Title:  the condition of that dead bone upon which he partly stood.  For it
Title:  had not been very long prior to the Pequod's sailing from Nantucket,
Title:  that he had been found one night lying prone upon the ground, and
Title:  insensible; by some unknown, and seemingly inexplicable, unimaginable
Title:  casualty, his ivory limb having been so violently displaced, that it
Title:  had stake-wise smitten, and all but pierced his groin; nor was it
Title:  without extreme difficulty that the agonizing wound was entirely
Title:  cured.
Title:  
Title:  Nor, at the time, had it failed to enter his monomaniac mind, that
Title:  all the anguish of that then present suffering was but the direct
Title:  issue of a former woe; and he too plainly seemed to see, that as the
Title:  most poisonous reptile of the marsh perpetuates his kind as
Title:  inevitably as the sweetest songster of the grove; so, equally with
Title:  every felicity, all miserable events do naturally beget their like.
Title:  Yea, more than equally, thought Ahab; since both the ancestry and
Title:  posterity of Grief go further than the ancestry and posterity of Joy.
Title:  For, not to hint of this: that it is an inference from certain
Title:  canonic teachings, that while some natural enjoyments here shall have
Title:  no children born to them for the other world, but, on the contrary,
Title:  shall be followed by the joy-childlessness of all hell's despair;
Title:  whereas, some guilty mortal miseries shall still fertilely beget to
Title:  themselves an eternally progressive progeny of griefs beyond the
Title:  grave; not at all to hint of this, there still seems an inequality in
Title:  the deeper analysis of the thing.  For, thought Ahab, while even the
Title:  highest earthly felicities ever have a certain unsignifying pettiness
Title:  lurking in them, but, at bottom, all heartwoes, a mystic
Title:  significance, and, in some men, an archangelic grandeur; so do their
Title:  diligent tracings-out not belie the obvious deduction.  To trail the
Title:  genealogies of these high mortal miseries, carries us at last among
Title:  the sourceless primogenitures of the gods; so that, in the face of
Title:  all the glad, hay-making suns, and soft cymballing, round
Title:  harvest-moons, we must needs give in to this: that the gods
Title:  themselves are not for ever glad.  The ineffaceable, sad birth-mark
Title:  in the brow of man, is but the stamp of sorrow in the signers.
Title:  
Title:  Unwittingly here a secret has been divulged, which perhaps might more
Title:  properly, in set way, have been disclosed before.  With many other
Title:  particulars concerning Ahab, always had it remained a mystery to
Title:  some, why it was, that for a certain period, both before and after
Title:  the sailing of the Pequod, he had hidden himself away with such
Title:  Grand-Lama-like exclusiveness; and, for that one interval, sought
Title:  speechless refuge, as it were, among the marble senate of the dead.
Title:  Captain Peleg's bruited reason for this thing appeared by no means
Title:  adequate; though, indeed, as touching all Ahab's deeper part, every
Title:  revelation partook more of significant darkness than of explanatory
Title:  light.  But, in the end, it all came out; this one matter did, at
Title:  least.  That direful mishap was at the bottom of his temporary
Title:  recluseness.  And not only this, but to that ever-contracting,
Title:  dropping circle ashore, who, for any reason, possessed the privilege
Title:  of a less banned approach to him; to that timid circle the above
Title:  hinted casualty--remaining, as it did, moodily unaccounted for by
Title:  Ahab--invested itself with terrors, not entirely underived from the
Title:  land of spirits and of wails.  So that, through their zeal for him,
Title:  they had all conspired, so far as in them lay, to muffle up the
Title:  knowledge of this thing from others; and hence it was, that not till
Title:  a considerable interval had elapsed, did it transpire upon the
Title:  Pequod's decks.
Title:  
Title:  But be all this as it may; let the unseen, ambiguous synod in the
Title:  air, or the vindictive princes and potentates of fire, have to do or
Title:  not with earthly Ahab, yet, in this present matter of his leg, he
Title:  took plain practical procedures;--he called the carpenter.
Title:  
Title:  And when that functionary appeared before him, he bade him without
Title:  delay set about making a new leg, and directed the mates to see him
Title:  supplied with all the studs and joists of jaw-ivory (Sperm Whale)
Title:  which had thus far been accumulated on the voyage, in order that a
Title:  careful selection of the stoutest, clearest-grained stuff might be
Title:  secured.  This done, the carpenter received orders to have the leg
Title:  completed that night; and to provide all the fittings for it,
Title:  independent of those pertaining to the distrusted one in use.
Title:  Moreover, the ship's forge was ordered to be hoisted out of its
Title:  temporary idleness in the hold; and, to accelerate the affair, the
Title:  blacksmith was commanded to proceed at once to the forging of
Title:  whatever iron contrivances might be needed.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 107
Title:  
Title:  The Carpenter.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Seat thyself sultanically among the moons of Saturn, and take high
Title:  abstracted man alone; and he seems a wonder, a grandeur, and a woe.
Title:  But from the same point, take mankind in mass, and for the most part,
Title:  they seem a mob of unnecessary duplicates, both contemporary and
Title:  hereditary.  But most humble though he was, and far from furnishing
Title:  an example of the high, humane abstraction; the Pequod's carpenter
Title:  was no duplicate; hence, he now comes in person on this stage.
Title:  
Title:  Like all sea-going ship carpenters, and more especially those
Title:  belonging to whaling vessels, he was, to a certain off-handed,
Title:  practical extent, alike experienced in numerous trades and callings
Title:  collateral to his own; the carpenter's pursuit being the ancient and
Title:  outbranching trunk of all those numerous handicrafts which more or
Title:  less have to do with wood as an auxiliary material.  But, besides the
Title:  application to him of the generic remark above, this carpenter of the
Title:  Pequod was singularly efficient in those thousand nameless mechanical
Title:  emergencies continually recurring in a large ship, upon a three or
Title:  four years' voyage, in uncivilized and far-distant seas.  For not to
Title:  speak of his readiness in ordinary duties:--repairing stove boats,
Title:  sprung spars, reforming the shape of clumsy-bladed oars, inserting
Title:  bull's eyes in the deck, or new tree-nails in the side planks, and
Title:  other miscellaneous matters more directly pertaining to his special
Title:  business; he was moreover unhesitatingly expert in all manner of
Title:  conflicting aptitudes, both useful and capricious.
Title:  
Title:  The one grand stage where he enacted all his various parts so
Title:  manifold, was his vice-bench; a long rude ponderous table furnished
Title:  with several vices, of different sizes, and both of iron and of wood.
Title:  At all times except when whales were alongside, this bench was
Title:  securely lashed athwartships against the rear of the Try-works.
Title:  
Title:  A belaying pin is found too large to be easily inserted into its
Title:  hole: the carpenter claps it into one of his ever-ready vices, and
Title:  straightway files it smaller.  A lost land-bird of strange plumage
Title:  strays on board, and is made a captive: out of clean shaved rods of
Title:  right-whale bone, and cross-beams of sperm whale ivory, the carpenter
Title:  makes a pagoda-looking cage for it.  An oarsman sprains his wrist:
Title:  the carpenter concocts a soothing lotion.  Stubb longed for
Title:  vermillion stars to be painted upon the blade of his every oar;
Title:  screwing each oar in his big vice of wood, the carpenter
Title:  symmetrically supplies the constellation.  A sailor takes a fancy to
Title:  wear shark-bone ear-rings: the carpenter drills his ears.  Another
Title:  has the toothache: the carpenter out pincers, and clapping one hand
Title:  upon his bench bids him be seated there; but the poor fellow
Title:  unmanageably winces under the unconcluded operation; whirling round
Title:  the handle of his wooden vice, the carpenter signs him to clap his
Title:  jaw in that, if he would have him draw the tooth.
Title:  
Title:  Thus, this carpenter was prepared at all points, and alike
Title:  indifferent and without respect in all.  Teeth he accounted bits of
Title:  ivory; heads he deemed but top-blocks; men themselves he lightly held
Title:  for capstans.  But while now upon so wide a field thus variously
Title:  accomplished and with such liveliness of expertness in him, too; all
Title:  this would seem to argue some uncommon vivacity of intelligence.  But
Title:  not precisely so.  For nothing was this man more remarkable, than for
Title:  a certain impersonal stolidity as it were; impersonal, I say; for it
Title:  so shaded off into the surrounding infinite of things, that it seemed
Title:  one with the general stolidity discernible in the whole visible
Title:  world; which while pauselessly active in uncounted modes, still
Title:  eternally holds its peace, and ignores you, though you dig
Title:  foundations for cathedrals.  Yet was this half-horrible stolidity in
Title:  him, involving, too, as it appeared, an all-ramifying
Title:  heartlessness;--yet was it oddly dashed at times, with an old,
Title:  crutch-like, antediluvian, wheezing humorousness, not unstreaked now
Title:  and then with a certain grizzled wittiness; such as might have served
Title:  to pass the time during the midnight watch on the bearded forecastle
Title:  of Noah's ark.  Was it that this old carpenter had been a life-long
Title:  wanderer, whose much rolling, to and fro, not only had gathered no
Title:  moss; but what is more, had rubbed off whatever small outward
Title:  clingings might have originally pertained to him?  He was a stript
Title:  abstract; an unfractioned integral; uncompromised as a new-born babe;
Title:  living without premeditated reference to this world or the next.  You
Title:  might almost say, that this strange uncompromisedness in him involved
Title:  a sort of unintelligence; for in his numerous trades, he did not seem
Title:  to work so much by reason or by instinct, or simply because he had
Title:  been tutored to it, or by any intermixture of all these, even or
Title:  uneven; but merely by a kind of deaf and dumb, spontaneous literal
Title:  process.  He was a pure manipulator; his brain, if he had ever had
Title:  one, must have early oozed along into the muscles of his fingers.  He
Title:  was like one of those unreasoning but still highly useful, MULTUM IN
Title:  PARVO, Sheffield contrivances, assuming the exterior--though a little
Title:  swelled--of a common pocket knife; but containing, not only blades of
Title:  various sizes, but also screw-drivers, cork-screws, tweezers, awls,
Title:  pens, rulers, nail-filers, countersinkers.  So, if his superiors
Title:  wanted to use the carpenter for a screw-driver, all they had to do
Title:  was to open that part of him, and the screw was fast: or if for
Title:  tweezers, take him up by the legs, and there they were.
Title:  
Title:  Yet, as previously hinted, this omnitooled, open-and-shut carpenter,
Title:  was, after all, no mere machine of an automaton.  If he did not have
Title:  a common soul in him, he had a subtle something that somehow
Title:  anomalously did its duty.  What that was, whether essence of
Title:  quicksilver, or a few drops of hartshorn, there is no telling.  But
Title:  there it was; and there it had abided for now some sixty years or
Title:  more.  And this it was, this same unaccountable, cunning
Title:  life-principle in him; this it was, that kept him a great part of the
Title:  time soliloquizing; but only like an unreasoning wheel, which also
Title:  hummingly soliloquizes; or rather, his body was a sentry-box and this
Title:  soliloquizer on guard there, and talking all the time to keep himself
Title:  awake.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 108
Title:  
Title:  Ahab and the Carpenter.
Title:  
Title:  The Deck--First Night Watch.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  (CARPENTER STANDING BEFORE HIS VICE-BENCH, AND BY THE LIGHT OF TWO
Title:  LANTERNS BUSILY FILING THE IVORY JOIST FOR THE LEG, WHICH JOIST IS
Title:  FIRMLY FIXED IN THE VICE.  SLABS OF IVORY, LEATHER STRAPS, PADS,
Title:  SCREWS, AND VARIOUS TOOLS OF ALL SORTS LYING ABOUT THE BENCH.
Title:  FORWARD, THE RED FLAME OF THE FORGE IS SEEN, WHERE THE BLACKSMITH IS
Title:  AT WORK.)
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Drat the file, and drat the bone!  That is hard which should be soft,
Title:  and that is soft which should be hard.  So we go, who file old jaws
Title:  and shinbones.  Let's try another.  Aye, now, this works better
Title:  (SNEEZES).  Halloa, this bone dust is (SNEEZES)--why it's
Title:  (SNEEZES)--yes it's (SNEEZES)--bless my soul, it won't let me speak!
Title:  This is what an old fellow gets now for working in dead lumber.  Saw
Title:  a live tree, and you don't get this dust; amputate a live bone, and
Title:  you don't get it (SNEEZES).  Come, come, you old Smut, there, bear a
Title:  hand, and let's have that ferule and buckle-screw; I'll be ready
Title:  for them presently.  Lucky now (SNEEZES) there's no knee-joint to
Title:  make; that might puzzle a little; but a mere shinbone--why it's
Title:  easy as making hop-poles; only I should like to put a good finish on.
Title:  Time, time; if I but only had the time, I could turn him out as neat
Title:  a leg now as ever (SNEEZES) scraped to a lady in a parlor.  Those
Title:  buckskin legs and calves of legs I've seen in shop windows wouldn't
Title:  compare at all.  They soak water, they do; and of course get
Title:  rheumatic, and have to be doctored (SNEEZES) with washes and lotions,
Title:  just like live legs.  There; before I saw it off, now, I must call his
Title:  old Mogulship, and see whether the length will be all right; too
Title:  short, if anything, I guess.  Ha! that's the heel; we are in luck;
Title:  here he comes, or it's somebody else, that's certain.
Title:  
Title:  AHAB (ADVANCING)
Title:  
Title:  (DURING THE ENSUING SCENE, THE CARPENTER CONTINUES SNEEZING AT TIMES)
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Well, manmaker!
Title:  
Title:  Just in time, sir.  If the captain pleases, I will now mark the
Title:  length.  Let me measure, sir.
Title:  
Title:  Measured for a leg! good.  Well, it's not the first time.  About it!
Title:  There; keep thy finger on it.  This is a cogent vice thou hast here,
Title:  carpenter; let me feel its grip once.  So, so; it does pinch some.
Title:  
Title:  Oh, sir, it will break bones--beware, beware!
Title:  
Title:  No fear; I like a good grip; I like to feel something in this
Title:  slippery world that can hold, man.  What's Prometheus about
Title:  there?--the blacksmith, I mean--what's he about?
Title:  
Title:  He must be forging the buckle-screw, sir, now.
Title:  
Title:  Right.  It's a partnership; he supplies the muscle part.  He makes a
Title:  fierce red flame there!
Title:  
Title:  Aye, sir; he must have the white heat for this kind of fine work.
Title:  
Title:  Um-m.  So he must.  I do deem it now a most meaning thing, that that
Title:  old Greek, Prometheus, who made men, they say, should have been a
Title:  blacksmith, and animated them with fire; for what's made in fire must
Title:  properly belong to fire; and so hell's probable.  How the soot flies!
Title:  This must be the remainder the Greek made the Africans of.
Title:  Carpenter, when he's through with that buckle, tell him to forge a
Title:  pair of steel shoulder-blades; there's a pedlar aboard with a
Title:  crushing pack.
Title:  
Title:  Sir?
Title:  
Title:  Hold; while Prometheus is about it, I'll order a complete man after a
Title:  desirable pattern.  Imprimis, fifty feet high in his socks; then,
Title:  chest modelled after the Thames Tunnel; then, legs with roots to 'em,
Title:  to stay in one place; then, arms three feet through the wrist; no
Title:  heart at all, brass forehead, and about a quarter of an acre of fine
Title:  brains; and let me see--shall I order eyes to see outwards?  No, but
Title:  put a sky-light on top of his head to illuminate inwards.  There,
Title:  take the order, and away.
Title:  
Title:  Now, what's he speaking about, and who's he speaking to, I should
Title:  like to know?  Shall I keep standing here? (ASIDE).
Title:  
Title:  'Tis but indifferent architecture to make a blind dome; here's one.
Title:  No, no, no; I must have a lantern.
Title:  
Title:  Ho, ho!  That's it, hey?  Here are two, sir; one will serve my turn.
Title:  
Title:  What art thou thrusting that thief-catcher into my face for, man?
Title:  Thrusted light is worse than presented pistols.
Title:  
Title:  I thought, sir, that you spoke to carpenter.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Carpenter? why that's--but no;--a very tidy, and, I may say, an
Title:  extremely gentlemanlike sort of business thou art in here,
Title:  carpenter;--or would'st thou rather work in clay?
Title:  
Title:  Sir?--Clay? clay, sir?  That's mud; we leave clay to ditchers, sir.
Title:  
Title:  The fellow's impious!  What art thou sneezing about?
Title:  
Title:  Bone is rather dusty, sir.
Title:  
Title:  Take the hint, then; and when thou art dead, never bury thyself under
Title:  living people's noses.
Title:  
Title:  Sir?--oh! ah!--I guess so;--yes--dear!
Title:  
Title:  Look ye, carpenter, I dare say thou callest thyself a right good
Title:  workmanlike workman, eh?  Well, then, will it speak thoroughly well
Title:  for thy work, if, when I come to mount this leg thou makest, I shall
Title:  nevertheless feel another leg in the same identical place with it;
Title:  that is, carpenter, my old lost leg; the flesh and blood one, I mean.
Title:  Canst thou not drive that old Adam away?
Title:  
Title:  Truly, sir, I begin to understand somewhat now.  Yes, I have heard
Title:  something curious on that score, sir; how that a dismasted man never
Title:  entirely loses the feeling of his old spar, but it will be still
Title:  pricking him at times.  May I humbly ask if it be really so, sir?
Title:  
Title:  It is, man.  Look, put thy live leg here in the place where mine once
Title:  was; so, now, here is only one distinct leg to the eye, yet two to
Title:  the soul.  Where thou feelest tingling life; there, exactly there,
Title:  there to a hair, do I.  Is't a riddle?
Title:  
Title:  I should humbly call it a poser, sir.
Title:  
Title:  Hist, then.  How dost thou know that some entire, living, thinking
Title:  thing may not be invisibly and uninterpenetratingly standing
Title:  precisely where thou now standest; aye, and standing there in thy
Title:  spite?  In thy most solitary hours, then, dost thou not fear
Title:  eavesdroppers?  Hold, don't speak!  And if I still feel the smart of
Title:  my crushed leg, though it be now so long dissolved; then, why mayst
Title:  not thou, carpenter, feel the fiery pains of hell for ever, and
Title:  without a body?  Hah!
Title:  
Title:  Good Lord!  Truly, sir, if it comes to that, I must calculate over
Title:  again; I think I didn't carry a small figure, sir.
Title:  
Title:  Look ye, pudding-heads should never grant premises.--How long before
Title:  the leg is done?
Title:  
Title:  Perhaps an hour, sir.
Title:  
Title:  Bungle away at it then, and bring it to me (TURNS TO GO).  Oh, Life!
Title:  Here I am, proud as Greek god, and yet standing debtor to this
Title:  blockhead for a bone to stand on!  Cursed be that mortal
Title:  inter-indebtedness which will not do away with ledgers.  I would be
Title:  free as air; and I'm down in the whole world's books.  I am so rich,
Title:  I could have given bid for bid with the wealthiest Praetorians at the
Title:  auction of the Roman empire (which was the world's); and yet I owe
Title:  for the flesh in the tongue I brag with.  By heavens!  I'll get a
Title:  crucible, and into it, and dissolve myself down to one small,
Title:  compendious vertebra.  So.
Title:  
Title:  CARPENTER (RESUMING HIS WORK).
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Well, well, well!  Stubb knows him best of all, and Stubb always says
Title:  he's queer; says nothing but that one sufficient little word queer;
Title:  he's queer, says Stubb; he's queer--queer, queer; and keeps dinning
Title:  it into Mr. Starbuck all the time--queer--sir--queer, queer, very
Title:  queer.  And here's his leg!  Yes, now that I think of it, here's his
Title:  bedfellow! has a stick of whale's jaw-bone for a wife!  And this is
Title:  his leg; he'll stand on this.  What was that now about one leg
Title:  standing in three places, and all three places standing in one
Title:  hell--how was that?  Oh!  I don't wonder he looked so scornful at me!
Title:  I'm a sort of strange-thoughted sometimes, they say; but that's only
Title:  haphazard-like.  Then, a short, little old body like me, should never
Title:  undertake to wade out into deep waters with tall, heron-built
Title:  captains; the water chucks you under the chin pretty quick, and
Title:  there's a great cry for life-boats.  And here's the heron's leg! long
Title:  and slim, sure enough!  Now, for most folks one pair of legs lasts a
Title:  lifetime, and that must be because they use them mercifully, as a
Title:  tender-hearted old lady uses her roly-poly old coach-horses.  But
Title:  Ahab; oh he's a hard driver.  Look, driven one leg to death, and
Title:  spavined the other for life, and now wears out bone legs by the cord.
Title:  Halloa, there, you Smut! bear a hand there with those screws, and
Title:  let's finish it before the resurrection fellow comes a-calling with
Title:  his horn for all legs, true or false, as brewery-men go round
Title:  collecting old beer barrels, to fill 'em up again.  What a leg this
Title:  is!  It looks like a real live leg, filed down to nothing but the
Title:  core; he'll be standing on this to-morrow; he'll be taking altitudes
Title:  on it.  Halloa!  I almost forgot the little oval slate, smoothed
Title:  ivory, where he figures up the latitude.  So, so; chisel, file, and
Title:  sand-paper, now!
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 109
Title:  
Title:  Ahab and Starbuck in the Cabin.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  According to usage they were pumping the ship next morning; and lo!
Title:  no inconsiderable oil came up with the water; the casks below must
Title:  have sprung a bad leak.  Much concern was shown; and Starbuck went
Title:  down into the cabin to report this unfavourable affair.*
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *In Sperm-whalemen with any considerable quantity of oil on board, it
Title:  is a regular semiweekly duty to conduct a hose into the hold, and
Title:  drench the casks with sea-water; which afterwards, at varying
Title:  intervals, is removed by the ship's pumps.  Hereby the casks are
Title:  sought to be kept damply tight; while by the changed character of the
Title:  withdrawn water, the mariners readily detect any serious leakage in
Title:  the precious cargo.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Now, from the South and West the Pequod was drawing nigh to Formosa
Title:  and the Bashee Isles, between which lies one of the tropical outlets
Title:  from the China waters into the Pacific.  And so Starbuck found Ahab
Title:  with a general chart of the oriental archipelagoes spread before him;
Title:  and another separate one representing the long eastern coasts of the
Title:  Japanese islands--Niphon, Matsmai, and Sikoke.  With his snow-white
Title:  new ivory leg braced against the screwed leg of his table, and with a
Title:  long pruning-hook of a jack-knife in his hand, the wondrous old man,
Title:  with his back to the gangway door, was wrinkling his brow, and
Title:  tracing his old courses again.
Title:  
Title:  "Who's there?" hearing the footstep at the door, but not turning
Title:  round to it.  "On deck!  Begone!"
Title:  
Title:  "Captain Ahab mistakes; it is I.  The oil in the hold is leaking,
Title:  sir.  We must up Burtons and break out."
Title:  
Title:  "Up Burtons and break out?  Now that we are nearing Japan; heave-to
Title:  here for a week to tinker a parcel of old hoops?"
Title:  
Title:  "Either do that, sir, or waste in one day more oil than we may make
Title:  good in a year.  What we come twenty thousand miles to get is worth
Title:  saving, sir."
Title:  
Title:  "So it is, so it is; if we get it."
Title:  
Title:  "I was speaking of the oil in the hold, sir."
Title:  
Title:  "And I was not speaking or thinking of that at all.  Begone!  Let it
Title:  leak!  I'm all aleak myself.  Aye! leaks in leaks! not only full of
Title:  leaky casks, but those leaky casks are in a leaky ship; and that's a
Title:  far worse plight than the Pequod's, man.  Yet I don't stop to plug my
Title:  leak; for who can find it in the deep-loaded hull; or how hope to
Title:  plug it, even if found, in this life's howling gale?  Starbuck!
Title:  I'll not have the Burtons hoisted."
Title:  
Title:  "What will the owners say, sir?"
Title:  
Title:  "Let the owners stand on Nantucket beach and outyell the Typhoons.
Title:  What cares Ahab?  Owners, owners?  Thou art always prating to me,
Title:  Starbuck, about those miserly owners, as if the owners were my
Title:  conscience.  But look ye, the only real owner of anything is its
Title:  commander; and hark ye, my conscience is in this ship's keel.--On
Title:  deck!"
Title:  
Title:  "Captain Ahab," said the reddening mate, moving further into the
Title:  cabin, with a daring so strangely respectful and cautious that it
Title:  almost seemed not only every way seeking to avoid the slightest
Title:  outward manifestation of itself, but within also seemed more than
Title:  half distrustful of itself; "A better man than I might well pass over
Title:  in thee what he would quickly enough resent in a younger man; aye,
Title:  and in a happier, Captain Ahab."
Title:  
Title:  "Devils!  Dost thou then so much as dare to critically think of
Title:  me?--On deck!"
Title:  
Title:  "Nay, sir, not yet; I do entreat.  And I do dare, sir--to be
Title:  forbearing!  Shall we not understand each other better than hitherto,
Title:  Captain Ahab?"
Title:  
Title:  Ahab seized a loaded musket from the rack (forming part of most
Title:  South-Sea-men's cabin furniture), and pointing it towards Starbuck,
Title:  exclaimed: "There is one God that is Lord over the earth, and one
Title:  Captain that is lord over the Pequod.--On deck!"
Title:  
Title:  For an instant in the flashing eyes of the mate, and his fiery
Title:  cheeks, you would have almost thought that he had really received the
Title:  blaze of the levelled tube.  But, mastering his emotion, he half
Title:  calmly rose, and as he quitted the cabin, paused for an instant and
Title:  said: "Thou hast outraged, not insulted me, sir; but for that I ask
Title:  thee not to beware of Starbuck; thou wouldst but laugh; but let Ahab
Title:  beware of Ahab; beware of thyself, old man."
Title:  
Title:  "He waxes brave, but nevertheless obeys; most careful bravery that!"
Title:  murmured Ahab, as Starbuck disappeared.  "What's that he said--Ahab
Title:  beware of Ahab--there's something there!"  Then unconsciously using
Title:  the musket for a staff, with an iron brow he paced to and fro in the
Title:  little cabin; but presently the thick plaits of his forehead relaxed,
Title:  and returning the gun to the rack, he went to the deck.
Title:  
Title:  "Thou art but too good a fellow, Starbuck," he said lowly to the
Title:  mate; then raising his voice to the crew: "Furl the t'gallant-sails,
Title:  and close-reef the top-sails, fore and aft; back the main-yard; up
Title:  Burton, and break out in the main-hold."
Title:  
Title:  It were perhaps vain to surmise exactly why it was, that as
Title:  respecting Starbuck, Ahab thus acted.  It may have been a flash of
Title:  honesty in him; or mere prudential policy which, under the
Title:  circumstance, imperiously forbade the slightest symptom of open
Title:  disaffection, however transient, in the important chief officer of
Title:  his ship.  However it was, his orders were executed; and the Burtons
Title:  were hoisted.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 110
Title:  
Title:  Queequeg in His Coffin.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Upon searching, it was found that the casks last struck into the hold
Title:  were perfectly sound, and that the leak must be further off.  So, it
Title:  being calm weather, they broke out deeper and deeper, disturbing the
Title:  slumbers of the huge ground-tier butts; and from that black midnight
Title:  sending those gigantic moles into the daylight above.  So deep did
Title:  they go; and so ancient, and corroded, and weedy the aspect of the
Title:  lowermost puncheons, that you almost looked next for some mouldy
Title:  corner-stone cask containing coins of Captain Noah, with copies of
Title:  the posted placards, vainly warning the infatuated old world from the
Title:  flood.  Tierce after tierce, too, of water, and bread, and beef, and
Title:  shooks of staves, and iron bundles of hoops, were hoisted out, till
Title:  at last the piled decks were hard to get about; and the hollow hull
Title:  echoed under foot, as if you were treading over empty catacombs, and
Title:  reeled and rolled in the sea like an air-freighted demijohn.
Title:  Top-heavy was the ship as a dinnerless student with all Aristotle in
Title:  his head.  Well was it that the Typhoons did not visit them then.
Title:  
Title:  Now, at this time it was that my poor pagan companion, and fast
Title:  bosom-friend, Queequeg, was seized with a fever, which brought him
Title:  nigh to his endless end.
Title:  
Title:  Be it said, that in this vocation of whaling, sinecures are unknown;
Title:  dignity and danger go hand in hand; till you get to be Captain, the
Title:  higher you rise the harder you toil.  So with poor Queequeg, who, as
Title:  harpooneer, must not only face all the rage of the living whale,
Title:  but--as we have elsewhere seen--mount his dead back in a rolling sea;
Title:  and finally descend into the gloom of the hold, and bitterly sweating
Title:  all day in that subterraneous confinement, resolutely manhandle the
Title:  clumsiest casks and see to their stowage.  To be short, among
Title:  whalemen, the harpooneers are the holders, so called.
Title:  
Title:  Poor Queequeg! when the ship was about half disembowelled, you should
Title:  have stooped over the hatchway, and peered down upon him there;
Title:  where, stripped to his woollen drawers, the tattooed savage was
Title:  crawling about amid that dampness and slime, like a green spotted
Title:  lizard at the bottom of a well.  And a well, or an ice-house, it
Title:  somehow proved to him, poor pagan; where, strange to say, for all the
Title:  heat of his sweatings, he caught a terrible chill which lapsed into a
Title:  fever; and at last, after some days' suffering, laid him in his
Title:  hammock, close to the very sill of the door of death.  How he wasted
Title:  and wasted away in those few long-lingering days, till there seemed
Title:  but little left of him but his frame and tattooing.  But as all else
Title:  in him thinned, and his cheek-bones grew sharper, his eyes,
Title:  nevertheless, seemed growing fuller and fuller; they became of a
Title:  strange softness of lustre; and mildly but deeply looked out at you
Title:  there from his sickness, a wondrous testimony to that immortal health
Title:  in him which could not die, or be weakened.  And like circles on the
Title:  water, which, as they grow fainter, expand; so his eyes seemed
Title:  rounding and rounding, like the rings of Eternity.  An awe that
Title:  cannot be named would steal over you as you sat by the side of this
Title:  waning savage, and saw as strange things in his face, as any beheld
Title:  who were bystanders when Zoroaster died.  For whatever is truly
Title:  wondrous and fearful in man, never yet was put into words or books.
Title:  And the drawing near of Death, which alike levels all, alike
Title:  impresses all with a last revelation, which only an author from the
Title:  dead could adequately tell.  So that--let us say it again--no dying
Title:  Chaldee or Greek had higher and holier thoughts than those, whose
Title:  mysterious shades you saw creeping over the face of poor Queequeg, as
Title:  he quietly lay in his swaying hammock, and the rolling sea seemed
Title:  gently rocking him to his final rest, and the ocean's invisible
Title:  flood-tide lifted him higher and higher towards his destined heaven.
Title:  
Title:  Not a man of the crew but gave him up; and, as for Queequeg himself,
Title:  what he thought of his case was forcibly shown by a curious favour he
Title:  asked.  He called one to him in the grey morning watch, when the day
Title:  was just breaking, and taking his hand, said that while in Nantucket
Title:  he had chanced to see certain little canoes of dark wood, like the
Title:  rich war-wood of his native isle; and upon inquiry, he had learned
Title:  that all whalemen who died in Nantucket, were laid in those same dark
Title:  canoes, and that the fancy of being so laid had much pleased him; for
Title:  it was not unlike the custom of his own race, who, after embalming a
Title:  dead warrior, stretched him out in his canoe, and so left him to be
Title:  floated away to the starry archipelagoes; for not only do they
Title:  believe that the stars are isles, but that far beyond all visible
Title:  horizons, their own mild, uncontinented seas, interflow with the blue
Title:  heavens; and so form the white breakers of the milky way.  He added,
Title:  that he shuddered at the thought of being buried in his hammock,
Title:  according to the usual sea-custom, tossed like something vile to the
Title:  death-devouring sharks.  No: he desired a canoe like those of
Title:  Nantucket, all the more congenial to him, being a whaleman, that like
Title:  a whale-boat these coffin-canoes were without a keel; though that
Title:  involved but uncertain steering, and much lee-way adown the dim ages.
Title:  
Title:  Now, when this strange circumstance was made known aft, the carpenter
Title:  was at once commanded to do Queequeg's bidding, whatever it might
Title:  include.  There was some heathenish, coffin-coloured old lumber
Title:  aboard, which, upon a long previous voyage, had been cut from the
Title:  aboriginal groves of the Lackaday islands, and from these dark planks
Title:  the coffin was recommended to be made.  No sooner was the carpenter
Title:  apprised of the order, than taking his rule, he forthwith with all
Title:  the indifferent promptitude of his character, proceeded into the
Title:  forecastle and took Queequeg's measure with great accuracy, regularly
Title:  chalking Queequeg's person as he shifted the rule.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah! poor fellow! he'll have to die now," ejaculated the Long Island
Title:  sailor.
Title:  
Title:  Going to his vice-bench, the carpenter for convenience sake and
Title:  general reference, now transferringly measured on it the exact length
Title:  the coffin was to be, and then made the transfer permanent by cutting
Title:  two notches at its extremities.  This done, he marshalled the planks
Title:  and his tools, and to work.
Title:  
Title:  When the last nail was driven, and the lid duly planed and fitted, he
Title:  lightly shouldered the coffin and went forward with it, inquiring
Title:  whether they were ready for it yet in that direction.
Title:  
Title:  Overhearing the indignant but half-humorous cries with which the
Title:  people on deck began to drive the coffin away, Queequeg, to every
Title:  one's consternation, commanded that the thing should be instantly
Title:  brought to him, nor was there any denying him; seeing that, of all
Title:  mortals, some dying men are the most tyrannical; and certainly, since
Title:  they will shortly trouble us so little for evermore, the poor fellows
Title:  ought to be indulged.
Title:  
Title:  Leaning over in his hammock, Queequeg long regarded the coffin with
Title:  an attentive eye.  He then called for his harpoon, had the wooden
Title:  stock drawn from it, and then had the iron part placed in the coffin
Title:  along with one of the paddles of his boat.  All by his own request,
Title:  also, biscuits were then ranged round the sides within: a flask of
Title:  fresh water was placed at the head, and a small bag of woody earth
Title:  scraped up in the hold at the foot; and a piece of sail-cloth being
Title:  rolled up for a pillow, Queequeg now entreated to be lifted into his
Title:  final bed, that he might make trial of its comforts, if any it had.
Title:  He lay without moving a few minutes, then told one to go to his bag
Title:  and bring out his little god, Yojo.  Then crossing his arms on his
Title:  breast with Yojo between, he called for the coffin lid (hatch he
Title:  called it) to be placed over him.  The head part turned over with a
Title:  leather hinge, and there lay Queequeg in his coffin with little but
Title:  his composed countenance in view.  "Rarmai" (it will do; it is easy),
Title:  he murmured at last, and signed to be replaced in his hammock.
Title:  
Title:  But ere this was done, Pip, who had been slily hovering near by all
Title:  this while, drew nigh to him where he lay, and with soft sobbings,
Title:  took him by the hand; in the other, holding his tambourine.
Title:  
Title:  "Poor rover! will ye never have done with all this weary roving?
Title:  where go ye now?  But if the currents carry ye to those sweet
Title:  Antilles where the beaches are only beat with water-lilies, will ye
Title:  do one little errand for me?  Seek out one Pip, who's now been
Title:  missing long: I think he's in those far Antilles.  If ye find him,
Title:  then comfort him; for he must be very sad; for look! he's left his
Title:  tambourine behind;--I found it.  Rig-a-dig, dig, dig!  Now, Queequeg,
Title:  die; and I'll beat ye your dying march."
Title:  
Title:  "I have heard," murmured Starbuck, gazing down the scuttle, "that in
Title:  violent fevers, men, all ignorance, have talked in ancient tongues;
Title:  and that when the mystery is probed, it turns out always that in
Title:  their wholly forgotten childhood those ancient tongues had been
Title:  really spoken in their hearing by some lofty scholars.  So, to my
Title:  fond faith, poor Pip, in this strange sweetness of his lunacy, brings
Title:  heavenly vouchers of all our heavenly homes.  Where learned he that,
Title:  but there?--Hark! he speaks again: but more wildly now."
Title:  
Title:  "Form two and two!  Let's make a General of him!  Ho, where's his
Title:  harpoon?  Lay it across here.--Rig-a-dig, dig, dig! huzza!  Oh for a
Title:  game cock now to sit upon his head and crow!  Queequeg dies
Title:  game!--mind ye that; Queequeg dies game!--take ye good heed of that;
Title:  Queequeg dies game!  I say; game, game, game! but base little Pip, he
Title:  died a coward; died all a'shiver;--out upon Pip!  Hark ye; if ye find
Title:  Pip, tell all the Antilles he's a runaway; a coward, a coward, a
Title:  coward!  Tell them he jumped from a whale-boat!  I'd never beat my
Title:  tambourine over base Pip, and hail him General, if he were once more
Title:  dying here.  No, no! shame upon all cowards--shame upon them!  Let 'em
Title:  go drown like Pip, that jumped from a whale-boat.  Shame! shame!"
Title:  
Title:  During all this, Queequeg lay with closed eyes, as if in a dream.
Title:  Pip was led away, and the sick man was replaced in his hammock.
Title:  
Title:  But now that he had apparently made every preparation for death; now
Title:  that his coffin was proved a good fit, Queequeg suddenly rallied;
Title:  soon there seemed no need of the carpenter's box: and thereupon,
Title:  when some expressed their delighted surprise, he, in substance, said,
Title:  that the cause of his sudden convalescence was this;--at a critical
Title:  moment, he had just recalled a little duty ashore, which he was
Title:  leaving undone; and therefore had changed his mind about dying: he
Title:  could not die yet, he averred.  They asked him, then, whether to live
Title:  or die was a matter of his own sovereign will and pleasure.  He
Title:  answered, certainly.  In a word, it was Queequeg's conceit, that if a
Title:  man made up his mind to live, mere sickness could not kill him:
Title:  nothing but a whale, or a gale, or some violent, ungovernable,
Title:  unintelligent destroyer of that sort.
Title:  
Title:  Now, there is this noteworthy difference between savage and
Title:  civilized; that while a sick, civilized man may be six months
Title:  convalescing, generally speaking, a sick savage is almost half-well
Title:  again in a day.  So, in good time my Queequeg gained strength; and at
Title:  length after sitting on the windlass for a few indolent days (but
Title:  eating with a vigorous appetite) he suddenly leaped to his feet,
Title:  threw out his arms and legs, gave himself a good stretching, yawned
Title:  a little bit, and then springing into the head of his hoisted boat,
Title:  and poising a harpoon, pronounced himself fit for a fight.
Title:  
Title:  With a wild whimsiness, he now used his coffin for a sea-chest; and
Title:  emptying into it his canvas bag of clothes, set them in order there.
Title:  Many spare hours he spent, in carving the lid with all manner of
Title:  grotesque figures and drawings; and it seemed that hereby he was
Title:  striving, in his rude way, to copy parts of the twisted tattooing on
Title:  his body.  And this tattooing had been the work of a departed
Title:  prophet and seer of his island, who, by those hieroglyphic marks, had
Title:  written out on his body a complete theory of the heavens and the
Title:  earth, and a mystical treatise on the art of attaining truth; so that
Title:  Queequeg in his own proper person was a riddle to unfold; a wondrous
Title:  work in one volume; but whose mysteries not even himself could read,
Title:  though his own live heart beat against them; and these mysteries were
Title:  therefore destined in the end to moulder away with the living
Title:  parchment whereon they were inscribed, and so be unsolved to the
Title:  last.  And this thought it must have been which suggested to Ahab
Title:  that wild exclamation of his, when one morning turning away from
Title:  surveying poor Queequeg--"Oh, devilish tantalization of the gods!"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 111
Title:  
Title:  The Pacific.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  When gliding by the Bashee isles we emerged at last upon the great
Title:  South Sea; were it not for other things, I could have greeted my dear
Title:  Pacific with uncounted thanks, for now the long supplication of my
Title:  youth was answered; that serene ocean rolled eastwards from me a
Title:  thousand leagues of blue.
Title:  
Title:  There is, one knows not what sweet mystery about this sea, whose
Title:  gently awful stirrings seem to speak of some hidden soul beneath;
Title:  like those fabled undulations of the Ephesian sod over the buried
Title:  Evangelist St. John.  And meet it is, that over these sea-pastures,
Title:  wide-rolling watery prairies and Potters' Fields of all four
Title:  continents, the waves should rise and fall, and ebb and flow
Title:  unceasingly; for here, millions of mixed shades and shadows, drowned
Title:  dreams, somnambulisms, reveries; all that we call lives and souls,
Title:  lie dreaming, dreaming, still; tossing like slumberers in their beds;
Title:  the ever-rolling waves but made so by their restlessness.
Title:  
Title:  To any meditative Magian rover, this serene Pacific, once beheld,
Title:  must ever after be the sea of his adoption.  It rolls the midmost
Title:  waters of the world, the Indian ocean and Atlantic being but its
Title:  arms.  The same waves wash the moles of the new-built Californian
Title:  towns, but yesterday planted by the recentest race of men, and lave
Title:  the faded but still gorgeous skirts of Asiatic lands, older than
Title:  Abraham; while all between float milky-ways of coral isles, and
Title:  low-lying, endless, unknown Archipelagoes, and impenetrable Japans.
Title:  Thus this mysterious, divine Pacific zones the world's whole bulk
Title:  about; makes all coasts one bay to it; seems the tide-beating heart
Title:  of earth.  Lifted by those eternal swells, you needs must own the
Title:  seductive god, bowing your head to Pan.
Title:  
Title:  But few thoughts of Pan stirred Ahab's brain, as standing like an
Title:  iron statue at his accustomed place beside the mizen rigging, with
Title:  one nostril he unthinkingly snuffed the sugary musk from the Bashee
Title:  isles (in whose sweet woods mild lovers must be walking), and with
Title:  the other consciously inhaled the salt breath of the new found sea;
Title:  that sea in which the hated White Whale must even then be swimming.
Title:  Launched at length upon these almost final waters, and gliding
Title:  towards the Japanese cruising-ground, the old man's purpose
Title:  intensified itself.  His firm lips met like the lips of a vice; the
Title:  Delta of his forehead's veins swelled like overladen brooks; in his
Title:  very sleep, his ringing cry ran through the vaulted hull, "Stern all!
Title:  the White Whale spouts thick blood!"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 112
Title:  
Title:  The Blacksmith.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Availing himself of the mild, summer-cool weather that now reigned
Title:  in these latitudes, and in preparation for the peculiarly active
Title:  pursuits shortly to be anticipated, Perth, the begrimed, blistered
Title:  old blacksmith, had not removed his portable forge to the hold again,
Title:  after concluding his contributory work for Ahab's leg, but still
Title:  retained it on deck, fast lashed to ringbolts by the foremast; being
Title:  now almost incessantly invoked by the headsmen, and harpooneers, and
Title:  bowsmen to do some little job for them; altering, or repairing, or
Title:  new shaping their various weapons and boat furniture.  Often he would
Title:  be surrounded by an eager circle, all waiting to be served; holding
Title:  boat-spades, pike-heads, harpoons, and lances, and jealously watching
Title:  his every sooty movement, as he toiled.  Nevertheless, this old man's
Title:  was a patient hammer wielded by a patient arm.  No murmur, no
Title:  impatience, no petulance did come from him.  Silent, slow, and
Title:  solemn; bowing over still further his chronically broken back, he
Title:  toiled away, as if toil were life itself, and the heavy beating of
Title:  his hammer the heavy beating of his heart.  And so it was.--Most
Title:  miserable!
Title:  
Title:  A peculiar walk in this old man, a certain slight but painful
Title:  appearing yawing in his gait, had at an early period of the voyage
Title:  excited the curiosity of the mariners.  And to the importunity of
Title:  their persisted questionings he had finally given in; and so it came
Title:  to pass that every one now knew the shameful story of his wretched
Title:  fate.
Title:  
Title:  Belated, and not innocently, one bitter winter's midnight, on the
Title:  road running between two country towns, the blacksmith half-stupidly
Title:  felt the deadly numbness stealing over him, and sought refuge in a
Title:  leaning, dilapidated barn.  The issue was, the loss of the
Title:  extremities of both feet.  Out of this revelation, part by part, at
Title:  last came out the four acts of the gladness, and the one long, and as
Title:  yet uncatastrophied fifth act of the grief of his life's drama.
Title:  
Title:  He was an old man, who, at the age of nearly sixty, had postponedly
Title:  encountered that thing in sorrow's technicals called ruin.  He had
Title:  been an artisan of famed excellence, and with plenty to do; owned a
Title:  house and garden; embraced a youthful, daughter-like, loving wife,
Title:  and three blithe, ruddy children; every Sunday went to a
Title:  cheerful-looking church, planted in a grove.  But one night, under
Title:  cover of darkness, and further concealed in a most cunning
Title:  disguisement, a desperate burglar slid into his happy home, and
Title:  robbed them all of everything.  And darker yet to tell, the
Title:  blacksmith himself did ignorantly conduct this burglar into his
Title:  family's heart.  It was the Bottle Conjuror!  Upon the opening of
Title:  that fatal cork, forth flew the fiend, and shrivelled up his home.
Title:  Now, for prudent, most wise, and economic reasons, the blacksmith's
Title:  shop was in the basement of his dwelling, but with a separate
Title:  entrance to it; so that always had the young and loving healthy wife
Title:  listened with no unhappy nervousness, but with vigorous pleasure, to
Title:  the stout ringing of her young-armed old husband's hammer; whose
Title:  reverberations, muffled by passing through the floors and walls, came
Title:  up to her, not unsweetly, in her nursery; and so, to stout Labor's
Title:  iron lullaby, the blacksmith's infants were rocked to slumber.
Title:  
Title:  Oh, woe on woe!  Oh, Death, why canst thou not sometimes be timely?
Title:  Hadst thou taken this old blacksmith to thyself ere his full ruin
Title:  came upon him, then had the young widow had a delicious grief, and
Title:  her orphans a truly venerable, legendary sire to dream of in their
Title:  after years; and all of them a care-killing competency.  But Death
Title:  plucked down some virtuous elder brother, on whose whistling daily
Title:  toil solely hung the responsibilities of some other family, and left
Title:  the worse than useless old man standing, till the hideous rot of life
Title:  should make him easier to harvest.
Title:  
Title:  Why tell the whole?  The blows of the basement hammer every day grew
Title:  more and more between; and each blow every day grew fainter than the
Title:  last; the wife sat frozen at the window, with tearless eyes,
Title:  glitteringly gazing into the weeping faces of her children; the
Title:  bellows fell; the forge choked up with cinders; the house was sold;
Title:  the mother dived down into the long church-yard grass; her children
Title:  twice followed her thither; and the houseless, familyless old man
Title:  staggered off a vagabond in crape; his every woe unreverenced; his
Title:  grey head a scorn to flaxen curls!
Title:  
Title:  Death seems the only desirable sequel for a career like this; but
Title:  Death is only a launching into the region of the strange Untried; it
Title:  is but the first salutation to the possibilities of the immense
Title:  Remote, the Wild, the Watery, the Unshored; therefore, to the
Title:  death-longing eyes of such men, who still have left in them some
Title:  interior compunctions against suicide, does the all-contributed and
Title:  all-receptive ocean alluringly spread forth his whole plain of
Title:  unimaginable, taking terrors, and wonderful, new-life adventures; and
Title:  from the hearts of infinite Pacifics, the thousand mermaids sing to
Title:  them--"Come hither, broken-hearted; here is another life without the
Title:  guilt of intermediate death; here are wonders supernatural, without
Title:  dying for them.  Come hither! bury thyself in a life which, to your
Title:  now equally abhorred and abhorring, landed world, is more oblivious
Title:  than death.  Come hither! put up THY gravestone, too, within the
Title:  churchyard, and come hither, till we marry thee!"
Title:  
Title:  Hearkening to these voices, East and West, by early sunrise, and by
Title:  fall of eve, the blacksmith's soul responded, Aye, I come!  And so
Title:  Perth went a-whaling.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 113
Title:  
Title:  The Forge.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  With matted beard, and swathed in a bristling shark-skin apron, about
Title:  mid-day, Perth was standing between his forge and anvil, the latter
Title:  placed upon an iron-wood log, with one hand holding a pike-head in
Title:  the coals, and with the other at his forge's lungs, when Captain Ahab
Title:  came along, carrying in his hand a small rusty-looking leathern bag.
Title:  While yet a little distance from the forge, moody Ahab paused; till
Title:  at last, Perth, withdrawing his iron from the fire, began hammering
Title:  it upon the anvil--the red mass sending off the sparks in thick
Title:  hovering flights, some of which flew close to Ahab.
Title:  
Title:  "Are these thy Mother Carey's chickens, Perth? they are always flying
Title:  in thy wake; birds of good omen, too, but not to all;--look here,
Title:  they burn; but thou--thou liv'st among them without a scorch."
Title:  
Title:  "Because I am scorched all over, Captain Ahab," answered Perth,
Title:  resting for a moment on his hammer; "I am past scorching; not easily
Title:  can'st thou scorch a scar."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, well; no more.  Thy shrunk voice sounds too calmly, sanely
Title:  woeful to me.  In no Paradise myself, I am impatient of all misery in
Title:  others that is not mad.  Thou should'st go mad, blacksmith; say, why
Title:  dost thou not go mad?  How can'st thou endure without being mad?  Do
Title:  the heavens yet hate thee, that thou can'st not go mad?--What wert
Title:  thou making there?"
Title:  
Title:  "Welding an old pike-head, sir; there were seams and dents in it."
Title:  
Title:  "And can'st thou make it all smooth again, blacksmith, after such
Title:  hard usage as it had?"
Title:  
Title:  "I think so, sir."
Title:  
Title:  "And I suppose thou can'st smoothe almost any seams and dents; never
Title:  mind how hard the metal, blacksmith?"
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, sir, I think I can; all seams and dents but one."
Title:  
Title:  "Look ye here, then," cried Ahab, passionately advancing, and leaning
Title:  with both hands on Perth's shoulders; "look ye here--HERE--can ye
Title:  smoothe out a seam like this, blacksmith," sweeping one hand across
Title:  his ribbed brow; "if thou could'st, blacksmith, glad enough would I
Title:  lay my head upon thy anvil, and feel thy heaviest hammer between my
Title:  eyes.  Answer!  Can'st thou smoothe this seam?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh! that is the one, sir!  Said I not all seams and dents but one?"
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, blacksmith, it is the one; aye, man, it is unsmoothable; for
Title:  though thou only see'st it here in my flesh, it has worked down into
Title:  the bone of my skull--THAT is all wrinkles!  But, away with child's
Title:  play; no more gaffs and pikes to-day.  Look ye here!" jingling the
Title:  leathern bag, as if it were full of gold coins.  "I, too, want a
Title:  harpoon made; one that a thousand yoke of fiends could not part,
Title:  Perth; something that will stick in a whale like his own fin-bone.
Title:  There's the stuff," flinging the pouch upon the anvil.  "Look ye,
Title:  blacksmith, these are the gathered nail-stubbs of the steel shoes of
Title:  racing horses."
Title:  
Title:  "Horse-shoe stubbs, sir?  Why, Captain Ahab, thou hast here, then,
Title:  the best and stubbornest stuff we blacksmiths ever work."
Title:  
Title:  "I know it, old man; these stubbs will weld together like glue from
Title:  the melted bones of murderers.  Quick! forge me the harpoon.  And
Title:  forge me first, twelve rods for its shank; then wind, and twist, and
Title:  hammer these twelve together like the yarns and strands of a
Title:  tow-line.  Quick!  I'll blow the fire."
Title:  
Title:  When at last the twelve rods were made, Ahab tried them, one by one,
Title:  by spiralling them, with his own hand, round a long, heavy iron bolt.
Title:  "A flaw!" rejecting the last one.  "Work that over again, Perth."
Title:  
Title:  This done, Perth was about to begin welding the twelve into one, when
Title:  Ahab stayed his hand, and said he would weld his own iron.  As, then,
Title:  with regular, gasping hems, he hammered on the anvil, Perth passing
Title:  to him the glowing rods, one after the other, and the hard pressed
Title:  forge shooting up its intense straight flame, the Parsee passed
Title:  silently, and bowing over his head towards the fire, seemed invoking
Title:  some curse or some blessing on the toil.  But, as Ahab looked up, he
Title:  slid aside.
Title:  
Title:  "What's that bunch of lucifers dodging about there for?" muttered
Title:  Stubb, looking on from the forecastle.  "That Parsee smells fire like
Title:  a fusee; and smells of it himself, like a hot musket's powder-pan."
Title:  
Title:  At last the shank, in one complete rod, received its final heat; and
Title:  as Perth, to temper it, plunged it all hissing into the cask of water
Title:  near by, the scalding steam shot up into Ahab's bent face.
Title:  
Title:  "Would'st thou brand me, Perth?" wincing for a moment with the pain;
Title:  "have I been but forging my own branding-iron, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "Pray God, not that; yet I fear something, Captain Ahab.  Is not this
Title:  harpoon for the White Whale?"
Title:  
Title:  "For the white fiend!  But now for the barbs; thou must make them
Title:  thyself, man.  Here are my razors--the best of steel; here, and make
Title:  the barbs sharp as the needle-sleet of the Icy Sea."
Title:  
Title:  For a moment, the old blacksmith eyed the razors as though he would
Title:  fain not use them.
Title:  
Title:  "Take them, man, I have no need for them; for I now neither shave,
Title:  sup, nor pray till--but here--to work!"
Title:  
Title:  Fashioned at last into an arrowy shape, and welded by Perth to the
Title:  shank, the steel soon pointed the end of the iron; and as the
Title:  blacksmith was about giving the barbs their final heat, prior to
Title:  tempering them, he cried to Ahab to place the water-cask near.
Title:  
Title:  "No, no--no water for that; I want it of the true death-temper.
Title:  Ahoy, there!  Tashtego, Queequeg, Daggoo!  What say ye, pagans!  Will
Title:  ye give me as much blood as will cover this barb?" holding it high
Title:  up.  A cluster of dark nods replied, Yes.  Three punctures were made
Title:  in the heathen flesh, and the White Whale's barbs were then tempered.
Title:  
Title:  "Ego non baptizo te in nomine patris, sed in nomine diaboli!"
Title:  deliriously howled Ahab, as the malignant iron scorchingly devoured
Title:  the baptismal blood.
Title:  
Title:  Now, mustering the spare poles from below, and selecting one of
Title:  hickory, with the bark still investing it, Ahab fitted the end to the
Title:  socket of the iron.  A coil of new tow-line was then unwound, and
Title:  some fathoms of it taken to the windlass, and stretched to a great
Title:  tension.  Pressing his foot upon it, till the rope hummed like a
Title:  harp-string, then eagerly bending over it, and seeing no strandings,
Title:  Ahab exclaimed, "Good! and now for the seizings."
Title:  
Title:  At one extremity the rope was unstranded, and the separate spread
Title:  yarns were all braided and woven round the socket of the harpoon; the
Title:  pole was then driven hard up into the socket; from the lower end the
Title:  rope was traced half-way along the pole's length, and firmly secured
Title:  so, with intertwistings of twine.  This done, pole, iron, and
Title:  rope--like the Three Fates--remained inseparable, and Ahab moodily
Title:  stalked away with the weapon; the sound of his ivory leg, and the
Title:  sound of the hickory pole, both hollowly ringing along every plank.
Title:  But ere he entered his cabin, light, unnatural, half-bantering, yet
Title:  most piteous sound was heard.  Oh, Pip! thy wretched laugh, thy
Title:  idle but unresting eye; all thy strange mummeries not unmeaningly
Title:  blended with the black tragedy of the melancholy ship, and mocked it!
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 114
Title:  
Title:  The Gilder.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Penetrating further and further into the heart of the Japanese
Title:  cruising ground, the Pequod was soon all astir in the fishery.
Title:  Often, in mild, pleasant weather, for twelve, fifteen, eighteen, and
Title:  twenty hours on the stretch, they were engaged in the boats, steadily
Title:  pulling, or sailing, or paddling after the whales, or for an
Title:  interlude of sixty or seventy minutes calmly awaiting their uprising;
Title:  though with but small success for their pains.
Title:  
Title:  At such times, under an abated sun; afloat all day upon smooth, slow
Title:  heaving swells; seated in his boat, light as a birch canoe; and so
Title:  sociably mixing with the soft waves themselves, that like
Title:  hearth-stone cats they purr against the gunwale; these are the times
Title:  of dreamy quietude, when beholding the tranquil beauty and brilliancy
Title:  of the ocean's skin, one forgets the tiger heart that pants beneath
Title:  it; and would not willingly remember, that this velvet paw but
Title:  conceals a remorseless fang.
Title:  
Title:  These are the times, when in his whale-boat the rover softly feels a
Title:  certain filial, confident, land-like feeling towards the sea; that he
Title:  regards it as so much flowery earth; and the distant ship revealing
Title:  only the tops of her masts, seems struggling forward, not through
Title:  high rolling waves, but through the tall grass of a rolling prairie:
Title:  as when the western emigrants' horses only show their erected ears,
Title:  while their hidden bodies widely wade through the amazing verdure.
Title:  
Title:  The long-drawn virgin vales; the mild blue hill-sides; as over these
Title:  there steals the hush, the hum; you almost swear that play-wearied
Title:  children lie sleeping in these solitudes, in some glad May-time, when
Title:  the flowers of the woods are plucked.  And all this mixes with your
Title:  most mystic mood; so that fact and fancy, half-way meeting,
Title:  interpenetrate, and form one seamless whole.
Title:  
Title:  Nor did such soothing scenes, however temporary, fail of at least as
Title:  temporary an effect on Ahab.  But if these secret golden keys did
Title:  seem to open in him his own secret golden treasuries, yet did his
Title:  breath upon them prove but tarnishing.
Title:  
Title:  Oh, grassy glades! oh, ever vernal endless landscapes in the soul; in
Title:  ye,--though long parched by the dead drought of the earthy
Title:  life,--in ye, men yet may roll, like young horses in new morning
Title:  clover; and for some few fleeting moments, feel the cool dew of the
Title:  life immortal on them.  Would to God these blessed calms would last.
Title:  But the mingled, mingling threads of life are woven by warp and woof:
Title:  calms crossed by storms, a storm for every calm.  There is no steady
Title:  unretracing progress in this life; we do not advance through fixed
Title:  gradations, and at the last one pause:--through infancy's unconscious
Title:  spell, boyhood's thoughtless faith, adolescence' doubt (the common
Title:  doom), then scepticism, then disbelief, resting at last in manhood's
Title:  pondering repose of If.  But once gone through, we trace the round
Title:  again; and are infants, boys, and men, and Ifs eternally.  Where lies
Title:  the final harbor, whence we unmoor no more?  In what rapt ether sails
Title:  the world, of which the weariest will never weary?  Where is the
Title:  foundling's father hidden?  Our souls are like those orphans whose
Title:  unwedded mothers die in bearing them: the secret of our paternity
Title:  lies in their grave, and we must there to learn it.
Title:  
Title:  And that same day, too, gazing far down from his boat's side into
Title:  that same golden sea, Starbuck lowly murmured:--
Title:  
Title:  "Loveliness unfathomable, as ever lover saw in his young bride's
Title:  eye!--Tell me not of thy teeth-tiered sharks, and thy kidnapping
Title:  cannibal ways.  Let faith oust fact; let fancy oust memory; I look
Title:  deep down and do believe."
Title:  
Title:  And Stubb, fish-like, with sparkling scales, leaped up in that same
Title:  golden light:--
Title:  
Title:  "I am Stubb, and Stubb has his history; but here Stubb takes oaths
Title:  that he has always been jolly!"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 115
Title:  
Title:  The Pequod Meets The Bachelor.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  And jolly enough were the sights and the sounds that came bearing
Title:  down before the wind, some few weeks after Ahab's harpoon had been
Title:  welded.
Title:  
Title:  It was a Nantucket ship, the Bachelor, which had just wedged in her
Title:  last cask of oil, and bolted down her bursting hatches; and now, in
Title:  glad holiday apparel, was joyously, though somewhat vain-gloriously,
Title:  sailing round among the widely-separated ships on the ground,
Title:  previous to pointing her prow for home.
Title:  
Title:  The three men at her mast-head wore long streamers of narrow red
Title:  bunting at their hats; from the stern, a whale-boat was suspended,
Title:  bottom down; and hanging captive from the bowsprit was seen the long
Title:  lower jaw of the last whale they had slain.  Signals, ensigns, and
Title:  jacks of all colours were flying from her rigging, on every side.
Title:  Sideways lashed in each of her three basketed tops were two barrels
Title:  of sperm; above which, in her top-mast cross-trees, you saw slender
Title:  breakers of the same precious fluid; and nailed to her main truck was
Title:  a brazen lamp.
Title:  
Title:  As was afterwards learned, the Bachelor had met with the most
Title:  surprising success; all the more wonderful, for that while cruising
Title:  in the same seas numerous other vessels had gone entire months
Title:  without securing a single fish.  Not only had barrels of beef and
Title:  bread been given away to make room for the far more valuable sperm,
Title:  but additional supplemental casks had been bartered for, from the
Title:  ships she had met; and these were stowed along the deck, and in the
Title:  captain's and officers' state-rooms.  Even the cabin table itself
Title:  had been knocked into kindling-wood; and the cabin mess dined off the
Title:  broad head of an oil-butt, lashed down to the floor for a
Title:  centrepiece.  In the forecastle, the sailors had actually caulked
Title:  and pitched their chests, and filled them; it was humorously added,
Title:  that the cook had clapped a head on his largest boiler, and filled
Title:  it; that the steward had plugged his spare coffee-pot and filled it;
Title:  that the harpooneers had headed the sockets of their irons and filled
Title:  them; that indeed everything was filled with sperm, except the
Title:  captain's pantaloons pockets, and those he reserved to thrust his
Title:  hands into, in self-complacent testimony of his entire satisfaction.
Title:  
Title:  As this glad ship of good luck bore down upon the moody Pequod, the
Title:  barbarian sound of enormous drums came from her forecastle; and
Title:  drawing still nearer, a crowd of her men were seen standing round her
Title:  huge try-pots, which, covered with the parchment-like POKE or stomach
Title:  skin of the black fish, gave forth a loud roar to every stroke of the
Title:  clenched hands of the crew.  On the quarter-deck, the mates and
Title:  harpooneers were dancing with the olive-hued girls who had eloped
Title:  with them from the Polynesian Isles; while suspended in an
Title:  ornamented boat, firmly secured aloft between the foremast and
Title:  mainmast, three Long Island negroes, with glittering fiddle-bows of
Title:  whale ivory, were presiding over the hilarious jig.  Meanwhile,
Title:  others of the ship's company were tumultuously busy at the masonry of
Title:  the try-works, from which the huge pots had been removed.  You would
Title:  have almost thought they were pulling down the cursed Bastille, such
Title:  wild cries they raised, as the now useless brick and mortar were
Title:  being hurled into the sea.
Title:  
Title:  Lord and master over all this scene, the captain stood erect on the
Title:  ship's elevated quarter-deck, so that the whole rejoicing drama was
Title:  full before him, and seemed merely contrived for his own individual
Title:  diversion.
Title:  
Title:  And Ahab, he too was standing on his quarter-deck, shaggy and black,
Title:  with a stubborn gloom; and as the two ships crossed each other's
Title:  wakes--one all jubilations for things passed, the other all
Title:  forebodings as to things to come--their two captains in themselves
Title:  impersonated the whole striking contrast of the scene.
Title:  
Title:  "Come aboard, come aboard!" cried the gay Bachelor's commander,
Title:  lifting a glass and a bottle in the air.
Title:  
Title:  "Hast seen the White Whale?" gritted Ahab in reply.
Title:  
Title:  "No; only heard of him; but don't believe in him at all," said the
Title:  other good-humoredly.  "Come aboard!"
Title:  
Title:  "Thou art too damned jolly.  Sail on.  Hast lost any men?"
Title:  
Title:  "Not enough to speak of--two islanders, that's all;--but come aboard,
Title:  old hearty, come along.  I'll soon take that black from your brow.
Title:  Come along, will ye (merry's the play); a full ship and
Title:  homeward-bound."
Title:  
Title:  "How wondrous familiar is a fool!" muttered Ahab; then aloud, "Thou
Title:  art a full ship and homeward bound, thou sayst; well, then, call me
Title:  an empty ship, and outward-bound.  So go thy ways, and I will mine.
Title:  Forward there!  Set all sail, and keep her to the wind!"
Title:  
Title:  And thus, while the one ship went cheerily before the breeze, the
Title:  other stubbornly fought against it; and so the two vessels parted;
Title:  the crew of the Pequod looking with grave, lingering glances towards
Title:  the receding Bachelor; but the Bachelor's men never heeding their
Title:  gaze for the lively revelry they were in.  And as Ahab, leaning over
Title:  the taffrail, eyed the homewardbound craft, he took from his pocket a
Title:  small vial of sand, and then looking from the ship to the vial,
Title:  seemed thereby bringing two remote associations together, for that
Title:  vial was filled with Nantucket soundings.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 116
Title:  
Title:  The Dying Whale.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Not seldom in this life, when, on the right side, fortune's favourites
Title:  sail close by us, we, though all adroop before, catch somewhat of the
Title:  rushing breeze, and joyfully feel our bagging sails fill out.  So
Title:  seemed it with the Pequod.  For next day after encountering the gay
Title:  Bachelor, whales were seen and four were slain; and one of them by
Title:  Ahab.
Title:  
Title:  It was far down the afternoon; and when all the spearings of the
Title:  crimson fight were done: and floating in the lovely sunset sea and
Title:  sky, sun and whale both stilly died together; then, such a sweetness
Title:  and such plaintiveness, such inwreathing orisons curled up in that
Title:  rosy air, that it almost seemed as if far over from the deep green
Title:  convent valleys of the Manilla isles, the Spanish land-breeze,
Title:  wantonly turned sailor, had gone to sea, freighted with these vesper
Title:  hymns.
Title:  
Title:  Soothed again, but only soothed to deeper gloom, Ahab, who had
Title:  sterned off from the whale, sat intently watching his final wanings
Title:  from the now tranquil boat.  For that strange spectacle observable in
Title:  all sperm whales dying--the turning sunwards of the head, and so
Title:  expiring--that strange spectacle, beheld of such a placid evening,
Title:  somehow to Ahab conveyed a wondrousness unknown before.
Title:  
Title:  "He turns and turns him to it,--how slowly, but how steadfastly, his
Title:  homage-rendering and invoking brow, with his last dying motions.  He
Title:  too worships fire; most faithful, broad, baronial vassal of the
Title:  sun!--Oh that these too-favouring eyes should see these too-favouring
Title:  sights.  Look! here, far water-locked; beyond all hum of human weal
Title:  or woe; in these most candid and impartial seas; where to traditions
Title:  no rocks furnish tablets; where for long Chinese ages, the billows
Title:  have still rolled on speechless and unspoken to, as stars that shine
Title:  upon the Niger's unknown source; here, too, life dies sunwards full
Title:  of faith; but see! no sooner dead, than death whirls round the
Title:  corpse, and it heads some other way.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, thou dark Hindoo half of nature, who of drowned bones hast
Title:  builded thy separate throne somewhere in the heart of these
Title:  unverdured seas; thou art an infidel, thou queen, and too truly
Title:  speakest to me in the wide-slaughtering Typhoon, and the hushed
Title:  burial of its after calm.  Nor has this thy whale sunwards turned his
Title:  dying head, and then gone round again, without a lesson to me.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, trebly hooped and welded hip of power!  Oh, high aspiring,
Title:  rainbowed jet!--that one strivest, this one jettest all in vain!  In
Title:  vain, oh whale, dost thou seek intercedings with yon all-quickening
Title:  sun, that only calls forth life, but gives it not again.  Yet dost
Title:  thou, darker half, rock me with a prouder, if a darker faith.  All
Title:  thy unnamable imminglings float beneath me here; I am buoyed by
Title:  breaths of once living things, exhaled as air, but water now.
Title:  
Title:  "Then hail, for ever hail, O sea, in whose eternal tossings the wild
Title:  fowl finds his only rest.  Born of earth, yet suckled by the sea;
Title:  though hill and valley mothered me, ye billows are my
Title:  foster-brothers!"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 117
Title:  
Title:  The Whale Watch.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  The four whales slain that evening had died wide apart; one, far to
Title:  windward; one, less distant, to leeward; one ahead; one astern.
Title:  These last three were brought alongside ere nightfall; but the
Title:  windward one could not be reached till morning; and the boat that had
Title:  killed it lay by its side all night; and that boat was Ahab's.
Title:  
Title:  The waif-pole was thrust upright into the dead whale's spout-hole;
Title:  and the lantern hanging from its top, cast a troubled flickering
Title:  glare upon the black, glossy back, and far out upon the midnight
Title:  waves, which gently chafed the whale's broad flank, like soft surf
Title:  upon a beach.
Title:  
Title:  Ahab and all his boat's crew seemed asleep but the Parsee; who
Title:  crouching in the bow, sat watching the sharks, that spectrally played
Title:  round the whale, and tapped the light cedar planks with their tails.
Title:  A sound like the moaning in squadrons over Asphaltites of unforgiven
Title:  ghosts of Gomorrah, ran shuddering through the air.
Title:  
Title:  Started from his slumbers, Ahab, face to face, saw the Parsee; and
Title:  hooped round by the gloom of the night they seemed the last men in a
Title:  flooded world.  "I have dreamed it again," said he.
Title:  
Title:  "Of the hearses?  Have I not said, old man, that neither hearse nor
Title:  coffin can be thine?"
Title:  
Title:  "And who are hearsed that die on the sea?"
Title:  
Title:  "But I said, old man, that ere thou couldst die on this voyage, two
Title:  hearses must verily be seen by thee on the sea; the first not made by
Title:  mortal hands; and the visible wood of the last one must be grown in
Title:  America."
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, aye! a strange sight that, Parsee:--a hearse and its plumes
Title:  floating over the ocean with the waves for the pall-bearers.  Ha!
Title:  Such a sight we shall not soon see."
Title:  
Title:  "Believe it or not, thou canst not die till it be seen, old man."
Title:  
Title:  "And what was that saying about thyself?"
Title:  
Title:  "Though it come to the last, I shall still go before thee thy pilot."
Title:  
Title:  "And when thou art so gone before--if that ever befall--then ere I
Title:  can follow, thou must still appear to me, to pilot me still?--Was it
Title:  not so?  Well, then, did I believe all ye say, oh my pilot!  I have
Title:  here two pledges that I shall yet slay Moby Dick and survive it."
Title:  
Title:  "Take another pledge, old man," said the Parsee, as his eyes lighted
Title:  up like fire-flies in the gloom--"Hemp only can kill thee."
Title:  
Title:  "The gallows, ye mean.--I am immortal then, on land and on sea,"
Title:  cried Ahab, with a laugh of derision;--"Immortal on land and on sea!"
Title:  
Title:  Both were silent again, as one man.  The grey dawn came on, and the
Title:  slumbering crew arose from the boat's bottom, and ere noon the dead
Title:  whale was brought to the ship.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 118
Title:  
Title:  The Quadrant.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  The season for the Line at length drew near; and every day when Ahab,
Title:  coming from his cabin, cast his eyes aloft, the vigilant helmsman
Title:  would ostentatiously handle his spokes, and the eager mariners
Title:  quickly run to the braces, and would stand there with all their eyes
Title:  centrally fixed on the nailed doubloon; impatient for the order to
Title:  point the ship's prow for the equator.  In good time the order came.
Title:  It was hard upon high noon; and Ahab, seated in the bows of his
Title:  high-hoisted boat, was about taking his wonted daily observation of
Title:  the sun to determine his latitude.
Title:  
Title:  Now, in that Japanese sea, the days in summer are as freshets of
Title:  effulgences.  That unblinkingly vivid Japanese sun seems the blazing
Title:  focus of the glassy ocean's immeasurable burning-glass.  The sky
