Title:  looks lacquered; clouds there are none; the horizon floats; and this
Title:  nakedness of unrelieved radiance is as the insufferable splendors of
Title:  God's throne.  Well that Ahab's quadrant was furnished with coloured
Title:  glasses, through which to take sight of that solar fire.  So,
Title:  swinging his seated form to the roll of the ship, and with his
Title:  astrological-looking instrument placed to his eye, he remained in
Title:  that posture for some moments to catch the precise instant when the
Title:  sun should gain its precise meridian.  Meantime while his whole
Title:  attention was absorbed, the Parsee was kneeling beneath him on the
Title:  ship's deck, and with face thrown up like Ahab's, was eyeing the same
Title:  sun with him; only the lids of his eyes half hooded their orbs, and
Title:  his wild face was subdued to an earthly passionlessness.  At length
Title:  the desired observation was taken; and with his pencil upon his ivory
Title:  leg, Ahab soon calculated what his latitude must be at that precise
Title:  instant.  Then falling into a moment's revery, he again looked up
Title:  towards the sun and murmured to himself: "Thou sea-mark! thou high
Title:  and mighty Pilot! thou tellest me truly where I AM--but canst thou
Title:  cast the least hint where I SHALL be?  Or canst thou tell where some
Title:  other thing besides me is this moment living?  Where is Moby Dick?
Title:  This instant thou must be eyeing him.  These eyes of mine look into
Title:  the very eye that is even now beholding him; aye, and into the eye
Title:  that is even now equally beholding the objects on the unknown,
Title:  thither side of thee, thou sun!"
Title:  
Title:  Then gazing at his quadrant, and handling, one after the other, its
Title:  numerous cabalistical contrivances, he pondered again, and muttered:
Title:  "Foolish toy! babies' plaything of haughty Admirals, and Commodores,
Title:  and Captains; the world brags of thee, of thy cunning and might; but
Title:  what after all canst thou do, but tell the poor, pitiful point, where
Title:  thou thyself happenest to be on this wide planet, and the hand that
Title:  holds thee: no! not one jot more!  Thou canst not tell where one drop
Title:  of water or one grain of sand will be to-morrow noon; and yet with
Title:  thy impotence thou insultest the sun!  Science!  Curse thee, thou
Title:  vain toy; and cursed be all the things that cast man's eyes aloft to
Title:  that heaven, whose live vividness but scorches him, as these old eyes
Title:  are even now scorched with thy light, O sun!  Level by nature to this
Title:  earth's horizon are the glances of man's eyes; not shot from the
Title:  crown of his head, as if God had meant him to gaze on his firmament.
Title:  Curse thee, thou quadrant!" dashing it to the deck, "no longer will I
Title:  guide my earthly way by thee; the level ship's compass, and the level
Title:  deadreckoning, by log and by line; THESE shall conduct me, and show
Title:  me my place on the sea.  Aye," lighting from the boat to the deck,
Title:  "thus I trample on thee, thou paltry thing that feebly pointest on
Title:  high; thus I split and destroy thee!"
Title:  
Title:  As the frantic old man thus spoke and thus trampled with his live and
Title:  dead feet, a sneering triumph that seemed meant for Ahab, and a
Title:  fatalistic despair that seemed meant for himself--these passed over
Title:  the mute, motionless Parsee's face.  Unobserved he rose and glided
Title:  away; while, awestruck by the aspect of their commander, the seamen
Title:  clustered together on the forecastle, till Ahab, troubledly pacing
Title:  the deck, shouted out--"To the braces!  Up helm!--square in!"
Title:  
Title:  In an instant the yards swung round; and as the ship half-wheeled
Title:  upon her heel, her three firm-seated graceful masts erectly poised
Title:  upon her long, ribbed hull, seemed as the three Horatii pirouetting
Title:  on one sufficient steed.
Title:  
Title:  Standing between the knight-heads, Starbuck watched the Pequod's
Title:  tumultuous way, and Ahab's also, as he went lurching along the deck.
Title:  
Title:  "I have sat before the dense coal fire and watched it all aglow, full
Title:  of its tormented flaming life; and I have seen it wane at last, down,
Title:  down, to dumbest dust.  Old man of oceans! of all this fiery life of
Title:  thine, what will at length remain but one little heap of ashes!"
Title:  
Title:  "Aye," cried Stubb, "but sea-coal ashes--mind ye that, Mr.
Title:  Starbuck--sea-coal, not your common charcoal.  Well, well; I heard
Title:  Ahab mutter, 'Here some one thrusts these cards into these old hands
Title:  of mine; swears that I must play them, and no others.'  And damn me,
Title:  Ahab, but thou actest right; live in the game, and die in it!"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 119
Title:  
Title:  The Candles.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Warmest climes but nurse the cruellest fangs: the tiger of Bengal
Title:  crouches in spiced groves of ceaseless verdure.  Skies the most
Title:  effulgent but basket the deadliest thunders: gorgeous Cuba knows
Title:  tornadoes that never swept tame northern lands.  So, too, it is, that
Title:  in these resplendent Japanese seas the mariner encounters the direst
Title:  of all storms, the Typhoon.  It will sometimes burst from out that
Title:  cloudless sky, like an exploding bomb upon a dazed and sleepy town.
Title:  
Title:  Towards evening of that day, the Pequod was torn of her canvas, and
Title:  bare-poled was left to fight a Typhoon which had struck her directly
Title:  ahead.  When darkness came on, sky and sea roared and split with the
Title:  thunder, and blazed with the lightning, that showed the disabled
Title:  masts fluttering here and there with the rags which the first fury of
Title:  the tempest had left for its after sport.
Title:  
Title:  Holding by a shroud, Starbuck was standing on the quarter-deck; at
Title:  every flash of the lightning glancing aloft, to see what additional
Title:  disaster might have befallen the intricate hamper there; while Stubb
Title:  and Flask were directing the men in the higher hoisting and firmer
Title:  lashing of the boats.  But all their pains seemed naught.  Though
Title:  lifted to the very top of the cranes, the windward quarter boat
Title:  (Ahab's) did not escape.  A great rolling sea, dashing high up
Title:  against the reeling ship's high teetering side, stove in the boat's
Title:  bottom at the stern, and left it again, all dripping through like a
Title:  sieve.
Title:  
Title:  "Bad work, bad work!  Mr. Starbuck," said Stubb, regarding the wreck,
Title:  "but the sea will have its way.  Stubb, for one, can't fight it.  You
Title:  see, Mr. Starbuck, a wave has such a great long start before it
Title:  leaps, all round the world it runs, and then comes the spring!  But
Title:  as for me, all the start I have to meet it, is just across the deck
Title:  here.  But never mind; it's all in fun: so the old song
Title:  says;"--(SINGS.)
Title:  
Title:  Oh! jolly is the gale,
Title:  And a joker is the whale,
Title:  A' flourishin' his tail,--
Title:  Such a funny, sporty, gamy, jesty, joky, hoky-poky lad, is the Ocean, oh!
Title:  
Title:  The scud all a flyin',
Title:  That's his flip only foamin';
Title:  When he stirs in the spicin',--
Title:  Such a funny, sporty, gamy, jesty, joky, hoky-poky lad, is the Ocean, oh!
Title:  
Title:  Thunder splits the ships,
Title:  But he only smacks his lips,
Title:  A tastin' of this flip,--
Title:  Such a funny, sporty, gamy, jesty, joky, hoky-poky lad, is the Ocean, oh!
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "Avast Stubb," cried Starbuck, "let the Typhoon sing, and strike his
Title:  harp here in our rigging; but if thou art a brave man thou wilt hold
Title:  thy peace."
Title:  
Title:  "But I am not a brave man; never said I was a brave man; I am a
Title:  coward; and I sing to keep up my spirits.  And I tell you what it is,
Title:  Mr. Starbuck, there's no way to stop my singing in this world but to
Title:  cut my throat.  And when that's done, ten to one I sing ye the
Title:  doxology for a wind-up."
Title:  
Title:  "Madman! look through my eyes if thou hast none of thine own."
Title:  
Title:  "What! how can you see better of a dark night than anybody else,
Title:  never mind how foolish?"
Title:  
Title:  "Here!" cried Starbuck, seizing Stubb by the shoulder, and pointing
Title:  his hand towards the weather bow, "markest thou not that the gale
Title:  comes from the eastward, the very course Ahab is to run for Moby
Title:  Dick? the very course he swung to this day noon? now mark his boat
Title:  there; where is that stove?  In the stern-sheets, man; where he is
Title:  wont to stand--his stand-point is stove, man!  Now jump overboard,
Title:  and sing away, if thou must!
Title:  
Title:  "I don't half understand ye: what's in the wind?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes, round the Cape of Good Hope is the shortest way to
Title:  Nantucket," soliloquized Starbuck suddenly, heedless of Stubb's
Title:  question.  "The gale that now hammers at us to stave us, we can turn
Title:  it into a fair wind that will drive us towards home.  Yonder, to
Title:  windward, all is blackness of doom; but to leeward, homeward--I see
Title:  it lightens up there; but not with the lightning."
Title:  
Title:  At that moment in one of the intervals of profound darkness,
Title:  following the flashes, a voice was heard at his side; and almost at
Title:  the same instant a volley of thunder peals rolled overhead.
Title:  
Title:  "Who's there?"
Title:  
Title:  "Old Thunder!" said Ahab, groping his way along the bulwarks to his
Title:  pivot-hole; but suddenly finding his path made plain to him by
Title:  elbowed lances of fire.
Title:  
Title:  Now, as the lightning rod to a spire on shore is intended to carry
Title:  off the perilous fluid into the soil; so the kindred rod which at sea
Title:  some ships carry to each mast, is intended to conduct it into the
Title:  water.  But as this conductor must descend to considerable depth,
Title:  that its end may avoid all contact with the hull; and as moreover, if
Title:  kept constantly towing there, it would be liable to many mishaps,
Title:  besides interfering not a little with some of the rigging, and more
Title:  or less impeding the vessel's way in the water; because of all this,
Title:  the lower parts of a ship's lightning-rods are not always overboard;
Title:  but are generally made in long slender links, so as to be the more
Title:  readily hauled up into the chains outside, or thrown down into the
Title:  sea, as occasion may require.
Title:  
Title:  "The rods! the rods!" cried Starbuck to the crew, suddenly admonished
Title:  to vigilance by the vivid lightning that had just been darting
Title:  flambeaux, to light Ahab to his post.  "Are they overboard? drop them
Title:  over, fore and aft.  Quick!"
Title:  
Title:  "Avast!" cried Ahab; "let's have fair play here, though we be the
Title:  weaker side.  Yet I'll contribute to raise rods on the Himmalehs and
Title:  Andes, that all the world may be secured; but out on privileges!  Let
Title:  them be, sir."
Title:  
Title:  "Look aloft!" cried Starbuck.  "The corpusants! the corpusants!
Title:  
Title:  All the yard-arms were tipped with a pallid fire; and touched at each
Title:  tri-pointed lightning-rod-end with three tapering white flames, each
Title:  of the three tall masts was silently burning in that sulphurous air,
Title:  like three gigantic wax tapers before an altar.
Title:  
Title:  "Blast the boat! let it go!" cried Stubb at this instant, as a
Title:  swashing sea heaved up under his own little craft, so that its
Title:  gunwale violently jammed his hand, as he was passing a lashing.
Title:  "Blast it!"--but slipping backward on the deck, his uplifted eyes
Title:  caught the flames; and immediately shifting his tone he cried--"The
Title:  corpusants have mercy on us all!"
Title:  
Title:  To sailors, oaths are household words; they will swear in the trance
Title:  of the calm, and in the teeth of the tempest; they will imprecate
Title:  curses from the topsail-yard-arms, when most they teeter over to a
Title:  seething sea; but in all my voyagings, seldom have I heard a common
Title:  oath when God's burning finger has been laid on the ship; when His
Title:  "Mene, Mene, Tekel Upharsin" has been woven into the shrouds and the
Title:  cordage.
Title:  
Title:  While this pallidness was burning aloft, few words were heard from
Title:  the enchanted crew; who in one thick cluster stood on the forecastle,
Title:  all their eyes gleaming in that pale phosphorescence, like a far away
Title:  constellation of stars.  Relieved against the ghostly light, the
Title:  gigantic jet negro, Daggoo, loomed up to thrice his real stature, and
Title:  seemed the black cloud from which the thunder had come.  The parted
Title:  mouth of Tashtego revealed his shark-white teeth, which strangely
Title:  gleamed as if they too had been tipped by corpusants; while lit up by
Title:  the preternatural light, Queequeg's tattooing burned like Satanic
Title:  blue flames on his body.
Title:  
Title:  The tableau all waned at last with the pallidness aloft; and once
Title:  more the Pequod and every soul on her decks were wrapped in a pall.
Title:  A moment or two passed, when Starbuck, going forward, pushed against
Title:  some one.  It was Stubb.  "What thinkest thou now, man; I heard thy
Title:  cry; it was not the same in the song."
Title:  
Title:  "No, no, it wasn't; I said the corpusants have mercy on us all; and I
Title:  hope they will, still.  But do they only have mercy on long
Title:  faces?--have they no bowels for a laugh?  And look ye, Mr.
Title:  Starbuck--but it's too dark to look.  Hear me, then: I take that
Title:  mast-head flame we saw for a sign of good luck; for those masts are
Title:  rooted in a hold that is going to be chock a' block with sperm-oil,
Title:  d'ye see; and so, all that sperm will work up into the masts, like
Title:  sap in a tree.  Yes, our three masts will yet be as three spermaceti
Title:  candles--that's the good promise we saw."
Title:  
Title:  At that moment Starbuck caught sight of Stubb's face slowly beginning
Title:  to glimmer into sight.  Glancing upwards, he cried: "See! see!" and
Title:  once more the high tapering flames were beheld with what seemed
Title:  redoubled supernaturalness in their pallor.
Title:  
Title:  "The corpusants have mercy on us all," cried Stubb, again.
Title:  
Title:  At the base of the mainmast, full beneath the doubloon and the
Title:  flame, the Parsee was kneeling in Ahab's front, but with his head
Title:  bowed away from him; while near by, from the arched and overhanging
Title:  rigging, where they had just been engaged securing a spar, a number
Title:  of the seamen, arrested by the glare, now cohered together, and hung
Title:  pendulous, like a knot of numbed wasps from a drooping, orchard twig.
Title:  In various enchanted attitudes, like the standing, or stepping, or
Title:  running skeletons in Herculaneum, others remained rooted to the deck;
Title:  but all their eyes upcast.
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, aye, men!" cried Ahab.  "Look up at it; mark it well; the white
Title:  flame but lights the way to the White Whale!  Hand me those mainmast
Title:  links there; I would fain feel this pulse, and let mine beat against
Title:  it; blood against fire!  So."
Title:  
Title:  Then turning--the last link held fast in his left hand, he put his
Title:  foot upon the Parsee; and with fixed upward eye, and high-flung right
Title:  arm, he stood erect before the lofty tri-pointed trinity of flames.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh! thou clear spirit of clear fire, whom on these seas I as Persian
Title:  once did worship, till in the sacramental act so burned by thee, that
Title:  to this hour I bear the scar; I now know thee, thou clear spirit, and
Title:  I now know that thy right worship is defiance.  To neither love nor
Title:  reverence wilt thou be kind; and e'en for hate thou canst but kill;
Title:  and all are killed.  No fearless fool now fronts thee.  I own thy
Title:  speechless, placeless power; but to the last gasp of my earthquake
Title:  life will dispute its unconditional, unintegral mastery in me.  In the
Title:  midst of the personified impersonal, a personality stands here.
Title:  Though but a point at best; whencesoe'er I came; wheresoe'er I go;
Title:  yet while I earthly live, the queenly personality lives in me, and
Title:  feels her royal rights.  But war is pain, and hate is woe.  Come in
Title:  thy lowest form of love, and I will kneel and kiss thee; but at thy
Title:  highest, come as mere supernal power; and though thou launchest
Title:  navies of full-freighted worlds, there's that in here that still
Title:  remains indifferent.  Oh, thou clear spirit, of thy fire thou madest
Title:  me, and like a true child of fire, I breathe it back to thee."
Title:  
Title:  [SUDDEN, REPEATED FLASHES OF LIGHTNING; THE NINE FLAMES LEAP
Title:  LENGTHWISE TO THRICE THEIR PREVIOUS HEIGHT; AHAB, WITH THE REST,
Title:  CLOSES HIS EYES, HIS RIGHT HAND PRESSED HARD UPON THEM.]
Title:  
Title:  "I own thy speechless, placeless power; said I not so?  Nor was it
Title:  wrung from me; nor do I now drop these links.  Thou canst blind; but
Title:  I can then grope.  Thou canst consume; but I can then be ashes.  Take
Title:  the homage of these poor eyes, and shutter-hands.  I would not take
Title:  it.  The lightning flashes through my skull; mine eye-balls ache and
Title:  ache; my whole beaten brain seems as beheaded, and rolling on some
Title:  stunning ground.  Oh, oh!  Yet blindfold, yet will I talk to thee.
Title:  Light though thou be, thou leapest out of darkness; but I am darkness
Title:  leaping out of light, leaping out of thee!  The javelins cease; open
Title:  eyes; see, or not?  There burn the flames!  Oh, thou magnanimous! now
Title:  I do glory in my genealogy.  But thou art but my fiery father; my
Title:  sweet mother, I know not.  Oh, cruel! what hast thou done with her?
Title:  There lies my puzzle; but thine is greater.  Thou knowest not how
Title:  came ye, hence callest thyself unbegotten; certainly knowest not thy
Title:  beginning, hence callest thyself unbegun.  I know that of me, which
Title:  thou knowest not of thyself, oh, thou omnipotent.  There is some
Title:  unsuffusing thing beyond thee, thou clear spirit, to whom all thy
Title:  eternity is but time, all thy creativeness mechanical.  Through thee,
Title:  thy flaming self, my scorched eyes do dimly see it.  Oh, thou
Title:  foundling fire, thou hermit immemorial, thou too hast thy
Title:  incommunicable riddle, thy unparticipated grief.  Here again with
Title:  haughty agony, I read my sire.  Leap! leap up, and lick the sky!  I
Title:  leap with thee; I burn with thee; would fain be welded with thee;
Title:  defyingly I worship thee!"
Title:  
Title:  "The boat! the boat!" cried Starbuck, "look at thy boat, old man!"
Title:  
Title:  Ahab's harpoon, the one forged at Perth's fire, remained firmly
Title:  lashed in its conspicuous crotch, so that it projected beyond his
Title:  whale-boat's bow; but the sea that had stove its bottom had caused
Title:  the loose leather sheath to drop off; and from the keen steel barb
Title:  there now came a levelled flame of pale, forked fire.  As the silent
Title:  harpoon burned there like a serpent's tongue, Starbuck grasped Ahab
Title:  by the arm--"God, God is against thee, old man; forbear! 'tis an
Title:  ill voyage! ill begun, ill continued; let me square the yards, while
Title:  we may, old man, and make a fair wind of it homewards, to go on a
Title:  better voyage than this."
Title:  
Title:  Overhearing Starbuck, the panic-stricken crew instantly ran to the
Title:  braces--though not a sail was left aloft.  For the moment all the
Title:  aghast mate's thoughts seemed theirs; they raised a half mutinous
Title:  cry.  But dashing the rattling lightning links to the deck, and
Title:  snatching the burning harpoon, Ahab waved it like a torch among them;
Title:  swearing to transfix with it the first sailor that but cast loose a
Title:  rope's end.  Petrified by his aspect, and still more shrinking from
Title:  the fiery dart that he held, the men fell back in dismay, and Ahab
Title:  again spoke:--
Title:  
Title:  "All your oaths to hunt the White Whale are as binding as mine; and
Title:  heart, soul, and body, lungs and life, old Ahab is bound.  And that
Title:  ye may know to what tune this heart beats; look ye here; thus I blow
Title:  out the last fear!"  And with one blast of his breath he extinguished
Title:  the flame.
Title:  
Title:  As in the hurricane that sweeps the plain, men fly the neighborhood
Title:  of some lone, gigantic elm, whose very height and strength but render
Title:  it so much the more unsafe, because so much the more a mark for
Title:  thunderbolts; so at those last words of Ahab's many of the mariners
Title:  did run from him in a terror of dismay.
Title:

Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 120
Title:  
Title:  The Deck Towards the End of the First Night Watch.
Title:  
Title:  AHAB STANDING BY THE HELM.  STARBUCK APPROACHING HIM.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  We must send down the main-top-sail yard, sir.  The band is working
Title:  loose and the lee lift is half-stranded.  Shall I strike it, sir?"
Title:  
Title:  "Strike nothing; lash it.  If I had sky-sail poles, I'd sway them up
Title:  now."
Title:  
Title:  "Sir!--in God's name!--sir?"
Title:  
Title:  "Well."
Title:  
Title:  "The anchors are working, sir.  Shall I get them inboard?"
Title:  
Title:  "Strike nothing, and stir nothing, but lash everything.  The wind
Title:  rises, but it has not got up to my table-lands yet.  Quick, and see
Title:  to it.--By masts and keels! he takes me for the hunch-backed skipper
Title:  of some coasting smack.  Send down my main-top-sail yard!  Ho,
Title:  gluepots!  Loftiest trucks were made for wildest winds, and this
Title:  brain-truck of mine now sails amid the cloud-scud.  Shall I strike
Title:  that?  Oh, none but cowards send down their brain-trucks in tempest
Title:  time.  What a hooroosh aloft there!  I would e'en take it for
Title:  sublime, did I not know that the colic is a noisy malady.  Oh, take
Title:  medicine, take medicine!"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 121
Title:  
Title:  Midnight.--The Forecastle Bulwarks.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  STUBB AND FLASK MOUNTED ON THEM, AND PASSING ADDITIONAL LASHINGS OVER
Title:  THE ANCHORS THERE HANGING.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  No, Stubb; you may pound that knot there as much as you please, but
Title:  you will never pound into me what you were just now saying.  And how
Title:  long ago is it since you said the very contrary?  Didn't you once say
Title:  that whatever ship Ahab sails in, that ship should pay something
Title:  extra on its insurance policy, just as though it were loaded with
Title:  powder barrels aft and boxes of lucifers forward?  Stop, now; didn't
Title:  you say so?"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, suppose I did?  What then?  I've part changed my flesh since
Title:  that time, why not my mind?  Besides, supposing we ARE loaded with
Title:  powder barrels aft and lucifers forward; how the devil could the
Title:  lucifers get afire in this drenching spray here?  Why, my little man,
Title:  you have pretty red hair, but you couldn't get afire now.  Shake
Title:  yourself; you're Aquarius, or the water-bearer, Flask; might fill
Title:  pitchers at your coat collar.  Don't you see, then, that for these
Title:  extra risks the Marine Insurance companies have extra guarantees?
Title:  Here are hydrants, Flask.  But hark, again, and I'll answer ye the
Title:  other thing.  First take your leg off from the crown of the anchor
Title:  here, though, so I can pass the rope; now listen.  What's the mighty
Title:  difference between holding a mast's lightning-rod in the storm, and
Title:  standing close by a mast that hasn't got any lightning-rod at all in
Title:  a storm?  Don't you see, you timber-head, that no harm can come to
Title:  the holder of the rod, unless the mast is first struck?  What are you
Title:  talking about, then?  Not one ship in a hundred carries rods, and
Title:  Ahab,--aye, man, and all of us,--were in no more danger then, in my
Title:  poor opinion, than all the crews in ten thousand ships now sailing
Title:  the seas.  Why, you King-Post, you, I suppose you would have every
Title:  man in the world go about with a small lightning-rod running up the
Title:  corner of his hat, like a militia officer's skewered feather, and
Title:  trailing behind like his sash.  Why don't ye be sensible, Flask? it's
Title:  easy to be sensible; why don't ye, then? any man with half an eye can
Title:  be sensible."
Title:  
Title:  "I don't know that, Stubb.  You sometimes find it rather hard."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, when a fellow's soaked through, it's hard to be sensible,
Title:  that's a fact.  And I am about drenched with this spray.  Never mind;
Title:  catch the turn there, and pass it.  Seems to me we are lashing down
Title:  these anchors now as if they were never going to be used again.
Title:  Tying these two anchors here, Flask, seems like tying a man's hands
Title:  behind him.  And what big generous hands they are, to be sure.  These
Title:  are your iron fists, hey?  What a hold they have, too!  I wonder,
Title:  Flask, whether the world is anchored anywhere; if she is, she swings
Title:  with an uncommon long cable, though.  There, hammer that knot down,
Title:  and we've done.  So; next to touching land, lighting on deck is the
Title:  most satisfactory.  I say, just wring out my jacket skirts, will ye?
Title:  Thank ye.  They laugh at long-togs so, Flask; but seems to me, a
Title:  Long tailed coat ought always to be worn in all storms afloat.  The
Title:  tails tapering down that way, serve to carry off the water, d'ye see.
Title:  Same with cocked hats; the cocks form gable-end eave-troughs, Flask.
Title:  No more monkey-jackets and tarpaulins for me; I must mount a
Title:  swallow-tail, and drive down a beaver; so.  Halloa! whew! there goes
Title:  my tarpaulin overboard; Lord, Lord, that the winds that come from
Title:  heaven should be so unmannerly!  This is a nasty night, lad."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 122
Title:  
Title:  Midnight Aloft.--Thunder and Lightning.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  THE MAIN-TOP-SAIL YARD.--TASHTEGO PASSING NEW LASHINGS AROUND IT.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "Um, um, um.  Stop that thunder!  Plenty too much thunder up here.
Title:  What's the use of thunder?  Um, um, um.  We don't want thunder; we
Title:  want rum; give us a glass of rum.  Um, um, um!"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 123
Title:  
Title:  The Musket.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  During the most violent shocks of the Typhoon, the man at the
Title:  Pequod's jaw-bone tiller had several times been reelingly hurled to
Title:  the deck by its spasmodic motions, even though preventer tackles had
Title:  been attached to it--for they were slack--because some play to the
Title:  tiller was indispensable.
Title:  
Title:  In a severe gale like this, while the ship is but a tossed
Title:  shuttlecock to the blast, it is by no means uncommon to see the
Title:  needles in the compasses, at intervals, go round and round.  It was
Title:  thus with the Pequod's; at almost every shock the helmsman had not
Title:  failed to notice the whirling velocity with which they revolved upon
Title:  the cards; it is a sight that hardly anyone can behold without some
Title:  sort of unwonted emotion.
Title:  
Title:  Some hours after midnight, the Typhoon abated so much, that through
Title:  the strenuous exertions of Starbuck and Stubb--one engaged forward
Title:  and the other aft--the shivered remnants of the jib and fore and
Title:  main-top-sails were cut adrift from the spars, and went eddying away
Title:  to leeward, like the feathers of an albatross, which sometimes are
Title:  cast to the winds when that storm-tossed bird is on the wing.
Title:  
Title:  The three corresponding new sails were now bent and reefed, and a
Title:  storm-trysail was set further aft; so that the ship soon went through
Title:  the water with some precision again; and the course--for the present,
Title:  East-south-east--which he was to steer, if practicable, was once more
Title:  given to the helmsman.  For during the violence of the gale, he had
Title:  only steered according to its vicissitudes.  But as he was now
Title:  bringing the ship as near her course as possible, watching the
Title:  compass meanwhile, lo! a good sign! the wind seemed coming round
Title:  astern; aye, the foul breeze became fair!
Title:  
Title:  Instantly the yards were squared, to the lively song of "HO! THE FAIR
Title:  WIND! OH-YE-HO, CHEERLY MEN!" the crew singing for joy, that so
Title:  promising an event should so soon have falsified the evil portents
Title:  preceding it.
Title:  
Title:  In compliance with the standing order of his commander--to report
Title:  immediately, and at any one of the twenty-four hours, any decided
Title:  change in the affairs of the deck,--Starbuck had no sooner trimmed
Title:  the yards to the breeze--however reluctantly and gloomily,--than he
Title:  mechanically went below to apprise Captain Ahab of the circumstance.
Title:  
Title:  Ere knocking at his state-room, he involuntarily paused before it a
Title:  moment.  The cabin lamp--taking long swings this way and that--was
Title:  burning fitfully, and casting fitful shadows upon the old man's
Title:  bolted door,--a thin one, with fixed blinds inserted, in place of
Title:  upper panels.  The isolated subterraneousness of the cabin made a
Title:  certain humming silence to reign there, though it was hooped round by
Title:  all the roar of the elements.  The loaded muskets in the rack were
Title:  shiningly revealed, as they stood upright against the forward
Title:  bulkhead.  Starbuck was an honest, upright man; but out of Starbuck's
Title:  heart, at that instant when he saw the muskets, there strangely
Title:  evolved an evil thought; but so blent with its neutral or good
Title:  accompaniments that for the instant he hardly knew it for itself.
Title:  
Title:  "He would have shot me once," he murmured, "yes, there's the very
Title:  musket that he pointed at me;--that one with the studded stock; let
Title:  me touch it--lift it.  Strange, that I, who have handled so many
Title:  deadly lances, strange, that I should shake so now.  Loaded?  I must
Title:  see.  Aye, aye; and powder in the pan;--that's not good.  Best spill
Title:  it?--wait.  I'll cure myself of this.  I'll hold the musket boldly
Title:  while I think.--I come to report a fair wind to him.  But how fair?
Title:  Fair for death and doom,--THAT'S fair for Moby Dick.  It's a fair
Title:  wind that's only fair for that accursed fish.--The very tube he
Title:  pointed at me!--the very one; THIS one--I hold it here; he would have
Title:  killed me with the very thing I handle now.--Aye and he would fain
Title:  kill all his crew.  Does he not say he will not strike his spars to
Title:  any gale?  Has he not dashed his heavenly quadrant? and in these same
Title:  perilous seas, gropes he not his way by mere dead reckoning of the
Title:  error-abounding log? and in this very Typhoon, did he not swear that
Title:  he would have no lightning-rods?  But shall this crazed old man be
Title:  tamely suffered to drag a whole ship's company down to doom with
Title:  him?--Yes, it would make him the wilful murderer of thirty men and
Title:  more, if this ship come to any deadly harm; and come to deadly harm,
Title:  my soul swears this ship will, if Ahab have his way.  If, then, he
Title:  were this instant--put aside, that crime would not be his.  Ha! is he
Title:  muttering in his sleep?  Yes, just there,--in there, he's sleeping.
Title:  Sleeping? aye, but still alive, and soon awake again.  I can't
Title:  withstand thee, then, old man.  Not reasoning; not remonstrance; not
Title:  entreaty wilt thou hearken to; all this thou scornest.  Flat
Title:  obedience to thy own flat commands, this is all thou breathest.  Aye,
Title:  and say'st the men have vow'd thy vow; say'st all of us are Ahabs.
Title:  Great God forbid!--But is there no other way? no lawful way?--Make
Title:  him a prisoner to be taken home?  What! hope to wrest this old man's
Title:  living power from his own living hands?  Only a fool would try it.
Title:  Say he were pinioned even; knotted all over with ropes and hawsers;
Title:  chained down to ring-bolts on this cabin floor; he would be more
Title:  hideous than a caged tiger, then.  I could not endure the sight;
Title:  could not possibly fly his howlings; all comfort, sleep itself,
Title:  inestimable reason would leave me on the long intolerable voyage.
Title:  What, then, remains?  The land is hundreds of leagues away, and
Title:  locked Japan the nearest.  I stand alone here upon an open sea, with
Title:  two oceans and a whole continent between me and law.--Aye, aye, 'tis
Title:  so.--Is heaven a murderer when its lightning strikes a would-be
Title:  murderer in his bed, tindering sheets and skin together?--And would I
Title:  be a murderer, then, if"--and slowly, stealthily, and half sideways
Title:  looking, he placed the loaded musket's end against the door.
Title:  
Title:  "On this level, Ahab's hammock swings within; his head this way.  A
Title:  touch, and Starbuck may survive to hug his wife and child again.--Oh
Title:  Mary!  Mary!--boy! boy! boy!--But if I wake thee not to death, old
Title:  man, who can tell to what unsounded deeps Starbuck's body this day
Title:  week may sink, with all the crew!  Great God, where art Thou?  Shall
Title:  I? shall I?--The wind has gone down and shifted, sir; the fore and
Title:  main topsails are reefed and set; she heads her course."
Title:  
Title:  "Stern all!  Oh Moby Dick, I clutch thy heart at last!"
Title:  
Title:  Such were the sounds that now came hurtling from out the old man's
Title:  tormented sleep, as if Starbuck's voice had caused the long dumb
Title:  dream to speak.
Title:  
Title:  The yet levelled musket shook like a drunkard's arm against the
Title:  panel; Starbuck seemed wrestling with an angel; but turning from the
Title:  door, he placed the death-tube in its rack, and left the place.
Title:  
Title:  "He's too sound asleep, Mr. Stubb; go thou down, and wake him, and
Title:  tell him.  I must see to the deck here.  Thou know'st what to say."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 124
Title:  
Title:  The Needle.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Next morning the not-yet-subsided sea rolled in long slow billows of
Title:  mighty bulk, and striving in the Pequod's gurgling track, pushed her
Title:  on like giants' palms outspread.  The strong, unstaggering breeze
Title:  abounded so, that sky and air seemed vast outbellying sails; the
Title:  whole world boomed before the wind.  Muffled in the full morning
Title:  light, the invisible sun was only known by the spread intensity of
Title:  his place; where his bayonet rays moved on in stacks.  Emblazonings,
Title:  as of crowned Babylonian kings and queens, reigned over everything.
Title:  The sea was as a crucible of molten gold, that bubblingly leaps with
Title:  light and heat.
Title:  
Title:  Long maintaining an enchanted silence, Ahab stood apart; and every
Title:  time the tetering ship loweringly pitched down her bowsprit, he
Title:  turned to eye the bright sun's rays produced ahead; and when she
Title:  profoundly settled by the stern, he turned behind, and saw the sun's
Title:  rearward place, and how the same yellow rays were blending with his
Title:  undeviating wake.
Title:  
Title:  "Ha, ha, my ship! thou mightest well be taken now for the sea-chariot
Title:  of the sun.  Ho, ho! all ye nations before my prow, I bring the sun
Title:  to ye!  Yoke on the further billows; hallo! a tandem, I drive the
Title:  sea!"
Title:  
Title:  But suddenly reined back by some counter thought, he hurried towards
Title:  the helm, huskily demanding how the ship was heading.
Title:  
Title:  "East-sou-east, sir," said the frightened steersman.
Title:  
Title:  "Thou liest!" smiting him with his clenched fist.  "Heading East at
Title:  this hour in the morning, and the sun astern?"
Title:  
Title:  Upon this every soul was confounded; for the phenomenon just then
Title:  observed by Ahab had unaccountably escaped every one else; but its
Title:  very blinding palpableness must have been the cause.
Title:  
Title:  Thrusting his head half way into the binnacle, Ahab caught one
Title:  glimpse of the compasses; his uplifted arm slowly fell; for a moment
Title:  he almost seemed to stagger.  Standing behind him Starbuck looked,
Title:  and lo! the two compasses pointed East, and the Pequod was as
Title:  infallibly going West.
Title:  
Title:  But ere the first wild alarm could get out abroad among the crew, the
Title:  old man with a rigid laugh exclaimed, "I have it!  It has happened
Title:  before.  Mr. Starbuck, last night's thunder turned our
Title:  compasses--that's all.  Thou hast before now heard of such a thing, I
Title:  take it."
Title:  
Title:  "Aye; but never before has it happened to me, sir," said the pale
Title:  mate, gloomily.
Title:  
Title:  Here, it must needs be said, that accidents like this have in more
Title:  than one case occurred to ships in violent storms.  The magnetic
Title:  energy, as developed in the mariner's needle, is, as all know,
Title:  essentially one with the electricity beheld in heaven; hence it is
Title:  not to be much marvelled at, that such things should be.  Instances
Title:  where the lightning has actually struck the vessel, so as to smite
Title:  down some of the spars and rigging, the effect upon the needle has at
Title:  times been still more fatal; all its loadstone virtue being
Title:  annihilated, so that the before magnetic steel was of no more use
Title:  than an old wife's knitting needle.  But in either case, the needle
Title:  never again, of itself, recovers the original virtue thus marred or
Title:  lost; and if the binnacle compasses be affected, the same fate
Title:  reaches all the others that may be in the ship; even were the
Title:  lowermost one inserted into the kelson.
Title:  
Title:  Deliberately standing before the binnacle, and eyeing the
Title:  transpointed compasses, the old man, with the sharp of his extended
Title:  hand, now took the precise bearing of the sun, and satisfied that the
Title:  needles were exactly inverted, shouted out his orders for the ship's
Title:  course to be changed accordingly.  The yards were hard up; and once
Title:  more the Pequod thrust her undaunted bows into the opposing wind, for
Title:  the supposed fair one had only been juggling her.
Title:  
Title:  Meanwhile, whatever were his own secret thoughts, Starbuck said
Title:  nothing, but quietly he issued all requisite orders; while Stubb and
Title:  Flask--who in some small degree seemed then to be sharing his
Title:  feelings--likewise unmurmuringly acquiesced.  As for the men, though
Title:  some of them lowly rumbled, their fear of Ahab was greater than their
Title:  fear of Fate.  But as ever before, the pagan harpooneers remained
Title:  almost wholly unimpressed; or if impressed, it was only with a
Title:  certain magnetism shot into their congenial hearts from inflexible
Title:  Ahab's.
Title:  
Title:  For a space the old man walked the deck in rolling reveries.  But
Title:  chancing to slip with his ivory heel, he saw the crushed copper
Title:  sight-tubes of the quadrant he had the day before dashed to the deck.
Title:  
Title:  "Thou poor, proud heaven-gazer and sun's pilot! yesterday I wrecked
Title:  thee, and to-day the compasses would fain have wrecked me.  So, so.
Title:  But Ahab is lord over the level loadstone yet.  Mr. Starbuck--a lance
Title:  without a pole; a top-maul, and the smallest of the sail-maker's
Title:  needles.  Quick!"
Title:  
Title:  Accessory, perhaps, to the impulse dictating the thing he was now
Title:  about to do, were certain prudential motives, whose object might have
Title:  been to revive the spirits of his crew by a stroke of his subtile
Title:  skill, in a matter so wondrous as that of the inverted compasses.
Title:  Besides, the old man well knew that to steer by transpointed needles,
Title:  though clumsily practicable, was not a thing to be passed over by
Title:  superstitious sailors, without some shudderings and evil portents.
Title:  
Title:  "Men," said he, steadily turning upon the crew, as the mate handed
Title:  him the things he had demanded, "my men, the thunder turned old
Title:  Ahab's needles; but out of this bit of steel Ahab can make one of his
Title:  own, that will point as true as any."
Title:  
Title:  Abashed glances of servile wonder were exchanged by the sailors, as
Title:  this was said; and with fascinated eyes they awaited whatever magic
Title:  might follow.  But Starbuck looked away.
Title:  
Title:  With a blow from the top-maul Ahab knocked off the steel head of the
Title:  lance, and then handing to the mate the long iron rod remaining, bade
Title:  him hold it upright, without its touching the deck.  Then, with the
Title:  maul, after repeatedly smiting the upper end of this iron rod, he
Title:  placed the blunted needle endwise on the top of it, and less strongly
Title:  hammered that, several times, the mate still holding the rod as
Title:  before.  Then going through some small strange motions with
Title:  it--whether indispensable to the magnetizing of the steel, or merely
Title:  intended to augment the awe of the crew, is uncertain--he called for
Title:  linen thread; and moving to the binnacle, slipped out the two
Title:  reversed needles there, and horizontally suspended the sail-needle by
Title:  its middle, over one of the compass-cards.  At first, the steel went
Title:  round and round, quivering and vibrating at either end; but at last
Title:  it settled to its place, when Ahab, who had been intently watching
Title:  for this result, stepped frankly back from the binnacle, and pointing
Title:  his stretched arm towards it, exclaimed,--"Look ye, for yourselves,
Title:  if Ahab be not lord of the level loadstone!  The sun is East, and
Title:  that compass swears it!"
Title:  
Title:  One after another they peered in, for nothing but their own eyes
Title:  could persuade such ignorance as theirs, and one after another they
Title:  slunk away.
Title:  
Title:  In his fiery eyes of scorn and triumph, you then saw Ahab in all his
Title:  fatal pride.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 125
Title:  
Title:  The Log and Line.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  While now the fated Pequod had been so long afloat this voyage, the
Title:  log and line had but very seldom been in use.  Owing to a confident
Title:  reliance upon other means of determining the vessel's place, some
Title:  merchantmen, and many whalemen, especially when cruising, wholly
Title:  neglect to heave the log; though at the same time, and frequently
Title:  more for form's sake than anything else, regularly putting down upon
Title:  the customary slate the course steered by the ship, as well as the
Title:  presumed average rate of progression every hour.  It had been thus
Title:  with the Pequod.  The wooden reel and angular log attached hung, long
Title:  untouched, just beneath the railing of the after bulwarks.  Rains and
Title:  spray had damped it; sun and wind had warped it; all the elements
Title:  had combined to rot a thing that hung so idly.  But heedless of all
Title:  this, his mood seized Ahab, as he happened to glance upon the reel,
Title:  not many hours after the magnet scene, and he remembered how his
Title:  quadrant was no more, and recalled his frantic oath about the level
Title:  log and line.  The ship was sailing plungingly; astern the billows
Title:  rolled in riots.
Title:  
Title:  "Forward, there!  Heave the log!"
Title:  
Title:  Two seamen came.  The golden-hued Tahitian and the grizzly Manxman.
Title:  "Take the reel, one of ye, I'll heave."
Title:  
Title:  They went towards the extreme stern, on the ship's lee side, where
Title:  the deck, with the oblique energy of the wind, was now almost dipping
Title:  into the creamy, sidelong-rushing sea.
Title:  
Title:  The Manxman took the reel, and holding it high up, by the projecting
Title:  handle-ends of the spindle, round which the spool of line revolved,
Title:  so stood with the angular log hanging downwards, till Ahab advanced
Title:  to him.
Title:  
Title:  Ahab stood before him, and was lightly unwinding some thirty or forty
Title:  turns to form a preliminary hand-coil to toss overboard, when the old
Title:  Manxman, who was intently eyeing both him and the line, made bold to
Title:  speak.
Title:  
Title:  "Sir, I mistrust it; this line looks far gone, long heat and wet have
Title:  spoiled it."
Title:  
Title:  "'Twill hold, old gentleman.  Long heat and wet, have they spoiled
Title:  thee?  Thou seem'st to hold.  Or, truer perhaps, life holds thee;
Title:  not thou it."
Title:  
Title:  "I hold the spool, sir.  But just as my captain says.  With these
Title:  grey hairs of mine 'tis not worth while disputing, 'specially with a
Title:  superior, who'll ne'er confess."
Title:  
Title:  "What's that?  There now's a patched professor in Queen Nature's
Title:  granite-founded College; but methinks he's too subservient.  Where
Title:  wert thou born?"
Title:  
Title:  "In the little rocky Isle of Man, sir."
Title:  
Title:  "Excellent!  Thou'st hit the world by that."
Title:  
Title:  "I know not, sir, but I was born there."
Title:  
Title:  "In the Isle of Man, hey?  Well, the other way, it's good.  Here's a
Title:  man from Man; a man born in once independent Man, and now unmanned of
Title:  Man; which is sucked in--by what?  Up with the reel!  The dead, blind
Title:  wall butts all inquiring heads at last.  Up with it!  So."
Title:  
Title:  The log was heaved.  The loose coils rapidly straightened out in a
Title:  long dragging line astern, and then, instantly, the reel began to
Title:  whirl.  In turn, jerkingly raised and lowered by the rolling billows,
Title:  the towing resistance of the log caused the old reelman to stagger
Title:  strangely.
Title:  
Title:  "Hold hard!"
Title:  
Title:  Snap! the overstrained line sagged down in one long festoon; the
Title:  tugging log was gone.
Title:  
Title:  "I crush the quadrant, the thunder turns the needles, and now the mad
Title:  sea parts the log-line.  But Ahab can mend all.  Haul in here,
Title:  Tahitian; reel up, Manxman.  And look ye, let the carpenter make
Title:  another log, and mend thou the line.  See to it."
Title:  
Title:  "There he goes now; to him nothing's happened; but to me, the skewer
Title:  seems loosening out of the middle of the world.  Haul in, haul in,
Title:  Tahitian!  These lines run whole, and whirling out: come in broken,
Title:  and dragging slow.  Ha, Pip? come to help; eh, Pip?"
Title:  
Title:  "Pip? whom call ye Pip?  Pip jumped from the whale-boat.  Pip's
Title:  missing.  Let's see now if ye haven't fished him up here, fisherman.
Title:  It drags hard; I guess he's holding on.  Jerk him, Tahiti!  Jerk him
Title:  off; we haul in no cowards here.  Ho! there's his arm just breaking
Title:  water.  A hatchet! a hatchet! cut it off--we haul in no cowards here.
Title:  Captain Ahab! sir, sir! here's Pip, trying to get on board again."
Title:  
Title:  "Peace, thou crazy loon," cried the Manxman, seizing him by the arm.
Title:  "Away from the quarter-deck!"
Title:  
Title:  "The greater idiot ever scolds the lesser," muttered Ahab, advancing.
Title:  "Hands off from that holiness!  Where sayest thou Pip was, boy?
Title:  
Title:  "Astern there, sir, astern!  Lo! lo!"
Title:  
Title:  "And who art thou, boy?  I see not my reflection in the vacant pupils
Title:  of thy eyes.  Oh God! that man should be a thing for immortal souls
Title:  to sieve through!  Who art thou, boy?"
Title:  
Title:  "Bell-boy, sir; ship's-crier; ding, dong, ding!  Pip!  Pip!  Pip!  One
Title:  hundred pounds of clay reward for Pip; five feet high--looks
Title:  cowardly--quickest known by that!  Ding, dong, ding!  Who's seen Pip
Title:  the coward?"
Title:  
Title:  "There can be no hearts above the snow-line.  Oh, ye frozen heavens!
Title:  look down here.  Ye did beget this luckless child, and have abandoned
Title:  him, ye creative libertines.  Here, boy; Ahab's cabin shall be Pip's
Title:  home henceforth, while Ahab lives.  Thou touchest my inmost centre,
Title:  boy; thou art tied to me by cords woven of my heart-strings.  Come,
Title:  let's down."
Title:  
Title:  "What's this? here's velvet shark-skin," intently gazing at Ahab's
Title:  hand, and feeling it.  "Ah, now, had poor Pip but felt so kind a
Title:  thing as this, perhaps he had ne'er been lost!  This seems to me,
Title:  sir, as a man-rope; something that weak souls may hold by.  Oh, sir,
Title:  let old Perth now come and rivet these two hands together; the black
Title:  one with the white, for I will not let this go."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, boy, nor will I thee, unless I should thereby drag thee to worse
Title:  horrors than are here.  Come, then, to my cabin.  Lo! ye believers in
Title:  gods all goodness, and in man all ill, lo you! see the omniscient
Title:  gods oblivious of suffering man; and man, though idiotic, and knowing
Title:  not what he does, yet full of the sweet things of love and gratitude.
Title:  Come!  I feel prouder leading thee by thy black hand, than though I
Title:  grasped an Emperor's!"
Title:  
Title:  "There go two daft ones now," muttered the old Manxman.  "One daft
Title:  with strength, the other daft with weakness.  But here's the end of
Title:  the rotten line--all dripping, too.  Mend it, eh?  I think we had
Title:  best have a new line altogether.  I'll see Mr. Stubb about it."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 126
Title:  
Title:  The Life-Buoy.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Steering now south-eastward by Ahab's levelled steel, and her
Title:  progress solely determined by Ahab's level log and line; the Pequod
Title:  held on her path towards the Equator.  Making so long a passage
Title:  through such unfrequented waters, descrying no ships, and ere long,
Title:  sideways impelled by unvarying trade winds, over waves monotonously
Title:  mild; all these seemed the strange calm things preluding some riotous
Title:  and desperate scene.
Title:  
Title:  At last, when the ship drew near to the outskirts, as it were, of the
Title:  Equatorial fishing-ground, and in the deep darkness that goes before
Title:  the dawn, was sailing by a cluster of rocky islets; the watch--then
Title:  headed by Flask--was startled by a cry so plaintively wild and
Title:  unearthly--like half-articulated wailings of the ghosts of all
Title:  Herod's murdered Innocents--that one and all, they started from their
Title:  reveries, and for the space of some moments stood, or sat, or leaned
Title:  all transfixedly listening, like the carved Roman slave, while that
Title:  wild cry remained within hearing.  The Christian or civilized part of
Title:  the crew said it was mermaids, and shuddered; but the pagan
Title:  harpooneers remained unappalled.  Yet the grey Manxman--the oldest
Title:  mariner of all--declared that the wild thrilling sounds that were
Title:  heard, were the voices of newly drowned men in the sea.
Title:  
Title:  Below in his hammock, Ahab did not hear of this till grey dawn, when
Title:  he came to the deck; it was then recounted to him by Flask, not
Title:  unaccompanied with hinted dark meanings.  He hollowly laughed, and
Title:  thus explained the wonder.
Title:  
Title:  Those rocky islands the ship had passed were the resort of great
Title:  numbers of seals, and some young seals that had lost their dams, or
Title:  some dams that had lost their cubs, must have risen nigh the ship and
Title:  kept company with her, crying and sobbing with their human sort of
Title:  wail.  But this only the more affected some of them, because most
Title:  mariners cherish a very superstitious feeling about seals, arising
Title:  not only from their peculiar tones when in distress, but also from
Title:  the human look of their round heads and semi-intelligent faces, seen
Title:  peeringly uprising from the water alongside.  In the sea, under
Title:  certain circumstances, seals have more than once been mistaken for
Title:  men.
Title:  
Title:  But the bodings of the crew were destined to receive a most plausible
Title:  confirmation in the fate of one of their number that morning.  At
Title:  sun-rise this man went from his hammock to his mast-head at the fore;
Title:  and whether it was that he was not yet half waked from his sleep (for
Title:  sailors sometimes go aloft in a transition state), whether it was
Title:  thus with the man, there is now no telling; but, be that as it may,
Title:  he had not been long at his perch, when a cry was heard--a cry and a
Title:  rushing--and looking up, they saw a falling phantom in the air; and
Title:  looking down, a little tossed heap of white bubbles in the blue of
Title:  the sea.
Title:  
Title:  The life-buoy--a long slender cask--was dropped from the stern, where
Title:  it always hung obedient to a cunning spring; but no hand rose to
Title:  seize it, and the sun having long beat upon this cask it had
Title:  shrunken, so that it slowly filled, and that parched wood also
Title:  filled at its every pore; and the studded iron-bound cask followed
Title:  the sailor to the bottom, as if to yield him his pillow, though in
Title:  sooth but a hard one.
Title:  
Title:  And thus the first man of the Pequod that mounted the mast to look
Title:  out for the White Whale, on the White Whale's own peculiar ground;
Title:  that man was swallowed up in the deep.  But few, perhaps, thought of
Title:  that at the time.  Indeed, in some sort, they were not grieved at
Title:  this event, at least as a portent; for they regarded it, not as a
Title:  foreshadowing of evil in the future, but as the fulfilment of an
Title:  evil already presaged.  They declared that now they knew the reason
Title:  of those wild shrieks they had heard the night before.  But again the
Title:  old Manxman said nay.
Title:  
Title:  The lost life-buoy was now to be replaced; Starbuck was directed to
Title:  see to it; but as no cask of sufficient lightness could be found, and
Title:  as in the feverish eagerness of what seemed the approaching crisis of
Title:  the voyage, all hands were impatient of any toil but what was
Title:  directly connected with its final end, whatever that might prove to
Title:  be; therefore, they were going to leave the ship's stern unprovided
Title:  with a buoy, when by certain strange signs and inuendoes Queequeg
Title:  hinted a hint concerning his coffin.
Title:  
Title:  "A life-buoy of a coffin!" cried Starbuck, starting.
Title:  
Title:  "Rather queer, that, I should say," said Stubb.
Title:  
Title:  "It will make a good enough one," said Flask, "the carpenter here can
Title:  arrange it easily."
Title:  
Title:  "Bring it up; there's nothing else for it," said Starbuck, after a
Title:  melancholy pause.  "Rig it, carpenter; do not look at me so--the
Title:  coffin, I mean.  Dost thou hear me?  Rig it."
Title:  
Title:  "And shall I nail down the lid, sir?" moving his hand as with a
Title:  hammer.
Title:  
Title:  "Aye."
Title:  
Title:  "And shall I caulk the seams, sir?" moving his hand as with a
Title:  caulking-iron.
Title:  
Title:  "Aye."
Title:  
Title:  "And shall I then pay over the same with pitch, sir?" moving his hand
Title:  as with a pitch-pot.
Title:  
Title:  "Away! what possesses thee to this?  Make a life-buoy of the coffin,
Title:  and no more.--Mr. Stubb, Mr. Flask, come forward with me."
Title:  
Title:  "He goes off in a huff.  The whole he can endure; at the parts he
Title:  baulks.  Now I don't like this.  I make a leg for Captain Ahab, and
Title:  he wears it like a gentleman; but I make a bandbox for Queequeg, and
Title:  he won't put his head into it.  Are all my pains to go for nothing
Title:  with that coffin?  And now I'm ordered to make a life-buoy of it.
Title:  It's like turning an old coat; going to bring the flesh on the other
Title:  side now.  I don't like this cobbling sort of business--I don't like
Title:  it at all; it's undignified; it's not my place.  Let tinkers' brats
Title:  do tinkerings; we are their betters.  I like to take in hand none but
Title:  clean, virgin, fair-and-square mathematical jobs, something that
Title:  regularly begins at the beginning, and is at the middle when midway,
Title:  and comes to an end at the conclusion; not a cobbler's job, that's at
Title:  an end in the middle, and at the beginning at the end.  It's the old
Title:  woman's tricks to be giving cobbling jobs.  Lord! what an affection
Title:  all old women have for tinkers.  I know an old woman of sixty-five
Title:  who ran away with a bald-headed young tinker once.  And that's the
Title:  reason I never would work for lonely widow old women ashore, when I
Title:  kept my job-shop in the Vineyard; they might have taken it into their
Title:  lonely old heads to run off with me.  But heigh-ho! there are no caps
Title:  at sea but snow-caps.  Let me see.  Nail down the lid; caulk the
Title:  seams; pay over the same with pitch; batten them down tight, and hang
Title:  it with the snap-spring over the ship's stern.  Were ever such things
Title:  done before with a coffin?  Some superstitious old carpenters, now,
Title:  would be tied up in the rigging, ere they would do the job.  But I'm
Title:  made of knotty Aroostook hemlock; I don't budge.  Cruppered with a
Title:  coffin!  Sailing about with a grave-yard tray!  But never mind.  We
Title:  workers in woods make bridal-bedsteads and card-tables, as well as
Title:  coffins and hearses.  We work by the month, or by the job, or by the
Title:  profit; not for us to ask the why and wherefore of our work, unless
Title:  it be too confounded cobbling, and then we stash it if we can.  Hem!
Title:  I'll do the job, now, tenderly.  I'll have me--let's see--how many in
Title:  the ship's company, all told?  But I've forgotten.  Any way, I'll
Title:  have me thirty separate, Turk's-headed life-lines, each three feet
Title:  long hanging all round to the coffin.  Then, if the hull go down,
Title:  there'll be thirty lively fellows all fighting for one coffin, a
Title:  sight not seen very often beneath the sun!  Come hammer,
Title:  caulking-iron, pitch-pot, and marling-spike!  Let's to it."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 127
Title:  
Title:  The Deck.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  THE COFFIN LAID UPON TWO LINE-TUBS, BETWEEN THE VICE-BENCH AND THE
Title:  OPEN HATCHWAY; THE CARPENTER CAULKING ITS SEAMS; THE STRING OF
Title:  TWISTED OAKUM SLOWLY UNWINDING FROM A LARGE ROLL OF IT PLACED IN THE
Title:  BOSOM OF HIS FROCK.--AHAB COMES SLOWLY FROM THE CABIN-GANGWAY, AND
Title:  HEARS PIP FOLLOWING HIM.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Back, lad; I will be with ye again presently.  He goes!  Not this
Title:  hand complies with my humor more genially than that boy.--Middle
Title:  aisle of a church!  What's here?"
Title:  
Title:  "Life-buoy, sir.  Mr. Starbuck's orders.  Oh, look, sir!  Beware the
Title:  hatchway!"
Title:  
Title:  "Thank ye, man.  Thy coffin lies handy to the vault."
Title:  
Title:  "Sir?  The hatchway? oh!  So it does, sir, so it does."
Title:  
Title:  "Art not thou the leg-maker?  Look, did not this stump come from thy
Title:  shop?"
Title:  
Title:  "I believe it did, sir; does the ferrule stand, sir?"
Title:  
Title:  "Well enough.  But art thou not also the undertaker?"
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, sir; I patched up this thing here as a coffin for Queequeg; but
Title:  they've set me now to turning it into something else."
Title:  
Title:  "Then tell me; art thou not an arrant, all-grasping, intermeddling,
Title:  monopolising, heathenish old scamp, to be one day making legs, and
Title:  the next day coffins to clap them in, and yet again life-buoys out of
Title:  those same coffins?  Thou art as unprincipled as the gods, and as
Title:  much of a jack-of-all-trades."
Title:  
Title:  "But I do not mean anything, sir.  I do as I do."
Title:  
Title:  "The gods again.  Hark ye, dost thou not ever sing working about a
Title:  coffin?  The Titans, they say, hummed snatches when chipping out the
Title:  craters for volcanoes; and the grave-digger in the play sings, spade
Title:  in hand.  Dost thou never?"
Title:  
Title:  "Sing, sir?  Do I sing?  Oh, I'm indifferent enough, sir, for that;
Title:  but the reason why the grave-digger made music must have been because
Title:  there was none in his spade, sir.  But the caulking mallet is full of
Title:  it.  Hark to it."
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, and that's because the lid there's a sounding-board; and what
Title:  in all things makes the sounding-board is this--there's naught
Title:  beneath.  And yet, a coffin with a body in it rings pretty much the
Title:  same, Carpenter.  Hast thou ever helped carry a bier, and heard the
Title:  coffin knock against the churchyard gate, going in?
Title:  
Title:  "Faith, sir, I've--"
Title:  
Title:  "Faith?  What's that?"
Title:  
Title:  "Why, faith, sir, it's only a sort of exclamation-like--that's all,
Title:  sir."
Title:  
Title:  "Um, um; go on."
Title:  
Title:  "I was about to say, sir, that--"
Title:  
Title:  "Art thou a silk-worm?  Dost thou spin thy own shroud out of thyself?
Title:  Look at thy bosom!  Despatch! and get these traps out of sight."
Title:  
Title:  "He goes aft.  That was sudden, now; but squalls come sudden in hot
Title:  latitudes.  I've heard that the Isle of Albemarle, one of the
Title:  Gallipagos, is cut by the Equator right in the middle.  Seems to me
Title:  some sort of Equator cuts yon old man, too, right in his middle.
Title:  He's always under the Line--fiery hot, I tell ye!  He's looking this
Title:  way--come, oakum; quick.  Here we go again.  This wooden mallet is
Title:  the cork, and I'm the professor of musical glasses--tap, tap!"
Title:  
Title:  (AHAB TO HIMSELF.)
Title:  
Title:  "There's a sight!  There's a sound!  The grey-headed woodpecker
Title:  tapping the hollow tree!  Blind and dumb might well be envied now.
Title:  See! that thing rests on two line-tubs, full of tow-lines.  A most
Title:  malicious wag, that fellow.  Rat-tat!  So man's seconds tick!  Oh!
Title:  how immaterial are all materials!  What things real are there, but
Title:  imponderable thoughts?  Here now's the very dreaded symbol of grim
Title:  death, by a mere hap, made the expressive sign of the help and hope
Title:  of most endangered life.  A life-buoy of a coffin!  Does it go
Title:  further?  Can it be that in some spiritual sense the coffin is, after
Title:  all, but an immortality-preserver!  I'll think of that.  But no.  So
Title:  far gone am I in the dark side of earth, that its other side, the
Title:  theoretic bright one, seems but uncertain twilight to me.  Will ye
Title:  never have done, Carpenter, with that accursed sound?  I go below;
Title:  let me not see that thing here when I return again.  Now, then, Pip,
Title:  we'll talk this over; I do suck most wondrous philosophies from thee!
Title:  Some unknown conduits from the unknown worlds must empty into thee!"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 128
Title:  
Title:  The Pequod Meets The Rachel.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Next day, a large ship, the Rachel, was descried, bearing directly
Title:  down upon the Pequod, all her spars thickly clustering with men.  At
Title:  the time the Pequod was making good speed through the water; but as
Title:  the broad-winged windward stranger shot nigh to her, the boastful
Title:  sails all fell together as blank bladders that are burst, and all
Title:  life fled from the smitten hull.
Title:  
Title:  "Bad news; she brings bad news," muttered the old Manxman.  But ere
Title:  her commander, who, with trumpet to mouth, stood up in his boat; ere
Title:  he could hopefully hail, Ahab's voice was heard.
Title:  
Title:  "Hast seen the White Whale?"
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, yesterday.  Have ye seen a whale-boat adrift?"
Title:  
Title:  Throttling his joy, Ahab negatively answered this unexpected
Title:  question; and would then have fain boarded the stranger, when the
Title:  stranger captain himself, having stopped his vessel's way, was seen
Title:  descending her side.  A few keen pulls, and his boat-hook soon
Title:  clinched the Pequod's main-chains, and he sprang to the deck.
Title:  Immediately he was recognised by Ahab for a Nantucketer he knew.  But
Title:  no formal salutation was exchanged.
Title:  
Title:  "Where was he?--not killed!--not killed!" cried Ahab, closely
Title:  advancing.  "How was it?"
Title:  
Title:  It seemed that somewhat late on the afternoon of the day previous,
Title:  while three of the stranger's boats were engaged with a shoal of
Title:  whales, which had led them some four or five miles from the ship; and
Title:  while they were yet in swift chase to windward, the white hump and
Title:  head of Moby Dick had suddenly loomed up out of the water, not very
Title:  far to leeward; whereupon, the fourth rigged boat--a reserved
Title:  one--had been instantly lowered in chase.  After a keen sail before
Title:  the wind, this fourth boat--the swiftest keeled of all--seemed to
Title:  have succeeded in fastening--at least, as well as the man at the
Title:  mast-head could tell anything about it.  In the distance he saw the
Title:  diminished dotted boat; and then a swift gleam of bubbling white
Title:  water; and after that nothing more; whence it was concluded that the
Title:  stricken whale must have indefinitely run away with his pursuers, as
Title:  often happens.  There was some apprehension, but no positive alarm,
Title:  as yet.  The recall signals were placed in the rigging; darkness came
Title:  on; and forced to pick up her three far to windward boats--ere going
Title:  in quest of the fourth one in the precisely opposite direction--the
Title:  ship had not only been necessitated to leave that boat to its fate
Title:  till near midnight, but, for the time, to increase her distance from
Title:  it.  But the rest of her crew being at last safe aboard, she crowded
Title:  all sail--stunsail on stunsail--after the missing boat; kindling a
Title:  fire in her try-pots for a beacon; and every other man aloft on the
Title:  look-out.  But though when she had thus sailed a sufficient distance
Title:  to gain the presumed place of the absent ones when last seen; though
Title:  she then paused to lower her spare boats to pull all around her; and
Title:  not finding anything, had again dashed on; again paused, and lowered
Title:  her boats; and though she had thus continued doing till daylight;
Title:  yet not the least glimpse of the missing keel had been seen.
Title:  
Title:  The story told, the stranger Captain immediately went on to reveal
Title:  his object in boarding the Pequod.  He desired that ship to unite
Title:  with his own in the search; by sailing over the sea some four or five
Title:  miles apart, on parallel lines, and so sweeping a double horizon, as
Title:  it were.
Title:  
Title:  "I will wager something now," whispered Stubb to Flask, "that some
Title:  one in that missing boat wore off that Captain's best coat; mayhap,
Title:  his watch--he's so cursed anxious to get it back.  Who ever heard of
Title:  two pious whale-ships cruising after one missing whale-boat in the
Title:  height of the whaling season?  See, Flask, only see how pale he
Title:  looks--pale in the very buttons of his eyes--look--it wasn't the
Title:  coat--it must have been the--"
Title:  
Title:  "My boy, my own boy is among them.  For God's sake--I beg, I
Title:  conjure"--here exclaimed the stranger Captain to Ahab, who thus far
Title:  had but icily received his petition.  "For eight-and-forty hours let
Title:  me charter your ship--I will gladly pay for it, and roundly pay for
Title:  it--if there be no other way--for eight-and-forty hours only--only
Title:  that--you must, oh, you must, and you SHALL do this thing."
Title:  
Title:  "His son!" cried Stubb, "oh, it's his son he's lost!  I take back the
Title:  coat and watch--what says Ahab?  We must save that boy."
Title:  
Title:  "He's drowned with the rest on 'em, last night," said the old Manx
Title:  sailor standing behind them; "I heard; all of ye heard their
Title:  spirits."
Title:  
Title:  Now, as it shortly turned out, what made this incident of the
Title:  Rachel's the more melancholy, was the circumstance, that not only was
Title:  one of the Captain's sons among the number of the missing boat's
Title:  crew; but among the number of the other boat's crews, at the same
Title:  time, but on the other hand, separated from the ship during the dark
Title:  vicissitudes of the chase, there had been still another son; as that
Title:  for a time, the wretched father was plunged to the bottom of the
Title:  cruellest perplexity; which was only solved for him by his chief
Title:  mate's instinctively adopting the ordinary procedure of a whale-ship
Title:  in such emergencies, that is, when placed between jeopardized but
Title:  divided boats, always to pick up the majority first.  But the
Title:  captain, for some unknown constitutional reason, had refrained from
Title:  mentioning all this, and not till forced to it by Ahab's iciness did
Title:  he allude to his one yet missing boy; a little lad, but twelve years
Title:  old, whose father with the earnest but unmisgiving hardihood of a
Title:  Nantucketer's paternal love, had thus early sought to initiate him in
Title:  the perils and wonders of a vocation almost immemorially the destiny
Title:  of all his race.  Nor does it unfrequently occur, that Nantucket
Title:  captains will send a son of such tender age away from them, for a
Title:  protracted three or four years' voyage in some other ship than their
Title:  own; so that their first knowledge of a whaleman's career shall be
Title:  unenervated by any chance display of a father's natural but untimely
Title:  partiality, or undue apprehensiveness and concern.
Title:  
Title:  Meantime, now the stranger was still beseeching his poor boon of
Title:  Ahab; and Ahab still stood like an anvil, receiving every shock, but
Title:  without the least quivering of his own.
Title:  
Title:  "I will not go," said the stranger, "till you say aye to me.  Do to
Title:  me as you would have me do to you in the like case.  For YOU too have
Title:  a boy, Captain Ahab--though but a child, and nestling safely at home
Title:  now--a child of your old age too--Yes, yes, you relent; I see
Title:  it--run, run, men, now, and stand by to square in the yards."
Title:  
Title:  "Avast," cried Ahab--"touch not a rope-yarn"; then in a voice that
Title:  prolongingly moulded every word--"Captain Gardiner, I will not do it.
Title:  Even now I lose time.  Good-bye, good-bye.  God bless ye, man, and
Title:  may I forgive myself, but I must go.  Mr. Starbuck, look at the
Title:  binnacle watch, and in three minutes from this present instant warn
Title:  off all strangers: then brace forward again, and let the ship sail
Title:  as before."
Title:  
Title:  Hurriedly turning, with averted face, he descended into his cabin,
Title:  leaving the strange captain transfixed at this unconditional and
Title:  utter rejection of his so earnest suit.  But starting from his
Title:  enchantment, Gardiner silently hurried to the side; more fell than
Title:  stepped into his boat, and returned to his ship.
Title:  
Title:  Soon the two ships diverged their wakes; and long as the strange
Title:  vessel was in view, she was seen to yaw hither and thither at every
Title:  dark spot, however small, on the sea.  This way and that her yards
Title:  were swung round; starboard and larboard, she continued to tack;
Title:  now she beat against a head sea; and again it pushed her before it;
Title:  while all the while, her masts and yards were thickly clustered with
Title:  men, as three tall cherry trees, when the boys are cherrying among
Title:  the boughs.
Title:  
Title:  But by her still halting course and winding, woeful way, you plainly
Title:  saw that this ship that so wept with spray, still remained without
Title:  comfort.  She was Rachel, weeping for her children, because they were
Title:  not.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 129
Title:  
Title:  The Cabin.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  (AHAB MOVING TO GO ON DECK; PIP CATCHES HIM BY THE HAND TO FOLLOW.)
Title:  
Title:  Lad, lad, I tell thee thou must not follow Ahab now.  The hour is
Title:  coming when Ahab would not scare thee from him, yet would not have
Title:  thee by him.  There is that in thee, poor lad, which I feel too
Title:  curing to my malady.  Like cures like; and for this hunt, my malady
Title:  becomes my most desired health.  Do thou abide below here, where they
Title:  shall serve thee, as if thou wert the captain.  Aye, lad, thou shalt
Title:  sit here in my own screwed chair; another screw to it, thou must be."
Title:  
Title:  "No, no, no! ye have not a whole body, sir; do ye but use poor me for
Title:  your one lost leg; only tread upon me, sir; I ask no more, so I
Title:  remain a part of ye."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh! spite of million villains, this makes me a bigot in the fadeless
Title:  fidelity of man!--and a black! and crazy!--but methinks
Title:  like-cures-like applies to him too; he grows so sane again."
Title:  
Title:  "They tell me, sir, that Stubb did once desert poor little Pip, whose
Title:  drowned bones now show white, for all the blackness of his living
Title:  skin.  But I will never desert ye, sir, as Stubb did him.  Sir, I
Title:  must go with ye."
Title:  
Title:  "If thou speakest thus to me much more, Ahab's purpose keels up in
Title:  him.  I tell thee no; it cannot be."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh good master, master, master!
Title:  
Title:  "Weep so, and I will murder thee! have a care, for Ahab too is mad.
Title:  Listen, and thou wilt often hear my ivory foot upon the deck, and
Title:  still know that I am there.  And now I quit thee.  Thy hand!--Met!
Title:  True art thou, lad, as the circumference to its centre.  So: God for
Title:  ever bless thee; and if it come to that,--God for ever save thee, let
Title:  what will befall."
Title:  
Title:  (AHAB GOES; PIP STEPS ONE STEP FORWARD.)
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "Here he this instant stood; I stand in his air,--but I'm alone.
Title:  Now were even poor Pip here I could endure it, but he's missing.
Title:  Pip!  Pip!  Ding, dong, ding!  Who's seen Pip?  He must be up here;
Title:  let's try the door.  What? neither lock, nor bolt, nor bar; and yet
Title:  there's no opening it.  It must be the spell; he told me to stay
Title:  here: Aye, and told me this screwed chair was mine.  Here, then, I'll
Title:  seat me, against the transom, in the ship's full middle, all her keel
Title:  and her three masts before me.  Here, our old sailors say, in their
Title:  black seventy-fours great admirals sometimes sit at table, and lord
Title:  it over rows of captains and lieutenants.  Ha! what's this? epaulets!
Title:  epaulets! the epaulets all come crowding!  Pass round the decanters;
Title:  glad to see ye; fill up, monsieurs!  What an odd feeling, now, when a
Title:  black boy's host to white men with gold lace upon their
Title:  coats!--Monsieurs, have ye seen one Pip?--a little negro lad, five
Title:  feet high, hang-dog look, and cowardly!  Jumped from a whale-boat
Title:  once;--seen him?  No!  Well then, fill up again, captains, and let's
Title:  drink shame upon all cowards!  I name no names.  Shame upon them!
Title:  Put one foot upon the table.  Shame upon all cowards.--Hist! above
Title:  there, I hear ivory--Oh, master! master!  I am indeed down-hearted
Title:  when you walk over me.  But here I'll stay, though this stern
Title:  strikes rocks; and they bulge through; and oysters come to join me."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 130
Title:  
Title:  The Hat.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  And now that at the proper time and place, after so long and wide a
Title:  preliminary cruise, Ahab,--all other whaling waters swept--seemed to
Title:  have chased his foe into an ocean-fold, to slay him the more securely
Title:  there; now, that he found himself hard by the very latitude and
Title:  longitude where his tormenting wound had been inflicted; now that a
Title:  vessel had been spoken which on the very day preceding had actually
Title:  encountered Moby Dick;--and now that all his successive meetings with
Title:  various ships contrastingly concurred to show the demoniac
Title:  indifference with which the white whale tore his hunters, whether
Title:  sinning or sinned against; now it was that there lurked a something
Title:  in the old man's eyes, which it was hardly sufferable for feeble
Title:  souls to see.  As the unsetting polar star, which through the
Title:  livelong, arctic, six months' night sustains its piercing, steady,
Title:  central gaze; so Ahab's purpose now fixedly gleamed down upon the
Title:  constant midnight of the gloomy crew.  It domineered above them so,
Title:  that all their bodings, doubts, misgivings, fears, were fain to hide
Title:  beneath their souls, and not sprout forth a single spear or leaf.
Title:  
Title:  In this foreshadowing interval too, all humor, forced or natural,
Title:  vanished.  Stubb no more strove to raise a smile; Starbuck no more
Title:  strove to check one.  Alike, joy and sorrow, hope and fear, seemed
Title:  ground to finest dust, and powdered, for the time, in the clamped
Title:  mortar of Ahab's iron soul.  Like machines, they dumbly moved about
Title:  the deck, ever conscious that the old man's despot eye was on them.
Title:  
Title:  But did you deeply scan him in his more secret confidential hours;
Title:  when he thought no glance but one was on him; then you would have
Title:  seen that even as Ahab's eyes so awed the crew's, the inscrutable
Title:  Parsee's glance awed his; or somehow, at least, in some wild way, at
Title:  times affected it.  Such an added, gliding strangeness began to
Title:  invest the thin Fedallah now; such ceaseless shudderings shook him;
Title:  that the men looked dubious at him; half uncertain, as it seemed,
Title:  whether indeed he were a mortal substance, or else a tremulous shadow
Title:  cast upon the deck by some unseen being's body.  And that shadow was
Title:  always hovering there.  For not by night, even, had Fedallah ever
Title:  certainly been known to slumber, or go below.  He would stand still
Title:  for hours: but never sat or leaned; his wan but wondrous eyes did
Title:  plainly say--We two watchmen never rest.
Title:  
Title:  Nor, at any time, by night or day could the mariners now step upon
Title:  the deck, unless Ahab was before them; either standing in his
Title:  pivot-hole, or exactly pacing the planks between two undeviating
Title:  limits,--the main-mast and the mizen; or else they saw him standing
Title:  in the cabin-scuttle,--his living foot advanced upon the deck, as if
Title:  to step; his hat slouched heavily over his eyes; so that however
Title:  motionless he stood, however the days and nights were added on, that
