Title:  he had not swung in his hammock; yet hidden beneath that slouching
Title:  hat, they could never tell unerringly whether, for all this, his eyes
Title:  were really closed at times; or whether he was still intently
Title:  scanning them; no matter, though he stood so in the scuttle for a
Title:  whole hour on the stretch, and the unheeded night-damp gathered in
Title:  beads of dew upon that stone-carved coat and hat.  The clothes that
Title:  the night had wet, the next day's sunshine dried upon him; and so,
Title:  day after day, and night after night; he went no more beneath the
Title:  planks; whatever he wanted from the cabin that thing he sent for.
Title:  
Title:  He ate in the same open air; that is, his two only meals,--breakfast
Title:  and dinner: supper he never touched; nor reaped his beard; which
Title:  darkly grew all gnarled, as unearthed roots of trees blown over,
Title:  which still grow idly on at naked base, though perished in the upper
Title:  verdure.  But though his whole life was now become one watch on deck;
Title:  and though the Parsee's mystic watch was without intermission as his
Title:  own; yet these two never seemed to speak--one man to the
Title:  other--unless at long intervals some passing unmomentous matter made
Title:  it necessary.  Though such a potent spell seemed secretly to join the
Title:  twain; openly, and to the awe-struck crew, they seemed pole-like
Title:  asunder.  If by day they chanced to speak one word; by night, dumb
Title:  men were both, so far as concerned the slightest verbal interchange.
Title:  At times, for longest hours, without a single hail, they stood far
Title:  parted in the starlight; Ahab in his scuttle, the Parsee by the
Title:  mainmast; but still fixedly gazing upon each other; as if in the
Title:  Parsee Ahab saw his forethrown shadow, in Ahab the Parsee his
Title:  abandoned substance.
Title:  
Title:  And yet, somehow, did Ahab--in his own proper self, as daily, hourly,
Title:  and every instant, commandingly revealed to his subordinates,--Ahab
Title:  seemed an independent lord; the Parsee but his slave.  Still again
Title:  both seemed yoked together, and an unseen tyrant driving them; the
Title:  lean shade siding the solid rib.  For be this Parsee what he may, all
Title:  rib and keel was solid Ahab.
Title:  
Title:  At the first faintest glimmering of the dawn, his iron voice was
Title:  heard from aft,--"Man the mast-heads!"--and all through the day,
Title:  till after sunset and after twilight, the same voice every hour, at
Title:  the striking of the helmsman's bell, was heard--"What d'ye
Title:  see?--sharp! sharp!"
Title:  
Title:  But when three or four days had slided by, after meeting the
Title:  children-seeking Rachel; and no spout had yet been seen; the
Title:  monomaniac old man seemed distrustful of his crew's fidelity; at
Title:  least, of nearly all except the Pagan harpooneers; he seemed to
Title:  doubt, even, whether Stubb and Flask might not willingly overlook the
Title:  sight he sought.  But if these suspicions were really his, he
Title:  sagaciously refrained from verbally expressing them, however his
Title:  actions might seem to hint them.
Title:  
Title:  "I will have the first sight of the whale myself,"--he said.  "Aye!
Title:  Ahab must have the doubloon! and with his own hands he rigged a nest
Title:  of basketed bowlines; and sending a hand aloft, with a single sheaved
Title:  block, to secure to the main-mast head, he received the two ends of
Title:  the downward-reeved rope; and attaching one to his basket prepared a
Title:  pin for the other end, in order to fasten it at the rail.  This done,
Title:  with that end yet in his hand and standing beside the pin, he looked
Title:  round upon his crew, sweeping from one to the other; pausing his
Title:  glance long upon Daggoo, Queequeg, Tashtego; but shunning Fedallah;
Title:  and then settling his firm relying eye upon the chief mate,
Title:  said,--"Take the rope, sir--I give it into thy hands, Starbuck."
Title:  Then arranging his person in the basket, he gave the word for them to
Title:  hoist him to his perch, Starbuck being the one who secured the rope
Title:  at last; and afterwards stood near it.  And thus, with one hand
Title:  clinging round the royal mast, Ahab gazed abroad upon the sea for
Title:  miles and miles,--ahead, astern, this side, and that,--within the
Title:  wide expanded circle commanded at so great a height.
Title:  
Title:  When in working with his hands at some lofty almost isolated place in
Title:  the rigging, which chances to afford no foothold, the sailor at sea
Title:  is hoisted up to that spot, and sustained there by the rope; under
Title:  these circumstances, its fastened end on deck is always given in
Title:  strict charge to some one man who has the special watch of it.
Title:  Because in such a wilderness of running rigging, whose various
Title:  different relations aloft cannot always be infallibly discerned by
Title:  what is seen of them at the deck; and when the deck-ends of these
Title:  ropes are being every few minutes cast down from the fastenings, it
Title:  would be but a natural fatality, if, unprovided with a constant
Title:  watchman, the hoisted sailor should by some carelessness of the crew
Title:  be cast adrift and fall all swooping to the sea.  So Ahab's
Title:  proceedings in this matter were not unusual; the only strange thing
Title:  about them seemed to be, that Starbuck, almost the one only man who
Title:  had ever ventured to oppose him with anything in the slightest degree
Title:  approaching to decision--one of those too, whose faithfulness on the
Title:  look-out he had seemed to doubt somewhat;--it was strange, that this
Title:  was the very man he should select for his watchman; freely giving his
Title:  whole life into such an otherwise distrusted person's hands.
Title:  
Title:  Now, the first time Ahab was perched aloft; ere he had been there ten
Title:  minutes; one of those red-billed savage sea-hawks which so often fly
Title:  incommodiously close round the manned mast-heads of whalemen in these
Title:  latitudes; one of these birds came wheeling and screaming round his
Title:  head in a maze of untrackably swift circlings.  Then it darted a
Title:  thousand feet straight up into the air; then spiralized downwards,
Title:  and went eddying again round his head.
Title:  
Title:  But with his gaze fixed upon the dim and distant horizon, Ahab seemed
Title:  not to mark this wild bird; nor, indeed, would any one else have
Title:  marked it much, it being no uncommon circumstance; only now almost
Title:  the least heedful eye seemed to see some sort of cunning meaning in
Title:  almost every sight.
Title:  
Title:  "Your hat, your hat, sir!" suddenly cried the Sicilian seaman, who
Title:  being posted at the mizen-mast-head, stood directly behind Ahab,
Title:  though somewhat lower than his level, and with a deep gulf of air
Title:  dividing them.
Title:  
Title:  But already the sable wing was before the old man's eyes; the long
Title:  hooked bill at his head: with a scream, the black hawk darted away
Title:  with his prize.
Title:  
Title:  An eagle flew thrice round Tarquin's head, removing his cap to
Title:  replace it, and thereupon Tanaquil, his wife, declared that Tarquin
Title:  would be king of Rome.  But only by the replacing of the cap was that
Title:  omen accounted good.  Ahab's hat was never restored; the wild hawk
Title:  flew on and on with it; far in advance of the prow: and at last
Title:  disappeared; while from the point of that disappearance, a minute
Title:  black spot was dimly discerned, falling from that vast height into
Title:  the sea.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 131
Title:  
Title:  The Pequod Meets The Delight.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  The intense Pequod sailed on; the rolling waves and days went by; the
Title:  life-buoy-coffin still lightly swung; and another ship, most
Title:  miserably misnamed the Delight, was descried.  As she drew nigh, all
Title:  eyes were fixed upon her broad beams, called shears, which, in some
Title:  whaling-ships, cross the quarter-deck at the height of eight or nine
Title:  feet; serving to carry the spare, unrigged, or disabled boats.
Title:  
Title:  Upon the stranger's shears were beheld the shattered, white ribs, and
Title:  some few splintered planks, of what had once been a whale-boat; but
Title:  you now saw through this wreck, as plainly as you see through the
Title:  peeled, half-unhinged, and bleaching skeleton of a horse.
Title:  
Title:  "Hast seen the White Whale?"
Title:  
Title:  "Look!" replied the hollow-cheeked captain from his taffrail; and
Title:  with his trumpet he pointed to the wreck.
Title:  
Title:  "Hast killed him?"
Title:  
Title:  "The harpoon is not yet forged that ever will do that," answered the
Title:  other, sadly glancing upon a rounded hammock on the deck, whose
Title:  gathered sides some noiseless sailors were busy in sewing together.
Title:  
Title:  "Not forged!" and snatching Perth's levelled iron from the crotch,
Title:  Ahab held it out, exclaiming--"Look ye, Nantucketer; here in this
Title:  hand I hold his death!  Tempered in blood, and tempered by lightning
Title:  are these barbs; and I swear to temper them triply in that hot place
Title:  behind the fin, where the White Whale most feels his accursed life!"
Title:  
Title:  "Then God keep thee, old man--see'st thou that"--pointing to the
Title:  hammock--"I bury but one of five stout men, who were alive only
Title:  yesterday; but were dead ere night.  Only THAT one I bury; the rest
Title:  were buried before they died; you sail upon their tomb."  Then
Title:  turning to his crew--"Are ye ready there? place the plank then on the
Title:  rail, and lift the body; so, then--Oh!  God"--advancing towards the
Title:  hammock with uplifted hands--"may the resurrection and the life--"
Title:  
Title:  "Brace forward!  Up helm!" cried Ahab like lightning to his men.
Title:  
Title:  But the suddenly started Pequod was not quick enough to escape the
Title:  sound of the splash that the corpse soon made as it struck the sea;
Title:  not so quick, indeed, but that some of the flying bubbles might have
Title:  sprinkled her hull with their ghostly baptism.
Title:  
Title:  As Ahab now glided from the dejected Delight, the strange life-buoy
Title:  hanging at the Pequod's stern came into conspicuous relief.
Title:  
Title:  "Ha! yonder! look yonder, men!" cried a foreboding voice in her wake.
Title:  "In vain, oh, ye strangers, ye fly our sad burial; ye but turn us
Title:  your taffrail to show us your coffin!"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 132
Title:  
Title:  The Symphony.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  It was a clear steel-blue day.  The firmaments of air and sea were
Title:  hardly separable in that all-pervading azure; only, the pensive air
Title:  was transparently pure and soft, with a woman's look, and the robust
Title:  and man-like sea heaved with long, strong, lingering swells, as
Title:  Samson's chest in his sleep.
Title:  
Title:  Hither, and thither, on high, glided the snow-white wings of small,
Title:  unspeckled birds; these were the gentle thoughts of the feminine air;
Title:  but to and fro in the deeps, far down in the bottomless blue, rushed
Title:  mighty leviathans, sword-fish, and sharks; and these were the strong,
Title:  troubled, murderous thinkings of the masculine sea.
Title:  
Title:  But though thus contrasting within, the contrast was only in shades
Title:  and shadows without; those two seemed one; it was only the sex, as it
Title:  were, that distinguished them.
Title:  
Title:  Aloft, like a royal czar and king, the sun seemed giving this gentle
Title:  air to this bold and rolling sea; even as bride to groom.  And at the
Title:  girdling line of the horizon, a soft and tremulous motion--most seen
Title:  here at the Equator--denoted the fond, throbbing trust, the loving
Title:  alarms, with which the poor bride gave her bosom away.
Title:  
Title:  Tied up and twisted; gnarled and knotted with wrinkles; haggardly
Title:  firm and unyielding; his eyes glowing like coals, that still glow in
Title:  the ashes of ruin; untottering Ahab stood forth in the clearness of
Title:  the morn; lifting his splintered helmet of a brow to the fair girl's
Title:  forehead of heaven.
Title:  
Title:  Oh, immortal infancy, and innocency of the azure!  Invisible winged
Title:  creatures that frolic all round us!  Sweet childhood of air and sky!
Title:  how oblivious were ye of old Ahab's close-coiled woe!  But so have I
Title:  seen little Miriam and Martha, laughing-eyed elves, heedlessly gambol
Title:  around their old sire; sporting with the circle of singed locks which
Title:  grew on the marge of that burnt-out crater of his brain.
Title:  
Title:  Slowly crossing the deck from the scuttle, Ahab leaned over the side
Title:  and watched how his shadow in the water sank and sank to his gaze,
Title:  the more and the more that he strove to pierce the profundity.  But
Title:  the lovely aromas in that enchanted air did at last seem to dispel,
Title:  for a moment, the cankerous thing in his soul.  That glad, happy air,
Title:  that winsome sky, did at last stroke and caress him; the step-mother
Title:  world, so long cruel--forbidding--now threw affectionate arms round
Title:  his stubborn neck, and did seem to joyously sob over him, as if over
Title:  one, that however wilful and erring, she could yet find it in her
Title:  heart to save and to bless.  From beneath his slouched hat Ahab
Title:  dropped a tear into the sea; nor did all the Pacific contain such
Title:  wealth as that one wee drop.
Title:  
Title:  Starbuck saw the old man; saw him, how he heavily leaned over the
Title:  side; and he seemed to hear in his own true heart the measureless
Title:  sobbing that stole out of the centre of the serenity around.  Careful
Title:  not to touch him, or be noticed by him, he yet drew near to him, and
Title:  stood there.
Title:  
Title:  Ahab turned.
Title:  
Title:  "Starbuck!"
Title:  
Title:  "Sir."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, Starbuck! it is a mild, mild wind, and a mild looking sky.  On
Title:  such a day--very much such a sweetness as this--I struck my first
Title:  whale--a boy-harpooneer of eighteen!  Forty--forty--forty years
Title:  ago!--ago!  Forty years of continual whaling! forty years of
Title:  privation, and peril, and storm-time! forty years on the pitiless
Title:  sea! for forty years has Ahab forsaken the peaceful land, for forty
Title:  years to make war on the horrors of the deep!  Aye and yes, Starbuck,
Title:  out of those forty years I have not spent three ashore.  When I think
Title:  of this life I have led; the desolation of solitude it has been; the
Title:  masoned, walled-town of a Captain's exclusiveness, which admits but
Title:  small entrance to any sympathy from the green country without--oh,
Title:  weariness! heaviness!  Guinea-coast slavery of solitary
Title:  command!--when I think of all this; only half-suspected, not so
Title:  keenly known to me before--and how for forty years I have fed upon
Title:  dry salted fare--fit emblem of the dry nourishment of my soil!--when
Title:  the poorest landsman has had fresh fruit to his daily hand, and
Title:  broken the world's fresh bread to my mouldy crusts--away, whole
Title:  oceans away, from that young girl-wife I wedded past fifty, and
Title:  sailed for Cape Horn the next day, leaving but one dent in my
Title:  marriage pillow--wife? wife?--rather a widow with her husband alive!
Title:  Aye, I widowed that poor girl when I married her, Starbuck; and
Title:  then, the madness, the frenzy, the boiling blood and the smoking
Title:  brow, with which, for a thousand lowerings old Ahab has furiously,
Title:  foamingly chased his prey--more a demon than a man!--aye, aye! what a
Title:  forty years' fool--fool--old fool, has old Ahab been!  Why this
Title:  strife of the chase? why weary, and palsy the arm at the oar, and the
Title:  iron, and the lance? how the richer or better is Ahab now?  Behold.
Title:  Oh, Starbuck! is it not hard, that with this weary load I bear, one
Title:  poor leg should have been snatched from under me?  Here, brush this
Title:  old hair aside; it blinds me, that I seem to weep.  Locks so grey did
Title:  never grow but from out some ashes!  But do I look very old, so very,
Title:  very old, Starbuck?  I feel deadly faint, bowed, and humped, as
Title:  though I were Adam, staggering beneath the piled centuries since
Title:  Paradise.  God!  God!  God!--crack my heart!--stave my
Title:  brain!--mockery! mockery! bitter, biting mockery of grey hairs, have
Title:  I lived enough joy to wear ye; and seem and feel thus intolerably
Title:  old?  Close! stand close to me, Starbuck; let me look into a human
Title:  eye; it is better than to gaze into sea or sky; better than to gaze
Title:  upon God.  By the green land; by the bright hearth-stone! this is the
Title:  magic glass, man; I see my wife and my child in thine eye.  No, no;
Title:  stay on board, on board!--lower not when I do; when branded Ahab
Title:  gives chase to Moby Dick.  That hazard shall not be thine.  No, no!
Title:  not with the far away home I see in that eye!"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my Captain! my Captain! noble soul! grand old heart, after all!
Title:  why should any one give chase to that hated fish!  Away with me! let
Title:  us fly these deadly waters! let us home!  Wife and child, too, are
Title:  Starbuck's--wife and child of his brotherly, sisterly, play-fellow
Title:  youth; even as thine, sir, are the wife and child of thy loving,
Title:  longing, paternal old age!  Away! let us away!--this instant let me
Title:  alter the course!  How cheerily, how hilariously, O my Captain, would
Title:  we bowl on our way to see old Nantucket again!  I think, sir, they
Title:  have some such mild blue days, even as this, in Nantucket."
Title:  
Title:  "They have, they have.  I have seen them--some summer days in the
Title:  morning.  About this time--yes, it is his noon nap now--the boy
Title:  vivaciously wakes; sits up in bed; and his mother tells him of me, of
Title:  cannibal old me; how I am abroad upon the deep, but will yet come
Title:  back to dance him again."
Title:  
Title:  "'Tis my Mary, my Mary herself!  She promised that my boy, every
Title:  morning, should be carried to the hill to catch the first glimpse of
Title:  his father's sail!  Yes, yes! no more! it is done! we head for
Title:  Nantucket!  Come, my Captain, study out the course, and let us away!
Title:  See, see! the boy's face from the window! the boy's hand on the
Title:  hill!"
Title:  
Title:  But Ahab's glance was averted; like a blighted fruit tree he shook,
Title:  and cast his last, cindered apple to the soil.
Title:  
Title:  "What is it, what nameless, inscrutable, unearthly thing is it; what
Title:  cozening, hidden lord and master, and cruel, remorseless emperor
Title:  commands me; that against all natural lovings and longings, I so keep
Title:  pushing, and crowding, and jamming myself on all the time; recklessly
Title:  making me ready to do what in my own proper, natural heart, I durst
Title:  not so much as dare?  Is Ahab, Ahab?  Is it I, God, or who, that
Title:  lifts this arm?  But if the great sun move not of himself; but is as an
Title:  errand-boy in heaven; nor one single star can revolve, but by some
Title:  invisible power; how then can this one small heart beat; this one
Title:  small brain think thoughts; unless God does that beating, does that
Title:  thinking, does that living, and not I.  By heaven, man, we are turned
Title:  round and round in this world, like yonder windlass, and Fate is the
Title:  handspike.  And all the time, lo! that smiling sky, and this
Title:  unsounded sea!  Look! see yon Albicore! who put it into him to chase
Title:  and fang that flying-fish?  Where do murderers go, man!  Who's to
Title:  doom, when the judge himself is dragged to the bar?  But it is a
Title:  mild, mild wind, and a mild looking sky; and the air smells now, as
Title:  if it blew from a far-away meadow; they have been making hay
Title:  somewhere under the slopes of the Andes, Starbuck, and the mowers are
Title:  sleeping among the new-mown hay.  Sleeping?  Aye, toil we how we may,
Title:  we all sleep at last on the field.  Sleep?  Aye, and rust amid
Title:  greenness; as last year's scythes flung down, and left in the half-cut
Title:  swaths--Starbuck!"
Title:  
Title:  But blanched to a corpse's hue with despair, the Mate had stolen
Title:  away.
Title:  
Title:  Ahab crossed the deck to gaze over on the other side; but started at
Title:  two reflected, fixed eyes in the water there.  Fedallah was
Title:  motionlessly leaning over the same rail.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 133
Title:  
Title:  The Chase--First Day.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  That night, in the mid-watch, when the old man--as his wont at
Title:  intervals--stepped forth from the scuttle in which he leaned, and
Title:  went to his pivot-hole, he suddenly thrust out his face fiercely,
Title:  snuffing up the sea air as a sagacious ship's dog will, in drawing
Title:  nigh to some barbarous isle.  He declared that a whale must be near.
Title:  Soon that peculiar odor, sometimes to a great distance given forth by
Title:  the living sperm whale, was palpable to all the watch; nor was any
Title:  mariner surprised when, after inspecting the compass, and then the
Title:  dog-vane, and then ascertaining the precise bearing of the odor as
Title:  nearly as possible, Ahab rapidly ordered the ship's course to be
Title:  slightly altered, and the sail to be shortened.
Title:  
Title:  The acute policy dictating these movements was sufficiently
Title:  vindicated at daybreak, by the sight of a long sleek on the sea
Title:  directly and lengthwise ahead, smooth as oil, and resembling in the
Title:  pleated watery wrinkles bordering it, the polished metallic-like
Title:  marks of some swift tide-rip, at the mouth of a deep, rapid stream.
Title:  
Title:  "Man the mast-heads!  Call all hands!"
Title:  
Title:  Thundering with the butts of three clubbed handspikes on the
Title:  forecastle deck, Daggoo roused the sleepers with such judgment claps
Title:  that they seemed to exhale from the scuttle, so instantaneously did
Title:  they appear with their clothes in their hands.
Title:  
Title:  "What d'ye see?" cried Ahab, flattening his face to the sky.
Title:  
Title:  "Nothing, nothing sir!" was the sound hailing down in reply.
Title:  
Title:  "T'gallant sails!--stunsails! alow and aloft, and on both sides!"
Title:  
Title:  All sail being set, he now cast loose the life-line, reserved for
Title:  swaying him to the main royal-mast head; and in a few moments they
Title:  were hoisting him thither, when, while but two thirds of the way
Title:  aloft, and while peering ahead through the horizontal vacancy between
Title:  the main-top-sail and top-gallant-sail, he raised a gull-like cry in
Title:  the air.  "There she blows!--there she blows!  A hump like a
Title:  snow-hill!  It is Moby Dick!"
Title:  
Title:  Fired by the cry which seemed simultaneously taken up by the three
Title:  look-outs, the men on deck rushed to the rigging to behold the famous
Title:  whale they had so long been pursuing.  Ahab had now gained his final
Title:  perch, some feet above the other look-outs, Tashtego standing just
Title:  beneath him on the cap of the top-gallant-mast, so that the Indian's
Title:  head was almost on a level with Ahab's heel.  From this height the
Title:  whale was now seen some mile or so ahead, at every roll of the sea
Title:  revealing his high sparkling hump, and regularly jetting his silent
Title:  spout into the air.  To the credulous mariners it seemed the same
Title:  silent spout they had so long ago beheld in the moonlit Atlantic and
Title:  Indian Oceans.
Title:  
Title:  "And did none of ye see it before?" cried Ahab, hailing the perched
Title:  men all around him.
Title:  
Title:  "I saw him almost that same instant, sir, that Captain Ahab did, and
Title:  I cried out," said Tashtego.
Title:  
Title:  "Not the same instant; not the same--no, the doubloon is mine, Fate
Title:  reserved the doubloon for me.  I only; none of ye could have raised
Title:  the White Whale first.  There she blows!--there she blows!--there
Title:  she blows!  There again!--there again!" he cried, in long-drawn,
Title:  lingering, methodic tones, attuned to the gradual prolongings of the
Title:  whale's visible jets.  "He's going to sound!  In stunsails!  Down
Title:  top-gallant-sails!  Stand by three boats.  Mr. Starbuck, remember,
Title:  stay on board, and keep the ship.  Helm there!  Luff, luff a point!
Title:  So; steady, man, steady!  There go flukes!  No, no; only black water!
Title:  All ready the boats there?  Stand by, stand by!  Lower me, Mr.
Title:  Starbuck; lower, lower,--quick, quicker!" and he slid through the air
Title:  to the deck.
Title:  
Title:  "He is heading straight to leeward, sir," cried Stubb, "right away
Title:  from us; cannot have seen the ship yet."
Title:  
Title:  "Be dumb, man!  Stand by the braces!  Hard down the helm!--brace up!
Title:  Shiver her!--shiver her!--So; well that!  Boats, boats!"
Title:  
Title:  Soon all the boats but Starbuck's were dropped; all the boat-sails
Title:  set--all the paddles plying; with rippling swiftness, shooting to
Title:  leeward; and Ahab heading the onset.  A pale, death-glimmer lit up
Title:  Fedallah's sunken eyes; a hideous motion gnawed his mouth.
Title:  
Title:  Like noiseless nautilus shells, their light prows sped through the
Title:  sea; but only slowly they neared the foe.  As they neared him, the
Title:  ocean grew still more smooth; seemed drawing a carpet over its waves;
Title:  seemed a noon-meadow, so serenely it spread.  At length the
Title:  breathless hunter came so nigh his seemingly unsuspecting prey, that his
Title:  entire dazzling hump was distinctly visible, sliding along the sea as
Title:  if an isolated thing, and continually set in a revolving ring of
Title:  finest, fleecy, greenish foam.  He saw the vast, involved wrinkles of
Title:  the slightly projecting head beyond.  Before it, far out on the soft
Title:  Turkish-rugged waters, went the glistening white shadow from his
Title:  broad, milky forehead, a musical rippling playfully accompanying the
Title:  shade; and behind, the blue waters interchangeably flowed over into
Title:  the moving valley of his steady wake; and on either hand bright
Title:  bubbles arose and danced by his side.  But these were broken again by
Title:  the light toes of hundreds of gay fowl softly feathering the sea,
Title:  alternate with their fitful flight; and like to some flag-staff
Title:  rising from the painted hull of an argosy, the tall but shattered
Title:  pole of a recent lance projected from the white whale's back; and at
Title:  intervals one of the cloud of soft-toed fowls hovering, and to and
Title:  fro skimming like a canopy over the fish, silently perched and rocked
Title:  on this pole, the long tail feathers streaming like pennons.
Title:  
Title:  A gentle joyousness--a mighty mildness of repose in swiftness,
Title:  invested the gliding whale.  Not the white bull Jupiter swimming away
Title:  with ravished Europa clinging to his graceful horns; his lovely,
Title:  leering eyes sideways intent upon the maid; with smooth bewitching
Title:  fleetness, rippling straight for the nuptial bower in Crete; not
Title:  Jove, not that great majesty Supreme! did surpass the glorified White
Title:  Whale as he so divinely swam.
Title:  
Title:  On each soft side--coincident with the parted swell, that but once
Title:  leaving him, then flowed so wide away--on each bright side, the whale
Title:  shed off enticings.  No wonder there had been some among the hunters
Title:  who namelessly transported and allured by all this serenity, had
Title:  ventured to assail it; but had fatally found that quietude but the
Title:  vesture of tornadoes.  Yet calm, enticing calm, oh, whale! thou
Title:  glidest on, to all who for the first time eye thee, no matter how
Title:  many in that same way thou may'st have bejuggled and destroyed
Title:  before.
Title:  
Title:  And thus, through the serene tranquillities of the tropical sea,
Title:  among waves whose hand-clappings were suspended by exceeding rapture,
Title:  Moby Dick moved on, still withholding from sight the full terrors of
Title:  his submerged trunk, entirely hiding the wrenched hideousness of his
Title:  jaw.  But soon the fore part of him slowly rose from the water; for
Title:  an instant his whole marbleized body formed a high arch, like
Title:  Virginia's Natural Bridge, and warningly waving his bannered flukes
Title:  in the air, the grand god revealed himself, sounded, and went out of
Title:  sight.  Hoveringly halting, and dipping on the wing, the white
Title:  sea-fowls longingly lingered over the agitated pool that he left.
Title:  
Title:  With oars apeak, and paddles down, the sheets of their sails adrift,
Title:  the three boats now stilly floated, awaiting Moby Dick's
Title:  reappearance.
Title:  
Title:  "An hour," said Ahab, standing rooted in his boat's stern; and he
Title:  gazed beyond the whale's place, towards the dim blue spaces and wide
Title:  wooing vacancies to leeward.  It was only an instant; for again his
Title:  eyes seemed whirling round in his head as he swept the watery circle.
Title:  The breeze now freshened; the sea began to swell.
Title:  
Title:  "The birds!--the birds!" cried Tashtego.
Title:  
Title:  In long Indian file, as when herons take wing, the white birds were
Title:  now all flying towards Ahab's boat; and when within a few yards began
Title:  fluttering over the water there, wheeling round and round, with
Title:  joyous, expectant cries.  Their vision was keener than man's; Ahab
Title:  could discover no sign in the sea.  But suddenly as he peered down
Title:  and down into its depths, he profoundly saw a white living spot no
Title:  bigger than a white weasel, with wonderful celerity uprising, and
Title:  magnifying as it rose, till it turned, and then there were plainly
Title:  revealed two long crooked rows of white, glistening teeth, floating
Title:  up from the undiscoverable bottom.  It was Moby Dick's open mouth and
Title:  scrolled jaw; his vast, shadowed bulk still half blending with the
Title:  blue of the sea.  The glittering mouth yawned beneath the boat like
Title:  an open-doored marble tomb; and giving one sidelong sweep with his
Title:  steering oar, Ahab whirled the craft aside from this tremendous
Title:  apparition.  Then, calling upon Fedallah to change places with him,
Title:  went forward to the bows, and seizing Perth's harpoon, commanded his
Title:  crew to grasp their oars and stand by to stern.
Title:  
Title:  Now, by reason of this timely spinning round the boat upon its axis,
Title:  its bow, by anticipation, was made to face the whale's head while yet
Title:  under water.  But as if perceiving this stratagem, Moby Dick, with
Title:  that malicious intelligence ascribed to him, sidelingly transplanted
Title:  himself, as it were, in an instant, shooting his pleated head
Title:  lengthwise beneath the boat.
Title:  
Title:  Through and through; through every plank and each rib, it thrilled
Title:  for an instant, the whale obliquely lying on his back, in the manner
Title:  of a biting shark, slowly and feelingly taking its bows full within
Title:  his mouth, so that the long, narrow, scrolled lower jaw curled high
Title:  up into the open air, and one of the teeth caught in a row-lock.  The
Title:  bluish pearl-white of the inside of the jaw was within six inches of
Title:  Ahab's head, and reached higher than that.  In this attitude the
Title:  White Whale now shook the slight cedar as a mildly cruel cat her
Title:  mouse.  With unastonished eyes Fedallah gazed, and crossed his arms;
Title:  but the tiger-yellow crew were tumbling over each other's heads to
Title:  gain the uttermost stern.
Title:  
Title:  And now, while both elastic gunwales were springing in and out, as
Title:  the whale dallied with the doomed craft in this devilish way; and
Title:  from his body being submerged beneath the boat, he could not be
Title:  darted at from the bows, for the bows were almost inside of him, as
Title:  it were; and while the other boats involuntarily paused, as before a
Title:  quick crisis impossible to withstand, then it was that monomaniac
Title:  Ahab, furious with this tantalizing vicinity of his foe, which placed
Title:  him all alive and helpless in the very jaws he hated; frenzied with
Title:  all this, he seized the long bone with his naked hands, and wildly
Title:  strove to wrench it from its gripe.  As now he thus vainly strove,
Title:  the jaw slipped from him; the frail gunwales bent in, collapsed, and
Title:  snapped, as both jaws, like an enormous shears, sliding further aft,
Title:  bit the craft completely in twain, and locked themselves fast again
Title:  in the sea, midway between the two floating wrecks.  These floated
Title:  aside, the broken ends drooping, the crew at the stern-wreck clinging
Title:  to the gunwales, and striving to hold fast to the oars to lash them
Title:  across.
Title:  
Title:  At that preluding moment, ere the boat was yet snapped, Ahab, the
Title:  first to perceive the whale's intent, by the crafty upraising of his
Title:  head, a movement that loosed his hold for the time; at that moment
Title:  his hand had made one final effort to push the boat out of the bite.
Title:  But only slipping further into the whale's mouth, and tilting over
Title:  sideways as it slipped, the boat had shaken off his hold on the jaw;
Title:  spilled him out of it, as he leaned to the push; and so he fell
Title:  flat-faced upon the sea.
Title:  
Title:  Ripplingly withdrawing from his prey, Moby Dick now lay at a little
Title:  distance, vertically thrusting his oblong white head up and down in
Title:  the billows; and at the same time slowly revolving his whole spindled
Title:  body; so that when his vast wrinkled forehead rose--some twenty or
Title:  more feet out of the water--the now rising swells, with all their
Title:  confluent waves, dazzlingly broke against it; vindictively tossing
Title:  their shivered spray still higher into the air.*  So, in a gale, the
Title:  but half baffled Channel billows only recoil from the base of the
Title:  Eddystone, triumphantly to overleap its summit with their scud.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  *This motion is peculiar to the sperm whale.  It receives its
Title:  designation (pitchpoling) from its being likened to that preliminary
Title:  up-and-down poise of the whale-lance, in the exercise called
Title:  pitchpoling, previously described.  By this motion the whale must
Title:  best and most comprehensively view whatever objects may be encircling
Title:  him.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  But soon resuming his horizontal attitude, Moby Dick swam swiftly
Title:  round and round the wrecked crew; sideways churning the water in his
Title:  vengeful wake, as if lashing himself up to still another and more
Title:  deadly assault.  The sight of the splintered boat seemed to madden
Title:  him, as the blood of grapes and mulberries cast before Antiochus's
Title:  elephants in the book of Maccabees.  Meanwhile Ahab half smothered in
Title:  the foam of the whale's insolent tail, and too much of a cripple to
Title:  swim,--though he could still keep afloat, even in the heart of such a
Title:  whirlpool as that; helpless Ahab's head was seen, like a tossed
Title:  bubble which the least chance shock might burst.  From the boat's
Title:  fragmentary stern, Fedallah incuriously and mildly eyed him; the
Title:  clinging crew, at the other drifting end, could not succor him; more
Title:  than enough was it for them to look to themselves.  For so
Title:  revolvingly appalling was the White Whale's aspect, and so
Title:  planetarily swift the ever-contracting circles he made, that he
Title:  seemed horizontally swooping upon them.  And though the other boats,
Title:  unharmed, still hovered hard by; still they dared not pull into the
Title:  eddy to strike, lest that should be the signal for the instant
Title:  destruction of the jeopardized castaways, Ahab and all; nor in that
Title:  case could they themselves hope to escape.  With straining eyes,
Title:  then, they remained on the outer edge of the direful zone, whose
Title:  centre had now become the old man's head.
Title:  
Title:  Meantime, from the beginning all this had been descried from the
Title:  ship's mast heads; and squaring her yards, she had borne down upon
Title:  the scene; and was now so nigh, that Ahab in the water hailed
Title:  her!--"Sail on the"--but that moment a breaking sea dashed on him
Title:  from Moby Dick, and whelmed him for the time.  But struggling out of
Title:  it again, and chancing to rise on a towering crest, he
Title:  shouted,--"Sail on the whale!--Drive him off!"
Title:  
Title:  The Pequod's prows were pointed; and breaking up the charmed circle,
Title:  she effectually parted the white whale from his victim.  As he
Title:  sullenly swam off, the boats flew to the rescue.
Title:  
Title:  Dragged into Stubb's boat with blood-shot, blinded eyes, the white
Title:  brine caking in his wrinkles; the long tension of Ahab's bodily
Title:  strength did crack, and helplessly he yielded to his body's doom: for
Title:  a time, lying all crushed in the bottom of Stubb's boat, like one
Title:  trodden under foot of herds of elephants.  Far inland, nameless wails
Title:  came from him, as desolate sounds from out ravines.
Title:  
Title:  But this intensity of his physical prostration did but so much the
Title:  more abbreviate it.  In an instant's compass, great hearts sometimes
Title:  condense to one deep pang, the sum total of those shallow pains
Title:  kindly diffused through feebler men's whole lives.  And so, such
Title:  hearts, though summary in each one suffering; still, if the gods
Title:  decree it, in their life-time aggregate a whole age of woe, wholly
Title:  made up of instantaneous intensities; for even in their pointless
Title:  centres, those noble natures contain the entire circumferences of
Title:  inferior souls.
Title:  
Title:  "The harpoon," said Ahab, half way rising, and draggingly leaning on
Title:  one bended arm--"is it safe?"
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, sir, for it was not darted; this is it," said Stubb, showing
Title:  it.
Title:  
Title:  "Lay it before me;--any missing men?"
Title:  
Title:  "One, two, three, four, five;--there were five oars, sir, and here
Title:  are five men."
Title:  
Title:  "That's good.--Help me, man; I wish to stand.  So, so, I see him!
Title:  there! there! going to leeward still; what a leaping spout!--Hands
Title:  off from me!  The eternal sap runs up in Ahab's bones again!  Set the
Title:  sail; out oars; the helm!"
Title:  
Title:  It is often the case that when a boat is stove, its crew, being
Title:  picked up by another boat, help to work that second boat; and the
Title:  chase is thus continued with what is called double-banked oars.  It
Title:  was thus now.  But the added power of the boat did not equal the
Title:  added power of the whale, for he seemed to have treble-banked his
Title:  every fin; swimming with a velocity which plainly showed, that if
Title:  now, under these circumstances, pushed on, the chase would prove an
Title:  indefinitely prolonged, if not a hopeless one; nor could any crew
Title:  endure for so long a period, such an unintermitted, intense straining
Title:  at the oar; a thing barely tolerable only in some one brief
Title:  vicissitude.  The ship itself, then, as it sometimes happens, offered
Title:  the most promising intermediate means of overtaking the chase.
Title:  Accordingly, the boats now made for her, and were soon swayed up to
Title:  their cranes--the two parts of the wrecked boat having been
Title:  previously secured by her--and then hoisting everything to her side,
Title:  and stacking her canvas high up, and sideways outstretching it with
Title:  stun-sails, like the double-jointed wings of an albatross; the Pequod
Title:  bore down in the leeward wake of Moby-Dick.  At the well known,
Title:  methodic intervals, the whale's glittering spout was regularly
Title:  announced from the manned mast-heads; and when he would be reported
Title:  as just gone down, Ahab would take the time, and then pacing the
Title:  deck, binnacle-watch in hand, so soon as the last second of the
Title:  allotted hour expired, his voice was heard.--"Whose is the doubloon
Title:  now?  D'ye see him?" and if the reply was, No, sir! straightway he
Title:  commanded them to lift him to his perch.  In this way the day wore
Title:  on; Ahab, now aloft and motionless; anon, unrestingly pacing the
Title:  planks.
Title:  
Title:  As he was thus walking, uttering no sound, except to hail the men
Title:  aloft, or to bid them hoist a sail still higher, or to spread one to
Title:  a still greater breadth--thus to and fro pacing, beneath his slouched
Title:  hat, at every turn he passed his own wrecked boat, which had been
Title:  dropped upon the quarter-deck, and lay there reversed; broken bow to
Title:  shattered stern.  At last he paused before it; and as in an already
Title:  over-clouded sky fresh troops of clouds will sometimes sail across,
Title:  so over the old man's face there now stole some such added gloom as
Title:  this.
Title:  
Title:  Stubb saw him pause; and perhaps intending, not vainly, though, to
Title:  evince his own unabated fortitude, and thus keep up a valiant place
Title:  in his Captain's mind, he advanced, and eyeing the wreck
Title:  exclaimed--"The thistle the ass refused; it pricked his mouth too
Title:  keenly, sir; ha! ha!"
Title:  
Title:  "What soulless thing is this that laughs before a wreck?  Man, man!
Title:  did I not know thee brave as fearless fire (and as mechanical) I
Title:  could swear thou wert a poltroon.  Groan nor laugh should be heard
Title:  before a wreck."
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, sir," said Starbuck drawing near, "'tis a solemn sight; an
Title:  omen, and an ill one."
Title:  
Title:  "Omen? omen?--the dictionary!  If the gods think to speak outright to
Title:  man, they will honourably speak outright; not shake their heads, and
Title:  give an old wives' darkling hint.--Begone!  Ye two are the opposite
Title:  poles of one thing; Starbuck is Stubb reversed, and Stubb is
Title:  Starbuck; and ye two are all mankind; and Ahab stands alone among the
Title:  millions of the peopled earth, nor gods nor men his neighbors!  Cold,
Title:  cold--I shiver!--How now?  Aloft there!  D'ye see him?  Sing out for
Title:  every spout, though he spout ten times a second!"
Title:  
Title:  The day was nearly done; only the hem of his golden robe was
Title:  rustling.  Soon, it was almost dark, but the look-out men still
Title:  remained unset.
Title:  
Title:  "Can't see the spout now, sir;--too dark"--cried a voice from the
Title:  air.
Title:  
Title:  "How heading when last seen?"
Title:  
Title:  "As before, sir,--straight to leeward."
Title:  
Title:  "Good! he will travel slower now 'tis night.  Down royals and
Title:  top-gallant stun-sails, Mr. Starbuck.  We must not run over him
Title:  before morning; he's making a passage now, and may heave-to a while.
Title:  Helm there! keep her full before the wind!--Aloft! come down!--Mr.
Title:  Stubb, send a fresh hand to the fore-mast head, and see it manned
Title:  till morning."--Then advancing towards the doubloon in the
Title:  main-mast--"Men, this gold is mine, for I earned it; but I shall let
Title:  it abide here till the White Whale is dead; and then, whosoever of ye
Title:  first raises him, upon the day he shall be killed, this gold is that
Title:  man's; and if on that day I shall again raise him, then, ten times
Title:  its sum shall be divided among all of ye!  Away now!--the deck is
Title:  thine, sir!"
Title:  
Title:  And so saying, he placed himself half way within the scuttle, and
Title:  slouching his hat, stood there till dawn, except when at intervals
Title:  rousing himself to see how the night wore on.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 134
Title:  
Title:  The Chase--Second Day.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  At day-break, the three mast-heads were punctually manned afresh.
Title:  
Title:  "D'ye see him?" cried Ahab after allowing a little space for the
Title:  light to spread.
Title:  
Title:  "See nothing, sir."
Title:  
Title:  "Turn up all hands and make sail! he travels faster than I thought
Title:  for;--the top-gallant sails!--aye, they should have been kept on her
Title:  all night.  But no matter--'tis but resting for the rush."
Title:  
Title:  Here be it said, that this pertinacious pursuit of one particular
Title:  whale, continued through day into night, and through night into day,
Title:  is a thing by no means unprecedented in the South sea fishery.  For
Title:  such is the wonderful skill, prescience of experience, and invincible
Title:  confidence acquired by some great natural geniuses among the
Title:  Nantucket commanders; that from the simple observation of a whale
Title:  when last descried, they will, under certain given circumstances,
Title:  pretty accurately foretell both the direction in which he will
Title:  continue to swim for a time, while out of sight, as well as his
Title:  probable rate of progression during that period.  And, in these
Title:  cases, somewhat as a pilot, when about losing sight of a coast, whose
Title:  general trending he well knows, and which he desires shortly to
Title:  return to again, but at some further point; like as this pilot stands
Title:  by his compass, and takes the precise bearing of the cape at present
Title:  visible, in order the more certainly to hit aright the remote, unseen
Title:  headland, eventually to be visited: so does the fisherman, at his
Title:  compass, with the whale; for after being chased, and diligently
Title:  marked, through several hours of daylight, then, when night obscures
Title:  the fish, the creature's future wake through the darkness is almost
Title:  as established to the sagacious mind of the hunter, as the pilot's
Title:  coast is to him.  So that to this hunter's wondrous skill, the
Title:  proverbial evanescence of a thing writ in water, a wake, is to all
Title:  desired purposes well nigh as reliable as the steadfast land.  And as
Title:  the mighty iron Leviathan of the modern railway is so familiarly
Title:  known in its every pace, that, with watches in their hands, men time
Title:  his rate as doctors that of a baby's pulse; and lightly say of it,
Title:  the up train or the down train will reach such or such a spot, at
Title:  such or such an hour; even so, almost, there are occasions when these
Title:  Nantucketers time that other Leviathan of the deep, according to the
Title:  observed humor of his speed; and say to themselves, so many hours
Title:  hence this whale will have gone two hundred miles, will have about
Title:  reached this or that degree of latitude or longitude.  But to render
Title:  this acuteness at all successful in the end, the wind and the sea
Title:  must be the whaleman's allies; for of what present avail to the
Title:  becalmed or windbound mariner is the skill that assures him he is
Title:  exactly ninety-three leagues and a quarter from his port?  Inferable
Title:  from these statements, are many collateral subtile matters touching
Title:  the chase of whales.
Title:  
Title:  The ship tore on; leaving such a furrow in the sea as when a
Title:  cannon-ball, missent, becomes a plough-share and turns up the level
Title:  field.
Title:  
Title:  "By salt and hemp!" cried Stubb, "but this swift motion of the deck
Title:  creeps up one's legs and tingles at the heart.  This ship and I are
Title:  two brave fellows!--Ha, ha!  Some one take me up, and launch me,
Title:  spine-wise, on the sea,--for by live-oaks! my spine's a keel.  Ha,
Title:  ha! we go the gait that leaves no dust behind!"
Title:  
Title:  "There she blows--she blows!--she blows!--right ahead!" was now the
Title:  mast-head cry.
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, aye!" cried Stubb, "I knew it--ye can't escape--blow on and
Title:  split your spout, O whale! the mad fiend himself is after ye! blow
Title:  your trump--blister your lungs!--Ahab will dam off your blood, as a
Title:  miller shuts his watergate upon the stream!"
Title:  
Title:  And Stubb did but speak out for well nigh all that crew.  The
Title:  frenzies of the chase had by this time worked them bubblingly up,
Title:  like old wine worked anew.  Whatever pale fears and forebodings some
Title:  of them might have felt before; these were not only now kept out of
Title:  sight through the growing awe of Ahab, but they were broken up, and
Title:  on all sides routed, as timid prairie hares that scatter before the
Title:  bounding bison.  The hand of Fate had snatched all their souls; and
Title:  by the stirring perils of the previous day; the rack of the past
Title:  night's suspense; the fixed, unfearing, blind, reckless way in which
Title:  their wild craft went plunging towards its flying mark; by all these
Title:  things, their hearts were bowled along.  The wind that made great
Title:  bellies of their sails, and rushed the vessel on by arms invisible as
Title:  irresistible; this seemed the symbol of that unseen agency which so
Title:  enslaved them to the race.
Title:  
Title:  They were one man, not thirty.  For as the one ship that held them
Title:  all; though it was put together of all contrasting things--oak, and
Title:  maple, and pine wood; iron, and pitch, and hemp--yet all these ran
Title:  into each other in the one concrete hull, which shot on its way, both
Title:  balanced and directed by the long central keel; even so, all the
Title:  individualities of the crew, this man's valor, that man's fear; guilt
Title:  and guiltiness, all varieties were welded into oneness, and were all
Title:  directed to that fatal goal which Ahab their one lord and keel did
Title:  point to.
Title:  
Title:  The rigging lived.  The mast-heads, like the tops of tall palms, were
Title:  outspreadingly tufted with arms and legs.  Clinging to a spar with
Title:  one hand, some reached forth the other with impatient wavings;
Title:  others, shading their eyes from the vivid sunlight, sat far out on
Title:  the rocking yards; all the spars in full bearing of mortals, ready
Title:  and ripe for their fate.  Ah! how they still strove through that
Title:  infinite blueness to seek out the thing that might destroy them!
Title:  
Title:  "Why sing ye not out for him, if ye see him?" cried Ahab, when, after
Title:  the lapse of some minutes since the first cry, no more had been
Title:  heard.  "Sway me up, men; ye have been deceived; not Moby Dick casts
Title:  one odd jet that way, and then disappears."
Title:  
Title:  It was even so; in their headlong eagerness, the men had mistaken
Title:  some other thing for the whale-spout, as the event itself soon
Title:  proved; for hardly had Ahab reached his perch; hardly was the rope
Title:  belayed to its pin on deck, when he struck the key-note to an
Title:  orchestra, that made the air vibrate as with the combined discharges
Title:  of rifles.  The triumphant halloo of thirty buckskin lungs was heard,
Title:  as--much nearer to the ship than the place of the imaginary jet, less
Title:  than a mile ahead--Moby Dick bodily burst into view!  For not by any
Title:  calm and indolent spoutings; not by the peaceable gush of that mystic
Title:  fountain in his head, did the White Whale now reveal his vicinity;
Title:  but by the far more wondrous phenomenon of breaching.  Rising with
Title:  his utmost velocity from the furthest depths, the Sperm Whale thus
Title:  booms his entire bulk into the pure element of air, and piling up a
Title:  mountain of dazzling foam, shows his place to the distance of seven
Title:  miles and more.  In those moments, the torn, enraged waves he shakes
Title:  off, seem his mane; in some cases, this breaching is his act of
Title:  defiance.
Title:  
Title:  "There she breaches! there she breaches!" was the cry, as in his
Title:  immeasurable bravadoes the White Whale tossed himself salmon-like to
Title:  Heaven.  So suddenly seen in the blue plain of the sea, and relieved
Title:  against the still bluer margin of the sky, the spray that he raised,
Title:  for the moment, intolerably glittered and glared like a glacier; and
Title:  stood there gradually fading and fading away from its first sparkling
Title:  intensity, to the dim mistiness of an advancing shower in a vale.
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, breach your last to the sun, Moby Dick!" cried Ahab, "thy hour
Title:  and thy harpoon are at hand!--Down! down all of ye, but one man at
Title:  the fore.  The boats!--stand by!"
Title:  
Title:  Unmindful of the tedious rope-ladders of the shrouds, the men, like
Title:  shooting stars, slid to the deck, by the isolated backstays and
Title:  halyards; while Ahab, less dartingly, but still rapidly was dropped
Title:  from his perch.
Title:  
Title:  "Lower away," he cried, so soon as he had reached his boat--a spare
Title:  one, rigged the afternoon previous.  "Mr. Starbuck, the ship is
Title:  thine--keep away from the boats, but keep near them.  Lower, all!"
Title:  
Title:  As if to strike a quick terror into them, by this time being the
Title:  first assailant himself, Moby Dick had turned, and was now coming for
Title:  the three crews.  Ahab's boat was central; and cheering his men, he
Title:  told them he would take the whale head-and-head,--that is, pull
Title:  straight up to his forehead,--a not uncommon thing; for when within a
Title:  certain limit, such a course excludes the coming onset from the
Title:  whale's sidelong vision.  But ere that close limit was gained, and
Title:  while yet all three boats were plain as the ship's three masts to his
Title:  eye; the White Whale churning himself into furious speed, almost in
Title:  an instant as it were, rushing among the boats with open jaws, and a
Title:  lashing tail, offered appalling battle on every side; and heedless of
Title:  the irons darted at him from every boat, seemed only intent on
Title:  annihilating each separate plank of which those boats were made.  But
Title:  skilfully manoeuvred, incessantly wheeling like trained chargers in
Title:  the field; the boats for a while eluded him; though, at times, but by
Title:  a plank's breadth; while all the time, Ahab's unearthly slogan tore
Title:  every other cry but his to shreds.
Title:  
Title:  But at last in his untraceable evolutions, the White Whale so crossed
Title:  and recrossed, and in a thousand ways entangled the slack of the
Title:  three lines now fast to him, that they foreshortened, and, of
Title:  themselves, warped the devoted boats towards the planted irons in
Title:  him; though now for a moment the whale drew aside a little, as if to
Title:  rally for a more tremendous charge.  Seizing that opportunity, Ahab
Title:  first paid out more line: and then was rapidly hauling and jerking
Title:  in upon it again--hoping that way to disencumber it of some
Title:  snarls--when lo!--a sight more savage than the embattled teeth of
Title:  sharks!
Title:  
Title:  Caught and twisted--corkscrewed in the mazes of the line, loose
Title:  harpoons and lances, with all their bristling barbs and points, came
Title:  flashing and dripping up to the chocks in the bows of Ahab's boat.
Title:  Only one thing could be done.  Seizing the boat-knife, he critically
Title:  reached within--through--and then, without--the rays of steel;
Title:  dragged in the line beyond, passed it, inboard, to the bowsman, and
Title:  then, twice sundering the rope near the chocks--dropped the
Title:  intercepted fagot of steel into the sea; and was all fast again.
Title:  That instant, the White Whale made a sudden rush among the remaining
Title:  tangles of the other lines; by so doing, irresistibly dragged the
Title:  more involved boats of Stubb and Flask towards his flukes; dashed
Title:  them together like two rolling husks on a surf-beaten beach, and
Title:  then, diving down into the sea, disappeared in a boiling maelstrom,
Title:  in which, for a space, the odorous cedar chips of the wrecks danced
Title:  round and round, like the grated nutmeg in a swiftly stirred bowl of
Title:  punch.
Title:  
Title:  While the two crews were yet circling in the waters, reaching out
Title:  after the revolving line-tubs, oars, and other floating furniture,
Title:  while aslope little Flask bobbed up and down like an empty vial,
Title:  twitching his legs upwards to escape the dreaded jaws of sharks; and
Title:  Stubb was lustily singing out for some one to ladle him up; and while
Title:  the old man's line--now parting--admitted of his pulling into the
Title:  creamy pool to rescue whom he could;--in that wild simultaneousness
Title:  of a thousand concreted perils,--Ahab's yet unstricken boat seemed
Title:  drawn up towards Heaven by invisible wires,--as, arrow-like, shooting
Title:  perpendicularly from the sea, the White Whale dashed his broad
Title:  forehead against its bottom, and sent it, turning over and over, into
Title:  the air; till it fell again--gunwale downwards--and Ahab and his men
Title:  struggled out from under it, like seals from a sea-side cave.
Title:  
Title:  The first uprising momentum of the whale--modifying its direction as
Title:  he struck the surface--involuntarily launched him along it, to a
Title:  little distance from the centre of the destruction he had made; and
Title:  with his back to it, he now lay for a moment slowly feeling with his
Title:  flukes from side to side; and whenever a stray oar, bit of plank, the
Title:  least chip or crumb of the boats touched his skin, his tail swiftly
Title:  drew back, and came sideways smiting the sea.  But soon, as if
Title:  satisfied that his work for that time was done, he pushed his pleated
Title:  forehead through the ocean, and trailing after him the intertangled
Title:  lines, continued his leeward way at a traveller's methodic pace.
Title:  
Title:  As before, the attentive ship having descried the whole fight, again
Title:  came bearing down to the rescue, and dropping a boat, picked up the
Title:  floating mariners, tubs, oars, and whatever else could be caught at,
Title:  and safely landed them on her decks.  Some sprained shoulders,
Title:  wrists, and ankles; livid contusions; wrenched harpoons and lances;
Title:  inextricable intricacies of rope; shattered oars and planks; all
Title:  these were there; but no fatal or even serious ill seemed to have
Title:  befallen any one.  As with Fedallah the day before, so Ahab was now
Title:  found grimly clinging to his boat's broken half, which afforded a
Title:  comparatively easy float; nor did it so exhaust him as the previous
Title:  day's mishap.
Title:  
Title:  But when he was helped to the deck, all eyes were fastened upon him;
Title:  as instead of standing by himself he still half-hung upon the
Title:  shoulder of Starbuck, who had thus far been the foremost to assist
Title:  him.  His ivory leg had been snapped off, leaving but one short sharp
Title:  splinter.
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, aye, Starbuck, 'tis sweet to lean sometimes, be the leaner who
Title:  he will; and would old Ahab had leaned oftener than he has."
Title:  
Title:  "The ferrule has not stood, sir," said the carpenter, now coming up;
Title:  "I put good work into that leg."
Title:  
Title:  "But no bones broken, sir, I hope," said Stubb with true concern.
Title:  
Title:  "Aye! and all splintered to pieces, Stubb!--d'ye see it.--But even
Title:  with a broken bone, old Ahab is untouched; and I account no living
Title:  bone of mine one jot more me, than this dead one that's lost.  Nor
Title:  white whale, nor man, nor fiend, can so much as graze old Ahab in his
Title:  own proper and inaccessible being.  Can any lead touch yonder floor,
Title:  any mast scrape yonder roof?--Aloft there! which way?"
Title:  
Title:  "Dead to leeward, sir."
Title:  
Title:  "Up helm, then; pile on the sail again, ship keepers! down the rest
Title:  of the spare boats and rig them--Mr. Starbuck away, and muster the
Title:  boat's crews."
Title:  
Title:  "Let me first help thee towards the bulwarks, sir."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, oh, oh! how this splinter gores me now!  Accursed fate! that the
Title:  unconquerable captain in the soul should have such a craven mate!"
Title:  
Title:  "Sir?"
Title:  
Title:  "My body, man, not thee.  Give me something for a cane--there, that
Title:  shivered lance will do.  Muster the men.  Surely I have not seen him
Title:  yet.  By heaven it cannot be!--missing?--quick! call them all."
Title:  
Title:  The old man's hinted thought was true.  Upon mustering the company,
Title:  the Parsee was not there.
Title:  
Title:  "The Parsee!" cried Stubb--"he must have been caught in--"
Title:  
Title:  "The black vomit wrench thee!--run all of ye above, alow, cabin,
Title:  forecastle--find him--not gone--not gone!"
Title:  
Title:  But quickly they returned to him with the tidings that the Parsee was
Title:  nowhere to be found.
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, sir," said Stubb--"caught among the tangles of your line--I
Title:  thought I saw him dragging under."
Title:  
Title:  "MY line! MY line?  Gone?--gone?  What means that little word?--What
Title:  death-knell rings in it, that old Ahab shakes as if he were the
Title:  belfry.  The harpoon, too!--toss over the litter there,--d'ye see
Title:  it?--the forged iron, men, the white whale's--no, no, no,--blistered
Title:  fool! this hand did dart it!--'tis in the fish!--Aloft there!  Keep
Title:  him nailed--Quick!--all hands to the rigging of the boats--collect
Title:  the oars--harpooneers! the irons, the irons!--hoist the royals higher--a
Title:  pull on all the sheets!--helm there! steady, steady for your life!
Title:  I'll ten times girdle the unmeasured globe; yea and dive straight
Title:  through it, but I'll slay him yet!
Title:  
Title:  "Great God! but for one single instant show thyself," cried Starbuck;
Title:  "never, never wilt thou capture him, old man--In Jesus' name no more
Title:  of this, that's worse than devil's madness.  Two days chased; twice
Title:  stove to splinters; thy very leg once more snatched from under thee;
Title:  thy evil shadow gone--all good angels mobbing thee with warnings:--
Title:  what more wouldst thou have?--Shall we keep chasing this murderous
Title:  fish till he swamps the last man?  Shall we be dragged by him to the
Title:  bottom of the sea?  Shall we be towed by him to the infernal world?
Title:  Oh, oh,--Impiety and blasphemy to hunt him more!"
Title:  
Title:  "Starbuck, of late I've felt strangely moved to thee; ever since that
Title:  hour we both saw--thou know'st what, in one another's eyes.  But in
Title:  this matter of the whale, be the front of thy face to me as the palm
Title:  of this hand--a lipless, unfeatured blank.  Ahab is for ever Ahab,
Title:  man.  This whole act's immutably decreed.  'Twas rehearsed by thee
Title:  and me a billion years before this ocean rolled.  Fool!  I am the
Title:  Fates' lieutenant; I act under orders.  Look thou, underling! that
Title:  thou obeyest mine.--Stand round me, men.  Ye see an old man cut down
Title:  to the stump; leaning on a shivered lance; propped up on a lonely
Title:  foot.  'Tis Ahab--his body's part; but Ahab's soul's a centipede,
Title:  that moves upon a hundred legs.  I feel strained, half stranded, as
Title:  ropes that tow dismasted frigates in a gale; and I may look so.  But
Title:  ere I break, yell hear me crack; and till ye hear THAT, know that
Title:  Ahab's hawser tows his purpose yet.  Believe ye, men, in the things
Title:  called omens?  Then laugh aloud, and cry encore!  For ere they drown,
Title:  drowning things will twice rise to the surface; then rise again, to
Title:  sink for evermore.  So with Moby Dick--two days he's floated--tomorrow
Title:  will be the third.  Aye, men, he'll rise once more,--but only to
Title:  spout his last!  D'ye feel brave men, brave?"
Title:  
Title:  "As fearless fire," cried Stubb.
Title:  
Title:  "And as mechanical," muttered Ahab.  Then as the men went forward, he
Title:  muttered on: "The things called omens!  And yesterday I talked the
Title:  same to Starbuck there, concerning my broken boat.  Oh! how valiantly
Title:  I seek to drive out of others' hearts what's clinched so fast in
Title:  mine!--The Parsee--the Parsee!--gone, gone? and he was to go
Title:  before:--but still was to be seen again ere I could perish--How's
Title:  that?--There's a riddle now might baffle all the lawyers backed by
Title:  the ghosts of the whole line of judges:--like a hawk's beak it pecks
Title:  my brain.  I'LL, I'LL solve it, though!"
Title:  
Title:  When dusk descended, the whale was still in sight to leeward.
Title:  
Title:  So once more the sail was shortened, and everything passed nearly as
Title:  on the previous night; only, the sound of hammers, and the hum of the
Title:  grindstone was heard till nearly daylight, as the men toiled by
Title:  lanterns in the complete and careful rigging of the spare boats and
Title:  sharpening their fresh weapons for the morrow.  Meantime, of the
Title:  broken keel of Ahab's wrecked craft the carpenter made him another
Title:  leg; while still as on the night before, slouched Ahab stood fixed
Title:  within his scuttle; his hid, heliotrope glance anticipatingly gone
Title:  backward on its dial; sat due eastward for the earliest sun.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  CHAPTER 135
Title:  
Title:  The Chase.--Third Day.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  The morning of the third day dawned fair and fresh, and once more the
Title:  solitary night-man at the fore-mast-head was relieved by crowds of
Title:  the daylight look-outs, who dotted every mast and almost every spar.
Title:  
Title:  "D'ye see him?" cried Ahab; but the whale was not yet in sight.
Title:  
Title:  "In his infallible wake, though; but follow that wake, that's all.
Title:  Helm there; steady, as thou goest, and hast been going.  What a
Title:  lovely day again! were it a new-made world, and made for a
Title:  summer-house to the angels, and this morning the first of its
Title:  throwing open to them, a fairer day could not dawn upon that world.
Title:  Here's food for thought, had Ahab time to think; but Ahab never
Title:  thinks; he only feels, feels, feels; THAT'S tingling enough for
Title:  mortal man! to think's audacity.  God only has that right and
Title:  privilege.  Thinking is, or ought to be, a coolness and a calmness;
Title:  and our poor hearts throb, and our poor brains beat too much for
Title:  that.  And yet, I've sometimes thought my brain was very calm--frozen
Title:  calm, this old skull cracks so, like a glass in which the contents
Title:  turned to ice, and shiver it.  And still this hair is growing now;
Title:  this moment growing, and heat must breed it; but no, it's like that
Title:  sort of common grass that will grow anywhere, between the earthy
Title:  clefts of Greenland ice or in Vesuvius lava.  How the wild winds blow
Title:  it; they whip it about me as the torn shreds of split sails lash the
Title:  tossed ship they cling to.  A vile wind that has no doubt blown ere
Title:  this through prison corridors and cells, and wards of hospitals, and
Title:  ventilated them, and now comes blowing hither as innocent as fleeces.
Title:  Out upon it!--it's tainted.  Were I the wind, I'd blow no more on
Title:  such a wicked, miserable world.  I'd crawl somewhere to a cave, and
Title:  slink there.  And yet, 'tis a noble and heroic thing, the wind! who
Title:  ever conquered it?  In every fight it has the last and bitterest
Title:  blow.  Run tilting at it, and you but run through it.  Ha! a coward
Title:  wind that strikes stark naked men, but will not stand to receive a
Title:  single blow.  Even Ahab is a braver thing--a nobler thing than THAT.
Title:  Would now the wind but had a body; but all the things that most
Title:  exasperate and outrage mortal man, all these things are bodiless, but
Title:  only bodiless as objects, not as agents.  There's a most special, a
Title:  most cunning, oh, a most malicious difference!  And yet, I say again,
Title:  and swear it now, that there's something all glorious and gracious in
Title:  the wind.  These warm Trade Winds, at least, that in the clear
Title:  heavens blow straight on, in strong and steadfast, vigorous mildness;
Title:  and veer not from their mark, however the baser currents of the sea
Title:  may turn and tack, and mightiest Mississippies of the land swift and
Title:  swerve about, uncertain where to go at last.  And by the eternal
Title:  Poles! these same Trades that so directly blow my good ship on; these
Title:  Trades, or something like them--something so unchangeable, and full
Title:  as strong, blow my keeled soul along!  To it!  Aloft there!  What
Title:  d'ye see?"
Title:  
Title:  "Nothing, sir."
Title:  
Title:  "Nothing! and noon at hand!  The doubloon goes a-begging!  See the
Title:  sun!  Aye, aye, it must be so.  I've oversailed him.  How, got the
Title:  start?  Aye, he's chasing ME now; not I, HIM--that's bad; I might
Title:  have known it, too.  Fool! the lines--the harpoons he's towing.  Aye,
Title:  aye, I have run him by last night.  About! about!  Come down, all of
Title:  ye, but the regular look outs!  Man the braces!"
Title:  
Title:  Steering as she had done, the wind had been somewhat on the Pequod's
Title:  quarter, so that now being pointed in the reverse direction, the
Title:  braced ship sailed hard upon the breeze as she rechurned the cream in
Title:  her own white wake.
Title:  
Title:  "Against the wind he now steers for the open jaw," murmured Starbuck
Title:  to himself, as he coiled the new-hauled main-brace upon the rail.
Title:  "God keep us, but already my bones feel damp within me, and from the
Title:  inside wet my flesh.  I misdoubt me that I disobey my God in obeying
Title:  him!"
Title:  
Title:  "Stand by to sway me up!" cried Ahab, advancing to the hempen basket.
Title:  "We should meet him soon."
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, aye, sir," and straightway Starbuck did Ahab's bidding, and
Title:  once more Ahab swung on high.
Title:  
Title:  A whole hour now passed; gold-beaten out to ages.  Time itself now
Title:  held long breaths with keen suspense.  But at last, some three points
Title:  off the weather bow, Ahab descried the spout again, and instantly
Title:  from the three mast-heads three shrieks went up as if the tongues of
Title:  fire had voiced it.
Title:  
Title:  "Forehead to forehead I meet thee, this third time, Moby Dick!  On
Title:  deck there!--brace sharper up; crowd her into the wind's eye.  He's
Title:  too far off to lower yet, Mr. Starbuck.  The sails shake!  Stand over
Title:  that helmsman with a top-maul!  So, so; he travels fast, and I must
Title:  down.  But let me have one more good round look aloft here at the
Title:  sea; there's time for that.  An old, old sight, and yet somehow so
Title:  young; aye, and not changed a wink since I first saw it, a boy, from
Title:  the sand-hills of Nantucket!  The same!--the same!--the same to Noah
Title:  as to me.  There's a soft shower to leeward.  Such lovely
Title:  leewardings!  They must lead somewhere--to something else than common
Title:  land, more palmy than the palms.  Leeward! the white whale goes that
Title:  way; look to windward, then; the better if the bitterer quarter.  But
Title:  good bye, good bye, old mast-head!  What's this?--green? aye, tiny
Title:  mosses in these warped cracks.  No such green weather stains on
Title:  Ahab's head!  There's the difference now between man's old age and
Title:  matter's.  But aye, old mast, we both grow old together; sound in our
Title:  hulls, though, are we not, my ship?  Aye, minus a leg, that's all.
Title:  By heaven this dead wood has the better of my live flesh every way.
Title:  I can't compare with it; and I've known some ships made of dead trees
Title:  outlast the lives of men made of the most vital stuff of vital
Title:  fathers.  What's that he said? he should still go before me, my
Title:  pilot; and yet to be seen again?  But where?  Will I have eyes at the
Title:  bottom of the sea, supposing I descend those endless stairs? and all
Title:  night I've been sailing from him, wherever he did sink to.  Aye, aye,
Title:  like many more thou told'st direful truth as touching thyself, O
Title:  Parsee; but, Ahab, there thy shot fell short.  Good-bye,
Title:  mast-head--keep a good eye upon the whale, the while I'm gone.  We'll
Title:  talk to-morrow, nay, to-night, when the white whale lies down there,
Title:  tied by head and tail."
Title:  
Title:  He gave the word; and still gazing round him, was steadily lowered
Title:  through the cloven blue air to the deck.
Title:  
Title:  In due time the boats were lowered; but as standing in his shallop's
Title:  stern, Ahab just hovered upon the point of the descent, he waved to
Title:  the mate,--who held one of the tackle-ropes on deck--and bade him
Title:  pause.
Title:  
Title:  "Starbuck!"
Title:  
Title:  "Sir?"
Title:  
Title:  "For the third time my soul's ship starts upon this voyage,
Title:  Starbuck."
Title:  
Title:  "Aye, sir, thou wilt have it so."
Title:  
Title:  "Some ships sail from their ports, and ever afterwards are missing,
Title:  Starbuck!"
Title:  
Title:  "Truth, sir: saddest truth."
Title:  
Title:  "Some men die at ebb tide; some at low water; some at the full of the
Title:  flood;--and I feel now like a billow that's all one crested comb,
Title:  Starbuck.  I am old;--shake hands with me, man."
Title:  
Title:  Their hands met; their eyes fastened; Starbuck's tears the glue.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my captain, my captain!--noble heart--go not--go not!--see, it's
Title:  a brave man that weeps; how great the agony of the persuasion then!"
Title:  
Title:  "Lower away!"--cried Ahab, tossing the mate's arm from him.  "Stand
Title:  by the crew!"
Title:  
Title:  In an instant the boat was pulling round close under the stern.
Title:  
Title:  "The sharks! the sharks!" cried a voice from the low cabin-window
Title:  there; "O master, my master, come back!"
Title:  
Title:  But Ahab heard nothing; for his own voice was high-lifted then; and
Title:  the boat leaped on.
Title:  
Title:  Yet the voice spake true; for scarce had he pushed from the ship,
Title:  when numbers of sharks, seemingly rising from out the dark waters
Title:  beneath the hull, maliciously snapped at the blades of the oars,
Title:  every time they dipped in the water; and in this way accompanied the
Title:  boat with their bites.  It is a thing not uncommonly happening to the
Title:  whale-boats in those swarming seas; the sharks at times apparently
Title:  following them in the same prescient way that vultures hover over the
Title:  banners of marching regiments in the east.  But these were the first
Title:  sharks that had been observed by the Pequod since the White Whale had
Title:  been first descried; and whether it was that Ahab's crew were all
Title:  such tiger-yellow barbarians, and therefore their flesh more musky to
Title:  the senses of the sharks--a matter sometimes well known to affect
Title:  them,--however it was, they seemed to follow that one boat without
Title:  molesting the others.
Title:  
Title:  "Heart of wrought steel!" murmured Starbuck gazing over the side, and
Title:  following with his eyes the receding boat--"canst thou yet ring
Title:  boldly to that sight?--lowering thy keel among ravening sharks, and
Title:  followed by them, open-mouthed to the chase; and this the critical
Title:  third day?--For when three days flow together in one continuous
Title:  intense pursuit; be sure the first is the morning, the second the
Title:  noon, and the third the evening and the end of that thing--be that
Title:  end what it may.  Oh! my God! what is this that shoots through me,
Title:  and leaves me so deadly calm, yet expectant,--fixed at the top of a
Title:  shudder!  Future things swim before me, as in empty outlines and
Title:  skeletons; all the past is somehow grown dim.  Mary, girl! thou
Title:  fadest in pale glories behind me; boy!  I seem to see but thy eyes
Title:  grown wondrous blue.  Strangest problems of life seem clearing; but
Title:  clouds sweep between--Is my journey's end coming?  My legs feel
Title:  faint; like his who has footed it all day.  Feel thy heart,--beats
Title:  it yet?  Stir thyself, Starbuck!--stave it off--move, move! speak
Title:  aloud!--Mast-head there!  See ye my boy's hand on the
Title:  hill?--Crazed;--aloft there!--keep thy keenest eye upon the boats:--
Title:  mark well the whale!--Ho! again!--drive off that hawk! see! he
Title:  pecks--he tears the vane"--pointing to the red flag flying at the
Title:  main-truck--"Ha! he soars away with it!--Where's the old man now?
Title:  see'st thou that sight, oh Ahab!--shudder, shudder!"
Title:  
Title:  The boats had not gone very far, when by a signal from the
Title:  mast-heads--a downward pointed arm, Ahab knew that the whale had
Title:  sounded; but intending to be near him at the next rising, he held on
Title:  his way a little sideways from the vessel; the becharmed crew
Title:  maintaining the profoundest silence, as the head-beat waves hammered
Title:  and hammered against the opposing bow.
Title:  
Title:  "Drive, drive in your nails, oh ye waves! to their uttermost heads
Title:  drive them in! ye but strike a thing without a lid; and no coffin and
Title:  no hearse can be mine:--and hemp only can kill me!  Ha! ha!"
Title:  
Title:  Suddenly the waters around them slowly swelled in broad circles; then
Title:  quickly upheaved, as if sideways sliding from a submerged berg of
Title:  ice, swiftly rising to the surface.  A low rumbling sound was heard;
Title:  a subterraneous hum; and then all held their breaths; as bedraggled
Title:  with trailing ropes, and harpoons, and lances, a vast form shot
Title:  lengthwise, but obliquely from the sea.  Shrouded in a thin drooping
Title:  veil of mist, it hovered for a moment in the rainbowed air; and then
Title:  fell swamping back into the deep.  Crushed thirty feet upwards, the
Title:  waters flashed for an instant like heaps of fountains, then brokenly
Title:  sank in a shower of flakes, leaving the circling surface creamed like
Title:  new milk round the marble trunk of the whale.
Title:  
Title:  "Give way!" cried Ahab to the oarsmen, and the boats darted forward
Title:  to the attack; but maddened by yesterday's fresh irons that corroded
Title:  in him, Moby Dick seemed combinedly possessed by all the angels that
Title:  fell from heaven.  The wide tiers of welded tendons overspreading his
Title:  broad white forehead, beneath the transparent skin, looked knitted
Title:  together; as head on, he came churning his tail among the boats; and
Title:  once more flailed them apart; spilling out the irons and lances from
Title:  the two mates' boats, and dashing in one side of the upper part of
Title:  their bows, but leaving Ahab's almost without a scar.
Title:  
Title:  While Daggoo and Queequeg were stopping the strained planks; and as
Title:  the whale swimming out from them, turned, and showed one entire flank
